column2: Good string quartets are rare in any age. The United States is fortunate to have had several fine ones, notably the Budapest, the Galimir, the Kroll and the Juilliard. But now a new quartet has emerged that promises to become of importance not only to this country but to the world as well.
PITTSBURGH, Feb. 28 -- Steel officials are resigned to at major inventory dislocation.

ALGIERS, Feb. 28 -- The Communist-backed African-Asian economic conference here ended a week-long meeting today amid confusion provoked partly by a Chinese Communist attempt to push through a resolution condemning the United Nations.

CANNES, France, Feb. 28 (UPI) -- Colin Stubs of Australia celebrated his 24th birthday today by defeating first-seeded Robin Sanders of South Africa in the final of the Gallia Cup international tennis tournament.

A new city within the city -- a home for 55,000 people -- will arise in the presently barren area in the Bronx where Freedomland now stands. It will be the world's largest cooperative housing development, with 15,500 moderately priced apartments for middle-income families. Its cost is estimated at $285 million, most of which will be financed by a loan from New York State.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- The Administration faces crucial action this week on two Great Society programs -- economic aid to Appalachia and the $1.25 billion school-aid bill.
HONG KONG, Monday, March 1 -- North Vietnam has denounced the United States for using B-57 bombers in "massive and repeated bombing raids of utmost savagery" in South Vietnam.
The New York Rangers scored three goals in the first 2 minutes 16 seconds of the game last night and dealt the Stanley Cup champion Toronto Maple Leafs a 6-2 defeat at Madison Square Garden.
The Soviet Communist party's influence over the international Communist movement appears from this side of the Atlantic to be at the lowest point in history.
Although Ian and Sylvia have been singing folk songs professionally for nearly four years, they did not present their first Town Hall recital until Saturday night.
Hugh Hardy, a New York architect and stage designer, has been placed in charge of a special study directed toward establishing a permanent home for modern dance in New York.

LEIPZIG, Germany, Feb. 28 -- Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin of the Soviet Union tonight labeled the United States white paper on Vietnam a "black book" of evil deeds that would unite all Asia against the United States.
BALTIMORE, Feb. 28 (UPI) -- James Hamer, who has spent 35 years in football, was named commissioner of the new North American professional league today.
The Federal Communications Commission will consider on Friday a proposal for sweeping changes in the economic structure of the television industry.

If the operators of the small, independent apparel company today seem to looking over their shoulders in an agonized manner, there are good reasons for it. The spread of giantism in the industry continues unabated, casting doubts on the future of the small company.
There seems to be general agreement that the United States faces a severe balance of payments problem. Net capital outflow is usually singled out as the culprit causing our unfavorable balance.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 28 -- Warren Spahn ended his "holdout" today and agree to a $70,000 contract that will make him the highest paid prayer in the history of the New York Mets and the highest paid 43-year-old pitcher in baseball.

A detailed analysis of the testimony of 121 witnesses before the commission that investigated President Kennedy's assassination was given yesterday show that 51 said that shots had sounded as though they had come from a grassy knoll "on the right of the President's car."

MOSCOW, Feb. 28 -- A controversial conference of Communist parties will open here tomorrow under circumstances indicating that the new Soviet leaders have failed in their efforts to regain leadership of the entire Communist camp.
Employes of Stern's department store voted yesterday to extend for a month their contract, which expired at midnight.

Canada, struggling with Quebec's "Quiet Revolution," has just been given her worst shock in many a year. The Royal Commission on Bilingualism and Biculturalism, after twenty months of study, has issued a report which says that Canada is going through her "greatest crisis" and that "the clash of English and French could destroy the country if permitted to deepen."
Relaxing on weekends in the suburbs in Connecticut is a strenuous business these days for a growing number of commuters and other residents.
Dave Faherty of Iona College pulled ahead in the final two miles yesterday to win the Road Runners Club of New York 12-mile handicap run in the Bronx.

The tentative settlement of the seven-week dock strike on the Gulf of Mexico brings closer what could prove a new era of peace and productivity in East Coast labor-management relations. All that is required for a full start is a pact to reopen the still blockaded harbors in the South Atlantic states.
The pianist Rudolf Firkusny and the composers Roger Sessions and Luciano Berio will join the faculty of the Juilliard School of Music for the 1965-66 school year.

Erich Leinsdorf stretched the familiar three B's to four in the Boston Symphony Concert in Carnegie Hall on Saturday night. Besides Bach, Beethoven and Brahms, the program listed Alban Berg, staying within the German-Austrian orbit of composers.
SALT LAKE CITY, Feb. 26 -- Calvin L. Rampton, the new Governor of Utah, appears to have been successful thus far in maneuvering his program through the State Legislature.
The vestry of St. George's Episcopal Church, 16th Street and Stuyvesant Square, has resigned to make way for the election of "forward-looking" members.

" Where are the customers' yachts?" This old plaint may well be justified by the New York Stock Exchange's tentative proposals to raise the cost of stock trading for individual customers by granting brokers an increase in commission rates and letting them charge mandatory fees for maintaining investors' accounts.

Everything is later than usual in Albany this year. But the Legislature will settle down this week to exhaustive study of the mammoth spending and tax program Governor Rockefeller delivered a month ago. The Democratic majority in the Legislature -- in charge for the first time in three decades -- could dally almost interminably on choice of its own leadership, and now appears willing to sit into the summer on other business.
Federal mediators will move into Miami today in hopes of bringing a complete end to the dock strike that began last Jan. 11.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- The American economy quietly celebrated an important birthday today.
Traffic Commissioner Henry Barnes called yesterday for retention of the 15-cent subway fare, "even if it means increased subsidies."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) -- Secretary of Labor W. Willard Wirtz announced today the approval of 15 new Neighborhood Youth Corps projects in 12 states.
CAIRO, Feb. 28 -- The Government has called up several thousand army reservists in the last six weeks, well qualified Egyptian and foreign sources reported today.
President Johnson last night proclaimed March as Red Cross Month, the once-a-year appeal the Red Cross makes for funds to carry on its vital services.
A Venetian-style Purim will be celebrated March 27 at the Jewish Museum, where members, sustaining, associate and sponsoring, will give their sixth annual Queen Esther Purim Ball.
Teamsters Local 814 voted yesterday to strike against 320 moving and storage companies here beginning at 12:01 A.M. today.

SELMA, Ala., Feb. 28 -- The pastor of a rural Negro church in nearby Lowndes County said here tonight that his board of deacons fired him on the spot this morning after a group of armed white men visited the church and threatened to kill him if he was not dismissed.

DURING his four-year reign as president of the Columbia Broadcasting System television network, James Thomas Aubrey Jr. was a king who ruled his subjects totally and completely. He probably had as much power as Louis B. Mayer at the height of his movie domi nance.
MADRID, Feb. 28 -- The medical school of Madrid University has been ordered closed for an indefinite period as a result of the student revolt there. It was the second closing of a major school.
YOUTH is not only the time of hope. It is also the time of idealism still untarnished by a wicked world and the time of yearning for something unnamable, something romantic, adventurous and strange.

School custodians whose high incomes led to public protests and subsequent investigation in 1963 are now providing cleaner schools at far less cost under a revised payment system, the Board of Education said yesterday.
" Insure my wife? Are you out of your mind? I'm the provider for my family. If anything should happen to her -- God forbid -- I'll still be the provider."
STOCKHOLM, Feb. 28 -- Swedish bankers and investors during the last few weeks have expressed some anxiety over the trend toward inflation in this year's financial outlook.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Feb. 28 -- The United States Ambassador protested to the Indonesian Government today after about 500 students invaded the grounds of his residence in an anti-American demonstration.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 28 -- A meticulously planned routine, aimed at having the New York Yankees fully prepared to open the baseball season in Minnesota on April 12 and the World Series in Yankee Stadium on Oct. 6, begins on a full scale tomorrow.
PARIS, Feb. 28 -- An agreement reached here last night is expected to end the showing of movies on trans-Atlantic air routes by next summer.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 28 (UPI) -- The Baltimore Bullets lost a 12-point lead in regulation time, then scored the first 10 points in an overtime period today in defeating the San Francisco Warriors, 129-116.

James T. Aubrey Jr. was dismissed yesterday as president of the Columbia Broadcasting System's television network. The circumstances rivaled the best of C.B.S. adventure or mystery shows, and the dismissal stunned the broadcasting industry.

The international Communist meeting opening in Moscow today provides a historic demonstration of the disarray now existing among the world's Marxist-Leninist. Fewer than twenty of the twenty-six invited parties have sent delegates. The absentees include the Chinese Communist party, the largest in the world, and the Indonesian Communist party, the largest in any non-Communist state.

Senator Jacob K. Javits has asked to be dropped from consideration for the Republican designation for Mayor, and Representative John V. Lindsay is expected to take the same step shortly. Governor Rockefeller's insistence that a choice can safely be delayed until April or May, "when the Legislature is ready to go home," was understood to be the deciding factor for both men.

CINCINNATI, Feb. 25 -- On the bank of the Little Miami River here stands an inconspicuous sheet-metal shack in which a project that many might consider both revolutionary and repugnant is under way. Its aim is to perfect methods of converting sewage into drinking water.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) -- Baseball's share of $85 million to be put up by radio and television sponsors this season will be more than $25 million, an increase of $7 million over last season.

DAYTON, Ohio, Feb. 28 (AP) -- Jerry Lucas, out of action for three weeks, returned to the Cincinnati line-up tonight and sparked the Royals to a 126-117 victory over New York. Lucas made 17 points and grabbed 19 rebounds.
BELIZE, British Honduras, Feb. 28 -- This small crown colony in Central America will decide in an election tomorrow whether to end completely Britain's 300-year rule.
It may seem premature to call a 22-year-old a master pianist, but the kind of artistry Daniel Barenboim demonstrated Saturday night at Hunter College was so impressive, there is no alternative.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 28 (AP) -- An all-Canadian team led by Sergio Zardini captured the international Diamond Trophy for four-man bobsleds today while, in the same race, a crew headed by Bucky Snow took the National Amateur Athletic Union title.
LONDON, Feb. 28 -- Work will begin tomorrow on implementing the final stage of the massive plan for Barbican, the last of London's major war-battered areas to undergo redevelopment.

As an ordinary citizen I read with dismay Secretary of Defense McNamara's report describing "unemotionally" possible mortality rates in atomic attacks. What such a prediction means is the inevitability of a truce. There will have to be agreement between the United States and U.S.S.R. to call off further production of atomic weapons and to destroy immediately those existing which could accidentally cause a holocaust at any time.

A NEW oasis for jazzy, young clothes has appeared on Ohrbach's second floor. No bigger than a large corner and decorated with pseudo-Tiffany lampshades and flower-printed walls, the Junior V.I.P. Shop blossoms with fashions that are in the Ye-Ye and Mod spirit but in most cases turn out to have been manufactured in California.

Comdr. Edward Whitehead, long an outspoken critic of British industry's lack of competitive power, has been named head of a group whose task will be to help British companies increase sales in this country.

BOSTON, Feb. 27 -- Massachusetts will switch its state officers to a four-year term in the general election of November, 1966, and that enticing fact is bringing out the Commonwealth's indefatigable politicians early and often.

An innovation in boxing -- the posting of round-by-round scoring by the referee and judges -- will be proposed today to the New York State Athletic Commission for the March 30 championship double-header at Madison Square Garden.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- Vice President Humphrey has placed more than half of his net assets in trust to avoid any conflict of interest.
MOSCOW, Feb. 28 -- The Soviet Union lifted today a corner of the veil of secrecy that had concealed the full extent of the catastrophic grain failure of 1963.

" The Oxford History of the American People," by Samuel Eliot Morison, will be published on April 22. The author, a member of the Harvard University faculty from 1915 to 1955, entered the United States Navy just after Pearl Harbor and wrote the 15-volume "History of United States Naval Operations in World War II."
A major British ship automation and engineering control company has named a representative in this country and plans to expand a drive for business here.
The Paramount Theater is scheduled to get more musical fare next month.

Mrs. Constance Baker Motley, Manhattan's new Borough President, declared yesterday that Malcolm X's death offered New Yorkers "a brand-new opportunity to move in now and lead the people that he attempted to lead into constructive channels of activity."

PAHOKEE, Fla. -- Anyone who would disparage the country cooking of America simply doesn't know what good is. Much of the finest food in Florida comes from the kitchens of non-urban areas where they beat a little love into biscuits and generally say grace before meals.

LEONTYNE PRICE seldom gives recitals. She sang last night in Carnegie Hall, and it was her first concert here since 1954. Most of her energies are, of course, expended in opera! There she has made hosts of friends, and 2,760 of them turned out, filling every seat in the hall.

TOKYO, Feb. 28 -- The Japanese Government has promised to provide subsidies to eliminate deficit financing in the health-insurance system, thus easing a long political controversy over increases in medical fees.
New York Typographical Union No. 6 announced yesterday that its members would take a strike vote next Sunday as a result of a deadlock in contract negotiations with the city's newspaper publishers.
Building and permanent mortgage financing of $1,987,200, insured by the Federal Housing Administration, has been arranged for two six-story apartment houses at 145 Lincoln Avenue in Grant City, S.I.
Increases of 10.8 per cent in earnings and 6.4 per cent in sales were achieved last year by Sterling Drug, Inc., both setting records, the weekend report disclosed.

A number of airlines flying the Atlantic have been studying the possibility of movies and musical entertainment, but most said yesterday that they would install the costly systems only if necessary to meet competition.
GENEVA, Feb. 28 -- Swiss voters agreed today to retain for at least a year the Government's emergency restraints on economic activity as a weapon against inflation.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 28 -- United States and South Vietnamese officials were attempting today to moderate a peace movement begun by the Buddhist clergy this morning.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 28 -- Ken Miles of Hollywood and Lloyd Ruby of Wichita Falls, Tex., were the driving heroes today as Ford-powered cars dominated the fourth 2,000-kilometer Continental race at Daytona International Speedway.

Samuel Barber's opera "Vanessa," which had its premiere at the Metropolitan Opera on Jan. 15, 1958, will be revived by the company on March 13, written to a libretto by Gian Carlo Menotti, it was last heard there in the season following its premiere.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 28 -- The highest American and South Vietnamese officials here say they are "virtually certain" that President Johnson has decided to open a continuing, limited air war against North Vietnam to bring about a negotiated settlement of the Vietnam problem on honorable terms.

Mayor Wagner and Senator Robert F. Kennedy, rumored to be squaring away for an ultimate battle for political power in the state, lose no opportunity to scoff at the rumor and insist that they are the best of friends.
Senator Robert F. Kennedy declared last night that "we have to see that the next generation of Puerto Ricans in New York City is not a lost generation."
A $60 million complex of six 50-story apartment towers atop two two-story commercial buildings has been proposed for the Washington Market site in lower Manhattan.

NAIROBI, Kenya, Feb. 28 -- "Some days there are no refugees," the Ugandan soldier said. "Some days 200 of them come across the border here. Should I shoot them? Should I turn them back? How can I? They are my brothers."

BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 28 -- The labor federation will make an effort this spring to insure full compliance of all affiliates with the equal-employment-opportunity section of the 1964 Civil Rights Act.

What this city did not need was another small chamber orchestra to dig up baroque and classic music, but it got a new one last night, and, judging from its debut program, it is just the kind to make one forget about the surplus.

The plan evolved by Governor Rockefeller of New York and Governor Dempsey of Connecticut to rescue the sagging suburban operations of the bankrupt New Haven Railroad sounds at first hearing like the answer to a commuter's prayer. Unfortunately, the vital question it does not seem to answer is whether either state is going to come up with the quick cash needed to prevent abandonment of some New Haven service and curtailment of the rest.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 28 (AP) -- Tom Heinsohn scored 11 of his 23 points in the final quarter today and enabled the Boston Celtics to hold off the St. Louis Hawks for a 108-102 National Basketball Association victory.
WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 28 -- Rita Timpanaro, a 15-year-old sophomore at St. Joseph's Academy in Deer Park. L.I., won the hunter seat championship at the Secor Farms Horse Show today.
A state experiment that will provide apartments for low-income families in middle-income developments will be started here today.
LAKE HOPATCONG, N.J., Feb. 28 -- Homer Sieder of Mountain Lakes skippered his Yankee-Class yacht to the open title today in the Eastern Ice Yachting Association's annual championship.
The Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company has leased an additional floor of 135,000 square feet to be built atop the three-story St. Johns Building at 340 West Street on the lower West Side.
Senator Russell B. Long warned yesterday that if the United States withdrew from South Vietnam "there will be no place to stop until we reach our own borders."
HONG KONG, Monday, March 1 -- Communist China charged today that the Soviet Union had deepened the split in the international Communist movement.
ALBANY, Feb. 28 -- The Democratic majorities in the Senate and Assembly expect to pass the first major bills of the 1965 session this week.
The 53d annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund closed yesterday after receiving gifts totaling $709,885.72 from 15,202 donors.

TOKYO, Feb. 28 -- Japan's radically new economic complexion, highly Westernized on the surface but with an Asian concept operating beneath the alien patina, has been underscored in the Government's attention today to the plight of the gradually retreating independent businessman.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Feb. 28 -- Ron Clarke flew from Australia to San Francisco last Wednesday, won a two-mile run in San Francisco Friday night, slept four hours, flew here yesterday, won a two-mile race here last night and flew home to Australia today.
The advertising budgets of toy companies are anything but child's play.
GLADWYNE, Pa., Feb. 28 -- Joyce Davenport rallied today to win the United States women's squash racquets championship at the Philadelphia Country Club.

David L. Wolper has been named a vice president of Metromedia, Inc., the company that recently acquired Wolper Productions. Announcement of the appointment was made yesterday by John W. Kluge, president and chairman of Metromedia.

CHICAGO, Feb. 28 (UPI) -- The Boston Bruins rallied twice tonight to beat the National Hockey League-leading Chicago Black Hawks, 5 -- 4, on John Bucyk's goal with less than five minutes left to play.
Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public that will mature within 12 months amount to $95,557,146,157. They consist of Treasury securities as follows:
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- Vice President Humphrey went to Miami Beach last week to speak to the executive council of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations.
WASHINGTON, March 1 -The Supreme Court today upheld Maryland's requirement of a year's residence for persons to vote in Presidential elections.

WASHINGTON, March 1 (UPI) -- Senator Jacob K. Javits, Republican of New York, introduced a bill today to establish a Federal commission to review the antitrust laws. A companion bill was being offered in the House by Representatives John Lindsay and Ogden Reid, Republicans of New York.
LEIPZIG, Germany, March 1 -- Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin of the Soviet Union said tonight that he had sent a letter to President Johnson about a possible meeting with him.

One of the best-known landmarks in the Yorkville area of Manhattan -- the Casino Theater on the south side of 86th Street between Second and Third Avenues -- will be demolished to make way for an office building.

YONKERS, March 1 -- There was a sufficient number of horses' names in the entry box today to fill two divisions of the third and final segment of the Snowball Pacing Series, listed for Thursday night at Yonkers Raceway.

Entries for the gold medal competition and exhibition of the Architectural League of New York will be accepted through May 10. Entries in the nation-wide competition will be accepted from architects or professionals of the related building arts.

WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) -- A California high school boy who has "one of the nation's best satellite making stations" in his home garage was named tonight as top winner of the 21th annual Westinghouse Science Talent Search.
LONDON, March 1 -- Goldie, a golden eagle that escaped Saturday from the London Zoo, remained perched in nearby trees tonight as keepers waited for hunger to bring him within reach.

After a long campaign to build its own church, the Church of God of Prophecy, a pentecostal sect of Brooklyn, has obtained a home through a collateral bond of $18,000 guaranteed by members of the congregation.

A DOUBLE of a no-trump contract is for penalties and the doubler's partner should take action only if he has strongest possible reason for doing so. The only exception to this rule is a double of a one no-trump response and even this is often passed for penalties.

In announcing the indictment of an official of a Queens meat processing firm, District Attorney Frank S. Hogan observed last week that seven meat inspectors of the United States Department of Agriculture had refused to waive immunity from prosecution when questioned by the grand jury, but were still on duty.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., March 1 -- Supervisor Robert J. Flynn announced today that a 300-car commuter parking field was scheduled to be completed by Sept. 1 as the first sub-project of Huntington Station's $12.5 million urban renewal program.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 1 -- The New York Mets scored another success in collective bargaining today when Jesse Gonder, their most experienced catcher, ended his holdout and headed for spring training four days late.

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York disclosed yesterday that its holdings of gold for other nations decreased last year by a net $235 million. This was the first such decrease in physical gold holdings since 1957.

HOUSTON, March 1 -- An amendment to the Texas Constitution that would grant a property-owner the right to sell to whom he pleases -- and would preclude the state from passing prohibitions against racial discrimination in real estate transactions -- has been introduced in the Texas Legislature.

CAIRO, March 1 -- The United Arab Republic signed a $100 million economic-aid package with East Germany today in the wake of authoritative reports that it planned to open a consulate general in East Berlin.
WASHINGTON, March 1 -The possibility of a shutdown of the natural gas supply to Anchorage and other communities in Alaska was averted today by a ruling of the Supreme Court.
A meteorologist contradicted yesterday earlier testimony in the first-degree murder trial of Alvin L. Mitchell by declaring it was not raining on the morning of the crime.
Stock prices declined yesterday on the London Stock Exchange, due more to a lack of support than any widespread selling.

ATLANTA, Feb. 27 -- A sign on Marietta Boulevard at the edge of town says, "Welcome to Atlanta -- The Dogwood City." But no dogwood, or much other attractive vegetation, is evident along the banks of the Chattahoochee River where it courses under the boulevard.
Mediators made another unsuccessful attempt yesterday to bring an end to a 20-day-old strike that has severely curtailed the operations of the Henry Street Settlement.

BRUSSELS, March 1 -The Councils of Ministers of the Common Market also reviewed today the seventh activity report of the monetary committee. The committee is the top financial consultant body for the Common Market's Executive Commission.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -Another contingent of United States Marines may be landed soon in South Vietnam to act as a security force at major American military installations. Administration sources said tonight.
BOWIE, Md., March 1 (AP) -- No. 8 was the lucky figure at Bowie race track today.
The New York State law authorizing electronic eavesdropping was declared unconstitutional yesterday by Justice Nathan R. Sobel in Supreme Court in Brooklyn.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 1 -- The cold war will not be settled by a victory for capitalism or communism, Walter Lippmann said tonight in a lecture for International Cooperation Year 1965.

Reports of warmer weather over southern potato rowing area wilted futures prices here yesterday. As a result, potato futures prices dropped 24 to 33 cents a hundredweight on the old crop and 3 cents on the new crop November contract.
SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, March 1 -- Fred A. Somerford, second secretary and labor attache of the United States Embassy here, died of a gunshot wound yesterday.
SYDNEY, Australia, March 1 -- Dawn Fraser, one of the world's greatest swimmers, was suspended for 10 years today by the Australian Swimming Union for alleged misconduct at the 1964 Olympics.

The two top teams in the National Basketball Association's Western Division and the tailenders in the Eastern Division will see action tonight in the final professional basketball double-header of the season at Madison Square Garden.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -The Supreme Court declined to review today the two-year-old conviction of Jack Molinas, a former Columbia University basketball star, for his role as master fixer in the basketball scandals of 1957-61.

TO celebrate its 65th year of music-making, the Dallas Symphony Orchestra is making an American tour. Last night its stopping place was Carnegie Hall, and it marked the first time the organization had appeared in this city.
Steel production in the United States dropped 1.2 per cent in the week ended Saturday.
TOKYO, March 1 -- Seven leading Japanese shipbuilding companies declined today to submit bids for the construction of the country's first nuclear-powered vessel.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -The Department of State is disturbed over the widespread acceptation of its "White Paper" on North Vietnamese aggression in South Vietnam as notice of a change in United States "policy."

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Marci 1 -- Mickey Mantle and Whitey Ford, a significant portion of New York Yankee assets, issued optimistic reports on their physical fitness today, even as 10 per cent more of them was being acquired by the Columbia Broadcasting System.
BRUSSELS, March 1 -- The threat of a strike by the 7,500 employes of the European Economic Community persisted tonight despite the offer of a pay increase by the Community's Council of Ministers.
How to turn a $17.9 million net operating loss (1963) into a $26.6 million profit (1964): Turn away business.
WASHINGTON, March 1 (UPI) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board rejected today a protest by the National Trailways Bus System against the 50 per cent discount offered by airlines to military personnel.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -Postmaster General John A. Grounouski continued today to resist disclosing the names of persons whose mail has been put under surveillance during the last two years. It was the eve of the deadline set by a Senate panel investigating possible governmental invasions of privacy of individuals to produce the list.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -President Johnson, the papers say, has a pocket full of polls which show overwhelming public support for his policy in Vietnam. Question: Who is responding to the President's polltakers?

WARSAW, March 1 -- A Polish journalist in North Vietnam reported today that stores in villages in North Vietnam near the 17th Parallel were open "only at night when there is no threat of American air raids."
WASHINGTON, March 1 -The Treasury bill rate declined slightly today from the level at the preceding auction, but the change was insignificant.

HACKENSACK, N.J., March 1 -- A Superior Court upheld today the right of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Newark to build a regional high school in an exclusive residential section of the borough of Ho-Ho-Kus.
THIS country's preparations for putting a man on the moon by 1970 were shown yesterday, on-the-spot, as remote units for the Columbia Broadcasting System visited five space-training centers.

Your editorial of Feb. 16 on "Trouble with Tanzania" will certainly hearten a good many Americans and other non-Africans, as well as Africans, who have known Tanganyika in recent decades and Julius Nyerere for the last 25 years or more.
MADRID, March 1 -- University students decided today to take their case for greater freedom on the campus into the streets of the capital tomorrow.

Brooklyn District Attorney Aaron E. Koota will consent today to a new trial for George Whitmore Jr., who was convicted last November on a charge of the attempted rape of Mrs. Elba Borrero, sources close to the district attorney's office said.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, March 1 (AP) -- President Sukarno of Indonesia flew to Cambodia today to add his voice to an Indochinese peoples' conference attended by leftist elements from Laos, Vietnam and Cambodia.
New York University, with a late second-half surge, defeated Wagner, 79 -- 68, last night in basketball at Alumni Gym in the Bronx.
Prices on the New York Stock Exchange were generally off yesterday in moderately active trading.

KARACHI, Pakistan, March 1 -- President Mohammad Ayub Khan will set out this week on foreign travels designed to show Pakistan as a force for reasonableness in Asian-African affairs and a possible "honest broker" in easing tensions among major powers.

H. CHANDLEE TURNER JR., a man who is accustomed to tackling big jobs, has taken on one of his biggest yet in organizing corporation executives here for an enterprise that will seek to reverse the flow of business and jobs from New York City.

WHITE PLAINS, March 1 -- The Democrats gained three times as many new Westchester enrollments as the Republicans, according to tabulations completed today by the county Board of Elections. The Democrats gained 24,196, against 7,988 for the Republicans.

Concerned by the lack of diversity that characterizes television programing, the Federal Communications Commission is considering a proposal designed to break the tight grip of the three national networks over what is presented to the public.
WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) -- The Supreme Court refused a hearing today to KWK Radio, Inc., operator of a station in St. Louis, on an appeal against revocation of its license.

" Hazel," the situation comedy starring Shirley Booth, has been purchased for presentation next season by the Columbia Broadcasting System. For the last four seasons the show has been televised by the National Broadcasting Company. The series will undergo some changes in format, but Screen Gems, the producer, said details of the changes had not been decided.

HOLLYWOOD, March 1 -- Filmmakers here seem bent on erasing the once-clear distinction between a motion picture and a television snow. More television shows are being released, with minor changes, as full-fledged motion pictures and more movies are being transformed into television showes.
NEW HAVEN, March 1 -Fifty Yale students began picketing the university's administrative offices today to protest Yale's policy on faculty tenure.

NAIROBI, Kenya, March 1 -Kenya, Uganda and Tanzania complained to the Organization of African Unity today that while they were sustaining economic losses through their boycott of South Africa, some Communist countries had entered the South African trade to their great advantage.

While the prime topic of conversation on Madison Avenue yesterday was the ouster of James T. Augrey Jr. as president of Columbia Broadcasting System's television network, there was an undercurrent of talk and controversy over the proposal to curb the networks in determining programming.
SALT LAKE CITY, Feb. 26 -It looked for a while as if Utah might liberalize its liquor laws to permit the sale of liquor by the drink in restaurants.
MIAMI, March 1 -- The world record for the twin double at a thoroughbred racing track, which was established at Hialeah only last Thursday, was shattered today when one player won $123,217.60.

The Maritime Administration, in an effort to get more for its ship-construction subsidy dollars, yesterday proposed a new policy based on standardization of design for tonnage to be built with Federal aid.
Paintings and sculptures by more than 100 persons will be exhibited and sold at the annual meeting of the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies on March 10 at the Americana.

The manager's share of Oscar Bonavena's purse for last Friday night's losing fight to Zora Folley at Madison Square Garden will continue to be withhold. James A. Farley Jr. of the New York State Athletic Commission said yesterday.
ALBANY, March 1 Governor Rockefeller said today that he would approve a bill to raise New York's minimum drinking age from 18 to 21 should the Legislature pass such a measure.
The country's biggest corporations are going to the aid of small business the backbone of New York City's economy.
Computers are changing the nature of corporate management, according to an American Management Association survey.
DETROIT, March 1 -- A leading businessman called today for an overhauling of the international monetary system as a means of solving the nation's balance-of-payments problem.
DUBLIN, March 1 -- Just before his execution at Pentonville Prison in England in 1916. Roger Casement appealed to his Irish countrymen not to leave his remains "in this dreadful place."

The year-long study of future development of downtown Manhattan ordered by Mayor Wagner is certainly needed. The Christian Science Monitor was printed for the first time yesterday in a new, five-column format designed to make it more readable.

The president of the giant Metropolitan Life Insurance Company remains serene and confident, although his company's sales last year did not exceed those of the hotly competitive Prudential Insurance Company.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -President Johnson predicted this afternoon that the House would pass his $1.2 billion bill for aid to education next week. He also indicated that he intended to ask for a greater sum next year.
DETROIT, March 1 (AP) -United States Automobile makers overcame the handicap of widely scattered snowstorms last week to wind up February with a healthy production report.

The Newspaper Guild of New York will begin contract negotiations today with The Daily News and The New York Journal-American. It will also resume contract talks with The New York Herald Tribune. Tomorrow it will start to negotiate with The New York World Telegram and The Sun.

MONTREAL, March 1 -- A powerful explosion, followed by fire, destroyed a large suburban apartment house today killing 24 or more persons and leaving as many as 50 injured. Most of the victims were children.

MINEOLA, L.I., March 1 -- Nassau County Democrats made political history in the county last year by topping the Republicans in new party enrollments for the first time in modern times, John F. English, the county Democratic chairman, reported today.
The Boys Harbor Alumni Association will hold its annual dinner dance March 20 at Mayers Parkway Restaurant in the Bronx.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 1 (UPI) -- The Detroit Pistons beat the Cincinnati Royals, 130 -- 110, tonight in the Ohio State Fair Grounds Coliseum for their fourth straight victory.

HOBART, Tasmania, March 1 (AP) -- The suspension of Miss Fraser, if enforced, will mean the end of the amazing amateur career of the powerful, 149-pound Melbourne swimmer. The first to crack the 60-second barrier in the 100-meter free-style for women, she went on to set 11 women's record in the sprints.
Exhibitors at the World's Fair said yesterday that they were investing $75 million in advertising and tie-in promotional campaigns to help the fair in its 1965 season.

WASHINGTON, March 1 (UPI) -- Roy Wilkins, executive director of the National Association far the Advancement of Colored People, said today that civil rights leaders would insist on a new voting-rights law this year. His remarks brought a rebuke from Senator Howard W. Cannon, Democrat of Nevada.

MOSCOW, March 1 -- A Soviet statistical yearbook just published reports a continuing decline in the country's birth rate but predicts an upswing in the next 15 years that would raise the population to 280 million by 1980. As of Jan. 1, 1965, the population was officially estimated at 229 million.

" My Dear Mr. Churchill," by Walter Graebner, will be published by Houghton Mifflin on March 25. The shares of the Norfolk Southern Railway attracted investor attention on the American Stock Exchange yesterday. The result was ,a delayed opening because of a flood of buy orders and a substantial gain for the day.
CHICAGO, Feb. 25 (AP) -A group of Chicago investors and real estate men announced today acquisition of the Flor-A-Mar development on the Florida Gulf Coast.

WHITE PLAINS, March 1 -- The Westchester Board of Supervisors authorized a study today to determine whether the New Haven Railroad can stop its passenger service in the county without losing ownership of its railroad roadbed.
ALBANY, March 1 -- A second Democratic Assemblyman asked today to be relieved of a committee chairmanship.

Representative John V. Lindsay took himself out of consideration for the Republican designation for Mayor yesterday, despite a late-hour effort by Governor Rockefeller to get him to make the race.

ARCADIA, Calif., March 1 -- Last week, the horse on the spot was Gun Bow -- and he ran out of the money in the Santa Anita Handicap. This week, Jacinto steps front and center as the horse that can't be beaten. He will run in the $100,000-added Santa Anita Derby for 3-year-olds here Saturday.
The Canadian dollar continued to decline yesterday in moderate trading in foreign exchange markets here. It closed at 92.547, compared with Friday's 92.687.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara encountered tough questioning and apparent opposition today as the Senate opened hearings on his proposed reduction and reorganization of the Army reserve forces.

INDIO, Calif., March 1 (UPI) -- Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower said today that Ray C. Bliss would "rejuvenate interest" in the Republican party when he takes over as national chairman on April 1.

The ushers stood in the lobby of Radio City Music Hall yesterday telling the crowd that there was no show -- but inside there was a rather remarkable performance, a blend of the circus and Goldfinger.

Seventy-five members of the Moscow Art Theater emplaned for home today with luggage that cut across class lines.

WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) -- The Supreme Court agreed today to review the conviction of the Rev. Fred L. Shuttlesworth on charges of obstructing a sidewalk in Birmingham, Ala., and refusing to obey a policeman's order.

Mr. Cohen was assistant counsel for the State Employes' Retirement System and earlier was staff assistant in the administrative office of the New York Army National Guard.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 1 -- The red and white Indonesian flag was missing today from the row of flags on the United Nations grounds, symbolizing Indonesia's resignation. There are now 114 members.

John A. Schneider, who went home on Friday evening as head of Channel 2, reported to work yesterday morning as president of the Columbia Broadcasting System's television network. On the 19th floor of the C.B.S. Building at 485 Madison Avenue, he occupied the office from which James T. Aubrey Jr., suddenly dismissed as network president over the weekend, had packed all his papers and departed on Sunday afternoon.

ROME, March 1 -- Communist and other left-wing newspapers protested today the presence of Lieut. Gen. Nguyen Khanh of South Vietnam in Rome and hinted that there might be demonstrations against him.

IT will be good news to aficionados of Asian handicrafts that the Shibui shop, which has operated for the last few years as a mail-order concern under the name Ambassador of Asia, is again a retail establishment. The shop was formerly on East 57th Street until it closed in June of 1962 to go into the mailorder business.

NAHA, Okinawa, March 1 -A 36-year-old San Diego housewife, defying Marine Corps efforts to remove her from Okinawa, charged today that the Third Marine Division had pressured United States officials here to persuade immigration authorities to send her home.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 1 -Mel Stottlemyre went hunting one day while he still was a schoolboy in the bustling metropolis of Mabton, Wash., and he bagged a pheasant. He tossed the bird in the trunk of his car and drove home. When he opened the trunk, the supposedly dead pheasant fluttered his wings and flew off into the night.

In Central Park, on a wooded knoll overlooking the Model Boat Pool, two boys were hurling rocks at squirrels yesterday. Patrolman Fred Taylor, seated on his motor scooter at the pool's edge, gunned his motor and raced up the bumpy hillside.

If, and it's a big if, the Republicans ever had a chance of unseating Mayor Wagner in next November's election, their prospects took a nose dive over the weekend. LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, March 1 -- The Congolese rebels are reported to be removing large quantities of gold ore from mines in the northeastern Congo and shipping it out through the Sudan and Uganda.

MOSCOW, March 1 -- Valerian A. Zorin, now a Deputy Foreign Minister, and an experienced diplomat, is slated to become Ambassador to Paris, informed sources said here today.

Maria Kouba, the Austrian soprano who made her Metropolitan Opera debut 17 days ago in the title role of "Salome," appeared in her second role with the company last night.

Mrs. Betty Shabazz, widow of Malcolm X, met yesterday with detectives investigating the militant black nationalist leader. The meeting was at an unannounced place away from any police office, according to her lawyer, Oliver Sutton.

OMAHA, March 1 (AP) -Winds of 60 miles an hour, accompanied by snow, sleet and high water, lashed several mid-western states today. Many families were evacuated from their homes as rivers and streams overflowed.

The Coca-Cola Company had refreshing news yesterday for its stockholders -- record sales and earnings for 1964 and an increased dividend.

TORONTO, March 1 (Canadian Press) -- Massey-Furguson., Ltd.'s net income for the first quarter ended Jan. 31 fell to $1,122,000 or 7 cents a share, from $5,666,000 or 39 cents a share, a year earlier, A.A. Thornbrough, president, said today.

GENEVA, March 1 -- The recent move by the United States and Canada toward the formation of a common automobile market is expected to come under criticism at the session of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) that begins here tomorrow.
ST. LOUIS, March 1 (AP) -- Bob Pettit, who has scored more points than any other player in National Basketball Association history, announced his retirement today.
The men with the muscles and the broad backs -- the moving and storage men -- went on strik yesterday, to the surprise of many families expecting them to come and take the furniture and the dishware.
HOBART, Tasmania, March 1 (AP) -- Rocky Trosize, 25 years old, of Australia was killed today when his car ran off the road during the Australian Grand Prix.
DALLAS, March 1 (AP) -A slightly rumpled-looking Billie Sol Estes saw the choosing of a jury and the beginning of testimony today for his trial on charges of lying to the Government about his debts.

In James Reston's column of Feb. 17 he discussed demonstrations at Harvard protesting recent United States action in Vietnam. We of the Harvard Law Graduate School Democratic Club believe that these demonstrations do not reflect the views of a majority of Harvard students.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 1 -- Del E. Webb severed his connection with the New York Yankees today by selling his 10 per cent of the club to the Columbia Broadcasting System for $1.4 million. In the 20 years during which Webb was part-owner of the Yankees the team won 15 pennants.

ALBANY, March 1 -- The state named a special prosecutpr and special judge today to handle the inquiry into the City of Buffalo's purchase of a garage for $800,000 from a company that had bought it two minutes earlier for $657,000.
Sales of department stores in the metropolitan area declined in February from the level of a year earlier for the first time in the last 15 months.

LONDON, Feb. 28 -- The Royal Ballet's "Romeo and Juliet" has proved to be one of the biggest box-office hits in the history of British ballet. There are two things in London today for which it is impossible to get seats: Laurence Olivier in the National Theater's "Othello" and any cast in Kenneth MacMillan's new version of Prokofiev's ballet.

The annual Elsie de Wolfe award of the New York Chapter of the American Institute of Interior Designer was presented last night to Philip Johnson, the New York architect. Representative John V. Lindsay made the presentation in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza Hotel before a room filled with professional designers.
ALBANY, March 1 -- The Democrats moved today to add $15 million to Governor Rockefeller's current budget. If approved by the Legislature, it could throw the budget out of balance.

ALBANY, March 1 -- Senator Robert F. Kennedy looked in on the political turmoil in Albany today and used the occasion to attack Governor Rockefeller's sales-tax proposal and to smooth over some frictions between himself and other Democrats.
PITTSBURGH, March 1 -- Pablo Casals will visit Carnegie Institute of Technology for two weeks beginning April 15, as visiting Andrew Mellon Professor of Music.

Members of the Brooklyn Museum and their families participating in the museum's second Study Tour to Peru, from March 16 to April 2, will receive a final briefing tomorrow evening at a reception and meeting in the museum.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo., March 2 (AP) -- Christine Haigler of Colorado Springs took a narrow lead in compulsory figures of women's singles in the opening event of the 1965 world figure skating championships today.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- An investigation of the long-standing, but now controversial stock-exchange rules, that prohibit exchange members from doing off-floor business in listed stocks, has been ordered by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Beginning today, The New York Times will publish an air-pollution index based on data supplied by the city's Air Pollution Control Laboratory. The laboratory will not provide data on weekends and therefore no index will be published in The Times on Sundays and Mondays.

MIAMI, March 2 -- A Florida-bred, Mrs. Ben Cohen's Hail to All, will be the "one to beat" in the Flamingo Stakes for 3-year-olds tomorrow. The stretch-running son of Hail to Reason will be the favorite in the 36th running of the 1 1/8 mile classic that will feature the closing day of Hialeah's successful 40-day meeting.

NEW HAVEN, March 2 -- A group of determined Yale students protesting the university's policy on faculty tenure, paraded doggedly through a second day of around-the-clock picketing today at the university's administrative offices.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Congress came to grips today with the complex and controversial problem of keeping the New Haven Railroad running.
Investors are continuing to show strong interest in the stock of airlines whose profits have climbed still higher in the first month of this year.

A selling stockholders committee, representing the Christiana Securities Company and certain stockholders of E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., announced yesterday that a registration statement covering a secondary offering of 2,815,106 shares of General Motors Cor poration common stock has been filed The total amount would have a market value of more than $282 million.
