The corporate bond market had its most successful offering yesterday in three months.

The proposed development of a supersonic transport aircraft should be financed from private money guaranteed by Government insurance against major risks, Prof. Paul W. Cherington told a transportation conference at Northwestern University yesterday.

WARSAW, March 3 -- The tension has been growing for the last 10 days among the 83 competitors in the seventh Frederic Chopin international piano competition. The first round ended today and the judges will announce tomorrow the names of the 36 who will go on.
Initial reaction to the Board of Education's request for the Superintendent's resignation is shock mixed with sadness.

CHICAGO, March 3 -- Eddie Machen trains on a red-pile carpet in a gold, marbled motel here for a fight against Ernie Terrell Friday night that has been billed as the world heavyweight championship. But Eddie Machen is 32 years old and the scars of 54 other fights surround the eyes that study the carpet when he talks.
PORTSMOUTH, Va., March 3 (UPI) -- The Eagle, a three-masted bark, will not cruise to European ports in 1965 for the first time in the 19 years it has been used for training Coast Guardsmen.

The former Brass Rail Restaurant at 8 Nevins Street, opposite the Fox Theater in downtown Brooklyn, has been sold to clients of the Charles F. Noyes Company and Realty Associates, Inc. Assessed at $325,000, the property consists of a two-story and a three-story building, both vacant, on a plot 90 by 100 feet.

SHORT HILLS, N.J., March 3 -- The young clergyman stood at the front of the crowded Erie Lackawanna coach No. 2245, whisky and cigarette advertisements behind him, and addressed more than 100 passengers seated and standing before him.

More than 450 members of the cotton trade, perplexed by sagging volume in cotton futures, have formed a group to "re-establish a free market" in the fiber, it was announced here yesterday. The group, which will press for a revision of the present cotton-subsidy program, hopes to revivify the now enfeebled New York Cotton Exchange.
WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Representative Frank Thompson Jr. of New Jersey was elected chairman of the Democratic Study Group today.

MOSCOW, March 3 -- The Soviet Union recentralized the management of its defense industries today by removing them from the control of regional industrial councils established by Nikita S. Khrushchev eight years ago.
MIAMI, March 3 -- Native Charger rushed out of the obscurity cast over the field by the three standout horses in the $143,600 Flamingo Stakes, the closing-day feature at Hialeah today.

BRUSSELS, March 3 -- Officials of the International Confederation of Free Trade Unions denied tonight a charge by George Meany, the American labor leader, yesterday that the staff had been infiltrated by homosexuals.

TIMMINS, Ont., March 3 -- A 36-year-old prospector disclosed today that he had been the source of two bullish reports concerning Windfall Oils and Mines, Ltd., at a time of volatile price movements in the stock last July.
" Catholics do not need the support of civil law to be faithful to their own religious convictions and they do not seek to impose by law their moral views on other members of society."
The New York Stock Exchange agreed yesterday to postpone a public hearing on the question of whether Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, Inc., common stock should be delisted.

" I'M just terrified," Mrs. S. Carter Burden Jr. said yesterday at noon as she sat in the dressing room of the Imperial Ballroom of the Americana Hotel while Mr. Rodney of Kenneth drew a line of green eyeshadow down the middle of her nose and then glued green five-and-dime-store glitter over it. "I've never done it before."

STARTING Monday it will be possible to pause between the fur and shoe salons on Bonwit Teller's second floor to buy a cup of coffee, a sandwich or a flowered shift. The store's new Espresso Shop for Young Sports will house a refreshment area as well as snappy, young casual clothes that rarely go over $35.

CAIRO, March 3 -- The United Arab Republic has decided to raise its diplomatic mission in North Vietnam to an embassy and will permit the Hanoi regime to follow suit with its mission here, authoritative Egyptian sources said tonight.
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 3 -- As spring training progresses through the next five weeks, a fierce battle for jobs will develop among half a dozen or more New York Yankee pitchers.
MANY mothers-to-be are very unprofessional about selecting the professional men who will deliver their babies.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 3 -- South Vietnam's former strong man, Lieut. Gen. Nguyen Khanh, conferred for an hour today with Adlai E. Stevenson, permanent United States representative, on the increasingly critical situation in South Vietnam.
SAIGON, March 3 -- An American pilot who flew in yesterday's bombing attack against North Vietnam denied today reports from Hanoi that civilian targets had been hit.
PARIS, March 3 -- Le Mesnil-Saint-Denis (pop. 1,856), a one-church, one-chateau, six-cafe village 18 miles southwest of Paris, is taking the plunge into suburbia, American style.
The separation trial of the Alan Jay Lerners began in State Supreme Court yesterday with Mr. Lerner, the Broadway lyricist, giving two hours of testimony.

A Brooklyn detective admitted yesterday in State Supreme Court that he had "made a mistake" when he told a grand jury last May about the arrest of George Whitmore Jr. on charges of assault and attempted rape of Mrs. Elba Borrero.
PEKING, March 3 -- President Mohammad Ayub Khan of Pakistan is an important and popular visitor in Communist China.
An investment banking syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., won $40 million of first-mortgage bonds sold yesterday by the Florida Power and Light Company.
WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Navy recruiting problems were aired yesterday at a closed session of the House Armed Services Committee.
DALLAS, March 3 (AP) -- Prison-bound Billie Sol Estes was acquitted by a Federal jury today on charges of lying to the Government about his debts.
The trucking industry declared an embargo yesterday on exports moving to piers because of congestion remaining in the aftermath of last month's dock strike.

LONDON, March 3 (AP) -- Britain's Professional Golfers Association put a severe penalty on slow players into the books today. The association imposed a two-stroke penalty on any pro found guilty of persistently delaying play.

DR. MAYNARD WOLFE of Morristown, N.J., wanted a good shooting dog for pheasant and quail. He wanted a dog that was small enough for suburban living, so he bought a vizsla, sometimes called the Hungarian pointer.
WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. said today that his life had been threatened because of his determination to expose crime and police corruption in Harlem.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, March 3 (Reuters) -- One Unesco-sponsored teacher in the Congo was behind bars today. Others were in hiding, three were awaiting expulsion and one was in refuge in the Polish Embassy with his family.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The State Department suggested today United States air strikes in North Vietnam were justified by the concept of collective defense under provisions of the United Nations Charter.

" Selena Mead," a television adventure series that was to star Polly Bergen, has been dropped from the Columbia Broadcasting System's program schedule for next season. The show had been selected by James T. Aubrey Jr., the C.B.S. television network president who was ousted by the company last weekend.

The spark that had twice led the New York Rangers to victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs last week-end went out last night. The Blues were whipped, 6 -- 1, by the Boston Bruins, who had lost seven of the 12 previous National Hockey League games between the teams.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 3 -- Liu Chieh, the Nationalist Chinese delegate, said today that Soviet opposition and inadequate United States support had kept his country off the Special Committee on Peace-Keeping Operations.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., March 3 -- The Bridgeport Gas Company announced a $1,000 reward today for information leading to the arrest and conviction of persons responsible for the sabotaging of gas service lines
The City Health Department relaxed its regulations covering the serving of milk in restaurants and schools yesterday to prevent a shortage of dairy containers.
ALBANY, March 3 -- The Republicans beat the Democrats today, 3 to 0, in a Senate match that lasted three hours and accomplished almost nothing.
OTTAWA, March 3 -- The escape from a Montreal jail last night of an inmate accused as a drug smuggler has set off a new political bombardment of Prime Minister Lester B. Pearson's Liberal Government.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Senator Robert F. Kennedy, Democrat of New York, denounced a Senate investigating subcommittee today for having raised what he said was a false implication that he had acted improperly while Attorney General.
An indecisive trend prevailed in the stock market yesterday in heavy trading.

The Morgan Guaranty Trust Company staged an upset yesterday in the municipal bond markets by sweeping $70.64 million of the Public Housing Authority's $115.88 million offering. The bank, bidding alone, took seven of the 26 issues that make up the package.

HOLLYWOOD, March 3 -- Support seems to be developing in union and guild circles on the West Coast in favor of the Federal Communications Commission's proposed rule curtailing network control over television programming.
Robert Moses urged yesterday that the Eastchester Bay shoreline of the Bronx be saved from commercial exploitation by the construction of a six-lane highway.

CHICAGO, March 3 (UPI) -- Floyd Smith's goal midway through the second period tonight started the Detroit Red Wings to a 2-0 victory over the Chicago Black Hawks. The triumph moved the Wings to within 3 points of the first-place Hawks in the National Hockey League.

The decision of the New Jersey Supreme Court prohibiting the construction of a motel with a ten-story tower on the Palisades is an isolated but welcome curb on the defacement of this magnificent natural wonder. It comes too late and is too limited in scope to have much effect in stemming the onrush of commercialization, but it will protect a site of great natural beauty from a particularly gross desecration.
A remapping of the 1,080-acre Annadale-Huguenot section of Staten Island was proposed yesterday by the City Planning Commission. It would replace the urban renewal plan discarded last year.
HOLLYWOOD, March 3 -- A Methodist Bishop called today for an overhaul of the Motion Picture Production Code, charging that its provisions now "sound like a maiden aunt's fussy regulations."

Cotton manufacturers apprised of the formation of a committee for a free market in cotton indicated yesterday that they favored the objective but doubted that there would be any change in the Government marketing program in the near future.

The Timken Roller Bearing Company, the world's largest manufacturer of tapered roller bearings, in 1964 rolled up the highest sales and earnings in its history, according to figures reported yesterday.
HAVANA, March 3 -- Premier Fidel Castro regretted on television tonight that Cuba was not closer to North Vietnam "so we could send antiaircraft weapons and war planes with pilots and all" there.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. March 3 -- Ron Hunt checked into the New York Mets' training base today and immediately opened his title defense as the best second baseman on the team.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Francis Keppel, the United States Commissioner of Education, asserted today that the Administration's Federal aid to education bill did not infringe on the separation of church and state.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, March 3 (UPI) -- The American manager of a Shell Oil refinery in eastern Borneo was ordered replaced by Indonesian authorities amid indications today that the Shell Oil fields and those of the American-owned Stanvac Oil Company soon would be nationalized.
Macy's New York said yesterday that it would definitely retain its Jamaica, Queens, store, despite the planned opening this fall of its new "store in the round" in Elmhurst Queens.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Senator Everett McKinley Dirksen of Illinois said today that the voters should have the right to say whether one house of their State Legislatures should be apportioned on factors other than population.
MARION, Ala., March 3 -- Jimmie Lee Jackson was proclaimed a martyr and buried in a country graveyard here today.
Models employed by an advertising agency to "demonstrate" the efficiency of Regimen diet pills took other medication to lose weight, the Government asserted yesterday in Federal Court, Brooklyn.
Paul Borman, 32 years old, was elected yesterday to the presidency of Borman Food Stores, Inc. The concern operates the 79-store Food Fair supermarket chain in Michigan.

The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People threatened yesterday to hold nationwide demonstrations this spring to win compliance with laws prohibiting discriminatory hiring practices by building trade unions and contractors.
Rudolph Smith, a test engineer who began in the Pueblo plant of the Colorado Fuel and Iron Corporation in July, 1927, yesterday became president of the nation's 12th largest steel producer.

The Borden Foods Company said yesterday it would reduce wholesale prices for its instant coffee to meet competition. The concern also said it would temporarily close its instant-coffee plant at Newport, N.Y., because of the market's present instability.
The Times Mirror Company, the large Los Angeles publishing concern, announced late yesterday several executive changes.
Prices for Maine potato futures rose yesterday for the second day after dropping sharply on Monday on the New York Mercantile Exchange.

A national union leader indicated last night that the support given by the top three officers of the Temporary Commission on City Finances to Governor Rockefeller's budget program did not represent the thinking of all 15 commission members.
An $8 million acquisition plan involving the proposed sale of Chicago Aerial Industries, Inc., to the Itek Corporation was canceled suddenly yesterday by the Chicago concern.

A highly heralded Puerto Rican self-help effort announced last night that it was closing its antipoverty program. It charged that it could not get a city decision on a pending $12.5 million, two-year plan and did not want to be "wasteful of public funds" with a holding operation.

Marvin Kratter, board chairman of the Kratter Corporation, a real estate investment company, will speak on "Trends in Modern Real Estate: New York City's First Condominium" at the luncheon meeting tomorrow of the Graduate School of Business Administration Financial Club of New York University.
The people at Basford, Inc., boasted of a new look yesterday -- both outside and inside the agency.

We believe that Congress has erred in granting a $370,000 appropriation for the House Committee on Un-American Activities. The committee, many of whose activities are unconstitutional, has shown an inability to judge what is "un-American"; it is costly, and, of greatest moment, has repeatedly trampled the civil liberties of Americans.
WASHINGTON, March 3 (UPI) -- Love and marriage obviously are vital parts of President Johnson's "Great Society" program. He proved it today.
MINEOLA, L.I., March 3 -- A reported increase in narcotics adiction in Nassau County, especially among teen-agers, was attributed here today to the "infection spreading from New York City."

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The United States, seemingly modifying its Middle East arms policy, has agreed to discuss with Israel the possibility of supplying American weapons to offset Soviet arms shipments to Arab states.

THE perennial generosity of the acting profession in aiding worthy undertakings found expression last night in the appearance of a number of stars on Channel 13 to champion the cause of educational station WNDT.
ALBANY, Mar. 3 -- The state told hundreds of local government leaders here today that most of New York's counties would have to reapportion themselves quickly.
A policeman was beaten by a mob of girls yesterday when he tried to break up a fight between two girls in a Brooklyn schoolyard.
Diners' Club cards, a symbol of an affluent capitalist class, are to be honored for the first time east of the Iron Curtain this year.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 3 -- United States Air Force jets struck secret targets today in a follow-up to yesterday's raids made with South Vietnamese planes on military installations in North Vietnam.

Executive appointments at the top level were announced yesterday by two of the country's big food-processing companies. At the General Foods Corporation, Chauncey William Wallace Cook will become chief executive officer on April 1, succeeding Charles G. Mortimer, chairman, who is retiring on July 27.

THE command of the outpost KB5 at all cost is the recurrent theme behind many victories of the New York master Edmar Mednis. His most recent triumph along these lines was as White in a Ruy against Hyman Schneid in the Marshall Club championship.
Dr. Calvin E. Gross said yesterday he did not know whether he would comply with the Board of Education's demand that he resign as Superintendent of Schools.
A new war has begun on the Indochinese peninsula with the latest series of aerial strikes against North Vietnamese military objectives.
AMARILLO, Tex. -- An eerie roar awakened Albert McGarraugh before dawn on Feb. 23.
Mayor Wagner has named a new standard-bearer in his long effort to undermine the leadership of Brooklyn's Democratic chief, Assemblyman Stanley Steingut.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 3 (AP) -- Maj. Gen. Nguyen Van Thieu replaced Lieut. Gen. Nguyen Khanh, ousted strong man, today as the top officer of the nation's 25-man Armed Forces Council, but he has only a fraction of the power General Khanh wielded.

A spokesman for industry said yesterday that Maritime Administrator Nicholas Johnson, whose primary function is to promote the American merchant fleet, was offering "prescriptions that could kill rather than cure."
LONDON, March 3 -- The Government proposed legislation today that would require official consent for any major newspaper mergers.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The Budget Bureau will soon distribute a "draft circular" to all departments and agencies of the Federal Government emphasizing President Johnson's desire to end, to the extent practical, Government enterprises that compete with private enterprise.
WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The New Haven Railroad's effort to abandon a third of its New York City commuter service March 29 was blocked today by the Interstate Commerce Commission.
CHICAGO, March 3 -- Chicago water officials called for "drastic corrective action" today to abate the industrial discharge of contaminants into Lake Michigan.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Pierre Salinger, former White House press secretary, called upon the news media today to go beyond mere reporting of political campaigns to prevent vilification, slander and libel of public figures.
OTTAWA, March 3 -- Canada's gold and United States dollar reserves dropped $19.5 million (United States) during the month of February, the Ministry of Finance announced today.
The Right Rev., Horace W.B. Donegan, Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of New York, proposed yesterday that the 40-day Lenten season be shortened to the two weeks preceding Easter.
The nation's electric power production rose 7.2 per cent in the week ended Feb. 27 from the level in the corresponding 1964 week, it was reported yesterday by the Edison Electric Institute.
The pressmen's union has made the expiration date of a new working contract a major issue in its negotiations with the Publishers Association of New York City.

WASHINGTON, March 3 (UPI) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board, in a rare admission of defeat, said today it had been unable to determine how lightning could have blown off the wing of a Pan American World Airways jet over Elkton, Md.
THE people who avoid involvement when their neighbors are in trouble have been in the news in recent months, and Frank Gagliano has written a long one-acter about such a terrified, cowardly creature.

Marino Marini, Italian sculptor and painter, is the subject of a biographical critique by Franco Russoli, which Harry N. Abrams will issue March 19. In "Marino Marini." Mr. Russoli uses 219 illustrations, including 50 full color plates.

TOKYO, Thursday, March 4 (AP) -- Communist China asserted today that the United States had demanded that North Vietnam hand over territory south of the 19th Parallel. It did not say how or when the alleged demand was made.
The Electric Bond and Share Company reported yesterday that 1964 earnings were the highest since 1959.

HONG KONG, March 3 -- The Chinese Communist party warned the leaders of the Soviet Union today that they would suffer the same fate as former Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev if they persisted in their present policies.

SYDNEY, Australia, March 3 (Reuters) -- Dawn Fraser was mobbed by young fans tonight when she made what could be her last appearance at an official swimming carnival. At one point she had to dive into the water to avoid the crush of the fans.
MADRID, March 3 -- One of the most widespread protest movements ever held here against the regimentation of university life appeared today to be approaching its end.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., March 3 -- The possibility that some students had paid fees to have their credits altered is being investigated by the University of Bridgeport and the police.
NAIROBI, Kenya, March 3 -- The Congo accused her fellow members of the Organization of African Unity today of having lost sight of their fight against colonialism to meddle in Congolese affairs.

MOSCOW, March 3 -- Soviet and foreign Communist leaders severely criticized today the American bombing attack on North Vietnam yesterday and gave vague assurances of support for the Communist regime in Hanoi.
WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Sheldon S. Cohen, the new Commissioner of Internal Revenue, is trying to make the income tax forms and instructions easier to understand -- for next year.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- A vigorous new movement for the economic integration of Latin America is urgently required if the hemisphere is ever to make real progress in its development, the chief executive officer of the Alliance for Progress warned today.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The Senate Rules Committee voted today not to recommend changes in the present filibuster rule. The action is expected to have little effect on the prospects for voting rights legislation this year.
LONDON, March 3 -- Britain promised today a big reduction in her armed forces and suggested that her 51,000-man ground force in West Germany might be affected.
WASHINGTON, March 3 -- A Senate Subcommittee suggested today that Congress consider a bill to legalize wiretapping and make it a crime to belong to such criminal societies as the Mafia.
WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The House passed the $1.1 billion Appalachia bill late this afternoon and sent it to the White House. The vote was 257 to 165.
Creditors searching -- mostly in vain -- for the $150 million that disappeared in the great soybean oil swindle are wrestling with a new puzzler.

PALM BLEACH, Fla., March 3 -- No one in Palm Beach has more fun than the yachtsmen, those elegant adventurers who go down to the sea in ships stocked with Lowestoft china, crystal chandeliers and wall-to-wall carpeting.

Winston Moseley, a convicted murderer under sentence of death, was cited five times yesterday for contempt by Supreme Court Justice Edward Thompson in Queens for refusing to answer questions as a witness in Alvin L. Mitchell's murder trial.
MIAMI, Fla. -- "Florida may not be celebrated for its kitchens." Alex Hawkes said recently, "but it has some of the most interesting foods of any state in America."
Satisfied with what's inside the can, the National Brewing Company is attempting to add a little zip to the outside.
Sales of new cars in February reached a new high, rising by 18 per cent over a year ago. The auto industry continues to be a major contributor to the current boom in the national economy.
A third Negro was arrested yesterday on charges of taking part in the murder of Malcolm X, the black nationalist leader, during a rally on Feb. 21.

FOR one player to win two events during a weekend tournament is unusual. To win three is very rare indeed. Charles Bailey of New York was a triple winner at the recent tournament organized by the Metropolitan Unit of the American Bridge Association.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, March 3 -- Arthur Bottomley, Britain's Secretary of State for Commonwealth Relations, ended a 10-day visit to Rhodesia today with a denunciation of any unilateral declaration of independence by the self-governing colony.
WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The United States set off an underground nuclear explosion today, and the Soviet Union apparently did, too.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 3 -- Galo Plaza Lasso, the United Nations mediator for Cyprus, gave a first-hand report today to the Secretary General, U Thant, on the latest efforts to work out a settlement acceptable to the island's Greek and Turkish communities.

MELBOURNE, Australia, March 3 (AP) -- The indefatigable Ron Clarke added the world 10-mile record to his imposing list of distance running marks tonight, a few hours after havflown home from the United States.

ALBANY, March 3 -- Mayor Wagner came to Capitol Hill today to express the city's gratitude for the largess in Governor Rockefeller's record budget, and to ask for more. The Mayor was the first of 23 speakers at a public hearing on the portions of the budget that provide for state aid to local governments.
ARCADIA, Calif. March 3 (UPI) -- Manuel Ycaza and Bill Harmatz were fined $100 each today for their fight in the jockeys' room at Santa Anita after Saturday's $145,000 Santa Anita Handicap.
IT appears that the New York State Conservation Department is considering special regulations for a portion of the Battenkill River.

The Rev. Milton A. Galamison said yesterday he might call off the six-week-old boycott because the Board of Education has demanded the resignation of Dr. Calvin E. Gross, as Superintendent of Schools.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., March 3 (UPI) -- The Louisiana state champion, W.C. Cole of Monroe, fired a one-under-par 70 today to tie Larry Suhre of Hamel, Ill., for the medal at 142 in the national championship of golf club champions.

George MacCall, a 45-year-old insurance broker from Los Angeles, was named captain of the United States Davis Cup squad yesterday. MacCall, the fifth-ranking senior in the United States, was named by Martin Tressel of Pittsburgh, the newly elected president of the United States Lawn Tennis Association, and Harcourt Wood, the chairman of the U.S.L.T.A.
Public holdings of Series E and H United States savings bonds rose $95 million in February, the Treasury Department reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Manufacturers who use steel had built up their inventories to 11.9 million tons at the end of January from the presumably "normal" average of 9.3 million tons in the first half of last year, the Commerce Department reported today.

FORT WAYNE, Ind., March 4 (AP) -- The San Francisco Warriors rallied tonight to defeat the Detroit Pistons, 115 -- 110, and drop the Pistons three games behind Baltimore for the third and final playoff spot in the National Basketball Association's Western Division.

The New York City Center Light Opera Company will open its 12th annual spring season with Cole Porter's "Kiss Me, Kate" on May 12. Patricia Morison, who was selected by Mr. Porter to sing the role of Kate, will appear in it again.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- Roman Catholic bishops in the United States have been told not to participate in joint worship services with Protestants until a procedure for such participation has been approved by the Vatican.
WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP) -- Proposed legislation to establish a National Wild Rivers System was sent to Congress today by the Johnson Administration.
WASHINGTON, Mar. 4 -The value of new construction in February was estimated at about the January level after seasonal adjustment, the Commerce Department reported today.

Queen Elizabeth has appointed Edward R. Murrow, former head of the United States Information Agency, an honorary Knight Commander of tile Most Excellent Order of the British Emph-e "in recognition of the outstanding services rendered by him in furthering AngloAmerican friendship and understanding."

PENSACOLA, Fla., March 4 (AP) -- Four players, Jack Nicklaus, Doug Sanders, Ken Nagle and Dave Marr, tied for first place today with four-under-par 68's in the opening round of the $65,000 Pensacola open golf tournament.
Advances outnumbered declines by a slight margin yesterday on the American Stock Exchange in the most active trading of 1965.
NICE, France, March 4 (AP) -- Doctors treating Somerset Maugham for flu and pulmonary complications declared tonight that he was improving.
The New York Life Insurance Company, in its 120th annual report, disclosed yesterday that it set records last year in assets, insurance on its books, premium income and sales of new insurance.
TEANECK, N.J., March 4 -- Understandably, the nautical event that opened last night at the Teaneck Armory looks more like the Lesser New Jersey Boat Show than the Greater New Jersey Boat Show.
The International Typographical Union will continue its direct role in the New York newspaper negotiations, Elmer Brown, president of the printers' union, emphasized yesterday.

VISITING New York this week is a notable bridge personality whom many good judges rate as the world's No. 1 woman player. She is Mrs. Rixi Markus of London, whom New Yorkers will remember as a star of the British women's team that captured the World Olympiad Team title here last May.
Robert Moses yesterday made public his "tentative conclusions" as to which World's Fair structures should be retained and which demolished after the close of the fair.
A BRASH young artist who is also a businessman and a scavenger is putting the results of his scavenging on exhibition today.
HONG KONG, March 4 -- A Hong Kong publisher has printed a Chinese-language version of "The Story of The New York Times" by the late Meyer Berger.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., March 4 -- Local 1199 of the Drug and Hospital Employes Union offered today to end its strike at Lawrence Hospital here if the strikers were rehired. It had demanded recognition as bargaining agent for the employes.
HALLANDALE, Fla., March 4 -- Despite a heavy morning rainfall, the Gulfstream Park Race Track attracted a crowd of 19.094 for the opening day of its meeting today.
ALBANY, March 4 (AP) -The Public Service Commission today urged Federal refusal of the bankrupt New Haven Railroad's request to abandon a third of its New York City commuter service.
A Black Muslim fought in vain yesterday to be freed from charges of taking part in the murder of Malcolm X or to be given a more formal complaint to counter.

ADELAIDE, Australia, March 4 (Comtelburo) -- The Australian Petroleum Exploration Association has decided to petition Prime Minister Menzics, to ask the United States Government to have Australia shielded from the full effects of the United States proposed restrictive policy on overseas capital investment.
Swift Co. is expanding its industrial specialty products business through the acquisition of the National Wax Company of Skokie, Ill.
Chanting, sign-waving students from Manhattan, Fordham, New York University and St. John's gathered at Madison Square Garden last night in lawful, if not peaceful, assembly.
WASHINGTON, March 4 -The national unemployment rate rose in February to 5 per cent, the Labor Department reported today. It had been 4.8 in January.
Every night except Sunday, they laugh when Leonid Hambro, official pianist for the New York Philharmonic, sits down at the piano.
MOSCOW, March 4 (UPI) -Mrs. Nikita S. Khrushchev was reported today to have attended the opera this week in her first appearance at the Kremlin since her husband was ousted from power last October.

On Jan. 16 service and maintenance workers at Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville, Westchester County, began a strike aimed at securing union recognition. It is now eight weeks later and this strike continues.
BERLIN, March 3 -- East Germany is at the point of no return along the path it embarked upon two years ago.

The French Government is employing the disruptive tactics of a sit-down strike in international monetary relations. Officials here and in Washington concede that France is refusing to participate actively in the international club of finance ministers and central bankers to strengthen the existing monetary system.
YORK, S.C., March 4 -- A damage award of $780,000 against the Ford Motor Company and a local construction concern was handed down by a jury here tonight.
PITTSBURGH, March 4 (AP) -- The steelworkers were back at the contract bargaining table today amid a report that David J. McDonald was on the way out as union president.

TAMPERE, Finland, March 4 (AP) -- A seasoned Swedish team strafed Goalie Tom Haugh of Providence, R.I., with 47 shots today and trounced an inexperienced United States team, 5 -- 2, in an opening-round game of the world amateur hockey tournament.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 4 -- The Secretary General, U Thant, expressed the hope today that all members of the United Nations would donate at least 80 per cent of the $18,367,000 required to maintain the United Nations Middle Eastern force in 1965.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -The Office of Economic Opportunity has held up a $132,000 planning grant to Louisiana because it does not like some of Gov. John J. McKeithen's appointments under the state's antipoverty program.
Eastman Dillon, Union Securities Co., investment bankers, announced yesterday the admission of Burch Williams, Richard H. Robinson and Lawrence T. Ryan as general partners.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -Housing Administrator Robert C. Weaver said today the President's new housing program was a "realistic" effort to solve the problems of families with low and moderate incomes. But he readily conceded that "it obviously doesn't meet the whole need."
Brookside Park Apartments, a garden development of 74 suites at 31 Morris Place, in Bloomfield, N.J., has been sold by Brookside Park Associates to the Place Realty Company.
PARIS (Reuters) -- A Christian Dior evening gown may cost a private client $1,400, but the house makes only $70 profit on the sale.
NAIROBI, Kenya, March 4 -Premier Moise Tshombe of the Congo arrived by air today to resent to the Organization of African Unity his case for more political support.

C.L. Sulzberger, foreign affairs columnist of The New York Times, has written "Unfinished Revolution: America and the Third World," which Atheneum will publish on April 27. The revolution he writes about is the one arising out of Woodrow Wilson's concept of self-determination.
SAIGON, Friday, March 5 (UPI) -- One American soldier was killed and another critically wounded in clashes with Communist guerrillas on the Laotian border, it was officially reported today.

A current State Department directive to passport offices states: "You may, of course, continue to assist travelers by having available visas and public-health information." Ruled out, however, are travel brochures and other related matter "which encourage foreign travel."
Secretary of State Dean Rusk declared here last night that negotiations for a settlement in Southeast Asia remained impossible because North Vietnam had shown no indication of ending its aggression.

EVERY winter thousands of prosperous residents of Boston, New York, Chicago, and Peoria flee the blizzards, ice storms, colds and chilblains of their native habitat and spend several weeks, or even several months, on one of the beautiful green islands of the Caribbean. A new traffic-control system in Manhattan, to be ready by late November, is "going to scare the daylights out of cab and truck drivers," Traffic Commissioner Henry A. Barnes quipped yesterday.

A decline of $125 million in the Treasury's gold stock as the result of purchases by "a few countries" was reported yesterday.
PITTSBURGH, March 4 -- A score of Protestant, Roman Catholic and Eastern Orthodox theologians have been meeting here since Monday, deliberately sizing one another up.
WASHINGTON, March 4 -The United States Information Agency announced today that it was ending its activities in Indonesia because of "intolerable" harassment by the Indonesian Government.
Josef Krips lead the New York Philharmonic last night at Philharmonic Hall in the fifth Bruckner-cycle concert.
The Singer Company achieved the highest sales and earnings in its 113-year history in 1964, marking the sixth successive year of records, Donald P. Kircher, president, reported yesterday.

St. Louis University's basketball coach decided yesterday to bypass the National Collegiate Athletic Association playoffs for the National Invitation Tournament so that one of his players would have a chance to play in a post-season tourney.

Tunnels, unlike bridges, have never brought great fame to their builders or inspired the praise of poets. Dug out of the darkness beneath the river bed, too narrow for any dream except escape, they are merely functional.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 4 -- No self-respecting baseball fan in America would fail to identify Joe Pepitone as a "flake." And any stranger, watching the 24-year-old New York Yankee clown tirelessly through any 24-hour period, would eventually declare, with affection or astonishment, "What a nut!"
The best commercial demand in about 10 days buoyed most soybean and grain futures prices yesterday. About the only minus signs on the Chicago Board of Trade were in a few distant deliveries.

SANDS POINT, L.I., March 4 -- The faculty and scholarship funds of Wellesley College will benefit from the 17th house and garden tour sponsored by Wellesley-on-Long Island. Four homes here will be opened to the public from 1 P.M. to 5 P.M. on May 12.
The wholesale commodity price index fell to 102.5 on Wednesday from 102.8 on Tuesday.

LONDON, March 4 -- The Cunard Steamship Company assured its critics tonight that the interior of the new Q4 liner would "reflect all that is best in British design."

A panel of lawyers and economists addressed themselves yesterday to the subject of "antitrust in an expanding economy" and left an audience of more than 600 businessmen more convinced than ever of the need for caution before rushing into merger plans.

The New York and the American Stock Exchanges have reported the changes carried below in the shareholdings of officers, directors and controlling stockholders of listed companies.

An agreement that many settle the 53-day dock strike in South Atlantic ports was reached last night after days of bargaining under Federal mediation in Miami.

Market volume is booming in Wall Street these days and stock brokers are crossing their fingers that the good fortune will last.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 4 -- With one exception -but with midseason confusion -the New York Mets were all under one roof today for the first time since last October.

GENEVA, March 4 -- The International Committee of the Red Cross announced today that for the first time the Vietcong Communist rebel authorities in South Vietnam had taken delivery of letters and parcels for American prisoners.

The United States can produce within 30 months a flyable rocket capable of generating seven million pounds of thrust, Harold W. Ritchey, president of Thiokol Chemical Corporation, said yesterday. MONTREAL, March 4 (UPI) -- Claude Provost scored his 25th goal of the season late in the third period tonight to give the Montreal Canadiens a 2-2 tie with the Toronto Maple Leafs and move them within 2 points of first-place Chicago in the National Hockey League.

A special committee appointed by the Borad of Education to study proposed educational complexes, or clusters of schools, designed to aid integration declared yesterday that the plan, unless used only as a first step, was inadequate.

The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. affirmed here yesterday his conviction that more and more responsible white people in the Southern states favored and supported the restoration of racial peace on the basis of social justice and equality.
The Board of Education stripped Dr. Calvin E. Gross of his authority as Superintendent of Schools yesterday and placed him on a three-month leave of absence with pay.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 4 -- The telephone rang in Casey Stengel's hotel room at 7 A.M. today and the manager of the New York Mets, thinking it was the "wake up" call, was astonished to hear a familiar voice from 3,000 miles away say with urgency, "This is Edna."
JACKSON, Miss., March 4 -- A civil rights lawyer said today that he had been beaten by officers in the Pike County jail when he went there to see clients arrested in a racial demonstration.

The flow of population to the suburbs and the sheer number of new-store branches are allowing outlying stores to make greater sales strides than ever. WASHINGTON, March 4 -Three New England Governors promised Congress today that they would do their utmost to match Federal grants with state money to save the New Haven Railroad.

BRUSSELS, March 4 (AP) -The secretary general of the International Confederation of Free Trade Unions suggested today that George Meany, president of the American labor movement, would play a more constructive role if he brought his criticism of the organization to the board table.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -Legislation authorizing a program of research and development aimed at the establishment of passenger trains running more than 100 miles an hour between New York, Boston and Washington was proposed to Congress today by President Johnson.

WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP) -- The House passed today a bill to increase by $750 million the United States contribution to funds for loans in Latin America.
THE state of Missouri is hoping that a bulldozing project will solve a pressing problem.

OXFORD, Miss., March 4 -- Mississippi now has most of the problems and many of the attitudes of an underdeveloped country. It is short on capital, short on industry and industrial skills, short on leadership and education.

Visiting strangers often have trouble comprehending the geographical relationships of New York's five boroughs and the adjacent metropolitan regions surrounding them. Even the citizen who knows his way fairly well in his own bailiwick gets nonplused in less familiar territory, often having to consult higher authority such as a map, a police officer or a road direction agency.
ALBANY, March 5 -- Governor Rockefeller has decided to appoint Walter J. Mahoney of Buffalo, former Majority Leader of the State Senate, as a member of the State Thruway Authority.
For the third consecutive day, volume on the American Stock Exchange set a record yesterday as prices generally ended lower.

PARIS, March 5 -- Maurice Girodias, head of the Olympia Press here, confirmed today that he was leaving France "just as soon," he says, "as this legal thing is settled." He plans to begin his business again in the United States this year.

VIENNA, March 5 By agreement between the Conservatives and Socialists who make up the coalition Government, Austria is becoming more land more an East-West trade bridge between the Communist and non-Communist spheres of Europe.

Commissioner of Correction Anna M. Kross has ordered an investigation into charges by a Bennington College freshman that she had been denied the right to contact her lawyer and had been humiliated by a doctor who examined her at the Women's House of Detention.
Two new British jetliners -- the long-range Super VC-10 and the short-range BAC 111 -- will make their first appearances in this country next week.

Yale University's decision to review the denial of tenure to Prof. Richard J. Bernstein represents a significant victory for the students who demonstrated on his behalf. Whether the young men at Yale were right or wrong in this particular case, it seems evident that they were trying to express opposition to academic policies that reward research while ignoring the quality of classroom teaching.
PARIS, March 5 -- Some of the fellows at the bar around the corner are thinking of writing to Senator J.W. Fulbright for information.

Nathan W. Goldstein, circulation director of The New York Times, will be honored by the Publishers Division of the Anti-Defamation League Appeal at a testimonial dinner on Wednesday, March 10, at 6 P.M. at the Savoy Plaza Hotel.

I.W. Abel won election as president of the United Steelworkers of America by 8,342 votes, according to a complete but unofficial tabulation of the union's national election that was circulated yesterday in Pittsburgh.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 5 The Secretary General, U Thant, has been given a proclamation expressing support of the United Nations that was adopted by student leaders from the United States and 36 other countries.

TRENTON, March 5 -- State Senator Charles W. Sandman Jr. of Cape May County entered the race for the Republican nomination for Governor today, then withdrew, and finally left, uncertain whether he was in or out.

MOSCOW, March 5 -- Workmen sent by the Soviet For-eight Ministry started this morning replacing broken windows in the United States Embassy and ridding the face of the building of several hundred black, blue, red and orange ink blotches.
MIAMI, Fla. -- Although Florida enjoys an abundance and variety of foods of a scale rarely known beyond its borders, the state is not fabled for the excellence of its restaurants.

There was a sadness in the lighthouse this week. Even the cry of the gulls seemed muted and melancholy as the birds wheeled in over the rocks around Robbins Reef Light Station, a short row out from Bayonne in the Upper Bay of the world's busiest harbor.
In reply to criticism that he has imprudently chartered too many new national banks, the Controller of the Currency, James J. Saxon, has published an interesting tabulation.
PITTSBURGH, March 5 -- A Roman Catholic Bishop said here today that the directive would in no way hamper the growing rapprochement between Catholics and Protestants in this country.

That Senator Lyndon Johnson's nomination for Vice President displeased a substantial number of the delegates at the Democratic convention of 1960 was audibly evident, for they were fully aware that in order to vote for Kennedy, though disliking Johnson, they must vote for him as well.
The Rev. Milton A. Galamison, school boycott leader, served 20 minutes in a detention room in Brooklyn Supreme Court yesterday.

CINCINNATI, March 5 (UPI) -- The Philadelphia 76ers blew an 18-point second-quarter lead tonight and then rallied behind Wilt Chamberlain's heavy scoring to nip the Cincinnati Royals, 110 -- 109, in a National Basketball Association contest.

" PORGY AND BESS" -- Gershwin, you know -- seems to have taken roots as an American classic, and everybody accepts it as a kind of masterpiece. It turned up last night as given by the New York City Opera Company.
The Board of Education, after meeting with its new Acting Superintendent, promised yesterday to take steps by the end of next month to bring about better integration of the city schools.
The future of the railroads, at least as a means of transporting passengers, is very much at stake these days.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, March 6 -- The Vietcong struck hard at Government troops yesterday in mountains 40 miles southwest of the United States air base at Danang.
Willis Reed, the New York Knicks' fine rookie center, scored 46 points last night in a desperate effort to halt the Los Angeles Lakers.

Abbey Simon has been living in Europe for nearly 15 years, and the pianist's appearance last night was only his fourth home-town recital in all that time. There ought to be a law. An artist of such technical prowess, exciting temperament and musical sensitivity should be heard again and again.

OP art is traveling into fashion with virtually the speed of light. The first shot launched from Europe -- an extremely successful one -- arrived Thursday evening in the form of a collection of clothes by the Italian couturier Germana Marucelli.
CHICAGO, March 5 -- Senator Everett McKinley Dirksen testified in Federal Court today on behalf of his old friend, former Gov. William G. Stratton, and in favor of campaign contributions.

The importance of promoting brand names at the retailer and manufacturer levels was stressed yesterday by representatives of both groups at a meeting of the American Apparel Manufacturers Association.

Abuses of the tax-exempt privilege practiced by a small minority of foundations will be eliminated if the Treasury's new proposals in this field are passed by Congress. The rules would not work hardship on legitimate foundations engaged in philanthropic activities. But they would prevent some foundations from conducting questionable private activities while posing as public trusts.

There was growing evidence yesterday of last-minute selling in the bond markets by dealers and investors rounding up capital for next Tuesday's offering of 11,166,438 common shares of the General Aniline and Film Corporation.
CAMDEN, Ala., March 5 -- Nearly 200 Negroes trying to march on the courthouse here to protest voter registration practices were turned back twice today at the city limits.
Issues closed out the week on a quiet and mixed note yesterday on the London Stock Exchange.
Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians is cracking down on discotheques, the nightclubs using recorded music, that refuse to employ its members.

BRAZZAVILLE, the Congo, March 5 -- Moving quietly but with astonishing speed, the Chinese Communists seem to have won in this former French colony their first firm foothold in West Africa. This is the unanimous conclusion of Western diplomats here.
The collegians take over Madison Square Garden tonight for the fifth, final and perhaps most exciting meet of the local indoor track season.
Success may be spoiling the private schools, one of the nation's leading private school headmasters warned yesterday.
LONDON, March 5 -- The Labor Government suffered a surprising defeat today in the House of Commons.
INDIANOLA, Miss., March 5 -- A Freedom School and library containing 2,000 volumes burned to the ground before dawn today.

BOWIE, Md., March 5 (AP) -- The $100,000-added John B. Campbell, with heavily weighted Gun Bow declining the issue, attracted a field of 16 today for its renewal over 1 1-16 miles at Bowie Race Course tomorrow.
A superior evening of polished lieder singing was offered last night at Carnegie Hall by Christa Ludwig, mezzo-soprano, and Walter Berry, baritone, in their New York recital debut.

The National Broadcasting Company announced plans yesterday for turning "Dr. Kildare" into a new type of serialized evening drama beginning next fail. Under the plan, some stories would require six hours to tell.
Kings Point, winning six of the 11 events, captured the fifth annual Athletic Association of Long Island Colleges swimming championship yesterday at the Queens College pool.

ATLANTA, March 5 -- The Atlanta Times, a conservative newspaper buffeted by financial problems since its start last June, said today it would ask stockholders to vote March 16 on a reorganization plan.
The British pound declined six points to $2.7942 yesterday in quiet trading on foreign exchange markets here.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 5 -- Providence College closed out its regular basketball schedule tonight with a 90-65 victory over Brown before a crowd of 2,400 at Marvel Gym.
THE man observers call "the work horse of the school system" is in the traces again.

BOSTON, March 3 -- Samuel Eliot Morison, who has written and lived history for 50 years and has capped it all with five years of intensive work on "The Oxford History of the American People," sums it all up with, "I'm proud of being all American."

ELIZABETHTOWN, Pa., March 5 -- Bucknell jumped to a big lead in the first day of competition in the Middle Atlantic Conference university-division swimming championships at Elizabethtown College while three schools were in a tight battle for college-division honors.
ROME, March 5 -- Former Premier Amintore Fanfani was appointed Foreign Minister of Italy today as part of a compex effort to shore up the shaky center-left coalition Cabinet of Premier Aldo Moro.

A list of about 15 possibilities as candidates to run against Mayor Wagner was compiled yesterday by Republican leaders. It included one of the city's most decorated ex-policemen, Mario Biaggi, but did not include David Rockefeller.

ALTHOUGH the International Flower Show, which opens at the New York Coliseum today, calls up images of middle-aged clubwomen with pouter-pigeon figures, many of the movers and shakers of the fashion world will be seen on the escalators rising eagerly toward the displays during the nine-day run.
Under nearly three hours of heavy cross-examination Alvin L. Mitchell continued yesterday to maintain that the police had beaten and coerced him to confess that he murdered a Queens schoolgirl.

On Aug. 10, 1932, some 10,000 well-wishers crowded a Chelsea pier to watch the liner Manhattan depart on her maiden voyage. Last night not a soul paid attention as a gray ghost passed through the city on her final voyage to the scrap heap.

I.D. Robbins, president of the City Club, yesterday denounced the city's chief housing official, Milton Mollen, as ineffective. He said that the Housing and Redevelopment Board was overstaffed and had "miserably botched" the job of providing housing for New Yorkers.
Robert Moses charged in a newspaper interview yesterday that Mayor Wagner "ran out on his promises" to give the World's Fair his full support.
Mayor Wagner moved yesterday to assure that school children would get milk despite a strike of steelworkers against the American Can Company.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation received a patent this week on the design of its Videx television transmitter, which sends still pictures over an ordinary telephone line.

CHICAGO, March 5 -- Circuit Judge Charles S. Dougherty upheld today a state Fair Employment Practices Commission ruling against Motorola Inc., the radio-television and electronics firm. But the judge reversed the commission's imposition of a $1,000 levy against the company to compensate Leon Myart, a Negro, for "embarrassment and possible loss of employment."
The General Tire and Rubber Company of Akron, Ohio, which has undertaken a wide-ranging diversification program, announced its entry yesterday into the newspaper publishing business.
The election of Lester Nadel as a vice president of the Royal National Bank of New York has been announced by William Goldfine, president.

TRIVANDRUM, India, Saturday, March 6 -- Pro-Peking Communists, sympathizers of India's neighbor and antagonist to the north, were leading the field early today in elections to the legislature of the politically restless state of Kerala.
WASHINGTON, March 5 -- Belgium, the Netherlands, Spare and Switzerland joined France as major takers of United States gold in the final quarter of last year, a Treasury report disclosed today.

PHILLIPSBURG, N.J., March 5 -- Two Keystone State cops were caught yesterday in this border town and forced back across the Delaware River in the latest round of the whisky war between this Garden State and Pennsylvania.
BONN, March 5 -- The West German Government and industry are waging a vigorous campaign to persuade German technicians to quit their jobs in the Egyptian aircraft and rocket industry.

Yevgeny Yevtushenko, the Soviet poet, has written to E.P. Dutton Co. expressing chagrin that another American book publisher is going to issue an edition of his poems even though he and Dutton have a contract for such a book.
MOSCOW, March 5 -- A controversial conference of pro-Soviet Communist parties ended here today after five days of deliberation in complete secrecy.

YONKERS, March 5 -- An inquiry by the New York State Harness Racing Commission into circumstances surrounding the eighth and ninth races at Yonkers Raceway Wednesday night has uncovered no evidence of wrongdoing.

NEW HAVEN, March 5 -- A foreign student at Yale University has joined the ranks of the "dropouts," but with a difference he quit school to become a Cabinet minister in the new Government of the Sudan.

The Kratter Corporation, a leading real-estate investment company, has formed a new organization called the National Equities, Inc., to own and operate the Jacob Ruppert breweries and certain other properties.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- Administration officials have begun to balance their stepped-up military actions in Vietnam with a more open acknowledgment of their interest in an eventual political settlement there.

Many Jews who did not approve of the intemperate advertisement of the Jewish War Veterans in The Times of Feb. 18 will nevertheless resent the letter of the West German Ambassador published on Feb. 27.

The confusion surrounding the accounts of the financially ailing Yale Express Systems, Inc., deepened yesterday as the company issued a report that, on its face, indicated a $4 million loss for a single quarter.
There is growing concern in a number of Protestant churches about the increasingly acute shortage of young Negroes who want to become ministers.

MIDDLEBURY, Vt., March 5 (AP) -- Gordon Eaton, the only competitor who consistently mastered slopes made treacherous by a thaw, won two events and led Middlebury to a 6.12-point lead over Dartmouth today in the transplanted Eastern Intercollegiate Ski Association championships.

There may be good news in store for some people who last year dropped exemptions on withholding statements in an effort to keep up with Federal taxes. In dropping ex emptions for Federal purposes, they automatically did the same on their state withholding statements. Since New York State's tax and withholding rates were not changed, they may well have overpaid their state tax.

Dartmouth University's swimming team broke two pool records yesterday while defeating Columbia, 63 -- 31, at the loser's pool. Tom Hober set a record of 2 minutes 9.5 seconds in the 200-yard butterfly event and the Dartmouth 400-yard medley relay team set a record of 3:56.2.

CHICAGO, March 5 -- Ernie Terrell tonight became the heavyweight champion of those parts of the world that hadn't already had one. He did it by falling all over Eddie Machen in the International Amphitheater, an arena built for livestock expositions.

WARSAW, March 5 -- Findlay Cockrell, a young American pianist eliminated in the first round of the seventh Frederic Chopin international competition, formally charged the jury today with favoring Russian and Polish entrants.
The wives of two suspects in the murder of Malcolm X bowed to the orders of Supreme Court Justice Abraham J. Gellinoff yesterday and testified before the grand jury.
LONDON, March 5 -- The state funeral of Sir Winston Churchill cost Britain the equivalent of $134,624.
ALBANY, March 5 -- A parade of witnesses continued before the legislative finance committees today, most of them protesting Governor Rockefeller's proposed 2 per cent statewide sales tax.
LONDON, March 5 -- A junior official has resigned his post in the Labor Government to join left-wing critics of its policy on Vietnam, it was announced today.
WASHINGTON, March 5 -- The United States called upon the Soviet Union today to provide better protection for the American Embassy in Moscow against any future demonstrations.

The Health and Sanitation Departments yesterday destroyed large quantities of pills that were found Thursday in and near the schoolyard of Public School 42, at Washington Avenue and Claremont Parkway, the Bronx, and in a nearby building.
LONDON, March 5 (AP) -- The authorities at nearby Chelmsford Prison were in a delicate dilemma today -- should they allow the jail's winning soccer team to play games outside the prison walls?

MIAMI BEACH, March 5 (AP) -- Dennis Ralston and Nicola Pietrangeli, the only seeded players remaining, advanced today to the semi-finals of the Good Neighbor tennis championships along with two 19-year-olds.
SAIGON, March 5 -- Gen. Harold K. Johnson, the United States Army Chief of Staff, spent the first day of a four-day tour of South Vietnam being briefed by the commanders here.

LEAVENWORTH, Kan., March 5 (UPI) -- Billie Sol Estes was removed secretly from the Dallas County jail before dawn today and brought to the Federal prison here to begin a 15-year sentence for mail fraud and conspiracy.

AS a dogged missionary for the cause of fine prints, and especially for the cause of getting people to buy them to own for pleasure, this observer must plug a very uneven show -- the 46th annual exhibition of SAGA (The Society of American Graphic Artists) presented at the A.A.A. (Associated American Artists) Gallery, 605 Fifth Avenue.
The Alan Jay Lerners spent the third day of their separation trial yesterday alternately accusing each other and defending themselves against charges of marital misconduct.

DANANG, South Vietnam, March 4 -- Almost 7,000 South Vietnamese crowded around the large American-manned air base on the outskirts of Danang will soon be uprooted from their homes and moved to another sector of city.

COLORADO SPRINGS, March 5 (AP) -- Alain Calmat of France finished first in the compulsory figures phase of the men's singles today, brightening his bid for his first world figure-skating title in the 11 years he has been competing.
After a day of controversy and hurried consultations, the Rev. Dr. Norman Vincent Peale was unanimously elected president of the Protestant Council of the City of New York yesterday.

TUCSON, Ariz., March 5 -- "For the first time in years, I can say -- without tongue in cheek -- that the Yankees will be under severe duress. This will be an extremely competitive American League race -- and we confidently expect to be a factor in it."

DETROIT, March 5 -- Marriage counselors and lawyers opened their first joint conference here tonight in the long battle the two groups have been waging separately against charlatan advisers and antiquated divorce laws.

PHILADELPHIA, March 5 -- The seventh and eighth seeded players, Frank Satterthwaite of Princeton and Tim Londergan of the University of Rochester, were defeated in the second round of the United States inter-collegiate squash racquets championship today on the University of Pennsylvania's courts.
CHICAGO, March 5 (AP) -- The United States Court of Appeals upheld today the dismissal of a suit against the Food and Drug Administration filed by Dr. Stevan Durovic, developer of the drug Krebiozen.
ATLANTA -- An aggressive duck named "George Quacker" is becoming as widely publicized a two-dimensional figure in Georgia as Smokey, the fire prevention bear.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, March 5 -- About 150 French army veterans, many of them former Foreign Legionnaires, are expected in the Congo to strengthen the mercenary forces of Premier Moise Tshombe's Government.
The tricot industry in an effort to obtain new markets is turning to outerwear.
PEKING, March 5 -- In talks with Chinese leaders, President Mohammed Ayub Khan of Pakistan is pressing for a negotiated settlement of the war in Vietnam.
PENSACOLA, Fla., March 5 (AP) -- Ken Venturi, who has been bothered with a circulatory ailment, withdrew today from the $65,000 Pensacola open.
AUSTIN, Tex., March 5 (AP) -- Quietly, in an almost empty courtroom, Texas's school segregation laws were stricken from the statute books today.
MOSCOW, March 5 -- The Communist party newspaper Pravda, commenting on United States policies in Southeast Asia, came closer than usual today, to making a personal attack on President Johnson.

A ragtag band of young drifters assembled from the loiterers in the Times Square area was seized early yesterday by the police, who said that they had vowed to "take over the city" this weekend with a dazzling display of armed robberies.
A Brooklyn detective said yesterday in State Supreme Court that George Whitmore Jr. "gave us details only the killer could have known" in connection with the knife-murder of a cleaning woman.
Wagner's "Die Walkure" will be given this afternoon by the Metropolitan Opera at 2:30 and Puccini's "Tosea" tonight at 8.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, March 4 -- To be a politician here, you need a name for your party, access to a mimeograph, a retinue of three or four to follow wherever you go a guileless appearance and money.

HALLANDALE, Fla.. March 5 -- Lyrico, owned by Mrs. H. Schneider, won a six-furlong sprint at Gulfstream today and the victory was a mild surprise even though the straight pay-off on her was $4,40. She was the weaker part of the favored entry trained by George Odom, whose other filly in the race was the Bohemia Stable's Chary.
Mayor Wagner said last night that the problems of his city, and cities in general, were many and widespread, but he said also that these problems could be solved and were being solved here.
The Long Island Women's Division of the Karen Horney Clinic will hold its sixth annual art show and sale March 20 and 21 at the Karen Horney Clinic, 329 East 62d Street.
WASHINGTON, March 5 (UPI) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board denied today an appeal by Northeast Airlines, Inc., to reverse a decision taking away the airline's New York-to-Florida route.

BRUSSELS, March 5 Belgian labor loaders are up in arms over the criticism this week by George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor-Congress of Industrial Organizations, of the headquarters staff of the International Confederation of Free Trade Unions.

PATERSON, N.J., March 6 -- Ch. Alekai Pokoi, the brilliant white 2 1/2-year-old standard poodle owned by Mr. and Mrs. Henry J. Kaiser's Alekai Kennels of Honolulu, continued to dominate the post-Westminister Show competition tonight.

The Agency for International Development is still pretty timid about carrying out President Johnson's pledge to find "new ways to use our knowledge to help deal with the explosion of world population." The AID says it will supply information, training and educational material for countries specifically requesting help in their birth control programs, but it will not make available birth control devices.
BATESVILLE, Miss., March 3 -- Negro sharecroppers in this racially tense Mississippi Delta area are seeking to organize to improve their lot.
The National Association of Engine and Boat Manufacturers, as expected, has changed the format for its 1966 National Motor Boat Show.
WASHINGTON, March 6 -- A Congressional subcommittee devoted four days of hearings this week to the esoteric but vital subject of high-energy physics.

MARCH is the month of flower shows which merely hint of April's spring. Here in New York the International Flower Show is in full bloom at the Coliseum. This year the theme is "Patios -Nature's Living Rooms." Nurserymen, landscape contractors and private estates are among the exhibitors who are demonstrating how the outdoors can be a part of family living.

IN a scene in "The Odd Couple," a new comedy by Neil ("Barefoot in the Park") Simon opening Wednesday at the Plymouth, someone asks a newswriter for C.B.S.: "Where do you gel your ideas?" When the same question is addressed, offstage, to the author of "The Odd Couple," Simon replies, unhelpfully: "From my life.
KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Sunday, March 7 (Reuters) -- The Malaysian Government announced today that it had accepted a United States offer of a $4 million defense credit.

When Tom decided to become a Red Cross disaster volunteer, he hoped that a disaster would never actually occur in his area. But he knew that storms brought flooding to low-lying areas in the Long Island neighbor hood where he lived. He took the Red Cross course for disaster volunteers and learned all about setting up shelters, mass care, emergency assistance and feeding.

AGAINST the exotic setting of Laos, Desmond Meiring, a political reporter born in Kenya, tells a tale of Oriental and Occidental intrigue in which the delineation of plot and character is less impressive than the frequent passages of straight reportage on a little-known war in a never-never land.

Last Monday the New York Blood Center announced that in cooperation with the National Rare Blood Club it was beginning a search for 10,000 volunteers to serve as members of an emergency blood-donor panel.
SHARON, Conn. -- Liberal Republicans here last week started what they hope will become a national movement to rebuild the Republican party under the banner of a Lincoln type of individualism.
A massive "physical clean-up" of Harlem to be led by last year's rioters was suggested yesterday as a measure to avert "long hot summer" of race tensions.
YONKERS, March 6 -- Carolina Kid, a bay gelding driven by Anthony Garafola, closed with a burst of speed through the stretch and won the feature mile pace at Yonkers Raceway tonight.
NEW ORLEANS, March 6 (AP) -- Valiant Man set a track record today in winning the $64,000 New Orleans Handicap, Louisiana's richest stakes race, by a nose at the Fair Grounds.

CHAMPAIGN. Ill., March 6 (UPI) -- Wisconsin captured the Big Ten track championship today when the Badger one-mile relay team picked up enough points to nose out a surprising Michigan State bid for the title.
Two major industrial expositions and two conferences will bring some 30,000 executives and engineers to Cobo Hall in Detroit beginning tomorrow for separate four-day sessions.
PARIS, March 6 -- An Intensive and realistic review of the North Atlantic alliance's military-force goals is planned for this spring, qualified sources disclosed yesterday.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 6 The New York Mets, who were left at the post in their three previous seasons in the National League, faced another setback today as they headed toward the fourth: the weather.

ONE voice speaks in this odd narrative, a feminine voice, bemused and compulsively recollective, which recounts love gained, love lost, love found again. British-born Barbara Compton's protagonist begins by describing her romance in London and marriage in New York with a refugee German doctor.

Fears that the much-delayed Surveyor program might have been further pushed back by the explosion of the Atlas-Centaur launching vehicle last Tuesday at Cape Kennedy, Fla., appear to have been laid to rest.
BONN, March 6 -- West Germany's three major allies -- with the United States taking a vigorous lead -- are urging Bonn not to break diplomatic relations with the United Arab Republic.

Yeshiva University has redrawn its "blueprint for the '60's" to include a $5 million university library at its Washington Heights campus, a new midtown center for its women's college and a new graduate center on lower Fifth Avenue for its schools of education and social work.

CASA GRANDE, Ariz., March 6 -- Dennis the Menace no longer ranges the desert plain but the Giants' baseball training camp still is distinguished more by the presence of children and wives than the ball players aspiring to major league fame.
The Detroit Red Wings, with their sights set on first place in the National Hockey League, will be at Madison Square Garden tonight to face the Rangers. Game time is 7:30.
CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex., March 6 -- The South Texas Planned Parenthood Center here made plans this week to use Federal funds for the purchase and distribution of contraceptive devices.

The eight men and a girl arrested Friday in a plot to "take over the city" in a series of armed robberies were held on bail of $2,500 to $15,000 each yesterday in Criminal Court. A hearing was set for March 15.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- Secretary of State Dean Rusk implored the Atlantic alliance today to move toward new joint ventures in defense, diplomacy and economics. Warning against "traditional nationalism" and the "collapse of another postwar order," he urged those Western nations that are ready to cooperate to proceed on a series of projects now.
GUATEMALA, March 5 -- After nearly two years of boom, Guatemala will soon be told that austerity is the next order of business.

IN recent years, tourists in the South during early spring have seen snow on the azaleas and camellias, but the people of that region like to regard such circumstances as unusual. So, again this year, from the Rio Grande north to the Potomac, plans have been made to celebrate spring for the salubrious time of year it usually is.

Suppliers are backing up wholesalers and retailers for the longer spring and Easter selling season this year, particularly in soft-goods lines. They are doing it by expanding production and inventories necessary to support the increased retail sales which, on the department store level, have been running 14 per cent ahead of a year ago thus far in 1965.
Pacem in Terris, a modest encyclical promulgated by Pope John XXIII two months before his death, is emerging as one of the most significant features of the Pontiff's five-year reign.

The 70th annual meeting of the Society of Mayflower Descendants in the State of New York will be held on Tuesday in the society's headquarters at 122 East 58th Street.

The Union Carbide Corporation said last week that it spent $271.2 million last year on new construction in the United States, Canada and Puerto Rico. This was 50 per cent higher than in 1963 and represented the largest one-year outlay for new plants in the company's history.

GREENWICH, Conn., March 6 -- A team of five Indian Harbor Yacht Club frostbite dinghy skippers swept an interfleet match with winter sailors from American Yacht Club today, four races to none.

A YEAR ago, the magazine Bridge World instituted a Bridge Hall of Fame, which provides for the annual election of three of the game's greatest personalities. Ely Culbertson, Charles Goren and Harold S. Vanderbilt were the first to be elected.

Faubus, was hostess Wednesday to about 35 white and Negro leaders of the Little Rock area in a meeting at the Governor's Mansion for a briefing on a Federally assisted program to help pre-school children prepare for entering school next fall.

TAMPERE, Finland, March 7 (UPI) -- The Soviet Union took first place in the world ice hockey championship tonight by crushing East Germany, 8 -- 0, while Sweden was held to a 2-2 tie by Finland.

LOS ANGELES, March 9 (UPI) -- Jerry West hit on a 25-foot jump shot with 8 seconds to play tonight to give the Los Angeles Lakers a 106-104 National Basketball Association victory over the Cincinnati Royals.
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 7 -- As the New York Yankees went through their longest and most spirited workout of spring training, the quip quotient picked up, too.
LONDON, March 7 -- Prof. Fred Hoyle, one of Britain's leading astronomers and most popular scientists, is considering offers of positions in the United States.
Vice President Hubert H. Humphrey went through a hectic day here yesterday with characteristic aplomb and a ready handshake.
LONDON, March 7 -- The Bank of England, ending long-guarded secrecy, revealed today the extent of Britain's huge international borrowings during the sterling crisis last November and December.
SANTIAGO, Chile, March 7 -- The Christian Democratic party of President Eduardo Frei Montalva scored a decisive victory tonight in Chile's Congressional elections.
SYDNEY, Australia, March 7 -- The Labor party victory in yesterday's South Australian elections has brought to power a third state Labor government in Australia.
The Greystone Park Association, an auxiliary of the New Jersey State Hospital, will honor its past presidents at a luncheon April 1 at the Governor Morris Hotel in Morristown, N.J.

ARCADIA, Calif., March 7 (AP) -- Lucky Debonair and his jockey, Bill Shoemaker, who teamed to score an impressive victory yesterday in the Santa Anita Derby, apparently will join forces again in the Kentucky Derby on May 1.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, March 8 -- United States marines began landing this morning at the bay north of Danang to take up security duties around the large United States jet airfield there.

CAIRO, March 7 -- The visit of President Walter Uubricht of East Germany and the furor over Western arms for Israel have raised new fears in the West about the shift of President Gamal Abdel Nasser's Socialist regime to the East.
Pay-television was fully endorsed yesterday by the American Civil Liberties Union after having given the system only conditional approval since 1955.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 7 -- The arguments by President Habib Bourguiba of Tunisia in favor of moderation and reason in dealing with "the Jews" cast a pall of uneasiness over the hero's welcome he was given here today.
NEW HAVEN, March 7 -- The senior professors of the Yale philosophy department voted 5 to 2 this weekend to withdraw their support of Dr. Richard J. Bernstein in his tenure battle with the university.

New York enjoyed a 3 -- 0 lead over Detroit at one point last night at Madison Square Garden, but managed to drop a 6 -- 5 National Hockey League decision as the Red Wings came up with three third-period goals.
Union machinists reached agreement yesterday on a new contract with the American Can Company and the Continental Can Company that will give 13-cent-an-hour wage increases to 5,000 workers.

Maria Callas and Tito Gobbi will return to the Metropolitan Opera March 19 as Tosea and Scarpia in Puccini's "Tosca." Miss Callas has not sung with the company since March 5, 1958, when she also sang Tosea. Mr. Gobbi sang the role last season.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- The Federal Reserve Board published today a set of 14 guidelines for commercial banks under the new voluntary program aimed at reducing or limiting, foreign lending. The broader purpose of the program is to help the United States balance its international payments.
ST. LOUIS, March 7 (UPI) -- The St. Louis Hawks made it eight in a row over the New York Knicks tonight with a 132 -- 106 National Basketball Association victory.

Printers voted 1,978 to 28 yesterday to authorize a strike against seven New York City newspapers if a contract is not reached by March 30.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- Two Administration "must" bills -- health care for the aged and aid to schools -- will be in the spotlight as Congress moves into a busy week tomorrow.

The heads of 80 missions to the United Nations will attend the New York Philharmonic's Pension Fund benefit concert on March 29 in Philharmonic Hall.

Aluminium, Ltd., announced over the weekend that primary output by its worldwide subsidiaries and affilates reached one million tons in 1964, a record for the aluminum industry. WASHINGTON, March 7 -- Sargent Shriver will explain the nation's antipoverty program tomorrow to a joint session of the Arkansas State Legislature.
