Moore-McCormack Lines, Inc., announced yesterday elections and appointments of officers following the formation last month of Moore and McCormack Company, Inc., a holding company, to allow diversification. William T. Moore is chairman and president of both companies.
WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported tonight that Communist China's production of food and other farm products continued to lag behind population growth.
CHINCOTEAGUE, Va. -- In a short while Guglielmo G. De-Briganti will leave and this fishing village will have lost something it values.
MOSCOW, March 7 -- Vietcong infiltrators were said today to be among the South Vietnamese being trained by American instructors in the use of modern arms and military equipment.

Eighty-six students at St. John's University have scheduled a rally for today in support of the faculty's effort to win an independent voice in university affairs and of greater academic freedom for students.

Food Fair Stores, Inc., reported over the weekend that its net income in the nine months ended Feb. 6 dipped to $6,672,000, equal to 93 cents a common share, compared with $8,169,000, or $1.14 in the corresponding period a year earlier.

The 18-story luxury apartment building at 44 Gramercy Park North has been sold to an investing client of Douglas L. Elliman Co., for more than $1 million in cash.

American Airlines is participating in a new kind of corporate sponsorship to help present concerts by young people in three cities.

Douglas Moore's opera. "The Ballad of Baby Doe," which reappeared yesterday afternoon in the repertory of the New York City Opera at the City Center, seems to be holding its own. It had its premiere nine years ago, and the company has frequently given it since.

The Super VC-10, a new British jetliner, made its first trans-Atlantic flight yesterday. The airliner landed at Kennedy International Airport at 1:32 P.M. after a flight of 6 hours and 50 minutes that had followed a two-and-a-half-hour delay at London's fogbound airport.

The General Motors Corporation announced yesterday it would apply for listing of its common stock on the London Stock Exchange. It expects the listing to become effective later this month.

SELMA, March 7 -- The long line of Negroes walked slowly and silently to the main sidewalk of Selma's business district on this quiet Sunday. There were 525 of them, walking two abreast, and they were headed for a small concrete bridge at the end of the street.

The Legislature in West Virginia will meet today to complete a bill on the abolition of capital punishment. New York, Kentucky and Illinois are also considering such proposals, and Vermont and Indiana have begun work toward them.
The view that marital infidelity is now deeply rooted in the American cultural pattern was expounded over the weekend at a symposium on marriage sponsored by the Society of Medical Psychoanalysts.

An important voice to be heard on Wall Street starting today belongs to Robert Rew, a handsome electrical engineer with perfect diction. PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti -- Haiti, poorest of the Western Hemisphere nations, is facing a new downward turn in economic fortunes. Coffee is the country's main money earner on export markets, and in a good year 500,000 to 550,000 bags are sold.

THE New York master Paul Brandts, a former champion of the Manhattan Club, performed strongly in the recent First National Open Championship at Las Vegas. Tom McCarthy of the Gaelic-American Athletic Club successfully defended his Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union 30-kilometer championship and added an A.A.U. regional title as well yesterday.

The admission of Robert G. Rouse as a partner in the private banking firm of Laidlaw Co. was announced yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, March 8 -- Princeton, held at bay by Penn State's fine zone defense during much of the second half, came charging back to score an exciting 60-58 victory tonight in the first round of the National Collegiate basketball championship.

Maia Wojciechowska, a Polish-born woman who is an authority on bullfighting, and Beni Montresor, an Italian-born theatrical designer, won the two awards of the American Library Association yesterday for the most distinguished children's books published in the United States in 1964.

The Old Lady of Thread-needle Street -- formally known as the Bank of England -- has taken a close look at Britain's financial problems and sees one basic solution: The nation must divert more of her resources into exports if she is going to pay her current way, repay debts and rebuild reserves.

ARCADIA, Calif., March 8 (UPI) -- Real Good Deal, assuming the favorite's role after Native Diver and Doc Jocoy were scratched, galloped to a three-length victory today in the $27,750 San Bernardino Handicap, the feature of the Santa Anita Park program.

LONDON, March 8 -- The International Control Commission for Vietnam has urged Britain and the Soviet Union to issue "an immediate appeal" for measures to "stem the deteriorating situation" in the divided Southeast Asian country.

MERIDIAN, Miss., March 8 (AP) -- Attorneys for 17 men charged in the slaying of three civil rights workers today opposed attempts by the Justice Department to expedite a Supreme Court hearing on dismissal of the felony charge in the case.

BOWIE, Md., March 8 (AP) -- After two seconds and a pair of thirds at the meeting, William T. Moller's John V. finally crashed the winner's circle in the $6,000 Centerville Purse at Bowie today. He paid $6.20 for $2 to win.
The Belmont Stakes, the oldest and longest race in the Triple Crown series for 3-year-olds, has attracted 129 nominees for its 97th running at Aqueduct June 5, according to the list issued yesterday.
WMCA began a tongue-in-cheek campaign yesterday to make the radio station as popular with advertisers as it believes it is with teen-agers.

WASHINGTON, March 8 (AP) -- Senator Edward V. Long, Democrat of Missouri, announced tonight that he and Postmaster General John A. Gronouski had reached an amicable settlement of their dispute over mail covers.

PARIS, March 8 -- Andre Courreges, the designer who first opened a couture salon here in 1960 and was relatively ignored by Paris until his collection last month, is now under heavy intellectual inspection by the French.

A Brooklyn Supreme Court Justice threw up his hands yesterday when a patrolman testified that he did not arrest George Whitmore Jr. a few hours after a nurse was attacked even though Whitmore closely fit the description of the assailant.

NEWCASTLE, Wyo., March 8 (UPI) -- A Troy, N.Y., insurance man was reported working in a Wyoming ranch as a "regular cowboy" today, nearly five years after he was believed to have drowned in a reservoir.
Maurice Chevalier will be the guest of honor April 1 at a champagne reception at the French Consulate, 934 Fifth Avenue, after the premiere of his one-man show at the Alvin Theater.
Attention on the London Stock Exchange was drawn yesterday to gold-mining stocks, which showed price advances on a broad front in response to increased demand.
An agreement for exchanging productions has been worked out by Princeton University's McCarter Theater and the Great Lakes Shakespeare Festival of Lakewood, Ohio.

ALBANY, March 8 (AP) -- The University of Notre Dame asked the State Court of Appeals today to ban permanently distribution of the movie "John Goldfarb, Please Come Home." The university also sought to block further publication of the novel on which the film is based.
WASHINGTON, March 8 -- The House will open debate tomorrow on a bill to shut off the illicit traffic in the so-called pep pills, goof balls and similar stimulant and depressant drugs.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, March 8 (UPI) -- The police said tonight that a thumb print from the body found in a trunk in a suburban Montevideo villa matches the print in the passport of Herberts Cukurz, a former Nazi.
MINEOLA, L.I., March 8 -- Robert Moses doesn't believe it will be possible much longer for anyone to enjoy complete isolation 20 miles from New York City.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 8 -- The Secretary General, U Thant, has sent messages to some of the principal powers involved in the situation in Vietnam recommending a seven-power conference as a step toward ending the war there.
Wilt Chamberlain will make his final appearance at Madison Square Garden this season when the New York Knicks face the Philadelphia 76ers tonight.
WASHINGTON, March 8 -- The Supreme Court agreed today to review four cases raising important issues as to the scope of the Federal Power Commission's authority to regulate natural gas prices.
WASHINGTON, March 8 -- Following is the text of President Johnson's Message to Congress on Law Enforcement and Administration of Justice:

If you have never despaired of educational prose, you have not read much of "the professional literature" or listened to many academic convention speeches. Much of what you have missed will not hurt you. But chances are that some of the edicts issued by your child's school or some of the fine print in the college catalogue will be of sufficient importance to you to warrant a comprehensible translation.

WASHINGTON, March 8 (AP) -- Legislation designed to "bring some order into the time confusion that marks the change to and from daylight saving time each year" was introduced today by Senator Norris Cotton, Republican of New Hampshire.
MIAMI, March 8 (AP) -- Miami and Fort Lauderdale longshoremen unanimously voted down the new dock contract tonight and planned to walk off the job tomorrow morning.
MOSCOW, March 8 -- Soviet news and propaganda media struck a relatively mild note today in their criticism of the landing of United States Marines in South Vietnam.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 8 -- Iraq recalled her Ambassador from West Germany today in response to Bonn's decision to seek diplomatic relations with Israel.
DETROIT, March 8 (AP) -- Auto makers in the United States reported today they were off to a fast start in their bid to build a record-breaking 947,000 passenger cars this month.

" The Breath of Life," by Donald Carr, will be published by Norton on March 19. This is a study of air pollution. The author suggests that burning gasoline and low-grade heating oil are a principal cause of lung cancer and that these hazards can be eliminated.

A convicted murderer scheduled to go to the electric chair at Sing Sing on April 1 was granted a stay of execution yesterday by the United States Court of Appeals pending application to the United States Supreme Court for a review.
LONDON, March 8 -- The Government plans to set up a "full and impartial" inquiry into Britain's pharmaceutical industry and its relationship with the National Health Service.

The annual national intercollegiate indoor polo tournament will begin tonight at the Squadron A Armory, Madison Avenue and 94th Street, when the University of California plays Yale at 6:30 P.M. There will be no admission charge.

More than 95 per cent of the National Broadcasting Company's regularly scheduled evening programs -- all but two shows -- will be televised in color next season, the network announced yesterday. This season 70 per cent of the shows are in color.
Robert Glenn Thompson, a former Air Force enlisted man who pleaded not guilty on Jan. 7 to charges of having been a spy for the Soviet Union, changed his plea to guilty yesterday.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., March 8 (AP) -- Maj. Virgil I. Grissom and Lieut. Comdr. John W. Young conducted a countdown rehearsal today for America's first two-man space flight. If it had been the real thing, the shot would have been postponed.

TRENTON, March 8 -- Gov. Richard J. Hughes rejected today the latest Republican proposal for the reapportionment of the State Legislature under the "one man, one vote" mandate of the United States Supreme Court.
Civil rights groups were divided yesterday in their reactions to the city's proposed school integration plan.
TRENTON, March 8 -- Senate President Charles W. Sandman Jr. of Cape May County tonight re-entered the race for nomination as the Republican candidate for Governor on a no-new-tax platform.
LONDON, March 7 -- Emily Frankel's American dance drama company, now on its second British tour, made its London debut at the Lamda Theater tonight.
WASHINGTON, March 8 -- The treasury bill rate slipped back at today's auction from last Monday's level, the Treasury disclosed tonight.
GEORGETOWN, British Guiana, March 2 Each morning a crowd of Negroes gathers beside the Botanical Gardens here and gazes raptly at workmen hurrying in and out of a large, old-fashioned house.
The New York State Labor Relations Board ruled yesterday that an employer was not obligated to bargain with a union unless it demonstrated that it was a legitimate labor organization.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 8 -- The president of the American Bankers Association said today there was no doubt that some people had gained control of "a handful of banks" to line their own pockets.
There was a new twist yesterday in the increasingly heated battle over the organization of the city's taxi drivers.
Most major foreign currencies weakened in active transactions yesterday on foreign exchange markets here.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- Brig Gen. Frederick Joseph Karch, a marine officer who is described as "one of the new breed," has taken over as commander of the first American combat infantry forces to land in Vietnam.
WASHINGTON, March 8 -- President Johnson proposed today a long-range attack on the rising crime rate that includes a study in depth of its causes.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- Special tax-relief legislation, designed to induce foreigners to invest an additional $100 million to $200 million a year in United States securities, was proposed today by the Treasury Department.

CAIRO, March 8 -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser sharply attacked West Germany tonight but sidestepped an immediate showdown with Bonn over its declaration yesterday that it was seeking diplomatic relations with Israel.

AT intermission point in the Town Hall recital last night, a scroll of honor was presented by James J. O'Brien, Commissioner of Public Events, on behalf of Mayor Wagner, to Ormond J. Drake, associate dean of New York University and director of Town Hall.

PARIS, March 8 -- Another "Tosca" with Maria Callas has been added to the program at the Paris Opera to molify disappointed fans who broke windows and scuffled with each other here on Saturday, when booking for the guest series closed.
The Interstate Commerce Commission approved yesterday the Missouri Pacific Railroad's application to acquire control of the Chicago Eastern Illinois Railroad by a 10 to 1 vote.

The board of trustees of the University of Illinois sold yesterday $9.5 million of housing-revenue bonds to an underwriting syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., F.S. Smithers Co. and Goodbody Co.
BONN, March 8 -- The head of West Germany's central bank proposed today that international payments be made in a fixed gold-to-foreign exchange ratio in order to insure world liquidity.

Full-time enrollments in New York State's public and private institutions of higher education will increase between 43 and 50 per cent over the next six years the Board of Regents predicted yesterday.
Enough votes are available in both the Board of Estimate and the City Council to approve funds for a $5.05 million, three-tier garage under Madison Square Park.
The Federal Reserve Board reports below the following percentage changes in department store sales by cities. The figures, customarily reported in Sunday editions, had been delayed.

MIAMI, March 8 -- Slicing through 10-foot seas on a spinnaker run under full sailpower, the 72-foot ketch, Ticonderoga, led the 51-boat fleet in the Miami-to-Nassau race tonight around the first mark, 67 miles northeast of Miami.
About 3,000 men and women crowded manufacturers' showrooms in New York yesterday to look at, of all things, toys.
The story of Morris Block and his wife, Mollie, who left for the Soviet Union five years ago and returned disillusioned last June, came to a surprising end for them in court yesterday.
Prices of most stocks continued to advance on the American Stock Exchange yesterday in heavy trading.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), March 8 -- A special West German representative began talks here today with Israel's leaders on the possibility of establishing diplomatic relations between the two countries.

DIRGES are heard these days for Irwin Shaw's talent. Outstanding novelists must endure that inevitable ritual. They generally survive. I think Mr. Shaw will, when he gets out of his dinner jacket and back into his working clothes.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- After allowing for normal seasonal movements, consumer installment credit rose more sharply in January than in any other month on record, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
HOW to divide a one-room apartment into sleeping, conversation and dining areas without sacrificing a feeling of openness is a problem that faces 13 per cent of New York's inhabitants.

The United States quest for the Davis Cup it lost to Australia last September will begin in May with the invasion of Europe by a preliminary four-man team under the new captain, George R. MacCall of North Hollywood, Calif.
The Mayor's Temporary Commission on Narcotics Addiction named a 13-member executive group yesterday to expedite the fight against narcotics.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 8 -- A United States Embassy spokesman acknowledged today that Vietcong infiltrators among the South Vietnamese armed forces were probably being trained by American advisers in modern warfare.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 8 -- Alex Quaison-Sackey, President of the General Assembly, said today that he was "pained" by a recent protest from Nationalist China that it was not included in a 33-nation negotiating committee on peace-keeping operations.
DALLAS, March 8 (UPI) -- Judge Joe B. Brown today ordered a jury trial to rule on Jack L. Ruby's sanity, but touched off a squabble by assigning the condemned slayer an attorney he opposes.
The construction of an eternal light monument to President Kennedy at Grand Army Plaza in Brooklyn was approved yesterday by the Municipal Art Commission.
SCARSDALE, N.Y., March 8 -- The annual philanthropy-fund benefit dessert, bridge and fashion show of the Simmons College Alumnae Club of Westchester will be held at the Woman's Club here April 1.
Mr. and Mrs. Alan Jay Lerner settled their separation suits out of court yesterday after three days of bitter testimony in which each had charged the other with martial misconduct.
A measure to spur further use of export-installment credit through a guarantee to lending banks was announced yesterday by the Foreign Credit Insurance Association.
WASHINGTON, March 8 -- From England comes yet another study of man's relationship to his car. Many drivers, it says, are secretly in love with their automobiles.

The Radio Corporation of America announced yesterday the appointment of J.J. Brant and F.L. McClure as staff vice presidents. Mr. Brant, who will handle personnel administration, had served since 1956 as personnel director of the R.C.A. corporate staff.

GLASGOW, Scotland, March 8 (AP) -- Teams from the United States, Canada, Scotland, Sweden, Switzerland and Norway were involved today in the draw for the Scotch Curling Cup, the sport's unofficial world championship tournament at Perth, Scotland, March 15 to 18.

New York University will permit the American National Theater and Academy to continue its operation of the ANTA Washington Square Theater, 40 West 4th Street, at least until June of 1966. The new arrangement was verified yesterday by Dr. James M. Hester, president of the university, which donated the site.

NAIROBI, Kenya, March 8 (AP) -- International Red Cross sources reported today that they had word, still unconfirmed, that a missing Danish cameraman and an Indian were executed a month ago by Congolese rebels.
PARIS, March 8 -- Britain's participation in talks on European political unity was urged today by her new Ambassador to France, Sir Patrick Reilly.

BONN, March 8 -- Buoyed by solid domestic support of the offer to seek full diplomatic relations with Israel, Chancellor Erhard was described as fully prepared for the United Arab Republic to grant diplomatic recognition to Communist East Germany in response to Bonn's announcement on Israel.
LAWRENCE, Kan., March 8 (UPI) -- More than 100 students demonstrating against what they called racial discrimination in fraternities and sororities at the University of Kansas were arrested today.

Some of New York's top Republican leaders gathered in a party committal service a few days ago. The purpose was, presumably, to persuade a doubting public that they were really in earnest this year about electing a Mayor and defeating Mr. Wagner.
HAROLD WILLIS writes about the South and the racial passions that are tearing it apart with a viewpoint different from what the Northern theater is accustomed to.
The men who rule the Kremlin have in the last ten days suffered a series of humiliations of a magnitude without precedent in the history of world Communism.
CHICAGO, March 8 -- A defense motion for a directed verdict acquitting former Gov. William G. Stratton of income tax evasion was denied late today by Federal Judge Hubert L. Will.
WASHINGTON, March 8 -- The Supreme Court took the following actions today:
President Johnson's message to Congress on law enforcement and the administration of justice is thoughtful, restrained and open-minded.

The report of Martin-Marietta Corporation disclosed 1964 net earnings of $37,159,684, or $1.67 a share, compared with $34,639,586, or $1.54 a share, the year before. Sales fell to $774,196,694 from $974,183,637.
CASA GRANDE, Ariz., March 8--Evaluating the National League pennant contenders is a frustrating thing. There are so many of them, so well matched.
WASHINGTON, March 8 -- The value of world trade rose steeply again last year, the International Monetary Fund reported today.

CHICAGO March 8 (AP) -- An executive of the Chicago and North Western Railway testified today that elimination of duplicating facilities will be carried out promptly if the Interstate Commerce Commission approves a merger with the Chicago Great Western Railway.
Three aircraft producers reported yesterday increased earnings over the preceding year.

WASHINGTON, March 8 (UPI) -- The Supreme Court narrowed today the application of Federal antitrust laws which bar corporate officers in an interstate carrier from profiting from "substantial interests" in another company.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 8 -- United States marines dug in around Danang at dusk tonight to take up their task of defending the large United States airfield there. Unloading of their equipment continued despite heavy surf on the landing beaches north of the city.

WASHINGTON, March 8--The State Department altered the framework of United States diplomatic recognition of the republican Government of Yemen by opening the door today to the shipment of food to royalist forces there.

SUBIC BAY NAVAL BASE, the Philippines, March 8 (UPI) -- Two young United States marines were acquitted of charges of negligent homicide by a military court today after a trial arising from the shooting of a Filipino fisherman last Dec. 13.
WASHINGTON, March 8 (AP) The Senate passed and sent to President Johnson today a bill authorizing $750 million in additional United States subscriptions to the Inter-American Development Bank.
Negotiations with either Hanoi or Peking for a cease fire would be an exercise in futility unless carried out from a position of strength.

How much exposure of the female body may be permitted in a film under the terms of the motion-picture industry's self-administered morals code? The appeals board of the Motion Picture Association of America is expected to decide this question in New York sometime this week.

SCARCELY a week after the first Paris spring fashions landed at Kennedy Airport, Macy's showed its selections -- and a good many reproductions -- to the press yesterday. By Monday, customers will be able to try on and take home the newest couture copies, starting at $35 for a black and white checked dress by Pierre Cardin.

The smashing victory of President Frei's Christian Democratic party in the Congressional elections just held in Chile confirms the belief and hope that the country will really have what the President calls "a revolution in liberty." When Mr. Frei won the Presidency last September by the greatest plurality in Chile's history, doubts still remained about the extent to which a merely negative vote of conservatives against the extreme left contributed to the victory.
CHICAGO, March 8 (AP) -- Chicago, which has 7,300 industries and, like most big cities, an air-pollution problem, has signed an agreement with four major steel producers to help whisk its smog away.

Impact hammers continued yesterday to drive piles for an $80 million Federal office building near City Hall. But uptown the noise was nearly as loud as architects continued to fuss over exactly where the 41-story building should stand.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 8 -- Manager Johnny Keane of the New York Yankees listed his exhibition-game plans today and Mickey Mantle indicated a strong preference for continuing his career as a center fielder.
ALBANY, March 8 -- Governor Rockefeller said today that he would veto a pending measure that would allow students to use Regents scholarships at out-of-state colleges.

LEXINGTON, Ky., March 8 (AP) -- The Thoroughbred Club of America said today that it opposes off-track betting as proposed in New York on grounds it would do great harm to the thoroughbred racing industry.

WASHINGTON, March 8 (AP) -- A bill sent to Congress today would give Federal officers the authority to arrest and prosecute anyone involved in an assassination, kidnapping or assault on the President of the United States.
We regret both the request for the resignation of School Superintendent Calvin Gross and the manner in which it was handled.
WASHINGTON, March 8 -- The Supreme Court reversed itself today and refused jurisdiction over the complex legal and financial battle between Howard Hughes and Trans World Airlines.
PHILADELPHIA, March 8 (AP) -- "There were six men standing near one end of the subway platform. They just stood there. They didn't go to the girl's aid."

SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 8 -- The United States mission in Saigon is preparing an intensified program to win support from the Vietnamese people for the war against the Communists.

New York City pension funds sold yesterday $50,939,760 of short-maturity city bonds in the 10th sale since January, 1962, in a program to shift away from tax-exempt bonds into higher-yielding investments.

A $35 million issue of General Acceptance Corporation debentures, priced to yield 4.95 per cent, sold out quickly yesterday soon after it was offered by a group of investment bankers headed by Salomon Brothers a Hutzler.
The bond market flattened out yesterday.
JERSEY CITY, March 8 -- Four housewives were arrested this morning in protests over the removal of trees along the John F. Kennedy Memorial Boulevard.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., March 8 -- A union demanded today that Governor Rockefeller remove Sheriff John E. Hoy of Westchester from office for allegedly permitting police brutality at a sit-down demonstration by strike supporters at Lawrence Hospital last Saturday.
Strong demand for copper sent futures prices up as much as 2.5 cents a pound here yesterday. Trading on the Commodity Exchange was moderately active at 527 lots of 50,000 pounds each.

LUBBOCK, Tex., March 8 (AP) -- Houston beat Notre Dame, 99 -- 98, in overtime tonight to advance to the National Collegiate Athletic Association regional basketball tournament as Ed Winch sank two free throws with six seconds remaining.

Hundreds of representatives of religious, medical and civil rights groups and other concerned persons were on their way to Alabama last night to walk with the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. from Selma to Montgomery.
The use of force against Negro marchers Sunday by the police and possemen of Selma, Ala., drew protests yesterday in many parts of the country.
OTTAWA, March 8 -- The soup cans and soap boxes of Andy Warhol, the New York pop artist, are not deemed "original sculpture" in Canada.
Fourteen leading businessmen have been appointed to an organizing committee to establish a business development corporation for New York City.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 8 -- Henry R. Labouisse, American Ambassador to Greece since 1962, has been named executive director of the United Nations Children's Fund. He succeeds Maurice Pate, who died Jan. 19. Mr. Pate headed the aid agency for 18 years.

The defense in the murder trial of Alvin L. Mitchell completed its case in Queens Supreme Court yesterday with a series of sharp exchanges between defense and prosecution and a threat from the bench to hold Herbert A. Lyon, Mitchell's lawyer, in contempt.
ALBANY, March 8 -- The Legislature today approved Governor Rockefeller's $5 million plan to keep the New Haven Railroad alive.
The appointment of Allen H. Douglas as vice president in charge of industrial development for the Southern Railway was announced yesterday by D.W. Brosnan, president.

TAMPERE, Finland, March 8 (AP) -- Canada, led by Al Johnson's three goals, handed the United States team its third straight setbacks, 5 -- 2, today and tied the Soviet Union and Czechoslovakia for first place in the world amateur hockey tournament.

NEW HAVEN, March 8 -- Kingman Brewster Jr., president of Yale University, refused today to interfere in a heated campus controversy involving the refusal of tenure to a popular young associate professor of philosophy.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 8--Gov. George C. Wallace denied today that Alabama state troopers and sheriff's deputies had used unnecessary force in routing Negro marchers at Selma yesterday.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 8 (AP) -- Ohio State, behind the 32-point scoring of Dick Ricketts, posted a 93-85 basketball upset of top-ranked Michigan, the Big Ten champion, tonight.
Cumberland Hospital acknowledged yesterday that a misinterpretation of X-rays led an emergency-room physician to send a patient home, where he died several hours later.
HARLAN, Ky., March 8 (AP) -- A 13-year-old boy died and two of his cousins were feared buried beneath tons of rock tonight in an abandoned mine near here.

WASHINGTON, March 8 (AP) -- The Government announced today that a "significant technological advancement," applicable to some of the peacetime uses of atomic energy, had been achieved in a production reactor ordinarily employed to make explosives for atomic bombs and hydrogen bombs.
Justice Frankfurter may well have smiled when anyone recognized Thompson's "Hound of Heaven" as the source of "with all deliberate speed."
A nationwide chain of franchised nursing homes is being actively planned by Kemmons Wilson, chairman, and Wallace E. Johnson, president of Holiday Inns of America, Inc.
WASHINGTON, March 8 President Johnson trebled today the funds for a program to help deprived preschool children this summer.
SELMA, Ala., March 8 -- The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. returned to Selma tonight to lead a second attempt to protest for Negro voting rights with a march to the state capital.

Police Department reports indicate that only 3.6 per cent of all property stolen here last year -- excluding automobiles -- was recovered. The rate of recovery has gone down from 9.8 per cent a decade ago.

Jan DeGaetani, mezzo-soprano, sang last night at Carnegie Recital Hall. She has a reasonably sized, pure voice that floated calmly over the audience throughout her recital without much change in color or quality.

THE crisis in Vietnam was the subject last night of a constructive debate on the network of the Columbia Broadcasting System. It was the first major use of television in prime evening time to acquaint the mass audience with the agonizing alternatives that may lie ahead in Southeast Asia.

In giving its editorial support to the pickets at Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville ("The Bronxville Strike," March 5) The Times, in effect, is advising its readers that ends justify means after all. Ostensibly the desired end in any union organizing effort is a fair wage scale and decent working conditions.
A Connecticut law banning the use of contraceptives was challenged today by the American Civil Liberties Union in a brief filed with the Supreme Court.

The chairman of President Johnson's Council of Economic Advisers said yesterday that the "unprecedented duration and strength" of the nation's economic boom was the result of public and private fiscal policies that had created a favorable climate for expansion.
THE haute couture chose to snub curly hair during the Paris showings this year, but the haute coiffure is striking back.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 8 -- Joe Christopher flew into town today with his outfielder's mitt but with his contract still unsigned and threatened to become the New York Mets' biggest financial headache of the season.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- Senate hearings indicated today that the survival of helicopter passenger airlines in New York, Los Angeles and Chicago may depend largely on greater financial help from these cities and the major airlines.

YONKERS, March 8 -- When the author of the early odds line at Yonkers Raceway sent out his listings today, for Thursday night's qualifying races in the fourth annual Adios Festival Pacing Series, the standardbreds trained by Stanley Dancer were held in the highest esteem.

SANTIAGO, Chile, March 8 -- Leaders of the Christian Democratic party were jubilant today over their sweeping election victory, which exceeded their most optimistic estimates.

Students at St. John's University booed the name of the Very Rev. Edward J. Burke, president of the university, yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 8 (AP) -- The Baltimore Bullets moved within a game of clinching at least a tie for third place in the National Basketball Association's Western Division with a 111-102 victory over the San Francisco Warriors tonight.
The effect of recent increases in savings deposit interest rates fat commercial banks showed up yesterday in reports on the thrift industry.

BRAZZAVILLE, Congo Republic, March 5 -- The youths came about 20 minutes after midnight. They wore khaki shorts and Chinese peaked caps with a red star on a black shield. Most were armed with wooden staves and empty quart-size beer bottles.
A TEN-DAY Sportsman's Carnival featuring artisans and personalities involved with sporting goods will be held at Abercrombie Fitch on Madison Avenue beginning tomorrow.
Duke Ellington, Leonard Bernstein, Darius Milhaud and Aaron Copland will conduct their own works during the New York Philharmonic's French-American Festival at Philharmonic Hall July 14 through 31.
PARIS, March 9 -- Premier Georges Pompidou promised tonight that the de Gaulle Government, with "action as its sole policy," would build a new and greater France.
Copper futures prices bounded forward again here yesterday in heavy trading.
Saul Bellow, Louis Fischer and Eleanor Clark received National Book Awards yesterday as authors of "the most distinguished books written by Americans and published in the United States in 1964."
SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 9 -- Government forces achieved a major victory yesterday in the repulse of a Vietcong assault on a Special Forces camp 270 miles northeast of Saigon.

Yale Express Systems, Inc., was reported yesterday to be involved in "very serious negotiations" for refinancing. Those taking part were identified as its senior creditors, First National City Bank, the Marine Midland Trust Company of New York and the Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance Company.

The Lunt-Fontanne Theater, 205 West 46th Street, near Broadway, has been sold by Cy Feuer and Ernest Martin to Max Stahl and his son, Stanley, who are active in the real estate field. The current tenant there is "Ben Franklin in Paris."

BOWLING GREEN, Ky., March 9 (UPI) De Paul defeated Eastern Kentucky, 99 -- 52, and Dayton downed Ohio University, 66 -- 65, tonight in the Mideast preliminary playoffs of the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tourney.

NEW DELHI, March 9 -- Prime Minister Lal Bahadur Shastri will visit Moscow as well as Washington this spring in an effort to improve his own stature and that of his country as the principal spokesman for the nonaligned nations.
THE HAGUE, March 9 -- The Dutch Court will announce tomorrow or Thursday the engagement of 22-year-old Princess Margriet, the third daughter of Queen Juliana and Prince Bernhard.
CATHOLICISM at the crossroads of liberal and conservative thought was taken up last night on the National Broadcasting Company's documentary, "The Pope and the Vatican."
Replacements for the "ghost patrol" became available to the city yesterday in the effort to stop assaults against taxicab drivers.
WASHINGTON, March 9 -- A program to invigorate the lagging economy of Appalachia became law today in the sunny Rose Garden of the White House.
The Chicago Black Hawks will face the New York Rangers at Madison Square Garden tonight. Game time is 7:30 P.M.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- The major airlines opposed today a suggestion that they increase their support for the helicopter airlines in New York, Los Angeles and Chicago that are facing the loss of Federal subsidies.
Justice Edward Thompson of the Queens Supreme Court ruled out yesterday the dying statements of Barbara Kralik in the first-degree murder trial of Alvin L. Mitchell.

WEST HEMPSTEAD, L.I., March 9 -- In more than an hour of stormy debate, stockholders of the Meadow Brook National Bank expressed anger today with an offer by the C.I.T. Financial Corporation to buy the bank.
Rates on major currencies continued to ease yesterday in foreign exchange markets here in apparent reflection of the tightening supply of United States dollars abroad.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 9 (AP) -- Attorney General Nicholas de B. Katzenbach said tonight in a telephone interview with radio station WCTC that it would be difficult to prove criminal conduct by law enforcement officers who halted Sunday's civil rights march in Selma, Ala.
Political leaders, legislators and religious leaders from across the country condemned yesterday the actions of Alabama authorities in suppressing Negro voter-registration protests in Selma, Ala.
LONDON, March 9 -- Leaders of all parties joined today in a move to take the racial issue out of British politics.
SELMA, Ala., March 9 -- The peaceful confrontation between 1,500 civil rights marchers and state troopers on U.S. 80 today was worked out in advance with the Federal Government as mediator.

Mayor Wagner proposed last night that a panel of "public-spirited citizens" be appointed to intervene in the campaign to organize New York's taxicab drivers into a new union.

A well-rounded Yale team, directed by Alan L. Corey 3d, moved into the final round of the national intercollegiate indoor polo championship tournament last night at the Squadron A Armory by defeating the University of California, 17 -- 3.
Students at Brooklyn College protested yesterday the dismissal of a music professor because he did not perform, conduct, compose or engage in musical research.

" IT'S going to be another Fifth Avenue," predicted Samuel J. Lefrak. Mr. Lefrak, an energetic builder and college track star who hasn't slowed down or lost his optimism, pointed across 10 lanes of fast-moving traffic in the general direction of a one-story taxpayer, whose tenants include "Bo Bowl, Ch inese Food to Take Out."
After two weeks of steady gains, prices of most issues on the American Stock Exchange declined yesterday in active trading.
NEW HAVEN, March 9 -- The Yale Law School Association's highest award, the Citation of Merit, will be presented at the university May 1 to Dean Eugene V. Rostow of the Yale Law School.

LONDON, March 9 -- Rubin (Hurricane) Carter, the Patterson, (N.J.) middleweight with a fiery reputation in and out of the ring, didn't make many new friends at the Royal Albert Hall tonight when he stopped Harry Scott of Britain after 1 minute 15 seconds of the ninth round.

SELMA, Ala., March 9 -- The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. led 1,500 Negroes and whites on a second attempted protest march today. State troopers turned them back on the outskirts of Selma, after they had gone one mile.

New mystery was injected into the tangled affairs of the law and George Whitmore Jr. yesterday in Brooklyn Supreme Court.
LONDON, March 9 -- Imperial Chemical Industries, Britain's largest industrial company, said today it hoped to increase its already substantial trade with Communist China.
Hunt Foods and Industries, Inc., announced yesterday the election of Harding L. Lawrence 44 years old, as a director.

The battle to save Storm King Mountain has been lost. By a vote of 3 to 1, the Federal Power Commission has granted a license to the Consolidated Edison Company to build the world's largest pumped storage hydroelectric project there, with a powerhouse gouged out of the base of the mountain and a huge reservoir created at its top.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, March 10 -- The Soviet-sponsored conference of 19 Communist parties that met here last week failed to produce any plan of action that might prevent further fragmentation of the international Communist movement.

Music by Israeli composers will be heard on the Composers Showcase concert at Philharmonic Hall tonight at 8:30. Charles Munch and Julius Rudel will conduct members of the American Symphony Orchestra and the Masterwork Chorus, with Jennie Tourel and Janice Harsanyi, sopranos; Jan Peerce, tenor: Joseph Tal and Eugene Istomin, pianists; Odeon Partos, violist and Paul Price, percussionist as soloists.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 9 -- An 11-nation committee issued a declaration today expressing "concern and indignation" that the South African Government was arresting opponents of its race segregation policies.
Price movements failed to develop any trend yesterday in quiet trading on the London Stock Exchange.
The Board of Education has directed Dr. Bernard E. Donovan, the Acting Superintendent, to proceed immediately with drafting plans for decentralizing the school systeem.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., March 9 (UPI) -- The Birmingham Post-Herald editorially urged today that Gov. George C. Wallace give Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and his followers police protection during their protest march from Selma to Montgomery because they "thrive on violence."
It will take "a miracle" to get Bold Lad ready in time for the Kentucky Derby, one of the colt's handlers said yesterday.

TIMMINS, Ont., March 9 (AP) -- Mines Minister George Wardrope put in an unexpected appearance today at the Royal Commission hearings on Windfall Oils and Mines, Ltd., to deny that he made $100,000 trading in Windfall stocks.

PARIS -- Before departing for Vietnam it is worth examining France's position on the crisis, a position founded on cold analysis even though we don't accept its tenets or conclusions. The essence of this French analysis is that China will never admit an American military presence on the Asian mainland.
MOSCOW, March 9 -- The Soviet Union disclosed today that it had widened sentencing powers of its six-year-old citizens' courts in an effort to combat petty thefts of Government property.

A $341 million block of General Aniline and Film Corporation common stock, the largest asset seized by the Government as enemy property during World War II, was sold out quickly to the public yesterday.
YAPHANK, L.I., March 9 -- Suffolk County Democrats surged ahead of Republicans in new voter enrollment for the first time last year, according to figures released today by the Board of Elections.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 9 -- A New York banker asserted today that bank customers had been "bamboozled for the last 50 years" in one phase of commercial account operations.
Art, as a part of liberal education, is still "essentially a spectator sport," Dr. James A. Perkins, president of Cornell University, said here last night.

SALT LAKE CITY, March 9 (AP) -- Roy Jefferson, Negro football star, led a group of civil rights advocates to the world headquarters of the Mormon Church today to protest what they called racial injustice in Utah.

SANTIAGO, Chile, March 9 -- President Eduardo Frei Montalva, strengthened by a landslide victory in Sunday's Congressional election, will make another attempt shortly to obtain quick action on vital copper legislation.
HUE, South Vietnam, March 5 -- "To end this war we must get political stability and find a government that has popular support, whether the Americans like it or not," the young man said.

Those few fans who thought it worth while to go to Madison Square Garden last night and watch the Knickerbockers play the Philadelphia 76ers were a special sort of treat for their pains-an overtime thriller that the Knicks won.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- Secretary of State Dean Rusk told Congress today that "it would be dangerous for our security and tragic for the future of the world" if the United States discontinued or substantially reduced its foreign-aid program.

The General Tire and Rubber Company, in its third acquisition move in as many months, is planning to enter the home electronics business in Canada it was reported yesterday, through the purchase of a controlling interest in the Fleetwood Corporation.

WINNIPEG, March 9 (Canadian Press) -- Eight North American groups concerned with real estate appraisals linked to mortgage loans outlined a code for the industry today to combat forgeries and pressures that result in inflated estimates of realty values.

THE fast, new Ferrari 830 that blew a tire and finally retired with a broken suspension part from the recent 2,000-kilometer Continental at Daytona Beach most likely will appear in the 12-hour race at Sebring, Fla., March 27 under a different sponsor.

The Government has filed liens totaling $14 million in its first major action to enforce payment of interest-equalization taxes, the Internal Revenue Service announced yesterday. Three individuals and four corporations were named.

In a world where mass murder by the megaton is all too terribly possible, "The Semi-Artificial Man" offers inspiring evidence that there also is a pioneer, if minuscule, vanguard who should be dead but are wondrously alive, thanks to researchers, physicians and surgeons dedicated to the replacement or transplantation of organs and tissues.

For the fourth time within a year, directors of the Bucyrus-Erie Company have increased the quarterly dividend. The latest declaration calls for 50 cents a common share payable April 5 to holders of March 19.

DURBAN, South Africa, March 9 (Reuters) -- British and South African police tonight recovered all 20 gold bars, valued at $280,000, that were reported missing from the liner Capetown Castle over a month ago.
WASHINGTON, March 9 -- The White House said today that President Johnson expected to hold a news conference "in the next two or three days."

Sheed and Ward is preparing a book that will emphasize the role of American bishops in the Ecumenical Council Vatican II. Called "Decrees and American Interventions of the Second Vatican Council," it will contain some unpublished oral and written statements made by the American bishops in the Council's debates as well as texts of decrees promulgated by the Pope.
Your news report of March 2 accurately characterizes "the law-of-the-jungle" atmosphere prevailing in Haiti.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- Plant and equipment investment by United States industry is expected to rise 12 per cent this year to $50.2 billion, the Department of Commerce and Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.
THE following dinner menu is given as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A recipe is offered for an easy-to-prepare main dish.
IF you're willing to sit through the thin plot and the thinner laughs, "Catch Me If You Can" will reward you in the final 15 minutes as a murder mystery should.
ANKARA, Turkey, March 9 -- The new Foreign Minister, Hasan Isik, said today that Turkey could apply to countries outside Western Europe for assistance, "and the Soviet Union could be one of these."
HALLANDALE, Fla., March 9 (AP) -- Barry Pearl, an apprentice, rode four winners at Gulfstream Park today with the odds ranging from 5-2 to 12-1.
SANTA MONICA, Calif., March 9 (AP) -- Manager Charlie Dressen of the Detroit Tigers has suffered a minor heart attack and will be hospitalized for about three weeks.

The New York City Opera will make its first trip to the West Coast when it appears at Stanford University's 1965 Summer Festival of the Arts in Palo Alto, Calif. The farthest west the company has been is St. Louis, visited in 1960.
A number of philosophers believe that a fundamental tension between divergent approaches to philosophy underlies academic disputes such as the current tenure battle at Yale.

CLEARWATER, Fla., March 9 -- Gene Mauch slammed shut the door on the past during the winter baseball meetings in Houston last December, and no amount of coaxing can get the fiery manager of the Phillies to reopen it.

BERKELEY, Calif., March 9 -- Clark Kerr announced today his intention to resign as president of the University of California. Martin Meyerson announced that he would resign as acting chancellor of the Berkeley campus.
WASHINGTON, March 9 (UPI) -- Following is the text of President Johnson's statement on the racial violence in Selma, Ala.:
BONN, March 9 -- Prime Minister Harold Wilson of Britain ended today a four-day visit to West Germany that was friendly but without much concrete achievement.

A Bronx County Bar Association report, made public yesterday, charged that "mass assembly-line justice" was rushing defendants into pleas of guilty and into convictions, in violation of their legal rights.
LONDON, March 9 -- Prime Minister Harold Wilson said today that if Communist attacks stopped in Vietnam, "then talks in some form should be started."
Tiffany Co., the Fifth-Avenue-based chain of jewelry stores reported yesterday substantially increased sales and earnings for 1964.
VIENNA, March 9 -- The conservative Peoples party nominated former Federal Chancellor Alfons Gorbach today for the Presidency of Austria. The election has been set for May 23.

MOSCOW, March 9 -- The Soviet Union is completing the construction of a plant for the production of titanium and magnesium, two key metals of the nuclear and space age, in the virtual heart of Asia. The plant, which has been under construction since the late nineteen-fifties, produced its first magnesium and titanium metal within last two weeks, according to Soviet press reports.
About 3,500 viewers contributed almost $40,000 to WNDT (Channel 13) as the result of a special fund-raising program televised last Wednesday by the educational station.

MANILA, March 9 (AP) -- The United States Ambassador to Indonesia said today that the Jakarta Government seemed to want an income-sharing agreement with American rubber companies similar to one it reached in 1963 with foreign oil companies.

YONKERS, March 9 -- Del Insko, the leading driver at Yonkers Raceway, snapped a 15-race losing streak tonight when he guided home Screwball in the feature one-mile invitation pace. The South Beloit, Ill., reinsman had not finished first since he triumphed with Sweet Shilah last Wednesday night.
DETROIT, March 9 -- Governor Romney and Mayor Jerome P. Cavanagh led thousands of persons today in a 10-block march through downtown Detroit to protest events in Selma, Ala.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 9 -- Following the text of an order signed here today by Federal District Judge Frank M. Johnson Jr.:

SCARSDALE, N.Y., March 9 -- The Scarsdale Board of Education announced today that Dr. Donald G. Emery, Superintendent of Schools in Shaker Heights, Ohio, had accepted appointment as Superintendent here.

The International Toy and Trade Fair, which is being held this week at the New York Hilton Hotel, seems to be giving as much emphasis this year to trade as it normally gives to toys. Products on display range from Christmas decorations and sporting goods to transistor radios and artificial flowers.
The New York Chapter of the American Red Cross will receive the proceeds of a cocktail dance to be held next Tuesday at Ondine, a discotheque at 308 East 59th Street.

DETROIT, March 9 (UPI) -- Alex Delvecchio scored twice, including the winning goal in the final five seconds, and Gordie Howe made three assists as the Detroit Red Wings beat the Montreal Canadiens, 3-2, tonight and took first place in the National Hockey League.
LEOPOLDVILLE, The Congo, March 9 (AP) -- The Congolese Army imposed a blackout today on the news from the northeastern war zone after one of its battalions there announced it would refuse to fight.

A COLLECTION of pretty, well-dressed women came to Lord Taylor Monday evening to view another handsome collection -- the spring and summer designs of Manuel Pertegaz, the Spaniard who is the store's favorite couturier. (Lord Taylor has his clothes exclusively in New York.)

The Appalachia program, which President Johnson signed into law yesterday, is a significant forward step; but the passage of this law must not obscure the plight of certain forgotten people whom the program will not help.
Although the Pure Oil Company has found a corporation to merge with, some stockholders are insisting that the marriage dowry should be improved.
An arbitrator awarded 4,000 garage workers in 652 Manhattan and Bronx garages a $9 weekly package increase yesterday. The decision to accept binding arbitration averted a strike set for Jan. 27.
WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP) -- Administrators of college student loans in the Washington area asked Congress today for the right to take court action against students delinquent in their payments.
PRINCETON, N.J., March 9 -- Governors Rockefeller of New York and Richard J. Hughes of New Jersey reached agreement today on a tristate transportation planning agency.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- The Federal Power Commission today granted the Consolidated Edison Company a license to build the world's largest pumped-storage hydroelectric power plant on the banks of the Hudson River near Cornwall.

PEKING, March 9 -- The Lu Ku Chao commune is just outside Peking, near what used to be called the Marco Polo Bridge. Its land is fully used, mainly for vegetables. But it has piggeries and young orchards as well.
Thousands of Negroes and whites demonstrated in major cities yesterday to show their sympathy with Negroes whose voter registration march in Selma, Ala., was broken up by the Alabama police Sunday.
The clouds of uncertainty that have recently been hanging over the municipal bond market appeared to be lifting yesterday, making for a better climate for new bond offerings.
DURHAM, N.C., March 9 -- The trustees of Duke University announced today a 10-year, $187-million expansion and improvement program.
The stock market fell slightly yesterday in moderate trading.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- The Western alliance is now in deep trouble. It is divided on China, Vietnam, Germany, Africa, nuclear policy, economic policy, monetary, policy -- on almost every major issue of world politics today -- and it is not even consulting much together, let alone acting together, on its common problems.
ALBANY, March 9 -- State Controller Arthur Levitt advocated today increases in three existing taxes that he said would do away with any need for Governor Rockefeller's proposed statewide sales tax.

CHICAGO, March 9 -- Cities and industries on the south end of Lake Michigan were given an antipollution timetable today: They were ordered to stop contamination of the lake within one year and to curb the danger from pollutants within six months. Otherwise, they were told, they face the threat of legal action.
A joint effort by three prominent school groups to seek $290.8 million more for the New York City public schools was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- The United States has told U Thant, the Secretary General of the United Nations, that it cannot accept his or any other invitation to a conference on Vietnam until North Vietnam indicates a readiness to halt its "aggression."
The words were hardly out of Secretary General Thant's mouth when the United States rejected his proposal. He had recommended a seven-power conference on the Vietnamese conflict.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, March 9 (UPI) -- The police said today that an Israeli Government employe was involved in the slaying here of Herbert Albert Cukurs, a Latvian-born former Nazi wanted for alleged war crimes.
WASHINGTON, March 9 -- A 23-year-old multimillion-dollar legal conflict ended today with a ceremony in the office of the Attorney General of the United States, whose mind was 800 miles away.
" There it is! Blyth got it!" At exactly 10:45 A.M. yesterday, this shout erupted in the trading room of Greene Co., a firm dealing in over-the-counter stocks at 37 Wall Street.

WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP) -- A study conducted for the Association of Local Transport Airlines reported yesterday that loss of trunk airline service in some cities had resulted in even better service from local airlines.
The Appellate Division unanimously reversed yesterday the first-degree murder conviction of a man because he had not been permitted to see his family before confessing to the police.

Record sales, the reduced Federal tax rate and additional earning power from capital programs enabled the International Paper Company to lift 1964 profits 17 per cent above the previous year, the company report disclosed yesterday.
ROME, March 9 -- Britain reaffirmed today her desire to join a "common European market" eventually provided that her "essential" Commonwealth and other special interests were safeguarded.

LAWRENCE, Kan., March 9 -- Two days of student demonstrations against alleged racial discrimination at the University of Kansas ended tonight when Chancellor W. Clarke Wescoe yielded to demands to reinstate 110 students suspended yesterday.
HOLLYWOOD, March 9 (UPI) -- Patricia Neal, who was near death after suffering two strokes on Feb. 17, has improved and is no longer in critical condition, her doctor reported today.

NASSAU, Bahamas, March 9 -- The domination of the 184-mile Miami-to-Nassau yacht race by Florida's West Coast sailors continued today as Joe Byars of Tampa skippered Doubloon to a victory in a record 51-boat fleet.

ONE of the odd things about fiction is that a novel doesn't necessarily have to be good to be fun. A novelist can be slipshod in his prose, indifferent to the art of characterization and overly fond of implausible melodramatics and still write a book worth reading. It sounds impossible; but it isn't.

There was joy yesterday in the little village of Cornwall-on-Hudson over the Federal Power Commission's decision to allow the Consolidated Edison Company to build a hydroelectric project at Storm King Mountain.
Deputy Mayors Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. and John V. Connorton received salary increases from $30,000 to $37,500 a year yesterday.

Most bond dealers spent most of yesterday watching the proceedings in the 11.1 million share common stock offering of General Aniline and Film Corporate. The result was that little business was done in either the Government or corporate market.

Twelve religious leaders called yesterday for an end to the peacetime draft, while acclaiming the United States Supreme Court's decision Monday favoring a broad interpretation in the exemption of religious objectors from combat training and service.

WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP) -- Gen. William C. Westmoreland, commander of United States forces in South Vietnam, has insisted in a report that American fighting men there "are getting adequate equipment."

NAIROBI, Kenya, March 9 -- The Organization of African Unity has postponed further discussion of the Congo problem.

ONE of Joseph Charles Swidler's friends said of him yesterday, "He's quite accustomed to controversy, so this one's not likely to bother him much."
CAIRO, March 9 -- Pressures mounted among Arab states today for concerted and sharp retaliation against West Germany for its decision to seek diplomatic relations with Israel.
TAMPERE, Finland, March 9 (UPI) -- East Germany rallied to defeat the United States, 7 -- 4, today in the world ice hockey tournament.
About 800 persons held an animated but orderly march along Fifth Avenue yesterday to protest the use of police force against Negro marchers Sunday in Selma, Ala.
PITTSBURGH, March 9 (UPI) -- Steel contract negotiations resumed today after a two-month recess and struck a sour note right at the start.
An economist said yesterday that the current decline in housing construction starts was basically the result of "plain and simple" over building of apartment houses.
ALBANY, March 9 -- Two key bills in Governor Rockefeller's traffic-safety program were virtually killed today by a coalition of Republicans and Democrats in the Senate.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- President Johnson and his representatives successfully urged the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. today not to carry out a protest march from Selma, Ala., to Montgomery, the state capital.

BERLIN, March 9 -- The Western Allies have asserted their sovereign rights in West Berlin and their ultimate responsibility for the city's security in talks with Mayor Willy Brandt and other officials over the case of a local security officer.

WASHINGTON, March 9 (UPI) -- The sponsor of a bill to impose stiff Federal controls on "pep pills" and "goof balls" said today football players from local high schools used such drugs during recent games.

TRIVANDRUM, India, March 9 -- Conservative parties in the politically upset state of Kerala have begun to rally their forces to meet the threat of the pro-Peking Communists, who elected 40 candidates, the largest single party bloc, to the State Legislature last Thursday.

The Westinghouse Electric Corporation raised prices yesterday for some substation and power transformers. The increase of 5 per cent was ascribed to added labor and material costs and to an attempt to provide for future needs of the industry.
Negotiations between the printers and seven of the newspapers here will be resumed tomorrow in an effort to lay the basis for a contract agreement before the March 30 expiration of current contracts.
WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP) -- Crime in United States suburbs rose 18 per cent last year. J. Edgar Hoover, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, said today.

THE biggest bridge game in the world will be held on Friday. It is the American Contract Bridge League's Nationwide Charity Game, which will be played in some 230 centers in addition to the focal game in Cleveland, where it acts as the curtain-raiser to the Spring National Championships.
The Midland-Ross Corporation, a widely diversified manufacturing concern based in Cleveland, announced yesterday the election of David E. Walbert as president.
Four bakeries were fined $50 each by the Department of Markets yesterday as a result of complaints about short-weight loaves.

THE third of Lukas Foss's "Evenings for New Music" was given at Carnegie Recital Hall last night, and it proved to be one that kept the imagination stretched, sometimes taut and to a purpose, sometimes thin.

SAIGON, Wednesday, March 10 (AP) -- One United States Marine Corps officer adviser was killed and another was wounded late yesterday in a clash with a Vietcong force about 285 miles northeast of Saigon.

TOKYO, Wednesday, March 10 -- An invited audience, including Emperior Hirohito, Premier Eisaku Sato and top Government leaders, will attend today a preview of the Olympic Games movie, which is expected to break box-office records here.
Plans were disclosed yesterday for a drive to combat traffic congestion on the waterfront, including a possible pier pick-up and delivery appointment system.
ALBANY, March 9 -- The Democrats plan to introduce a bill in the Legislature this week to increase the number of City Council districts in New York City from 25 to 27.
WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP) -- Government policemen waded into a crowd of singing, chanting demonstrators and hauled them bodily away tonight from the office of Attorney General Katzenbach.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 9 -- Evidence collected here indicates that both North and South Vietnamese Communists have become aware that talk of proposed peace negotiations could undermine the spirit of the Vietcong.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 9 -- Gov. George C. Wallace denied today that he or top officials of the Alabama Highway Patrol had "made a deal" to avoid another violent confrontation between state troopers and Negro marchers at Selma.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- The State Department said today that its approval in principle of surplus food shipments to royalist-held territory in Yemen did not signify any change in the United States' diplomatic recognition of the republican Government in that Arab country.

More than 2,300 urgent calls for police aid or ambulances are being delayed every day because the public is forgetting the special number, Police Commissioner Michael J. Murphy said yesterday.
The Oklahoma Gas Electric Company's $25 million first-mortgage bonds were won yesterday by an underwriting group headed by the Equitable Securities Corporation.

SELMA, Ala., March 9 -- There were young blondes in polo coats and hipsters with beards, and the wives of Senators; there were white faces and black faces, ministers' collars and turtlenecked sweaters.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 9 -- One of the more pleasant social aspects of spring training is the arrival, often unexpected, of new faces day after day. Some of the faces are familiar, some not; some have clearly established relationships to the baseball world, others must identify themselves.
TROY, N.Y., March 9 (AP) -- Two days before Norman H. Briggs disappeared in 1960, an insurance office here received an anonymous telephone call, Sheriff Harold H. Harriman said today.
WASHINGTON, March 9 (UPI) -- The Senate voted 88 to 0 today to set up a special House-Senate committee to study and make recommendations in the field of Congressional reform.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 9 -- George M. Weiss put $250 more on the table today, Joe Christopher agreed and the New York Mets' last and longest holdout of 1965 was ended.

PHILADELPHIA, March 9 -- This city is regularly a tryout spot for Broadway productions. It is also, occasionally, a tryout town for an opera singer. Tonight Joan Sutherland, one of today's leading sopranos, undertook the role of Marguerite in "Faust" for the first time, in the Academy of Music under the auspices of the enterprising Philadelphia Lyric Opera Company.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- Secretary of the Treasury Douglas Dillon told a Congressional Committee today that restraints on American bank lending abroad to industrial countries might have to continue indefinitely in order to balance the nation's international payments and to keep them balanced.

Buildings Commissioner Harold Birns confronted critics yesterday with statistics showing that in one year's time there had been a 25 per cent increase in inspections, a third more violations uncovered and twice as many corrected.

CHICAGO, March 9 -- Zenith Radio Corporation, the radio set and television maker, will ask the Federal Communications Commission tomorrow to authorize pay television on "an extended nation-wide basis."
WASHINGTON, March 9 -- The Senate's investigation into the possibility of widespread criminal infiltration into banks got started today on a low key.
NAHA, Okinawa, March 9 -- Okinawa's vital role in the Vietnamese crisis has diluted the popular movement here for the island's reversion to Japanese rule.
A $10.87 million permanent first mortgage has been placed on the new 32-story office building at 555 Madison Avenue for the Cloverton Corporation.
Venezuela is investing more than $250,000 in expanding its pavilion for the 1965 World's Fair, Robert Moses, president of the fair corporation, was told yesterday.
PRINCETON, N.J., March 9 -- The Daily Princetonian has given Princeton University $500 for "the cause of coeducation at Princeton."
The Missouri Pacific Railroad created a finance committee yesterday and named Robert H. Craft as is chairman.
Job discrimination too frequently stunts the ambition of the city's youth, Mrs. Constance Baker Motley, the new Borough President of Manhattan, declared yesterday.
A business agent for the Chelsea local of the International Longshoremen's Association was shot and wounded at his 11th Avenue headquarters yesterday. A disgruntled member of the Union was sought.
The Rev. Milton A. Galamison, leader of the seven-week-old school boycott, said yesterday that the demonstration was in a "state of suspension."
JERUSALEM, (Israeli Sector) March 9 -- Premier Levi Eshkol will make a statement on Israeli-West German relations next Tuesday in the Knesset (Parliament).

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- A House Republican group on voting rights accused President Johnson today of being dilatory both in dealing with the explosive racial situation in Selma, Ala., and in sending a voting bill to Congress.
BRAZZAVILLE, Congo Republic, March 5 -- Peking's diplomatic style has many Western observers wondering why the Chinese have been so startlingly successful in this former French colony.

The Appellate Division ordered in a 4 to 1 decision yesterday that Supreme Court Justice Theodore Velsor in Mineola reconsider the tie-vote battle between Francis X. Altimari of Westbury and Julius R. Lipp-of New Hyde Park in an election for judge of the District Court.

A decline in revenues and earnings in February and for the first two months of this year, reported by the Illinois Central Railroad, were attributed yesterday to the strike of longshoremen at seaboard and gulf ports.

WASHINGTON, March 9 The United State has concluded that the Soviet Union may technically have violated the nuclear test ban treaty with an underground nuclear explosion in mid-January that released radioactivity, the State Department said today.

Seven more persons were arrested yesterday and charged with contempt of court in connection with a grand jury investigation into last July's Harlem riots. Five persons arrested on similar charges last October have been tried and are awaiting a decision in their cases in Criminal Court.
PLEASANTVILLE, N.J., March 9 (AP) -- Parents of girls attending Pleasantville High School are upset because their daughters must take "mass showers" during physical education classes.
Two indictments charging fraud in connection with the Government's foreign aid program were returned yesterday by a Federal grand jury.
WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP) -- The Senate confirmed today President Johnson's nomination of Thomas C. Mann to be Under Secretary of State for Economic Affairs.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- The Committee for a More Beautiful Capital toured the Washington Mall today to see how it will be converted from a "backyard -- a wasteland that cuts the city in two" -- to a place where people can enjoy themselves.
WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP) -- Legislation to guide the states in setting up Congressional districts under the one-man, one-vote rule was cleared today for House action that is expected in about a week.

BOWIE, Md., March 9 (AP) -- Cycloblond, a 19-to-1 shot owned by Mrs. Irene D. Karr rallied strongly in the final eighth to beat John G. Fitzgerald's Rex de Plumbum by a nose in the $6,000 Richmond Belles Purse at the Bowie track today.
WASHINGTON, March 9 -- The Administration wants to avoid, if it is at all possible, sending Federal troops or a large force of Federal marshals to Selma, Ala.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., March 9 -- One hundred and seventy-five students and 17 faculty members of Sarah Lawrence College, a liberal arts school here for women, marched two miles from campus to the Village Hall this afternoon to dramatize their sympathy for service and maintenance workers on strike at Lawrence Hospital.
When fire swept the whole block on Atlantic Avenue in Brooklyn during the morning hours of Jan. 15 more than 80 persons barely had time to reach the street.
CLEVELAND, March 10 (AP) -- Bulk fleet vessels will be moving on the Great Lakes late this month as the lake shipping season gets off to an early start.

Page 17 of your March 3 issue describes a failure which, if it had been a success, would have been front-page news. That is, the Surveyor rocket fired at Cape Kennedy, a trial for a moon shot scheduled for next fall, exploded on its launching pad.

ROME, March 10 (Reuters) -- An Italian Jesuit priest who caused a sensation in 1952 when he abandoned his vows and became an active member of the Communist party has ben received back by the Roman Catholic Church, the Milan weekly magazine Oggi said today.
Lillian D. Wald Day was marked here yesterday in honor of the 98th anniversary of the birth of the founder of the Henry Street Settlement and organizer of the public health nursing profession.
Washington, March 10 -- Opposing party leaders in the Senate agreed today that they did not like the complexity of Administration proposals to enforce voting rights.

DETROIT, March 10 -- The State of Michigan said today that it was investigating the legal feasibility of filing a suit in the United States Supreme Court to reduce Alabama's Congressional representation for denying Negroes the right to vote.
The question of yardsticks came up at a luncheon of the American Chamber of Commerce in London yesterday.
PARIS, March 10 -- Frenchmen's wives, citizens with sharply curtailed rights, are soon to enjoy almost as much legal freedom as their husbands.

WINDHAM, N.Y., March 10 (AP) -- Hias Leitner, an Austrian representing the Stratton Mountain (Vt.) Ski Area turned in the best combined time today in the second event of the American Pro Ski League series of races at Windham Mountain.
WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Representative Wilbur D. Mills predicted today broad public support for an enlarged version of the Administration's program of medical care for the aged.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 10 -- The more interesting phase of spring training, playing exhibition games, begins for the New York Yankees tomorrow. They will go to Pompano Beach, only a few miles north of their own ball park here, to face the Washington Senators.
CAIRO, March 10 -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser warned tonight that the United Arab Republic would recognize East Germany if West Germany established formal relations with Israel.
The American Express Company set sales and profit records last year, the travel and banking concern reported yesterday.

Judge Lloyd F. McMahon's opinion in the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company antitrust case was sprinkled with barbed witticisms and the fruits of legal and historical research.

The 17-story office building at 80 Fifth Avenue, the southwest corner of 14th Street, has been sold to the Ames-Boston Corporation, a Massachusetts real estate concern for cash over a first mortgage of $890,000.

The election of David A. Shepard as a director of Merck Co. was announced yesterday by Charles S. Garland, chairman of the drug and chemicals producer.
Smith, Barney Co., investment bankers, announced the election yesterday of Harvey S. Gerry as a vice president and European representative.

WASHINGTON, March 10 (UPI) -The State Department announced today formation of a citizens' group to work with Government officials in compiling a series of reports on international cooperation.

SARASOTA, Fla., March 10 -- Dave Nicholson, the huge outfielder with the home-run swing and a fantastic ratio of strikeouts, took a vicious cut at the ball in the batting cage this morning. If he had connected, the ball would have disappeared beyond the palm trees on the far side of the distant fence.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -Controller of the Currency James J. Saxon proposed some controversial rules today to restrict unwise banking practices and help prevent illegal ones that have led to a recent increase in bank failures.

The proposal to build a $5 million parking garage underneath Madison Square Park comes before the Board of Estimate and the City Council today for final decision. We are opposed to it because it would be a misuse of park land, would entail destruction of magnificent old trees and because it would encourage the entry of more automobiles into an area where the city's policy should be to discourage them.

BOWIE, Md., March 10 (AP) -- Uncle Willie M., a 3-year-old Maryland-bred colt by Prince Dare, joined the elite ranks of stakes winners at Bowie today when he scored in the 33d running of the $24,500 Prince George's Stakes.
LONDON, March 10 -- A meeting between Queen Elizabeth II and the Duchess of Windsor will take place within the next few days at the bedside of the Duke of Windsor.
SALT LAKE CITY, March 10 -- The Utah Senate passed today and sent to Gov. Calvin L. Rampton a bill prohibiting discrimination in employment because of race, creed, color or religion.

WASHINGTON, March 10 (UPI) -- The American Catholic Bishops' Committee on Ecumenism met here today to draw up guidelines for Catholic participation in joint worship services with Protestants and other Christian unity activities.
HUNTINGTON, L.I. March 10 -- The Cravero family has found itself in a forest of red tape over a tree house it wants to build.

The Deadline Club, which is the New York City chapter of Sigma Delta Chi, the professional journalistic society, paid tribute last night to four news and magazine executives. They were guests of honor at a dinner meeting of the club at the 71st Regiment Armory, 34th Street and Park Avenue.

Byron Janis has canceled a piano recital scheduled for tonight in Mobile, Ala., as a protest against what he called "the repugnant, brutal and thoroughly un-American actions" of Gov. George Wallace of Alabama.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -The Chairman of the Federal Reserve Board cited today this week's sharp increase in European dollar interest rates as evidence that the Administration's new balance-of-payments program is having an effect.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., March 10 -- A concert sponsored by the Yale Alumni Association of New Canaan to benefit its scholarship fund will be given on Saturday evening by the Yale Glee Club, and its informal singing group, the Whiffenpoofs, at the New Canaan High-School auditorium.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -Retail sales in February rose by 7 per cent from 1964 and 1 per cent from the January level, of $22.88 billion, to a total of $23 billion, the Commerce Department reported today.

The election of Thomas P. Lynch and John S.R. Shad as directors of E.F. Hutton Co., member of the New York Stock Exchange, was announced yesterday by Sylvan C. Coleman, chairman. The move increased the size of the board to 10 members.
SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., March 10 -- "We've got enough good players to be competitive. What we need most is to get rid of the defeatist attitude this club has had for the last four or five years."

SELMA, Ala., March 10 -- In the early afternoon today the demonstrators lined up along the road outside the Negro church and prepared to march to the county courthouse. But just a half block away, stretching across the road, stood 17 Selma policeman, and posing in front of them, puffing a cigar, waiting, stood their boss, Wilson Baker.
