CAP-HAITIEN, Haiti -- This old port on the northern shore of Haiti has been deeply stirred by the murder of a prominent resident and the fact that his killer appears to be protected by She Government.

Don Schollander, winner of four gold medals in swimming for the United States in the 1964 Olympic Games, was awarded the "grand award of sports" tonight by the editors of Sports Illustrated magazine.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), March 10 -- West Germany's special envoy left here today carrying assurances that Israel will establish diplomatic relations with West Germany.
The election of John A. Gambling, the radio commentator, as a director of the Hempstead Bank was announced yesterday at the bank's annual meeting.

ONE of the oldest bridge clubs in New York moved to new and attractive quarters on Tuesday. It is the Bridge House, which was for many years at 645 Madison Avenue and is now at the Hotel Alrae, 37 East 64th Street.

HONG KONG, March 10 -Communist China today rejected an appeal by the recent Moscow conference for an end of open polemics.

W.R. Grace Co. in 1964 had the most successful year in its 110-year history. The annual report of J. Peter Grace, president, issued yesterday, also disclosed that chemical sales exceeded $500 million for the first time.

In his new collection, the Iowan poet, Paul Engle, remarks, "Verse is not written. It is bled/ Out of the poet's abstract head." These poems, however, give no sign of parturition. If Clark Kerr carries out his announced intention to resign as president of the University of California, his departure will be a heavy blow to that giant institution as well as to higher education in the United States.
Yeshiva University contracted yesterday to buy the 19-story office building at 55 Fifth Avenue, at 12th Street and the adjoining four-story office building at No. 57 for $4 million.

The March potato futures contract expired yesterday at $4.60, down 5 cents on the day. The contract life's range had been $5.20 to $2.32. Each cent represents $5 a contract.
WASHINGTON, March 10 (UPI) -- The Senate approved a two-year, $20 million extension of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency today.

THOUGH covers were skimpy in the East this winter, recreational skiing enjoyed a boom season west of the Great Divide. The principal reason was an abundance of snow that has kept Western operators measuring depths in feet rather than in inches.

The Johnson Administration has been contemplating a shift in its policy toward the Middle East. In the past it used to support shipment of arms to Israel from Western European sources. Now it plans to send arms directly to Israel.

The stock market drifted aimlessly yesterday, with the tendency slightly to the downside in moderately active trading. On the New York Stock Exchange, a few more issues declined than advanced and the leading averages fell slightly.

HAROLD PINTER'S startling dark comedy, "The Dumb Waiter," was presented last night on Channel 5's "Esso Repertory Theater." The production -- and choice of play -- contributed to an hour of distinctive television.

TRIVANDRUM, India, March 10 -- E.M.S. Namboodiripad, leader of the pro-Peking Communists in Kerala state said today that "agitation" had been started to force the release of 29 Communists elected last Thursday to the state legislature.

BERKELEY, Calif., March 10 -- Clark Kerr's decision to resign as president of the University of California was ascribed by knowledgeable sources today to continued interference with administrative details by individual members of the Board of Regents.

BONN, March 10 -- The West German Parliament, challenged by a member to acknowledge that "we all share the guilt," registered overwhelming support today for the principle of unlimited prosecution of Nazis accused as murderers.
General Industrial Enterprises, Inc., an investment trust, has increased its common stock holdings in Best Co., a women's specialty store chain.

George Whitmore Jr. took the stand yesterday in Brooklyn Supreme Court and said that his confessions last April 24 to three murders and an attempted rape came as a result of beatings and threats by the police.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., March 11 (AP) -- The first round of a major attack against tax aid to religious institutions in the United States ended today with a ruling that it is constitutional for Maryland to help construct buildings at church-affiliated colleges.
DUBLIN, March 11 -- The Republic of Ireland faces an early general election following the defeat tonight of the Government party's candidate in the mid-Cork by-election.
William E. McKenna was named president of the Royal typewriter division of Litton Industries yesterday. He had been president of Monroe International, another Litton division.
WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP) -- The Senate passed a bill today to extend four existing programs of Federal grants to community health services.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- Clergymen of Washington have been instructed by the highest levels of the religious hierarchy here to preach and pray this weekend for Federal intervention in the Selma, Ala., racial crisis.
AUSTIN, Tex., March 11 -- Walter W. Jenkins, former member of President Johnson's White House staff, has moved to Austin and plans to make it his home.
NEWARK, March 11 (AP) -- Students and faculty members of the Rutgers University Law School marched to the Federal Building here today in support of civil rights efforts in Selma, Ala.
The Royal Dutch-Shell group said yesterday that 1964 earnings fell below the 1963 level, despite a substantial gain in sales and other operating income.
Controller Abraham D. Beame voted yesterday against giving a $120,000 Worlds Fair contract to Pinkerton's National Detective Agency without public bidding.

Several articles appeared in The Times recently referring to a bill recommended to the City Council to require stores that prepare and sell prepackaged food by weight to provide a scale for shoppers to check the weight of merchandise.
Since the murder of Catherine Genovese, the police are getting a little more cooperation from the public in reporting crime.
Plans to establish new antipoverty centers and job programs in slums here were announced yesterday by city, state and Federal officials.

BERKELEY, Calif., March 11 -- Dr. Clark Kerr, as president of the multicampus University of California, gives a reception every fall for new students at Berkeley. Inevitably, among the 3,000 or so on hand, several go down the receiving line a second time.
Gains outnumbered declines by a wide margin on the American Stock Exchange yesterday and trading was active. Two airline issues strengthened in heavy demand.

The Upstairs at the Downstairs has polished its successful fall revue for the spring and the six talented performers breaking all the rules in "The Game Is Up" remain as impishly bright as most of their revised material.
The Power Corporation of Canada, Ltd., has agreed to purchase the 785,100 shares of Consolidated Paper Corporation, Ltd., held by the St. Regis Paper Company, Inc.
The Benny Golson Jazz Quintet played "The Squirrel yesterday at a funeral in the Advent Lutheran Church at Broadway and 93d Street.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 11 -- President Habib Bourguiba of Tunisia announced today that he had information that West Germany had rejected Israel's conditions for establishment of diplomatic relations.
The 26th annual White Elephant Ball for the benefit of the Child Care and Adoption Service was held at the Waldorf-Astoria last night.

In a recent address before a conference on urban affairs Mayor Wagner said: "In general, I would say that we in New York City are on top of our problems, in the sense that we are actively coping with them. We are overcoming some of them."

WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP) -- The Commerce Department estimated today that retail sales for the week ended March 6 totaled $4.8 billion, about 2 per cent below the level of the previous week, but up 5 per cent from the corresponding 1964 week.
A 58-year-old professor was cheered by his students yesterday for helping to capture a hit-and-run driver.
TRENTON, March 11 -- A truce was reached today in the whisky war between New Jersey and Pennsylvania.

NEW HAVEN, March 11 -- Steve Clark, the chunky, curly haired Yale captain who has not lost a race this season, led the Elis into first place as the Eastern Seaboard intercollegiate swimming championships opened today in the Yale exhibition pool.

There is a refreshing candor about the Soviet admission that the Communist-ruled nations will fall far short this year of attaining the 50 per cent of world industrial production they had earlier boasted they would have in 1965. WASHINGTON, March 11 -- A group of youthful civil rights demonstrators staged a sitdown in the White House for almost seven hours today demanding Federal intervention in Selma, Ala.
TAMPERE, Finland, March 11 -- A scrappy but uncoordinated American hockey team lost, 9 -- 2, tonight to the Soviet Union in a penalty-ridden contest.
Riker Co., Inc., a realty concern widely known as specialists in managing high-priced cooperative apartment buildings here, has been enjoined from doing business because of alleged insolvency.
LANSING, Mich., March 11 (AP) -- House members voted 95 to 0 today to deny Representative-elect Daniel West his seat in the Michigan Legislature.
Two Italian singers, Mirella Freni, soprano, and Gianni Raimondi, tenor, will make their debuts together with the Metropolitan Opera next season.
ALBANY, March 11 -- New York City won permission from the Court of Appeals today to build a pavilion and sidewalk cafe in Central Park with a gift from Huntington Hartford.
There was a bargain-day atmosphere yesterday behind the high wire-fenced wall on the eighth floor of the Bureau of Customs' storeroom at 201 Varick Street.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- Total trading off the exchange floors in stocks listed on major exchanges -- the so-called "third market" -- is somewhat larger than previously estimated, and extremely large in certain issues.

POMPANO BEACH, Fla., March 11 -- The New York Yankees opened the Grapefruit League season today by beating the Washington Senators, 4 -- 3, in a low key performance devoid of significant developments.

Seven legislators from New York, New Jersey, Pennsylvania and Connecticut agreed here yesterday to press for passage of a bill that would raise New York State's minimum legal drinking age from 18 to 21 years.

Eudowood Shopping Plaza,! Inc., a subsidiary of Food Fail". Properties, Inc., that operatesl the Eudowood Plaza shopping[ center in Towson, Md has filed, a claim for $9,209,966 against Arnold Constable Corporation.

ARCADIA, Calif., March 11 (UPI) -- George Royal, a Canadian-bred horse closed with a big surge in the final stages and pulled away by more than two lengths today to capture the $125,000 invitation San Juan Capistrano Handicap over Santa Anita's turf course.
The country's journalistic tyros -- 5,500 schoolboy and girl editors, aided by counselors and teachers -- swarmed over the Columbia University campus yesterday in pursuit of newspaper knowledge.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 11 -- Seven Negroes, including James Forman, executive director of the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee, were arrested here today for blocking traffic on Capitol Hill after they had failed in an attempt to approach the State House.
The movement for abolition of the death penalty gained support yesterday from two important sources that had previously been indifferent or hostile to such a change in state law.

ST. CATHARINES, Ont., March 11 (AP) -- Stuart Armour of Toronto, president and general manager of the Great Lakes waterways Development Association, said today that Canada could revert to toll-free inland waterways by building a lock at Cornwall, Ont.
Automation, which is reachAutomation, which is reaching into virtually every field of human endeavor, also has been making strong inroads in real estate activities.

EVANSVILLE, Ind., March 11 (UPI) -- Evansville's unbeaten Aces tonight scored a 93-70 victory over St. Michael's and Southern Illinois routed North Dakota, 97-64, in semi-final games of the National Collegiate Athletic Association college division basketball tournament.

BERKELEY, Calif., March 11 -- Regents of the University of California have been summoned to a special session here Saturday to deal with pressing problems on the Berkeley campus and with Dr. Clark Kerr's announced intention of resigning as the university president.

" The Other Mr. Churchill," by MacDonald Hastings, which Dodd, Mead will publish on Monday, is not a portrayal of some little known aspect of the late Winston Churchill but a biography of Robert Churchill. This Mr. Churchill was a sportsman, gunsmith and expert witness on ballistics.

With mounting investor interest in the stocks of new life insurance companies as his backdrop, the New York State Superntendent of Insurance warned yesterday that his department, "for the public's sake, intends to make sure that new companies here do not 'build their house upon the sand.'"

CARACAS, Venezuela, March 11 -- President Raul Leoni, in his annual message to Congress, announced today a four-year plan aimed at bringing substantial increases in all phases of the national economy.

MIAMI, March 11 (AP) -- Doug Sanders, who won last week's Pensacola open, creacked the record at the par-72 Doral Country Club golf course today with a 65 and a two-stroke lead in the first round of the Doral tournament over the watery 7,028-yard layout.
A parade of the Negro and Puerto Rican poor protested a slum-clearance plan for Morningside Heights yesterday on the ground that it would destroy their homes and simply drive them into other slums.

American Airlines will move its New York reservations center and sales force to the Chrysler Building, where it has leased 46,000 square feet of space, from the West Side Airlines Terminal and from 99 Park Avenue.

OSLO, Norway, March 11 (AP) -- Lorns Skjemstad, a 24-year-old Norwegian sports instructor, won the 15-kilometer cross-country race in the Holmenkollen ski meet today, beating Gianfranco Stella of Italy by two seconds.
The wholesale commodity price index was unchanged at 102.9 Wednesday.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 11 (AP) -- The Boston Celtics achieved a record-tying 60th victory tonight by defeating the Detroit Pistons, 112-100. Bill Russell set the pace with 27 points.
WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP) -- The Pentagon's plans to merge the Army Reserves and National Guard and cut back their manpower drew sharp criticism today at a Senate hearing.
The stock market rallied yesterday in moderately heavy trading, after two sessions of an irregular decline.

The National Hockey League, which has not had a franchise change since 1942, drafted a radical plan yesterday that would eventually double the number of league clubs.
TEL AVIV -- The invitation to the gala dinner that wound up Israel's first Fashion Week bore this gentle reminder to local male recipients: "Please wear a dark suit."

MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 11 -- The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. testified in Federal Court here today that he had had no intention of leading a march of Negroes and civil rights partisans from Selma to Montgomery last Tuesday.

Two inspectors of the United States Department of Agriculture, a meat broker and the president of a defunct processing company were indicted here yesterday in connection with the illegal sale of horsemeat.

Bertram Ross, a modern dancer who came to fame and has stayed there for many years as the leading male performer, of the Martha Graham Dance Company, has succumbed to the choreographic urge that overtakes many Graham dancers.

LOS ANGELES, March 11 -- Suffolk County, N.Y., and some other areas plagued by foam on drinking water have little prospect of relief through the pending national change-over in detergent chemicals, the latest comprehensive study of the problem forecast today.

" The movies have a history," writes Richard Schickel, "and despite the many perversions which commerce has forced upon it, it is an honorable one artistically." Unfortunately, in this book Mr. Schickel has barely room to do more than make the assertion. "The Movies" is international ill scope and mentions most of the essential events, names and techniques since Edison's Vitascope first enthralled moviegoers back in 1896.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- Intercity truck tonnage and total carloadings of rail freight in the recent week ended March 6 were both considerably above the level of the corresponding week of 1964.
WALL STREET was long -- on rumors and reactions yesterday, ranging from Cabinet posts and antitrust decisions to the trading antics of the General Aniline and Film Corporation.

Kennedy, Democrat of New York, and Senator Ed ward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, urged in testimony before Mr. Udall the removal as soon as possible of the quotas on the oil used to heat large buildings and to generate electricity.

LONDON, March 11 -- A report on London housing pointed today to citywide planning as the only solution for the capital's worsening housing shortage.

MOSCOW, March 11 -- The Soviet Government has energetically rejected a Chinese Communist protest against the methods used by the Soviet police in breaking up a student riot in front of the United States Embassy a week ago.

Elyakum Shapira and George Cleve are sharing the podium of the New York Philharmonic this week, and last night it was Mr. Shapira's turn. The two men are conducting by arrangement with the American Conductors Project, a Ford Foundation enterprise at Peabody Conservatory in Baltimore with which both were associated in 1962-63.
SYDNEY, Australia, March 11 -- The release yesterday of figures for United States trade with Australia has increased concern here over Washington's new foreign-investment policy.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- Twenty-four House Republicans called today for the creation of an Office of Community Development as a "more effective and efficient" alternative to a Cabinet-level Department of Urban Affairs.

BELGRADE, March 11 -A spokesman for the Communist Government reported today that Mihajlo Mihajlov, a young Yugoslav scholar who wrote critically of the Soviet Union, was under arrest and was being interrogated.

The Board of Estimate whisked a $664,382,319 capital budget for 1965-66 through to passage yesterday in just three minutes at midday. But the identical program was debated hotly and at length before it won late-hour approval in the City Council.

On Feb. 20 [International edition Feb. 22] your paper carried a news article by Alfred Clark which reported that Russians had tried to seize an American boat. On learning of this, we communicated with the skippers of the Soviet fishing vessels in that part of the Atlantic Ocean, checked thoroughly the information received and came to the conclusion that the Clark news article had misinformed your readers.
LONDON, March 11 -- A Labor Member of Parliament who accused some Conservatives of having been "half drunk" in the House was found guilty today of "gross contempt of the House of Commons."
CHICAGO, March 11 -- A Federal Court jury of six men and six women today found former Gov. William G. Stratton not guilty of income tax fraud.

One year and several hundred speeches after her appointment as Special Assistant to the President for Consumer Affairs, Mrs. Esther Peterson is convinced that merchandising abuses can be remedied best by industry cooperation.
WASHINGTON, March 11 -- The Labor Department failed today in an attempt to take custody of the ballots cast in the contested election of the International Union of Electrical Workers.
Business loans at 14 leading New York City banks declined $122 million in the week ended March 10, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
Prices were advanced yesterday on some steel products and some chemicals.
TRAVEL is broadening, particularly where the food and drink are good. But the journey home is an exultant occasion.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- The United States expressed the hope today that the Arab nations would maintain "friendly relations" with West Germany even if the Bonn extended diplomatic recognition to Israel.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 11 -- A United States jet bomber crashed today during a raid in Binhdinh Province in Central Vietnam. A search was under way for two Air Force crewmen.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, March 12 -- Government sources here said today that three sponsors of a peace movement were flown yesterday to Hue, 400 miles north of here, for deportation to North Vietnam.
BUENOS AIRES, March 11 -- A group of businessmen from the Americas has been meeting here this week to forge a wider alliance for hemisphere progress.

The search for a brightly colored haven through hallucination-producing drugs may lead even the so-called normal person only to his particular brand of hell, according to the first large-scale study of the effect of L.S.D. on different personality types.
One advantage of a corner location in Manhattan's swiftly changing commercial districts is that the address can be changed as the balance of prestige shifts on the cross streets.
The New York Philharmonic will play at Philharmonic Hall tonight at 8:30 as part of the Cornell University Centennial Celebration. George Cleve will conduct, with Jorge Bolet as piano soloist.

DARMSTADT, Germany, March 11 (UPI) -- An American military spokesman said today that 16 officers who had dressed as Ku Klux Klansmen at an Army-sponsored masquerade party had been reprimanded by their commanding officer for poor judgment.

WASHINGTON, March 11 (UPI) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission disclosed today it has been investigating for several months the accuracy of financial reports filed by Yale Express System, Inc., of New York City.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara warned congress today that the Vietcong must be defeated in South Vietnam. Otherwise, the United States will have to face the same problem again in another place or permit the Communists "to have all of Southeast Asia by default."

DETROIT, March 11 (UPI) -- A 17-year-old Negro expelled from Northwestern High School admitted stabbing one of nine white persons who were attacked Tuesday night after a high school basketball tournament game, the police said today.
PITTSBURGH. March 12 (AP) -- At least one of the "big 11" steel producers has started bargaining with the United Steelworkers of America over wages and fringe benefits.
PARIS, March 12 -- "Welded," a play by Eugene O'Neill that was first and last seen on Broadway in 1924, had its Parisian premiere tonight at the Theater Recamier in an adaptation called "Enchaines."
WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Timothy Pagano, sporting a luxuriant beard and clad in tight denim trousers, heather-green sport coat and loafers, turned to a friend and said:
A driver was assessed $6,500 in punitive damages by a jury yesterday for causing an automobile accident while drunk.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 12 -- A Minister in British Guiana's three-months-old coalition Cabinet said today that his Government was determined to eliminate the menace of Communism but would need outside economic help to succeed.
A 22-year-old man was stabbed to death in a subway train in Brooklyn last night as 11 other passengers sat by, watching in in horror.

DANANG, South Vietnam, Saturday, March 13 (Reuters) -- United States marines who reached here last Monday clashed with Communist guerrillas for the first time last night, a marine spokesman said today.

The State Department has sent a note to the Soviet Embassy complaining about what it regards "as improper maritime behavior" on the part of a Soviet trawler charged with the failure to send a distress signal for an American lobster boat.
ALBANY, March 12 -- The State Parole Board reported today significant progress in the treatment of narcotic addicts who had been released from prison under intensive parole supervision.
WASHINGTON, March 12 -- The nation's money supply stopped growing in the first two months of this year, a Federal Reserve Board report disclosed today.
PARIS, March 12 -- The Harkness Ballet of New York tonight followed up its world debut in Cannes last month with a grand opening at the handsome red and gold Opera-Comique.

WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP) -- Secretary of State Dean Rusk informed France today that the United States was cool toward any French-Soviet move for an international conference on Southeast Asia at this time.
Eight Assemblymen toured the Women's House of Detention yesterday and described it as a "hellhole" that made them "physically sick."

Public protests over the treatment of Negro and white integrationists in Selma, Ala., continued across North America yesterday. There were sit-in demonstrations at the base of the Liberty Bell in Philadelphia and on the steps of the United States consulate in Toronto.

More effective organization of economic aid to developing countries was urged here yesterday at the opening of a three-day conference at the Columbia University School of Law. The conference was organized by the law school's research project on public in ternational development financing, which is supported by the Ford Foundation.
LONDON, March 12 (AP) -- A British company will make you a drip-dry undershirt that it says will stop a .45-caliber bullet.

ALBANY, March 12 (AP) -- Assemblyman James A. Lombard said today that he had asked the State controller to investigate what he termed an apparent shortage of almost $2 million in finds of the Rensselaer County government.
WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP) -- President Johnson, proclaiming May 1 as Loyalty Day, declared today that this nation again affirmed its "eternal hostility to tyranny and oppression wherever it exists."
The five stocks in which investors could have made the most money on the New York Stock Exchange last year were not blue chips. In fact, they could be described as fairly speculative.
Republican leaders narrowed their list of potential party nominees for Mayor from 15 to 10 at a meeting here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Bipartisan teams of Congressmen will start fanning out around the country next week to take a "hard look" at the nation's antipoverty programs.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- A mass rally, of religious leaders erupted in shouts of fury and accusation here today over what they regard as President Johnson's failure to act on the racial crisis in Selma, Ala.

COLLEGE PARK, Md., March 12 -- Princeton had a surprisingly easy time tonight beating North Carolina State, 66 -- 48, to advance to the final of the National Collegiate Athletic Association Eastern Regional basketball championship.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 12 -- The International Court of Justice will open oral proceedings Monday in a case linking the segragation struggle of the American Negro and the fate of 430,000 African Bantus and bushmen.

John Baldwin of East Meadow, L.I., dominated the compulsory figures and the free-skating events to capture the Middle Atlantic junior men's figure-skating championship last night at Iceland rink atop Madison Square Garden.
MOSCOW, March 12 (AP) -- A Tass dispatch from Washington on the civil rights demonstrations there said today "these days the White House looks like a fortress in siege."

PRINCETON, N.J., March 12 -- Physicists from Princeton and Stanford Universities announced today the successful use of a new type of storage ring to produce electron collisions with more available energy than ever before.
PEKING, March 12 -- Communist China charged yesterday that Canadian members of the International Control Commission for Vietnam were serving United States interests and defaming North Vietnam.
ITHACA, N.Y., March 12 -- A battle seemed in the offing tonight after the close of the quarter-final round of the Eastern Intercollegiate Wrestling Association championships at Barton Hall.
TEL AVIV, Israel, March 12 (Reuters) -- Foreign Minister Golda Meir said today she expected that the Cabinet would decide Sunday on a West German request for diplomatic relations with Israel.

Potato futures dealings were even more of a guessing game than usual yesterday as traders awaited the Government's report of stocks on hand. When it arrived after the close of the market, it showed the lowest figure for a March 1 report since 1957.

Haryou-Act is the weapon through which the Federal and city governments are trying to change the whole character of Harlem. For generations that unfortunate community has been notorious for slums, crime, delinquency and dismal atmosphere that sporadically erupts in rioting. To change it is truly a herculean task, but one of tremendous importance not only to Harlem but to all of New York City.
The New York Court of Appeals unanimously affirmed yesterday a decision dismissing a $1.1 million damage suit filed by Local 824 of the International Longshoremen's Association.
NAIROBI, Kenya, March 12 -- At a traffic circle in the center of town, people of all shades and backgrounds sit at tables under a spreading thorn tree and exchange gossip in a Babel of languages.

TROY, N.Y., March 12 (AP) -- The District Attorney hinted today that there was more than had been reported in the disappearance case of Norman H. Briggs, who left his family and a gross estate of $158,859 to become a cowboy in Wyoming.

A good deal of material new to the repertory of the Clancy Brothers and Tommy Makem was introduced last night at Carnegie Hall. Although the capacity audience responded more vivaciously to the familiar rebel, drinking and love songs of the Irish-American folk quartet, one could only appreciate the additions to their already large store of songs.
WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP) -- The two chief members of an Air Force Academy cheating ring made a profit of about $900 in selling examinations to other cadets, the Air Force has told Congress.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 12 -- An agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation testified here today that "in the interest of public safety," troopers of the Alabama Highway Patrol "were justified in using teargas" against the Negro marchers at Selma last Sunday.

NEW HAVEN, March 12 -- Swimming championships, long a matter of tenure at Yale, continued to accrue to the Elis tonight at the Eastern Seaboard intercollegiate championships. The boys in the blue and white trunks accounted for three of the five titles decided in the Yale pool on the second day of this three-day event.

Quotations supplied by the National Association of Securities Dealers, at approximately 3 P.M. Bids are representative inter-dealer prices and do not include retail markdown or commission. Asked prices have been adjusted upward to include approximate markup.

PROVO, Utah, March 12 (UPI) -- Gail Goodrich set a school scoring record tonight with a brilliant 40-point performance that led the defending National Collegiate champion, University of California, Lost Angeles, to an unexpectedly easy 100-76 victory over Brigham Young University.

A short man who speaks in cultured accents and who rarely raises his voice above a parlor-conversation whisper, stands at the center of a great stage in black tie and cummerbund, talking. WASHINGTON, March 12 (UPI) -- The Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith charged today that a Palm Beach, Fla., hotel had discriminated against Jews and asked Justice Department action.
Fifty Negro publishers were urged yesterday to present a clearer image of the Negro press to the nation's major advertisers.

President Johnson, according to news accounts of his day, rises at 6:30 A.M. In doing this he is conforming to the Great American Tradition, that early risers are the beneficiaries of special salvific grace. "Early to bed, early to rise makes a man healthy, wealthy and wise."
To two Staten Islanders on Fifth Avenue last night, the time seemed right for the smearin' of the green, according to the police.
BOSTON, March 12 (AP) -- The widow and father of Mr. Reeb were flown here from Birmingham today in a jet plane provided by President Johnson.

CAIRO, March 12 -- The stakes have risen sharply for President Gamal Abdel Nasser in his showdown with West Germany now that President Habib Bourguiba of Tunisia has exposed a breach in the Arabs' ranks on the German question.
TAMPERE, Finland, March 12 (AP) -- The United States scored its first victory today in the world amateur hockey championships by heating Finland, 4 -- 0, and escaped last place in the standing.
MOSCOW, March 12 -- Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn, author of the prison-camp novel "A Day in the Life of Ivan Denisovich," appears to be under a political cloud.

BOSTON, March 12 (AP) -- Bob Gaudreau and Gerry Boyle, a sophomore, scored for Brown at the start of the game as the Bruins upset top-seeded Boston University, 5 -- 2, tonight in the semi-finals of the Eastern College Athletic Conference Hockey tournament.
BONN, March 12 -- The West German Bundesrat, or upper house of Parliament, moved today to force judges and state prosecuters who had served Nazi courts to resign.
An unsettled week on the London Stock Exchange ended yesterday on a subdued note.
WASHANGTON, March 12 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission will begin on April 12 its study of whether the New Haven Railroad's commuter service should be heavily cut back.

WSINGTON, March 12 (AP) -- A hearing of the Department of the Interior on the Government's program for the control of oil imports ended today after some 125 persons, companies and organizations expressed their views. An estimated one million words of testimony and statements were recorded.
PALM BEACH, Fla. -- Lilly Pulitzer, the fragile, little-girl intellectual the fashion world is always raving about, does not exist.

DARIEN, Conn., March 12 -- Benjamin Ferris, the prosecutor here, indicated today that he would press for the trial of four more persons charged with serving liquor to minors at a debutante party last June 26.
A faculty organization at St. John's University called on the administration yesterday to answer its demands on education policy and salary studies by Monday.

The price situation was full of confusion yesterday. Prices went down, and also up. Some were advanced, but decreases were included. Prices that had been increased the day before were decreased. And some that had been cut on Thursday were rescinded yesterday.
Entries for Monday's opening-day program at Aqueduct close today, and the word is that they will be plentiful.

SPRING is in the stores. The line-for-line copies of the Paris couture clothes will be on the racks next week. They carry a hopeful message for those who have wondered if the current youth wave in fashion and allied fields requires a woman to emulate Dorian Gray.

The stars of "In Harm's Way" and Otto Preminger, producer of the movie, will meet with guests at a champagne supper April 6 at Gracie Mansion, residence of Mayor Wagner, after the film's premiere at the DeMille Theater.

EVANSVILLE, Ind., March 12 (UPI) -- Jerry Sloan's two free throws in the last second of overtime clinched an 85-82 victory tonight for Evansville over Southern Illinois in the championship game of the National Collegiate college-division basketball tournament.
WASHINGTON, March 12 (UPI) -- The automobile industry is uniting behind a drive for immediate and retroactive repeal of the 10 per cent automobile tax, it was reported today.

Two ferryboats nudged into retirement by the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge may be employed again if someone comes up with a satisfactory bid when the city auctions them next Friday at Peir 7, Tompkinsville S.I. No bid under $50,000 for each boat will be accepted.

LONDON, March 12 -- Britain is preparing to move closer to the American pattern of antitrust laws, but she hopes to avoid what are regarded here as excessive rigidity and intricacy in the United States.
HALLANDALE, Fla., March 12 (AP) -- Only four owners chose today to send their horses against Gun Bow and Candy Spots in tomorrow's $50,000 added Donn Handicap at Gulfstream Park.

BERKELEY, Calif., March 12 -- Dr. Edward W. Strong said today that he was forced out Jan. 2 as chancellor of the Berkeley campus of the University of California. He also blamed the university's president, Dr. Clark Kerr for the decline of student discipline.
The pound sterling declined sharply yesterday, falling to $2,7917 from $2,7936 on Thursday.

Dick Tiger scored a technical knockout over Juan (Rocky) Rivero in the sixth round of their scheduled 10-rounder at Madison Square Garden last night, beating upon the fat and sloppy Argentine until his heaving belly dragged him to the canvas.

Editorial license, I suppose, entitles The Times to ignore the facts of history and of the world today and hold to its opinion that an American-flag merchant marine is not important to our country. The retirement of two venerable dowagers from the North Atlantic sea lanes, the 24,336-ton Saturnia and her sister ship, the 24,495-ton Vulcania, was announced yesterday.
HAVANA, March 12 -- Cuba has one of the fastest-growing merchant navies in the world and expects to have more tonnage in two years than most other Latin-American nations, it was stated today.

LONDON -- In a sprawling black brick building in southwestern London an elegantly tailored man sits in a corner office with a red carnation in his lapel, a cigar between his fingers and a new, big-wheeled baby carriage beside his desk.

Johannes Somary led the Amor Artis Chorale and Orchestra at Town Hall last night in the first local performance of the Requiem Mass by Maximilian Albrecht. He balanced the evening with Bach's grand Cantata No. 21, "Ich hatte viel Bekummernis"
WASHINGTON, March 12 -- News correspondents in South Vietnam may be asked to refrain from reporting news of aerial missions while the missions are going on.

LEXINGTON, Ky., March 12 (UPI) -- Bill Buntin, an aggressive pivotman, scored 26 points tonight as Michigan defeated Dayton, 98 -- 71, and advanced to the National Collegiate Mideast regional final against Vanderbilt.

HONG KONG, Saturday, March 13 -- Communist China declared in statement today that the dispatch of United States ground forces to South Vietnam had "further blocked the way to a political settlement of the Vietnam question."
Benjamin Britten's opera, "A Midsummer Night's Dream," was given by the New York City Opera last night at the City Center. While the music cannot be called profound, it is solid entertainment.

James (Jimmy Doyle) Plumeri, one of the top garment center racketeers and a central figure in organized crime, was sentenced yesterday in Federal Court to two and a half years in prison for making false statements on his 1960 and 1962 tax returns.
The concluding paragraphs of your Feb. 23 editorial entitled "Road Block to School Aid" are ambiguous and misleading.
Employes of New York moving companies started returning to their jobs yesterday afternoon after having voted in the morning to accept terms of a settlement ending an 11-day strike.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 12 -- An increasing danger of new fighting in Cyprus was reported to the Security Council today by the Secretary General, U Thant.

In the wake of the tragic and disgraceful police violence in Selma on March 7, a prominent Negro was reported to have wondered how "President Johnson can send troops to Vietnam . . . and can't send troops to Selma. . . ."

License Commissioner Joseph C. DiCarlo conferred for an hour yesterday with owners and representatives of legitimate and motion-picture theaters on how best to end confusion over what constitutes a balcony, mezzanine or loge.

MOSCOW, March 12 -- The Soviet Government accused Communist China tonight of conducting an "extensive slander campaign" over methods used by the Soviet police in curbing a riot at the United States Embassy eight days ago.
WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Senate leaders and the Justice Department reached agreement tonight on a bipartisan bill to hasten and make effective the right of Negroes to register and vote.

Last year, a moonlighting magazine writer decided to junk his old typewriter and buy top-flight equipment to use at home. In all, he spent $800 for a good desk, a new elec tric typewriter, file cabinets, lamps and related office equipment.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- The first American attempt to put two men into orbit in one spacecraft may take place March 22, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said today.
UNDERHILL, Vt., March 12 -- Bright clouds of steam billowing from a hundred sugar houses off the highways of Vermont are among the surest signs of approaching spring.
BOWIE, Md., March 12 (AP) -- Nine 3-year-olds, six of them eligible for the Kentucky Derby, were named today for tomorrow's 11th running of the $75,000 added Governor's Gold Cup.

DETROIT. March 12 -- Indoor track made its local debut tonight with the fastest quarter-mile ever on an 11-lap board oval, a defeat by Gerry Lindgren that didn't count and one scratch because of fatherhood.

CAIRO, March 12 -- A group of West German aircraft experts have told the Egyptian press they wanted to continue working here in spite of a possible break in diplomatic relations between Bonn and Cairo. But others have privately informed Western friends they will leave.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- The index of wholesale primary market prices advanced one-tenth of 1 per cent to 101.3 of the 1957-59 base during the week ended March 9, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

YONKERS, March 12 -- An upset victory by Scotch Time in the $12,500 Adios Harry segment of the Adios Festival and a frightening chain-reaction pile-up in the first race highlighted tonight's harness racing program at Yonkers Raceway.

NASSAU, Bahamas, March 12 -- William Snaith of Stamford, Conn., pulled off an impressive coup today by winning the Nassau yacht race and the Southern Ocean Racing Conference championship with his 50-foot yawl, Figaro.

The University of Pennsylvania's fencing team scored a double-edged triumph in the Intercollegiate Fencing Association championships yesterday as the Quakers swept both the epee and foil titles at the Columbia University gymnasium.
CHARLESTON, W. Va., March 12 -- A bill to abolish capital punishment wont final approval today in the West Virigina Legislature.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, March 12 -- The mercenary force that was expected to march against rebel positions in the northeastern Congo is not moving, according to military sources here, because it is shot of boots.

CHICAGO, March 12 -- William Casey Marland, who was Governor of West Virginia with two chauffeur-driven Cadillacs at his command from 1953 to 1957, is a cab driver here. He drives a white Ford cab for the Flash Cab Company.
ALBANY, March 12 (AP) -- The State Teachers Retirement System was accused today by 130 school districts of collecting $35 million dollars by requiring illegal contributions.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 12 -- Authoritative sources said today that recommendations by American officials in Saigon would probably lead to the stationing of a United States Army division in South Vietnam for defensive security.
The New York Temple Corps of the Salvation Army is observing this weekend the 85th anniversary of its first beachhead in the United States.
The Olin Mathieson Chemical Corporation announced yesterday the appointment of Maurice E. Dare, Richard J. Grunewald and James F. Rowe as divisional vice presidents.

PHILADELPHIA, March 12 -- Twenty-five youthful civil rights demonstrators, including two coeds and a Negro, staged a sit-in today at the base of the Liberty Bell in Independence Hall to dramatize their demand for Federal intervention in Selma.
Salary increases totaling $85,000 were proposed by the city yesterday for the 93 assistant district attorneys on the staff of New York County District Attorney Frank S. Hogan.

BOSTON, March 12 -- More than 50 college students began a quiet sit-in today in the Federal Building here. A spokesman for the group said the students planned to remain in the building until Federal troops are sent to Selma.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- In the Radio Corporation of America Laboratories at Princeton, N.J., engineers have invented a syllable analyzer that takes spoken words apart and compresses them into electronic code.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 12 -- Most of the press and radio of the Arab Middle East expressed indignation today over President Bourguiba's statements here yesterday.
NEW HYDE PARK, L.I., March 12 -- Coach Red Sullivan inadvertently sent a puck careening off the boards and smashing into Rod Seiling's face today.

HARTSDALE, N.Y., March 12 -- A high school student was killed and six others were injured here this afternoon when a school bus caught fire and rolled out of control into a group who had fled the fire.

Three Hunter College student were held on narcotics charges yesterday as the result of a raid on a Bronx gathering Thursday night.

All three television networks provide continuous coverage this month of the two-man Gemini space flight in which Maj. Virgil I. Grissom of the Air Force and Lieut. Comdr. John W. Young of the Navy are to orbit the earth three times.

GEORGE CLEVE: 29 years old, born in Vienna, trained mostly in the United States, scholarship pupil at the Mannes College of Music here, pianist and violinist, pupil of Pierre Monteux and George Szell.
New York basketball will be on display again in Madison Square Garden today when the 28th annual National Invitation Tournament ends its first-round action with day and night double-headers.
The H.J. Heinz Company reported yesterday that consolidated sales and earnings for the nine months to Jan. 27 were the highest in the company's 96-year history.

Seiji Ozawa, assistant conductor of the New York Philharmonic, will direct next week's concerts, Friday at 2:15 P.M.; Saturday at 8:30 and Sunday at 3, all at Philharmonic Hall There will be no concert on Thursday.

As many as 150 Lower East Side youngsters are studying ballet, art, drama, fashions, singing or baton-twirling each week, thanks to the Blue Curtain Youth Foundation, an energetic body of people who have on their hands more children than money.
One thousand laborers who fought the City of New York through the courts to win a principle on their wage scales will divide about $3 million in back pay.
ALBANY, March 12 -- Governor Rockefeller vetoed today a bill that would have reinstated a mandatory free-tuition policy at the City University of New York.

NEW HAVEN, March 12 -- Louis H. Pollak, a professor of constitutional law who has been active in civil rights cases, was named yesterday as the new Dean of Yale University's Law School by Yale's President, Kingman Brewster Jr.
QUEBEC, March 12. -- A group of visiting United States newspaper editors was told today that French Canada is a "fact" without which Canada could not exist.

The handling of the Gareth Martinis case by District Attorney Isidore Dollinger of the Bronx will be severely criticized in a report to Governor Rockefeller by his special investigator, Herman Stichman.

BONN, March 12 -- West Germany affirmed today its determination to deliver no more arms to Israel.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- The Pentagon announced today a new type of defense contract for the projected new 700-passenger supertransport and cargo plane.
Erasmus Hall and DeWitt Clinton, the favorites, gained Tuesday's final round of the Public Schools Athletic League basketball tournament yesterday.

MANHATTAN, Kan., March 12 (AP) -- Wichita's Shockers, sparked by Kelly Pete, defeated Southern Methodist, 86 -- 81, tonight and advanced to the finals of the National Collegiate Athletic Association Midwest regional basketball championship.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., March 12 -- A 55-day strike of Lawrence Hospital workers for union recognition and a wage increase ended tonight without attainment of either goal but with a pledge that most of the strikers would be rehired.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 12 -- Gov. George C. Wallace tonight requested a meeting "at the earliest possible moment" with President Johnson in Washington to discuss the increasingly tense racial situation in Alabama.
TUCSON, Ariz., March 12 (AP) -- United States claims of monopoly and violation of antitrust laws in the purchase of The Arizona Daily Star by owners of The Tucson Daily Citizen were denied yesterday.

Edwin O. Reischauer, Ambassador to Japan, has rewritten the latter part of his book, "The United States and Japan," first published in 1950. Harvard University Press will issue the new edition on March 22. The Ambassador was a Harvard professor specializing in Far Eastern languages and Japanese history when he wrote the original work.

THE children in Central Park who scramble over the bronze statues of Alice in Wonderland and the Mad Hatter on fine summer days barely notice the small, well-tailored gentleman who watches them intently, smiles when they smile, and who was responsible for it all.

Elm trees can now be "inoculated" to protect them from elm bark beetles which spread the Dutch elm fungus. The new chemical, Bidrin, is a systemic insecticide that is injected into tree trunks in spring when the sap is running. As beetles emerge from their winter nesting sites in dead or dying elms, they fly to healthy elms to feed.

John Graham, a violist from California who is freelancing here, put together an interesting program at Carnegie Recital Hall yesterday afternoon.

BALTIMORE, March 14 (AP) -- Gus Johnson of the Baltimore Bullets arrived late for a National Basketball Association game with the Philadelphia 76ers today and was fined $500 by the general manager. Paul Hoffman. He was not allowed to suit up for the game, which the Bullets went on to win by 143-126.

But Churchill's greatness as a writer was not as widely stressed.
