OMAHA, March 15 (AP) -- At least 10 Omaha artists removed their paintings from the Governor's Art Show today as a protest after the sponsors withdrew the picture that had been awarded first plate and substituted another winner.

The New York City Opera Guild has arranged a reception and dinner for Saturday evening at the Seventh Regiment Armory at Park Avenue and 66th Street. Chartered buses will later take the informally attired guests to the Squadron A Armory at 94th Street and Madison Avenue for a polo program.

CLEVELAND, March 15 -- Jeff Rubens of New York and Lawrence Rosler of Murray Hill, N. J., triumphed in the Men's Pair Championship, which ended here late last night. They won by more than two boards, totaling 849 points at the end of the four-session event in which 430 pairs were entered.
WASHINGTON, March 15 -- The increase in the number of employed workers outside of agriculture continued strong in February, the Labor Department reported today.

ALBANY, March 15 -- A wallpaper scroll bearing the signatures of 20,000 residents of Brooklyn's Bedford-Stuyesant section was desposited today on Governor Rockefeller's doorstep; it demanded a moratorium on liquor stores in their neighborhood.
Marybeth Peil, soprano from Davenport, Iowa, made a most auspicious New York solo debut at Carnegie Recital Hall last night on the Young Concert Artists Series.

ALTHOUGH Sutton Place is reputed for its style as a neighborhood, it is not an area that abounds in distinguished dining places. The latest to establish itself in that vicinity is a restaurant with several commendable aspects.
Mayor Wagner accused Gov. George C. Wallace yesterday of using "camouflage and diversion" in attempting to compare the civil rights struggle in Selma with last summer's riots in New York.

BONN, March 15 -- West Germany's ambassadors will remain on post in the Middle East and redouble their efforts to talk the Arab governments out of "irretrievable" reprisals against Bonn for its pending recognition of Israel.

YONKERS, March 15 -- Not all of the money wagered on horse races in the metropolitan area today found its way into the mutuel machines at the Big A. Some of it was deposited in their mechanical counterparts at Yonkers Raceway, where 21,319 harness-racing buffs bet $2,176,972 tonight.
A $15 million suit, the second in the aftermath of the crash of an Eastern Air Lines plane off Jones Beach on Feb. 8, was filed yesterday in Federal Court, Brooklyn.
Although a record number of entries is expected, fewer places in the 1965 Unites States Open championship field will be available in qualifying trials.

Plans have been filed with the Department of Buildings for the north half of a middle-income residential development in the Tompkins Square urban renewal area bounded by 10th and 13th Streets and Avenues C and D.

WASHINGTON, March 15 (UPI) -- The Supreme Court ruled today that the National Labor Relations Board rather than state courts had jurisdiction over a union picketing dispute involving Mobile radio station WSIM.
A ripple of confidence over the balance-of-payments situation went through the bond market yesterday.
CAPETOWN, South Africa March 15 -- The South African Government announced today its strictest ruling yet concerning racial segregation at sports events.

In discussions about the bipartisan bills now before Congress, S.500 and H.R.2580, that propose revision of our basic immigration law, it is interesting that few people are objecting to the elimination of the discriminatory National Origins quota system, possibly because it would be embarrassing to defend such blatant racism today.

Supreme Court Justice Matthew M. Levy ruled yesterday that all four redistricting plans approved last December by the lame-duck Republican-controlled State Legislature violated the State Constitution. On Jan. 26 a special three-judge Federal Court found that three of the four plans violated the Federal Constitution.
After opening at a low of $2.7914, the British pound improved to close at $2.7922 on foreign exchange markets here yesterday.

KLM Royal Dutch Airlines whose stock has tripled in price during the last 12 months, reported yesterday a $4,196,000 net loss for 1964. This compared with a $15,370,000 net loss reported in 1963. About 70 per cent of the company's stock is owned by the Netherlands Government.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- The annual informal meeting of leading central bankers and other financial officials, sponsored by the American Bankers Association, will take place this week in Princeton, N.J.

WASHINGTON, March 15 (AP) -- The Pentagon said today the states were accepting the controversial plan to merge Army Reserve units into the National Guard. But its report was described by a Congressman as inaccurate, double-talk and "press agent semantics."
The Ashland Oil and Refining Company of Ashland, Ky., announced yesterday it would increase its price for benzene by 1 cent a gallon on April 1.
LONDON, March 15 -- Thousands of Londoners traveled to work on the honor system today, dropping their fares into buckets, boxes and cartons at subway stations.
A basic split among leaders of New York's 700,000 Puerto Ricans over plans for an antipoverty program was emphasized yesterday.
Nedick's Stores Inc., will go nationwide if merger negotiations now under way are consummated.

IN the race to get the Paris haute couture designs copied for their customers, Ohrbach's is not afraid to be last. Macy's and Alexander's, its chief competitors in the tricky business of line-for-line copying, disclosed their purchases last week.
WASHINGTON, March 15 -- President Johnson's doctors have urged him to set aside regular days for relaxation and to follow faithfully a program of exercise.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 15 -- Israel has asked for membership in the United Nations Regional Economic Commission for Asia and the Far East.

Irene Dalis and Jerome Hines will not sing as scheduled in the Metropolitan Opera's performance of "Aida" Saturday afternoon, and Giuletta Simionato has canceled all her Metropolitan as well as her other New York appearances scheduled for this season.
American merchant seamen continue to suffer accidents or illness at an "appalingly high rate, the Marine Index Bureau reported here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- The Alliance for Progress quietly marked its fourth anniversary last weekend with specialists here in general agreement that it has scored considerable achievements despite many unavoidable weaknesses.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 15 -- United States Air Force jets joined Navy bombers from the Seventh Fleet and flew deep into North Vietnam this afternoon to bomb an ammunition depot 100 miles south of Hanoi.

The man who directs urban renewal in Boston came to New York City yesterday and said that the city "ought to throw away coordination as a system" of running urban renewal projects and create a single, Boston-style agency to do the job.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- The Supreme Court turned down today the Government's plea that it make a quick decision on whether to review the dismissal of part of the indictments in the killing of three civil rights workers in Mississippi last summer.
THE most provocative thing about "The Day the Whores Came Out to Play Tennis" is the title.

MILWAUKEE, March 15 (UPI) -- Robin Lingle of the University of Missouri ran the fastest 1,000 yards indoors this season, and John Camion of Emporia State equaled his best mile time tonight in the third annual United States Track and Field Federation championships.

SAIGON, March 15 (Reuters) -- South Vietnamese authorities called off today a plan to deport three leaders of a peace movement said to be Communist-controlled. The plan was to drop them into North Vietnam by parachute.
The last of the cynical and politically oriented reapportionment measures passed by the lame-duck Republican Legislature in December has now been swept from the statute books by court decision.
LISBON, March 15 -- Portugal entered her fifth year of guerrilla war in Africa today confident that, although the end is not in sight, she holds the upper hand.

YONKERS, March 15 -- The Otis Elevator Company, which is the largest employer in this city, said today it would eliminate from its local payroll 26 per cent of the 2,100 employes. Efforts of state officials to alter the decision have failed.
WASHINGTON, March 15 (AP) -- The House passed today two bills aimed at bolstering bank credit available to farmers. Both bills now go to the Senate.
Faculty and students at St. John's University joined yesterday in a caustic attack on the university administration. The theme was academic freedom.

WARSAW, March 15 -- Martha Argerich of Argentina won the Seventh Frederic Chopin Piano Competition today. Arturo Moreira-Lima of Brazil was second in a competition in which no one from the Western Hemisphere had ever reached the finals before.
The policy you advocate in your March 14 editorial on Alabama is little more than that followed with horrifying failure by Eisenhower, Kennedy and now by Johnson.
ALBANY, March 15 -- Governor Rockefeller took issue with Robert Moses today on the controversial question of a bridge across Long Island Sound.
John T. Connor, Secretary of Commerce, told businessmen last night the Administration program to combat the balance of payments deficit would succeed.

In The Times of March 7 Jack Langguth writes about the use of napalm in South Vietnam and quotes a "senior American officer" who remarked that "the public seems to have this aversion to napalm because people think it kinder to blast a man's head off than to fry him to death."

THE first day of spring has not yet arrived and summer is officially months away, but many swimming instructors and parents are planning now for seashore safety for thousands of children by giving them pool lessons.

VERO BEACH, Fla., March 15 -- Only Houston and the dear old Mets scored fewer runs than the Dodgers last season as the Hollywood hotshots plunged from the eminence of a four-game sweep of the Yankees in the 1963 World Series to a dolorous tie for sixth place in 1964. Since that shocking misadventure, Los Angeles has traded away its only genuine power hitter, Frank Howard, to bolster an already glittering pitching staff.
IN England, the reviews of Saul Bellow's "Herzog" have been less awe-stricken than they were in America last year. British reviewers have been able to keep off their knees.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., March 15 (AP) -- Sister M. Margaret Bealmear, a Benedictine nun studying for a doctorate in physiology at the University of Notre Dame, said today she was declining an invitation to apply for astronaut training.
Can Nikita S. Khrushchev make a comeback ?
Representative John V. Lindsay depreciated yesterday a campaign to draft him to run for Mayor and repeated that he was not a candidate.

PLEIKU, South Vietnam, March 14 -- In the rapidly developing campaign for control of the central highlands the Vietcong have gathered the largest striking force they have ever had in this strategically vital area of South Vietnam.
History partially repeated itself in the Argentine Congressional elections just held. The Peronists made another comeback.
LONDON, March 15 -- A letter, reported to have been smuggled from a prison in Ghana, was delivered today to 10 Downing Street, the Prime Minister's residence.
TAOS, N.M., March 15 (AP) -- Jean Meyer, a 27-year-old Taos ski lodge operator, broke his Taos Ski Valley marathon record yesterday by skiing 97,200 vertical feet in seven hours.
DETROIT, March 15 (AP) -- United States auto assembly lines moved in high gear this week as the industry aimed at a record output of five million cars for the first half of calendar 1965.

Harvard University Press will issue on March 29 a new edition of "Tottel's Miscellany," edited by Hyder Edward Rollins. This is a revision of an edition published in 1928-29. "Tottel's Miscellany," correctly known as "Songs and Sonnets," was published by Richard Tottel in 1557.

A young Negro named Laplois Ashford, a native of McCool, Miss., organized a demonstration three and a half years ago in Rochester, his adopted home. He led a march on police headquarters to protest what was termed police brutality.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 15 -- Communist China made more substantial economic gains in 1964 than in any other year since the drastic reverses of 1959-61, the Economic Commission for Asia and the Far East has reported in an annual survey of the region.

The results of France's nationwide municipal elections failed to produce a clear-cut trend for or against the regime of President de Gaulle. Despite a very large turnout, there were few important changes. The "apolitical" Gaullists held on to most of the positions that they already controlled, but the same was true for the traditional political parties opposed to the Fifth Republic.
The election of Raymond L. Brittenham as a director of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation was announced yesterday by Harold S. Geneen, chairman and president.

NEW DELHI, March 15 -- Opposition members charged the Government of Prime Minister Lal Bahadur Shastri today with supression of vital information and "political chicanery" in dealing with charges of corruption against the chiefs of the Orissa State government.
Oklahoma County, Okla., sold $4.7 million of improvement bonds yesterday to an underwriting syndicate headed by the First National Bank of Chicago.

A group of upper West Side businessmen complained to Deputy Mayor Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. yesterday that city policies encouraged narcotics addicts, alcoholics, prostitutes and other social misfits to concentrate in the area.
Heavy profit taking developed in the stock market in the final hour of trading yesterday and prices on the New York Stock Exchange closed mixed in active trading.
Two airline issues received most of the attention on the American Stock Exchange yesterday. The rest of the market closed slightly up in active trading.

Shortly before 10 A.M. yesterday a small group of men gathered on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange, just below the members' gallery. They were there for a very special occasion, at least for them. Few others on the already busy floor, however, took notice of their presence.
The city's 741 warning sirens will be tested today at 11 A.M., Robert E. Condon, Civil Defense director, announced yesterday.

An exquisite pagoda, a towering bodhisattva, clusters of Buddhistic votive monuments and other gems of fifth to seventh century Chinese art are the sparse occupants of a huge gallery opening today at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

In the grandstand after the first race, a loser juggled a stack of worthless daily-double tickets in the palm of his hand and shook his head like a prospector who had come up with a panful of fool's gold.
PIRAEUS, Greece, March 15 (Reuters) -- Queen Anne-Marie of Greece christened after her own name today the 26,300-ton former Canadian liner Empress of Britain.
The Long Island Expressway is being given a 30-day deep cleaning by six city departments, the Department of Highways announced yesterday.
The defending champions in the women's pairs and mixed pairs retained their titles Sunday in the 43d annual Middle Atlantic figure-skating championships at Iceland Rink atop Madison Square Garden.

The news division of the Columbia Broadcasting System is negotiating to obtain Theodore H. White's forthcoming documentary film, "The Making of the President 1964," for televising next fall. The film, being produced by David L. Wolper in association with the author, will be a pictorial account of Mr. White's reporting of the election campaign between President Johnson and Senator Barry Goldwater.
ALBANY, March 15 -- The State Board of Social Welfare said today it would postpone a vote on a controversial plan to supply birth-control information to unmarried persons on relief.
SYDNEY, Australia, March 15 -- Sir Robert Menzies, Australia's Prime Minister, will ask President Johnson to soften United States efforts to reduce American business expenditures to Australia.
A Times Square theater draped a canvas yesterday over an eight-story drawing of a nude, reclining Jane Fonda that advertised her lates film, "Circle of Love."
The Ford Motor Company announced yesterday a new system for handling visitors to its World's Fair Pavilion.
The Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company has set aside between $250,000 and $500,000 for the legal expenses of fighting a Government antitrust suit.
PITTSBURGH, March 15 (UPI) -- Steel contract talks continued today on local issues, advancing in some areas and stalling in others.

For the second time in less than five years, a consortium of West German banks has agreed to float a $62.5 million loan for the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank), it was announced yesterday.
LONDON, March 15 -- Concern is growing here about the course of United States action in Vietnam.

QUEBEC, March 15 -- "The French language and our French traditions are more important to us than anything -- even prosperity," the president of the 5,000-member Laval University Students Union said today.
WASHINGTON, March 15 (AP) -- The police carried 11 sit-in demonstrators out of the Capitol today as the building was being prepared for President Johnson's appearance before Congress.
PARIS, March 15 -- Mrs. Golda Meir, Israel's Foreign Minister, predicted today that a large majority of the Knesset would approve the establishment of diplomatic relations with West Germany.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- The Administration's bill to extend the Federal power to state elections, with Federal penalties for discrimination by individuals and groups, was being constantly retouched today. This was prudent, because the bill would reverse precedents deeply embedded in the constitutional and political history of the United States.
BONN, March 15 -- The Bundestag, or lower house of Parliament, announced today it would meet in plenary session in West Berlin April 7.
PEKING, March 15 -- China gave fresh proof today of the student confidence with which it views world affairs.
CAIRO, March 15 -- A diplomatic showdown between the Arab states and West Germany over the latter's plans to recognize Israel is expected to produce a new "no Germany" policy by several countries.

On the theory that 17-year-old Andrew A. Mormile might have been slain in the subway last Friday night because he tried to protect three young Negro girls, the police appealed to them yesterday for help.

MOSCOW, March 15 -- The Soviet Union, in identical notes to the United States, Britain and France, expressed the hope today that the three governments would insure that German war criminals on West German territory were brought to trial and punished.
The first concrete was poured yesterday for the new Madison Square Garden and an adjoining 29-story office building on the site of Pennsylvania Station.

Straus-Duparquet, Inc., a 113-year old company that designs, builds and installs foodservice equipment and interiors for restaurants, hotels and institutions, filed a Chapter XI bankruptcy petition yesterday.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Tuesday, March 16 (AP) -- A Communist mob staged another anti-American demonstration today and proclaimed that it had seized the offices of three American film companies.

After the leadership struggle in the Legislature was decided early last month, feuding Democrats talked a lot about closing ranks in the party. They hoped that damage to the party's prestige, incurred after Democratic control of the Legislature had been won for the first time in 30 years, might be repaired by joining on constructive legislation.

HONG KONG, March 15 -- A Peking newspaper accused the Soviet Government today of being subservient to the United States. The criticism was a new Chinese Communist attack on Moscow following the suppression of a student demonstration against the United States earlier this month and the alleged ill treatment of Chinese participants.

ONE of the most persistently vexing problems of the shooting sport is that a target match, as dull a thing to watch as one could hope to avoid. Paradoxically, it's as exciting as any other sport -and more so than some -- in which to participate.

During the Northern California floods last December, a Red Cross boat made a hazardous trip up the roaring Klamath River, reaching the isolated Indian village of Pecwan, with 400 pounds of food and blankets.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- The United States and the European Common Market have reached agreement after months of deadlock on a negotiating procedure and schedule for the agricultural side of the Kennedy round of trade negotiations, United States officials disclosed today.

WHATEVER the higher courts may ultimately do with yesterday's State Supreme Court decision on legislative reapportionment, nobody will accuse Justice Matthew Malitz Levy of treating the case casually.
WASHINGTON, March 15 -- The Supreme Court today held, in effect, that New York State's movie censorship procedures were unconstitutional.
Following is a transcript of President Johnson's address on voting rights to a joint session of Congress last night, as recorded by The New York Times:
LONDON, March 15 -- Queen Elizabeth met the Duchess of Windsor this evening for the first time since the abdication crisis in 1936.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether the Sherman Antitrust Act forbids an automobile manufacturer and dealers' associations to prevent the sale of automobiles through discount houses and referral services.

Mrs. Ella Collins, a half-sister of Malcolm X, said yesterday she had taken over the leadership of the Organization of Afro-American Unity, of which the murdered black nationalist leader was chairman.

The executive committee of the New York State Council of School Superintendents has expressed concern over the manner in which the City Board of Education deposed Dr. Calvin E. Gross as Superintendent of Schools.

A grant of $2,500 has been made by the New York Foundation to the New Dramatists Committee, a nonprofit group that trains aspiring playwrights. The money will enable playwrights to attend rehearsals as observers.

An experimental housing project that will substitute the social bustle of a village market square or a city stoop for the drab open spaces that now mark many housing developments is planned for the Southeast Bronx.

On its home ground last night, the American Ballet Theater attempted to repay the hospitality tendered it abroad. United Nations diplomats from the countries the company has visited on tour were invited to the New York State Theater for the opening night of the company's 25th anniversary season.

ATLANTIC CITY, March 16 (AP) -- The Glass Bottle Blowers Association announced today that its members had rejected new contract proposals, signaling a strike in the nation's glass container industry Thursday.
More than 1,000 representations of manufacturers heard Pentagon officials outline the nation's military needs for the next decade and offer guidance in planning defense contracts.
MINEOLA, L.I., March 16 -- The village of Old Westbury was ordered in State Supreme Court here today to permit the New York Institute of Technology to establish its main campus on a former estate.
ALBANY, March 16 -- After almost four years of study a special state commission submitted a completely rewritten Penal Code to the Legislature today.

NAIROBI, Kenya, March 16 -- Vice President Jaramogi Ajuma Oginga Odinga declared today that the "selfish capitalistic" powers of the West should not seek to carry on their ideological warfare with the East in Africa.
RIO DE JANEIRO, March 16 -- David Rockefeller, president of the Chase Manhattan Bank, said today a unified Latin American market would improve conditions for United States investments in this area.

The El Paso Natural Gas Company has reported gains in operating revenues and net income for 1964. Gas sales volume rose to a high of 1.36 trillion cubic feet during the year, an increase of 8 per cent over the record set in 1960.
SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, March 16 -- There are signs in Haiti that President Francois Duvalier may proclaim himself emperor of Haiti this year.
WASHINGTON, March 16 -- Women members of the American Jewish Congress meeting in convention here today gave their unanimous endorsement to President Johnson's call for full voting rights for Negroes.
The city will need additional tax revenue even if it receives the increased aid proposed by Governor Rockefeller, Budget Director William F. Shea said yesterday.

TAMPA, Fla., March 16 -- Jesse Owens won his first game for the New York Mets today when one of his star pupils, Ran Hunt, stole home with the bases loaded and two out in the ninth inning to defeat the Cincinnati Reds, 5-4.
Representative Adam Clayton Powell won a tactical victory yesterday in his legal fight to avoid paying $262,000 arising out of a defamation of character suit.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- Secretary of Commerce John T. Connor made public today a letter sent to 632 corporations detailing the new voluntary program for reducing the deficit in the nation's balance of international payments.

DESIGNS from the boutiques of Paris couturiers have been added to the Plaza Collections at Bergdorf Goodman, which also include the store's favorite ready-to-wear designers of long standing -- Bernard Newman and Gigliola Curiel of Milan.
Printers and publishers of seven metropolitan daily newspapers broke off negotiations temporarily yesterday after an all-night bargaining session failed to produce agreement on the automation issue.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange edged off yesterday in quiet trading.
PARIS, March 16 -- The Allied Mobile Force is an "important deterrent" to Communist attack on the northern and eastern flanks of the Atlantic alliance, Gen. Lyman L. Lemnitzer declared today.

CHATTANOOGA, March 16 (AP) -- One of the oldest and one of the youngest Presbyterian groups in America will be merged April 6 at Covenant College on Lookout Mountain, church officials announced today.

You are quite right in your March 3 editorial "Cuba Is Still There" in decrying the "Cuban wall." The ideological battle which rages over any statement of the situation in Cuba can only be overcome by first-hand study.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., March 16 -- When the Milwaukee Braves' bus rolled into Veto Beach the other day to open the Grapefruit League season, the visiting firemen were greeted by Fresco Thompson, the Merry Andrew who is a vice president of the Los Angeles Dodgers.
HONG KONG, March 16 -- Peking sent a second protest note to Moscow today denouncing "shameless suppression" of a student demonstration against the United States in Moscow on March 4.
VALHALLA, N.Y., March 16 -- To show the effects of drinking on drivers, state officials here plied a young woman with three double shots of whisky before lunchtime today.

The monthly meeting of the Jamaica-Queens County Real Estate Board will be held at noon next Wednesday at the Young Men's Christian Association at 89-25 Parsons Boulevard in Jamaica, Queens. The guest speaker will be Albert J. Grace, a loan guaranty officer, who will discuss Veterans Administration mortgages.
In view of all the emphasis these days on the youth market, the results or an exploratory study just completed by the Brand Names Foundation, Inc., might well have an aging effect on some ad men.
LONDON, March 16 -- A 52-year-old civil servant in the guided weapons division of the Ministry of Aviation was charged in court today with violation of the Official Secrets Act.
MOSCOW, March 16 -- The Soviet Union disclosed today the establishment of a centralized civil defense organization to prepare the populace against missile attack in a thermonuclear war.

TORONTO, March 16 -- A University of Toronto scientist reported tonight what was described as evidence of a biochemical link between smoking and cancer. Previous connections have been based mainly on statistical studies.
The police sent out an alarm yesterday for the arrest of a 17-year-old drifter wanted in the slaying of a schoolboy in a subway car in Brooklyn last Friday night.

OTTAWA, March 16 (Canadian Press) -- A suggestion that there were irregularities in the federally supervised election held last fall by the Seafarers International Union of Canada was made before a House of Commons committee today.
POINT LOOKOUT, L.I., March 16 -- A 180-foot steel, silver-blue water tower across from Hempstead's town park has drawn compliments from residents and visitors here.
A new edition of "This Was Burlesque," the satirical revue starring Ann Corio, opened last night at the Hudson Theater, 141 West 44th Street.
Matters were formful at Aqueduct yesterday, in that the turnout for the second day of the local thoroughbred season approximated the figures of last year's opening day.

TRENTON, March 16 -- The New Jersey Supreme Court heard arguments today on the question of whether an advertised day camp for youngsters is a "public accommodation" subject to the state antidiscrimination law.
President Johnson and his family will attend a special performance by John Gielgud of his one-man Shakespearean program, "Ages of Man," on March 29 in the State Department's Auditorium in Washington.

ON Jan. 11, 1940, a new and exciting era American dance history began with the debut of Ballet Theater at the Center Theater in Rockefeller Center. Last night the American Ballet Theater, as it is now called, moved into the New York State Theater to begin a month-long performing celebration of its 25th anniversary.

The telephone rang at 11:30 P.M. and William Borst knew before he answered who would be on the other end -- it was his week for duty as a Red Cross volunteer night driver. A young father had been gravely injured in a collision on Grand Central Parkway.
BRUSSELS, March 16 -- George Meany Charged the staff of the International Confederation of Free Trade Unions today with financial irregularities.
The Banks for Cooperatives are offering today a new issue of $175 million of 4 1/4 per cent debentures dated April 1, 1965, and maturing Oct. 4, 1965. They are priced at 100.
WASHINGTON, March 16 -- New York State has engaged Thomas E. Dewey to argue its legislative reapportionment case, or cases, in the United States Supreme Court.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, March 16 (AP) -- Danish demonstrators, protesting the presence of West German soldiers temporarily on Danish soil for Atlantic alliance maneuvers, threw themselves in front of a German convoy today and swarmed over an army jeep leading the convoy.
Shareholders of the One William Street Fund, which eliminated its sales charge last July 20, heard cautiously optimistic words at the annual meeting yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, March 16 (AP) -- General proposals, including some touching on the key issue of total job security, were made for the first time today in the basic-steel labor negotiations that resumed last week after a two-month recess.
The State Commission of Corrections will consider tomorrow a request for a hearing whether to close the New York City Women's House of Detention.
When it comes to subsidies, cotton takes the cake. The American taxpayer is now doling out about $800 million a year in three different subsidies on cotton.

YONKERS, March 16 -- Because too few higher-grade trotters at Yonkers Raceway are fit to race at this time of year, the second annual Rodney Festival, scheduled to start the night of March 25, has been set back until the summer meeting.
LONDON, March 13 -- "I never liked the word horror," Boris Karloff said, "it should have been terror. They needed a word to describe what we were filming, but they just picked the wrong one."

Vladimir Horowitz is planning to return to the concert stage, ending a 12-year self-imposed retirement. The date has not been set, but the 60-year-old pianist may begin personal appearances in the spring or fall.
A self-exiled Vietnamese began a fast yesterday in a Brooklyn church and said he was prepared to continue it until his death if peace was not restored in his homeland.

BY accident or design, the two important novelties in the program of the National Orchestral Association in Carnegie Hall last night were written by Europeans who emigrated to the United States, eventually settling on the West Coast.
QUEBEC, March 16 -- "You know, they are building Manicouagan in French," a proud Quebecker said today.
TOKYO, March 16 (UPI) -- Masanori Murakami, whose homesickness endangered American-Japanese baseball relations will retrain to pitch for the San Francisco Giants this season.
LONDON -- Sir Leon Bagrit is a sprightly, cultured man who once played the violin in the London Philharmonic and who loves to surround himself with books and fine works of sculpture.
WASHINGTON, March 16 -- The Senate approved today a $454 million bill to extend and expand the training of unemployed persons to fit them for jobs and to Improve their skills. The vote was 76 to 8.

Army and New York University eliminated Western Kentucky and Detroit and advanced to the semi-finals of the 28th National Invitation Tournament last night before a crowd of 14,180 at Madison Square Garden.
THIS is a great day -- or at least a green one -- for the Irish. Green flowers are sprouting from buttonholes; green hats from heads, and green foods assault the palate.
PHILADELPHIA, March 16 (UPI) -- The San Francisco Warriors rallied to defeat the Philadelphia 76ers, 115-107, tonight.

FRANKFURT, Germany, March 16 -- A $62.5 million loan floated in West Germany by the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development today is only the beginn ing of the World Bank's capital raising efforts in Europe this year.
The New York Central Railroad, once the owner of 29 per cent of the Reading Company's voting stock, disclosed yesterday that it had liquidated its entire interest.

WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP) -- The establishment of sea-grants colleges dedicated to the exploitation of ocean resources was proposed today by Dr. Athelstan Spilhaus, dean of the University of Minnesota's Institute of Technology and past chairman of the National Academy of Sciences.
Price erosion was more apparent yesterday on the London Stock Exchange, where a downward trend has persisted with only occasional interruption since the British elections last fall.
Boris Gresov, the Russian-born, Cambridge-educated mining engineer who resigned as chairman of the Standard Metal Corporation on Jan. 31, was back at his old job yesterday.
Federal Judge Sidney Sugarman yesterday acquitted Robert Neaderland, president of Pease Elliman, Inc., a leading real estate concern, of charges of income tax evasion.
There were some unexpected victories yesterday as residents of 45 New York suburban communities voted on local issues.

CHICAGO, March 16 -- With the announcement of the Administration's new proposals for farm commodity programs expected in a few days, farmers are at each other's throats again over the proper role of Government in agriculture.
Willy Brandt, Mayor of West Berlin, will be the principal speaker at the opening day ceremonies for the 1965 season at the World's Fair.
RIO DE JANEIRO, March 16 -- Civilian protests against the Brazilian revolutionary Government's police methods are rising.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 16--Just when it seemed that the New York Yankees were about to lose a game after all, five of their younger players took things in hand. They produced a five-run rally in the last half of the ninth inning and defeated the Pittsburgh Pirates, 6-5.

A hook-and-ladder fire truck responding to a fire alarm that turned out to be false collided with a station wagon in downtown Brooklyn last evening and crashed against the southwest wall of the Criminal Courts Building at 210 Schermerhorn Street.

WASHINGTON, March 16 (UPI) -- A co-sponsor of the American Medical Association's bill on health care for the elderly said today that the association had tried to "oversell" the bill to the public and Congress.

About 1,000 students and faculty members of Fordham University participated yesterday in an outdoor rally protesting the "denial of voting rights in Alabama" and honoring the Rev. James J. Reeb, the white minister fatally beaten in Selma, Ala., as "a civil rights martyr of Selma."

Television set prices may be headed downward for both color and black-and-white units, according to an announcement yesterday from Radio Corporation of America. The giant electronics maker cut the price of a 19-inch portable monochrome set by $10, to $139.95.

There is wider significance than first meets the eye in the news that the Soviet Union has joined the signatories of the 1883 Paris agreement that facilitates international protection of property rights in patents and trademarks.
THE following menu is suggested as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A recipe is given for the easy-to-prepare main dish.

WASHINGTON, March 16--At no time since the New Deal, and probably not even then, has this country had such a clear sense of Government purpose on the home front as it has today.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 16 -- United States Navy pilots who flew into North Vietnam yesterday skid today that the large ammunition depot they struck would not be of much use to anyone for a long time.

Robert B. Blaikie, insurance broker and former West Side Democratic leader, charged yesterday that "an unholy combine" existed in the dairy industry that was "milking and mulcting the public."

WHEN Jerry Goldfarb and Terry Ryan were looking for a site for a fashion boutique they wanted to open called Splendiferous, they had trouble finding a landlord who did not consider them irresponsible.

Mrs. Pierrette Daniels, wife of Billy Daniels, the entertainer, was booked on charges of felonious assault and violation of the weapons law yesterday after she allegedly fired a revolver in her apartment.

The Committee for Modern Courts proposed yesterday that the Mayor's Committee on the Judiciary be given the status of a permanent commission that would screen all appointments by the Mayor to the bench.

CAIRO, March 16 -- A spokesman for the West German Embassy said today the Government here had indicated that German citizens would be allowed to stay in the United Arab Republic if relations between Bonn and Cairo were broken.

SAIGON, March 16 (AP) -- An air raid today drove 200 Vietcong troops from Xomtruong, a village 15 miles south of Saigon. Four Government battalions went in to clear the area, on the upper outskirts of the Mekong delta.
The Harlem Cultural Council yesterday announced plans for a five-week arts festival in the uptown area. It probably will begin in October.

HARTFORD, March 16 -- Gov. John N. Dempsey signed today a bill providing for a bond issue of $5 million as Connecticut's share of a $20 million Federal-state program of assistance to the New Haven Railroad.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 16 (AP) -- Gov. George C. Wallace today granted voter-registration boards 10 extra days to process voter applications in six Alabama counties, including Dallas, whose county seat is Selma.

ATHENS, March 16 -- A new Cyprus crisis appeared to be developing tonight following reports that a shipment of So viet antiaircraft missiles to the Greek Cypriotes had prompted Turkish threats to bomb the island.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), March 16 -- In a leaden atmosphere, the Knesset today endorsed the Cabinet's decision to establish diplomatic relations with West Germany.

PALM SPRINGS, Calif., March 14 -- Winter residents of this luxurious desert retreat, normally a chauvinistic lot, sadly acknowledged and unexpected rainstorms this week that they had endured, on the whole, a cool, cloudy winter, quite unlike the balmy seasons of years past.
Potato futures prices dropped sharply again yesterday, but managed to recover half of the declines by the close of trading. Prices at the close were down 2 to 16 cents a hundredweight.

SELMA, Ala., March 16 -- Sheriff James G. Clark Jr. finally did what he said he would never do. He permitted a massive demonstration at the Dallas County Courthouse that blocked both the street and the sidewalk.
VAIL, Colo., March 16 (AP) -- Hugo Nindl of Austria took the men's crown anti Marielle Goitschel of France captured the women's title today in the Vail international trophy slalom races.

ATLANTA, March 16 (UPI) -- The Atlanta Times told its stockholders today that new capital must be raised immediately if the afternoon newspaper is to continue.

TOKYO, March 16 A top-level group of Japanese Government officials, legislators and businessmen is pushing ahead with plans for an ambitious art and cultural exhibition to be held in New York and other American cities at the end of this year.
A "retrofit" program for 88 American merchant vessels, designed to make the ships competitive with the most automated freighters afloat, ran into a dead end yesterday.
Civil rights leaders hailed President Johnson's voting rights address as eloquent and historic yesterday.

PARIS, March 15 -- The French Government, which derives 4 to 5 per cent of its income from the profits of its tobacco monopoly, is remaining silent while Governments throughout the world are intensifying their warnings about the health dangers in smoking cigarettes.
WASHINGTON, March 16 -- Under Secretary of State George W. Ball suggested today that France was undermining the efforts of nations carrying the "common burden" of the free world.

The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation raised its net income in 1964 to a record total of $45,108,000, from $43,254,000 the year before, despite a 20.5 per cent sales drop and rising expenditures in research and other areas.

Willie Pastrano, the light-heavyweight champion of the world signed yesterday to defend his title for a guarantee of $100,000 and Emile Griffith, the welterweight king, signed to defend his crown for $75,000.

THE Sebring, Fla., 12-hour race, to be run on March 27 from 10 A.M. to 10 P.M., is a rather complicated contest, in which the cars are divided into three main categories and nine classes. The topmost honor will not necessarily go to the first over-all finisher. As of yesterday there were 5'0 entries for the 12-. hour race.
WASHINGTON, March 16 (UPI) -- The House Judiciary Committee opened for business today in its new Rayburn Building quarters. The first reaction of members was less than enthusiastic.

" Captain Kangaroo," the children's program starring Bob Keeshan, will be discontinued by the Columbia Broadcasting System in September after a run of 10 years. It is televised from 8 to 9 A.M., Mondays through Fridays.
WASHINGTON, March 16 -- The Federal Reserve index of industrial production recorded another substantial gain in February.
THE World Crafts Council, an infant organization founded less than a year ago, took on adult status yesterday when it became the newest member of UNESCO.
WASHINGTON, March 16 -- The Johnson Administration was reported today to be studying a wide-ranging plan for granting preferential tariff treatment to Latin America's exports.
The British pound remained steady yesterday on foreign exchange markets here. After opening slightly under its Monday rate of $2.7922, the spot rate on the pound closed at $2.7923.
United Press International and the wire service unit of the American Newspaper Guild agreed yesterday on a new two-year contract providing wage increases for 1,000 employes.

NICOSIA, Cyprus March 16 -- Sporadic fighting, between Greek Cypriote national guards-broke out yesterday and continued today in the village of Ambelikou near the northern mining town of Lefka. One Turkish Cypriote was reported to have been seriously wounded in the shooting.

Cosmopolitan magazine added an "expert" on the problems of the single girl and sex to its executive roster yesterday when it named Helen Gurley Brown as editor. Mrs. Brown succeeds Robert C. Atherton, who was named international editor of Hearst magazines.

SELMA, Ala., March 16 -- The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. heaped praise on President Johnson and his proposed voting rights legislation today. But he called for continued demonstrations until the Administration bill becomes law.
HARTFORD, March 16 -- The University of Connecticut disclosed details today of its proposed $47.3 million combination medical and dental school to be built in nearby Farmington.

SURABAYA, Indonesia, March 16 -- A struggle for power between the Communist party and an informal alliance of Moslem and nationalist parties in East Java is growing in violence. Beatings, knifings, burning of homes and mob clashes have become almost daily occurrences throughout the province.
Some members of the City Planning Commission expressed displeasure yesterday over pressures that had been exerted on them to abandon an urban renewal plan for Staten Island.
ALBANY, March 16 -- Members of the New York City Board of Education came here today to do their own lobbying for increased state aid to education.
LOS ANGELES, March 16 (AP) -- Pancho Gonzalez was named today coach of the Davis Cup tennis team. He coached the successful United States team two years ago.
