ST. LOUIS March 17 (UPI) -- The St. Louis Hawks made a sweep of 10 games against the San Francisco Warriors, winning the final National Basketball Association game tonight against Coach Alex Hannum's club, 101-94.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- While the New York Central Railroad this week liquidated the last of its holdings of Reading Company stock, an old Central adversary, the Chesapeake Ohio Railway has strengthened an indirect interest it has in the Reading.
DALLAS, March 17 (AP) -- The first test-firing of the Army's new battlefield missile, the Lance, at the White Sands range in New Mexico was called highly successful here today.
Prices of most issues on the American Stock Exchange eased irregularly yesterday as the trading pace continued to slacken for the second consecutive day.
PRESIDENT JOHNSON'S drive to see the U.S.A. first will be sabotaged by the unfettered women of America starting April 5.

PALM BEACH, Fla. -- There's something more to Palm Beach's young women than long legs, white teeth and pretty faces. They are incredibly accomplished dancers, for instance, and they know what to do with their hair.
LONDON, March 17 -- Britain's newest ballet company. London Dance Theater, started its first season tonight in London's West End at the Vaudeville Theater.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- The Democratic majority of the Joint Economic Committee of Congress suggested today that Government policy should supply more stimulus to the economy this year than proposed by the Administration.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., March 17 (AP) -- A group of University of Michigan faculty members, condemned by the State Senate for planning a one-day classroom strike, announced today that members would seek permission for their absences from the university's board of regents.
Noramco, Inc., a Waukesha, Wis., holding company, announced yesterday the election of Victor L. Anfuso Jr. as a director.
Marshall Field Co., the big Chicago organization store, had earnings in the fiscal year ended Jan. 31 of $12,441,000, up 33 per cent from the 1963 profit of $9,368,000.
HOUSTON, March 17 -- The president of the National District Attorneys' Association called today for the abolition of capital punishment as the organization opened winter conference here.
WASHINGTON, March 17 -- (AP) -- If you want to earn top money, be a doctor, lawyer or merchant chief.
A persistent rumor along Wall Street that Britain would lower her bank discount rate today to 6 1/2 per cent from 7 per cent sparked a late rally yesterday in the bond market.

RIVERVALE, N.J., March 17 -- A silent color film made by a police lieutenant of a drunken driver suspect under examination at police headquarters has been admitted as evidence by a magistrate here. The case will provide the first court test in New Jersey of the legality of movie films in such cases.
RIO DE JANEIRO, March 17 -- An opposition politician who was released by Gov. Carlos Lacerda from arrest was back in jail today by order of an army commander.
The election of Hoyt Ammidon and Dale E. Sharp as directors of the Continental Insurance Company was announced at the annual stockholder meeting yesterday.

Fewer shows went on tour this season than last, according to statistics supplied yesterday by the Theater Guild-American Theater Society and National Performing Arts, Inc., subscription organizations that cater to out-of-town patrons.
" Keep 14th Street green -- Bring Money," urges a sign over a toy and novelties shop on that "street of bargains."
Jackie Robinson, the first Negro to play major league baseball, became the first of his race yesterday to be hired as a baseball commentator by a television network.
Rapid-American Corporation, which has a 51 per cent control of McCrory Corporation, is negotiating to acquire Inland Credit Corporation, a commercial finance and factoring company.

The 16-story apartment house at 41 Park Avenue -- one of the avenue's first post-war buildings -- has been sold by the estate of Louis Cowan to the Downing Management Corporation. The building at the northeast corner of 36th Street, was sold for cash over a first mortgage of $1,078,000.
ATLANTIC CITY, March 17 (AP) -- Members of the Glass Bottle Blowers Association went on strike tonight after they failed to agree with management negotiators on terms for a new contract.
Frank Wille, New York State's Superintendent of Banks, has removed a disadvantage that state-chartered commercial banks have suffered in comparison with national banks.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- Senate investigators were told today that James J. Saxon, the Controller of the Currency, knew of activities that were probably illegal at the now-defunct San Francisco National Bank eight months before he turned the information over to the Justice Department.
WASHINGTON, March 17 -- The House of Representatives refused today to give the Chief Justice and his associates on the Supreme Court $3,000 pay increases.
MOSCOW, March 17 -- The Moscow authorities are conducting a campaign against sidewalk peddlers, who create bottlenecks on city streets.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 17 -- Civil rights leaders won a public apology from the sheriff of Montgomery County tonight for the routing of 600 demonstrators with horses and clubs here yesterday.
HONG KONG, March 17 -- Communist China declared today that talk about a peaceful settlement in Vietnam was "nothing but the most fragrant, most shameless war blackmail" by the United States.
LONDON, March 17 -- The Labor Government has appointed Aubrey Jones, a Conserxtive Member of Parliament. as director of the effort Io hold down prices and illconics.

A 35-year-old woman and her 12-year-old daughter who boarded the Shalom as stowaways in Port-au-Prince, Haiti, last Thursday in the belief the ship was bound for Israel began a two-week Caribbean cruise last night aboard the ship.

The vicissitudinous racing plans of the Wheatley Stable's Bold Lad seem to have taken a turn for the better, on the basis of a workout at Belmont Park yesterday. The 3-year-old colt, unraced since he won the Champagne last October, breezed five furlongs over the main track and was clocked in 1:02 1-5.
PARIS, March 17 -- Pierre Jeancard today dismissed as a political maneuver the Soviet denial that his interview with former Premier Khrushchev was authentic.

WASHINGTON, March 17 (UPI) -- A professor charged in a Senate document released today that the late Harry Dexter White -- accused by the Federal Bureau of Investigation and others of being a Soviet spy -- deliberately tried to wreck China's monetary system during World War II.
The Hooker Chemical Corporation started its 1965 fiscal year with record first-quarter sales and earnings. Thomas Willers, president, told stockholders at the annual meeting here yesterday.
PARIS, March 17 -- Euripides's play, "The Trojan Women," began its run tonight at the Theatre National Populaire in an adaptation by Jean-Paul Sartre, directed by Michael Cacoyannis.
Vincent John Rao, 67-year-old millionaire Mafia underboss, was indicted yesterday on five counts of perjury in testimony before a Federal grand jury.
The New York Knickerbockers demonstrated their basketball technique to 5,000 youngsters in Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon under the sponsorship of the Journal-American.

THE water-color drawings by John White in an exhibition opening today at the Morgan Library, 33 East 36th Street, are not fine art in the usual sense, but they are an extraordinarily engaging group of pictures.
LONDON, March 17 (Reuters) -- Britain's industrial output in January of this year reached a record level for the fourth successive month, Government figures showed today.
STOCKTON, Calif., March 17 -- Amos Alonzo Stagg, patriarch of American athletics, died in a rest home today at the age of 102.

Clay D. Blair Jr. and Marvin D. Kantor, former senior vice presidents and directors of the Curtis Publishing Company, settled their breach of contract suits against the company for $75,000 each, it was disclosed yesterday.
DETROIT, March 17 -- An elderly widow was in critical condition here today after setting herself ablaze on a street corner last night in protest against United States foreign policy.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 17 -- Policemen broke up a news conference called this morning by leaders of the Cao Dai religious sect for the establishment of a peace organization.
A rise in prices helped lift futures in scrap metal as much as 2.47 cents a pound yesterday in the heaviest volume ever recorded on the New York Commodity Exchange.

MINEOLA, L.I., March 17 -- A contract authorizing further architectural drawings and the appointment of a Nassau County director of performing and fine arts has intensified a campaign for the $46 million John F. Kennedy Educational, Civic and Cultural Center at the old Mitchel Field air base.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 17 -- Red Schoendienst was hunting pheasants in Weldon Springs, Mo., last October when the startling news reached him that Johnny Keane had quit as manager of the St. Louis Cardinals, the newly minted champions of the world. All sorts of thoughts raced through his mind, but he never came up with the most obvious one.
A proposal to enclose Shea Stadium as an all-weather sports facility was put forward yesterday by Ben Finney, the city's Commissioner of Sports. He said it could be ready by the 1966 season.
WASHINGTON, March 17 (UPI) -- Leading exporters appealed today for more Government help in expanding their foreign trade.

Readers of The New York Times by now can judge the State Department white paper for themselves. Whatever we think of its arguments it cannot be said to justify the killing and destruction taking place in Vietnam.
A Federal District Court jury cleared National Airlines yesterday of negligence in the January, 1960, crash near Bolivia, N.C., that killed Julian A. Frank and 33 others.

STAMFORD, Conn., March 17 -- The Connecticut State Supreme Court of Errors will be asked to review the case of Dr. and Mrs. George Hughes of Darien, who were convicted of having served liquor to minors.
TRENTON, March 17 -- The Republican leadership canceled today a special legislative session that had been called for tomorrow to produce a G.O.P. reapportionment plan.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- United States officials are cautiously optimistic over recent events concerning the Congo. But they do not exclude the possibility of new setbacks for the Congolese Government.
The Morgan Guaranty Trust Company plans to open a new midtown branch -- its fourth -- on the east side of Park Avenue between 48th and 49th Streets.
Those who are close to Christopher Lynch described him yesterday as a quiet youth who was "lazy when it came to regular work" and who "had felt himself a misfit in school because of his bigness."

HOW some youngsters react to classical music becomes joyously apparent in an exhibition of paintings, ceramic sculpture and photographs that opened yesterday in the window galleries of the East River Savings Bank in Rockefeller Plaza.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- Secretary of the Treasury Douglas Dillon and a former assistant defended before Congress today a tax ruling that saved members of the du Pont family $56 million and could have saved them as much as $100 million.
PARIS, March 17 -- President de Gaulle's Government maintained silence today on criticism of French policy in Southeast Asia by George W. Ball, United States Under Secretary of State.

CARACAS, Venezuela, March 12 -- A mild-mannered President has quietly marked the anniversary of his inauguration as supporters sought for something very good and adversaries for something very bad to say about the state of the nation.
HAVANA, March 17 -- You ring up an office or a hotel here and the first thing the switchboard operator says before you have a chance to ask for an extension, is "The best ones to Algiers."

PARIS, March 17 -- Foreign Minister Paul-Henri Spaak of Belgium suggested today that the Atlantic alliance re-examine the Rapacki plan for a zone in Central Europe free of nuclear weapons and discuss it with the Communist bloc.
WASHINGTON, March 17 -- Personal income rose and housing starts declined in February, the Commerce Department reported today.

Foreign correspondents in South Vietnam report, according to an Associated Press survey, that official restrictions by United States military authorities are making the war there more difficult to cover now than at any other time since major United States involvement began in 1961.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- The House Judiciary Committee approved today a proposed constitutional amendment to deal with the long-standing problems of Presidential disability and vacancies in the office of Vice President.

The widow had been living on Social Security payments and $1,000 of taxable income. In 1964 the estate of her late husband was finally settled. She received a substantial executor's fee and certain assets of the estate which raised her taxable income to $10,000.

A block of General Motors Corporation common stock valued at about $284 million was sold to the public yesterday in one of the final steps implementing the 1962 antitrust decree separating the du Pont company from the giant automotive enterprise.
Mayor Wagner proposed to Governor Rockefeller yesterday a pioneering housing program that he said would provide 43,1500 middle- and low-income housing units in the state within four years.
Barber's "Vanessa" will be given by the Metropolitan Opera tonight at 8.

HERE are two excellent books about animals. "Wild Heritage" is bound to join Rachel Carson's "The Sea Around Us" as a reading adventure. "Animal Behavior," with Niko Tinbergen's lucid text, is full of wonderful pictures, many in color.

A book about American newspaper editors, "They Will Be Heard," by Jonathan Daniels, will be published by McGraw-Hill on April 19. Mr. Daniels, writes about Horace Greeley, William Lloyd Garrison, Roy Howard, Lafcadio Hearn, John Albert Cockerill

BUENOS AIRES. March 17 -- Leaders of the Peronist Popular Union served notice today that they considered that their party had a "complete mandate" to press for the return of the ousted dictator Juan D. Peron despite the slim majority the party won in Sunday's Congressional election.
Four-year-old Maria Centeno, walked across a treble clef painted on the floor of a West Side basement yesterday afternoon, carefully selected a line to stand on and announced, "I'm D."
With many flourishes of nonpartisan rectitude, the United States Senate created a body last July known as the Select Committee on Standards and Conduct.

I read your March 7 editorial on "Medicare Breakthrough" with great interest, particularly the following: "The more adequate a medical financial program the nation adopts, the more extensive will be the demands placed upon its resources of doctors, nurses, hospitals and related facilities."

FOR two acts "Billy Liar" is genre comedy written so broadly that it is often farce. In the third act this play by Keith Waterhouse and Willis Hall, which opened at the Gate Theater last night, tries to be penetrating and serious. The shift in gears is too drastic and grinding for comfort.

ROME, Thursday, March 18 -- Former King Farouk of Egypt died in a hospital here early today after collapsing over the dinner table at a fashionable restaurant on Via Cassia, north of Rome. He was 45 years old.
WASHINGTON, March 17 -- President Johnson sent to the Congress today legislation authorizing the United States to accept a 25 per cent increase in its quota in the International Monetary Fund.
TUCSON, Ariz., March 17 (AP) -- Former Senator Barry Goldwater said today he did not think any American liked to see what had happened in Selma, Ala.

A Staten Island Cricket Club squad of 16 players will fly to the West Indies Saturday and then start a seven-match tour between Sunday and April 4 in Antigua, Barbados, Trinidad and Tobago. The tour is recognized by the People-to-People Sports Committee.

The Realty Equities Corporation has sold two buildings in Albany that are occupied by state agencies. The buyer was Lawrence Mohr, a lawyer and former assistant counsel to the State Controller, Arthur Levitt.
CHICAGO, March 17 (AP) -- According to Amos Alonzo Stagg Jr., Mr. Stagg left an unpublished autobiography entitled "Stagg of Yale."
American Hydrofoil Lines, Inc., has petitioned the Federal Court for time to complete a financial reorganization, Ira E. Dowd, president, said yesterday.

SELMA, Ala., March 17 -- Thirty-six white adults, most of them ministers, were arrested today for picketing the home of Mayor Joseph T. Smitherman. The arrests were ordered by Wilson Baker, the city's Public Safety Director, who apparently was angered by what he considered a violation of an agreement.

The board of directors of the American Society of Newspaper Editors has announced the election of 11 editors to membership. This brings to 657 the number of members, all of whom have immediate charge of editorial or news policies of daily papers.
BANMETHUOT, South Vietnam, March 17 -- The battle for the loyalty of the tribesmen in the central highlands has been resumed, with the initial success going to Communists.
WASHINGTON, March 17 -- The State Department has persuaded foreign embassy personnel here to cut down on their abuse of the privilege of ignoring traffic tickets.
The Federal Maritime Commission will investigate complaints filed by the trucking industry about extra costs resulting from cargo congestion on piers.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- Although military history and fiction are studded with articulate and colorful heroes, the military profession is partial to commanders who do not say much but do their jobs well.
The city is considering using the upper floors of small hotels to detain women arrested for minor offenses.
Jean-Paul Sartre, the French writer and exponent of existentialist philosophy who turned down the 1964 Nobel Prize for Literature, canceled a lecture trip to the United States yesterday.

ALBANY, March 17 -- Democratic legislators exploded in heated indignation today over the state's hiring of former Republican Gov. Thomas E. Dewey to argue the case for the Republicans' reapportionment plans in the United States Supreme Court.

SWEEPING the opposition 7-0 in match points, the Queens Chess Club of Flushing won the team championship of the Long Island Chess League. Levittown, scoring 5-2, captured second place, followed by Nassau, 4 1/2-2 1/2.

The first of six new cargo-passenger vessels to be placed in the New York-Buenos Aires service of the Argentine Lines will make her maiden entry into the harbor March 31, Capt. R.C. Charpentier, manager of the line's New York office, announced yesterday.

To the skirl of hundreds of bagpipes and the echoing thud of thousands of drums. 110,000 Irish-Americans and their green-bedizened sympathizers laid siege yesterday to two miles of Fifth Avenue to honor one Patricius Magonus Sucatus.

IN a way it was like old times at the New York State Theater last night. There was an American Ballet Theater program with a premiere of a work by Agnes deMille. This would not have been an uncommon occurrence 26 years ago, when Miss deMille's "Fall River Legend" and "Tally-Ho" (now "The Frail Quarry") were introduced by the company, but since that era she and Ballet Theater have not been so closely associated.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 17 (AP) -- The State of California filed antitrust suits today against seven manufacturers of concrete and steel pipe.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 17 -- The Damascus radio reported that Israeli troops and tanks attacked a Syrian project for diversion of the Jordan River headwaters today "in the Dan and Doka areas."
Bill Bradley, an all-America athlete and a Rhodes scholar, led his 12 basketball teammates and one "tiger" in a cardboard box last night as the Princeton contingent left for Portland, Ore.
Associate Justice Arthur J. Goldberg of the United States Supreme Court urged yesterday that the United States adopt the Treaty on Human Rights that has been drafted by the United Nations.
The nation's electric power production rose 7.5 per cent in the week ended March 13 from the level in the corresponding 1964 week, it was reported yesterday by the Edison Electric Institute.
CLEVELAND, March 17 (AP) -- The Erie-Lackawanna Railroad lost $8.2 million in 1964, compared with a loss of $17.1 million the year before, the line's annual report showed today.

If looks were all the Metropolitan Opera would seem to have found the ideal principals for its current sumptuous production of "Samson et Dalila." Last night, in the season's ninth performance of the Saint-Saens work, Jon Vickers sang the role of Samson for the first time here, and Elena Cernei made her debut with the company as Dalila.
MOSCOW, Thursday, March 18 -- The spaceship Voskhod II with two cosmonauts on board was launched this morning, the Soviet press agency Tass announced.

PATERSON, N.J., March 17 -- Peter Lieberman, composer and pianist, introduced his most recent work, the four-part Kennedy Suite, to an interested audience of his colleagues last week. He drew the reaction to be expected from one's peers -- part enthusiasm and part criticism.

WASHINGTON, March 17 (UPI) -- Alabama Representatives, responding to the call of Gov. George C. Wallace, took to the floor of the House today to defend their state against what they termed unfair publicity and unjust attack.

LISBON, March 17 -- Premier Antonio de Oliveira Salazar reshuffled his Cabinet today in what appeared to be a move to check the new progressive trend of economic policy, instigated by the 37-year-old Minister of the Economy, Luis Teixeira Pinto.

TIMMINS, Ont., March 17 -- George and Viola MacMillan, a millionaire mining team, defended their business behavior today in their first public comment since wild fluctuations in Windfall stock rocked Canadian securities and mining markets last July.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 17 -- A Federal district judge authorized Negroes today to hold a mass march from Selma, Ala., to Montgomery, the state capital.
ALBANY, March 17 -- A bill that would have barred unaccompanied children under 16 years of age from attending motion pictures that are advertised "for adults only" was rejected today by the Assembly.

CLEVELAND, March 17 -- The first round of the Vanderbilt Cup knockout team championship here last night was marked by two resounding upsets. High-seeded teams captained by Charles Goren and Richard Kahn lost narrowly to teams with far less experience and reputation.
VERO BEACH, Fla., March 17 (UPI) -- The Los Angeles Dodgers sent 10 men to bat in a five-run second inning today and defeated the Minnesota Twins, 6 -- 4.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 17 -- Turkey exchanged charges of aggression and subversion with Cyprus and Greece in the Security Council today in a debate over the crisis between Greek and Turkish Cypriotes.
A taciturn, 17-year-old youth sought in the subway slaying of a Brooklyn schoolboy surrendered to the police early yesterday and was immediately charged with homicide.

TELEVISION viewers received their first glimpse, albeit an extremely cursory one, of the new Los Angeles Music Center last night. The West Coast cultural project served as the background for the Dinah Shore special variety show over the American Broadcasting Company network.
Yale Express System, Inc., announced last night that its chief creditors had agreed to defer current maturities of their debt and had rearranged the ailing company's finances.

The J.I. Kislak Organization, New Jersey real estate, mortgage banking and insurance concern, has promoted 12 executives. In J.I. Kislak, Inc., the parent company, Mrs. Florence Hayes has been named vice president in charge of the company's business in Hudson County and William Schuchman was elected vice president of residential sales.
Senators Jacob K. Javits and Robert F. Kennedy gave conditional approval yesterday to the work that is being done by Haryou-Act, Inc., the anti-poverty agency in Harlem.
ALBANY, March 17 -- George H. Van Lengen, the Democratic leader in Syracuse and the Secretary of the Senate, is expected to replace William H. McKeon soon as Democratic State Chairman.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 17 -- The New York Mets finally won or lost a baseball game by more than one run today. After four straight cliffhangers, they defeated the Cincinnati Reds, 7 -- 4, for their second victory in a row and their most solid performance of the spring.
LONDON, March 17 -- The Government told Britain's family doctors today that it would negotiate with them over a new national health service, but not over their pay.

The second all-East semi-final round in a National Invitation Tournament will take place tonight when Army meets St. John's and Villanova takes on New York University in the 28th N.I.T. at Madison Square Garden.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- President Johnson submitted to Congress today a bipartisan bill to attack discriminatory practices that have prevented Negroes from registering and voting in some Southern states.
The Arthritis Foundation's New York Chapter will benefit from a house tour here on April 6 and 13. Mrs. Monroe E. Spaght is chairman for the 12th annual event.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- (AP) -- Vice Adm. Hyman G. Rickover strongly urged Congress today to approve the construction of a new type of nuclear reactor that he said was vital to the welfare of the United States and perhaps to that of the whole world.

The Detroit Red Wings, who owe a large share of their first-place standing in the National Hockey League to the Rangers, will meet the New Yorkers tonight in the only Friday hockey game at Madison Square Garden this season.
DARIEN, Conn., March 18 -- Four teen-age boys have been suspended from high school for two weeks in another youth drinking incident in this well-to-do community.

ALBANY, March 18 -- Robert Moses, faced with attacks from the public, his associates and Governor Rockefeller, withdrew for the time being today his bill to authorize construction of a bridge across Long Island Sound.
Oprations of the United Shoe Machinery Corporation in the fiscal year ended Feb. 28 resulted in a net income of $12,921,400, second highest in the company's history.
WALLACE, Idaho, March 18 (UPI) -- The Hecla Mining company's total 1964 income of $5,198,379 jumped from the 1963 income of $1,846,227, the company said today.

LEXINGTON, Ky. March 18 -- Federal Judge Mac Swinford accepted today the essentials of a plan for undoing the merger that created the First Security National Bank and Trust Company. The plan was presented by the bank and the Justice Department.

New York City teachers, along with thousands of their colleagues across the nation, wilt soon vote for or against the Johnson Federal aid to education program in a membership referendum conducted by the American Federation of Teachers.
A former stockbroker indicted here last month on charges of stealing $429,709 was described yesterday by District Attorney Frank S. Hogan's office as a "bookmaker's dream."

The New York Court of Appeals has ruled that the police do not have to advise a suspect of his right to remain silent and his right to have a lawyer before taking his con fession. Legal observers consider the decision of great importance because the courts had appeared to be moving in the direction of requiring the police to inform suspects of their constitutional rights before questioning them.

CHICAGO, March 18 -- Definitive terms of a consolidation of the Chicago North Western Railway and the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad were approved today by directors of the two railroads at separate meetings.
WASHINGTON, March 18 -- United State officials suggested today that President Sukarno might be resisting pressures from the powerful Communist party for a final break with Washington.

DETROIT, March 19 (UPI) -- The Detroit Red Wings tonight scored five goals in the first period and defeated the last-place Boston Bruins, 10 -- 3. The victory increased Detroit's lead in the National Hockey League to 3 points.

HAVANA, March 18 -- The Government announced today that it expected a bumper crop of sugar of five million tons by May 1. Aides of Premier Fidel Castro urged "an arduous effort" by the nation to meet this target.
The Chrysler Corporation announced yesterday that it had registered its planned 5,611,000-share offering of common stock with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
Cue magazine went to press yesterday with its 30th anniversary issue -- an issue that looks to the future of New York in terms of what will be and what might be.
MOSCOW, March 18 (UPI) -- Lieut. Col. Aleksei A. Leonov made space history today by spending 10 minutes outside his capsule. But his career as an astronaut was almost a failure.

The modest salary increases proposed by Mayor Wagner for New York County's assistant prosecutors are well deserved and long overdue. Recent court decisions have breathed new urgency into the long-standing problem of interesting well-qualified law students in careers at the criminal bar.
WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Intercity truck tonnage and carloadings of rail freight in the week ended March 13 were both considerably above the level in the corresponding week of 1964.

LONDON, March 18 (AP) -- The Soviet Foreign Minister, Andrei A. Gromyko, discussed Vietnam with Prime Minister Harold Wilson for about two and a half hours tonight. British sources said afterward that the leaders had failed to reach agreement on a way to end the fighting.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 18 --United States officials, attuned to any change in the intensity of the South Vietnamese guerrilla war, have noticed a slight drop in incidents initiated by the Communists.
Cigarettes will cost 5 cents more a pack in New York State beginning April 1.

MOSCOW, March 18 -- The first man to step out of an orbiting craft and float in space is an amateur painter with a physique that, in Izvestia's view, is an achievement in bodybuilding. Lieut. Col. Aleksei Arkhipovich Leonov, known to his family and friends as Lyosha, has been dabbling in oils and pencil sketches since his schooldays.

The Friends of Public School 612 will sponsor a dance at the Gotham Hotel next Friday evening to raise additional funds for their work on behalf of the schoolboys at 612. Those attending classes at the school at 113 East 87th Street are 9 to 16 years old and have special behavior problems.

LONDON, March 18 (Reuters) -- A British rocket engineer today hailed the Soviet "spacewalk" as "the most incredible achievement yet" and said the next step would be for a spacewalker to be equipped with a rocket to propel himself about.
The Ohio State University Housing Commission sold yesterday $17 million of bonds to an investment banking group headed by Glore Forgan, Wm. R. Staats, Inc.
A recurring feud among members of the city's Tax Commission, which makes the final decisions on real estate valuations for tax purposes, has flared into the open once again.

BY licensing a power plant in the Hudson Highlands before the controversy over it has been resolved, the Federal Power Commission has indicated the value it attaches to public opinion. It regards public opinion as a nuisance and a bore.
Reform Democrats opened yesterday the first phase of their 1965 campaign to gain control of the New York County Democratic organization.

Mayor Wagner predicted yesterday that William H. McKeon would he replaced "very shortly" as Democratic State Chairman, and expressed warm support for George H. Van Lengen, Secretary of the State Senate, for the job.

Short interest in stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange rose to 6,762,151 shares in the month to last Monday, an increase of 294.246 shares from the total on Feb. 15 when it was 6,467,905 shares.
NEW YORK boatmen can't flash lights in the eyes of the operators of approaching vessels, but they can get as "lit" as they want on their own boats.

BUENOS AIRES, March 18 -- A bitter struggle between rightist and leftist factions for control of the University of Buenos Aires erupted today in the wake of the resignation of its rector, Dr. Julio H.G. Olivera.
Issues on the American Stock Exchange lost ground over a broad front yesterday in moderate trading.

HUE, South Vietnam -- Unless one proceeds by armed convoy or in the car of someone cautious enough to pay blackmail to the Vietcong rebels, the only sure way of traveling here nowadays is by air. And yet from above, if one ignores occasional helicopter clusters or echelons of bombers, this appears a tranquil, underpopulated land.
MONTREAL, March 18 (UPI) -- The Montreal Canadiens, still hoping to repeat as National Hockey League champions, scored three goals in the final period tonight to defeat the Toronto Maple Leafs, 4-1.
HAVANA, March 18 -- The Cuban Communist party disclosed today it had stamped out a center of opposition to Premier Fidel Castro in the seaport of Nuevitas on the north coast.
PARIS, March 18 -- West Germany has been cutting its dollar holdings and increasing its reserves of gold on a much larger scale than France with no commotion.
The New York City Opera opened the third week of its spring season with a new production of Gian Carlo Menotti's light opera, "The Saint of Bleecker Street."

KIHACHI OKAMOTO is a film director to watch -- one of the most exciting to turn up recently in Japan. Although his "Samurai Assassin," which came to the Toho Cinema last night with who else but Toshiro Mifune in the title role, is tedious and superficial so far as its commonplace story goes, it shows talent for using the camera that some of the big boys might wish they had.
MOSCOW, March 18 (AP) -- Following is the text of the first official Soviet announcement on the launching of spaceship Voskhod 2, as distributed by Tass press agency:

PRINCETON, N.J., March 18 -- American and European private and central bankers apparently agreed today that the American Administration's new voluntary program to eliminate the deficit in the United States balance of international payments was off to a good start, but expressed doubts about the longer run.

The first and least controversial part of Governor Rockefeller's tax-increase program has survived a test in the Legislature with passage of the doubled state levy on cigarettes, which was signed into law yesterday. But the extent of the Democratic defection casts an ominous shadow on prospects for underwriting the Governor's large budget, with its generous increase in state aid on which school systems through-out the state -- and New York City conspicuously -- depend.
Fears on the London Stock Exchange of a deflationary national budget continue to stifle enthusiasm generated by favorable news.

LA SYLPHIDE," one of the oldest ballets still in existence in an approximation of its original choreographic form, has been produced lavishly and, on the whole, successfully by the American Ballet Theater.
An arsonist who stole a photographer's equipment from a Greenwich Village studio last week is being sought for the murder of the photographer in this apartment a block away.
Construction has started in Newark on an 18-story office building that will have as its principal tenant the First National State Bank of New Jersey.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 18 -- President Johnson's address to Congress on Negro voting rights was acclaimed today by a Ghanaian diplomat who said echoes of the President's words "have gone ringing round the world."

EASTERN skiing, weighted down by the worst snow conditions in recent years, is taking a sharp turn for the better. Virtually all areas in New York, Vermont and Massachusetts are reporting good-to-excellent conditions, with nice dustings of new powder on solid bases.
Following are excerpts from Gov. George C. Wallace's address to a joint session of the Alabama Legislature last night as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of A.B.C. News:

Senator Robert F. Kennedy announced yesterday that the Joseph P. Kennedy Jr. Foundation had given $1.45 million to Yeshiva University's Albert Einstein College of Medicine to help build a center for the study of mental retardation and human development.
WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP) -- Don C. Silverthorne stated today that his San Francisco National Bank was run out of business because other banks objected to his com petition. He denied any wrongdoing.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 18 -- Al Yates is 20 years old, strums a guitar and spends much of his life underwater as a scuba diver. Frank McGraw, 20, is an amateur barber who practices on his teammates. Mike Buist is 18 and has already declined hockey offers from the New York Rangers and the Toronto Maple Leafs.
The first motion-picture films of the Soviet Air Force officer floating in space were seen here shortly after 7 P.M. yesterday over the Columbia Broadcasting System's Channel 2.

Kyriakoula was a dear girl indeed to the long-shot players yesterday at Aqueduct. The 4-year-old daughter of Mr. Turf and Mea Carissima scored by 2 1/2 lengths in the feature race on the card, covering the six furlongs in 1:12.
American scientists, for the first time, have worked out the structure of a nucleic acid -- a substance that helps direct the development of form and function of all living things.

The Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States announced yesterday the election of S. Ralph Hardison as a vice president. He succeeds R.O. Brown, vice president in charge of the residential mortgage department.
The recent Supreme Court decisions on movie censorship make imperative a new approach to the regulation of films.
A REPORT on research into the wonders and mysteries of space under the oceans was presented last night by the American Broadcasting Company in a documentary entitled "Man Invades the Sea."
BERKELEY, Calif., March 18 -- A 24-page magazine, Spider, was banned from the University of California campus today in the latest conflict between students and the school administration.

It would have been intellectually stimulating if in his March 11 letter M.T. Mehdi of the Action Committee of the American-Arab Relations Committee had made an effort to rebut Bishop James Pike's logical arguments in his letter published Feb. 28 on "Bonn's Capitulation to Nasser."
ALBANY, March 18 -- The Erie County Republican Committee was ordered by the Court of Appeals today to reorganize itself before April 8.
WINS, one of the city's leading outlets for rock 'n' roll music, will become an all-news station starting Monday, April 19.

ROME, March 18 -- Foreign Ministers of the six Common Market countries will meet in Italy, probably in Venice late in May or early m June in an effort to reactivate projects for political unity stalled for the last three year's.
The British pound strengthened yesterday in foreign exchange markets here. The spot rate closed at $2.7925, against $2.7916 on Wednesday.
Thousands of commuters on the Long Island Rail Road were delayed up to several hours last night when engineers refused to move trains until headlights were inspected.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 18 (AP) -- Gov. George C. Wal lace asked a Federal judge today to suspend his order allowing a 50-mile civil rights march from Selma to Montgomery.
WASHINGTON, March 13 -- The House approved today a $114,250,000 Coast Guard authorization for procurement and improvement of vessels and aircraft and for construction ashore and offshore.
Clarence C. Pell Jr., a former titleholder, defeated George Hendrick of Chicago yesterday in the opening round of the United States amateur racquets championship.

AT 10:20 A.M. yesterday, Sydney Gittler, the vice president of Ohrbach's whose name is a password among women who like their Paris couture clothes ready made in America at a sixth of the price, surveyed his domain, the Grey Room on the fifth floor, and found it a shambles.
Bills were introduced yesterday in the Legislature seeking to make New York the 17th state to adopt pari-mutuel quarter-horse racing.
PASADENA, Calif., March 18 (AP) -- The Mariner 4 spacecraft, nearly half way to Mars, has stopped sending useful radiation information back to earth. Jet Propulsion Laboratory officials said today.
BONN, March 18 -- West Germany has cased further its credit policy toward Communist-bloc countries.
The election of Henry B. Sargent and Edwin Thorne as directors of the First Boston Corporation was announced yesterday at the annual stockholder meeting in Boston.
PRINCETON, N.J., March 18 -- Princeton students sent a six-word good-luck telegram tonight to their basketball team in Portland, Ore., and added 2,000 signatures.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Walter Hallstein, President of the European Common Market Commission, said today that he had "happily confirmed" from President Johnson that the "fundamental orientation" of the United States toward Europe was unchanged.

American Electric Power Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday new highs in 1964 energy sales, operating enues and net income for the company also noted that rev- revenues and net income. The first two months and for 12 months ended Feb. 28 were at new highs.
Old-crop soybean futures prices fell sharply yesterday in hectic trading on the Chicago Board of Trade. The near deliveries in wheat were also under selling pressure.

The three teen-age girls who had been sought as witnesses to the subway slaying of 17-year-old Andrew Mormile last Friday night have come forward, Brooklyn District Atorney Aaron E. Koota said yesterday.

ARUSHA, Tanzania, March 16 -- An American stood on a hilltop and with a sweep of his arm outlined the limits of his 7,000-acre farm as he complained about the plight of non-African farmers in Tanzania.
WASHINGTON, March 18 (UPI) -- A fresh batch of 100 pickets squatted and lay down on the sidewalk in front of the White House today, demanding that Federal troops be sent to Alabama.
The United Jewish Appeal of Greater New York reported contributions of more than $10 million at a dinner last night opening its 27th annual fund-raising campaign.

CLEVELAND, March 18 -- Three more high-ranked teams were upset here last night in the third round of the Vanderbilt Cup contest. The event is the highlight of the spring national championships of the American Contract Bridge League being played here.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 18 -- Security Council members and the directly interested parties agreed today on the urgency of averting a threatened outbreak of violence in Cyprus.

GENEVA, March 18 (Reuters) -Poland told today's meeting of the Kennedy round Trade Negotiations Committee she would put forward an offer on trade concessions on April 1. Poland is not a member of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade but takes part in its work under a special arrangement.

YONKERS, March 18 -- The $25,000 Adios Festival final, loaded as it was with early speed, wound up at the mercy of Cold Front, the strongest rallying pacer in the field tonight at Yonkers Raceway. Vernon Dancer, driving the 7-year-old son of Adios, kept the chestnut comfortably in third place through most of the 1 1/4-mile pace, then came through in the stretch to triumph by a head.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 18 -- Boston College, counter-acting North Dakota's superb stick-handling tonight with timely checking, gained the final of the National Collegiate Athletic Association hockey championship with a 4-3 victory before a capacity crowd of 2,600 in Meehan Auditorium.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -The Administration's plan to help speed rail service between Washington and New York City is largely contingent on persuading the Pennsylvania Railroad to spend at least $8 million on new equipment in the next year or so.
WASHINGTON, March 18 -- The Johnson Administration has acquired apparently convincing evidence that Soviet-made antiaircraft missiles are about to be installed on Cyprus by the Cypriote Government.
A 35-year-old former marine entered a recent board meeting of the Wagner Baking Company as general sales manager. Two hours later, Gerald D. Sarhis emerged from the meeting as president.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- It is clear from the present crisis over voting rights in Alabama that the new activist spirit of the church and the university in America, allied to the modern television and airplane, is now having a profound influence on law and politics in the United States.
Twenty-three men and 16 women were named yesterday to the first United States track and field team that will compete in international indoor dual meets.

The 28th National Invitation Tournament boiled down to final between St. John's and Villanova last night when the Redmen overcame Army, 67-60 and the Wildcats routed New York University, 91-69, at Madison Square Garden.
BRASILIA, March 18 -- Brazil's Attorney General argued before the Supreme Court today that the iron mining rights of the American-owned Hanna Company be annulled.
ALBANY, March 18 -- Samuel D. Greenberg of Brooklyn, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, outlined a fiscal program today that would eliminate Governor Rockefeller's proposed state sales tax.

Robert W. Sarnoff, chairman of the board of the National Broadcasting Company, said yesterday that the Federal Communications Commission's proposal to curtail network control of programing would "shatter the structure of television."
The Commerce and Industry Association of New York has elected Charles E. Eble, Harold E. Gray and Edgar M. Bronfman as directors.
ALBANY, March 18 -- 20th Century-Fox won a major victory today in its legal fight to exhibit the film "John Goldfarb, Please Come Home."
WASHINGTON, March 18 -- The United States is planning an underground nuclear test late this year on Amchitka Island, which is near the end of the Aleutian chain off Alaska.

CLEVELAND, March 18 (AP) -- The huge Collinwood High School called off classes today as fist fights broke out between white and Negro pupils over what school officials said were racial incidents the last week.
WASHINGTON, March 18 -Senator Robert F. Kennedy is flying to the Yukon this weekend to join in an attempt to scale for the first time a 13,900-foot peak named after President Kennedy.
The F.W. Woolworth Company will offer for sale 500 art works, which it says are worth $500,000, at one of its New Jersey stores for one week starting Monday.
Plans for a bus line around the city linking the three major airports with all major bus lines converging on the city were outlined yesterday by a leading transportation executive.
A new, surprise confession by Nathan Jackson, convicted in the 1960 slaying of a policeman, went on the record in Brooklyn Supreme Court yesterday.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 18 -- Gov. George C. Wallace called on President Johnson tonight to send United States marshals to Alabama "to provide for the safety and welfare" of Negro and white members of the civil rights protest march from Selma to Montgomery.
WASHINGTON, March 18 -The overwhelming majority of families displaced by urban renewal projects wind up in better than substandard housing, the Housing and Home Finance Agency said today.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 18 -- A new technique for removing infected tonsils in adults by freezing instead of by surgery was disclosed today by Rhode Island Hospital.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, March 18 -- Communist labor unions cut off gas and electricity at a United States Embassy apartment building and the home of the American naval attxche here today and attempted to seize control of United States-owned oil installations in southern Sumatra.

MINEOLA, L.I., March 18 -- Republican enrollment in Nassau County declined 8,000 between 1960 and 1964 while Democratic enrollment increased 46,000, John F. English the Nassau Democratic chairman, reported today.
" The greatest thing that has happened to me was my divorce from Paris," Jo Copeland said, her large, brown eyes glowing.

THE tale of an American woman who seizes a moment of love in Venice was romantic and bittersweet when it was told as a straight play in "The Time of the Cuckoo." It is still romantic and bittersweet as a musical, "Do I Hear a Waltz?"

Lt. Col. Aleksei Leonov's space acrobatics were both spectacular and historic. He is a brave man who deserves enthusiastic congratulations, along with the scientists and technicians who made his achievement possible.

GENEVA, March 18 -- A major advance was made today in the Kennedy round of tariff-cutting negotiations. An accord was reached on how to deal with agriculture and room was made at the bargaining table for the underdeveloped countries and two Soviet-bloc nations.

HEIDELBERG, Germany, March 18 (Reuters) -- Gen. Andrew P. O'Meara took over command today of the United States Army in Europe and the Central Army Group of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization from Gen. Paul Freeman.
The fact that growth stocks can undergo growing pains is borne out amply by the current market action of seasoned life insurance issues.
LONDON, March 18 -- Prime Minister Harold Wilson announced today that the Labor Government would soon proceed with its bill to renationalize the steel industry.
The Board of Education's plans to hold classes next year on George Washington's Birthday has come under attack.
Price changes were announced in various fields yesterday.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., March 18 -- The spectacular flight by two Soviet astronauts and a gloomy weather forecast spread an air of disappointment today over preparations for the United States' two-man Gemini flight.
New York City is facing a possible "serious situation" in its water supply this year, and a summer conservation program will probably be necessary.
MADRAS, India, March 18 -- Kerala, the Communist stronghold in southern India, will continue under federal rule.

Harold M. Lane St., chairman of the Lerner Stores Corporation, a division of the McCrory Corporation, will probably be named chairman of the board of S. Klein Department Stores Inc., at a special board meeting to be held next week.

ROME, March 18 -- A decree approved by Pope Paul VI and disclosed today by the Congregation of Rites permits Roman Catholic priests to carry with them at all times a certain amount of "holy oil of the sick."

A $250 million decline in the United States monetary gold stock during the week ended Wednesday was reported yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York -- and promptly explained by the Treasury Department in Washington.
The night before last someone apparently stole the possession that Joseph Pepe needs most: His Seeing Eye dog.
Mayor Wagner lent his support yesterday to a benefit planned by leading artists of Broadway shows for the family of the Rev. James J. Reeb and three civil rights groups.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- A Presidential study committee praised the performance of the National Institutes of Health today but warned that unless organizational reforms were were "substantial problems will will arise in the future."
WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP) -- The National Aeronautics and Space Administration said today that it planned to select 10 to 20 scientists to start a year of astronaut flight training this summer.

CAIRO, March 18 -- Chancellor Ludwig Erhard of West Germany has sent a special envoy to Cairo in a final effort to end the impasse with the United Arab Republic and to soften the blow of the expected break in diplomatic relations between the two countries.

The Lenox Quartet gave the last of this season's four concerts at Carnegie Recital Hall last night and in so doing introduced a splendid, highly individual and tightly made string quartet to the repertory.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- New orders received by durable-goods manufacturers declined by about 1 per cent in February. The drop was centered in the machinery industry. Commerce Department figures made public today showed that total new orders received by manufacturers of durable goods during the month reached $21.1 billion, a decline of $200 million from the January level.
The Citizens' Housing and Planning Council charged yesterday that "elephantine caution" in the Housing and Redevelopment Board had produced an urban-renewal program more theoretical than real.

Sam Hunter, director of the Rose Art Museum and of the Poses Institute of Fine Art at Brandeis University, will become director of the Jewish Museum on Sept. 6. His appointment was announced yesterday by Dr. Louis Finkelstein, chancellor of the Jewish Theological Seminary of America, which operates the museum.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 18 -- Sonny Randle, one of the finest pass-catching ends in pro football and an expert on quick starts and instant acceleration, has given the St. Louis Cardinals an autumnal touch in their spring training exercises. Randle was borrowed from their football counterparts, also the St. Louis Cardinals.
WASHINGTON, March 18 -- The Labor Department is preparing a major program to recruit tens of thousands of additional workers to pick crops this spring, summer and fall.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 18 -- The New York Yankees, who usually spend spring training convincing the world they will be too strong for the American League, are busy establishing the Toledo Mudhens as the team to beat in the International League.
MOSCOW, March 18 -- Col. Pavel Ivanovich Balyayev, 39-year-old commander of the spaceship Voskhod 2, is one of the oldest Soviet astronauts and probably the only former Navy pilot in the group.
A fourth investigation of the Women's House of Detention was begun yesterday, this time by the State Commission of Correction.
ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, March 18 -- The Congo's first national election since it became independent in 1960 got off to a staid start in Katanga today.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -The bipartisan voting-rights bill started on its legislative journey through both houses of Congress today amid displays of overwhelming support that seemed to augur relatively quick enactment.
The Newspaper Guild of New York conferred its annual Page One Award in Public Affairs yesterday on Sargent Shriver, director of the Office of Economic Opportunity.
WASHINGTON, March 18 -President Johnson announced today that he had nominated Henry H. Fowler to succeed Douglas Dillon as Secretary of the Treasury.

BOSTON, March 18 -- The Boston church where the Rev. James J. Peeb and his family worshiped during his short ministry in this city paid tribute today to his memory as a victim of civil rights violence in Alabama.
WASHINGTON, March 18 -- The names of reporters who ask questions at the twice-daily press briefings at the White House are being recorded and passed on to President Johnson.
HOLLYWOOD, March 18 (AP) -- Patricia Neal, who suffered three massive strokes, is paralyzed on her right side and is pregnant, her husband, Roald Dahl, the British water, disclosed today.

AN experimental effort will be made to create better fishing off Fire Island. Forty reinforced concrete structures are to be sunk to the bottom of the ocean as part of a program to build a fish-attracting artificial reef.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given every Friday on this page. The restaurants are rated on the basis of four stars to none. Four stars pertain to restaurants regarded as among the finest in the area.
ALBANY, March 18 -- The Court of Appeals affirmed today the right of the Commissioner of Education to order the reorganization of school districts to promote integration.
HAVANA, March 18 -- The Cuban Government has undertaken a program of exacting pledges from schoolboys and girls to give up truancy and cheating.

" Hooded Americanism," by David M. Chalmers, a story of the Ku Klux Klan from 1865 to the present, will be published by Doubleday on April 16. The author teaches a course at the University of Florida on "American Vigilante Tradition."
WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Defense and State Department officials denied today that the Administration had ordered restrictions on news coverage in South Vietnam.
ALBANY, March 18 -- Senate Democrats introduced a bill today that would create a bipartisan commission to reapportion the Legislature by June 1.
The stock market weakened decidedly in the final hour of trading yesterday after following a mixed pattern in the earlier dealings.
LAGOS, Nigeria, March 18 (Reuters) -- Voters in eastern Nigeria and parts of Lagos elected 54 members of the 312-member Parliament today.

WASHINGTON, March 18 (UPI) -- United States officials today saluted the Soviet's new space feat and conceded that it helped maintain the Russians lead in manned flight.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 18 -- Gheorghe Gheorghiu Dej, the President of Rumania and the leader of Rumania's Communist party, is seriously ill.
Three members of a multi-million-dollar gambling syndicate were indicted by a Federal grand jury yesterday on charges of conspiracy in the interstate transportation of gambling paraphernalia.

Government bond prices, influenced by talk of a possible cut in the British bank rate, continued to rise yesterday morning. By noon, however, the market's strength evaporated and most issues lost their gains and then slipped further.

The merger of the Security-Columbian Banknote Company, which prints banknotes and does financial and commercial printing, and Lanston Industries, Inc., makers of graphic machinery and monotype equipment, was announced here yesterday.
Frank Gifford, a star of magnitude for the New York Giants over a dozen seasons, announced his retirement from football yesterday. His association with the Giants, however, is not at an end.

River Brand Rice Mills, Inc., announced yesterday the details of a recent acquisition of rice properties and plans for further purchases of such properties. The deals involve a total of more than $15 million in cash and stock.
The National Council on the Arts, legislation for which was signed by President Johnson on Sept. 23, will convene for the first time April 9 and 10 in Washington.
The Shell Oil Company announced here yesterday that it had placed an order for the world's largest merchant ships -- four 165,000-ton tankers.

MOSCOW, Friday, March 19 -- A Soviet Air Force officer, who yesterday became the first man to leave an orbiting spacecraft and float in space, was still circling the earth early today in the capsule with a fellow astronaut.

A race is on between Alexander's and Korvette to come up with the best site in the Flatlands section of Brooklyn for a new store. MOSCOW, March 19 -- The Soviet spacecraft from which a man floated out into space for the first time in history landed safely today after 26 hours in flight. Presumably it had completed 17 orbits of the earth.
WASHINGTON March 19 -- The United States, apparently in a change of policy, is using napalm bombs in aerial strikes against North Vietnam.

Only the spectators looked on in the Erasmus Hall High School gymnasium in Brooklyn yesterday as the home team won the Public Schools Athletic League citywide basketball championship. It was a play.

The Bristol-Myers Company plans to enter the household products field through the proposed acquisition of the Drackett Company of Cincinnati. The transaction involves an exchange of stock workth $156,829,525.
The New York Young Republican Club demanded yesterday that Mayor Wagner withhold city funds from any new construction involving segregated labor.

The Paumonok Handicap, the race that used to have the distinction of heading the opening-day program for the New York thoroughbred season, will be the feature attraction at Aqueduct today. The six-furlong test for older horses will be the first handicap stakes event of the campaign, which got under way only last Monday.
QUEBEC, March 19 -- From a pedestal on the boardwalk high over the St. Lawrence River, the statue of Samuel de Champlain, French cavalier's hat in hand, surveys the town he founded in 1608.

Because of a Lincoln Center Student Concert on Thursday afternoon, the New York Philharmonic is playing only three concerts this week, and the opener took place yesterday afternoon at Philharmonic Hall.
Top executives of the Reynolds Metals Company held out hope yesterday that the continuing expansion of aluminum markets would strengthen prices of fabricated products.
Pan American World Airways announced yesterday the purchase of 11 Boeing 727 jets for $70.5 million. The airline has options on four more of the craft.
" John Goldfarb, Please Come Home" will finally be exposed to public scrutiny next Wednesday, after a three-month legal hassle between 20th Century-Fox and the University of Notre Dame.
NEW DELHI, March 19 -- The Indian Government decided tonight to continue federal rule in the state of Kerala until a new election can he held.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- Attorney General Nicholas deB. Katzenbach said today that the voting-rights bill would not help those Puerto Ricans in New York City who have been disenfranchised because of inability to pass the state's English literacy test.

Montgomery Ward Co., Inc., reported yesterday a 4.3 per cent increase in earnings for the year ended Feb. 3 and a 13.2 per cent rise in sales.

JERSEY CITY, March 19 -- An experiment that would have given Route 3 four eastbound and two westbound lanes during the morning rush to the Lincoln Tunnel began to look today as though it wouldn't happen.

A small bath and gift shop with some attractive ideas opened recently at 425 Third Avenue (near 30th Street). Ditz Unlimited offers bath ensembles, mostly made from fabrics by Jack Lenor Larsen. Almost all the fabrics are stain-resistant, heavyweight, washable cotton.

Thomas Dunn has made quite a specialty of putting together colorful off-beat programs. He did it again last night at Philharmonic Hall, conducting the Festival Orchestra in one of Mozart's less familiar symphonies, and also, even more rarified scores by Mozart, Handel and Rameau.

The Stratford (Ont.) Shakespearean Festival has received $100,000 from the Floyd S. Chalmers Foundation, $10,000 for current operation and capital projects and $90,000 for rehabilitating the festival's Avon Theater.

The International Silver Company is offering to its common stockholders rights to subscribe to $12,091,000 of 4 per cent convertible debentures due 1985 at a rate of $100 of debentures for each 20 shares held of record March 19.

BONN, March 19 (AP) -- A committee of West Germany's Parliament made a new move today to extend the hunt for Nazi murderers from 1965 until 1980 but created a loophole for those whom West German courts consider minor offenders.

TUNIS, March 19 -- Tunisian newspaper readers and radio listeners learned for the first time today of demonstrations against Tunisian embassies in the Middle East that followed announcement of the stand taken by President Habib Bourguiba in the quarrel between the United Arab Republic and West Germany. Mr. Bourguiba opposes breaking ties with Bonn.
Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, the United Nations Under Secretary for Special Political Affairs, said yesterday that he would participate in the civil rights march from Selma to Montgomery.
PHILADELPHIA, March 19 (AP) -- Longshoremen refused today to unload 45 tons of Soviet-processed codfish from a ship berthed here.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 19 -- An economic boycott to compel South Africa to modify its racial policies may be possible in theory but difficult in practice, according to United States and British experts.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., March 19 (AP) -- Mrs. Annie Mae Turner was poised last night to tell the powerful Alabama Education Association, of which she is outgoing president, that she thinks it is morally right for the Negro in Alabama to have the right to vote.

City officials said yesterday that 140 prisoners would be moved within the next three weeks from the much-criticized Women's House of Detention to other quarters in an attempt to relieve overcrowding.
TOKYO, March 19 -- Premier Eisaku Sato has sent a senior diplomat, Shunichi Matsumoto, to Saigon to assess the facts of the war in Vietnam.

Vladimir Horowitz held his first press conference yesterday afternoon at Steinway Sons to repeat statements that had appeared Wednesday in an interview in The New York Times. He did not set a date for his first recital at Carnegie Hall, but said again that he would announce it two weeks in advance.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 19 -- The New York Mets scored five runs in the ninth inning tonight to defeat the St. Louis Cardinals in the first night game here since major league baseball came to Florida 50 years ago.
GENEVA, March 19 -- The World Health Organization said today that its experts found the outlook for sufferers from cancer "increasingly hopeful."

HOUSTON, March 19 (AP) -- Surgeons decided today that an operation to separate two Siamese twins from Puerto Rico would kill one of the girls and possibly both. The girls have a common five-chamber heart.
Educational station WNDT (Channel 13), which had to reduce its staff by 25 members on March 1, announced yesterday that 35 more would be discharged April 3.

Ten New York City patrolmen and a sergeant will leave next Friday on a two-week orientation trip to Puerto Rico to learn how to improve relations between policemen and the Puerto Rican community here.
Wall Street observers will keep a close eye on the market action of General Motors watching for a market-trend clue.
Hundreds of jubilant, cheering and chanting fans swarmed around Maria Callas as the soprano left the Metropolitan Opera House last night after her return to the Met stage.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, March 16 -- The best military judgment of the opposing forces in the eastern Congo seems to be that neither side looks like a winner.

The leaders of 250,000 members of 10 maritime unions will meet Tuesday to arrange protest demonstrations against a three-day meeting scheduled to begin that day between representatives of the State Department and 10 nations for a review of maritime matters.
MEMPHIS, March 19 -- More than 150 priests, nuns and laymen began a three-day meeting here today to seek to deepen Roman Catholic involvement in the civil rights drive in the South.
CLEVELAND, March 19 -- Two undefeated teams remained in the Vanderbilt Cup tournament tonight as it went int its seventh round.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, March 19 -- The Indonesian Government seized control today of three foreign oil companies here, two of them United States-owned.
A former evecutive of an advertising agency testified reluctantly in court yesterday that a highly successful promotion campaign for a reducing pill had been dishonest.
LONDON, March 19 -- A bizarre auction room dispute ended dramatically today when Rembrandt's portrait of his son, "Titus," was sold for $2,234,000 to the Norton Simon Foundation of Los Angeles.

A checklist for national sanity:

NORMAL, Ill., March 19 (UPI) -- Bucknell's defending champions captured two first places tonight in the National Collegiate Athletic Association college division swimming and diving championships, but failed to catch two front-running California teams.

BAY SHORE, L.I., March 19 -- Dick Scorese, Brook Yeager and Orlando Iacavelli all won tonight to give the favored New York Athletic Club a commanding position in the Metropolitan Senior Amateur Athletic Union wrestling championships.

THE annals of crime are largely in the public domain Paradoxically, however, the public domain can be a hiding place for lots of murderous skulduggery. What everyone has a right to know is by no means synonymous with what everyone can find out or be told.

The Amateur Athletic Union refused yesterday to get into the controversy over the amateur status of Abebe Bikila, the Olympic marathon champion, if he ran April 21 in connection with the opening of the World's Fair.

LONDON, March 19 (Reuters) -- A Laborite Member of Parliament and his wife protested today against the killing of 45 children when Vietnamese Air Force Skyraiders bombed a village in South Vietnam Wednesday.
SWATHED from head to toe in what looked like a sari but was actually a "tobe" (apparently they are wound differently), a young Sudanese woman recently discussed her native cuisine.

The Federal Communications Commission voted 1 to 2 yesterday to issue a proposal designed to curb economic domination of the television industry by the three coast-to-coast networks. Spokesmen for the industry have already made known their bitter opposition to the plan.

For every one of the 600 American teen-agers whose deaths are recorded as suicide each year, there are at least 100 who fail in the attempt or who take their own lives under the guise of accident, a group of social scientists and teachers was told yesterday.
ALBANY, March 19 -- The Court of Appeals has ruled that a director of a Brooklyn hospital is entitled to inspect the institution's medical records involving live cancer cell experiments.
WHITE PLAINS, March 19 -- Westchester officials and Republican leaders have agreed on a reapportionment of the County Board of Supervisors that would increase the number of members from 45 to 52.

WASHINGTON -- The index of wholesale primary market prices was unchanged at 101.4 of its 1957-59 base during the week ended March 16, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. Farm products advanced in price, while industrial commodities moved lower.

Peter Herman Adler brought the Baltimore Symphony to Carnegie Hall for a concert of contemporary music last night. The orchestra, which is celebrating its 50th anniversary, has not been here since 1946.

WARSAW, March 18 -- The story of how a talented Russian pianist lost out in the seventh Frederic Chopin international piano competition and how the embarrassed Polish judges tried to change the rules so that she could be a finalist became known today.
ATHENS, March 19 -- Premier Suat Hayri Urguplu of Turkey today proposed Greek-Turkish talks to break the Cyprus deadlock.

GENEVA, March 19 -- Experts from 26 nations have drafted an amendment to the International Agreement on Patents and other industrial property rights that would meet Moscow's demand for recognition of its "inventors certificate."

President Johnson's surprise appointment of Henry H. Fowler gives assurance that the Treasury Department will be headed by a man who recognizes the vital importance of restoring its influence and prestige in economic affairs.
PORT HURON, Mich., March 19 (AP) -- The ELTRA Corporation has offered to purchase all or any part of the outstanding shares of Mueller Brass Company common stock, the Port Huron company said today.
WASHINGTON, March 19 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board granted permission to Trans World Airlines today to discuss with helicopter operators possible ways of helping them financially.
DALLAS, March 19 (AP) -- A Federal judge sent the Jack Ruby sanity-lawyer dispute case back to state courts today after hearing a lengthy monologue from Ruby about lawyers and conspiracies.

BELLEVILLE, N.J., March 19 -- More than 5,400 public school pupils had an unscheduled holiday today as their teachers staged a demonstration at Town Hall to protest a $277,900 slash in the 1965-66 school budget.

Lutheran and Roman Catholic leaders of the United States completed plans this week for high-level theological talks, which will be the first formal conversations ever held by the two communions in this country.
WASHINGTON, March 19 -- The police began investigating today the defacing of ten paintings -- nine of them by well known New York artists -- at the Corcoran Gallery of Art.
ON THE NORTH VIETNAMESE BORDER, March 19 -- South Vietnamese border guards led three sponsors of a peace movement by the arm today across a bridge into North Vietnam.

ROME March 19 (AP) -- A Moslem funeral service was held today for former King Farouk of Egypt in Rome's municipal morgue. His lawyer-said Farouk had left his estate to his son and three daughters and nothing to his two former wives.

BOGALUSA, La., March 19 (AP) -- A radio station owner said today he was on the verge of being driven out of business by harassment and economic intimidation of his sponsors. He said the campaign was inspired by the Ku Klux Klan.
The Long Island Rail Road engineers' union agreed yesterday that there would be no slowdowns pending resumption of hearing Tuesday before Federal Judge George Rosling in Brooklyn.
WASHINGTON, March 19 -- The United States publicly urged Greece and Turkey today to call a new conference over Cyprus to prevent a war between them or major outbreaks of violence on the island.

BONN, March 19 -- Walt W. Rostow, the State Department's planning chief, warned European nations tonight that failure to support the United States in Southeast Asia might bring "erosion" of the Atlantic alliance.

Joseph Pepe, a blind news dealer, and his Seeing Eye dog, Gretel, are together again. The 90-pound shepherd, missing since Wednesday, was found in Manhattan and returned shortly before midnight on Thursday by John C. Quirke, a mechanic, of Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- The State Department was uncertain today whether the takeover of American oil companies in Indonesia by the Sukarno Government was a protective move or portended expropriation of the extensive foreign properties.
PARIS, March 19 -- President de Gaulle is expected by allied diplomats to resume his efforts to promote a negotiated settlement of the fighting in South Vietnam.

Dr. Robert M. Erdman, the principal witness in the 1962 trial that led to the imprisonment of former Supreme Court Justice J. Vincent Keogh and two others, was attacked and stabbed in his office at 1 A.M. yesterday.

Of its planned $500 million in capital spending each year for 1965 and 1966, the Chrysler Corporation has earmarked 25 per cent overseas. The most important outlays will be made in Australia, France Canada and South Africa. The total would amount to $250 million for both years.
WASHINGTON, March 19 (UPI) -- The life of a family goldfish is a secret compared to someone growing up in the White House, Lynda Bird Johnson said today -- on her 21st birthday.

The University of Bridgeport and the American Shakespeare Festival Theater of Stratford, Conn., have established the Shakespeare Institute, which will offer college credit courses in drama. Dr. Allan Lewis has been named its director, Dr. Henry W. Littlefield, president of the university, and Joseph Verner Reed, executive producer of the festival, announced yesterday.

CARACAS, Venezuela, March 12 -- The guerrilla bands that move through the mountains of northwest Venezuela and the humid scrublands of the northeast seem to be more a symbol than an instrument of what the far left may hope to accomplish here some day.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 19 -- In what amounted to a massive miscalculation, the New York Yankee A team was thoroughly squelched by the Minnesota Twins today, 5-0, while only a few miles to the north, at Pompano Beach, the Yankee B squad pummeled the Washington Senators, 12-5.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 19 -- The Security Council voted unanimously today to extend United Nations peacekeeping efforts in Cyprus through June 26 as speakers urged more effective action against mounting pressures for new violence there.

SAN LUIS, Cuba -- The sunburned men who grow Cuba's quality cigar tobacco here say they are harvesting the best crop since Fidel Castro seized power in 1959.

WASHINGTON, March 19 (AP) -- The Commerce Department estimated yesterday that retail sales for the week ended March 13 totaled $4.85 billion, up about 1 per cent from the level of the previous week and up 5 per cent from the level of the corresponding 1964 week.
The American Stock Exchange made a turnabout yesterday, with advances outnumbering declines for the first time in four days.
MONTICELLO, N.Y. March 19 -- Archie Moore, a former light-heavyweight champion was a visitor to Willie Pastrano's training camp today. Pastrano boxed five rounds with three sparring partners.
The London stock market lost ground in quiet trading yesterday, continuing the trend that prevailed all week.
Chas. Pfizer Co., Inc., won an opening round yesterday in what promises to be a continuing legal battle over its patent on tetracycline, a broad-spectrum antibiotic.
The role of the Surveyor of Customs in the economic life of the Port of New York was outlined in a talk Thursday evening before the Foreign Commerce Club of New York at the Astor Hotel.
TRENTON, March 19 (AP) -- State Senate Republican leaders filed a petition today seeking up to two years' delay in a State Supreme Court order to reapportion the Legislature.
SELMA, Ala., March 19 -- The leaders of the Negro movement at Selma sent 300 white visitors to pray at the Mayor's home today and they, were all arrested.

Driving along the Long Island Expressway to his Manhattan office from his home in Jamaica Estates, Queens. Highway Commissioner John T. Carroll found himself slowed to a crawl yesterday during the morning rush hour.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- Secretary of State Dean Rusk expressed regret today that the Soviet Union was apparently uninterested in further diplomatic efforts to promote a settlement of the war in Vietnam.

In his letter published March 15 Charles Sheedy suggests that all citizens should be permitted to decide the propriety and social consequences of the use of tax money to subsidize birth control services.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 19 -- Gov. George C. Wallace told President Johnson today that Alabama was too poor to pay the cost of mobilizing the National Guard to police the Selma-to-Montgomery Freedom March starting Sunday.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- The ruddy face, irascible nature, Southern charm and conservative outlook that characterize Henry Hamill Fowler are known throughout political Washington and by much of the power elite of the rest of the nation as well.
