Verdi's "Aida" will be given today by the Metropolitan Opera at 2 P.M. and his "La Forza del Destino" tonight at 8.

IT WAS a personal triumph last night at the Metropolitan Opera, and the person was, of course, Maria Callas. The occasion was the celebrated soprano's return to the house in Puccini's "Tosca." New York had been thrown into a tizzy ever since the announcement about the performance was made, and last night only served to bring everything to a boil.

NASHVILLE, March 19 -- In a dramatic appearance on death row of the Tennessee penitentiary Gov. Frank G. Clement today commuted to life imprisonment the death sentences of five convicts and, in effect, abolished capital punishment in Tennessee for the next two years of his term in office.

Blue Cross is planning to seek another big rate increase from its 7.5 million subscribers in the New York metropolitan area. Its charges for hospital insurance have gone up 124 per cent in the past five years. When the last increase of 32.9 per cent was upheld in State Supreme Court last fall, the judge warned that the plan was near bankruptcy and that only remedial legislation could stave off disaster.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 19 (AP) -- Kathy Whitworth of San Antonio, Tex., shot a 66 today to take the second-round lead in the $10,000 St. Petersburg women's open golf tournament.

WASHINGTON, March 19 (AP) -- Farmers are expected to plant about the same acreage to spring crops this year as last, but an Agriculture Department survey indicated today there may be some dramatic shifts. An increase of 8 per cent in soybean acreage is in prospect.

YONKERS, March 19 -- Among the 26,411 harness-racing enthusiasts at Yonkers Raceway tonight, some wouldn't have taken odds of 7-20 that it was Friday. Quite a few, however, took 7-20 that Harry's Laura, a 5-year-old pacing mare, would win the $12,500 Adios Festival consolation pace

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., March 19 (UPI) -- About 25 Negro and white demonstrators were routed from the Capitol basement by an irritating gas and club-swinging state policemen today in a third unsuccessful attempt to integrate the statehouse cafeteria.

Soybean futures for delivery this month rebounded yesterday after the sharp sell-off Thursday. At the same time, a largely divided speculative market on the Chicago Board of Trade sold off the September soybean contract and left most grain futures depressed.

Va., March 19 -- While operating revenues of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway so far this year have run about $2 million ahead of the $86 million gross for the first quarter of 1964, stockholders were told here today that net income for the current quarter would be about $350,000 to $400,000 below the $8.6 million net profit reported in 1964.

LONDON, March 19 -- Andrei A. Gromyko ended his talks in London today as he had begun, by saying that the way to peace in Vietnam was to end the "United States aggression."

ROME, March, 19 -- Pope Paul VI expressed the hope today that the "great and marvelous" Soviet space achievement would "serve to render men better, more united and intent to serve ideals of peace and common good."

For President Johnson, there really is no such thing as a "normal" day, but he adheres roughly to a routine. He usually awakens at about 6:30 A.M., and spends up to two hours in bed reading reports and newspapers, eating a light breakfast, making phone calls, and conferring with assistants. Around 10 o'clock, he begins the appointments, meetings, paper work, ceremonies and visits which ordinarily occupy him well past the dinner hour.

Luther Lassiter of Elizabeth City, N.C., is a slight favorite to regain the world pocket billiard championship in a tournament starting this afternoon in the Windsor Ballroom of the Hotel Commodore.

KINGSTON, N.Y. -- This town, where those properly attuned can still hear Aaron Burr's ghostly violin being played on melancholy evenings, is a fine place to stop during a weekend tour into the history of the Hudson Valley.

HILLSBOROUGH, Calif., March 20 (AP) -- Eight oil paintings -- including two Van Goghs and a Renoir -- have been reported missing from the late W.W. Crocker's Hillsborough mansion, Police Chief Russell Fisher said today.

A leading African psychiatrist, who was here for the annual meeting of the American Ortho-psychiatric Association last week, readily acknowledges his professional debt to the village healer -- the "witch doctor."
captured their second crown. The Houghton, Mich., team also won the championship in 1962. In 1956 and 1960, the Huskies finished in second place.
RABAT, Morocco, March 20 -- Morocco's first woman ambassador received her credentials today as envoy to Brittain, marking a significant breakthrough for her sex in this Moslem country.

CLEVELAND, March 20 -- As a result of seventh-round play in the Vanderbilt Cup contest here last night, only Oswald Jacoby's team remained unbeaten. With James Jacoby and Dr. John Fisher, both of Dallas. Philip Feldesman of Queens Village, Queens; Ira Rubin of Fair Lawn, N.J., and Albert Weiss of Miami Beach, Jacoby defeated Ed Rosen's Midwest team by 36 points
RICHMOND, March 20 -- Virginia's laws on voting and registration provide that a voter must reside in the state one year; the county, city or town six months, and precinct, 30 days.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 20 -- The new Interior Minister, Takieddin Solh, has announced that, to protect -- the dignity of shoeshine boys -- and men -- customers must take off their shoes instead of standing with one foot on the shine box while the shiner kneels or stoops over the shoe.

EXAMPLES gleaned from four decades of the photo essay, photojournalism's dominant approach, went on display last week at the Museum of Modern Art. The show, in the first-floor gallery, can be seen through May 16.
WASHINGTON, March 20 -- Passage and enforcement of the voting-rights legislation proposed by President Johnson could arrest the swing of some Southern states toward the Republican party.

Alwin Nikolais, the indefatigable man of all talents at the Henry Street Playhouse has created a dance theater work called "Galaxy." It was given its premiere at the playhouse on Friday night by a company of 27 dancers headed by Gladys Bailin, Bill Frank, Phyllis Lamhut and Murray Louis.

ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, March 20 -- The old province of Katanga, which was cut into three pieces after the failure of its attempts at secession, may be reunified if the forces of Premier Moise Tshombe score a strong victory in the general election now under way.

Your Feb. 27 editorial "Changing Spain" discussing Spanish demonstrations for a more democratic national student organization, attributed them to the economic boom that is changing Spain without giving enough importance to the intellectual changes that these demonstrations reflect.

HARRISBURG, Pa., March 20 -- Ch. Fezziwig Raggedy Andy, a great pigeon-blue Old English sheepdog owned by Serena and Hendrik Van Rensselaer of Basking Ridge, N.J., was named best in show tonight in the 30th Harrisburg Kennel Club event.
GRUBS, which are the larvae or immature stage of beetles, do considerable damage to lawns by feeding on the grass roots. They are white to gray in color with brown heads and six prominent legs.

Jane Krieger Rosen's article, "Africans in Darkest New York" (Feb. 28), was again evidence of the vast gulf of understanding between Americans and Africans. If Mrs. Rosen thinks that African wives find it difficult to adjust to New York life, she need only observe American wives in Nigeria who make little effort, if any, to know Nigerians or Nigerian life.

LONDON, Sunday, March 21 (UPI) -- The Earl of Avon, who as Anthony Eden was Britain's wartime Foreign Secretary, has criticised President Franklin D. Roosevelt for "recklessness" during World War II and has accused him of secretly negotiating with the Soviet Union without consulting the Allies.

IN this book about one of the most colorful and popular World War II heroes, Lawrence A. Keating sketches the career of William F. Halsey from his birth in Elizabeth, N.J. to his retirement as a fleet admiral in 1947. Inevitably, the book concentrates on Halsey's exploits as commander of the South Pacific area and later of the formidable Third Fleet.

The immediate fascination of the Berkeley story is, of course, in the clash of forces -- students vs. administration and administration vs. the Board of Regents. All the elements of battle are there, and the observer can enjoy the war because it is fought with words rather than bullets.
NORMAL, Ill., March 20 (AP) -- San Diego State chalked up 168 1/2 points during the three days of the National Collegiate swimming championships to triumph over 52 other schools tonight.

FROM an overall standpoint, the recent St. John Passion of Bach issued on the Deutsche Grammophon Archiv Production label is extraordinarily spacious and moving. Karl Richter, who conducts the Munich Bach Choir and Orchestra, brings out the fervor and drama of the work to a rare degree on the three disk album (3228-30; stereo 73328-30).

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- Mobilization of Alabama National Guard units today marks the 11th time in the last decade that members of these military reserve forces have been called to duty in racial crises -- the fourth time in Alabama.

AUSTIN, Tex., March 20 (UPI) -- President Johnson, replying to critics of his press relations, promised today to hold at least one news conference a month that would be announced in advance and open to television coverage.

A ARON SISKIND'S 30 years of work as a photographer will be placed on display Friday in the Dryden Theater of George Eastman House in Rochester, N.Y. The show will consist of 200 photographs, ranging from Mr. Siskind's early documentary photographic activity in New York City to his current work.

DOVER Records, which began recording its own material only last year (having contented itself until then with re-issues of monophonic recordings formerly offered by Vox and Period), has released three disks resulting from its initial New York sessions.

As a volunteer ski patrolman, retired after 25 years of efforts to promote some safety on skis, I must reply to W. Godfrey Cobliner's criticisms of area operators and patrolmen en masse. He accuses the ski operators of failing to "insure" the safety of their runs.
WATERBURY, Conn., March 20 -- A park called The Green in the heart of this mill city in the Naugatuck Valley started losing its old air of enchantment some years ago.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 20 James S. Killen, director of the United States mission in South Vietnam, said today that prospects for building an effective civilian government here were better now than at any time in tile last year.

CRABGRASS can now be controlled. Even if the home is in the middle of a field of crabgrass, a crabgrass-free lawn is possible. The trick is to prevent the weed from sprouting rather than to control it after it has germinated.

Zenon Fishbein's recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall was a study ill glittering piano sonority. French and Spanish works dominated the program, and in them the pianist, who teaches at the Manhattan School of Music, showed himself to be tasteful, intelligent, and serious.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 20 -- Gov. George C. Wallace declined to comment today on President Johnson's criticism of the segregationist Governor's refusal to use his state powers to police the Selma-to-Montgomery freedom march.

JULIO CORTAZAR is an Argentine who has lived and worked in Paris since 1952, and although his stories have been published in New World Writing, "The Winners" is the first book of his to be published in the United States. This formidable novel should be welcomed here, for it introduces an outstanding writer of immense scope in an excellent translation by Elaine Kerrigan.

BUENOS AIRES, March 20 -- The assembly of the University of Buenos Aires, made up of faculty, students and alumni representatives, failed today for the second time to elect a new rector for the influential state academy.

" The polls have spoken," a Peronist leader said last week in Argentina, "Peron must return to the country. This is an ineluctable mandate determined by the people and which admits no delay or distortion of any kind."
ORWIGSBURG, Pa., March 20 -- The Hawk Mountain Sanctuary Association has acquired 640 acres adjacent to its nature sanctuary near Kempton.

SELMA, Ala., Sunday, March 21 -- Selma was hovering between festivity and chaos last night and early today as plans were carried forward for the Alabama Freedom March to Montgomery, scheduled to begin at 10 A.M. today. Hundreds of marchers poured into the city, which has a normal population of 28,000.
NEWARK, March 20 -- Five persons were killed and at least seven others injured in a four-car accident here this afternoon.
St. Luke's Hospital researchers have reported promising gains in a battle against a cruel blood disease that afflicts thousands of persons in the Metropolitan area.

WOOD floors take on added charm and beauty when they are stained a rich-looking dark color. The stain enhances the grain and helps to bring out the wood's natural warmth and attractive appearance. Homeowners who would like to duplicate this effect in their own homes can do so -- but they must remove all of the old finish first.
Hugh McElhenny, at one time the most feared running back in the National Football League and now a New York businessman, will be honored at a testimonial dinner in Toots Shor's restaurant March 31.

MOSCOW, March 20 -- The Soviet Government announced today that it had rescinded a rule promulgated by Nikita S. Khrushchev that allotted 80 per cent of the university admissions quota to persons with at least two years work experience.

PROBABLY the most dangerous person on the road in the United States, both to himself and to others, is the young serviceman who drives along a familiar route at night in an old car with low horsepower -- and is going way above or way below the speed limit.
HALLANDALE, Fla., March 20 (AP) -- Gray Willows Farm's Ampose defeated Old Hat, the even money favorite, by a neck today in the $16,600 Appleton Handicap at Gulfstream Park.

MARIANNE (Pinkie) Rollo a and Patricia Mernone of Washington, an outstanding pair in endurance races last year with a French Peugeot 404, will compete in at least 10 races this year, starting with the sedan event at Danville, Va., on April 10.

BONN, March 20 -- A guide showing a visitor around the sprawling Adam Opel automotive plant in the Ruhr grimaced when he saw the visitor watching a row of blue-clad women bending over the assembly line.

PARIS, March 17 -- Step by step, often unnoticed, the institutions of the six nations that form the three European Communities are developing more power. Their authority has expanded beyond the routine and into basic policy.

PARIS. A TALL, slender man of very youthful appearance stood beyond the open door of the Paris UNESCO building. Was this possibly Julio Cortazar, the Argentinian writer born in 1914, who serves UNESCO four months out of the year as a freelance translator?
STOCKHOLM, March 18 -- At night in Stockholm, Malmo, Goteborg and other Swedish cities, the "raggare," or youths who chase girls with cars, come out in their souped-up vehicles 10 or more years old.
TORONTO, March 20 (AP) -- More than 150 clergymen came here from across Canada and spent a good part of the week casting stones -- curling stones, that is.

THE New York City Opera's recent new production of the Bertolt Brecht-Kurt Weill "Die Dreigroschenoper" sent me back for another look at John Gay's "Beggar's Opera." My impression was confirmed.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 20 -- Revised projections of world population growth indicate that the less-developed areas will account for 85 per cent of increases expected by the end of this century. The total increase is expected to double the world's population by the year 2000.

Thank you for including Curacao in the list of countries that do not require vaccination for entry. Strictly speaking, however, this is not accurate. Every country in the world that participates in the international health conventions requires a smallpox vaccination.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (UPI) -- The National Aeronautics and Space Administration was accused today of "playing an on-again, off-again secrecy game" about past Soviet satellite launchings that did little but confuse the American public.

VERO BEACH, Fla. -- With the opening late last month of a new, high-level bridge over the Sebastian Inlet, 16 miles north of here, the longest continuous stretch of oceanfront highway on the east coast of Florida is now available for travel.

The American Association of Junior Colleges announced recently that 41 new two-year college campuses were opened last year. It is estimated that the junior colleges will need 3,000 new administrators, including 1,400 presidents, within the next 15 years.

The home of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur' B. Krim will be the setting on April 4 for an evening of music and drama in behalf of the scholarship fund of the Hebrew Arts School for Music and Dance.

PHILADELPHIA, March 20 (AP) -- Jerry Lucas, wearing a contraption to protect a chest bruise, pumped in 16 field goals on 25 shots as he led the Cincinnati Royals to a 125-122 victory over the Philadelphia 76ers in a National Basketball Association game at Convention Hall tonight.
Antique furniture, English, French and Italian included, and as varied a collection of decorations, will be auctioned on Friday and Saturday at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue.

MONTREAL, March 20 (UPI) -- The Montreal Canadiens, scoring on their first two shots, defeated the Chicago Black Hawks tonight, 3-2, and moved within two points of the first place Detroit Red Wings in the National Hockey League.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- Latin-American countries have made significant plans in the last four years for economic and social reforms but so far the results have been extremely limited, according to a report issued here today.
BRUSSELS, March 20 -- The six member nations of the European Community will make their first concerted move this springspring toward political union this spring.
DETROIT, March 20 -- The question of fiscal reform, which resulted in a clash between Gov. George Romney and the Michigan Legislature in 1963, once again is becoming a major issue here.

Miss Barbara Ann White, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Stearns White of Enfield Conn., was married yesterday afternoon to Donald Charles Seibert, son of Mrs. Walter E. Seibert, of Wilmington, Del., and Westwood, N.J., and the late Mrs. Seibert.
ALBANY, March 20 -- Governor Rockefeller announced today that he has named his brother Laurance to head a new commission to help New York protect and preserve the Hudson River.

ARNHEM, the Netherlands -- To people over 30, this modest Dutch city on the Rhine has special significance. Here, in 1944, with great heroism and at great loss of life, the British Red Devils parachuted as part of General Montgomery's drive to rid the Netherlands of Nazis.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- Poets -- rather than scientists, technicians and statesmen -- will have to lead mankind out of the chaos and bewilderment of contemporary life because only the poet can "see around the unknown curve to guess by means of intuitive wisdom what the unborn thing we call our future will grow into."

CLEVELAND -- The first major events in the Spring National Championships of the American Contract Bridge League proved a triumph for three brilliant New York players. Jeff Rubens, at the age of 24 a player of the highest talent, won both the Men's Pair and Men's Team titles.

In modern times in the United States, Roman Catholic nuns have usually devoted themselves either to the contemplative world of the convent or to the world of service in teaching, nursing, missionary work and similar activities. Direct participation in political or civic affairs has been rare.

As the ski-jumping season in Europe nears its close, attention today will be centered at Mitterndorf, Austria. At that community's huge hill, dozens of the world's top jumpers will take part in the annual ski-flying (Kulmskifliegen) tournament.

BRADENTON, Fla., March 20 -- Ken Harrelson won a couple of recent ballplayers' golf tournaments but has yet to gain as much distinction on the diamond. If spring were merely a matter of the vernal equinox it would be a very dull event indeed. That incident of celestial mechanics occurred yesterday afternoon and, what with fresh snow pelting down, few of us could see that it made any particular difference in the day. No tree suddenly burst into leaf, no bank of flowers opened their petals, no chorus of birdsong hailed the moment or even the hour.

Swimsuits and beach apparel heading for one of the biggest seasons in recent years, orders from stores to resident buying offices indicate. Orders are particularly heavy for two-piece bathing suits, many with illusion fishnet styling.

THE author of "The Fire Within" Pierre Drieu la Rochelle, a Frenchman who wrote between the wars and is largely unknown to Americans. Unknown for good and sufficient reasons, if this short novel is anything to go by. For this is the kind of bad novel that could only happen in France (every literature has its troubles): a witch's brew of bad classical technique, undeviating angst and second-drawer cafe-philosophy.

DARIEN, Conn., March 20 -- Domestic and overseas projects aided by the First Congregational Church of Darien will gain from the second annual antiques show and sale at the parish house. It will be held from noon to 10 P.M. Wednesday through Friday.

The fourth annual report of the Social Progress Trust Fund, like its predecessors, is a gold mine of facts and figures on Latin America. Only the Economic Commission for Latin America (ECLA), an affiliate of the United Nations with headquarters in Santiago, Chile, provides any comparable amount of economic and social information.

The Transit Authority announced yesterday that major changes in subway service on two IRT lines serving the Bronx would be made on April 18. New routes will become effective for trains on the 241st Street-White Plains Road line and the East 180th Street-Dyre Avenue line.

Record sales exceeding $1 billion were announced over the weekend by Allied Chemical Corporation in its annual report for 1964. Earnings, at $3.08 per share, also set a record and were 11 per cent higher than the $2.77 earned in 1963.

BRUSSELS, March 21 -- It will be out of the frying pan and into the fire for the European Common Market's Executive Commission on Tuesday when international monetary reform is debated during the European Parliament's plenary session in Strasbourg, France.

Prominent criminologists and sociologists, in a growing controversy with law enforcement agencies, are challenging official statistics and claims that show a sharp increase in the crime rate.
Music from Mexico, Canada and the United States shared the third and final program of the Orchestra of America's sixth season, under Richard Korn's direction, at Carnegie Hall last night.

PARIS, March 21 -- The Socialist Mayor of Marseilles, Gaston Defferre, emerged triumphant tonight from the race for control of his city's Municipal Council. This considerably reinforced his position as an anti-Gaullist contender for the French Presidency.

THE combined freighter and passenger ship Malcolm pulled away from its dock at Buenos Aires secretly by night. It was all very mysterious. The passengers were the winners of a Tourist Lottery approved by the Office of Municipal Affairs. Those who wished had been permitted to bring members of their families with them.

The words and music of the President's housing message have been something less than a smash hit, but the melody lingers on. And it will, because it dealt not just with housing, but with the needs of 135 million Americans, or over 70 per cent of the population, who live in the country's urban areas.
MOSCOW, March 21 -- News of the death of a Ghanaian student, apparently by murder has caused emotion to run high among African students here, informed sources reported today.

BAY SHORE, L.I., March 21 -- A pair of seasoned wrestlers -- Bill Farrell and Lou Giani -- added to their impressive records last night as they led the New York Athletic Club to the team championship in the metropolitan senior Amateur Athletic Union tournament.

The movement, running at full tide across the nation, to abolish capital punishment has received the influential and authoritative support of New York's Commission on Revision of the Penal Code. This bipartisan body, composed of legislators and lawyers, has been at work for four years rewriting and recodifying criminal law, the first complete modernization in nearly 85 years.

HAVANA, March 21 -- A Zionist youth group held a Purim celebration today in the modern Jewish community center in Havana's skyscraper district. A foreigner commented that Cuba was the only Communist country where this was possible.
PORTLAND, Ore., March 21 -- From a truly exciting National basketball tournament, William Warren Bradley of Princeton emerged as the most exciting player.
James Stafford, an angry young pianist from Louisiana who made his local debut in 1963, played his first Town Hall program yesterday afternoon.

Mayor Wagner called on Governor Rockefeller yesterday for help in putting sharper penalties into housing law enforcement to take the government off "an endless treadmill" where slums grow faster than new housing.

Ossie Davis and Ruby Dee, his wife, who appeared on television together last summer in scenes from famous fictional courtships and marriages, will dramatize the love theme again on the new series, "The Creative Person."
Widespread abuse of the state income tax's life insurance deductions has been reported by State Controller Arthur Levitt.

ROME, March 21 -- Communist China's Foreign Minister, Chen Yi, was reported today to have said that if the United States crossed the 17th Parallel to attack North Vietnam "and if the Government of Vietnam asks us for aid, our help will be assured."
The United States Smelting, Refining and Mining Company has made an offer to buy all the common stock of the Mueller Brass Company at $42 a share, according to an announcement made over the weekend.
" All in Good Time" will close Saturday night at the Royale Theater after its 44th performance, joining the list of plays that were successful abroad but shortlived on Broadway.
Governor Rockefeller said yesterday that the March 1 target date for the selection of a candidate for Mayor had been "set by two people who refused to meet it."
Mayor Wagner approved plans yesterday for the construction of a $47,150 eternal light memorial to President Kennedy at Grand Army Plaza in Brooklyn.
LONDON, March 21 -- The Soviet Government may sell part of its huge and valuable collection of Czarist art treasures on the London auction market.
SELMA, Ala., March 21 -- The logistics of the five-day civil rights march to Montgomery that left Selma today rivaled those for Army maneuvers in scope, if not in orderliness.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- A record growth of frequency-modulation radio was reported at today's opening session of the annual convention of the National Association of Broadcasters. But a controversy developed immediately over what course the high-fidelity medium should pursue, including a suggestion that FM needed more bop and and less Bach.
An eminent Swiss psychiatrist emphasized yesterday the need to incorporate faith into one's professional work.
NASSAU, Bahamas, March 21 (AP) -- Basil Kelly nu Nassau won the only race today and took the lead in the Star Class spring sailing championships for the Meyers Cup.
The world's most powerful oceangoing tug and the first supertug under American ownership will be built in Japan for an affiliate of the Moran Towing and Transportation Company.
LYONS, France, March 21 -- Communist China is reported to be negotiating with Berliet, France's largest manufacturer of heavy trucks, for the construction of several Berliet plants in China.

Cicero Murphy, a 29-year-old Negro from Brooklyn, made his opening match in the world pocket billiard championship tournament yesterday a memorable one. Senator Robert F. Kennedy left last night for the Yukon, where he will attempt to be the first man to reach the top of a 13,900-foot mountain peak named after President Kennedy.
LONDON, March 21 -- When the New York World's Fair reopens next month, it will have a pavilion evoking dramatic memories of Sir Winston Churchill as politician, writer and artist.

KARACHI, Pakistan, March 21 -- President Mohammad Ayub Khan's Pakistan Moslem League scored an expected easy victory in the National Assembly elections today.

PARIS -- Italy, plagued by unstable government, has finally launched a serious effort to get itself out of a recession that the instability helped to create. France, slowly adjusting to uncommon government stability, is beginning to do the same for the same reason.

PHILADELPHIA, March 21 (AP) -- The Philadelphia 76ers raced to a 25-point half-time lead and then coasted to a 127-105 victory over the Baltimore@ Bullets today as the teams concluded their regular National Basketball Association season.

Puccini's one-act operas "Il Tabarro," "Suor Angelica" and "Gianni Schicci" formed the program of the New York City Opera last night. Their premiere was at the Metropolitan Opera in 1918, and they were first presented by the City Opera in 1961 and were repeated in 1962.

One of the biggest bargains in life insurance -- National Service Life Insurance -- again will be available, beginning May 1, to many veterans who either did not take the opportunity to carry it into civilian life or who did not take the $10,000 maximum.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 21 -- South Vietnamese Skyraider fighter-bombers, accompanied by United States Air Force fighter planes, attacked today the North Vietnamese base of Vucon, 15 miles north of the demilitarized zone dividing Vietnam.

ROXBURGH, Scotland, March 21 -- Two by-elections this week may give some clues to the standing of Prime Minister Harold Wilson and the Labor party. One will be in this Scottish border country, the other in Saffron Walden, 40 miles north of London.

CLEVELAND, March 21 -- A California pair leads the field of 312 qualifiers, survivors of an original entry of 756 pairs, into the final session of the Open Pair Championship here tonight but several New Yorkers are well in contention.

ATHENS, March 21 -- A preliminary settlement of the Cyprus problem is being pursued indirectly between Greece and Turkey with the help of Western diplomats, authoritative sources disclosed here today.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- British and American diplomatic strategy on Vietnam will be reviewed in talks here this week between Foreign Secretary Michael Stewart and President Johnson and Secretary of State Dean Rusk.

Will the dollar glut be replaced by a dollar shortage? For the first time in over a decade, this question is receiving serious attention in monetary and financial circles here and abroad. The quick success of the Johnson Administration's new "voluntary" program to curb the outflow of dollars is largely responsible.

Contemporary Dance, Inc., presented its fifth annual Youth Choreographers' Concert at the 41st Street Theater on Saturday and gave a performance of the event last night.

WASHINGTON, March 21 (UPI) -- James J. Saxon, Controller of the Currency, moved today to tighten Federal checks on the ownerships of national banks.

Bids are inter-dealer prices and do not include retail markdown or commission. Asked prices have been adjusted upward to include approximate markup.

Sixteen championships ranging from the 112-pound to the heavyweight class will be at stake tonight in the 39th annual New York Golden Gloves finals for amateur boxers at Madison Square Garden. The first match will begin at 8 P.M.

THE old adage that "style is the man" holds as good in chess as in other arts. The idea was saliently shown by the way Arnold Denker, a former United States champion, as White in a Slav Defense, defeated the master Robert Steinmeyer in the current Manhattan Club championship.

A group of licensed deck officers employed on the city's Staten Island ferries has petitioned the State Supreme Court for a judgment compelling the city to pay them 50 cents an hour retroactive to last July.

Queens District Attorney Frank D. O'Connor declared yesterday that he favored abolition of the death penalty because capital punishment "has not proved a deterrent" to crime.
Cardinal Spellman urged churchgoers yesterday in a pastoral letter to give "at least one day's income" to the 1965 appeal of New York Catholic Charities.

We believe continuing publicity and interpretation of this serious social problem can be of real assistance in the acceptance of battered-child legislation and in bringing protection to the children involved, as well as appropriate help and treatment to their parents.
RIO de JANEIRO, March 22 -- Brazil's revolutionary Government came out today for direct popular election of 11 state governors this year.

Southern politicians are watching a special Democratic Congressional primary in South Carolina today. They are seeking an up-to-date reading on the voter impact of openly promoting civil rights in an area where that type of campaigning has been unthinkable.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- The Surgeon General, Dr. Luther L. Terry, urged Congress today to require that a cautionary health label be printed on all cigarette packages as an important weapon in the war on lung cancer.
Disturbed by the increase in crime on the subways, the Transport Workers Union urged yesterday that transit patrolmen be assigned to all trains operating between 8 P.M. and 4 A.M.

The principals of the five recently boycotted "600" schools are studying the impact of the demonstration on their disturbed students.
TRENTON, March 22 -- The New Jersey Legislature all but gave up today its effort to produce a reapportionment plan in time for next fall's election.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 22 -- The United Nations conference on tin opened here today with Indonesia -- a leading producer of the metal -- absent. Observers attributed Indonesia's absence from the 50 delegations to the presence of Malaysia, with which she is quarreling.

Mayor Wagner said last night that New York City would still have to levy more taxes this year even if Governor Rockefeller's $3.49 billion budget, liberal in terms of assistance to the city, was passed by the Legislature as submitted.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- Corporate profits fell slightly in the final quarter of last year, but showed a $6.2 billion increase for the year as a whole, the Council of Eco nomic Advisors reported today.

About 10 years ago, Congress set up a formula designed to put on an equal footing those who pay taxes on their retirement income and those who do not -- persons who draw Social Security payments. The formula has been tinkered with on several occasions for the sake of fairness.

COCOA BEACH, Fla., March 22 -- Of all the peculiarities of the space environment, none is more alien to life than the neutralization of gravity. Tomorrow it is hoped that for the first time the effect of such weightlessness can be observed on the most basic level -- that of the living cell.
Luther Lassiter, the defending champion, from Elizabeth City, N.C., moved into the lead last night with a 4-0 won-lost record in the world pocket billiards championships at the Hotel Commodore.

Freight revenues for all groups of water-borne carriers reporting to the Interstate Commerce Commission were down in the third quarter of 1964 compared with the same quarter in 1963, even though two of the five groups reported traffic increases.

The award of a $32,740,605 contract the United States Coast Guard to Avondale Shipyards, Inc., of New Orleans for construction of three 378-foot cutters was announced here yesterday by the Ogden Corporation.
A Dutch banking group is negotiating to acquire Donmoor-Isaacson Inc., a leading maker of boys knit shirts and sportswear.

The Eltra Corporation, which made an offer last week to purchase all or any part of the Mueller Brass Company's 570,013 shares of common stock, said yesterday it did not intend to enter into an auction for the shares despite a competing bid made over the weekend by the United States Smelting, Mining and Refining Company.

Five persons were found guilty of contempt yesterday for their refusal to answer questions put to them by a Grand Jury investigating whether there was a conspiracy to incite to riot during last summer's disturbances in Harlem.
YONKERS, March 22 -- The freeze-out of thoroughbred racing at Aqueduct today had no appreciable effect, as some thought it might, on the attendance at Yonkers Raceway, tonight.

ITHACA, N.Y. March 22 (AP) -- A brother and sister were drowned today, despite the heroic efforts of a passing Motorist, when they plunged through thin ice into the waters of a city reservoir.
The directors of Hart Schaffner Marx yesterday announced the seventh annual increase in its dividend rate.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- It is becoming dangerous for a man to walk the streets alone at night. A solitary male night-walker tells of a harrowing experience on a lonely street within three blocks of his home recently, and his story illustrates the refinements of peril that result from the national crime-mindedness.

HONG KONG, March 22 -- A senior Communist official in North Vietnam has echoed the Chinese Communist stand that the United States must withdraw from South Vietnam before there can be any negotiated settlement.
Mechanical failures on three subway lines delayed thousands of Queens, Brooklyn and Bronx passengers on the way to their jobs in Manhattan yesterday morning.
Two men convicted Feb. 12 in a bribery scandal in the Manhattan office of the Internal Revenue Service were sentenced in Federal court yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 22 -- A major and controversial step toward uniformity in the basic financial structure of the nation's banks was proposed today by the Federal Reserve Board.

New York State collected nearly $140 million in taxes on pari-mutuel betting at flat and harness racing tracks in the past year. Nearly a billion and a half dollars was wagered. In the 25 years since pari-mutuel betting within race tracks has been legal, $16 billion was wagered. Betting outside the fence remains illegal, and is in the hands of illicit bookmakers.
SELMA, Ala., March 22 -- Hundreds of civil rights en thusiasts from all over the country milled about the Negro section of Selma all day today.

COCOA BEACH, Fla., March 22 -- The dancing girls are gone, there is no scandal along the beach; there are flamboyant lights blazing above the motels all night, but there seems to be no electricity in the air. Cocoa Beach has changed.

The three members of the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority -- Robert Moses, George V. McLaughlin and William J. Tracy -- announced yesterday that "harmony has been restored" among them.
PITTSBURGH, March 22 -- Accusations that college students who demonstrated in Montgomery, Ala., last week were deceived by a civil rights group were disputed today.

The pace of negotiations between newspaper unions and the Publishers Association of New York City is scheduled to quicken today. Only a week remains before the expiration date -- midnight March 30 -- of contracts of the 10 unions representing 17,000 employes of the city's newspapers.
Live coverage of the Alabama Freedom March has been promised for today or tomorrow by the National Broadcasting Company. The Selma-to-Montgomery march has so far been seen on tape and film.
WASHINGTON, March 22 -- The United States made a drawing of $75 million worth of three foreign currencies today from the International Monetary Fund.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 22 -- Thomas Dreier, an author, lecturer and public relations specialist, announced today that he and Mrs. Dreier were giving Florida Presbyterian College at St. Petersburg $100,000 because three of its faculty members participated in demonstrations at Selma, Ala.
MOSCOW, March 22 -- The two-man crew of the Soviet spaceship Voskhod 2 sighted another artificial satellite in the sky during their 26-hour orbital flight last week.

LONDON, March 22 -- Few British ballets can give so much pleasure as Frederick Ashton's "Scenes de Ballet," just restored to the Royal Ballet repertory at Covent Garden. Last night a newcomer, Antoinette Silbley, emerged in the ballerina role, and she was enchanting.

MOSCOW, March 22 -- The new Soviet Government today appeared for the first time to be accusing former Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev of having been mistaken about Communist theory as well as practical policy.

BONN, March 22 -- Chancellor Ludwig Erhard and Belgium's Foreign Minister, Paul-Henri Spaak, agreed today that a meeting of Common Market foreign ministers scheduled for May 10 in Venice should be followed by a meeting of the heads of state of the six European nations.

LONDON, March 22 -- Britain's newest ballet company, London Dance Theater, scored a resounding hit tonight at the Vaudeville Theater with a ballet by the young Dutch choreographer Rudi Van Dantzig called "Jungle."
Otis Harris, a 20-year-old garage mechanic in Kalamazoo, Mich., was successfully treated for pneumonia last summer, but in the course of treatment a heart defect that would require surgery was found.

Irving Rivkin, Staten Island member of the city's Tax Commission, ordered 49 reductions in tentative real-estate valuations yesterday and told the property owners they need not sign any pledge that they would not seek further cuts in court.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 22 -- United States planes attacked a radar station 60 miles inside North Vietnam today in carrying out an armed reconnaissance of roads for the first time in this war.
The Rev. Joseph T. Tinnelly, former dean of the St. John's law school, began a week of meetings with faculty and student representatives at St. John's University yesterday.
The stock market leaned toward the upside throughout most of yesterday's session, but slid near the close of trading.
WASHINGTON, March 22 -- President Johnson announced tonight the signing of all agreement with Mexico to solve the problem of salinity in the Colorado River that had been damaging Mexican crops.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, March 22 -- Leading Roman Catholic scholars unanimously approved today a declaration calling for a dialogue with Protestants over Marian belief -- the way in which the Virgin Mary is venerated.

The New York Legislature faces the momentous decision within the next week of what to do with the Rockefeller budget and tax-increase program. The new fiscal year begins April 1, a week from Thursday.
LONDON, March 22 -- A group of Labor members of Parliament tonight assailed the United States for its use of gas and napalm in Vietnam.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, Tuesday, March 23 -- The conservative pro-Western United National party appeared this morning to be winning in Ceylon's national election, held yesterday.

Igor Cassini, former society columnist and brother of the dress designer, Oleg Cassini, is preparing to publish a monthly magazine, Status, beginning on Sept. 1. He described the magazine yesterday as a "critical journal of elegance."

HONG KONG, March 22 -- The Chinese Communist party declared today that the Communist ideological clash had entered a new and critical stage in which the pro-Peking parties would battle harder against Moscow.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 22 -- The New York Yankees, having won five straight pennants, have the most firmly entrenched line-up in baseball. It is composed entirely of experienced winners. On the other hand, the Houston Astros, who played their first game only three years ago when the National League expanded, have concentrated on giving bright young prospects a chance while finishing eighth and ninth.
Greater New York's thoroughbred racing fans spent a blue Monday yesterday.
American steel mills set their third consecutive production record last week by pouring 2.78 million tons of ingots and steel for casting, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP) -- Senate leaders served notice today that if President Johnson's voting rights bill was not passed by April 15, the Senators would forfeit their customery Easter recess.

The Tenneco Corporation, a subsidiary of the Tennessee Gas Tranmission Company of Houston, announced yesterday it had filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering a proposed offering of $50 million of debentures.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- The Administration's $1.3 billion aid-to-education bill was cleared for floor action by the House Rules Committee today.

An initial step in a procedure intended to strip Mayor Wagner of some of his capital budget powers will be taken in the City Council at its City Hall meeting today.

President Johnson's decision to reappoint Charles R. Ross to the Federal Power Commission, nine months after his original term ran out, represents a victory for effective, professional regulation in fields vital to the public interest. Mr. Ross, a Republican, had earned the hostility of the powerful oil and gas lobby by supplying the key vote in several 3-to-2 decisions that have meant tighter scrutiny and lower rates for electric and gas producers and pipeline companies.

The Philadelphia Orchestra will play at Philharmonic Hall at 8:30 tonight. Georges Pretre will conduct.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- The House approved today a toughening up of District of Columbia law and regulations to fight crime in the nation's capital.

Nickerson announced today.

The New York State Athletic Commission expects to announce its decision tomorrow on a proposal that the round-by-round scoring of the officials at next week's championship boxing double-header at Madison Square Garden be made public during the matches.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- American military and intelligence circles have accumulated evidence that the United Arab Republic is making experimental use of chemical warfare against villages in the royalist held territory of Yemen.

One of two suspects, fleeing from a Bronx grocery holdup, was burned yesterday when he tried to hide in an incinerator.
DETROIT, March 22 (AP) -- The nation's auto industry, which has been breaking sales and production records with regularity, set out this week to break another one.

THE Ivy League, scorned at times for its approach to intercollegiate athletics, gained more individual and team honor in sports over the last weekend than any other college athletic conference has achieved in such a short span in recent memory.
TRENTON, March 22 -- The state Senate passed unanimously today a bill to permit New Jersey to join New York and Connecticut in a tri-state transportation commission.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -Vice President Humphrey said this morning that the broadcasting industry and the Government should not squander their energies by quarreling with each other. Four hours later the Federal Communications Commission and the network television business squared off for a controversy that could last for years.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Tuesday, March 23 -- The National Aeronautics and Space Administration began its countdown at 2 A.M. today for the scheduled attempt to put two astronauts into orbit aboard a Gemini spacecraft.

ELLENBURG DEPOT, N.Y., March 22 (AP) -- Three men wearing ski masks and gloves held up the National Commercial Bank and Trust Company here today, fatally wounded the head teller, who sought to thwart them, and fled with $5,000 to $7,000.

Paul I. Grinberg, a specialist in financial planning and control procedures, has been named vice president and treasurer of Reston, Va., the new town under construction about 18 miles west of Washington. Mr. Grinberg was formerly secretary-treasurer of the Atlantic Improvement Corporation, whose plans for an apartment-house community at Breezy Point, Queens were terminated when the city acquired the land for a public beach.

CASEY, Ala., March 22 -- The campfires of the Army sentries burned in the distance through the chill Alabama night. In two circus tents pitched next to a cotton field, 350 marchers lay in sleeping bags and blankets in long rows.

WHITE PLAINS, March 22 -- The Westchester County Board of Supervisors was told today that the Republican plan for reapportionment through an increase in the number of Supervisors from 45 to 52 would merely perpetuate illegal inequalities.
Long-term Government bond prices, which last week registered their largest gains since late 1964, continued to rise yesterday.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., March 22 -- The Suffolk Board of Supervisors endorsed today a proposal to the State Legislature that would permit the county to adopt a 2-house system of government.

PARIS -- One of the local candidates in the recent elections here endorsed better traffic conditions and more parking space in Paris, constant and discreet care for the elderly, and "classes in the snow." Moore McCormack Company, Inc., formerly known as Moore-McCormack Lines. Inc., had the most profitable year in 1964 in six years, according to the financial results reported yesterday. Voyage revenues of $88,496,000 were the largest in its history.

TRENTON, March 21 (AP) -- The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled today that savings banks may offer checking account services.
BOSTON, March 22 (AP) -- Red Auerbach became a part owner as well as general manager and coach of the Boston Celtics today.
The Commonwealth Edison Company reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and net income for twelve months ended Feb. 28. Similar gains were shown for the first two months this year.
JACKSON, Miss., March 22 (AP) -- Cleve McDowell lost another battle today in his fight to re-enter the University of Mississippi.
WASHINGTON, March 22 -- The nation's Governors asked today that President Johnson permit a new study of the so-called "Heller plan" to distribute some Federal income-tax revenue to the states.
LONDON, March 22 -- The Labor Government said tonight that if Britain's poorly housed were to get any relief it would have to come from public, rather than private, construction.
The tool gives the office for a left prat. As the stalls frame the mark, the tool forks the leather, which is standing on its feet, signals "It's off" and passes the score to the mitt man.
The weather in New York was just about perfect yesterday for retail buyers attending the semiannual market week of the Boys' Apparel and Accessories Manufacturers' Association.

A national fallout shelter program for every person in the United States costing about $5 billion might save something like 30 million lives in the event of an all-out nuclear attack. An additional expenditure of $20 billion -- $17 billion for an anti-ballistic missile system, $3 billion improved and more extensive anti-bomber defense -- might save an additional 40 million lives.
Gen. Thomas S. Power, retired commander in chief of the Strategic Air Command, called yesterday for testing nuclear weapons in the atmosphere and using SAC in Vietnam.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, March 22 (UPI) -- Lieut. Gen. Rene Barrientos Ortuno, president of Bolivia's ruling military junta, was shot and wounded in an assassination attempt at Cochabamba last night, press dispatches from the tin mining center reported.

The state's highest court plans to hold a special session next week to consider the intricate problem of legislative reapportionment. A source close to the top tribunal, the Court of Appeals, said yesterday a decision handed down in State Supreme Court last week involved constitutional questions that warrant a direct appeal to Albany.
DARIEN, Conn., March 22 -- A jangling alarm clock awoke 41-year-old Thomas Leach in his darkened New York City bedroom at 5:45 A.M. today.

ALBANY, March 22 -- The chairman of the Assembly's Committee on Penal Institutions proposed legislation today to give the State Commission of Correction broader powers and stricter controls over local prisons.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- Leonard H. Goldenson, president of American Broadcasting-Paramount Theaters, Inc., characterized network television today as a medium "stuck in a rut" and appealed for a surge of creativity in programing.

Fifty members of a group that represents Hungarian Jewish victims of Nazi persecution picketed yesterday in front of the West German consulate here. They demanded the broadening of agreements under which Bonn pays reparations to Nazi victims.
The C.I.T. Financial Corporation, after apparently hesitating as recently as last Friday, decided yesterday to buy control of the Meadow Brook National Bank.
WASHINGTON, March 22 -Three-month Treasury bill rates showed small and opposite movements at today's auction, the Treasury disclosed tonight.
The top-seeded players advanced to the quarter-final round yesterday in the 21st annual invitation scholastic squash racquets tournament at the Racquet and Tennis Club.
Industrial issues staged a strong rally on the London Stock Exchange yesterday, however British Government bonds eased.

OSLO, Norway, March 22 (UPI) -- A Norwegian reporter said today he was refused hotel accommodations in Selma, Ala., because he came from the "nation which gave the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King the Nobel Peace Prize.

Detective John C. Devlin was cleared by the Police Department yesterday of charges of "excessive use of force" in the near-fatal shooting of a 22-year-old Puerto Rican he mistook for a homicide suspect.
BUFFALO, N.Y., March 22 (UPI) -- Twelve major milling companies indicted 11 months ago on price-fixing conspiracy charges were fined a total of $190,000 today in Federal Court.
ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, March 23 -- Field Marshal Mohammad Ayub Khan was sworn in today for his second term as President.

SEABROOK Tex., March 23 (UPI) -- Excited and happy, the wives and children of America's space twins followed their progress today, from take-off to landing, by television and spaceship-to-ground earphones.
WASHINGTON, March 23 -- E. William Henry, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, today excoriated some phases of television programing and praised others.

The New Yorker Magazine, Inc., whih observed its 40th birthday last month, announced yesterday that Raoul H. Fleischmann had assumed the new title of publisher. The founder, chairman and president of the company is now in his 80th year.

THE slim, bearded young man in a brown leather suit, red socks, loafers and a black and white striped Egyptian vest looked like a bronzed Greek statue as he lifted a massive goblet and said: "It was all those bubbles in beer."

George R. Vila, chairman and president of the United States Rubber Company, said yesterday that reports of the possible loss to the company following the takeover of its plantations in Sumatra had been greatly exaggerated.
WASHINGTON, March 23 (UPI) -- Five House Republicans sent a letter to the President today to protest the use of gas

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 23 -- "Watch out, you're not just playing the Yankees," somebody shouted to Hank Bauer today, as his Baltimore Orioles took the field against the New York Mets, the new bullies of the Grapefruit League.

YOU won't find Cape Fear County on the map of North Carolina. Nevertheless, it lies somewhere between Wilmington and Fayetteville in good tobacco-growing country. Few counties south of Appomattox have seen such lively doings or such comical cutting up as nearly tore the county apart when Mordecai Jones, the FlimFlam Man, took on young Curley Treadaway as his apprentice.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., March 23 -- Maj. Virgil I. Grissom and Lieut. Comdr. John W. Young landed safely in the Atlantic today after taking the world's first maneuverable manned spacecraft through a near-perfect flight of four hours and 54 minutes.
Five former union officials pleaded guilty yesterday in Supreme Court to conspiring to commit assault in connection with organizing activities among telephone employes in 1963.

THE young man who went tumbling around the earth yesterday with Maj. Virgil Grissom is an ardent climber-beyond-the-skies whose achievements as jet pilot and astronaut may propel him yet deeper into the measureless heavens.

TROUT will no longer be killed or retained by anglers on a portion of the Beaverkill River in the Catskill Mountains under new regulations, according to Eli Dietsch, the regional fisheries manager for the New York State Conservation Department.
The old women shifted uneasily on their orange-crate perches yesterday afternoon outside a Lower East Side super market. It was chilly, with a threat of rain in the sky.
PASADENA, Calif., March 23 -- Scientists nudged the Ranger 9 spacecraft with a radio signal today, adjusting its course to land within a few miles of the lunar crater Alphonsus.

Jacob K. Javits has long demonstrated a talent for political survival. Foresight is one ingredient in his success. When he dropped out of a safe House seat to become State Attorney General in 1954, some thought it a backward step in his career. But two years later he was a United States Senator.
CHICAGO, March 23 -- The Air Line Pilots Association announced today that pilots of Pan American World Airways had "voted overwhelmingly" to strike.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, March 23 -- The United National party, conservative and pro-Western, has won 66 seats, the largest bloc for a single party, in the new Ceylonese Parliament, the official returns from yesterday's erection show.
What to do about "The Rising Tide of Consumer Inattention."
OTTAWA, March 23 -- Prime Minister Lester B. Pearson fended off today criticism of the refusal of Canadian immigration officials to admit a University of Minnesota pacifist professor last week.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 23 -- United States officials in Saigon attempted today to deflate a worldwide controversy over the use of gases in the South Vietnamese war.
Loew's Theaters, Inc., which operates 10 hotels and 60 theaters, has just filed plans for its first apartment house.
LONDON, March 23 (AP) -Western Europe's newspapers headlined the two-man Gemini space flight today, but the feat stirred less excitement than last week's stroll in space by a Soviet spaceman.

What is said to be the highest scale for a Broadway musical will apply to the Alan Jay Lerner-Burton Lane collaboration, "On a Clear Day You Can See Forever," due the week of Oct. 11 at the Mark Hellinger Theater.
The Kips Bay Boys' Club will benefit from the fifth annual Spring Boutique, to be held on Monday and Tuesday in the auditorium of the clubhouse at 301 East 52d Street.

The New York Civil Liberties Union called yesterday for repeal of New York State's "stop and frisk" law, contending that violent street corner encounters between policemen and civilians were inevitable under it.

The recent Pentagon plan eliminating the organized Army Reserve came as no surprise to any one familiar with the military inefficiency of this organization. While we can approve this decision and the political courage needed to make it, we must ask why this decision is not being put immediately into effect.

BLOOMINGDALE'S has given seven of its youngest staff designers, some only a few years out of college, the freedom to show off their own decorating talents in 10 model rooms for storybook young New Yorkers.

Paul Horgan, novelist and historian, has written a book of poems, "Songs After Lincoln," which Farrar, Straus and Giroux will publish on April 15, the 100th anniversary of President Lincoln's death. Mr. Horgan's poems include lyrics, meditations, narratives and recollections drawn from history.
A convention travel problem of the Disciples of Christ received the attention of a Congressional subcommittee yesterday.

TOKYO, Wednesday, March 24 (AP) -- apanese and South Korean negotiators cleared away today the last major obstacle to normal ties between the two countries by agreeing demarcation line for Korean fishermen.
Taxicab workers in all parts of the city except Staten Island went on strike last night to enforce their demands for recognition of a new union.
Old-crop soybean futures prices were cut sharply yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. Wheat closed up, but other grains were narrowly mixed.
The Federal Maritime Commission yesterday disclaimed jurisdiction in an ocean-rate case brought before it by waterfront truckers and foreign traders in the Pout of New York.
Your March 22 editorial on the emasculation of the King-Anderson bill by the American Medical Association lobby is timely, important, and deserves commendation.
WHITE PLAINS, March 23 -- Music for Westchester announced today that 10 concerts will be presented next season by its symphony orchestra and guest musicians.
SUN VALLEY, Idaho, March 23, (AP) -- Jean-Claude Killy of France finished one,two in the men's slalom at the Harriman Cup ski races today but Karl Schranz of Austria took the combined crown.
MOSCOW, March 23 -- The Soviet Union's two newest astronaut$ were given a triumphal home-coming reception in Moscow today.
The Navy may retain some of the Brooklyn Navy Yard's piers and land, Rear Adm. J.H. McQuilkin, the yard's commander, said yesterday.
CAIRO, March 23 -- An authoritative Egyptian official denied today reports that Egyptian troops in Yemen were experimenting with chemical warfare agents against royalist forces there.

MOSCOW, March 23 -- Leonid F. Ilyichev, Nikita S. Khrushchev's right-hand man in matters of ideology, was appointed a Deputy Foreign Minister today in an evident demotion from the Soviet leadership group.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, March 23 Archbishop Makarios, President of Cyprus, was reported today to have reaffirmed his independence of Athens in dealing with the crisis on the island.
CHICAGO, March 23 (AP) -- Heavy snow slowed traffic in a broad area in the central section of the nation today.
CAPE KENNEDY, March 23 -- Using 32 rockets, the pilots of today's Gemini flight repeatedly changed the spacecraft's orbital path, hauling it back and forth like someone impatiently parking his car.
MORRISTOWN, N.J., March 23 -- The Migratory Bird Conservation Commission allocated $2.8 million today for the acquisition of 3,267 acres in Morris County's Great Swamp Wildlife Preserve.

WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP) -- The House Armed Services Committee voted today to authorize $14,793,000,000 for new aircraft, missiles and ships after slashing $654 million from Defense Department requests.
The Playboy Club's second application for a cabaret license was turned down yesterday by License Commissioner Joseph C. DiCarlo.
The Gemini capsule that carried two American astronauts yesterday is far more than a larger version of its predecessor, Mercury.

WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP) -- Assurances of compliance with the Civil Rights Act of 1964 from nine state educational agencies and five state library boards have been accepted by the Office of Education as meeting requirements of the act.
WASHINGTON, March 23 -- "Gus? This is Lyndon Johnson. How are you?"
ALBANY, March 23 -- Small but immediate rate increases were urged today for the Blue Cross medical plan by one of the strongest unions in the state.
CAMARILLO, Calif., March 23 (UPI) -- A company owned by three brothers of Mrs. Robert F. Kennedy has purchased the 4,615-acre Camarillo Ranch for $20 million for community development.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. March 23 -- R.T. Adnan, Indonesia's representative on the International Tin Council, said today his country's output of tin "hit bottom" in 1963, and has been climbing back steadily since then.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- President Johnson will probably be receptive to a plea by the nation's governors for a new study of a plan to distribute about $2.5 billion a year in income tax revenues to the states informed sources said today.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. March 23 -- Two players, whose New York Yankee futures seemed more secure two weeks ago than they do now, played key roles in today's 13-inning 6-5 loss to the Kansas City Athletics.

Three members of the House Education and Labor Committee will start field investigations next week of government-supported antipoverty programs in New York, the Middle Atlantic states and Puerto Rico.
COCOA BEACH, Fla., March 23 -- It was a warm, sunny morning on the beach, and there were seagulls and pelicans floating lazily above.

Police Commissioner Michael J. Murphy announced yesterday that the department was distributing printed reminders of the emergency number, 440-1234, to be affixed to telephones in commercial establishments.

CLEVELAND, March 23 (AP) -- The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. said tonight that the voting rights march from Selma to Montgomery, Ala., "may turn out to be as important an event in American history as Gandhi's march to the sea was in Indian history."

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- A program under which the United States would seek to force South Africa to abandon her policy of apartheid -- racial separation -- was submitted to the Administration today by a conference organized by church, labor, student and political groups.
Maj. Virgil I. Grissom and Lieut. Comdr. John W. Young will proceed up lower Broadway in a traditional ticket-tape parade next Monday beginning at noon.

Dr. Bela Fabian, Hungarian exile leader, will marry Mrs. Edna Rabinavicious, widow of a former Lithuanian diplomat. The ceremony will be performed at noon tomorrow by Civil Court Judge Louis I. Kaplan in the judge's chambers at 111 Centre Street.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 23 -- A leading United Nations expert on economic and social questions told the Population Commission today that it was no longer possible to hope that the problem of overpopulation would solve itself without planning.
The Associated Dry Goods Corporation, which operates the Lord Taylor specialty stores, proposed a three-for-two stock split yesterday to be voted on at its annual meeting June 1.

LONDON, March 23 -- Geoffrey Agnew, a leading London art dealer and an unsuccessful bidder in last week's auction room dispute over Rembrant's "Titus," today publicly denounced the auctioneer's action in reopening the bidding.

LOS ANGELES, March 23 (AP) -- Senator Thomas J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, attacked tonight what he called the "wishful thinkers and conciliationists and appeasers" who advocate a change in approach toward the Soviet Union.
LOWNDESBORO, Ala., March 23 -- The Alabama Freedom Marchers passed the halfway point of their 54-mile protest walk today with sore feet and high spirits.
Volume on the American Stock Exchange fell sharply yesterday as declines outpaced advances by a good margin.
The New York Knickerbockers, who don't win often, finally have won their first individual award in the 19-year history of the National Basketball Association.
JERSEY CITY, March 23 (AP) -- Two tax liens totaling nearly $11 million were filed by the Federal Government today against Joseph (Newsboy) Moriarty, once termed the numbers kingpin of Hudson County.
More than $90 million of stock already outstanding was placed on the market yesterday in a continued heavy flow of secondary offerings.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 23 -- A huge civil rights show featuring some of the top names of the entertainment world will be held here tomorrow night -- the eve of the entry of the freedom marchers into this former capital of the Confederacy.
MOSCOW, March 23 (Reuters) -- Shirley Temple went to Red Square to watch the welcome for Russia's two new astronauts but her scheduled television appearance was cancelled.
While one New England riding alumnus dominated the winner's circle at unfrozen Aqueduct yesterday, another of more recent vintage took a small step in that direction.

As most international airlines continued yesterday to seek a ban on all forms of entertainment aboard planes, one of them went ahead with plans to introduce not only movies but also double features and various forms of listening entertainment for passengers.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., March 25 (UPI) -- The six time bombs planted near Negro areas Sunday and Monday morning were intended to explode but failed to go off because of a defect in the assembly, a police official reported today.
ALBANY, March 23 (AP) -- Governor Rockefeller engaged today in a brisk, impromptu debate with members of a Negro group concerned about licensing of liquor stores in low-income neighborhoods.
Television viewers this morning will be able to see for the first time live pictures of the moon's surface as they are relayed to earth from Ranger 9 only moments before impact.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 23 -- The knottiest problem the New York Yankees have now is where to play Mickey Mantle. And neither Mantle, Manager Johnny Keane, assorted club officials nor resident experts are sure what should be done.

Luther Lassiter of Elizabeth City, N.C., Joe Balsis of Minersville, Pa., and Frank McGown of Brooklyn were tied for first place after yesterday's play in the world pocket billiards championships at the Hotel Commodore. Each had a 5-0 won-lost record.

The election of Arthur D. Leidesdorf as president of the 92d Street Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association was announced last night. Mr. Leidesdorf, a partner in the accounting firm of S.D. Leidesdorf Co., succeeded as head of the association former Surrogate George Frankenthaler.
Jeremiah Kelley, the "millionaires' bookmaker" and close friend of Frank Costello, was indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on charges of soliciting bets across the country.
WASHINGTON, March 23 -- The House Ways and Means Committee approved today an expanded version of the Administration's program of health care for the aged.

Deterioration in Arab-West German relations did not start with the recent visit of Walter Ulbricht of East Germany to Cairo, as your March 15 editorial implied. It is the result of the secret agreement entered into as far back as 1960 with the explicit approval of the United States Government whereby West Germany would present the Israelis with arms, including American-made tanks, as a gift to the tune of $80 million.

The resolution establishing a joint committee to consider various Congressional reorganization proposals contained a curious little provision which is crippling or trivial -- depending upon how cynically one views Congressional behavior.
THE New York State Theater was filled for the beginning of the second week of the American Ballet Theater's New York season, and it was quite a beginning.

" Art: USA," the peripatetic and highly publicized collection of American paintings that in the last two years has covered 14 countries on three continents, has finally touched down in New York. After record-breaking runs in Washington and Philadelphia, it opens today at the Whitney Museum, 22 West 54th Street, where its 102 canvases have taken over all three exhibition floors.
The State Office of Transportation called yesterday for the preservation and improvement of commuter rail service in Westchester, Putnam and Rockland Counties.
The City Councilmen, who up to now have relied principally on lung power to make themselves heard, stepped into the electronic age yesterday.
HAWICK, Scotland, March 23 -- David Steel, the 26-year-old Liberal candidate for Parliament stood fingering a pile of half-finished cashmere sweaters.

SAIGON -- Whether it succeeds or fails, the world implications of our Vietnam policy are immense and far transcend this tattered land. The prospects in other backward areas of Asia, Africa and Latin America, now threatened by "revolutionary warfare," are inevitably linked to the outcome on this battlefield of that brilliant but diabolical technique.
LONDON, March 23 -- Benjamin Britten, the composer, and Dr. Dorothy Hodgkin, a biochemist, have been named members of the Order of Merit, Buckingham Palace announced today.
The British pound declined slightly in quiet trading on foreign exchange markets here yesterday.
Wagner's "Die Walkuere" will be given tonight by the Metropolitan Opera at 8.

Merger negotiations were terminated yesterday between the Arnold Constable Corporation, a Fifth Avenue-based specialty store chain, and Vornado, Inc., operator of the Two Guys chain of discount stores.

American Commercial Lines, Inc., has signed a contract to purchase the business and assets of Bauer Dredging Company, Inc., of Port Lavaca, Tex., and its subsidiaries. The consideration will be $18.2 million in cash.

Three auxiliaries of the Menorah Home and Hospital for the Aged and Infirm in Brooklyn will hold fund-raising events next month to help support the home's programs for 420 residents and 400 day-center members.

The Wagner administration filled the vacant post of counsel to the City Commission on Human Rights yesterday after being chided for giving priority consideration to "symbolic" representation at Selma.
ALBANY, March 23 -- Budget Director William F. Shea of New York City said today that he would urge Mayor Wagner to seek a major increase in the city real estate tax.

DARIEN, Conn., March 23 -- Arthur Fiedler will conduct the New Haven Symphony Orchestra in a Pops concert on Saturday evening at Darien High School in a benefit for the Stamford Junior League's Community Trust Fund. Miss Karen Shaw of Silvermine, a pianist, will be the guest soloist.

Maria Elena de Cardenas, mezzo-soprano from Cuba, made her first New York solo appearance last night at Carnegie Recital Hall. She is a singer with a theatrical flair who is at her best in music of intensity.

MONTREAL, March 23 (Canadian Press) -- Net profits of Canadian Petrofina, Ltd., in 1964 were $7,076,164, or 72 cents a share, compared with $6,972,654, or 71 cents a share, in the preceding year, President A.F. Campo said Tuesday.
TORONTO, March 22 -- A little cheer went up from economic nationalists this month when two moves were announced that reduced, ever so slightly, the heavy stake of United States investment in Canada.

ATLANTIC CITY, March 23 -- Ara Parseghian of Notre Dame, who was the coach of the year in college football for 1964, conceded today that he probably would not win any honors as husband of the year. The Notre Dame coach said that his wife had figured out last week that since Sept. 1 he had been home with his family only 17 nights.

VIRGIL IVAN GRISSOM, the only man to ride in a spaceship twice, is a quiet, solitary sort, a brooder, an intense worker and a devoted family man. He is laconic, and among strangers he grows impatient and uncommunicative.
LONDON, March 23 -- Two unobtrusive non-Jewish English spinsters traveled from their quiet suburban home today to receive Israel's thanks for smuggling 29 Jews out of prewar Germany.

The optimistic mood that has permeated the bond market for more than a week continued to reign yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 23 -- The Democratic National Committee moved today to eliminate racial discrimination in all state delegations seated at future national conventions.
