WASHINGTON, March 23 -- The White House said today that President Johnson had not been consulted about the use of nausea-inducing gases in the South Vietnamese war.
The Lever Brothers Company and the Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc., both announced yesterday a number of top management changes.
MOSCOW, March 23 -- The Soviet Union hinted today at the possibility of direct Soviet participation in the Vietnam war.

John Cheever will receive the Howells Medal, given by the American Academy of Arts and Letters every five years for the most distinguished work of American fiction published in that period. The academy announced yesterday that the award to Mr. Cheever was for "The Wapshot Scandal," published last year by Harper Row.

LONDON, March 23 (AP) -- A field of 56 horses was nominated today for the Grand National Steeplechase on Saturday. It was the biggest such list in 18 years. The Irish Sweepstakes are based on the race.
Wilt Chamberlain scored 2,534 points in the National Basketball Association's 19th season, which ended Sunday.

CARACAS, Venezuela, March 23 (AP) -- Ron Holmberg of Dallas defeated Michael Valdez of Trindad today and gained the third round of the Caracas international tennis tournament. The scores were 6 -- 3, 6 -- 4.

Central and South West Corporation and its subsidiaries reported gains yesterday in operating revenues and net income for the 12 months ended Feb. 28. Operating revenues rose to $226,661,056 from $218,127,007 one year earlier.
A 76 per cent increase in earnings and record sales for the first four months of the current fiscal year were reported yesterday by the West Virginia Pulp and Paper Company at the annual meeting.
An unusual picket line of 30 maritime union men took up a three-day vigil at United States Mission to the United Nations here yesterday afternoon to protest a potential grievance.
American companies were urged yesterday to sell as vigorously in export markets as they do on their own main streets.
There was a growing feeling yesterday among municipal-bond dealers that tile tax-exempt market was beginning to show the tell-tale effects of a tightening monetary situation.
MADRID, March 23 -- A petition making "elementary and urgent" demands upon the government was being circulated clandestinely today.
STRASBURG, France, March 23 -- The European Common Market's top economist today put the blame for the world's monetary troubles squarely on the United States.
Although buyers remained cautious on the London Stock Exchange yesterday, there was a generous sprinkling of gains among industrial issues and most leaders moved ahead.

The head of the printers union here announced yesterday that it had been authorized to strike at 2 A.M. next Wednesday if it did not have a contract proposal from the city's newspaper publishers that it considered satisfactory.
The market for a type of synthetic rubber used in a variety of end-products is expanding so rapidly that the price was cut yesterday as much as 5 cents a pound.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., March 23 -- Up-zoning and the adoption of building codes are priorities in a master plan submitted here today for this Suffolk County seat.

YONKERS, March 23 -- John Chapman, one of the more accomplished, as well as one of the unluckiest, reinsmen in harness racing, made his first local drive of the season a winning one tonight in the slop at Yonkers Raceway.
The three-orbit flight by Virgil I. Grissom and John W. Young was in some ways the most remarkable space trip yet accomplished by this country's astronauts.
The United Steelworkers of America accepted last night contract terms offered by the Continental Can Company, ending a 23-day strike.

FOR TV viewers who got up at 7 A.M. yesterday, the three major television networks offered a live step-by-step account of the events preceding the 9:24 A.M. take-off of the first two-man Gemini flight. The running news story did not reach its suspenseful climax until late afternoon, when Virgil Grissom and John Young completed their three orbits and returned safely to earth.

John Gassner, professor of playwriting and dramatic literature at Yale University, will be this year's recipient of the Kelcey Allen Award for "long and devoted service to the theater." The presentation will be made by John Mason Brown, lecturer and former drama critic, at a luncheon on April 26 in Sardi's.
CLEVELAND, March 23 -- Teams captained by Oswald Jacoby of Dallas and Robert Jordan of Philadelphia met here this afternoon in what could have been the final match for the Vanderbilt Cup.

The head of a family in the United States of 1965 should not have to get along on a wage of less than $1.50 an hour. But the method the Democratic majority at Albany has devised to establish such a wage floor for workers in New York State is likely to generate at least as much misery as it relieves.

Consolidated net earnings of the Avco Corporation in the first fiscal quarter ended Feb. 28 were reported yesterday at $5,841,273, equal to 43 cents a share on the 13,685,893 shares outstanding during the quarter.
The Dow Chemical Company increased its earnings 16.3 percent last year on a sales gain of 11.3 per cent, the annual report disclosed yesterday.
George Magher, a former building contractor, has been convicted on a charge of larceny in misappropriating trust funds and sentenced to one and a half to three years in prison.

FORT MYERS, Fla., March 23 -- One day last week the Pittsburgh Pirates exploded in a 14-run inning against the Chicago White Sox at Sarasota. It was to be presumed that this was typical of the unbridled power of the fierce Buccaneers.

WANAMASSA, N.J., March 23 (AP) -- Inspired by the Biblical Maccabees and their most recent counterparts in Brooklyn, a group of Jewish men here patrols the streets nightly in search of a band of rock-throwing vandals.

New products are commonplace at the international convention of the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers, which runs through Friday in the New York Coliseum and the New York Hilton Hotel.

Former Presidents Fulgencio Batista of Cuba and Miguel Aleman of Mexico are among stockholders of El Tiempo, the Spanish-language weekly here that bought a seven-paper Long Island newspaper chain last week.
Gareth Martinis was ordered yesterday to stand trial June 9 in Bronx Supreme Court on five counts of vehicular homicide and a count of assault.

SELMA, Ala., March 23 -- More than 300 Roman Catholic clergy -- men and nuns, here from all over the nation for the civil rights march to Montgomery, publicly rejected today the Alabama Archbishop's efforts to curb participation by Catholic priests and nuns in the demonstration.
While two American astronauts orbited the earth at extraordinary speed in the skies far overhead, 300 other Americans were trudging slowly along U.S. Highway 80 in central Alabama.
WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP) -- The Army and Air Force announced a new Reserve Officer Training Corps program today that will provide financial help to 2,000 qualified college students.

EVANSTON, Ill., March 23 (UPI) -- The president of the Woman's Christian Temperance Union, Mrs. Fred J. Tooze, accused a Chicago brewery today of "hatching a product and plot to promote the use of needle beer by teen-agers."

GEORGES PRETRE conducted the Philadelphia Orchestra last night in Philharmonic Hall. The young French conductor had appeared this season at the Metropolitan Opera, and in previous years he had conducted opera in concert form in this city.

KINGS POINT, L.I., March 23 -- A one-day modified hunger strike by midshipmen at the United States Merchant Marine Academy here ended this morning when all 700 students arrived at the mess hall and ate their breakfasts.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- Britain's Foreign Secretary, Michael Stewart, reported today after talks with President Johnson and other officials that none of the Communist nations had given any sign of readiness to discuss a satisfactory settlement in Vietnam.

An 81-year-old widow was raped and robbed of $3 late Monday night in the elevator and corridors of the Edenwald Houses, a city project in the Bronx. The police seized a 24-year-old shipping clerk and charged him with the crimes.

The Byline Award of the Newspaper Reporters Association of New York City has been won by Alfred Robbins, a reporter for The New York Journal-American, for two stories in 1964 on the Bedford-Stuyvesant riots in Brooklyn.

A 27-year-old philosophy teacher at Brooklyn College has set out to challenge the constitutionality of the loyalty oaths required by state law as a condition of employment at public schools and colleges in New York.
A patrolman transferred to a beat in Harlem last month after he was accused of insulting a Syrian diplomat has been returned to his East Side post, effective tomorrow.

Justice Owen McGivern of the New York State Supreme Court has been asked by several law firms to award them fees for their services by which Alleghany Corporation in 1961 regained voting control of Investors Diversified Services, Inc.
AUGUSTA, Mich., March 23 -- A noted medical researcher assailed today what he said "seem to be breaches of ethical conduct in experimentation" on humans.
NASSAU, Bahamas, March 23 (AP) -- E.W. (Skip) Etchells of Old Greenwich, Conn., the winner of the Star Class Meyers Cup on Monday, took an early lead today in the spring championship series.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -Spokesmen for two leading lay organizations concerned with the nation's health added their endorsements today to proposed legislation requiring the labeling of cigarettes as a menace to health.
TRENTON, March 23 -- The New Jersey Supreme Court accepted in effect today the role of architect for legislative reapportionment in time for this fall's elections.
LONDON, March 23 -- British anxiety over United States policies in South Vietnam was demonstrated today in 10 dramatic minutes in the House of Commons.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 23 -- South Vietnamese and United States pilots bombed a North Vietnamese radar station today. This followed by a day a strike by United States planes at another radar installation.
ROME, March 23 -- The newly established Harkness Ballet Company of New York won enthusiastic reviews from dance critics here today for its Roman debut last night at the Teatro Olimpico.
WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP) -- The Federal Highway Administrator, Rex M. Whitton, urged today the authorization of a comprehensive study of the needs of the Federal-aid highway system after 1972.

CAIRO, March 23 -- The fifth Arab oil congress closed today with the adoption of a resolution calling on the Arab states to halt shipments of oil to any country that "economically boycotts an Arab state or proves deterimental to its economic interests."

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- For more than three hours today Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr. of North Carolina maintained that the new voting-rights bill was unconstitutional. He insistently asked Attorney General Nicholas deB.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -Assistant Secretary of State Harlan Cleveland said today that Government policymakers had not been thinking ahead hard enough about the next steps in every field of international cooperation.
BUCHAREST, March 23 -- Reliable sources said today that Gheorghe Gheorghiu-Dej chose Nicolae Ceausescu to succeed him as First Secretary of the Rumanian Workers' (Communist) party.
The Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York reported a gross yield of 5.42 per cent on $412.1 million of new investments last year, it was disclosed in the company's 122d annual report.
DETROIT -- As the auto industry goes, so goes the National Steel Corporation, or so it is commonly said in steel circles.
SEBRING, Fla., March 23 -- This town of about 6,000 persons in south central Florida was founded 53 years ago by a man named George Sebring, who sought peace and quiet far from the big city's bustle.

A NEW YORK woman who has the new publication "Consumer Information Sources" may build up a private library of 288 free booklets or leaflets on every phase of homemaking and family living. The catalogue, also free, may be obtained from the New York State Department of Commerce Woman's Program, 112 State Street, Albany, or 230 Park Avenue, New York.
A 35-foot square-rigged, homemade raft that took her 71-year-old skipper 12,000 miles across the Pacific arrived here yesterday from Sydney, Australia. Her name, appropriately, is Age Unlimited.
In the elegant -- and outmoded -- dining room of tile old liner Saturnia, 100 guests of the Italian Line toasted the end of an era yesterday in sparkling white wine, Chianti and liqueurs.

MONTREAL, March 23 (UPI) -- Norm Ullman of the Detroit Red Wings scored five goals and had six assists in three games last week to move from third into second place in the National Hockey League scoring race.

ALBANY, March 23 -- A constitutional amendment designed to take the election of judges out of politics in New York City was introduced today in the Legislature at the request of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York and the New York Committee on Modern Courts.
PARIS, March 23 -- President de Gaulle today welcomed the growing area of "understanding and cooperation" between the policies of the French and Soviet Governments.

A dilapidated Dutch dwelling dating from 1641 -- believed to be the oldest house in the city and the oldest frame house in the United States -- is the rent-free home of a young theological student and his family.
What makes an effective productive relationship between design and business? "Good chemistry," replies Phillip Sills, a manufacturer of women's sportswear.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, March 23 -- A Communist union of postal workers has imposed a mail and telegraph boycott on the United States Embassy and has refused to handle traffic for American news agencies in Jakarta.
LONDON, March 23 -- A New York City law designed to protect tenants from harassment by landlords was cited today as the basis for a similar statute proposed here.
WASHINGTON, March 23 (UPI) -- Unmanned space flights are planned to Mars in 1971 and 1973 to see if life exists there, a space agency official said today.

MOUNT KENNEDY, Yukon territory, March 23 -- Senator Robert F. Kennedy and two climbers of Mount Everest were last observed from the air today about two-thirds the distance between their base camp on Mount Kennedy and No. 2 camp at 11,500 feet.
BURKVILLE, Ala., March 23 -- The road to Montgomery today was through desolate country, and the familiar knots of people who come to wave or shout "nigger" were not there.
HAVANA, March 23 -- Premier Fidel Castro's Government wants its soldiers to be ready to help "all countries in the world that fight for Communism and fight for their independence."
MINEOLA, L.I., March 23 -- The State Department of Social Welfare has found a serious lack of professional supervision of both the children and the staff at the Nassau County Children's Shelter.
ALBANY, March 23 -- An Assemblyman from Manhattan introduced today a bill that would seek to block the plan to operate helicopter flights from the Pan Am Building in mid-town New York.

" YOU think this is bad? This is nothing," panted Norman Saul, as he dashed up and down behind the counter of Harold's Fish Company, 2451 Broadway (near 90th Street), dodging his assistants, filleting fish, serving customers and talking.
CHICAGO, March 23 (UPI) -- Two goals by Rod Gilbert led the New York Rangers to a 3-2 victory tonight over the Black Hawks in Chicago's last home game of the season.
LONDON, March 23 -- Earl Mountbatten, retiring chief of the British defense staff, was named today to head a fact-finding mission to Commonwealth countries to study immigration problems.

Webster's New International Dictionary, Second Edition, Unabridged, gives only one pronunciation for "Gemini." It is GEM-in-eye. However, announcers for the Columbia Broadcasting System and the National Broadcasting Company pronounced it gem-in-ee yesterday.
LONDON, March 23 -- Cheer after cheer reverberated around the Saville Theater here tonight as the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater returned to London after an Australian tour.
A final version of landmarks preservation legislation was submitted to the City Council yesterday by its Codification Committee.
RUTHERFORD, N.J., March 23 -- Fifteen hundred students at Fairleigh Dickinson University today began the first of four days of picketing as an "expression of general student discontent."

Only two weeks ago, it seemed that every investor and his fifth cousin was clamoring for stock in the General Aniline and Film Corporation at the offering price, which turned out to be $30.60 a share.
COLUMBIA, S.C., March 23 -- Democratic voters chose a conservative over a Great Society advocate today in a special primary contest for the House of Representatives.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- Secretary of the Treasury Douglas Dillon, making his final appearance before a Congressional committee, said today that the "danger" for the world in the future would be a "shortage of international reserves rather than an excess."
The stock market edged forward yesterday in moderately active trading.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, Thursday, March 25 -- The post-election crisis in Ceylon appeared to be moving toward a solution early today after long maneuvering by leftists yesterday to keep Mrs. Sirimavo Bandaranaike in office as Prime Minister.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., March 24 -- The question of two astronauts' silence during yesterday's flight of the Gemini 3 spacecraft appeared to have been answered today, but clues to another question about the journey were still being pondered.
CHICAGO, March 24 -- A new approach to the dietary prevention of heart attacks is being tested on 10,000 to 15,000 Norwegian men between the ages of 50 and 59.
The stock market inched ahead yesterday in fairly active trading.

The McCrory Corporation reported yesterday a sharp improvement in earnings despite a drop in sales for fiscal 1964. The company also announced an extra dividend and the election of Meshulam Riklis, chairman, to the additional posts of president and chief executive officer.

ABOARD U.S.S. INTREPID, at sea, March 24 -- A spokesman for the space agency disclosed today that Maj. Virgil I. Grissom became ill and vomited in the Gemini space capsule yesterday after it had been floating in the water for 28 minutes.

ST. LOUIS March 24 -- A prediction that the labor force would soon become burdensomely large was virtually the only pessimistic forecast made at a National Industrial Conference Board meeting here today.

HUNTING for a quarterback can be a difficult job, especially in unpredictable weather. That's why Wagner's football coach, Bob Hicks, is hoping spring-like temperatures hit Grymes Hill, Staten Island, within the next week and a half.
Ralph E. Casey, president of the American Merchant Marine Institute called yesterday for a Congressional investigation into maritime labor's approach to automation of the nation's merchant fleet.
ROME, March 24 (AP) -- A Vatican weekly magazine criticized both the United States and the Soviet Union today on space research, saying they were using it as "a political instrument."

ANN ARBOR, Mich., March 24 (AP) -- Bomb scares marked the start tonight of a 12-hour series of rallies, speeches and seminars sponsored by some 200 University of Michigan faculty members to protest United States policy in Vietnam.
Two faculty organizations at St. John's University charged yesterday that the appointment of a mediator in their dispute with the administration was merely the latest "caper" in a strategy of delay.
CHICAGO, March 24 (AP) -- Roman Catholic and Protestant clergymen heard a suggestion at a meeting here today that Christian leaders take a more active role against anti-Semitism.
JEDBURGH, Scotland, Thursday, March 25 -- The Liberal Party won a smashing upset victory in a Scottish by-election yesterday.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., March 24 -- The Eastern bluebird, traditional "bird of happiness," appears to be making a firm comeback locally. Migrating flocks were decimated several years ago by a severe spring ice storm in the South.
Four public-spirited citizens who risked their lives to help the police capture suspects received civilian commendation bars in a ceremony at Police Headquarters yesterday.
ALBANY, March 24 -- Senate Majority Leader Joseph Zaretzki said tonight that the Democrats were hopelessly split over Governor Rockefeller's proposed state sales tax.
The British pound and the Canadian dollar continued to decline in active trading on foreign exchange markets here yesterday.
BUCHAREST, Rumania, March 24 -- Nicolae Ceausescu strongly reaffirmed Rumania's policy of national independence in his maiden speech today as head of the Workers' (Communist) party.
SAIGON, South Vietnam March 24 -- United States officials here foresee air strikes against North Vietnam continuing for several months before their effect on the Hanei Government can be measured.
The Publishers Association of New York City reached tentative agreements yesterday with four of the city's 10 newspaper unions.

CAPE KENNEDY, March 24 -- While American space officials rejoiced today over what they described as yesterday's "historic" debut of space maneuvers with the Gemini capsule, some skeptics grumbled that their enthusiasm was born of politics rather than a feeling for history.
WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP) -- Crawford H. Greenwalt, chairman of the Radio Free Europe Fund, called today for privately operated radio broadcasts to the Far East to counter anti-American propaganda.

The New York Stock Exchange and four major member firms and their partners have been named defendants in a suit filed last week in Federal District Court in Chicago charging them with violating the antitrust laws by setting minimum commission rates on stock purchases.

ALBANY, March 24 -- A state commission recommended today that New York City be given $99.36 million in fiscal 1965-66 -- almost twice what it is now receiving -- as part of Governor Rockefeller's huge new program of per-capita assistance.
A 100-story building, planned to be the world's largest combination apartment-and-office center when it opens in 1968, will be erected in Chicago by the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company.

WASHINGTON, March 24 (UPI) -- The Mississippi River Fuel Corporation has asked the Federal Trade Commission to postpone an antimerger complaint involving cement companies until the commission completes an industry-wide survey.

CLEVELAND, March 24 -- The classic contest for the Vanderbilt Cup ended here at 3 A.M. today with one of the most dramatic finishes in the history of the event. The team captained by Oswald Jacoby of Dallas won by the slender margin of 4 international match points in a match that remained in the balance until the final deal.

AS a steady extra, Charley Bono drives the night-line for a taxicab fleet that works out of a garage in Long Island City, Queens. That means he does not have a cab assigned to him on a regular schedule.

THE American Ballet Theater continues the celebration of the 25th anniversary of its founding by giving presents to the public. Last night, at the New York State Theater, the company offered another new dance work, Glen Tetley's "Sargasso."
Blue Cross asked the state yesterday to approve one of three proposed rate increases for New York City and 12 nearby counties.

Conferences are being held on conversion of the Palace -- that once-famous citadel of two-a- day vaudeville -- into a legitimate theater. The 1,683-seat theater at Broadway and 47th Street is said to be too expensive to continue operations as a movie house.
ALEXANDRIA, La., -- It is almost indisputably true that the cooking of Louisiana has the greatest range, scope and variety of any state in the union.
More than 400 clergymen, public officials and members of labor unions and civic groups left New York last night and early today to participate in the final hours of the Alabama Freedom March.
The House Public Works Committee has approved water pollution control bill that is significantly weaker than the measure which the Senate passed two months ago.

Braniff Airways, Inc., proposed yesterday an overhaul of its board of directors reflecting the acquisition of a majority control of the airline last year by the Greatamerica Corporation, a Dallas management company.

Two parts of a 2,500-year-old Egyptian figure in alabaster, separated perhaps in antiquity, are together again through persistent and patient sleuthing by an Egyptologist at the Brooklyn Museum.
Former Mayor Vincent R. Impellitteri will be voted a pension of $30,473.89 a year today, more than twice as much as any former Mayor in the city's 300-year history.

Senator Eugene J. McCarthy, a member of the Senate Finance Committee, warned yesterday that a sharp reduction in the United States dollar outflow could "cause great disturbance in the economic plans of most European nations."

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- A centralized, automated bookkeeping system in the vast, unorganized market for over-the-counter securities may be not far over the horizon. Such a system would mean cost savings for securities concerns, and perhaps for their customers as well.
Dick Clark, who, at the age of 36, is "America's oldest teenager," is at the same time one of America's young industrialists -- all because of his special role in the youth market.
New-car sales in mid-March continued to surge to records as the automobile boom showed no sign of slackening.
SAN JUAN, March 24 (AP) -- A Canadian Navy antisubmarine plane crashed 60 miles north of here today, killing all 16 men aboard.
WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Administration leaders sought today to assure House action within two weeks on medical care for the aged.
A leader in the fight against the Lower Manhattan Expressway was accused yesterday of "selling out" his opposition to the roadway for a promise of a middle-income housing project.

Indonesia is a monstrous problem child to much of the world and especially to the United States. Like all Asian peoples, Indonesians are very hard for Westerners to understand. THE girls who can wear clothes with the most flair as they strut and whirl on a runway have almost always been ugly ducklings as children, according to the man who stages most of the important fashion shows in New York and across the country.

The stock market went through another indecisive ses- sion yesterday. So flat and aim- less is the market these days, in fact, that it seems to con- tradict J. p. Morgan's famous remark that stock prices "will continue to fluctuate."
HONG KONG, March 24 -- The Asian Communists have begun a propaganda campaign to exploit the disclosure that gas has been used against the Vietcong in South Vietnam.

The Administration's $1.3 billion bill to aid elementary and secondary education is moving toward a vote on the floor of the House of Representatives. MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 24 -- The City of St. Jude, the 40-acre Roman Catholic compound that became the campsite tonight for the Alabama Freedom March, is operated by whites for Negroes.

VIENNA, March 24 -- Representatives of more than 20 nations will open a conference at the Hofburg Palace tomorrow to decide on a color television system for Europe. The principal contenders are the United States' system, which has Britain's support, and the French system, favored by the Soviet Union.

Regine Crespin sang her first Sieglinde with the Metropolitan Opera in last night's production of Wagner's "Die Walkure," and it came as no surprise that she achieved a solid triumph in the role. Prompt action by the Administration for a long-term solution of the United States' deficit in its international payments was urged yesterday by Prof. Henry Simon Bloch.

DONCASTER, England, March 24 (AP) -- Old Tom, a 22 -- 1 longshot ridden by Scobie Breasley, a 50-year-old Australian jockey, won the Lincolnshire Handicap today setting up a possible big payoff in the spring double betting.
Boris Gresov, who gained control of the Standard Metals Corporation last week, disclosed yesterday he now has 110,000 of the 1,521,162 outstanding Standard Metal shares.
BONN, March 24 -- West Germany has prevailed upon Israel to accept a commitment of economic support as a substitute for its canceled military-aid program, informed sources said today.

NEW ORLEANS, March 24 (AP) -- Lawrence Cardinal Shehan, Roman Catholic Archbishop of Baltimore, says participation by clergymen of all faiths in civil rights demonstrations should be encouraged.
DANANG, South Vietnam, March 24 (UPI) -- The big air and missile base here was closed to American newsmen today.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 24 -- The head of the Food and Agriculture Organization, B.R. Sen, warned the United Nations today the world's nations would face "disaster of an unprecedented magnitude" within 35 years unless they took all possible measures to raise food production and halt the population explosion.

HAVANA, March 24 -- Premier Fidel Castro's armed forces disclosed today that vast maneuvers were held in central Cuba last month involving various army divisions, tank formations, artillery, the air force and "chemical" troops.

MOSCOW, March 24 -- Leonid I. Brezhnev, First Secretary of the Soviet Communist party, called today for "urgent measures" in agriculture during a speech before the party's policy-making Central Committee.

New York University announced yesterday the election of Mrs. Vincent Astor, Mrs. Albert D. Lasker and Roswell L. Gilpatric as members of the board of trustees. Mrs. Lasker and Mrs. Astor are the first women chosen as trustees in the university's 134-year history.

The Eastern Life Insurance Company of New York announced yesterday that stockholders could be asked at the annual meeting May 4 to act on a proposed capital increase to permit a 50 per cent stock dividend followed by a one-for-10 rights offering.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, March 24 (UPI) -- Gen. Alfredo Ovando Candia withdraw today his candidacy for the Presidency in the wake of the attempted assassination of Gen. Rene Barrientos Ortuno, head of Bolivia's military junta.

LAKE GEORGE, N.Y., March 24 (AP) -- Skeletons uncovered by a contractor have been identified as probably those of French soldiers killed during a battle in the French and Indian War over 200 years ago.

WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP) -- An American soldier in South Vietnam, who wrote his mother, "I wish all those people back home who think we ought to pull out, and are raising so much hell about it, would think twice," has won the praise of President Johnson.
OTTAWA, March 24 -- Plans to have the Canadian Government pay most of the cost of medical and health care are advancing.

The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation achieved the highest sales and earnings in its 44-year history, the 1964 annual report disclosed yesterday. It marked the fifth successive year of new records.
The New York State Athletic Commission rejected yesterday the use of an electric scoreboard that would keep fans informed on the official scoring progress of a boxing match.

VERO BEACH, Fla., March 24 -- Apprehensive Yankee fans and long-suffering Yankee haters got more stimulation for their fears and hopes, respectively, today as Whitey Ford was hammered for 11 runs in five innings by the Los Angeles Dodgers.

LONDON, March 24 -- He is a 45-year-old New Testament scholar who has been nicknamed the "fast-thinking Bishop."
Fourteen Russian schoolchildren on spring holiday toured Hunter Elementary School yesterday until they arrived at Miss Marie Boylan's art class, where they were put to work.
LONDON, March 24 -- One chance in 636,763,050 came through today for three thermometer-factory workers who won $886,260.48 by forecasting the results of last Saturday's soccer matches.

An increase of 1,15,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline[ stocks in the week ended lastI Friday was reported yesterdayI by the American Petroleum In-I stitute. At the weekend, supplies vere 228,779,000 barrels, compared with 227,624,000 a week earlier and 214,115,000 a year ago.

CARACAS, Venezuela, March 24 (UPI) -- Ronald Barnes of Brazil eliminated Dennis Ralston of Bakersfield, Calif., from the Venezuelan international tennis tournament tonight by defeating the top-ranked United States player, 6-4, 10-8.

OKLAHOMA CITY, March 24 (UPI) -- Oklahoma Supreme Court Justice N.B. Johnson was impeached today by the State House of Representatives on two counts of selling favorable opinions. He is the third member of the state's highest court to be accused in a $150,000 payoff.
The Chesapeake Ohio Railway has filed an application with the Interstate Commerce Commission to acquire control of the Chicago, South Shore South Bend Railroad.
TORONTO, March 24 (UPI) -- The Toronto Maple Leafs downed the Montreal Canadiens in a National Hockey League game tonight, 3-2, on third-period goals by Frank Mahovlich and Ron Ellis.
WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Edwin L. Weisl Jr., son of the Democratic National Committeeman from New York, was named an Assistant Attorney General today by President Johnson.

The Golden Anniversary Ball of the Grosvenor Neighborhood House will be held at the Plaza on Oct. 28. In addition to the hotel's Grand Ballroom, its Baroque Room, Baroque Foyer and adjoining Crystal Room will be used for the festivities.
ALBANY, March 24 -- A bill to raise the state's minimum wage from $1.25 to $1.50 an hour received final legislative approval by the Assembly today and sent to Governor Rockefeller.
Correction Commissioner Anna M. Kross proposed last night that two aircraft carriers ready for scrapping be turned into prisons to ease overcrowding in city jails.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., March 24 -- A woman from Palm Beach gave Casey Stengel an oil portrait of himself and three jai alai pros from Spain gave him a cesta, a basket-like mitt, before the New York Mets played the Milwaukee Braves today.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- Senator Albert Gore of Tennessee proposed today that the Internal Revenue Service be required to make public some of the 40,000 special tax rulings for individuals and businesses that it makes each year.

PARIS, March 24 -- Russians may gambol in space and Americans photograph the moon but the brightest stars for France are those that follow the names of her best restaurants in the Guide Michelin, the hungry traveler's Baedeker.
SUN VALLEY, Idaho, March 24 (UPI) -- Marielle Goitschel of France became the only double winner in the Harriman cup ski races today when she won the women's slalom by one second.
A-rated utility bonds priced to yield 4.50 per cent are finding the going slow in the new securities issues market.

HACKENSACK, N.J., March 24 -- Two couples have formally charged the Packanack Lake Country Club and Community Association with barring membership to all persons except those with "northern European Christian" background.
Once again Asians are chosen as material for a new series of scientific experiments.
PHILADELPHIA, March 24 (AP) -- They're tearing down Philadelphia's grand old fake," a six-story building that it has long been contended, without proof, is America's first Mint, built in 1792.

In the face of mounting opposition from parents, teachers and civic organizations, the Board of Education reversed a decision last night that would have kept schools open on George Washington's birthday next year.
Mayor Wagner said yesterday that the city would get new taxes in the fiscal year beginning July 1.

Prices inched up in quiet trading on the London Stock Exchange yesterday, although investors remained selective.

CINCINNATI, March 24 (UPI) -- A disputed shot by A1 Bianchi with 11 seconds remaining in an overtime period and two free throws by Wilt Chamberlain with four seconds left gave the Philadelphia 76ers a 119-117 victory over the Cincinnati Royals tonight.

A SPIRITED seven-round Swiss race for the Queens Chess Club championship resulted in a tie for first place between the master Joseph Balint and the former national amateur champion E. Schuyler Jackson. Each scored 6 -- 1.

Governor Rockefeller and other leading Republicans joined last night in honoring Mrs. Preston Davie, retiring vice chairman of the New York County Republican Committee, at a Hotel Astor dinner given by the organization's executive committeee.

The American Tobacco Company announced yesterday that the Federal Trade Commission was making an inquiry into its proposed acquisition of the Consolidated Foods Corporation, which was announced last month.
Diplomat Magazine and all its assets have been acquired by Metromedia, Inc. The acquisition marks Metromedia's entry into the publishing field.
LONDON, March 24 -- The annual Royal Gala Performance at Covent Garden, the 17th to be staged by the Royal Ballet, took place tonight before the Queen Mother and Princess Margaret.

The Metropolitan Opera will begin its first season at Lewisohn Stadium on June 21. And lot surprisingly, the seven-week series will show a greater emphasis on opera than did previous stadium festivals.

LAUREL, Md., March 24 -- (AP) -- Woodlawn Farm's Uncle Willie M. took the lead in the season's context for Maryland-bred laurels in winning the $24.425 Maryland Derby today Laurel Race Course. Uncle Willie M. paid $13.60, $5.40 and $3.20 for $2 across the board.
Joan Brown, Juilliard-trained pianist from Seattle who made her local debut last night at Town Hall, was at her best in two Mozart Rondos, those in D (K.485) and A minor (K.511).
The recent decline in prices of frozen pork bellies for future delivery gathered momentum yesterday.

CHICAGO, March 24 (UPI) -- The G. Heileman Brewing Company announced today it had offered to buy the General Brewing Company of San Francisco for $18 million, or $18.50 a share of General Brewing stock.
John J. Gilhooley, Transit Authority Commissioner, asked Mayor Wagner yesterday for 782 new transit policemen to provide a patrolman for each train at night.

Mack Thomas, Texas-born, silences such frivolous skepticism by creating, in words chosen with a poet's care, the reality of an American family hard pressed by the Depression of the nineteen-thirties.
WASHINGTON, March 24 (UPI) -- House Republicans endorsed today a constitutional amendment to overturn the Supreme Court's one-man-one-vote rule as applied to State Senates.
RUTHERFORD, N.J., March 24 -- Students on the Fairleigh Dickinson University campus here picketed today for the second day in "an expression of general student discontent."

WASHINGTON March 24 -- Some badly needed professionalism and hilarity finally came to the convention of the National Association of Broadcasters last night when Jack Benny and George Burns appeared in one of the strangest line-ups of their careers.

CAIRO, March 24 -- Harib, an important republican stronghold in Southeast Yemen, has fallen to royalist forces in a bloody battle. The loss of the town has brought new tensions along the border with the British-backed Federation of South Arabia.

The ideal solution for the New Haven Railroad crisis is to turn over the New York-Connecticut commuter operation to the Port of New York Authority.
MOUNT KENNEDY, Yukon Territory, March 24 -- Senator Robert F. Kennedy reached the top of Mount Kennedy today and became the first person to scale the 13,900-foot peak.
YONKERS, March 24 -- Eddie Cobb drove Trader Nardin to a 1 1/2-length victory in the featured pace at Yonkers tonight.
ALBANY, March 24 -- The Democratic leadership in the Legislature, in an outline of the party's program, called today for ethics, education and election reforms.
WASHINGTON, March 24 -- The seemingly dormant church-state issue rose to haunt the Democrats today as Republicans mounted an attack on the Administration's $1.3 billion school aid bill.

HONG KONG, Thursday, March 25 -- Communist China declared today for the first time that it was ready to intervene in South Vietnam with men and war materiel should the Vietcong want such assistance. The statement was contained in an editorial in Jenmin Jih Pao, the party organ.
LONDON, March 24 -- Sotheby's auction house sold $2.5 million worth of old masters today and there wasn't a secret bid in the house.
Gordon's Gin appears to be taking its advertising on another logical step toward stressing' its English origins.

MADISON, Wis., March 24 -- A student-faculty committee at the University of Wisconsin, described by its organizers as an informal group, plans a protest April 1 on American policy in South Vietnam. The group has asked Senator Wayne Morse, Democrat of Oregon, to speak the next day.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 24 (UPI) -- The St. Louis Cardinals beat Detroit, 3-2, today. Barney Schultz left the bull pen in the fifth inning and stopped a Tiger rally by getting Al Kaline to hit into a double play.

Flag Raiser and Turn to Reason ran one, two in the $29,100 Bay Shore stakes at Aqueduct yesterday, calling for a complete re-evaluation of the 3-year-old picture hereabouts. The horses, owned respectively by Isidor Bieber and Patrice Jacobs, are trained by Hirsch Jacobs, who is planning to run theme -- as well as two other horses in his charge-in the Gotham on April 3.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara told Senators today that a Communist victory in Vietnam would only mean that the United States would have to renew the struggle elsewhere in Southeast Asia or let the whole area go by default.

VIENTIANE, Laos, March 24 -- It appears that the United States has established a bulwark against continuing Communist aggression in northern Laos. The operation, conducted in secret, has been going on for nine months.
ROTTERDAM, The Netherlands, March 24 (Reuters) -- A toss of a coin tonight put Liverpool into the semi-finals of the European Soccer Cup competition.
CROSSROAD is hardly the name for this book. It's really far more like one of those convoluted cloverleafs you encounter on our swarming superhighways.
ALGIERS, March 24 -- The Moroccan Embassy in Algiers reported tonight that peace had been restored in Casablanca and Rabat after two days of rioting.

Wellington Associates is renovating one of its recent purchases, the Gotham Hotel, at Fifth Avenue and West 55th Street, from interior to exterior to parking facilities. Two buildings at 23 and 25 West 55th Street, 40 feet west of the hotel, have been purchased and will be converted into a 300-car parking garage.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Secretary of State Dean Rusk was reported tonight to have told Cyprus' Foreign Minister of United States concern over the expected installation of Soviet ground-to-air missiles on Cyprus.

In anticipation of the legislative hearing this week in Albany on the death penalty, may I report some significant statistics on executions which I have been permitted by the United States Bureau of Prisons to use in advance of their publication.
MOSCOW, March 24 -- Well-informed Western diplomats believe that Moscow's implied threat to send volunteers to Vietnam represents a hardening, but not a fundamental change, in the Soviet position.
PARIS, March 24 -- A Gaullist spokesman told the European Parliament today that unless the political unity of Europe developed independently of the United States there would be no union.
LONDON, :March 24 (Reuters) -- Premier Levi Eshkol said here today that he was convinced world statesmanship could play an important role in creating a peaceful atmosphere in the Midcast.

Two Brooklyn teen-agers were stabbed last night, one fatally, in two street fights between white and Negro youths, the police reported. The dead boy was Perry Peterson, 16 years old, a Negro, of 1251 Hancock Street.

WASHINGTON; March 24 -- The Secretary of State who declined today to budge an inch under the barrage of foreign criticism of this Government for the employment of chemical warfare in South Vietnam hardly seemed to be the same official who so often made "world opinion" the principal consideration in shaping United States positions in the United Nations.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- The House Ways and Means Committee's approval of a plan of medical care for the aged tied to the Social Security system probably meant victory in a frustrating eight-year fight that began in 1957.

PARIS, March 24 -- A jeering crowd of angry students surged into an exhibition hall of the famous Ecole des Beaux-Arts today, set off smoke pots and firecrackers and ripped every one of the 349 architectural drawings on display off the walls.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange closed mixed yesterday in a quickened trading pace.

MINEOLA, L.I., March 24 -- The State Supreme Court today affirmed the right of the Waldemar Medical Research Foundation to obtain between $15,000 and $20,000 collected by its fundraising town councils.
The J.C. Penney Company, which operates 1,676 department stores throughout the nation, reported yesterday the highest sales and earnings in its 63-year history for the 12 months ended Jan. 31.

SARASOTA, Fla., March 24 -- If the White Sox are going to make a run at the pennant again this year, they'll have to do it on pitching, because there are times when their attack bears a suspicious resemblance to that of their ancestral forebears, Chicago's famed "Hitless Wonders" of almost 60 years ago.

The Investors Management Company, adviser to a mutual fund group, announced yesterday the election of Robert H. Daniel as president and chief executive officer. Mr. Daniel had been executive vice president.

ALBANY, March 24 -- Deep concern about alleged neglect of private medical schools, coupled with a plea for public assistance for them, emerged today during the first public hearing's on the Board of Regents master plan for higher education in the state.
The nation's electric power production rose 8.8 per cent in the week ended March 20 from the level in the corresponding 1964 week, it was reported yesterday by the Edison Electric Institute.

THE Department of Recreation for Rockville Centre, L. I., has an almost overwhelming program of activities, from acrobatics to yoga. Included is obedience training for dogs. New courses will begin in the two-story Recreation Center on Oceanside Road next Tuesday night.

Pan American World Airways and its pilots continued collective bargaining talks here yesterday. The pilots are legally free to walk out at midnight tonight although there has been no indication that they will.

CASABLANCA, Morocco, March 24 -- About 25 persons have been killed and scores injured in three days of demonstrations by teenagers, occasional gunfire and rioting here. Property damage has been heavy.

BOMBAY, India, March 24 -- The Bombay High Court yesterday ordered the sale by auction of the 10,500-ton American freighter Ponderosa, which has been under "arrest" in the harbor here for nine months.

ST. LOUIS, March 21 (UPI) -- Don Ohl sank a basket and Walt Bellamy two free throws in the last 58 seconds tonight to give the Baltimore Bullets a 108-105 victory in the first game of the Western Division National Basketball Association playoffs.

FIFTY 11th-grade biology students from the New Lincoln High School took part yesterday in a day-long experimental seminar under the direction and guidance of the department of obstetrics and gynecology of the New York Medical College, Flower and Fifth Avenue Hospitals.
Notice was served on Mayor Wagner yesterday that he faced a primary fight in September against at least one other candidate.

Quotations supplied by the National Association of Securities Dealers, at approximately 3 P.M. Bids are representative inter-dealer prices and de not include retail markdown or commission. Asked prices have been adjusted upward to include approximate markup.

A major phase of the city's transportation system was paralyzed yesterday by the taxicab strike. Public transport is so inadequate in this city that taxis are virtually a public necessity; and for the old and infirm, for luggage-laden travelers, and for many other individuals, the disappearance of taxicabs from the streets of New York was little short of calamitous.

PASADENA, Calif., March 24 -- The Ranger 9 crashed with remarkable precision in the Alphonsus crater near the center of the moon at 6:08 A.M. Pacific standard time (9:08 A.M. Eastern standard time) today.
THE recent discouraging developments on such Western fronts as Vail and Sun Valley have decreased the optimism of knowledgeable Americans about the future in international winter skiing competition.
JADOTVILLE, the Congo, March 20 -- While the Congo's fever chart fluctuates wildly, the production chart of Union Miniere du Haut-Katanga is recording a slow but steady rise.
WASHINGTON, March 24 -- A leading spokesman for the tobacco industry urged Congress today not to require the printing of a health warning on cigarette packages.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 24 -- The last day of the march on Montgomery here tomorrow is expected to be a crucial test of this city's new policy oft compliance with the constitutional guarantees of peaceful assembly.

ALBANY, March 24 -- Governor Rockefeller said today that Senator Jacob K. Javitz wanted to become Vice President. "This is a laudable ambition and one that I know he has had for some time," the Governor said at a news conference here.
A. Sulka Co., a New York haberdasher known for its expensive neckwear, added a young, attractive Parisian to its board yesterday.
LONDON, March 24 -- British reaction to the use of nausea-inducing gases by South Vietnamese troops appears to be undergoing a subtle change.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 24 -- In the vanguard of a throng of a thousand or more who marched singing into this city today was the hard-walk-band that had come all the way from Selma.
Capt. Frederick W. Mohle, master of the ill-fated American freighter Smith Voyager, pleaded not guilty yesterday to 14 charges of misconduct and negligence brought against him by the Coast Guard.
WASHINGTON, March 24 -- General Colonel, Chief of the Pentagon's Board of Humane Warfare, cannot understand the public refusal to applaud the use of nausea gas against the Vietcong.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Liberal Republicans in both houses of Congress began pressing in earnest today for a voting-rights bill broader and tougher than the bipartisan measure submitted by President Johnson.
WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Secretary of State Dean Rusk insisted today that the use of "police-type" gases in South Vietnam did not constitute "gas warfare."

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 24 (AP) -- A Federal grand jury indicted seven executives and a corporation today on charges of using the financially tangled Certified Credit Corporation to promote a vast securities fraud.

ALBANY, March 24 (AP) -- A Nassau County Republican struck sparks in the Senate today by calling for action on a bill that would override a state order requiring integration of public schools in Malverne.
" How wonderful it was to travel by bus today," a Madison Avenue commuter said on his arrival at work yesterday morning.
D.R. Comenzo Co., one of the commodities brokerage houses that were victims of the food-oil scandal, has been reinstated to membership on the Chicago Board of Trade, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- President Johnson hailed today the success and "far-out photography" of the Ranger 9 spacecraft. He then announced plans to decorate Maj. Virgil I. Grissom and Lieut. Comdr. John W. Young, the Gemini astronauts, on Friday in the White House Rose Garden.
Municipal bond dealers looking for some market direction from the $50 million Tacoma Light and Power offering, did not find it yesterday.
About 2,500 employes of Macy's and Bloomingdale's staged demonstrations outside the two Manhattan department stores yesterday in protest against what they called "stalled" contract negotiations.
MINEOLA, L.I., March 24 -- Nassau County Executive Eugene H. Nickerson announced today that he was replacing Leon Shapiro as director of the Children's Shelter in Westbury.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 24 -- The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. led a triumphal Freedom March into Montgomery this afternoon. The marchers stopped for the night 1.7 miles inside the city and prepared for the last leg of their historic Selma-to-Montgomery march, a 3 1/2-mile walk to the state Capitol tomorrow.
An investigation of pilfering of gasoline by employes at a garage of the city Department of Highways garage is under way, Leon A. Fischel, Commissioner of Investigation, said yesterday.
PARIS, March 24 -- The Cabinet took steps today to adapt French industry and agriculture to increasing competition from abroad.
BERKELEY, Calif., March 24 (UPI) -- Representatives of the magazine Spider challenged the University of California administration today by selling the publication on the campus here.
MOSCOW, March 25 -- The use of a special air lock for man's first step into space was said here today to have been a major factor in assuring the success of last week's Soviet orbital flight.
Will my baby be harmed psychologically if he looks through the bars or the mesh siding of a play pen? (No, he's too young to have an association about ciation about bars).
BEIRUT, Lebanon -- Three New York banks have sent representatives to Beirut to act as their eyes and ears for the entire Middle East.
WASHINGTON, March 25 -- Two Cabinet officers gave President Johnson optimistic reports today on the nation's balance of international payments.

Mum was the word along Wall Street yesterday in response to the news that a Chicago investment lawyer, Harold Z. Kaplan, had filed suit challenging the minimum commissions charged by New York Stock Exchange firms on stock purchases.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 25 -- The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. led 25,000 Negroes and whites to the shadow of the State Capitol here today and challenged Alabama to put an end to racial discrimination.

A Dutch Treat party will be held at Sardi's after the April 13 performance of "Do I Hear a Waltz?" at the 46th Street Theater. The evening will be a benefit for the African Medical and Research Foundations.

AMES, Iowa, March 25 -- Roy Saari of Southern California and Steve Clark of Yale scored impressive victories tonight as the 42d annual National Collegiate swimming championships began at Iowa State University. Each hopes to win twice more before the meet ends Saturday night.

BUENOS AIRES, March 25 (UPI) -- United States and a British concern are offering Argentina warplanes at bargain prices in hopes of selling her $30 million worth of commercial jetliners, reliable sources said today.

The New York, Susquehanna Western Railroad is planning to abandon all its passenger operations unless it is assured by July 1 that New Jersey will pay it a $200,000-a-year subsidy to cover its out-of-pocket loss on the business.

ROME, March 25 -- Pope Paul VI will soon announce the formation of a new Vatican secretariat to seek information on the world's atheists and to establish a dialogue with them, according to informed sources here.

THE first major contract bridge pair championship was held in New York in 1929 and one of the winners was a young actuary named Oswald Jacoby. Thirty-six years later the same Oswald Jacoby was still winning national titles.
WHAT label appears in a dress worn by the Duchess of Windsor -- and a fashion editor's secretary?

WASHINGTON, March 25 (UPI) -- Retail sales in the United States rose 1 per cent last week to $4.9 billion, the Commerce Department reported today, showing a 3 per cent gain over the level of the corresponding week a year ago.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- Everett McKinley Dirksen, the Senate Republican leader, will seek to change the language of the voting-rights bill to make certain that some areas of discrimination in Texas, Tennessee, Florida and Arkansas are covered.
Taxicab service returned to normal yesterday after a one-day strike that took more than 10,000 cars from the streets in four boroughs.
WHITEHORSE, Yukon Territory, March 25 -- An exhaust-returned from Mount Kennedy today and said that his climb to the summit had been "more difficult than I thought it would be."
Prices on the London Stock Exchange moved unevenly yesterday in the wake of small gains registered on Wednesday. Trading was on the dull side, although there was a certain amount of selective buying.

WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP) -- The Controller General chided the military today for wasting more than $1 million by following servicemen's desires rather than regulations in bringing privately owned cars back from overseas.

" OF all painters," Cezanne once remarked, "Camille Pissarro was the nearest to Nature." The truth of this observation, made by his great contemporary, who at one time worked with him, is handsomely borne out in an important loan exhibiton of Pissarro's paintings opening today at Wildenstein's, 19 East 64th Street, in aid of Recording for tile Blind, Inc.

BOSTON, March 25 (UPI) -- Stockholders of the Waldorf System, Inc., have supported the present management in a proxy fight, it was announced today. Charles J. Richardson, president of the restaurant chain, said the present company leadership received 285,480 share-votes as opposed to 95,568 for the dissident protective committee.

A boutique has come to mean a place where just about anything is sold. In Nancy Reals's boutique at Enrico Caruso (the hair salon at 110 East 55th Street), everything is for sale -- the rugs on the floor, the pictures on the walls, even the flower arrangements that decorate the room.

Three Brooklyn youths were arraigned yesterday in the aftermath of a street fight among 21 teen-agers the night before. One boy, Perry Peterson, 16 years old, of 1251 Hancock Street, died of stab wounds.
It was almost a stand-off on the American Stock Exchange yesterday as declines just nudged out advances in very active trading.

ALBANY, March 25 -- The political impasse over the state's next budget persisted today as Senate Majority Leader Joseph Zaretzki tried and failed to get the budget bills reported out of the Senate Finance Committee.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 25 -- Recent suggestions that the world monetary system undergo a radical overhaul were rejected here today by Pierre-Paul Schweitzer, managing director of the International Monetary Fund.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 25 (AP) -- The Homestake Mining Company reported its 1964 net income totaled $4,790,749, a gain of $680,203 from 1963. The earnings amounted to $2.23 a common share, compared with $2.01 in 1963.
The first major open-pit gold mining venture in the United States in 50 years is expected to get under way soon on a site near Carlin in northeastern Nevada.

As the dimensions of New York City's budgetary emergency become clearer and the legislative and political dissension at Albany increases, the danger grows that unwise tax decisions will be taken. Seldom has there been a time when such an accumulation of fiscal and party problems converged into crisis proportions, with so little time to solve them.
Two soldiers at Fort Totten, Queens, were trying to determine yesterday what they would do with the money they will receive for Republic of Texas currency they found while hunting for souvenirs.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 25 -- The weary Alabama Freedom Marchers headed for home this afternoon after a long night of entertainment and a day of triumph.

" For the People" will be discontinued after May 9 by the Columbia Broadcasting System. The television drama series (Sunday, 9 to 10 P.M.) had been rushed on the air Jan. 31 as art of the network's sweeping realignment of programing.

BUJUMBURA, Burundi, March 18 -- After 9:30 P.M. the curfew falls and this city is usually silent, except for the shrill scurrying of the gutter rats grown suddenly bold in the absence of pedestrians and traffic.

I.D. Robbins, who works for political reform as an independent Democrat, announced formally yesterday that he would not only enter the Democratic primary for Mayor but also seek the Republican nomination as well.
Weakness developed in the stock market yesterday after a show of strength in the early dealings, and closing prices were near their lows for the day. Trading continued moderately active.
BRUSSELS, March 25 -- Poland will become next week the firs Soviet-bloc nation to recognize the legal existence of the European Community.

Federal Judge Lloyd F. McMahon has indicated that the present distribution of votes in the city's Board of Estimate might be unconstitutional under the United States Supreme Court's "one-man, one-vote" ruling.

Vincent A.G. O'Connor, former City Commissioner of Marine and Aviation, has urged his successor, Leo Brown, to deny an application before that agency for approval of the roof heliport on the Pan Am Building in midtown Manhattan.

SEBRING, Fla. March 25 -- This was the first full day of practice for all the cars and drivers entered in Saturday's 12-hour endurance race for world championship points. It was a warm morning that built up to an 82-degree midday heat.

Twelve free-world maritime nations concluded yesterday a three-day meeting under the auspices of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, at which regulation of international shipping was discussed.
Net new orders for machine tools advanced sharply in February above the January figure.

The Union Pacific Railroad announced yesterday it had agreed to sell to the Southern Pacific Company for $120 million a total of 2,462 miles of main line and 1,063 miles of branch-line track of the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railroad.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 25 -- When the deal was made at the June 15 trading deadline, some of the more captious critics in St. Louis called it "Bing's Folly." They were convinced that Bing Devine, then the general manager of the Cardinals, had been grossly hoodwinked by the Chicago Cubs, who normally never hoodwink anyone but themselves.

In a move described as "the orderly progression of top management," Benton Bowles Inc., announced yesterday the election of William R. Hesse, agency president, as chief executive officer. The change is effective April 15.

WHITE PLAINS, March 25 -- The State Department Public Works received today a low bid of $23,528,965 for construction of the first leg of Westchester County's most controversial road, Interstate Highway 87.
PARIS, March 25 -- Premier Chou En-lai of China has predicted that "the Chinese and Russian people will close ranks" should the United States provoke a wider conflict in Asia.

COLLEGE skippers will battle one another this spring for the first time in a truly national big-boat sailing championship. The event, to be known as the John F. Kennedy Memorial Regatta, is the most recent addition to the long and varied list of tributes to the late President.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- The political logjam that has held up New York appointments to the Federal bench for as long as a year appeared to be breaking today.

ATLANTIC CITY, March 25 -- New Jersey's top health officer said today that the outbreak of St. Louis encephalitis in New Jersey last year, which caused eight deaths, had been "a disgrace for the state."

WASHINGTON, March 25 (UPI) -- Morris B. Abram, national president of the American Jewish Committee, was appointed by President Johnson today to represent the United States on the United Nations Human Rights Commission.

MENTON, France, March 25 (UPI) -- Bob Carmichael and Jim Kelso of Australia were among the survivors of today's quarter-final round in the Menton international lawn tennis championships.
A group of New York lawyers grappled here yesterday with the problem of how to subpoena a computer.
The Federal Reserve Bank of New York published one of its occasional statistical mysteries yesterday.
A group of Lower East Side residents who have organized a Community Committee to Settle the Henry Street Settlement Strike yesterday increased their efforts to end the 43-day-old walkout.

The Rabbinical Council of America, the largest Orthodox body established yesterday a Task Force for Civil, Rights designed to intensify involvement by Orthodox, spiritual leaders in the Negro fight for human equality and opportunity.
Five apartment buildings in New Jersey, appraised at $25 million, have been sold to the B.P.K. Realty Investment Company, a partnership headed by David L. Paul.
SCRATCH a craftsman and you'll find an individual If there is any one point made at yesterday's opening of the annual exhibition of the Artist-Craftsmen of New York, that is it.

THE end of the civil rights march and the mass rally in Montgomery received absorbingly vivid coverage on television yesterday afternoon. Just as the home medium played such a powerful and dramatic part in arousing the country to the brutality of the frustration on March 7 of the first attempt by Negroes to march from Selma, yesterday's presentation was an unforgetable personalization of society and history in change.
A SUCCESSION of seven wills by Mrs. Alexander Hamilton has been the pivotal element in a coast-to-coast search for furnishings in the last year.

SINCE last appearing with the New York Philharmonic two seasons back, Lorin Maazel has added still another string to his bow. The young American conductor has since then been named musical director of the West Berlin Opera.
District Attorney Frank S. Hogan has dropped first-degree murder charges against two drifters who were indicted last March after confessing to the hammer-slaying of a derelict.

WASHINGTON, March 25 (UPI) -- The House Appropriations Committee voted today to give the Interior Department and related agencies more than $1 billion for the next fiscal year, but it complained that too much money was going for whooping cranes.
DEPOSIT, N.Y. -- A 12-man expeditionary force from New York City's Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity is exploring the western Catskills, looking for water and not finding very much.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- Discussions here about the use of nausea-inducing gas in Vietnam have brought to light the story of an ingenious scheme by which the White House once nullified the use of a totally different kind of chemical agent on some sugar bound for the Soviet Union.
WASHINGTON, March 25 -- The Administration's $1.3 billion school aid bill survived several crucial test votes today and appeared headed for passage in the House tomorrow.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given every Friday on this page. The restaurants are rated on the basis of four stars to none. Four stars pertain to restaurants regarded as among the finest in the area.
TORONTO (Canadian Press) March 25 -- Falconbridge Nickel Mines, Ltd., reported net earnings of $24,965,000, or $5.12 a share, in 1964, compared with $14,288,000, or $2.94 a share, in 1963.
Mike Venezia, the 19-year-old jockey who grew up in Brooklyn, continued in the role of local favorite at Aqueduct yesterday.

NORWALK, Conn., March 25 -- Francis X. McBride, former Federal Bureau of Investigation official, announced his candidacy today for the Republican mayoral nomination. Mr. McBride was endorsed for the post several weeks ago by an independent citizens committee.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 25 -- Four past and present managers of the New York Yankees were on hand today for the annual meeting of the clans of New York's baseball teams -- but the man of the hour was Yogi Berra.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 25 -- A white woman worker for the Southern Christian Leadership Conference was shot to death tonight while returning to Montgomery from Selma, Ala., where she had delivered a carload of civil rights workers who took part in the Freedom March that ended here today.
Mayor Wagner said yesterday that the city had not decided whether it would pay the expenses of official city representatives participating in the Selma-to-Montgomery Freedom March.

Net income of Harper and Row, Publishers, Inc, rose to an indicated $305,000, or 40 cents a share, in the third fiscal quarter, from $160,000, or 16 cents a share, in the corresponding 1964 quarter, it was reported yesterday.

Nudity may be banned from the Broadway stage, but it found sanctuary last night in a dance program at the Judson Memorial Church. Vice President Hubert H. Humphrey will join city officials Monday in honoring the Gemini space team of Virgil I. (Gus) Grissom and John W. Young.

The Inter American Press Association Scholarship Fund awarded journalism scholarships yesterday to nine Latin-American newspapermen and students for a year of study at United States universities.
Different interpretations of news reports resulted in sharp declines in copper prices in London yesterday and strong advances in futures here.
The Swiss franc, which continued to bear the brunt of a major portion of the dollar shortage in Europe, fell yesterday to a 13-year low in the foreign exchange markets here.

VIENTIANE, Laos, March 25 (UPI) -- North Vietnamese res spearheaded an attact by Pathet Lao forces on an army camp near the Ho Chi Minh trial in southern Laos Monday night, a military spokesman reported today.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- Intercity truck tonnage and carloadings of rail freight in the week ended March 20 were both above the volume of the corresponding week of 1964. The backlog caused by the recently settled longshoremen's strike was cited as a major factor in the year-to-year increase.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 25 (UPI) -- Health authorities disclosed today that the pleague had broken out in central Vietnam. The Health Ministry also said cholera may have struck Saigon.
May Department Stores Company, a leading chain, and Meier Frank Company, Inc., a Portland, Ore., department store jointly announced yesterday their intention to merge.

DETROIT, March 25 (UPI) -- Alex Delvecchio scored three goals tonight and Norm Ullman two as the Detroit Red Wings routed the New York Rangers 7-4, and won their first National Hockey League championship in eight years.
PARIS, March 25 -- The European Common Market must be "prudent" in the Kennedy round of tariff negotiations, French Foreign Minister Maurice Couve de Murville warned today.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- A revised program of economic assistance to depressed areas, with emphasis on regional development rather than on individual cities or counties, was proposed today by President Johnson.

SELMA, Ala., March 25 (AP) -- The City of Selma filed a $100,000 suit against the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and other civil rights leaders and organizations today in an effort to recover money the city spent to police demonstrations for more than two months.

WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP) -- James J. Wadsworth was nominated by President Johnson today to fill a three-month-old vacancy on the Federal Communications Commission. He will succeed Frederick Ford, who resigned.
