WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP) -- President Johnson submitted to Congress today a plan to reorganize the Customs Bureau and eliminate all its patronage jobs.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -Representative Gerald R. Ford Jr. said today that Republicans should be given control of two Congressional investigating committees to guard against "any cover-up of wrongdoing" by the Democratic Administration.

BROOKVILLE, L.I., March 25 -- The Vesper Boat Club eight of Philadelphia that gained a stunning triumph in the Olympics is coming to Long Island to help accelerate the rapidly growing interest in rowing on the North Shore.

Montgomery is once again the home of a lost cause and the birthplace of a new freedom. Over the state Capitol yesterday there fluttered the battle flag of the Confederacy, where exactly one hundred years ago that lost cause had its final headquarters. Nearby, more than 25,000 Negroes and whites who believe in equality held a mass rally. The five-day walk for freedom from Selma had ended in triumph.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -The chairman of a House Armed Services subcommittee accused Pentagon officials today of "contemptuous disregard of the Congress" in the way they planned to merge the Army Reserve forces.
A Louisiana radio station beleaguered by segregationists is receiving support from a New York merchant group.
The Kingsborough Community College, which has been operating since last September on two temporary campuses, borrowed a third yesterday for the inauguration of its president.
The largest rally in the memory of the college's faculty and administration officials took place yesterday at the City College uptown campus.

Bits of news stories from The New York Times, The Washington Post and Time and Life magazines were immortalized in concert form at the third of Max Pollikoff's "Music in Our Times" series last night at the Kaufmann Auditorium of the 92d Street Y.
Twenty-eight singers from the United States and Canada have been engaged for the first season of the Metropolitan Opera National Company, which begins in Indianapolis in September.

Ever since New York State initiated compulsory public liability insurance on passenger automobiles, for younger drivers in 1952 and for all in 1956, the minimum coverage required has remained at $10,000 for injury to one person, $20,000 to two or more, and $5,000 for property damage.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, March 25 -- Government forces seized Aru today, the first important objective of their drive to sever rebel supply lines in the northeastern Congo.
CHICAGO, March 25 -- A team of California physicians reported here today success in fighting bacterial disease with bacteria.
WASHINGTON, March 25 -- President Johnson's chief trouble-shooter in the Alabama civil rights crisis said today that he hoped there could be a "respite" from demonstrations in the state.

CASABLANCA, Morocco, March 25 -- Under army surveillance, life resumed its normal pace in this sprawling Atlantic Coast city after three days of the worst street riots in Morocco since she became independent of France in 1956.

LEIPZIG, East Germany, March 25 -- They came from Dresden, Weimar, Gorlitz and Leipzig -- more than 6,000 in all -- to hear Louis Armstrong and his "All Stars" introduce American jazz in person to East Germany.

Can anyone imagine any greater bitterness than that of the parents of little children choking away their last few moments of life after being poisoned by "humane nauseating" gas spread by our military leaders?
The Owens-Illinois Glass Company said yesterday it would revise some of its glass container price lists in order to improve what it called subnormal profit areas.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, March 25 -- Dudley Senanayake, leader of the conservative and pro-Western United National party, was sworn in today as the new Prime Minister of Ceylon.
WASHINGTON, March 25 -- Following is the text of President Johnson's remarks today on Vietnam:
WASHINGTON, March 25 (UPI) -- Mississippi's House members, rejecting as illegal a Negro challenge to their election, declined today to go through the formalities of defending themselves.
BERLIN, March 25 -- The East German Communists announced today a shuffling of Government posts that brought younger men, identified as economic experts and business executives, to top positions.
WASHINGTON, March 25 -- Senator Gaylord Nelson urged the Federal Trade Commission today to publish testimony that he said documented "a national scandal in automobile tires."
MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 25 -- Following is the text of a petition prepared for presentation to Gov. George C. Wallace by leaders of the Negro march on Montgomery:

Your editorial of March 23 reluctantly supporting Governor Rockefeller's tax program although you would prefer an enlarged personal income tax, is a service to the City of New York at a critical moment. As a matter of fact, the state-wide sales tax is preferable to a personal income tax increase because it is much less likely to injure the economy of the city.
Following are excerpts from the address by the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. yesterday at the Alabama Capitol in Montgomery, as recorded by The New York Times:
Directors of the Monsanto Company elected Edward A. O'Neal Jr., 59-year-old vice president, as chairman of the company's board yesterday.
American Express Warehousing, Ltd., subsidiary of the American Express Company, filed yesterday an amended schedule of assets and liabilities in Federal Court here.

I was surprised and somewhat disappointed at the tone of The Times's obituary of the late King Farouk. It brought to mind Shakespeare's well-known line, "The evil that men do lives after them; the good is oft interred with their bones."
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 25 -- A personal triumph of heroic proportions was Warren Spahn's contribution today to the folklore of the antpodal rivalry between the Net York Yankees and Mets.
GENEVA, March 25 (Reuters) -- Britain took a firm stand against the proposed United States-Canadian free trade agreement in autos and parts, usually well-informed sources said today.

The results of the sixth general election in Ceylon since independence in 1948 were moderately encouraging for the West and for the cause of anti-Communism in Asia. There was a decided swing away from the Government coalition with its Trotskyite and Communist members, and there were big gains for the relatively conservative United National party and lesser gains for other small center and right parties.

HONG KONG, March 25 -- The Vietcong are prepared to fight against the United States forces in South Vietnam "for five or even 20 more years" until final victory, according to a Vietcong official quoted today by the North Vietnamese press agency.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 25 -- Government forces began a major action in the lower Mekong delta today in an attempt to take the offensive during an extended lull in Vietcong attacks.
BONN, March 25 -- The West German Parliament voted today the shortest suggested extension of the legal deadline for new prosecutions of Nazi war criminals.
LONDON, March 25 -- The Government announced today the first increase in postal charges in eight years in an effort to make British mail services run at a profit.
Steel stocks have proved as strong as any group in the market this week, and some Wall Street observers believe the steels could lead the way to a general price advance in 1965.
GENEVA, March 25 -- The United States is on notice that it will be breaking the first rule of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade if it goes ahead with a proposed auto agreement with Canada.
Treasury bill prices advanced yesterday but practically all sectors of the bond market stood still.
The first edition of The New York Times was delayed for more than an hour last night when the newspaper's printers left their jobs to attend a union meeting in the composing room.

Pink, white and yellow rabbits will stare in their special stuffed way at guests attending the Paradise Ball on April 9 in the Plaza's Grand Ballroom. The event is a benefit for the Sheltering Arms' Children's Service.

WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP) -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee approved legislation today designed to curb any hidden influence of foreign agents and lobbyists on United States foreign policy decisions.
STAMFORD, Conn., March 25 -- Governor John N. Dempsey of Connecticut today urged law-enforcement agencies to get into the education business.
WASHINGTON, March 25 -- A further group of physicians added their dissent today to the widely accepted hypothesis that cigarette smoking is a cause of lung cancer and other respiratory diseases.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -President Johnson's new plan for rent subsidies to some 500,000 lower-middle income families over the next four years came under searching questioning today in a House subcommittee.

DO all adolescents live in a permanent state of emotional turmoil, alternating between misery and exultation? Presumably they do, or else all the novelists who write with skill and feeling about adolescents are mistaken. Or could there be an aspect of this psychological-literary problem that hasn't yet been investigated?

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- (UPI) -- James E. Webb, administrator of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, reported to President Johnson and the Cabinet today that pictures from Ranger 9 gave strong indications that the moon's surface was strong enough to support a manned landing.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- For the first time in the 30-year history of the Social Security program, a major revision in benefits and taxes has been strongly influenced by the general impact of the changes in the economy rather than merely the actuarial conditions of the Social Security Trust Fund.
LONDON, March 25 -- Prime Minister Harold Wilson and Sir Alec Douglas-Home, the Conservative leader, exchanged sharp words over the Vietnam crisis in the House of Commons today.
ALBANY, March 25 --Capital punishment was attacked today as "a cruel, irrational instrument of retribution," and defended as "the ultimate deterrent to the ultimate crime."

WASHINGTON, March 25 AP) -- Secretary of the Air Force Eugene M. Zuckert announced today that he had accepted the resignations of 105 cadets who admitted involvement in cheating at the Air Force Academy in Colorado Springs.

Richard Robles, the 22-year-old narcotics addict indicted on charges of first degree murder in the slaying of Janice Wylie and Emily Hoffert in 1963, pleaded not guilty yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Abraham J. Gellinoff.

" Track of the Bear," by William Bixby, a story of a famous ship of the Arctic, will be published by McKay on April 16. The Bear's wooden hull was launched in Scotland in 1874. She became a sealing ship for 10 years.
WASHINGTON, March 25 -- President Johnson indirectly offered to North Vietnam today the prospect of "economic and social cooperation" if peace was restored in Southeast Asia.

WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP) -- A consent order announced today by the Federal Trade Commission allows Kaiser Cement and Gypsm Corporation, additional time to dispose of Olympic Portland Cement Company of Seattle.

The explosive growth of the Soviet Union's merchant marine has led to "unwarranted conclusions" printed in "unscrupulous press organs" that the Soviet Union plans to dominate the international shipping market, according to Viktor Bakayev, Minister of Merchant Marine.

James H. Lavenson has been elected president of the Premier Corporation of America, succeeding Paul Sonnabend, who has become executive vice president of the Hotel Corporation of America. Mr. Lavenson had been vice president of Premier, a diversified company with its main interests in the apparel industry.
A gang of bank robbers whose leader piloted them around the country in his private plane for holdup assignments was broken up yesterday by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.
A new discotheque, La Gigue, will erupt with the frug, the surf, the monkey and the bostela at the Waldorf-Astoria on April 7.
A local representing 700 employes of Yonkers Raceway served notice last night that it would call a strike Monday unless the harness racing track agreed to a contract.

LONDON, March 26 -- The Daily Telegraph said today that "a former paid Nazi sympathizer has been working for the Russians for at least three years while in a key Whitehall position." A spokesman for the Home Office said there was no official comment.
MOSCOW, March 26 -- The Soviet Union's newest cosmonauts conceded today that they had overshot their landing area in a manually controlled return to earth last week after a 26-hour orbital flight.
The New York City Opera will give the Puccini triple bill of "Il Tabarro," "Suor Angelica" and "Gianni Schicchi" at City Center tonight at 8:15.
KLATEN, Indonesia -- The peasants of Klaten are a gentle and friendly people. To an outsider they seem indifferent to anything beyond tilling their fields and raising their families.

A Brooklyn College philosophy lecturer, who had been dismissed for rescinding the loyalty oath required of all faculty members, presented his case yesterday to about 500 students at an outdoor campus rally.

" Music of the Mountaineer," the second of four concerts sponsored by the Newport Folk Foundation and the Friends of Oldtime Music was presented last night at the New School for Social Research. A nearly capacity audience of 500 persons attended.

ATLANTA, March 26 (UPI) -- Lester Maddox, who gave up his restaureant business rather than admit Negroes as customers, today was ordered into a Criminal Court trial. He was charged with pointing a pistol at a Negro.
The harness horses were off and running before record crowds at Roosevelt Raceway last year, and the track's profits and revenues soared.

HOLLYWOOD BEACH, Fla., March 26 -- Retention of the one-price cotton system because of its stimulating effect on the entire $17 billion-a-year textile business was urged here today by industry leaders.
THE performance of "Giselle" given by the American Ballet Theater at the New York State Theater last night indicated that Lupe Serrano must now be ranked as one of greatest ballerinas dancing today.

Even prosperous railroads in the West such as the Southern Pacific Company have their problems, Benjamin F. Biaggini, president, observed yesterday at the New York Society of Security Analysts luncheon.
The State Board of Social Welfare voted yesterday to make birth control information available to unmarried welfare recipients if they are the heads of families.
TORONTO, March 26 -- A complete overhaul of the securities laws of Ontario was recommended in a report submitted today in the provincial Legislature.
ALBANY, March 26 -- Democratic and Republican leaders in the Senate predicted today that Governor Rockefeller's proposed 2 per cent statewide sales tax would be defeated.

PHILADELPHIA, March 26 (UPI) -- A brilliant performance by Oscar Robertson enabled the Cincinnati Royals to edge the Philadelphia 76ers, 121-120, tonight and deadlock the National Basketball Association Eastern semi-final playoffs at 1-1. The game was tied 23 times.

Mignon Dunn sang her first Dalila with the company in the Metropolitan Opera's "Samson et Dalila" last night. She started coolly, and at first it seemed that she was a little uncomfortable vocally in the role. There were a few muffled sounds and she did not carry above the orchestra, even though it was being discreetly led by Fausto Cleva.
BEING named to the best-dressed list is something less than a signal honor, many of the nominees have said.

JACKSON, Miss., March 26 (UPI) -- JoAnn Prentice, playing on the rain-soaked, 6,602-yard, par-72 Colonial Country Club course, carded a 74 today to take the first-round lead in the $10,000 Allstate invitation golf tournament.

Maine potato futures rose 26 cents a hundredweight on the near months in active trading on the Mercantile Exchange here yesterday. In one of the year's busiest trading sessions a total of 6,100 contracts were traded on the increased demand.

The duel between Bill Mahorney and Mike Venezia for top honors among the riders generated day-long excitement yesterday for the 23,646 customers at Aqueduct. The two apprentices are within one victory of each other, Venezia leading with 14.
A strong New York Athletic Club squad began the defense of its Eastern Amateur Athletic Union wrestling championship on the mats of the Winged Foot Club last night.

The demand of youthful, educated readers and the impact of electronic journalism are resulting in new reporting, writing and editing techniques, Wes Gallagher, general manager of The Associated Press, said yesterday.
Mayor Wagner appointed one committee yesterday to investigate the taxi labor dispute and another to supervise the industry's new employe health insurance fund.
New York got back yesterday an industrial operation that moved to New Jersey four years ago.

If Controller Arthur Levitt, one of the greatest vote-getters statewide that the Democrats ever had, was unable to win a primary contest against Robert E. Wagner for Mayor in 1961, the chances that I.D. Robbins, president of the City Club, can do it in 1965 seem small indeed.
Another automated ship embroiled in a continuing labor dispute over the size of ship crews finally sailed from Mobile Ala., yesterday.

The Newspaper Fund, Inc., announced yesterday the award of summer study fellowships in journalism to 270 high school and junior college teachers. The grants cover tuition, room, board, textbooks and, in some cases, travel expenses.
Your editorial "Protection for Pension Funds" focuses attention on an area of great importance to millions of Americans. But it requires comment.
GENEVA, March 26 -- United Nations economists forecast today a slight slowdown in Western Europe's economic expansion this year.

WASHINGTON, March 26 (UPI) -- A Braniff Airways plane with 45 persons aboard lost the use of its radio communications and navigation instruments Wednesday but was guided to safety by an Air National Guard plane, the Federal Aviation Agency disclosed today.
The London stock market was unsettled at the close of the trading week yesterday mainly because of renewed weakness of the pound.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 26 -- Gov. George C. Wallace declared tonight that the murder of Mrs. Viola Gregg Liuzzo on lonely U.S. Highway 80 between Selma and the state capital was an "outrageous" and "cowardly" act.

Nathan Milstein will be the soloist in all three New York Philharmonic subscription concerts next week. The violinist last played with the orchestra in 1958. With Lorin Maazel conducting, Mr. Milstein will offer the Brahms Concerto.
KARACHI, Pakistan, March 26 -- A DC-3 transport of the Pakistan International Airlines with 22 persons aboard crashed today near Lowari Pass in the rugged Northwest Frontier territory of Pakistan.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- President Johnson has directed Secretary of State Dean Rusk and Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara to brief Congress periodically on all matters of national interest that do not violate security.

PHILIPPE ENTREMONT, the 30-year-old French pianist, has been giving concerts in this country for almost 15 years, and by now he has a faithful following. Carnegie Hall was well stocked last night when he played there.

WHEN weary from shopping, delivering the mail or pounding the beat, there is nothing nicer than a nice cup of tea -- particularly if it is free. And it is both available and free at the Tea Center, 16 East 56th Street, every weekday between 10 and 11:30 A.M. and 2 and 4 P.M.

SPRING isn't exactly busting out all over outdoors, but in the shops signs of balmier days are beginning to burgeon. Although it isn't quite time to put the fur coat into storage, there are a number of small things to add cheer to tired wardrobe -- hats, for instance, or what pass as hats.
The election of Guerino Salerni of Long Island City, Queens, as president of the Architects Council of New York City was announced yesterday.
Plans for the construction of a huge complex of fertilizer manufacturing plants and other production units were announced yesterday by the Allied Chemical Corporation.
Mohasco Industries, Inc., the largest producer in the home-furnishings industry, has begun a broad, diversification program to include the widest possible "mix" of related products.
The American Merchant Marine Institute's annual "status report," describing the nation's privately owned fleet, illustrates the continuing decline of the American merchant marine.
AMES, Iowa, March 26 -- Roy Saari, who has been eating like a champion, swam like one tonight as he beat Steve Clark in a classic duel in the National Collegiate championships.
Al Hirt, the jazz trumpeter who has been a guest on many television shows, will have his own summer program over the Columbia Broadcasting System network.

Your March 15 editorial "As the Wrecker's Ball Swings" conveys the impression that an undue amount of time has been consumed in considering the Landmarks Preservation Bill. An examination of the facts, however, points to a contrary conclusion.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- President Johnson declared war on the Ku Klux Klan today after announcing the arrest of four Klansmen in connection with the slaying last night of a white woman civil rights worker in Alabama.
LONDON, March 26 -- Premier Levi Eshkol of Israel said today that the chances for peace in the Middle East were "not very promising" but that Israel remained strong.
Employes at three major department stores will strike next week unless satisfactory new contracts are negotiated, a union official declared yesterday.
KARACHI, Pakistan, March 26 -- Pakistan and Communist China signed today an agreement delineating a border region high in the Himalayas and then provided for increased cultural exchanges.
WASHINGTON, March 26 (UPI) -- Sixteen Democratic House members urged President Johnson today to reserve to himself all future decisions on the use of chemical, biological and radiological weapons.
A theatrical jigsaw puzzle involving scores of actors, producers, managers and press agents is being pieced together in the office suite of a Broadway producer.

" We are all liable to exaggerate the stability of that which exists," writes the British Kremlinologist, Robert Conquest, in this sober, and sobering, examination of power transfer in the Soviet Union. He is right, and the sudden ouster of Khrushchev last October was a reminder of the anarchic political jockeying that is still the process of succession in one of the two major powers.

PARIS, March 26 -- The 2,000-year-old Temple of Dendur, dismantled and ready for shipment, has been offered to the United States by the United Arab Republic. Awed by the magnitude of the gift, a United States official expressed his gratitude but left acceptance of the offer up to Washington.

A concessionaire of the Finger Lakes Race Track said in Rochester on Thursday that Hyman E. Mintz, a Sullivan County Republican leader, had returned $100,000 that was to have been used in a plot to secure a license at the track because "Governor Rockefeller got wind of it and does not want any part of it."
A new venture in Spanish drama got under way last night.
ST. LOUIS, March 26 (UPI) -- The St. Louis Hawks, with Bob Pettit and Zelmo Beaty scoring key baskets in the final period, defeated the Baltimore Bullets, 129-105, tonight.
DETROIT, March 26 -- "It's everybody's fight," she had told her husband, who had tried to dissuade her from going to Alabama. "There are just too many people who just stand around talking."
A State Supreme Court Justice urged the city yesterday to make public its four-year-long investigation into alleged price-fixing by the milk industry.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., March 26 (AP) -- Following are sketches of the four men arrested by the Federal Bureau of Investigation in the slaying of Mrs. Viola Liuzzo:
PATERSON, N.J., March 26 -- A Brooklyn man who had been accused of stealing a car won a new trial today because a juror reported after the man had been convicted that her son-in-law was a policeman.

SEBRING, Fla., March 26 -- Two Chaparrals, three Ferraris and two Ford prototypes are rated the outstanding cars in a field of 70 that will compete for world championship points tomorrow in Sebring's 15th annual 12-hour endurance race.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, March 26 -- A deal has been worked out to pay Western oil companies 60 million rupees ($12.6 million) in compensation for the expropriation of installations in Ceylon, according to an authoritative source in Prime Minister Dudley Senanayake's United National party.
WASHINGTON, March 26 -- Secretary of State Dean Rusk discussed the Vietnam crisis for more than an hour today with Anatoly F. Dobrynin, the Soviet Ambassador.

Following is a transcript of President Johnson's broadcast announcement yesterday on the arrest of four Ku Klux Klan members in connection with the slaying of Mrs. Viola Gregg Liuzzo in Lowndes County, Ala., as recorded by The New York Times:

COCHRANE, Alberta -- About 40 miles off the old Banff-Calgary Highway, in rugged foothill country of the Canadian Rockies, a dozen aluminum trailers are huddled together to make a drill camp. In a gas-prone area known as Benjamin Creek, a 140-foot derrick, almost obscured by thesvirl of spring snow, was in its 48th day nf drilling.
WATERBURY, Conn., March 26 (AP) -- Seven policemen required hospital treatment tonight after a street fight broke out as the police attempted to make an arrest in a Negro neighborhood.
TOLEDO, Ohio, March 26 (AP) -- Ronald Pryor beat the defending champion, but then was beaten in the semi-finals of the Amateur Athletic Union boxing championships tonight.
Issues fell along a broad front yesterday on the American Stock Exchange in active trading.
The British pound dropped below the $2.79 level yesterday for the first time since the $3 billion rescue sterling operation by 11 nations began last November.

DETROIT, March 26 -- The body of Mrs. Viola Gregg Liuzzo, the Detroit woman who drove a group of students to Alabama last week to aid the civil rights movement, returned home to a lonely airport tonight in a gray coffin covered by brown wrapping paper.
Stanley Ross, editor of El Tiempo, Spanish-language weekly said yesterday he had inadvertently issued incorrect information" on stockholders of his enterprise in an interview last Tuesday.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 26 -- Westchester's special census, which officials believe will increase state aid to the county by $500,000 a year, was postponed today because of an insufficient number of applicants for jobs as enumerators at $12 to $15 a day.
ATLANTA, March 26 -- The Imperial Wizard of the United Klans of America, Knights of the Ku Klux Klan, Inc., called the President of the United States a "damn liar" today.

The Interstate Commerce Commission announced yesterday that its examiners' recommendation on the proposed merger of the New York Central into the Pennsylvania Railroad would be issued at 9:30 A.M. on Monday in Washington.
Government and corporate bonds registered substantial declines yesterday in a market buffeted by rumors. The rumors, which caused much speculation and excitement, were unfounded.

A marathon teach-in -- the newest of the socio-political tactics that have added sit-ins, stand-ins and wade-ins to the language of dissent -- came resoundingly to Columbia University early yesterday.
ALBANY, March 26 -- New York State reversed its film censorship procedure today to comply with recent decisions by the United States Supreme Court.
The Savings Bank of Rockland County came into being yesterday but will not be in business for perhaps a week.

The Zaretzki-Travia leadership of the Democratic party in the Legislature has at last delivered its long-promised blueprint of a program for the current session. The outline is admittedly partial, to be elaborated later. Some of the goals are excellent, others dubious.

The stock market dislikes uncertainty and the trading floor of the New York Stock Exchange received a double dose of unsettling news in midsession yesterday. The resultant nervousness helped to accelerate a slide in stock prices.
PHOENIX, Ariz., March 26 (UPI) -- Two of the seeded men and three of the top women players were upset in the first two rounds today of the 14th annual Thunderbird invitation tennis tournament.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 26 -- Measures to insure the continued international flow of capital and to control excessive population growth are essential to the economic strength of developing countries, the president of the World Bank said in his annual report today.

George Whitmore Jr. suffered a serious reversal in his bid for freedom yesterday when a Brooklyn Supreme Court Justice ruled that his confession to the knife-slaying of a charwoman last April was voluntary.
ROME, Ga., March 26 (UPI) -- A suspect in a Tennessee bank robbery took a prominent physician as hostage on an automobile ride into northern Georgia tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- The shutters on the Ranger 9 cameras, which took the moon photographs shown on home-television screens Wednesday morning, were opened and closed by a special magnetic actuator.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 26 -- The first meeting of the new committee on peacekeeping operations became the forum today for an attack by the Soviet bloc on United States policy in Asia.
DETROIT, March 26 -- An elderly widow who set herself ablaze on a street corner last week as a protest against United States foreign policy died today.

After years of successful sabotage by the corporate farm lobby, Congress finally was able to slam the door last Dec. 31 on the legal importation of hundreds of thousands of low-wage Mexican laborers to harvest American crops. Now California growers are engaged in a callous, rear-guard action to reopen the migration floodgates and thus to condemn American farm workers to continued exploitation.
WASHINGTON, March 26 (AP) -- Three Alabama Congressmen responded to Mrs. Griffith's comments by expressing the hope that the person or persons who killed Mrs. Liuzzo would be convicted.

Two grandparents were treating their two grandchildren to a rowboat ride on Lake Mohansic last summer when 18-month-old Victor fell from his grandmother's arms into the water. The grandfather stood up in an effort to reach for the child and he, too, fell overboard.

Hamilton College,' a 153-year-old liberal arts college for men, announced yesterday that it would establish a college for women. The institution will be the first in a series of coordinate undergraduate colleges to be established on land adjoining the present campus in Clinton N.Y. It will be named for Samuel Kirkland, a missionary, who founded the academy which became Hamilton College.

TOKYO, Saturday, March 27 -- Japan and South Korea initialed a draft agreement on trade relations today. The action marked a further significant step toward the establishment of diplomatic relations between this country and her former colony.

Plans are afoot to rearrange traffic in Greenwich Village and there is always talk of vigorous methods needed to improve the moral tone of the place. No doubt reform is needed in both sectors. However, all this makes the old Villager exclaim, "What! again?" for somebody has always been taking out after illegal parking, sin or something else in the Village.
The resignation of Robert W. Stone as manager of the Federal Reserve System's open-market account and the appointment of Alan R. Holmes to the position were announced yesterday.
Residents of Plainfield, N.J., will give blood today at the Cedarbrook School, 1049 Central Avenue, to the New York-New Jersey Red Cross Blood Program.

" Crisis in Our Cities," by Lewis Herber, which Prentice-Hall will publish on April 15, deals with air pollution, water contamination and physical and emotional stress. Secretary of the Interior Stewart L. Udall writes in an introduction that the book sets forth "vivid evidence that the most debilitating diseases of our time are a result of our persistent and arrogant abuse of a shared environment."
JAMAICA, a Caribbean island, is a beautiful place to forget the cares of the world. It is also a significant exemplar of our time's racial and economic predicaments.
The trifaith Chapel Plaza at Kennedy International Airport is rapidly assuming form and substance.

It was an evening of thoughtful, sensitive, sometimes genuinely exciting music-making yesterday at the Metropolitan Museum, where the violinist Berl Senofsky and the pianist Lawrence Smith joined in another of the concerts made possible by Ford Foundation grants
WASHINGTON, March 26 -- Douglas Dillon, in his final public speech as the Secretary of the Treasury, urged a further tax reduction today for the nation's low-income families.

" This is an institution of chivalry, humanity, mercy and patriotism; embodying in its genius and its principles all that is chivalric in conduct, noble in sentiment, generous in manhood and patriotic in purpose."

LOWNDESBORO, Ala., March 26 -- The young Negro who shared a car with Mrs. Viola Gregg Liuzzo said today that they had been harassed a number of times yesterday before Mrs. Liuzzo was shot to death from a passing car.
A tragic memory made an 18-year-old Brooklyn youth stay away from a ceremony yesterday at which he was honored for heroism.

Elmer Brown, international president of the Typographical Union, was expected to re-enter today the crucial negotiations between the printers and the publishers of seven of the city's daily newspapers

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, March 27 (AP) -- An American LST (landing ship tank) at a commerical pier at Danang was reavily damaged early today by a huge underwater explosion believed set off by Vietcong saboteur frogmen.

Regarding your editorial "Murder in the Subway" [March 16]. It seems to me that an electrically operated door-locking device, controlled by the motorman and conductor -- that would automatically seal off all exits from the train until the police arrived -- would have done the trick.

YONKERS, March 26 -- A horse with less heart would not have accomplished what Irish Napoleon did at Yonkers Raceway tonight. The game 7-year-old bay, parked out through the entire race, captured the $10,000 invitation handicap pace, beating Toby Star at a mile by three-quarters of a length in 2:03.
WASHINGTON, March 26 -- The House passed the Administration's $1.3 billion school-aid bill tonight after more than eight hours of argument that split Democrats and Republicans into two hostile camps.

LARAMIE, Wyo., March 26 (UPI) -- Yojiro Uetake, an Olympic gold medalist from Japan, and Jim Winer led Oklahoma State to a commanding lead tonight after the semi-finals of the National Collegiate wrestling championships.
A sociologist reported yesterday a rising tide of violence in Harlem caused by an increased use by narcotics addicts of nonopiate drugs.
WASHINGTON, March 26 -- President Johnson pinned medals today on America's Gemini astronauts and on two groundling administrators of the space program.

BONN, March 26 -- Chancellor Ludwig Erhard's coalition Government was threatened with collapse tonight in the wake of the Bundestag's approval of a bill that would extend to 1970 the deadline for new prosecutions of Nazi war criminals.
PARIS, March 26 -- The World Veterans Federation has been nominated for the 1965 Nobel Peace prize, it was announced today here and in Oslo.

The recent commotion at Yale over the forced departure of allegedly good teacher, indifferent scholar Richard Bernstein will perhaps have the salutary effect of drawing long overdue attention to the fact that America's major universities are about the most boring, uncreative, unstimulating places one can find.

BUENOS AIRES, March 26 -- The slender sky-blue silhouette of a modern dancer and other posters announcing recitals, the opening of the film "My Fair Lady," lectures and courses at the university have replaced, virtually overnight, the political propaganda that had plastered the walls of this busy metropolis for two months.

OTTAWA, March 26 -- Gov. Gen. Georges P. Vanier, with a large representation of the diplomatic corps in attendance, opened Canada's first exhibition of Victorian paintings last night in Ottawa's National Gallery of Art.
HALLANDALE, Fla., March 26 (AP) -- Gun Bow will face seven rivals tomorrow in the $111,900 Gulfstream Park Handicap, a stern test for older horses at 1 1/4 miles.

THE single most important old-master show of the week is that of landscapes by Camille Pissarro at Wildenstein's, 19 East 64th Street, in aid of Recording for the Blind. Like his fellow impressionists, Pissarro triumphed through his dazzling ability to transfer to the beholder the painter's actual visual experience.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 26 -- Forty United States Navy planes flew from carriers of the Seventh Fleet today and bombed four radar installations deep in North Vietnam.

The criminal contempt convictions of two young women who refused to say whether they had been told of attempts to start riots here last summer were upheld yesterday by the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court.
Your editorial of March 19 "The Space Race" is a touch of sanity in the discussion of space exploration.
INEXPERIENCED duplicate players not infrequently put 12 or 14 cards back into the duplicate board, thus causing alarm and confusion when the deal is played.
Taxpayers who used family cars last year to make urgent trips to the hospital, for business trips, or for charity can claim their expenses on a cents-per-mile basis.
WANAQUE, N.J., March 26 -- "If 125 working people go past your door, 10 or 15 may come in, and that could mean your margin of profit for the day."
MOSCOW, Saturday, March 27 -- The Soviet Union announced early today a major shuffle in top Government and party posts affecting the management of the national economy.
PARIS, March 26 -- Finance Minister Valery Giscard d'Estaing declared today that France would refuse any foreign capital that would result in foreign ownership of a French company.

MEN'S clothes have long been irresistible to some women. Now a good many ultrafeminine types who have never worn a man's shirt and would not be caught dead in pants, even by Chanel, are going in for masculine accouterments.

Two more men were indicted here yesterday in connection with the horse-meat scandal. They are Samuel Goldman, 44-year-old vice president of Merkel, Inc., and the concern's assistant treasurer, Sheldon Lokietz, 23.

MOSCOW, March 26 -- The Soviet Union delivered a note to the United States Embassy today protesting the use of "poisonous gases" by Americans in South Vietnam. The embassy returned it as "unacceptable."

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- A group of House Republicans is working on a new "triggering" device for a voting-rights bill that would reach areas of discrimination not covered by the Administration's measure.
A 16-year-old youth was arrested yesterday and charged with the rape on Monday of a 75-year-old widow who lives in the same aging Bronx apartment house.

AINTREE, England, March 26 -- The richest Grand National in history, with what promises to be one of the biggest starting line-ups of recent years, gets off tomorrow with a Scottish-trained horse named Freddie favored at 13 to 2.

The Tennessee Gas Transmission Corporation plans to enter the paperboard and packaging field.
KISUMU, Kenya, March 26 -- After three days of tension and sporadic anti-Asian rioting the people of Kisumu were venturing tentatively into sun-washed streets today.
The Governors of four states agreed yesterday to make a 30-day study of the New Haven Railroad's long-haul operation to determine how much financial aid might be needed to retain it.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- The index of wholesale market prices was unchanged at 101.3 of its 1957-59 base during the week ended March 23, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. Prices of farm products and processed foods were up slightly, while industrial commodities averaged unchanged.

PATERSON, N.J., March 26 -- A Paterson lawyer, Leopold Frankel, was cited for contempt today by County Judge Stanley J. Polack for refusing to take assignment as counsel to a defendant in a criminal case.

The naming of Mrs. Dorothy Orr as executive director of Bedford-Stuyvesant Youth in Action, 1273 Fulton Street, Brooklyn, was announced yesterday. The project was set up as a New York City antipoverty project last July and is now making a study to form the basis for proposals to be presented to the City's Antipoverty Operations Board.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., March 26 -- Four sullen Ku Klux Klansmen were arraigned and jailed here today on charges of conspiring to violate the civil rights of the young Detroit white woman shot to death last night on a central Alabama highway.

WILMINGTON, N.C., March 26 -- Dick Hart, who originally had planned to go fishing this week, shot a seven-under-par 65 today and took a two-stroke lead in the $28,750 Azalea open golf tournament with a 135 total.
Stock prices worked down gradually yesterday in relatively light trading as the market broke out of its indecisive trend of the last two weeks.

John Browning took on two Beethoven concertos last night with the Festival Orchestra at Philharmonic Hall, and the young American displayed the kind of honest, brilliant pianism that has kept him busy and popular.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- Standing at the President's right today as he made his dramatic television announcement of the arrest of the four Alabama suspects in the killing of Mrs. Viola Gregg Liuzzo was an authentic American folk hero.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 26 -- The New York Yankees ran up the highest score and the most lopsided margin of victory today in the brief but cataclysmic history of their series with the New York Mets.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- President Johnson named a 14-member advisory committee of prominent educators and business executives to make on-the-ground evaluations of United States foreign aid programs and to recommend steps to improve them.

LOS ANGELES, March 27 -Basketball's new Mr. Chips is the former Hoosier schoolmaster. John Wooden, coach of the repeating national champions from University of California, Los Angeles.

WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP) -- The income tax this year, is causing just a little more trouble than usual.

WILMINGTON, Del. -- For the springtime traveler, this area is the setting for three points of particular beauty and interest. They are the Hagley Museum, Winterthur and Longwood Gardens. Each is different, all are related in some way to the du Pont family, and a visit to the trio makes for a worthwhile weekend.

The Anaconda Company produced a record of 583,998 tons of copper last year, making it the world's largest producer of the metal for the second consecutive year, Clyde E. Weed, chairman, reports. PARIS -- Most Americans who come to Paris shortchange themselves by leaving too soon. VIENNA -- Austrians, who just love anniversaries, are having their full this year. It is the 600th anniversary of the founding of the University of Vienna; the 150th of the Congress of Vienna (1814-15), which remade the map of Europe after the Napoleonic wars; the 20th of Austria's Second Republic, and the 10th of the Austrian State Treaty.

The expanded medicare program approved by the House Ways and Means Committee promises benefits that go far beyond more adequate medical and hospital service for the elderly. IN the backwash of the sale of Rembrandt's "Titus" to an American last week, British art lovers are nattering nervously once again about the country's so-called "art drain." TRAVELERS with a yearning to meet the sun on its way north will find that spring is one of the most pleasant seasons for lounging on Florida beaches or for touching at Mediterranean and Caribbean ports on luxurious cruise ships. THE 25th dog show of the International Kennel Club of Chicago, second largest in the United States the last two years, has a chance of being the largest this year. The entries closed with 2,983 dogs, the closest the fixture ever came to the rarely achieved 3,000-mark.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- President Johnson hailed today the action of the House of Representatives in passing his $1.3 billion Aid-to-Education Bill, calling it "the greatest breakthrough in the advance of education since the Constitution was written."

DETROIT, March 27 -- Gov. George Romney today declared Monday and Tuesday as official days of mourning for Mrs. Viola Liuzzo as a number of dignitaries indicated they would attend the funeral of the slain civil rights worker.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, March 27 -- A 17-member Cabinet formed by the new Prime Minister, Dudley Senanayake, leader of the conservative and pro-Western United National party, was sworn in today.

MANHASSET, L.I., March 27 -- The Queens Club of London led Greentree, 4-3, today after the first day of play in the international court tennis series. Two matches in singles, starting at 9:30 in the morning, and four in doubles are on tomorrow's final program in the court of John Hay (Jock) Whitney.

Sales of department stores last week declined slightly from the corresponding level a year ago, but rose slightly from volume reported in the previous 1965 week.

Cooke, Inc., was thrown into involuntary bankruptcy last week, have come to his rescue. They have formed a new company, Cooke Vacuum Products, Inc., which will open next week in space rented from the Hat Corporation of America.

Sunder can patiently unravel the financial dealings of obscure and not very interesting men engaged in an obscure trade on the northern plains for no other reason than that they were there, part of a social pattern still glimpsed but dimly.

JOHN LeCARRE'S "The Spy Who Came in From the Cold," doubly unforgettable for its quality and for its phenomenal success (possibly the greatest in the history of the suspense novel), is now out in paperback (Dell, 75 cents); and the price, surprisingly high for a book of moderate length, indicates the extent to which the publishing world is convinced that the spy novel is the valuable property of the mid-1960's.

COLUMBIA, S.C., March 27 -- Senator Strom Thurmond of South Carolina, facing his first re-election test as a Republican, is refusing to oppose the re-election of Democratic state officeholders who have conservative records.

EL PASO, Tex. -- With dramatic effectiveness, the massive dome of El Captain, in the Guadalupe Mountains of West Texas, looms over a sweeping, four-lane highway. It can be seen for 75 miles on a clear day, and, out in this arid country, one can rely on clear days almost all of the time.
RIO DE JANEIRO, March 27 -- A baby boy in Brazil's impoverished northeastern states received a rubber nursing pacifier. He was happily sucking away when his brother tried to take it from him.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., March 27 -- Citizens of this North Shore community plan to complete this summer their campaign for funds to build an open-air band shell on the shore of Manhasset Bay in memory of John Philip Sousa.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- Everett McKinley Dirksen of Illinois, the leader of the Senate minority, defined the classic role of the political Opposition as an obligation to support the party in power when it is "right" and oppose it when "wrong." A corollary of the formula is that the Opposition should always seek first by thorough inspection to eliminate what it considers "wrong" in an otherwise constructive piece of legislation.

WASHINGTON, March 28 (AP) -- Domestic sugar industry leaders announced today an agreement on recommendations to Congress on revision of the United States Sugar Act. PARIS -- Washington's policy of bombing North Vietnam while avoiding negotiations is sowing confusion among America's friends. To cross East Asia, India and the Soviet Union to this NATO capital in Europe is to hear repeated questioning of the purposes and tactics of American policy.

The battle for court reform is never finally won. Three years ago the first major reorganization of New York State's judicial system in more than a century was achieved through adoption of a constitutional amendment. The change has brought about tremendous gains in the administration of justice in this state, but there is still room for improvement. And there is also need for constant vigilance against political tampering with the gains already won.

WHITEHORSE, Yukon Territory, March 26 -- Robert Service, the Klondike poet, called this territory of the big snow, ice mountains and glacier-touched valleys the "cussedest land." Warmth, however, has come early to the capital of the Yukon Territory this year, and the bush pilots flying out daily to the mining camps attest to the approach of spring.
RIO DE JANEIRO, March 28 -- The leader of a leftist Brazilian guerrilla group was reported captured by army forces today after a sharp gunfight.

The New York City League of Women Voters served notice yesterday that it will fight to get the necessary funds in the city's 1965-66 budget to give the City Council the expert assistance it needs to become an independent, effective legislative body.

Three restaurants will be built in the new Metropolitan Opera House at Lincoln Center by the Automatic Canteen Company of America. The Chicago concern has been granted a 10-year contract covering all restaurant facilities in the house, which is scheduled to open for the 1966-67 season.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- The political demand for voting rights legislation is so resounding that there is no doubt that Congress will respond to it. But enough questions have been raised about President Johnson's draft bill to cause House Republicans to break the bipartisan front and begin work on their own bill.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 28 -- Far more interesting than today's 6 -- 2 victory by the New York Mets over the Milwaukee Braves was the postgame announcement that the Mets had re-acquired Frank Lary from the Braves.

HAVANA, March 28 -- Attendance at Roman Catholic churches in Cuba has increased 15 per cent since liturgical reform became effective March 7, the island's religious hierarchy has reported to the Vatican.
