BOSTON, March 28 -- The oldest American choral group still giving concerts is here, the Handel and Haydn Society of Boston. Last Wednesday it was 150 years old. It celebrated that venerable birthday tonight in Symphony Hall by giving the premiere of a work it had commissioned for the occasion, Randall Thompson's "The Gospel According to St. Luke."

The New York Rangers left a rink strewn with beer cans, oranges and paper bags as they dropped their final contest of the National Hockey League season to the Montreal Canadiens, 5-3, before 13,413 fans at Madison Square Garden last night.

SELMA, Ala., March 28 -- A Protestant congregation was racially desegregated for the first time in modern history here today. St. Paul's Episcopal Church, one of the city's oldest and most respected churches, seated four Negroes at its morning worship service.

A ship takes on a load of cars at Hamburg, carries them through the Panama Canal, and then drops them off in Los Angeles and Vancouver. On her way home, the ship picks up a cargo of borax in Los Angeles for delivery to Western Europe.

LONDON, March 28 -- Prime Minister Harold Wilson announced tonight that Patrick Gordon Walker, his former Foreign Secretary, would visit Southeast Asia during the next month for a survey as a special representative of the British Government.

WHITE PLAINS, March 28 -- Mrs. O.D. Appleton's Malacca, a 6-year-old black gelding, won the working hunter under-saddle championship at the Secor Farms horse show today while his chief rival munched oats in a stable.

New Yorkers were urged yesterday to start a "concerted war" on the "wave of crime that threatens to destroy us all." The Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell, preaching at the Brick Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue at 91st Street, said:

A national boycott of Alabama, including a refusal to buy its products and a withdrawal of Federal support for activities in the state, was called for last night by the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.
ISTANBUL, Turkey -- Tobacco, this nation's most important cash crop, is selling briskly and bringing in badly needed foreign exchange.

The New York Stock Exchange outlined its own program yesterday to help balance the nation's overseas payments in pledging support for President Johnson's voluntary plan to curtail the flow of capital abroad.

Violin playing fit for a king was heard from Nathan Milstein at his recital Saturday night at Hunter College. He interwove baroque, classic and romantic compositions into a refreshing program that delighted the ear and sometimes staggered the imagination.
A Queens private school, established as a defiant response to the city's pairing of two public schools, reports it has received a charter from the State Department of Education.
Mayor Wagner called on newspaper unions and publishers yesterday to intensify efforts to reach an agreement before midnight tomorrow night, when contracts run out.
Greenwich Village leaders urged Mayor Wagner yesterday to take "immediate action" to clean up the area after a free-for-all at a popular coffeehouse.

VIENNA, March 26 -- Six weeks from now Austria will mark the 10th anniversary of the State Treaty that freed her from military occupation in 1955. She is still trying to figure out where to fit into Europe.

The Public Education Association, as a long-time advocate of substantial Federal aid for the public schools, strongly supports the Johnson Administration's proposals for Federal public school assistance,

Gilbert Eisner of the New York Athletic Club, a former national champion, easily won the Metropolitan qualifying tournament for the national epee championships yesterday at the New York Athletic Club.
THE following dinner menu is given as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A recipe is offered for an easy-to-prepare main dish.
MANHASSET, L.I., March 28 -- Greentree defeated Queens Club of London today in their international court tennis match.

Lane Bryant, Inc., which operates a nationwide chain of more than 100 stores, rang up record sales and earnings in the fiscal year ended Jan. 31, the company's annual report disclosed over the weekend.

VERO BEACH, Fla., March 28 -- There are some Dodger partisans here who insist that Willie Davis is not only the fastest now, but that he also is the fastest ever in the majors. They also are convinced that his blazing speed would have led him to Olympic championships as a sprinter, or broad jumper or both, had he not detoured to baseball instead.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, March 28 -- The voters of Leopoldville massed at polling stations from sunrise to sundown today without getting a chance to vote.
EDMONTON, Alberta -- The single-engine DeHavilland Otter dipped low over the oil patch, and A.L. "Labby" LaBerge pointed off to the right of the airplane.
CANTHO, South Vietnam, March 28 -- The question being asked most frequently in this area today is, What has happened to the war in the Mekong delta?
The voting rights bill now before Congress has come under heavy attack from its opponents on constitutional grounds.

Maritime management and labor joined in protest yesterday against recent testimony by Agriculture Department officials who blamed the Cargo Preference Act for the loss of surplus United States grain sales to Communist nations. The act reserves half of all aid cargoes for American vessels.

AMES, Iowa, March 28 -- Southern California won its third straight National Collegiate swimming championship under the new rules last night and it would have won under the old. Even so, a harsh argument raged among the coaches today on what the meet is all about.

ATHENS, March 28 -- An authoritative Greek source asserted today that "most of the Soviet missiles are now in Cyprus with only a few remaining abroad." By "abroad" he apparently meant the United Arab Republic, where the missiles are known to have been stockpiled.
THURMONT, Md., March 28 (AP) -- President Johnson relaxed today in the seclusion of Camp David.

IT should come as no surprise to those who know, or know about, Dr. Conor Cruise O'Brien that he is leaving his post as vice chancellor of the University' of Ghana because he disagrees with Accra's policy on the university.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 28 -- A group of 100 Alabama residents called Concerned White Citizens has attracted about 200 more interested persons since it marched in Selma three weeks ago to support the Negro drive there.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 28 -- Twelve destroyers and minesweepers from the United States Seventh Fleet are known to have begun patrolling the entire South Vietnamese coast to prevent North Vietnamese supply boats from reaching the Vietcong.
The competition among four international investment banking syndicates to handle the financing of an oil pipeline from the Adriatic Sea to southern Germany apparently has been settled.
MELBOURNE, Australia, March 28 (AP) -- The Olympic Games report that resulted in the expulsion of four girls, including Dawn Fraser, from swimming was made public today in censored form.

LOS ANGELES, March 28 -- The $11.5 million Los Angeles County Museum of Art will open officially Wednesday amid a numbing succession of banquets, receptions and other rituals of civic self-congratulation.
WASHINGTON, March 28 -- Maxwell D. Taylor, United States Ambassador to South Vietnam, arrived today for a week of consultations to determine future steps in the Southeast Asian war.

The nation's proved recoverable reserves of crude oil and natural gas liquids at the close of 1964 totaled 38,737 million barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute and the American Gas Association.

An economist who has spent most of his working life developing a system to analyze relationships between sectors of American industry is having a field day now with data collected in the 1963 Census of Manufactures.

BOGOTA, Colombia, March 28 -- One night last week a businessman and his wife drove to a friend's house in their small European car. When they got out the friend was startled to see two large, beefy, men climb with some difficulty from the back seat.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- Ch. Pandora of Stormhill, owned, bred and handled by Virginia R. Withington of Pasadena, Calif., was named best of breed today among 89 Afghan hounds at the D.C. Armory. The judge was C.K. Rickel in the Potomac Afghan Hound Club event.
To serve without dominating those who are helped is the hardest and most crucial lesson American women have to learn, an author and editor said yesterday.

It is always a grievous occurrence when an organ of public opinion which commands as much respect as The New York Times forgets the basic concepts of American liberty in its zeal to rid society of a particular menace.

WANTAGH, L.I., March 28 -- Thirteen-year-old Frank Louis, busying himself cleaning out cat cages, turned to 12-year-old Mitchell Maushay here yesterday in the Wantagh Aquarium on Park Avenue and said:
MODERN dance works choreographed by Marion Scott and Marie Marchowsky were seen in programs given at Kaufmann Concert Hall on the weekend.
" VERY little asparagus is available in New York before April. Early season prices are high because of the cost of shipping from California."
MARLINTON, W.Va. -- The old man in the tarpaper shack growled, "I wish the Government would leave us alone. We're doing fine around here."

LOS ANGELES, March 28 -- The most impressive thing about the new Los Angeles County Museum of Art may be that it exists at all. Interest in art in Los Angeles is a postwar phenomenon that gathered real momentum only about 10 years ago.
The 1965 Guggenheim Awards for 1965 were announced yesterday. A total of 313 scholars, scientists and artists will receive $2,115,700 in grants.

Melissa Hayden and Edward Villella, two of the most popular dancers of the New York City Ballet, performed three pas de deux at Hunter College Assembly Hall last night in a program they shared with Sabicas, the flamenco guitarist.
SAO PAULO, Brazil, March 26 -- A blue slip was waiting for Guilherme Leite da Silva today when he got to the factory after a month's vacation.

WASHINGTON, March 28 (AP) -- Secretary of the Treasury Douglas Dillon has asked Congress to add nearly $4 million to President Johnson's budget recommendation for the Secret Service so that more protection can be provided for the President.

When all is quiet in the Friends Meeting House at 144 East 20th Street, at the corner of Gramercy Park, its clock's ticking can be heard through much of the 105-year-old building -- in the plain Quaker pews and on the long, curving stairways.
Frederick Miller, cellist, and Jerrold Cox, pianist, members of the faculty of Syracuse University, made their debut as a performing duo here yesterday at Carnegie Recital Hall.
The Port Authority announced yesterday that it had acquired by direct purchase its first property for the proposed $350 million World Trade Center.
New Yorkers will give their traditional heroes' welcome today to the Gemini spacemen, Maj. Virgil I. Grissom and Lieut Cmdr. John W. Young.

Directors of the May Department Stores Company and of the Meier Frank Company, Inc., of Portland, Ore., will vote today on terms of a merger. The May board will meet in St. Louis, while the Meier Frank directors will meet in Portland.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., March 28 -- An attractive young housewife here has come up with the perfect stopper for salesmen who use the telephone to try to peddle everything from magazine subscriptions to roofing.
DRAPING a room in Brunsehwig prints is like dressing a woman in Balenciagas -- both carry the same cachet of elegance and expensive French taste.
A new independent steamship company whose rates will offer a $10 million annual saving in transportation costs for the Department of Defense will begin operations this week.
Mayor Wagner criticized the Board of Education yesterday for having "no clear policy" designed to provide an adequate number of "athletic fields for our high school physicial training programs."
LOS ANGELES, March 28 -- Secretary of Labor W. Willard Wirtz has proclaimed the advent of a new era in a major segment of American agriculture.

The three-man panel appointed by Mayor Wagner to investigate the city's taxicab labor dispute will meet at noon today with representatives of fleet owners and the city's central labor council, Theodore W. Kheel, head of the panel, announced yesterday.
TAMPA, Fla., March 28 -- For the second straight day, the New York Yankees lost a game in the first inning today, when the Cincinnati Reds scored three runs and went on to win, 4-2.

CINCINNATI, March 28 (AP) -- The Philadelphia 76ers defeated the Cincinnati Royals, 108-94, today and took a 2-1 lead in the three-of-five National Basketball Association Eastern Division semi-finals.
Teams of detectives ranged through the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn yesterday, looking for clues to the murder of three men in a meat market.

The Eltra Corporation has withdrawn its offer for the common stock of the Mueller Brass Company and Eltra is advising Mueller shareholders of an offer by the United States Smelting, Refining and Mining Company, according to a weekend announcement.
BOSTON, March 28 (UPI) -- The Boston Bruins wound up the National Hockey League son with a 3-1 victory over the Chicago Black Hawks tonight.
ATLANTIC CITY, March 28 (AP) -- Negotiations reached agreement on a new three-year contract tonight that will end the 11-day-old industry-wide strike against glass container plants.
AUGUSTA, Ga., March 28 (UPI) -- Two of the nation's top Ku Klux Klan leaders asked today for an immediate meeting with President Johnson to discuss an imminent Federal clampdown on Klan activities.
LONDON, March 28 -- The Liberals, Britain's third party, are becoming a real annoyance to the Conservatives.
MOSCOW, March 28 -- Chinese Communist obstruction was reported today to be delaying Soviet arms shipments to North Vietnam.

TUNIS, March 28 -- The Tunisian press charged today that a malicious, dishonest and mendacious" campaign against the Government was being waged by the United Arab Republic. It said Cairo was retaliating with demagogy" because President Habib Bourguiba had spoken favorably of West Germany's position in its dispute with the United Arab Republic.

A bill seeking to eliminate pollutants from the exhausts of automobiles and gasoline-burning trucks will be offered in the Legislature this week, State Senator Frederic S. Berman, Democrat, of Manhattan's 20th District, said yesterday.

VIENTIANE, Laos, March 28 -- Troops proclaiming loyalty to General Phoumi Nosavan, a former Deputy Premier of Laos, who fled to Thailand in February, revolted and took over the Mekong River town of Thakhek this morning, according to informed Western sources.

HILLSDALE, N.J., March 28 -- Jose Torres's training camp possesses many of the sights and sounds of a noisy tenement: Babies are crying, Puerto Rican women are running around, music is blaring, beds are unmade, big cars are pulling up outside all day with men yelling up, "Hey, where's Torres ?"

At this uneasy moment in world history, Soviet leaders have provided a welcome sign that internal economic improvement, rather than foreign military adventure, is at the center of their present concern. They have adopted a massive program for improving Soviet agriculture -- one that contemplates many billions of dollars in additional farm investment, as well as major price increases intended to raise production incentives for Soviet farmers.

BERLIN, March 28 -- East German intellectuals seeking to free their country's cultural life from the remnants of Stalinist rigidity have found unexpected but influential allies in some of their colleagues from the Eastern bloc.

The "public image" appears to be changing for the better on the waterfront. The type of men whose illicit activities earned them such names as Shakedown Charlie, Baseball-Bat Eddie, Icepick Frank and Nick the Bull no longer dominate the piers.
A coordinating body of 24 national Jewish groups charged yesterday that an article in a prominent Soviet newspaper reviles Judaism as an enemy of the Soviet people.

WILMINGTON, N.C., March 28 -- Over the longest extra-hole route of the current tour, Richard Byrd Hart won the Azalea open today. The slim, 32-year-old professional from Hinsdale, Ill., defeated Phil Rodgers with a par 3 at the eighth hole of the playoff.

" The Slaves We Rent," by Truman E. Moore, a survey of conditions among migrant workers, will be published by Random House on May 19. The author, who was born on a small farm in Georgia, is a writer and photographer who has traveled .with migrants to get their stories.
Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., reported yesterday a gain of 5.4 per cent in revenues for 1964.
The Chase Manhattan Bank and three upstate banks reluctantly decided yesterday to shelve their plan to form a bank holding company.

The Koppers Company plans to spend about $30 million on capital expenditures this year, double the figure of 1964, Fred C. Foy, chairman, told stockholders at the annual meeting in Pittsburgh yesterday.

THE New York Philharmonic took no chances last night. Its management disavowed responsibility for the progran. In place of the normal entries was a big, black question mark. This was understandable under the circumstances. How can genius be held down to the exigencies of a printed program?

HOUSTON, March 29 (UPI) -- The Federal space agency plans to send two astronauts, Capt. James A. McDivitt and Capt. Edward H. White, on a four-day flight into space in June -- about one month ahead of schedule.
GIBRALTAR -- The economic impact of Madrid's six-month campaign against Gibraltar has already been radically felt here and in the adjoining areas of Spain.
HALLANDALE, Fla., March 29 (AP) -- Walnut Hill Farm's Blinking Star, who had not won in 16 months, defeated the heavily favored Bud Wallace today at Gulfstream Park by 3 1/2 lengths.
MOSCOW, March 29 -- A new educational television channel began operations here today.
RABAT, Morocco, March 29 -- King Hassan II called tonight for national unity and strongly warned against a repetition of last week's bloody street riots in Casablanca.

AUCKLAND, New Zealand, March 29 -- The 21st session of the United Nations Economic Commission for Asia and the Far East closed in Wellington today after two weeks of meetings acclaimed by most delegates as an outstanding success.

WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP) -- The Pentagon was charged today with using press-agent tactics "as old as Barnum" to divert the public's attention from its plan to merge Army Reserve units into the National Guard.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- The gist of the rulings by the Supreme Court today in a set of labor relations cases is that neither employers nor employes may legally employ tactics designed to "divide and conquer." The Court's decisions matched the conception of justice in the Old Roman statue as blind to partiality and therefore dispensing the law with an even hand.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., March 29 (AP) -- Bud McKinney of Dallas, the medalist, lost four of the first five holes today, but rallied to win his second-round match in the Ponce de Leon senior golf tournament.

Seven high school scholar-athletes were honored at the annual awards luncheon of the Metropolitan Chapter of the National Football Foundation and Hall of Fame yesterday. They heard Archie Roberts of Columbia advocate that they get a solid education as well as play football in college.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -Important Johnson Administration sources responded coolly today to a proposal by the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. for an economic boycott of Alabama and a withdrawal of Federal funds and support from the state.

" La Grosse Valise," a musical hit in Paris, will be presented in November at the Royale Theater by Joseph Kipness, producer of "I had a Ball," starring Buddy Hackett. Robert Dhery wrote the libretto of "La Grosse Valise," adapted into English by Joseph Fields.
GREENVALE, L.I., March 29 -- The Long Island Festival will produce three operas and two ballet performances with Metropolitan Opera personnel next summer.
AT this time of year it would be pleasant to have direct two-way communication with an income-tax collection bureau -- an answer to a letter, to be precise.
WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP) -- The Johnson Administration's proposal for rent supplement payments to help lower income families obtain housing ran into a crossfire of Senatorial criticism today.

DUSSELDORF, Germany, March 29 -- Chancellor Ludwig Erhard's dissension-racked Christian Democratic Union met in pre-election convention today determined to establish the appearance of a united and purposeful party.

The Players, the club of theater people and enthusiasts of the arts at 16 Gramercy Park, plans to add a wing to the library housing its collection of rare books and play records. The annex will be named for Patrick Carroll, self-schooled librarian who died on March 16 after 32 years service to the club.
The freshman class presidents of the Ivy League colleges have joined in a new council to study the problems and pressures facing first-year students in these highly selective and competitive schools.
GALASHIELS, Scotland -- On the outside the building is just another drab gray Victorian factory. But the visitor who opens the door finds himself in another century and another state of mind.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- Justices of the Supreme Court questioned the opposing lawyers in the Connecticut birth-control case today about the widely known fact that contraceptives are sold "under the counter" in that state.
GEORGETOWN, British Guiana, March 29 -- Gov. Sir Richard Luyt opened today British Guiana's first 53-member Parliament elected under proportional representation.
The landlord of nine apartment buildings on Central Park West was fined $1,080 in Criminal Court yesterday for almost 500 violations of the Multiple Dwelling Law.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., March 29 (AP) -- Construction work at Cape Kennedy and the adjacent Merritt Island moonport was paralyzed today when an Orlando union local that does not work here set up picket lines to protest a contractor's use of nonunion labor.

BERLIN, March 29 -- A high-school student raised his voice to find attention. "I don't feel guilty for what happened under Hitler," he said. "I was not even born then, and anyway there is no such thing as collective guilt."

Whitney M. Young Jr., executive director of the National Urban League, and Senator Jacob K. Javits challenged yesterday the wisdom of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s appeal for an economic boycott of Alabama.

ROME, March 29 -- Pope Paul VI has urged his commission of priests, scientists and laymen to recommend soon a Roman Catholic policy on birth control in response to "the anguish of so many souls" on the issue.
Detectives investigating the murder of three butchers Saturday night in a meat market in the Bedford-Stuyveant section of Brooklyn determined yesterday that at least $2,000 was stolen by the slayers.
Declines outpaced andvances by a good margin yesterday on the American Stock Exchange for the second consecutive trading day as volume slackened.

Price increases for sulphur ranging from $2 to $4 were announced yesterday by the Texas Gulf Sulphur Company. The price rises will become effective April 1 for spot sales, and Oct. 1 for most contract customers and will apply to sales in the United States and Canada.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 29 -- King Faisal of Saudi Arabia named his brother Khaled, the Deputy Premier, as Crown Prince tonight.
LONDON, March 29 -- Doubts about Britain's economic future continued to hang heavy over the pound today in the foreign exchange market.
A slight runoff to the reservoirs over the weekend brought city water storage to 187.8 billion gallons, or 39.4 per cent of capacity, by 8 A.M. yesterday.
A national academy to improve education has been formed by 27 distinguished scholars.
DETROIT, March 29 (AP) -- Auto production lines rolled in high gear today as the United States auto industry prepared to write a new page in its record book -- its first 900,000-car month.
One long newspaper strike ended yesterday. But other lengthy walkouts continued against seven daily papers in the United States and Canada.
LINCOLN, Neb., March 29 (UPI) -- The Nebraska Legislature, under orders from a Federal court, reapportioned itself today on a population-only basis. The vote was 40 to 5.
CHICAGO, March 29 (AP) -- An advertising specialist told bankers today that they lose business when they make potential borrowers nervous.

CLEARWATER, Fla., March 29 -- Organized baseball set in motion today machinery for choosing a successor to Commissioner Ford C. Frick and came to grips with some of the conflict-of-interest issues raised by the Columbia Broadcasting System's purchase of the New York Yankees.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, March 29 -- Government forces occupied the town of Watsa today, the last important rebel stronghold in the northeastern Congo.
The program given by Richard Goode, pianist, and Robert Martin, cellist, at Carnegie Recital Hall last night promised on paper to be somewhat out of the ordinary.
NICOSLA, Cyprus, March 29 -- Archbishop Makarios, President of Cyprus, said today that some soviet-manufactured anti-aircraft missile equipment was on the island.

ALBANY, March 29 -- Special legislation will have to be passed to meet the State April 9 payroll if the budget is not passed by Thursday. The State Constitution requires a message of necessity from the Governor for the passage of interim legislation.
ALBANY, March 29 -- It appeared all but certain tonight that the state would begin its new fiscal year at 12:01 A.M. Thursday without a budget.
The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday the purchase of about 100,000 square feet of land on the east side of lower Broad Street as a site for its new home.
The merger of two major New York towboat companies -- McAllister Brothers, Inc., and Dalzell Towing Company -- is scheduled today.

There were some sad people among the 26,010 horse players at Aqueduct yesterday, because the law of diminishing returns says that there had to be. But a young non-horse-player, Mike Venezia, was a sadder figure than most of the dedicated losers on the cold, clammy, drizzly day.

Abraham Straus which is observing its 100th anniversary this year, announced yesterday the promotion of three employees as new operating vice presidents. They are Morgan W. Ayres, William L. Bohan and John D. Staley.
MOSCOW, March 29 (AP) -Lieut. Col. Alexei Leonov had to pass through two doors for his historic walk in space, Pravda said today.
HONG KONG, March 29 -- Children in Communist China are being told that they must stop discriminating against schoolmates who are sons and daughters of former landlords or rich peasants.
WASHINGTON, March 29 -President Johnson's attack on the Ku Klux Klan will probably take the form of strengthened penalties against those convicted of violating the civil rights of any person.
LONDON, March 29 -- The Alvin Ailey American dance theater, now on the first leg of its second European tour, gave a new program at the Saville Theater here tonight.
NEW ORLEANS, March 29 -- Further complications in the complex question of what causes cancer were suggested here today at a seminar on cancer research.

A three-man panel appointed by Mayor Wagner to investigate the taxicab labor dispute held a two-hour fact-finding meeting yesterday with represenatives of taxicab fleet owners and the Taxi Drivers Organizing Committee.

The first impression created by the Justice Department's trust busters immediately after they won the trial round of their suit against the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company was that they would press vigorously for splitting up the bank into its pre-merger components -- or something resembling them, since three and a half years have passed.

WASHINGTON, Tuesday, March 30 -- President Johnson, Secretary of State Dean Rusk and Maxwell D. Taylor, United States Ambassador to South Vietnam, were informed of the explosion at Saigon last night while they were attending a White House dinner for President Maurice Yameogo of Upper Volta.

APPARENTLY the Spaniards have a particularly loathful attitude toward their public executioners, who kill by the garrote, a gruesome way of strangling that requires a personal touch. And that is the basis of the story and the gist of the bleakly ghoulish joke that runs through the Spanish film "El Verdugo," called here "Not on Your Life."
The April and May contracts for Maine potato futures showed declines of 4 to 12 cents a hundredweight yesterday in active trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
The dedication yesterday of New York University's newest building, the largest mathematics research and teaching center in the world, was more like a family gathering than a formal ceremony.
CLEVELAND, March 29 (UPI) -- The Citizens Council of Ohio hopes to start a nationwide campaign to nullify the Civil Rights Act of 1964, its president told the City Club Citizens Rostrum today.
The most successful segment of the American merchant marine offered a solution yesterday for the problems of the industry's least successful segment.
American tourists this year are expected to travel abroad in record numbers despite Administration appeals that they see America first and in doing so keep American dollars at home.

A. Edward Morrison, who was described as a stockholder in the Columbia Broadcasting System, yesterday filed suit in Supreme Court here charging that the former president of CBS-TV, James T. Aubrey Jr., derived personal financial advantages by sharing profits from a production company that provided television shows to CBS.

Irving Rivkin, Staten Island member of the city's Tax Commission, disclosed yesterday that he had formally asked to look over offers of reductions of tentative assessed valuations on real estate made by Commissioners in the other boroughs.
SANTIAGO, Chile, March 29 -- A new series of tremors increased fear in central Chile today in the wake of one of the worst earthquakes to strike the country in half a century.

YONKERS, March 29 -- A strike by members of Local 32E of the Building Service Employes International Union, representing about 700 mutuel clerks, against Yonkers Raceway will close down the Westchester County harness racing track tomorrow.
LONDON, March 29 -- The Board of Trade said today that a decision on whether Rembrandt's "Titus" could be exported to the United States would be taken "as soon as possible."

A young Negro lawyer has organized what is believed to be the only "interracial" life insurance company in the country. The company, Intra-American Life Corporation, was formed by Clarence B Jones, the 34-year-old lawyer for such prominent Negroes as Dr. Martin Luther King, James Baldwin and Jesse Gray.

Your caption "Teachers Union Backs School Aid Bill" above the letter published March 19 from President Charles Cogen of the American Federation of Teachers is misleading. As President Cogen points out, A.F.T. members are now being polled on whether or not they will support the Johnson program.

The American Stock Exchange has moved quickly through a period of reorganization and is now developing a wider range of programs benefiting the public and member brokerage houses, Edwin D. Etherington, president, said yesterday.

Production in New York of network evening television shows will be at its lowest next fall. Of 96 entertainment shows on the three national networks, only 10 -- mostly music, game and variety programs -- are now scheduled to be produced here.
Several physicians set out yesterday to reduce drastically the usually costly psychiatric services for the city's Spanish-speaking community.
The British pound gained sharply in active trading in foreign exchange markets here yesterday.
Approval of the New York Central-Pennsylvania merger does away with out-of-date regulatory concepts that have plagued the railroad industry.
PARIS, March 29 -- President de Gaulle has castigated French scientists who "betray" their language by not speaking it at international scientific meetings.
ROME, March 29 -- France in effect vetoed today an Italian proposal for a meeting of Common Market foreign ministers this spring to discuss European political unity.

THE woman concerned about maneuvering gracefully in and out of taxicabs -- or airplanes -- in skirts that stop before they hit the knees can find peace of mind this summer. Culottes, which have been stepping in and out of fashion for many seasons, are set for another whirl.
Prices on the London Stock Exchange rose moderately yesterday mainly because of an absence of selling.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- The Federal Power Commission will hold a hearing on May 4 to decide a route for transmission lines from the Consolidated Edison Company's controversial Cornwall pumped-storage hydroelectric plant on the Hudson River.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, March 30 -- A huge bomb exploded at the United States Embassy today, causing scores of casualties.
A New Jersey druggist and his wife were indicted by a Federal grand jury here yesterday on charges of evading more than $150,000 in income taxes between 1958 and 1961.

WASHINGTON. March 29 -- Two Interstate Commerce Commission examiners recommended today that the New York Central and Pennsylvania Railroads are required to take over the freight service of the bankrupt New Haven, but not its passenger service, once they have merged.

Danny Kaye, who does not read a note of music, conducted the New York Philharmonic before an audience composed not of Philharmonic regulars (although there were some board members in the crowd), but of United Nations diplomats, political leader, stage stars, aristocrats and other fun-loving New Yorkers.
The city's publishers and printers reported some progress last night in their efforts to reach an agreement that would avert a strike threatened for 2 A.M. tomorrow.
DALLAS, March 29 -- H.L. Hunt, the right-wing Texas oil millionaire, said today that his Life Line Foundation had lost its tax-exempt status.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- Maxwell D. Taylor, United States Ambassador to South Vietnam, met with the Secretaries of State and Defense today to discuss the results of seven weeks of aerial warfare against North Vietnam.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 29 -- Almost 50,000 soldiers of Iraq's 65,000-man army have been massed in northern Iraq for an assault against the Kurds, a diplomatic informant said today.

When Henry P. Kidder, Francis H. Peabody and Oliver W. Peabody established their co-partnership in Boston on April 1, 1865, the articles of agreement said the venture would be "continuous for the term of five years from this date."
DETROIT, March 29 -- A white Protestant Episcopal priest called tonight for the resignation of the Episcopal Bishop of Alabama in a bitter attack on the church leader's stand on civil rights.

WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP) -- The supreme Court affirmed today an Interstate Commerce Commission order that 10 railroads must cease rate discrimination against grain arriving, at rail shipping points on the Mississippi River by barge transportation.

HERBERT LIEBERMAN'S first play to be produced in New York commands respect. "Matty and the Moron and Madonna," which opened last night at the Orpheum Theater, makes itself at home on the stage with impressive boldness and freedom.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -The Supreme Court held today that an employer could close down his business entirely to avoid dealing with a union, but not partly if the intent and effect is to discourage unionism at his other plants.

LONDON, March 29 (Reuters) -- A barbed, satirical British television show, which this weekend drew angry protests, will not reappear in its present form after its scheduled run ends on April 11, it was stated officially tonight.
GREAT NECK, L.I. -- Eight months ago, Inger, a pretty, brown-haired 24-year-old, left her home in Copenhagen for a job as a sleep-in domestic here. She was brimming with hope and excitement.
WASHINGTON, March 29 (UPI) --Attorney General Nicholas deB. Katzenbach proposed to Congress today that selected Federal prisoners be allowed to take outside jobs before their sentences are up.
WASHINGTON, March 29 -- The Treasury bill rate showed practically no change at this week's auction from last week's level, the Treasury disclosed tonight.

The bearded lady bowed out, but the North American Philips Company, Inc., had no trouble in encouraging a clown to carry a large model of its Norelco Speedshaver around the ring in the promenade of clowns. The circus with which Norelco has tied in its campaign is the Ringling Bros. Barnum Bailey Circus, which comes to Madison Square Garden Thursday night.

BRIDGE books not in the English language do not normally rate a review in this column, but an exception must be made in favor of a new book from France that will rank among the great bridge writings of all time.

COCOA, Fla., March 29 -- The Houston club, by any other name, remains a tartar for the Mets. As the Colts they maintained a 35-17 won-lost supremacy over their New York expansionist brothers the last three years.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 29 (AP) -- An economic boycott of Alabama products as proposed by the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. would boomerang and hurt all Negroes, Lieut. Gov. James Allen said today.

ACCORDING to a poll taken for the makers of Metrecal, 79 million Americans were overweight in 1964, 52 million were at least conscious of the fact, and about 9 million were trying to reduce. The other 27 million fatties either did not know anything was the matter with them, or didn't care.
Draper Daniels of Compton Advertising, Inc., struck out yesterday at magazines that "are being edited and published for advertisers rather than for readers."

TRENTON, N.J., March 29 (AP) -- The New Jersey Supreme Court scolded life insurance companies today for writing policies in obscure language and allowing agents to exaggerate the coverage provided by the companies.
Treasury bond prices declined early yesterday and then recovered partially

A BABY-FACED blonde who could pass for Lolita's kid sister nibbled on breakfast yesterday morning at Bonwit Teller, puckered her lips as she greeted fashion people who came to meet her, and inspected the clothes she will present to the public this afternoon on the store's eighth floor -- all based on the styles she herself wears.
Two reliefs by the Italian sculptor Giacomo Manzu will be installed at Rockefeller Center early in May, the center announced yesterday.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., March 29 (AP) -- An unmanned Air Force jet flew over western Missouri for more than an hour today after its pilot jumped from the craft.
Two hundred Brooklyn College students walked out yesterday in the middle of a lecture by President Harry D. Gideonse on "Berkeley -- Its Educational and Moral Meaning."
VIENTIANE, Laos, March 29 -- The Laotian Army High Command has given an ultimatum to rebels holding Thakhek to surrender within 48 hours, General Ouane Rathikone, the chief of staff, said today.
The number of public schools that are predominantly Negro and Puerto Rican has risen sharply in the last four years, the Central Zoning Unit of the city School system reported yesterday.

Rosina Lhevinne was given an 85th birthday tribute by her colleagues, students and friends yesterday afternoon at the Juilliard School of Music. She was also given a tape recorder, the first she has ever owned.
TRENTON, March 29 -- Jersey City and 21 of its residents sued in State Superior Court today to halt further reconstruction and widening of John F. Kennedy Boulevard.

A one-time 85-pound weakling, a middleweight who grew larger, a semi-retired milliner and a refugee from Oriente Province in Cuba will all fight at Madison Square Garden tonight. At stake are two championships and a piece of boxing's so-called boom.
NEW YORK'S last antiques fair of the season is winding up the series in better than usual style at the 71st Infantry Armory, Park Avenue and 34th Street.

LONDON, March 29 -- Patrick Gordon Walker, the former Labor Foreign Secretary, was chosen tonight to stand for Parliament again in Legton, the constituency where he suffered a dramatic defeat in January.

Wall Street observers greeted yesterday's favorable recommendation by two examiners of the Interstate Commerce Commission for the merger of the Pennsylvania and New York Central railroads with warm if not wild enthusiasm.
A program to curb the sale of pornographic material has been drawn up by Mayor Wagner's Citizens Anti-Pornography Commission, it was learned last night.

According to a news story which appeared in your issue of March 24, Senator Thomas J. Dodd has described me as "one of the most eloquent spokesmen for the school of thought which holds that only our own prejudices and suspicions prevent conciliation with the Soviet Union."

CARMARTHEN, Wales, March 29 (UPI) -- Howard Winstone of Wales, the British and European featherweight champion, used a left jab with piston-like precision tonight to score a 10-round decision over Don Johnson of Los Angeles.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., March 29 -- A new recording facility, described as one of the finest in the world, was added today to Nashville's rapidly expanding music industry.
The Baptist Ministers Conference of Greater New York urged Governor Rockefeller yesterday to support Dr. King's proposal for a national boycott of Alabama products.
HORNELL, N.Y., March 29 -- Senator Robert F. Kennedy today visited the Southern Tier counties and chided community leaders for lagging in the anti-poverty drive.
BONN, March 29 -- Erich Helbig, who served for eight years as an aide to former Chancellor Konrad Adenauer, went on trial today charged with spying for a Communist country.
The election of Robert T. Browning and Stewart G. Stalnecker as directors of the Colonial Life Insurance Company of America was announced yesterday.
ALBANY, March 29 -- The State Board of Regents denied today that it had accredited a New York City private school established by parents opposed to the city's school integration plan.

WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP) -- The Supreme Court refused today to consider a case raising the question whethert the President, when on a trip abroad, may order the postponement until his return of presentation to him of bills passed by Congress.
A meat-processing plant now being set up in Jersey City is headed by the former assistant secretary of Merkel, Inc. the Queens processors that closed after a horse-meat scandal.

Frances Steloff, who knew little about literature when she opened the Gotham Book Mart 45 years ago, but introduced such writers as James Joyce to New York, will receive the Award for Distinguished Service to the Arts, given by the National Institute of Arts and Letters.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) made public today a new international convention establishing a conciliation and arbitration service to help settle disputes between nations and foreign private investors.

The fundamental fact involved in the Rockefeller budget is that of $3,488 million in expenditures proposed by the Governor, $2,029 million -- or 58 per cent of the total -- is for aid to local governments.

SAIGON, March 29 (AP) -- The Peking radio charged today that eight airplanes had violated Communist China's airspace near Hainan island. Hainan is a base for MIG interceptors, but the United States Navy raiders sighted no aerial challenge in the area.
PARIS, March 29 (Reuters) -- Millions will see movies free tomorrow when movie houses throughout France throw open their doors to all comers to protest a tax on movie admissions.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- The President of Upper Volta, Maurice Yameogo, is a soft-spoken, tough-minded moderate who believes that the future of Africa lies with the Africans and not with the Chinese or other foreign Communists.

It is moving time on Capitol Hill for 169 Congressmen eligible for space in the new Rayburn House Office Building. The structure's three-room suites complete with refrigerators and safes are being raffled off to applicants who may have a view of the Capitol dome or an interior court, depending on seniority.
RACHGIA, South Vietnam, March 26 -- One of the primary purposes of United States support for South Vietnam is to bar Hanoi and Peking from the great rice-growing areas of the Mekong delta.
ALBANY, March 29 -- Without debate, the Democratic majority in the Senate pushed through today Governor Rockefeller's bill to enlarge the state's low-rent housing program by $200 million.
The circus came two days early to Madison Square Garden in the form of the mighty wrestling midgets, who entertained 19,614 fans last night.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 29 -- Forty-two United States Navy aircraft today carried out a second raid over the Bachlong radar station, 60 miles off North Vietnam.

Because of the long and well-known attitude of your paper on the improvement in the administration of justice and in the caliber of our judges, we wish to comment on a proposed constitutional amendment now pending in the New York State Legislature, about which you had an editorial on March 29.
WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP) -- President Johnson asked Congress today to authorize an increase of $200 million for the saline water conversion program.

The first separate furniture branch of a department store in this area will be opened tomorrow by Bloomingdale's. It will be situated about 100 feet from its Bergen County branch store, just off Route 4 in Hackensack, N.J.
Renata Tebaldi, Franco Corelli and other leading Metropolitan Opera singers will take part in a program that the company will present tomorrow night in place of the scheduled performance of "Ernani."

New Yorkers littered the sky yesterday with tons of swirling ticker tape, confetti and old newspaper headlines -- and at the bottom of it all, moving slowly up lower Broadway, surrounded by marching bands, were two quiet Americans: Virgil I. Grissom and John W. Young.
Harold M. Lane Sr. was elected yesterday chairman and chief executive officer of S. Klein Department Stores, Inc. His son, Harold M. Lane Jr., was elected vice chairman.
PITTSBURGH, March 29 (AP) -- The United Steelworkers of America told the basic steel industry today how much it wanted in wages and fringe benefits in a new contract.

WASHINGTON, March 29 (UPI) -- The Internal Revenue Service confirmed today that it had revoked the tax-exempt status of H.L. Hunt's Life Line Foundation on the ground that the foundation was political instead of educational. The agency said in a statement:
VERO BEACH, Fla., March 29 (UPI) -- Don Drysdale pitched seven strong innings today as the Los Angeles Dodgers stopped the Baltimore Orioles' winning streak at five games with a 7-3 triumph.
WASHINGTON, March 29 -Two Interstate Commerce Commission examiners recommended today approval of the proposed merger of the New York Central into the Pennsylvania Railroad.
A wide variety of preparations were being made yesterday in the face of a threatened newspaper strike that might halt the city's major dailies starting early tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, March 29 -The Supreme Court reversed today two libel judgments against Aaron Henry, a Mississippi civil rights leader.
WASHINGTON, March 29 -- The Supreme Court took the following actions today:
A statue of Moses that stands in the village square of the town of Herzogenrath in West Germany is about to be turned down for display at the American-Israel Pavilion at the World's Fair.

NYACK, N.Y., March 29 -R.H. Macy Co. has dropped options to buy 100 acres of meadow and hillsides in Clarkstown for a multimillion-dollar shopping center that would include a Macy department store, officials in Rockland County heard today.

LONDON, March 29 -- A bill to give the Government power to delay business mergers, particularly the amalgamation of important newspapers, was approved on second reading in the House of Commons tonight.
A first-degree manslaughter indictment against a Bronx woman charged with the fatal stabbing of her husband last fall was dismissed in Bronx Supreme Court yesterday.
TRENTON, March 29 -- The State Assembly abandoned today its effort to produce a stopgap measure for reapportioning the Legislature on a "one man, one vote" basis.
The stock market declined yesterday for the third successive session after a show of strength in the early dealings. Trading continued at a moderate pace.
BRUSSELS, March 29 -France's rejection of a foreign minister's conference this spring evoked mixed reactions from the nations of the European community here tonight.
ST. LOUIS, March 29 (AP) -- Directors of the two companies approved today acquisition of the Meier Frank Company of Portland Ore., by the May Department Stores Company of St. Louis.

SELMA, Ala., March 29 -- The office of Gov. George C. Wallace announced in Montgomery tonight that the Governor would meet tomorrow with Negro leaders who wish to present grievances against the state Government.
LAKELAND, Fla., March 29 Whitey Ford, the most valuable 36-year-old pitcher in baseball, cast aside his assorted miseries today and pitched seven strong innings against the Detroit Tigers.

The much-jolted commuters on the bankrupt New Haven Railroad have now had official confirmation that they will be orphans in the projected absorption of the New Haven into a merged Pennsylvania-New York Central system. As had been expected, the Interstate Commerce Commission's examiners recommend that only the New Haven's freight operations be taken over.
BONN, March 29 -- A West German court sentenced Albert Rapp today to life imprisonment 10 times over at hard labor for his role in the murder of 1,180 persons during World War II.
WASHINGTON, March 29 -A Republican Congressman from Georgia proposed a voting rights bill today that would have broader coverage in some respects, than the Administration measure.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- An underlying current of crisis for recreational shooting is felt at the 94th meeting of the Natoinal Rifle Association under way here. The crisis arises from the anti-gun legislation pending in legisaltve bodies throughout the nation.
The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King's proposal for a boycott of Alabama is wrong in principle and would be unworkable in practice.

The ninth floor an part of the eighth floor in the Trade Bank and Trust Building at 592 Fifth Avenue, southwest corner of 48th Street, have been leased by the Foster Kleiser division of Metromedia, Inc. Foster Kleiser is one of the country's largest outdoor advertising concerns.
Mayor Wagner was accused yesterday of delaying eleven City Court appointments so he could use them as "political" plums in the fall elections.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- The number of people who want to be machines increases daily. This is a development the sociologists failed to foresee a few years ago when they were worrying about the influence of machines on society.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -The chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, Paul Rand Dixon, told Congress today that his agency would go ahead with its plans to regulate cigarette advertising whether or not Congress authorizes it to do so.
The American Cyanamid Company is expanding its household-products line through the proposed acquisition of the Preen Company, a Connecticut manufacturer of floor cleaners and waxes.

Charles Nolte, a former actor, who is an instructor in playwriting at the University of Minnesota, where he is a candidate for a Ph.D. degree, will become an actor again on the New York stage in his own play, "Do Not Pass Go."

Leslie Fay, Inc., a dress producer, is negotiating to acquire Wippette Sportswear, Inc., a maker of junior sportswear, both companies announced yesterday. "Negotiations have been progressing extremely favorably," it was said in a statement by Fred P. Pomerantz, chairman of Leslie Fay, Zachary Buchalter, president, and by Walter Bernstein and Irwin Silver, principals of Wippette.
Edwin W. Pauley, the oil industrialist and former Government official, was elected yesterday to the board of Eversharp, Inc., producer of the Schick line of razors and toiletries.
United States steel mills kept their record production pace last week by pouring 2,785,000 tons of ingots and steel for casting. The American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
The Seven metropolitan newspapers facing the possibility of a strike have a combined circulation of about 4.4 million daily and just over 6 million Sunday.

Operations of the Douglas Aircraft Company in the quarter ended Feb. 28 resulted in a net profit of $3,495,646, compared with $3,725,320 earned in the corresponding first fiscal quarter of the preceding year, the concern disclosed yesterday.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, March 29 -- The new Prime Minister of Ceylon said today that credits from abroad, particularly from the United States, were essential if his Government were to make a "quick impact" on the problems of unemployment, the high cost of living and the shortage of foreign exchange.
CHICAGO, March 29 -- Paul F. Lorenz, a vice president of the Ford Motor Company predicted today that within the next five years the automobile industry will be selling 10 million cars a year.
MONROE, La. -- Spring has come late to Louisiana, but the weather has had no hold on the harvest of that most delectable of local creatures -- the highly esteemed crawfish.

WASHINGTON, March 29 (UPI) -- The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether customers of privately leased wire telephones are entitled to a $5 million to $7 million refund because of delays in putting reduced rates into effect as a result of lawsuits.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- President Maurice Yameogo of Upper Volta hinted today that his Government might shut off the water for Ghana's giant Volta River dam if President Kwame Nkrumah did not change his "hostile attitudes."
More than half of the New York Rangers crossed the Canadian border yesterday as they streamed home following their final National Hockey League contest of the season Sunday night.

Man is an incorrigible optimist, and so he goes back to live in regions where nature has told him all through history that the earth shakes and the rocks are split. That interminable ribbon of land called Chile is such a place.

Joseph A. D'Amelio has been appointed to the new position of manager of product planning of Sweet's Construction Catalog Services of the F.W. Dodge Company, division of McGraw-Hill, Inc. The Philadelphia Orchestra, led by Eugene Ormandy, went through its usual motions last night in a program of Russian music at Carnegie Hall.
A New York County grand jury has begun an investigation of the New York City Housing Authority.
ALBANY, March 30 -- The State Department of Education proposed today a drastic change in the method of selecting the members of the New York City Board of Education.
THE following menu is suggested as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A recipe is given for an easy-to-prepare main dish.

WEMBLEY, England, March 30 (Reuters) -- Billy Walker, considered the golden boy of British boxing, was outpointed by Brian London, the former British heavyweight champion, in 10 rounds at the Empire Pool tonight.
Prudent city policy in the future may call for acquiring sites for the dual purpose of schools and housing, in the opinion of Mrs. Constance Baker Motley, Borough President of Manhattan.
WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP) -- Four Republican Senators and 17 House colleagues called today for stricter enforcement to prevent racial discrimination by Federal agencies.
ALBANY, March 30 -- The Court of Appeals held a special hearing today on the tangled issue of redistricting the Legislature's seats, but put off its decision until April 12 at the earliest.
The sense of doom that seems to lie over the Vietnamese conflict was given a horrible symbol in the terrorist attack on the American Embassy in Saigon.
WASHINGTON, March 30 -- The National Guard Bureau has issued stern regulations that provide for the withdrawal of Federal recognition of any National Guard unit refusing membership to Negroes.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- An impending proxy fight over a seat on the board of directors of the Pure Oil Company was disclosed today when five dissident stockholders filed proxy materials with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

BALTIMORE, March 30 (AP) Kevin Loughery scored 31 points as the Baltimore Bullets defeated the St. Louis Hawks, 109 -- 103, tonight and advanced to the Western Division finals of the National Basketball Association playoffs.
Several Government bonds of intermediate maturity and a scattering of Treasury bills registered slight gains yesterday. Otherwise, the market was steady and quiet.

CHICAGO, March 30 (AP) -- A credit executive said today "irresponsible advertising" of long-term payments on new-car financing was doing "irreparable harm" to conservative and sound credit institutions.

Four Puerto Ricans have been found hanged in police precinct cells in the last two months. Deputy Commissioner Walter Arm said yesterday that the Police Department had ordered closer supervision than the required inspection of each prisoner every 30 minutes.
The $30 million offering of convertible debdntures of J.P. Stevens Co., Inc., which was placed on the market yesterday, sold out quickly.

RIO DE JANEIRO, March 30 -- President Humberto Castelo Branco marked today the first anniversary of Brazil's revolutionary regime by starting an agrarian reform institute and accepting $43.4 million in United States project loans.

JACKSON, Miss., March 30 (UPI) -- Persistent rains after two rounds of excellent golf gave JoAnn Prentice of Alabama, her first tournament victory today in more than eight years on the women's circuit.

THE "Eye on New York" television series of station WCBS-TV last night examined drug addiction among teen-agers, the habit that may begin with excessive doses of cough medicine containing codiene and ultimately lead to use of heroin and perhaps death.

" The Space Race" editorial which appears in your March 19 issue drastically underplays the enormous importance of Russia's latest achievement. By couching the rhetorical question "in terms of this planet's real problems and real needs . . ."

Jose Torres became the new light-heavyweight champion last night, scoring a technical knockout, after nine rounds, over Willie Pastrano. In the first bout of Madison Square Garden's first championship double-header, Emile Griffith retained his welterweight title with a lackluster victory over Jose Stable.
VALPARAISO, Chile, March 30 -- Central Chile struggled today to repair the wreckage left by Sunday's 90-second-long earthquake.
The Western Electric Company, the manufacturing and supply unit of the giant Bell Telephone system, reported yesterday that it had achieved new highs in almost every phase of its 1964 operations.
WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP) -- Farm product prices increased by about one-half of 1 per cent during the month ended March 15.
PARIS, March 30 -- The effectiveness of the new United States controls on overseas loans and investments is spreading.

The Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound came up yesterday with enough dates to keep the most eager yachtsman competing busily every weekend and many days in between. The delegates ratified season schedules for the Mid-Sound and Connecticut area championship regattas and a long list of distance events for cruising yachts at the annual spring meeting in the New York Yacht Club.

THERE'S no use looking for logic in literary matters. Although more adequately competent novels are being published today than ever before, the number of distinguished novels worthy of enthusiastic admiration is depressingly small. Even so, the flood of criticism devoted to novels, often to bad novels, flows on in undiminished spate.
LONDON, March 30 -- The ashes of Lord Morrison of Lambeth were scattered on the Thames today in a ceremony that marked the end of an era in the government of London.
OTTAWA, March 30 -- Canada's Liberal Government reached a milestone today with passage in the House of Commons of its public pension plan.

" Guns at the Forks," by Walter O'Meara, the first book in the "American Forts Series," will be published by Prentice-Hall on May 12. The series was planned by the late Stewart H. Holbrook with each volume relating the history of one fort to the story of the continent as a whole.
WASHINGTON, March 30 -- The United States District Court here dismissed today a suit that sought fewer seats in the House of Representatives for states that deny Negroes the vote.

CHICAGO, March 30 -- The Sears, Roebuck Co. slogan that "Sears has everything" seemed borne out today in its rosy report of last year's business.

Willie Pastrano, in his corner, hung his head and cried, while across the ring someone picked up Jose Torres and carried him around the ring.

In any event, Mr. Bagley, an incorrigible collector of forgotten songs from the theater, has built the most tuneful and witty musical in town around what might he considered the unknown Porter.
The City Council asked the Transit Authority yesterday to let the city's 854 housing police ride free in the subways when they are in uniform and traveling to and from official destinations.

Today signals the end of Red Cross month throughout the nation. During March 50,000 volunteers in New York have called on their neighbors and co-workers to help raise funds needed to support Red Cross services in the months ahead.

Thirty-four tenants in four old brownstones at 208-214 Central Park South, between Seventh Avenue and Broadway, are fighting an eviction move by their landlord, who wants to replace the rent-controlled brownstones with a 20-story apartment house.

NEW ORLEANS, March 30 -- The first successful anticancer vaccines are likely to be those designed to combat individual cases of existing diseases rather than those aimed at preventing cancer in whole populations, a specialist said here today.

THE outcome of the 12-hour race at Sebring, Fla. last Saturday, with a Chevrolet-powered Chaparral and a Ford-powered Grand Touring prototype in front of a privately owned Italian Ferrari was convincing proof that American-built racing cars have at long last caught and passed the best of the European products.
WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Following is the text of President Johnson's statement today on the bombing of the United States Embassy in Saigon:
George Champion, chairman of the Chase Manhattan Bank, assured the bank's shareholders yesterday that, in his view, a Federal antitrust suit against the bank was unlikely.
The New York Women's Bible Society will give a tea and a Biblical pageant on April 8 at 2:30 P.M. in the parish house of the Brick Presbyterian Church, 62 East 92d Street.

The higher than anticipated level of business activity reached in the first quarter just ending has prompted economists to revise their forecasts for the remainder of the year. Now most forecasters are predicting that the expansion will continue intact through 1965. Previously, some had feared that a downturn might take place in the second half.

GREENSBORO, N.C., March 30 -- At a breakfast reception, Greensboro officially declared this to be Sam Snead Week. Acting Mayor William Trotter said he was happy the $65,000 Greater Greensboro open, which opens Thursday, "is dedicated to Sam."

MONTREAL, March 30 (UPI) -- Stan Mikita of the Chicago Black Hawks withstood a closing rush from Norm Ullman of Detroit to win the National Hockey League scoring championship. It is the second straight season Mikita has accomplished the feat.
Trading on the American Stock Exchange lacked a definite trend yesterday as advances just barely exceeded declines in moderate trading.

Jerome Robbins burst back into the dance world last night with a production of Igor Stravinsky's "Les Noces" that is an almost overwhelming fusion of animal energy, ritualistic ardor and rhythmic attack.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- The Supreme Court took the Connecticut birth-control case under advisement today after a brisk exchange between one of the Justices and the lawyer representing the state of Connecticut.
NISSEQUOGUE, L.I., March 30 -- Aerial spraying to combat gypsy moths has been planned for an 800-acre wooded area in this North Shore community.

HOLLYWOOD, March 30 -- Having studied next fall's proposed network television schedules, some of the industry's most talented producers, directors and writers are switching their attention to motion pictures.

Two conferences designed to aid in the reduction of accidents in building construction and in industrial structures will be held next week as part of the annual Eastern Regional Safety Convention and Exposition. The five-day safety meeting will begin at the Statler-Hilton Hotel on Monday.
Six toy manufacturers have renewed or signed new leases for expanded space at 200 Fifth Avenue. Helmsley-Spear is the building's managing agent.
The Consolidated Foods Corporation of Chicago, a leading food processor and distributor, registered the highest sales and earnings in its 25-year history in the 12 and 36 weeks ended on March 6.
The City Planning Commission reported yesterday that 47,256 housing units were added to the city's housing supply in 1964.
The election of Charles W. Duke as vice president in charge of properties and concessions for Avis, Inc., was announced yesterday by Winston V. Morrow Jr., president of the car-rental concern.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 30 -- Johnny Keane returned to the St. Louis Cardinals' training headquarters today and saw a familiar sight: the Cardinals defeating the New York Yankees.
Landlords continue to show a reluctance to rent to United Nations diplomats, according to Mrs. Eleanor Clark French, New York City Commissioner to the United Nations.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- The deficit in the nation's international payments rose to $1,505,000,000 in the final quarter of last year, the biggest quarterly deficit since 1950, final Commerce Department figures disclosed today.
One of the doctors who figured in charges made by an 18-year-old Bennington College freshman has resigned his post at the Women's House of Detention.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, March 30 (AP) -- Two British patrol craft intercepted three Indonesian boats off Singapore shortly before midnight. Shots from the patrol craft struck one boat and killed three persons aboard, a Defense Ministry spokesman reported.
Mike Venezia, the young Brooklyn-born jockey, had just cause to believe yesterday that silver linings may be only a myth -- and that behind every dark cloud there is only another one.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Governor Rockefeller and Mayor Wagner, the nominal leaders of their parties in New York State, have both fallen to second place in popularity and face serious re-election problems, a group of polls show.
PARIS, March 30 -- Attendance at movie theaters throughout France was exceptionally good today, but box-office business couldn't have been worse. Admission was free.

MOSCOW, March 30 (UPI) -- Informed sources reported today that the ideological commission of the Communist party's Central Committee set up by former Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev had been dissolved by the new Kremlin leadership.
Jose Torres, the pride of Puerto Rico, was almost mobbed by his well-wishers as he struggled to reach his dressing room.

TRENTON, March 30 -- Gov. Richard J. Hughes reported today that he had been assured repeatedly" that the deficit-ridden Erie-Lackawanna Railroad would not abandon its North Jersey commuter service at the end of August.
A time of decision is approaching on the fate of the last unspoiled sections of the Missouri, once one of the nation's most beautiful rivers.

BRUSSELS, March 30 -- Italy and France were expected to relax their year-old programs of economic restraint in compliance with recommendations adopted today during a ministerial meeting of the European Common Market here.

LAUREL, Md., March 30 (AP) -- Trainer Frank Catrone said today that Lucky Debonair, early co-favorite for the Kentucky Derby, would go to Keeneland to prepare for the Derby because of continued bad weather in Maryland.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- A member of the Executive Commission of European Common Market said today that an agreement on agriculture in the Kennedy round of trade negotiations would require a move toward compromise by both the Common Market and the United States.

DUSSELDORF, Germany, March 30 -- Chancellor Ludwig Erhard promised the President of the American Jewish Congress today that West Germany's diplomatic relations with Israel would be "more than a formality."
Negotiators for the printers and the newspaper publishers worked past the 2 A.M. strike deadline today in an effort to achieve a settlement.
American Broadcasting-Paramount Theatres, Inc., expects first-quarter operating earnings to exceed the record of $3,425,000, or 76 cents a share, earned in the initial three months of 1961.

The price of aluminum can stock was increased yesterday by two major aluminum companies. While can stock represents only a relatively small part of aluminum sales, its use in containers for food has been growing rapidly in the last few years.

COLOMBO, Ceylon -- When the Government of Mrs. Sirimavo Bandaranaike, the world's only woman Prime Minister, was toppled by a parliamentary revolt, one Communist Ambassador stationed here confided to a Western colleague: "You very lucky. Me very unlucky."

SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 30 -- United States and South Vietnamese pilots bombed an important air base in North Vietnam today, but an American spokesman indicated that the raid was not in retaliation for the terrorist bombing of the United States Embassy in Saigon this morning.
