State Department officials were accused yesterday of applying "pressures" on Senate sponsors of a bill designed to frustrate the Arab economic boycott of Israel.
The home in which Edgar Allen Poe lived from 1846 to 1849, now owned and maintained by the Park Department, has become a bit shabby and is about to be refurbished.

" STARTING today," said Joe Lapchick, "I am a professional bum." There was a happy lilt in the voice of the St. John's basketball coach. His formal retirement from a sport he graced with such distinction for so many years has just begun. He still is riding the crest of the sentimental wave that has been swirling about him for weeks.

PARIS, March 30 -- Manfred Klaiber, the West German Ambassador, told President de Gaulle today of his Government's "disquiet" at France's rejection of an Italian proposal for talks next month on European political unity.
ROME, March 30 -- The Italian economy "has passed from an unfavorable situation of a temporary nature to a true and proper recession," the General Confederation of Italian Industry said today.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee voted today to override its chairman, J.W. Fulbright, and consider the Administration's $3.4 billion request for military and economic foreign aid in a single bill.

BONN, March 30 -- Shortly after the West German Parliament approved extension of the statutory deadline for the prosecution of Nazi criminals, a television commentator sarcastically suggested the unpopularity of the move.
Leo Brown, Commissioner of Marine and Aviation announced yesterday that the way had been cleared for the immediate construction of a new Hudson River sightseeing boat pier at West 43rd Street.

Two New York savings banks and the Federal Housing Administration have been victimized in the $2,140,000 financing by the promoters of a Brooklyn cooperative apartment project, Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz charged yesterday.
The Spanish Government announced yesterday that it was sending a major new collection of classical and contemporary art to the United States for display at the World's Fair.
The election of Frederick S. Beebe as a director of the Tri-Continental Corporation was announced yesterday at its annual stockholders meeting in Baltimore.

EASLEY BLACKWOOD in recent years has been best known as a composer, and some of his music has been played in New York by major symphonic organizations. Last night, however, he turned up in person as a pianist.

WASHINGTON, March 30 (UPI) -- An Alabama Congressman said today that "drunkenness and sex orgies were the order of the day" during civil rights demonstrations in Selma, Ala., and on the march to Montgomery.

The voting rights bill now before Congress is in its essentials admirably drawn. In those six Southern states where discrimination has been severe, the bill provides standards for Federal intervention that are clear and that go into effect automatically. Moreover, the bill is comprehensive, covering local and state as well as Federal elections.
Municipal bonds showed encouraging signs on two fronts yesterday, leading many dealers to believe that the recently apathetic market might be showing new life.
The stock market shook off yesterday the weakness that had prevailed for the three preceding sessions and advanced modestly in quiet trading.

Secretary of Labor Wirtz sharply reflected the expressed intention of Congress when he told importunate corporate farmers that they could never again expect Government authorization for the mass import of cut-rate foreign labor to harvest American crops.
WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Spain, which colonized much of Latin America four centuries ago, moved today to assist in its transition to the modern age.
The Cenco Instruments Corporation, based in Chicago, is negotiating to acquire two glass companies, Labglass, Inc., and the Doerr Glass Company, both of New Jersey.

A dispute between two major figures in the art world, Willem de Kooning and Sidney Janis, broke open yesterday when the artist filed a $150,000 court suit against the gallery owner. In turn, Mr. Janis, the dealer, plans to file a $203,000 suit against Mr. de Kooning this morning.

President Johnson has nominated John G. Adams, director of the Civil Aeronautics Board's Bureau of Enforcement, to succeed Chan Gurney as a member of the five-man board, according to a White House announcement.
VIENTIANE, Laos, March 30 -- A revolt led by two Laotian Army colonels collapsed today when Government troops and paratroopers captured Thakhek without firing a shot.
WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Plans to launch the world's first commercial satellite from Cape Kennedy, Fla., on April 6 were announced today by the Communications Satellite Corporation (Comsat).
WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Two hard-pressed railroads that only yesterday received a promise of a better future face only one problem today:
Reform or, preferably, abolition of the Board of Estimate has been the goal of advocates of good municipal government for years.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- The Seafarers International Union of North America assailed today the plans for closing seven United States Public Health Service hospitals as "fraught with flaws and unwarranted and misleading projections."

WASHINGTON, March 30 (UPI) -- Maj. Gen. Julian L. Schley, a former Governor of the Panama Canal and Army Chief of Engineers from 1937 to 1941, died last night at Walter Reed Hospital. He was 85 years old.
The Grangesberg Company, a large Swedish producer of iron ore and steel, reported yesterday that its operations in 1964 set records.

Robert Moses said yesterday that failure of the Legislature to act "immediately" on bills to authorize the Long Island Sound Bridge, the Pelham Bay shore drive and the Queensborough Bridge Manhattan terminal "simply postpones the day of reckoning" and might run up their ultimate cost to a prohibitive point.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Dr. Gorge James, the New York City Health Commissioner, told the Senate Commerce Committee today that approximately 2,000 New Yorkers died last year of lung cancer caused by cigarette smoking.
Pouring black smoke and sparks, a horse-drawn fire engine manned by volunteers pulled up in front of a burning shed on 11th Avenue near 37th Street that Patrick Dougherty used as a stable.
WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Consumer prices, taken as a whole, remained unchanged in February, the Labor Department reported yesterday.
The appointment of W. Alden Anderson Jr. as a vice president of the Bank of New York was announced yesterday. Paul Perillo and S. Wyman Rolph 3rd were named assistant treasurers.

American Metal Climax, Inc., said yesterday that it planned to spend about $500 million through 1969 on a program of expansion and diversification. At the same time, the large mining company defended its overseas investments as necessary for its own development and as beneficial to the United States economy.

Ithaca, seat of Cornell University will transfer 72 acres of its municipal airport site at the southern tip of Cayuga Lake to the Festival Theater, seating 1,500, scheduled for completion in the summer of 1967.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- An optimistic view of game management and sport hunting in the vast National Forest System was advanced today at the annual meeting of the National Rifle Association at the Sheraton-Park Hotel.
WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Stockpiling of steel inventories continued at an advanced rate in February, through perhaps a shade more slowly than in other recent months.
Clark Kerr's triumph at the University of California was not the supposed victory for free speech and liberal thought. Instead, it struck a serious blow at the foundations of democracy.

A gala triple bill will be given tonight at the Metropolitan Opera at 8, replacing Verdi's "Ernani," originally scheduled, consisting of Act I of Puccini's "La Boheme," Act II of Verdi's "La Traviata" and Act III of Puccini's "Turandot."

TRENTON, March 30 -- The New Jersey Attorney General asked the State Supreme Court today either to give the Legislature a last chance to devise a Senate reapportionment plan in time for the 1965 elections or to provide a "simple and uncomplicated" one of its own.
SALISBURY, Rhodesia, March 30 -- The Rhodesian Parliament was dissolved tonight and a general election called for May 7 in this self-governing colony.
PORTSMOUTH, Va., March 30 (AP) -- Two American ships, one on her maiden voyage, collided today in the Atlantic Ocean one mile off Cape Henry, Va. Both made it safely to port under their own power.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Attorney General Nicholas deB. Katzenbach and the Senate Republican leader, Everett McKinley Dirksen of Illinois, are agreed that the Administration's voting rights bill should be broadened to apply to areas of discrimination not now covered.

CANTON, Miss., March 30 -- More than 80 Madison County Negroes, noting what they called a "change of attitude" by white city and county leaders, marched quietly through the rain tonight to the courthouse.

SOME of the most difficult suit combinations in bridge arise when the defenders hold both the king and jack of a trump suit. Even when the declaring side has three honors in one hand, as in the example, the situation may not be as simple as it appears.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Maj. Gen. Winston Peabody (Wimpy) Wilson, the 53-year-old chief of the National Guard Bureau, is a friendly, quick-smiling man whose gregarious nature hides a steely determination.
MOSCOW, March 30 -- The Soviet Union expects to introduce color television on a commercial basis during the next five-year plan, from 1966 to 1970, it was announced today.
Prices on the London Stock Exchange edged forward yesterday for the second successive day on light selective buying.
DETROIT, MARCH 30 -- Four of the nation's leading Negro civil rights leaders paid homage today to Mrs. Viola Gregg Liuzzo, the white Detroit mother who gave her life for their common cause.
BONN, March 30 -- Foreign Minister Gerhard Schroder warned today that defeat for the United States in Southeast Asia could have serious consequences for the cause of freedom in Europe.
ALBANY, March 30 -- The Democratic legislative leaders have given up, at least for the moment, on Governor Rockefeller's proposed 2 per cent statewide sales tax.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- The House Committee on Un-American Activities voted today to conduct a full investigation of the Ku Klux Klan. The action, which was unanimous, grew out of President Johnson's appearance on television last Friday in which he denounced the organization as a "hooded society of bigots" and suggested a Congressional investigation.
Sixteen stones that may have originated on the moon will go on display today at the American Museum-Hayden Planetarium.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 30 -- The United Nations mediator for Cyprus, Galo Plaza Lasso, urged today that the Greek and Turkish Cypriotes end their communal conflicts by establishing a government in which all would have equal rights without regard to origin.

A BLUE cheese must have quite a pedigree in order to be a Roquefort. It must come from caves of Roquefort in southwest France, and it must be made entirely from the milk of ewes that graze the region's steep mountain slopes.

Four foreign journalists were cited yesterday for their reporting about the United States in the last two years. They were announced as winners of the 1965 foreign journalism awards of the University of California at Los Angeles.

HARTFORD, March 30 -- Gov. John N. Dempsey said today he would ask the Interstate Commerce Commission to "reconsider" an examiners' report that excludes the passenger service of the New Haven Railroad from the proposed merger of the New York Central and Pennsylvania Railroads.
YONKERS, March 30 -- Yonkers Raceway canceled its racing program tonight because of a strike by pari-mutuel workers over wages.

SAN BERNARDINO, Calif., March 30 (AP) -- Edward C. Strum started 28 years ago as a bank messenger and bookkeeper and worked his way to the vice presidency of the Security First National Bank's Inland Division.
Six city departments began work yesterday on plans to rid Greenwich Village of its carnival atmosphere and what has been described as increased rowdyism.

LONDON, March 30 -- A long-simmering academic dispute at Cambridge University has been set aside with a decision by its Downing College to halt the admission of English-literature students for at least one year.
The New York City Board of Education hopes to begin operating its ultra-high-frequency television station on Channel 25 on Oct. 4.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 30 -- Gov. George C. Wallace received a 16-member biracial delegation today and was handed a petition calling for the extension of Negro rights in Alabama.
Ted Bates Co., Inc., has been selected by the Advertising Council as the volunteer agency that will conduct an industry campaign to help the Government reduce its balance-of-payments deficit.

The countries in the European Common Market and the European Free Trade Association represent a market for American textile industries that is equivalent in scope and potential to that of the United States, according to the Borg Fabrics Company.

OTTAWA, March 30 -- Eighth-grade school musicians of Waukegan, Ill., won hearty applause from a large Ottawa audience last night. The young bandsmen, completing a goodwill tour of four Canadian cities, played a program highlighting two American composers, Aaron Copland and John Philip Sousa.
HONG KONG, March 30 -- Communist China welcomed today the bombing of the United States Embassy in Saigon as "heartening news to revolutionary people throughout the world."
A production of "Separate Tables" will open tomorrow at The Lighthouse, the New York Association for the Blind, at 111 East 59th Street.
WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Ghana denied today charges made against her yesterday by Maurice Yameogo, President of Upper Volta, who is visiting the United States.
ALGIERS, March 30 -- Chou En-lai, Premier of Communist China, arrived today for what is believed to be another attempt at countering Soviet influence in Africa and Asia. He received a quiet welcome.
Philip Ewald will join This Week magazine tomorrow as senior vice president and a board member. He had been senior vice president of the Curtis Publishing Company.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- President Johnson condemned today the "terrorist outrage" in the bombing of the United States Embassy in Saigon and said it would "only reinforce" the Administration's determination to give more help to South Vietnam.

The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. said yesterday that he was determined to press his plans for an economic boycott of Alabama despite the reported opposition of the Johnson Administration to the proposal.
The Lummus Company, a design, engineering and construction concern, announced yesterday the election of Richard J. Hallinan as a director.

ALBANY, March 30 -- Assemblymen of both parties from Nassau and Suffolk counties broke into furious but futile rebellion today over the selection of a leading Democrat for the non-salaried Board of Regents.

It's refreshing to find a securities firm today that feels it can cope successfully with the rising costs of operation. That note is sounded in the latest annual report issued by Weeden Co., a pioneer firm in the third market, which deals in listed stocks over-the-counter.

Future historians of science will undoubtedly point to the mid-twentieth century as the time when man first began to uncover and understand the incredibly complex blueprints that govern life's architecture.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 30 -- The president of one of two big longshoremen's locals on the Alabama Gulf Coast said today that "before anything can be done" about Dr. King's proposal for longshoremen to refuse to handle Alabama products, "King will have to meet with me."

The spring fashions on the American campus seem to be changing. Instead of chasing girls, the boys are now chasing college presidents. The inter-dormitory panty raid has been replaced by the international protests against the war in Vietnam, and the boozy beach picnics in Ft. Lauderdale by the singing marches on Montgomery, Ala.
NAIROBI, Kenya, March 30 -- The Soviet Union has been training Kenyans as fighter pilots without the Government's knowledge, it was disclosed in Parliament today.

The Link-Belt Company announced yesterday a 50 per cent stock dividend payable April 23 to holders of record April 1 and a quarterly dividend of 45 cents on the new shares, payable June 1 to holders of record May 4.
The British pound gave ground yesterday in active trading on foreign exchange markets here.
The establishment of a Center for International Studies at New York University and the appointment of Dr. Thomas M. Franck, professor of law at N.Y.U., as its director, were announced yesterday.
In a day of active trading and widely fluctuating price movements, Maine potato futures moved up 8 to 11 cents a hundredweight on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
LONDON, March 31 -- The specter of the tax collector hung over Sotheby's auction rooms today as $1,740,000 worth of Impressionist art went under the hammer.

The City Planning Commission yesterday set May 12 for a public hearing on plans jointly developed by the Traffic and Park Departments for a parking garage with a playground on its roof in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- The Administration will soon submit to the Senate for ratification two amendments to the United Nations Charter that would enlarge the membership of the Security Council and the Economic and Social Council.
Pan American World Airways' pilots struck last night in a dispute over new contract terms.
WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP) -- An exhibit of mementos of President Kennedy opened today at the National Archives.

THEY came spilling down the aisles of Madison Square Garden in an emotional wave, jabbering in ecstatic delight at the wondrous thing that had just occurred. Jose Torres, the idol of Puerto Ricans everywhere, was the new light-heavyweight champion of the world and his wildly excited well-wishers were demonstrating a vicarious pride in his accomplishment.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 31 -- Working day and night, the 38 members of the New York Met squad defeated their Buffalo farm team in the morning, 5-4, practiced during the afternoon, and took on the Washington Senators tonight in a formal exhibition game under the lights at Al Lang Field.

The Philadelphia Electric Power Company sold yesterday $25 million of 30-year sinking-fund debentures to an investment banking syndicate headed by Salomon Brothers Hutzler and Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, Inc.
Members of the mass media need "cross criticism" -- criticism of one by the other -- as a corrective for their shortcomings, Morris L. Ernst, lawyer and author, said yesterday.

ABOARD U.S.S. CORAL SEA, off Vietnam, March 31 -- The Navy's air strikes against North Vietnam, combined with its patrol duties along the Vietnamese coast, are straining the capacity of the Seventh Fleet, according to United States Navy officials.
A Wall Street investment banking house yesterday notified Alabama that it would no longer buy or sell bonds issued by the state or any of its political subdivisions.
Trans World Airlines and Eastern Air Lines each have announced the nomination of new directors.
The Contemporary Chamber Players of the University of Chicago paid tribute to that towering prophet of 20th Century music, Edgard Varese, in a concert at Carnegie Hall last night.

The Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, Inc., seeking to avoid delisting by the New York Stock Exchange, outlined yesterday a vigorous expansion program that includes a new "bus train" service on existing railroad tracks for a 100-mile radius of New York City.

IF A HAND that went wrong keeps you awake at night or returns to haunt your dreams it is likely to be a slam hand. The worst nightmares usually come from a misplayed slam, for misbidding can usually be blamed on one's partner.

The winning bids yesterday for two bond issues of the city of Philadelphia totaling $19,665,000, were submitted by a group consisting of the First National City Bank, Halsey Stuart Co. and the Philadelphia National Bank and associates.
The Texas Gas Transmission Corporation reported yesterday records in sales and revenue for 1964, with consolidated net income up 10 per cent to a new high of $11.8 million.

NEW HAVEN, March 31 -- Don Schollander, America's greatest swimming hero since Johnny Weissmuller, will return to championship competition in the Amateur Athletic Union national indoor meet starting tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- A Texas Congressman said today that before President Johnson sent the voting rights bill to Capitol Hill Attorney General Nicholas deB. Katzenbach showed it to five Supreme Court Justices and got their "enthusiastic" endorsement of its constitutionality.
The Emporium Capwell Company, a California department store chain, set records in sales and earnings in the fiscal year ended Jan. 31, the company reported yesterday.
WARSAW, March 31 -- They had seemed to be the ideal couple -- young, educated, in love, married only two years. Now they were getting a divorce.
The war in South Vietnam is beginning to divert funds, weapons and equipment from other United States commands, according to military sources.
An increase of 5 cents a pack in the state tax on cigarettes went into effect at midnight last night, raising the total of state, city and Federal taxes to 22 cents.
ALBANY, March 31 -- Two bills that would strengthen the ethics rules for state legislators and state employes were reported out of committee today for action by the Assembly.
MINEOLA, L.I., March 31 -- The State Supreme Court declared today that Francis X. Altimari, a Republican, was the winner of a tie-vote battle in Nassau for District Court judge.
The nation's electric power production rose 10.9 per cent in the week ended March 28 from the level in the corresponding 1964 week, it was reported yesterday by the Edison Electric Institute.
WHEN Bessie Van Der Beek was hired to work at B. Altman Co. on March 22, 1900, she was told to wear a plain black dress and black shoes, to keep her hair neat and her hands clean.
Former President Harry S. Truman will receive the 23d annual Freedom Award of Freedom House on April 13, the 20th anniversary of his first full day in office as President.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 31 -- More than 70 United States Air Force planes unleased the greatest incendiary attack of the war on a Vietcong concentration 25 miles miles northwest of Saigon.

The Times of March 28 gave great prominence to a photograph of the Imperial Wizard of the Ku Klux Klan holding a newspaper folded so as to read: "Highlander Communist Training School." The caption under the photograph was: "Klan Chief Accuses Communists: Robert M. Shelton Jr., in Birmingham Shows Report on Red School."

Two chemical companies announced plans yesterday to increase prices for sulphur by up to $4 per long ton. The increases become effective tomorrow on spot sales, and on Oct. 1 on shipments made under existing contracts.
TO dine well is one thing, and to dine well with an intellectual curiosity about what one dines on is another.
WASHINGTON March 31 -- The House approved today a 10-year program to promote the conservation and development of water resources.
WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP) -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee voted today to cut $19 million from support funds for foreign military assistance in the Administration's Foreign Aid Bill.
The British pound fell yesterday in heavy turnover on foreign exchange markets here. This was the second straight day of decline for the currency.
ALBANY, March 31 -- The Democratic proponents of Governor Rockefeller's 2 per cent state sales tax are planning a large-scale public appeal to rescue it from oblivion.

The Frank G. Shattuck Company, which operates a chain of restaurants under the name of Schrafft's, plans to open in a low nice and newly restaurants and six more franchised units and motor inns. H. Morgan Shattuck, president of the 59-year-old company, made the disclosure to stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday in Boston.
NEW ORLEANS, March 31 -- Little bits of human lung and kidneys are being grown in the brains of rats in an effort to show conclusively whether certain viruses are capable of causing cancer in men.
THESE three books present sharp portraits of men as seen by women writers. Various girls are sketched unsparingly. That saves the men from complete rout.
Total assets of the Alleghany Corporation, a diversified holding company, surged last year to $206,269,327 from $172,836,962 in 1963, it was announced yesterday.

LONDON, Thursday, April 1 (AP) -- North Vietnam is not demanding withdrawal of American troops from the South as a condition for ceasefire, according to William Warbey, a left-wing Laborite Member of Parliament.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- President Johnson sent to Congress today proposed legislation needed to carry out the recent agreement with Canada to eliminate all tariffs on automobiles and original-equipment auto components.
WASHINGTON, March 31 -- The Treasury bill issue next week will be $200 million larger than the expiring issue, it was disclosed today.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, March 31 -- The Government of Premier Moise Tshombe announced today that it had granted political asylum to the Rev. Fulbert Youlou, ousted President of the neighboring Congo Republic.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Don C. Silverthorne, the former president of the bankrupt San Francisco National Bank charged today that "some kind of a payoff" had been made in connection with a large withdrawal of funds from the bank just hours before it was closed.
Prices on the London Stock Exchange edged ahead yesterday in light trading. The advance was the third consecutive upturn in the market although buying was highly selective.

BONN, March 31 -- A consortium of 12 European and United States oil companies formed a corporation today to build the the German section of a new trans-Alpine pipeline from Trieste to Ingolstadt in southern Germany.
VIENNA, March 31 -- Fist fights and the hurling of stench bombs marked demonstrations here tonight for and against Prof. Taras Borodajkewycz, a former Nazi.

WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP) -- Secretary of State Dean Rusk agreed today to receive four Ambassadors who will speak for 16 nonaligned Governments tomorrow. The envoys will present an appeal for Vietnamese peace negotiations without any strings attached.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Mayor Wagner declared today that the creation of a new Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development would be "a giant step" toward a coordinated governmental solution of mounting city problems.

The lagging build-up of the State University system has created one of New York's critical educational deficits. As pressures for college admission are intensified year after year, the struggling units of this long neglected network of public higher education have assumed overwhelming importance in the hopes and aspirations of thousands of young people and their parents.

David Coleman, who has spent the last four years on death row for the rape-murder of a 77-year-old Brooklyn woman, told a State Supreme Court Justice yesterday that he had confessed to the crime because the police beat him and threatened to jail his common-law wife.
VIENNA, March 31 -- The recent emergency landing of the Soviet Voskhod space ship was the third such failure in the Soviet space program, a Czechoslovak scientist said last night on Radio Prague.
PARIS, March 31 -- Marion Williams returned to Paris with a small company of singers and a program of Negro spirituals and Gospel and folk songs last night. She is playing here for 12 nights.
Frank M. Folsom, chairman of the executive committee of the Radio Corporation of America, was elected yesterday to the board of the Tishman Realty and Construction Company.
A later Easter this year than in 1964 had the expected adverse effect on sales of leading New York City department stores during March.
WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP) -- Secretary of the Interior Stewart L. Udall today announced a 75,000 barrel-a-day increase in the import quota for residual fuel oil on the East Coast.

DANANG, South Vietnam, March 31 (UPI) -- An American photographer was arrested here today and his camera and film confiscated by American military officials when he tried to photograph United States helicopters returning from a mission against Communist guerrillas.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Ambassador Maxwell D. Taylor held the first of several meetings with President Johnson today to present what he called some "more definitive proposals" for United States operations in Vietnam.
Prices of frozen pork bellies futures declined to three-month lows yesterday in active trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.

WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP) -- The Army disclosed today that it had in orbit a three satellite earth-mapping system, with two of the spacecraft circling the earth from west to east and the third traveling from pole to pole.

A painting contractor who was sentenced 15 years ago to 7 1/2 to 15 years in prison for defrauding the city of $150,000 in a municipal hospitals paint fraud, refused yesterday to sign a waiver of immunity in a new city contract investigation.
CHICAGO, March 31 -- The first winners of the National Achievement Scholarship Program awards for outstanding Negro students were announced here today.

" The Subject Was Roses," one of Broadway's two dramas, is adding more chapters to its success story. The play, which had considerable difficulty in reaching the stage, will return almost half of its capitalization by the end of this month.
A murder conviction was upset yesterday on the ground that the defendant had been forced to incriminate himself in a confrontation with the victim's wife.

THE Paul Taylor Dance Company, which has performed in Europe frequently since 1960 and played extended engagements in London and Paris, came to the Ambassador Theater last night to open a series of four performances on Broadway under the auspices of Richard Barr's and Clinton Wilder's Theater 65.
WASHINGTON, March 31 -- The negotiator for the nation's railroads said tonight that they had made "dramatic gains" in eliminating jobs they considered unnecessary.

THE National Collegiate Athletic Association's plan to form federations in various sports to gain some control over them has been extended to wrestling. In the past such N.C.A.A. creations as the track and field and gymnastic federations have led to long, confusing and bitter struggles with the Amateur Athletic Union.
STAMFORD, Conn., March 31 -- The Superintendent of Schools here, Joseph J. Franchina, resigned today after an investigation into irregularities in students' transcripts sent to colleges.

TRENTON, March 31 -- The State Supreme Court denied today a request for a two-year postponement of legislative reapportionment and gave the State Legislature until June 3 to draw up a plan for redistricting the Senate.

MADRID, March 31 -- Jeeploads of police stood along one side of the red brick law school on the campus of the University of Madrid yesterday. Policemen guarded the entrance while an attendant at the door checked cards to make sure only law students entered.
Shares traded on the American Stock Exchange closed generally steady in quiet trading yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 31 -- The Indonesian cabinet shuffle] iwas viewed here as a major victory for the Indonesian Corn-I Imunist party.

A strong possibility exists that E.J. Korvette, Inc., the country's leading discount department-store chain, may soon acquire controlling or partial interest in H.L. Klion, Inc., operator of the leased Korvette Furniture Centers.
NEW HAVEN, March 31 -Trustees of the New Haven Railroad have agreed to transfer all the railroad's properties to a merged Pennsylvania-Central Railroad or cash and securities worth $140 million.
Philadelphia provided the interest in the bond market yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Ray C. Bliss of Ohio takes over tomorrow as chairman of a Republican party that is without an acknowledged leader, rent by ideological and organizational disputes and staggered by the worst election defeat in American history.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- The Food for Peace program is not only alleviating hunger abroad but is also stimulating commercial markets for United States products, President Johnson told Congress today in his annual report on the program.
The F. M. Schaefer Brewing Company, the large beer producer, announced yesterday the election of William M. Schaefer, 28 years old, as a director.
MOSCOW, March 31 -- The Soviet Union announced today that compulsory military service would be cut to one year for conscripts with a college degree.

LANSING, Kan., March 31 (AP) -- Harvey Bailey, convicted in the Urschel kidnapping case in the nineteen-thirties and for a Fort Scott, Kan., bank robbery, was released today on parole. He went to Joplin, Mo., where he has a home and a job offer.

ANKARA, Turkey, March 31 (AP) -- Turkey charged tonight that the United Nations Cyprus mediator, Galo Plaza Lasso, had exceeded his authority and said his status as mediator "should be considered as terminated."

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 31 -- By the end of this year the United Nations Institute for Training and Research will be in active operation, Gabriel d'Arboussier of Senegal, who has been appointed its executive director, predicted today.
A construction loan and permanent mortgage of $36 million has been arranged with the Chase Manhattan Bank for the 29-story office building planned as part of the new Madison Square Garden Center.
TARRYTOWN, N.Y., March 31 -- In a laboratory near here there are tarantulas, turtles, worms, cacti and other forms of earth life living, to varying degrees, within the assumed environment of Mars.

NEW HAVEN, March 31 -- The Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library at Yale University has acquired three manuscripts written in Europe between the seventh and tenth centuries. Herman W. Liebert, Beinecke librarian, said that the manuscripts "are of first importance for our teaching of paleography, the study of ancient modes of writing."
A campaign to halt the issuance of new liquorstore licenses was organized here yesterday by a group of civic, church and political leaders.
WASHINGTON, March 31 (UPI) -- Americans apparently are smoking more cigarettes now than they did before the Surgeon Gereral's report a year ago linking smoking with cancer and other diseases.
TANGIER, March 31 (AP) -- A chartered Iberia Airlines plane carrying tourists to a vacation in the mountain sun plunged into the Strait of Gibraltar today, killing 50 persons on board.
WASHINGTON, March 31 -- A resolution to permit a Government film about President Kennedy to be shown in this country was attacked by Republicans before House Rules Committee today.

WASHINGTON, March 31 (UPI) -- The House Rules Committee gave reluctant clearance today to a Senate-passed constitutional amendment on Presidential succession. The action came after members had assailed it as unwise, unworkable and a possible tool for a coup.
A woman without a country, who dreams of settling in Israel, arrived here yesterday for the second time in 17 days, headed this time for Paris.
In the insiders report issued yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange, Yale Express System, Inc., which has been having financial problems, was listed prominently.

SANTIAGO, Chile, March 31 -- The Chilean Government ordered a broad inquiry today into the possibility that a French-controlled copper company or mining safety authorities or both were negligent in the earthquake-triggered disaster that wiped out El Cobre workers' camp Sunday.

THE demand in the last several years for turn-of-the-century leaded glass lamps has reached such proportions that a number of lamp manufacturers have begun to mass-produce adaptations in both glass and plastic.

MOSCOW, March 31 -- Diplomats from a nonaligned country reported today that North Vietnamese officials had indicated that their Government might be willing to agree to a new Geneva conference on Indochina.
Employes of Bloomingdale's voted 1,318 to 380 last night to go on strike today. Picket lines will be posted at the store's main outlet in Manhattan and at its suburban branches.

YONKERS, Thursday, April 1 -- There will be harness racing at Yonkers Raceway tonight. Settlement of the mutuel clerks' strike, which caused a two-night shutdown of this Westchester County plant, was reached at 1:05 this morning, following nearly 30 hours of debate and deliberation.
ALBANY, March 31 -- New York City has scored two triumphs in the Assembly during the last two days that it has been seeking since early in the century.

The city's building trade unions have reported hiring of 2,916 nonwhites, mostly Negroes, as apprentices and journeymen during 1963 and 1964. Under Secretary of Labor John F. Henning said yesterday that this was "most encouraging for the future."
A man who was stabbed last July by a Queens secretary who was defending herself received a suspended sentence yesterday in the State Supreme Court in Queens.
ALBANY, March 31 -- Long Island bankers voiced strong opposition today to a bill before the Assembly that would allow commercial banks headquartered in Manhattan to open branches in Suffolk County.

SIXTEEN-YEAR-OLD Douglas Pader upset a strong 26-man field to score 8-1 and win the recent Marshall Club Candidates' Tournament. In this nine-round Swiss system, Pader topped his nearest rival by two points.

The seven-member Federal Reserve Board made public yesterday the resignation letter of Abbott L. Mills, who stepped down as a governor one month ago after serving as a "swing man" on several occasions.

TWENTY-FIVE years ago today Dr. Dean White of New York was founder of the Institute for Human-Animal Relationship, a national nonprofit organization with offices in New York and Washington. Its aim is to aid aged and physically handicapped persons through the ownership of pets.

The General Electric Company will ask its shareowners at the annual meeting on April 28 to create preferred stock that could be issued in series totaling as many as two million shares. It was explained in the proxy material that the directotrate believed it would be "in the best interests" of the company to establish authority for issuance of such preferred "in order to meet possible future developments.
" WHEN I was very young, I learned something I hope is true: that if I wiggled my little finger, it would affect the farthest star."

PARIS, March 31 -- President de Gaulle today made talks on political "cooperation" between leaders of the European Common Market conditional on a favorable outcome of negotiations on agricultural prices.
A COLD, but clear opening of the trout season, with generally excellent water conditions, appears in store for Central and Southern New York anglers who venture forth today.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 31 -- The Soviet Union asked today for a full-scale disarmament debate by the entire United Nations membership, 114 states, in early April. The debate would be held here in the Disarmament Commission, which last met in 1960.

The nation's gasoline stocks in the week ended last Friday increased 3,385,000 barrels, according to weekly figures released by the American Petroleum Institute. At the weekend, total supplies were at a record 232,164,000 barrels.
WASHINGTON, March 31 -- The United States gold loss in February was $215 million, Federal Reserve figures disclosed today.
CAMDEN, Ala., March 31 -About 120 Negro students demonstrating at the city limits here today were dispersed by policemen using smoke bombs. No one was hurt.

The Detroit Red Wings face the Chicago Black Hawks at Detroit and the Montreal Canadiens oppose the Toronto Maple Leafs at Montreal tonight in the opening games of the National Hockey League Stanley Cup playoffs.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- The Treasury made public today two extremely detailed proposed regulations dealing with the allocation, for tax purposes, of certain kinds of expenditures and income between corporations and their subsidiaries, specifically including foreign subsidiaries.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., March 31 -- Gov. Otto Kerner submitted his request today for a $4.4 billion biennial budget, including tax increases on cigarettes, public utilities, gasoline and horse racing.

Governor Rockefeller's proposal to reduce the statutory limit on Blue Cross administrative expenditures to 15 per cent of premium income, and Senator Thaler's counterproposal to impose stricter limits on Blue Cross administrative costs, are both beside the point.
Broadway-Hale Stores, Inc., a department store chain based in Los Angeles, will make a direct contact to the directors of Meier Frank, Portland, Ore., department store, to accept a new merger offer.

RIVER VALE, N.J., March 31 -- The conviction here last last night of a defendant on a drunken-driving charge paved the way for a definitive legal opinion on the use of movie films as evidence in such cases.

ANYONE with a queasy stomach should give a wide berth to "Mondo Pazzo," ("Insane World") the new Italian documentary at the Palace and other theaters. For that matter, this is one to avoid even if your digestion is in the best of shape.

Frustrated in its attempts to enforce the Fifteenth Amendment by the conventional arms in its legal arsenal, the Justice Department has brought forward its voting rights bill of 1965, a weapon as crude as a bull whip and as unselective as a tear-gas canister.

PARIS, March 31 -- A big French automobile company and a small German one -- Citroen and N.S.U. -- announced the creation of a joint subsidiary today to develop and produce an automobile with N.S.U.'s revolutionary Wankel engine.

" Yes, sir. She's the best filly I've ever trained," was Hirsch Jacobs' comment just after Affectionately had won the $27,550 Correction Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday. Affectionately, now a 5-year-old mare, had little trouble winning the stakes, covering the six furlongs in 1:11 while finishing two lengths in front of the runner-up.

" EVERYBODY felt at home there. Brooklyn people always swear allegiance to the store. It was never highfalutin,' but in a quiet way it always stood behind its things. It was first in our hearts -- the whole family shopped together.

The president of the State University of New York warned yesterday that a threatened $6.8 million budget cut would force him to turn away at least 1,000 students who would otherwise be admitted in September.

RED LANTERNS," which began to flicker fitfully yesterday at the 52d Street Trans-Lux and Rialto Theaters, is giving the world's oldest profession a distinct setback despite its millenniums of legend, glamour and success.
The World's Fair Corporation seized the Indonesian pavilion yesterday and notified the Indonesian Government that all its rights "to the premises are here-by terminated, effective immediately."

ERICH LEINSDORF is not one to present his Boston Symphony Orchestra in slight programs. Last night in Philharmonic Hall he began the organization's final set of New York appearances for the season with one of the meatiest of all concerts, and its interest lay in the arrangement and effect as much as in the music itself.
On-the-spot checks of sources of air contamination will be made this month by the City Council's Special committee to Investigate Air Pollution.

GREENSBORO, N.C., March 31 -- Tony Lema, the British Open champion, was fined $100 today "for conduct unbecoming a golf professional." The Professional Golfers' Association fined Lema for having failed to smooth his footprints after he had played from a bunker during the last round of the Tucson, Ariz., open Feb. 21.
WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP) -- President Johnson formally sent Congress legislation today to authorize a $510-million-a-year program to aid distressed areas.
STORRS, Conn., March 31 -- Fifty chanting students marched outside the Edwin O. Smith High School today carrying signs defending beards.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Secretary of the Treasury Douglas Dillon, who will terminate his Government service tomorrow, believes that the greatest unsolved problem he leaves behind him is the need to improve the International Monetary System.

A story that Theodore Dreiser and Hy Kraft wrote for a motion picture 30 years ago will reach the public in the form of a novel, "The Tobacco Men," written by Borden Deal, which Holt, Rinehart Winston will publish on May 17.

WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP) -- C.P. (Peck) Trussell, Pulitzer prize-winning reporter for The New York Times, tried to keep it a secret that today was his last day in harness after 48 years of journalism.
Even a traffic violator has constitutional rights that must be protected, the Appellatel Term, State Supreme Court, ruled in a decision filed yesterday in Brooklyn.

Those who complain about the high cost of concertgoing have only themselves to blame for not being at Town Hall last night. As it was, only about 400 took advantage of the complimentary admission to a fascinating program by the Colorado College Choir.

Olin Mathieson Chemical Corporation pleaded guilty yesterday in Federal Court to criminal fraud in obtaining foreign-aid financing on sale of drugs from its Squibb division to South Vietnam and Cambodia from 1958 to 1963.

PHILADELPHIA, March 31 (UPI) -- A brilliant all-round performance by Wilt Chamberlain tonight led the Philadelphia 76ers to a 119-112 victory over the Cincinnati Royals. The triumph sent the 76ers into the National Basketball Association's Eastern Division final playoffs against the Boston Celtics.

Harlan Cleveland, Assistant Secretary of State for International Organization Affairs, asserted last night that there was a role for the United Nations in any future settlement in Vietnam. He also suggested that the "good offices" of the Secretary General, U Thant, could be used in the case of Berlin.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Although movies are better than ever, movie-going has become a trial. This is probably because the idea of movies as art has become popularized among the middle class during the last few years; when the middle class finds itself confronted with art, it tends to go to pieces and make a misery of the whole business.

Assemblyman Hyman E. Mintz of Sullivan County was ordered yesterday to testify April 14 before a New York County grand jury investigating a bribe charge. Mr. Mintz has been described as a key witness in an alleged plot to secure a license at the Finger Lakes Race Track.

" I believe one thing that has kept us going in our three-year fight was the hope that somewhere, sometime we would find someone who would care," the letter said. "That was a futile hope until Thursday."

FORT-DE-FRANCE, Martinique, March 31 (AP) -- Two Portuguese sailors and a Martinique youth were convicted today of assault and theft in connection with the death of the American composer Marc Blitzstein.
TORONTO, March 31 -- Chrysler, Ltd., a subsidiary of the Chrysler Corporation, Detroit, is planning to make 80,000 vehicles at Windsor, Ont., for export to the United States next year.

Twelve hours after he had become the light-heavyweight champion of the world, Jose Torres challenged yesterday, in order, Muhammad Ali (Cassius Clay), the heavyweight champion; Joey Giardello, the middleweight champion, and Floyd Patterson, the former heavyweight champion.

The chief Federal supervisor of the savings-and-loan industry urged savings associations yesterday, particularly those in California, to resist any temptation to match dividend-rate increases just made by several associations.

GIBRALTAR, March 27 -- Spain's campaign against Britain's control of Gibraltar reflects in part her desire to extend her influence in North Africa, particularly in Morocco, according to qualified observers here.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- There are several reasons for the instant and widespread repudiation of the demand by Martin Luther King on all segments of the American society to isolate the people of Alabama in a kind of national leprosarium.

Floyd Patterson slipped quietly into Madison Square Garden Tuesday night. He wore a false mustache and a goatee, a slouch hat, large eyeglasses, and a dirty blue coat. He stood in the balcony behind thousands of spectators. Nobody recognized him.

The president of the typographical union here said yesterday that the printers achieved a significant "breakthrough" on the money issue during a tension-ridden round of contract negotiations at City Hall.
CANNES, France, March 31 (UPI) -- Three of the top-seeded players were eliminated today in the Cannes international tennis tournament.
ALBANY, March 31 -- A former New York City deputy treasurer, who was dismissed because he could not explain $56,500 in a "tin box," is working here as a committee clerk.
The stock market went through another quiet trading session yesterday, but managed to close with slightmore gains than losses.
WASHINGTON, March 31 -- The Senate Armed Services Committee resumed today a campaign in Congress for a new manned bomber, which the Administration has opposed.

PARIS, March 31 -- Under Secretary of State George W. Ball and Foreign Minister Maurice Couve de Murville conferred tonight on the Middle Eastern situation and progress toward European political unity.

In a letter published March 21 Alexander Rudzinski asks the question whether there is a difference between "negotiations" by aerial bombings and an undeclared war waged in flagrant violation of international law. As I understand it, the United States has finally established a policy to extend the war into North Vietnam by intensive bombardment of economic and military objectives and to force the Hanoi Government to sue for peace.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 31 -- Bobby Bragan is a man with an original turn of mind, a lack of inhibition for expressing his ideas and a talent for landing in only slightly tenable situations.
The Contemporary Chamber Players of the University of Chicago will play at Carnegie Recital Hall tonight at 8:30. Ralph Shapey will conduct, with Neva Pilgrim, soprano, and Irving Ilmer, violist.

Capt. Leonard H. Johnston, soft-spoken and stocky senior master of the Canadian Pacific Steamships fleet, took the liner Empress of Canada out of port yesterday afternoon on his final voyage of a 43-year career at sea.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -The Securities and Exchange Commission has proposed to Congress that the fee it charges registrants of new securities be doubled -- from 1/100th of one per cent of the maximum offering price to 1/50th. The minimum fee for a registration would, at the same time, be raised from $25 to $100.

GENEVA, March 31 -- The battle cry "Geneva is in danger" is being sounded by both the supporters and opponents of a bill to set up a foundation to help make office space available to international organizations.
WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Administration leaders won the House Rules Committee's cooperation today in a drive for House action next week on medical care for the aged.

WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP) -- Officials of Merchant Marine organizations said today a proposal to close seven of the 12 Public Health Service hospitals was part of a campaign by the Budget Bureau to remove all such facilities.
New York City is faced with a budget emergency as a result of inaction by Democratic legislative leaders on Governor Rockefeller's $3.49 billion budget.

Peter Castellana was arraigned yesterday in Brooklyn on a nine-count indictment charging income-tax fraud from 1959 through 1961. The alleged fraud was estimated to have cost the Government more than $100,000.

Faced with mounting complaints about the rapid rise in hospital insurance charges, Blue Cross has proposed a basic change in its billing method in the metropolitan area. It wants to shift to an experience-rating system, under which the rate for each group of subscribers would vary up or down in terms of how much its members used hospitals.

Thomas H. Quinn is a New Yorker in love with his city. He likes the World's Fair, too, and thinks everyone should support it. And, as a businessman in New York, he's not averse to having these feelings advertised.
ROME, March 31 -- Pope Paul VI has made further revisions in Holy Week prayers to eliminate degrading references to Jews and atheists.
WASHINGTON, March 31--The House passed today a bill to create all administration on aging and give it $17.5 million for long-range planning to help those over 65 years old.

WASHINGTON, March 31 (UPI) -- New factory orders, a key indicator of future business activity, declined slightly in February from their record level in January, the Commerce Department reported today. The total for February was $39.6 billion, seasonally adjusted, down from the revised $39.7 billion for the preceding month.
WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP) -- The National Guard is having difficulty getting Negro recruits in Northern as well as Southern states, officials said today.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, March 31 -- President Sukarno announced a Cabinet shuffle today that severely weakened the position of two leading anti-Communist ministers and strengthened that of Foreign Minister Subandrio and the Indonesian Communist party.

The report on Cyprus of United Nations mediator Galo Plaza comes at an opportune moment. He does not claim to have brought the contending forces -- Greek Cypriote, Turkish Cypriote, Greece and Turkey -- any closer, but he makes a sensible proposal. This is for the parties to get together and negotiate, rather than quarrel and sometimes fight.

WALTHAM, Mass., March 31 -- Henry Cabot Lodge asserted tonight that the war in Vietnam could be won if the United States did not "play into the enemy's hands by counting on a quick, sensational and easy way out."
WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Communist China has embarked on a new diplomatic offensive in Africa, Asia and the Middle East, apparently to try to undermine Soviet influence.

PITTSBURGH, March 31--Steelworkers, who are among the highest paid workers in the nation, have demanded that the basic steel industry increase their wages and benefits by nearly $1 an hour in the next three years.
The Transport Workers Union proposed yesterday that a policeman, extra conductor and alarm system be added to every subway train to reduce crime.

BRADENTON, Fla., March 31 -- The New York Yankees ended their losing streak at four games today and returned to Fort Lauderdale by bus after a one-week road trip on which they distinguished themselves chiefly by beating only the New York Mets and Kansas City Athletics.

A COMMITTEE of leaders in advertising, commercial broadcasting, publishing and industry has been formed to explore ways of popularizing and stimulating educational television. One of the matters the group will consider is whether the phrase "educational TV" could not be abandoned in favor of a descriptive identification that might be more enticing.

The winter birds have begun to sing again, and before long the migrants, which include the real virtuosos, will be here and making the mornings loud with music. Spring will arrive full of melody and even the casual listener will be aware of it.
The new British jetliner -- the Super VC-10 -- will enter trans-Atlantic passenger service today.

WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP) -- One of the two persons listed as American dead in the bombing of the United States Embassy in Saigon yesterday was a Filipino serving in the Navy, the Defense Department said today.
To the horror of a late afternoon crowd in search of cabs and cocktails, and to the delight of hundred of children, 18 elephants marched through Manhattan yesterday on their way to the circus.
An art gallery in the West Side Urban Renewal area may one day be a reality, but meanwhile a new day-care center is substituting to give the community its first art show.

Early morning jazz, a radio rarity, arrives on the scene here this morning when station WRVR begins broadcasting Ed Beach's "Just Jazz" from 7 to 9 A.M. Jack D. Summerfield, general manager of the station, said the switching from late afternoon to a wake-up hour was not an April Fool joke and that it would be on each morning, Monday through Friday.
The American predicament in Vietnam now is one for which the French have a word. It is "engrenage," which roughly translated means getting caught in a massive set of moving gears.
LONDON, March 31 -- The Government issued masses of economic statistics today that were immediately seen as pointers to a deflationary budget next Tuesday.
The International Terminal Operating Company, a leading stevedoring and materials handling concern announced the appointment of three executives to new posts as vice presidents.
Prices of Maine potato futures continued their recent strong gains yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange, where trading volume remained near record levels.

PARIS, April 1 -- On the Left Bank of the Seine the Literary elite at the Academie Francaise talked about gold this afternoon as they bestowed membership on Jacques Rueff, the economist. Mr. Rueff is sure that gold is the only sound base for the world's money.

The method of selecting subscription shows for the road by the Council of the Living Theater in conjunction with the combined Theater Guild-American Theater Society was attacked yesterday by two Broadway producers, Herman Shumlin and Robert Weiner.
The New York Giants, in keeping with the rest of the National Football League clubs, will start their home games at 1:30 P.M. this season, half an hour earlier than in previous years.
BONN, April 1 -- Chancellor Ludwig Erhard of West Germany paid tribute today to a famous predecessor -- Prince Otto von Bismarck, the Iron Chancellor of the Second German Reich.
Corporate and Government bond prices marked time, New Haven Railroad bonds dropped sharply and new municipal bond issues got off to a slow start yesterday.

It isn't that the Long Island Rail Road wants more commuters; there's hardly enough bar-car space now for all the Dashing Dans. It's just that the railroad wants to be loved as much in the off hours as it is in the rush hours.

SYDNEY, Australia, April 1 (Comtelburo) -- The Reserve Bank of Australia has freed about 24 million Australian pounds ($53.76 million) from the statutory reserve deposits of the major trading banks to give the banks the necessary liquidity to meet a drain on funds expected over the next few months.

A team of acrobats and a Noah's Arkload of animals soared and bounded around Madison Square Garden last night to start the Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus on a run that will extend through May 9.
Helena Rubinstein, the multimillionaire beauty expert and cosmetics manufacturer, died early yesterday morning in New York Hospital, where she had been admitted on Tuesday night.

GREENSBORO, N.C., April 1 -- Despite 30-degree temperature, Tommy Aaron shot a five-under-par 66 today to lead the $65,000 Greater Greensboro open by one stroke. The cold at the Sedgefield Country Club affected spectators, players and the course.

WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP) -- A bill to extend the manpower Training and Development Act until 1968 and liberalize its training programs and allowances was passed by the House today. The vote was 392 to 0.
Senator J. William Fulbright of Arkansas took the Senate floor yesterday to complain, in a speech mixing sarcasm with vitriol, that this newspaper had done his state gross injustice.
Mayor Wagner has thrown his support behind present plans for an $80 million Federal office building on Foley Square.

HAVANA, April 1 - The information media of Premier Fidel Castro's regime gave prominence today to a statement that it was "ready to reestablish diplomatic and commercial relations with the United States."

Your opposition [editorial March 24] to current legislative moves to raise the statutory minimum wages in New York State is apparently based on some misconception. There is no evidence that raising the minimum to $1.50 will encourage the "flight to New Jersey, Pennsylvania and the South of garment factories and other light manufacturing industries."

CAMDEN, N.J., April 1 -- The Camden County Young Republican Club has praised Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama for his "struggle against continued Federal encroachment into the private lives of the American citizenry."

Herman Kahn, the physicist-strategist, has written "On Escalation: Metaphors and Scenarios," a book about the danger of nuclear war, which Praeger will publish on May 17. Mr. Kahn suggests that there is an "escalation ladder" of which "the various rungs might be thought of as tactical options to be chosen when one side is trying to negotiate with and persuade another."
Police dogs will be used to combat crime in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn by members of a civilian patrol group created Thursday evening.
A young man accused of plotting to sell a million-dollar secret plan of one major company to its greatest rival was indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury.

YONKERS, April 1 -- The strike of the mutuel clerks at Yonkers Raceway having been settled in the wee hours of the morning, the stage was set tonight for the chalk-players to have a ball tonight at the Westchester County harness racing plant.
LONDON, April 1 -- Britain moved a step forward in social welfare today with the introduction of a bill in the House of Commons to set up a compensation plan for displaced workers.
CHICAGO, April 1 -- Depression that leads to thoughts of suicide appears to be most intense on Wednesday nights, The Journal of the American Medical Association said today.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., April 1 -- The sixth annual Florence Brevoort Kane Memorial Exhibition of the Providence Art Club opened here yesterday and will continue through April 24 with 78 exhibits of contemporary painting and sculpture.
Following is the text of President Johnson's news conference in Washington yesterday afternoon as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of A.B.C. News.

CHICAGO, April 1 -- Armour Co., the second largest meatpacking company in the United States, announced today that its directors had approved in principle a diversification move to acquire the Baldwin-Lima-Hamilton Corporation.
WASHINGTON, April 1 (UPI) -- A Federal Communications Commission official recommended today that news media using private leased wires be required to pay increased rates.
WASHINGTON, April 1 -- President Johnson jokingly disclosed today that, like many other Americans, he had had to borrow money to pay his current income taxes.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 1 -- The United States Government seems to be showing a little more interest in using the United Nations in any future talks about a peaceful settlement of the war in Vietnam.
The Communist forces in South Vietnam have organized five regimental commands, according to information reaching Washington.

Two prides of St. Louis -- Washington University's Choir and its Madrigal Singers -- came to Town Hall last night. Capably guided by Orland Johnson, they made a fine impression in a varied, generally ambitious program.
WASHINGTON, April 1 (UPI) -- Retail sales gained 2 per cent last week and totaled $5 billion, the Commerce Department reported today.
The Martin-Marietta Corporation announced yesterday it had offered to buy stock from its shareholders at $22 a share.
A gala dinner will be held at the Delmonico Restaurant, 56 Beaver Street, on April 10 for the benefit of the Casa Italiana of Columbia University.
CARDIFF, Wales, April 1 -- One of Britain's most famous ballets, Ninette de Valois's "The Haunted Ballroom," was given a new production by London's Festival Ballet here tonight.

President Johnson is not the only taxpayer who will borrow to pay taxes this year. Millions who are accustomed to receiving refunds will have to send checks with their tax returns because the withholding rate for 1964 was cut more than the tax schedule.

VIENTIANE, Laos, April 1 (AP) -- The National Congress approved a constitutional amendment today empowering the King to select a new assembly or to extend the terms of incumbents in case elections cannot be held. The vote was 41 to 5.
WASHINGTON, April 1 -- The $1.3 billion school-aid bill cleared a Senate subcommittee without change today, marking another major victory for President Johnson.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee rejected today President Johnson's request for authorization to use any amount of military-assistance funds that might be required for South Vietnam beyond the basic program.
WASHINGTON, April 1 -- The heads of state of 17 nonaligned countries appealed today for immediate negotiations "without any preconditions" for a political solution of the war in Vietnam.

WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP) -- The Oil Import Administration announced today that the maximum residual fuel oil import level for the area east of the Rocky Mountains for the year beginning today would be on a basis of 755,000 barrels daily.

EMMITSBURG, Md., April 1 (AP) -- A conflict over changes in Roman Catholic doctrine developed today between a priest at tiny Mount St. Mary's Seminary here and Lawrence Cardinal Shehan of Baltimore, a leading Catholic advocate of Christian unity.
The ranks of Wall Street runners are slowly thinning and an automation advance later this year may speed up the process.
WASHINGTON, April 1 -- An attempt to put a nuclear reactor into orbit for the first time is planned for Saturday at Vandenberg Air Force Base in California.

Columbia's baseball team scored in double figures for the second consecutive day yesterday when it routed the University of Vermont, 13-2, at Baker Field. The Lions beat Trinity, 11-2, in their season opener Wednesday.

ALBANY, April 1 (AP) -- A high school senior, described as "brilliant" by authorities, has admitted rigging a booby trap designed to blow up an automobile belonging to one of his teachers, the state police said today.
The Columbia Broadcasting System's schedule of National Football League games to be televised over Channel 2 in New York:
THE chances of skiing for Easter were rated good yesterday by New England's area operators, whose hopes for a late season have been buoyed by recent low temperatures and occasional snowfalls.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., April 1 (UPI) -- Romeo Trudeau of Montreal, the Canadian senior champion, upset Bud McKinney of Dallas, the medal winner, 1 up, today to win the Ponce de Leon senior golf championship.
The Republic of Venezuela disclosed yesterday that it planned to make its first bond sale in the world's capital markets since before World War I.

NAIROBI, Kenya, April 1 -- Kenya's House of Representatives was thrown into an uproar today when a member demanded that the Government put a stop to the smuggling of weapons into the country lest it be drawn into a revolution or be cast into an external war.
BOSTON, April 1 -- Eastern Airlines is planning to revert to conventional reservation flights between Boston and Washington, beginning April 25. This will replace the present shuttle service.
WASHINGTON, April 1 -- President Johnson indicated coolness today to the suggestion for an economic boycott of Alabama, but withheld final judgment on the plan. [Question 2, Page 18.]

WITH his current visit to the Middle East, Communist China's peripatetic Premier, Chou En-lai, is adding to an already long list of travels. The personable, 66-year-old leader has missed few world capitals since he first went to Moscow in 1928 for the sixth national congress of the then outlawed Chinese Communist party.
LONDON, April 1 -- "It's voluntary, but it works," thus an American banker in London described the recent action by President Johnson to curb the dollar outflow from the United States.
The Kaiser Jeep Corporation announced yesterday that it would offer an eight-cylinder engine on its Jeep family of vehicles for the first time.

Eight new silver and green buses with 35-foot-long metal signs mounted above the passenger window have been seen in the last week on Broadway, Fifth Avenue, Madison Avenue, St. Nicholas Avenue and on 42d Street.

A 19-year-old premedical student at Adelphi College, Garden City, L.I., was arrested last night on homicide charges following the rifle slaying of his father early in the morning at their Brooklyn apartment.

IT was during a luncheon honoring Lenny Moore of the Baltimore Colts that the idea came to Frank Gifford, a thoughtful and considerate guy. The recently retired Giant backfield wizard mentioned it casually to Carroll Rosenbloom, owner of the Colts, and that was all that was needed.

Two accountants and the operator of a travel agency were named in separate indictments yesterday by a Federal grand jury on charges of preparing false income tax returns for their clients. They were said to have cheated the Government of more than $1 million.
Thousands of air travelers around the world felt the full impact yesterday of a pilots' strike against Pan American World Airways. The walkout over terms of a new contract began at 7 P.M. Wednesday.
WASHINGTON, April 1 -- The national unemployment rate dropped last month to its lowest point in more than seven years, the Labor Department said today.

The Textile Research Institute at its annual meeting yesterday conferred its highest award, honorary fellowship, on Dr. Eugene Pacsu of Princeton University and Emery I. Valko of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
PITTSBURGH, April 1 (AP) -- The basic steel industry conferred today on what it considers exorbitant contract demands by the United Steelworkers of America.
The first Negro apprentice in the 77-year-old history of Local 28, Sheet Metal Workers International Association, was appointed yesterday after three white candidates dropped out.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, April 1 (AP) -- Professors at Robert College, America's oldest overseas college, are irritated by a security check required by the United States Government.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 1 -- Indications increased today that U Thant might be willing to undertake a direct role in trying to negotiate peace for Vietnam.

The Avenue of the Americas Association, whose members have been trying vainly for two decades to get people to call Sixth Avenue by its rightful name, yesterday presented Rip Van Winkle awards to individuals and organizations that have clung tenaciously to the old designation.

PITTSBURGH, April 1 (UPI) -- The Consolidation Coal Company's towboats, idled today by a strike of three maritime unions, were back in operation tonight after union leaders decided their owners were "bargaining in good faith."
Taxpayers who sharpen their wits as well as their pencils may find money-saving surprises when they fill out their tax returns.
The appointments of three divisional presidents as executive vice presidents of the McCrory Corporation were announced yesterday by Meshulam Riklis, chairman of the retailing organization.
ANNE KLEIN returned to the fashion world Wednesday, when she showed her first collection of leather and suede styles for Mallory.

The New Jersey Supreme Court has just read the State Legislature a salutary lesson. It has in effect told the lawmakers that they cannot dodge an unpleasant or difficult duty and that the court will not perform it for them. That is the meaning of its rejection of the State Senate's plea for a two-year postponement of legislative reapportionment.

LONDON, April 1 (AP) -- With her children and grandchildren around her, Lady Churchill celebrated her 80th birthday today at a luncheon party. The desert was Sir Winston's favorite, strawberries and cream.
A buoyant man sat in an office at the Astor Hotel yesterday and talked of the things he would allow as ingredients in a true Hungarian goulash. The list went on until another man broke in.

KABUL, Afghanistan, April 1 (AP) -- The Chinese Embassy in Kabul denied today that Peking was obstructing Soviet efforts to send aid to North Vietnam overland through China.
WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP) -- President Johnson, 56 years old and with at least three years to go in the White House, has decided what he would like to do in retirement.

THE third and last program of the Contemporary Chamber Music Players of the University of Chicago was given last night in Carnegie Recital Hall. In a way it was the most interesting of all, as it gave an insight into the orientation of the group and of its musical director, Ralph Shapey.

MONTREAL, April 1 -- The Government of Quebec announced last night plans to build a $225 million steel complex at Becancour on the south shore of the St. Lawrence River, less than 100 miles southeast of Montreal.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 1 -- The southern tip of Welfare Island, now a wasteland of abandoned buildings and weed-covered lots, has been offered as a site for a new building for the United Nations International School.

Expenditures exceeding $10 million for a major program of modernization, expansion and technology advancement for nitrogen and methanol operations were announced yesterday by the Commercial Solvents Corporation at its annual stockholder meeting in Sterling, La.
WE should all look as well at 77 as Maurice Chevalier does. We should all be as lively, as radiant, possessed of the same brisk step and abounding joie de vivre.

Robert W. Farrell, former editor and publisher of the old Brooklyn Eagle, announced yesterday he would begin publishing a new tabloid called The Sunday Mirror this weekend, with a guaranteed press run of more than 150,000 copies.
WASHINGTON, April 1 (UPI) -- The House Appropriations Committee disclosed today that the Secret Service had a file of 130,000 names of persons considered potentially dangerous to the President.

The Vatican's announcement of changes in Holy Week prayers that referred to the conversion of Jews met with little public response from Jewish leaders here yesterday.
TRENTON, April 1 -- Gov. Richard J. Hughes ordered today a preliminary engineering study to draw guidelines for a "major expansion" of the New Jersey Turnpike.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., April 1 -- Terrorists planted three more dynamite bombs in this tense city early today. One exploded and injured a Negro teen-ager, not seriously.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., April 1 -- Whitey Ford was pronounced fit today after two days of medical tests and was named to pitch the opening game of the New York Yankees' weekend trip to Puerto Rico on Saturday.

The pound sterling has been subject to a renewed spell of weakness, stemming chiefly from foreign skepticism about Britain's ability to refurbish her economic structure. The British have made some progress, but must do a great deal more to close the gap of over $2 billion in their annual balance of payments.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 1 -- South Vietnamese Government forces and the Vietcong were locked in battle today 25 miles south of the airbase at Danang. It was the biggest clash since the regular bombings of North Vietnam began Feb. 7.
An apprentice butcher and a gypsy cab driver were charged yesterday with the Saturday night slaying of three butchers in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn.
The Racquet and Tennis Club led Queens Club of London, 6-2, last night after the first day in their international court tennis match.

NEW HAVEN, April 1 -- Roy Saari of Southern California tried to achieve a masochistic one-day swimming double today as the Amateur Athletic Union's 41st annual national indoor championships opened at Yale. He failed by a foot.

THERE were some strange goings on last night at The Bridge, the freshly painted playhouse at St. Marks Place, where two one-act plays opened. And, no daffier characters could possibly have been involved -- off or on Broadway.
The merger trend may adversely affect the small business community, Eugene P. Foley, administrator of the Small Business Administration, said in the S.B.A.'s annual report, released yesterday.
MONTPELLIER, France April 1 -- The French wine that Americans drink comes from Burgundy, Bordeaux, Alsace and Champagne.

ALBANY, April 1 -- After another long and futile debate in the Senate, Republican leader Earl W. Brydges said today that if the budget impasse lasted much longer, the Republicans might step in and try to resolve it.

BREWSTER, N.Y., April 1 -- Three small miscreants, the oldest no more than 11 years old and the youngest about 8, hopped from one rock to another in the east branch of the Croton River today, their fishing rods flying.
Prices on the London Stock Exchange continued to edge upward yesterday for the fourth consecutive day.

PARIS -- The era of the platinum blonde was relived for a night in Paris. Regine, the cabaret hostess who occupies a position similar to that held by Texas Guinan in Prohibition New York, celebrated the second anniversary of her smart-set boite, New Jimmy's, on the Boulevard Montparnasse, with a party attended by 250.
BERKELEY, Calif., April 1 -- A mass trial of 155 of the University of California's free speech demonstrators of early December opened today.

PARIS, April 1 -- Jean-Paul Sartre, who canceled a lecture tour in the United States two weeks ago for what he described as political reasons, has amplified his attacks on American policies in Vietnam and has linked them to racial upheavals in the United States.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- Barry Goldwater, whose Senate vote aginst the 1964 civil rights act was a factor in his losing campaign for the Presidency, took an even darker view today of new voting rights legislation.

WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP) -- Billie Sol Estes appealed to the United States Supreme Court today to reverse his conviction on swindling charges because his trial had been conducted before television cameras. And his attorneys went beyond this complaint of the former promoter from West Texas in asking the Court to prohibit photography or broadcasting in all criminal trials throughout the land.

A spokesman for the Indonesian Foreign Ministry said yesterday that Indonesia might decide to give its "beautiful World's Fair pavilion" to the people of the United States.

MOSCOW, April 1 -- The Soviet press continued today its denunciation of American actions in Vietnam. But many Western diplomats thought they detected an air of embarrassment or even indecision behind the barrage of harsh words.

The British pound gained slightly in active trading on foreign exchange markets here yesterday. The final spot quotation was $2.7908, up 4 points from Wednesday's closing level.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 1 -- At the Saigon Airport chapel this morning the South Vietnamese Foreign Minister, Tran Van Do, pinned medals of gallantry and honor on the coffins of an American woman and a Filipino serving in the Navy who were killed in the terrorist attack on the United States Embassy Tuesday.
OSAKA, Japan, March 26 -- Leading businessmen in this industrial region of western Japan are impatient with the cautious policy of Premier Eisaku Sato on trade with Communist China.

Mayor Wagner asked yesterday that a sixth-grade education be allowed as proof of literacy, for voting purposes. The New York State law since 1923 has permitted literacy to be established by proof of an eighth-grade education.

THE CAVENDISH CLUB, perhaps the most famous bridge club in the world, will move to new quarters at 23 Central Park South tomorrow.
