The cosmetics manufacturer made 121 individual bequests, ranging from $500 to $250,000, to relatives, friends, business associates and employes here and abroad.
Prices on the London stock exchange were firm yesterday at the close of a week of modest gains.

WHAT Neimam-Marcus is to the affluent adult, F.A.O. Schwarz aims to be for the younger set. Its latest acquisition for the teen-ager who is too young to drive but lusts for a license is a six-foot version of the Ford Lotus, the stripped-down racing car of Indianapolis Speedway, Watkins Glen and Grand Prix fame.

SYDNEY, Australia, April 2 -- Bob Hayes, the world's fastest human, was in good form today and thinks he will make $500 tomorrow in a little less than 10 seconds by winning a 100-yard sprint against four Australian runners.

ALBANY, April 2 -- Strong pleas from governors and other officials of nearby states were made to New York legislators today to raise the minimum drinking age from 18 to 21 to cut down fatal drunken-driving accidents.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 2 -- Twenty-three American scholars signed a petition here today urging President Johnson to take the initiative in calling for peace in Vietnam.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- The Administration decided today upon an increase in men, money and equipment for South Vietnam to offset the growing strength of the Vietcong insurgents and to increase the pressure upon North Vietnam for a diplomatic settlement.
CHICAGO, April 2 (AP) -- The nation's traffic toll has taken its first monthly drop in 25 months.

HONG KONG, April 2 -- The Chinese Communist Government announced today that a pilotless United States reconnaissance plane shot down over China had been placed on public display in a military museum in Peking. It also gave a description of the plane.
CHICAGO, April 2 -- Remains of completely different three forms of primitive manlike creatures have been found in the same layer of a African hillside.
SAIGON, Saturday, April 3 (AP) -- Fighter-bombers rained tons of napalm today on guerrilla-infested swamplands 20 miles west of Saigon in a battle that has already taken four American lives.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 2 -- The Secretary General, U Thant, has asked the help of Britain, the United States, Norway and Sweden for an emergency program to educate and train young South Africans.
Maine potato futures prices again were higher yesterday, closing out an extremely active trading week.

Shipmasters in the North Atlantic were advised yesterday by the Coast Guard's International Ice Patrol to keep a sharp lookout and a wide berth of the first iceberg of the current season to drift into trans-Atlantic shipping lanes.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 2 -- United States officials have urged South Vietnamese authorities to tighten security throughout Saigon instead of greatly increasing guards around United States offices.

A former patient at the Jewish Memorial Hospital, who was critically injured in the three-car accident involving Gareth Martinis, learned yesterday that he had been elected the new president of the hospital.

Hill Wang will start off the publishing baseball season on April 14 by tossing out "The American League Story" and "The National League Story," both by Lee Allen. These are editions updated since original publication four years ago.

HALLANDALE, Fla., April 2 (UPI) -- Maj. Albert Warner's big gray colt, Native Charger, heads a field of nine for tomorrow's $100,000-added Florida Derby at Gulfstream Park, the last Florida prep for the Triple Crown -- the Kentucky Derby, the Preakness and the Belmont Stakes.

YONKERS, April 2 -- Harry's Laura, a 5-year-old mare, and George Sholty, her 32-year-old driver, had one thing in common tonight at Yonkers Raceway. Each found the winner's circle for the first time during the meeting, but it wasn't an easy chore for either.
NEW HAVEN, April 2 -- The last time Don Schollander swam in a championship meet, he won four gold medals in the Olympics. He returned to big-time competition tonight and looked as good as ever.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- Secretary of the Interior Stewart L. Udall said today that he would recommend to President Johnson the elimination of import quotas on the heavy-fuel oil used to fire electric utilities and large heating units.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 2 -- Former Vice President Richard M. Nixon said today that President Johnson had erred seriously in his initial handling of questions about the use of nonlethal gas in South Vietnam.
ATLANTA, April 2 (AP) -- A three-judge Federal court has given the Georgia Legislature three more years to complete re-apportionment.
WASHINGTON, April 2 (AP) -- Webster's New International Dictionary defines "American" as "any native or inhabitant of America; a citizen of the United States."
NAIROBI, Kenya, April 2 -- The role of Communist China in Kenya was discussed in Parliament today during a debate on arms smuggling.
KYOTO, Japan, March 29 -- This ancient temple city is trying to modernize gracefully without destroying a serene dignity that dates back 1,100 years.

The Federal Communications Commission has informed WNDT (Channel 13) that it has no objections to the New York educational station's proposal to initiate a new concept in the underwriting of programs by business corporations.

The spiritual leader of the Catholic Traditionalist Movement, despite an admonition from his church superior, maintained yesterday that Roman Catholic churchgoers had been "brainwashed" into accepting liturgical reforms promulgated by the Ecumenical Council.
" How come you guys know where it is?" a spokesman for Mayor Wagner exclaimed yesterday when told that the carefully hidden statue of Cuban hero Jose Marti had been photographed.
WASHINGTON, April 2 (AP) -- The American Farm Bureau Federation opposed today the creation of a Federal department of housing and urban development.

CRYSTAL MOUNTAIN, Wash., April 2 (UPI) -- European skiers demonstrated their superiority again today when France's Leo Lacroix and Christl Haas of Austria placed first in the downhill races in the national Alpine ski championships, but foreign competitors are not eligible for United States titles.
An improved tone prevailed in the stock market yesterday and prices advanced for the fourth consecutive day, with trading the heaviest of the week.
WASHINGTON, April 2 -- Representative Powell was honored, financially as well as personally, tonight at what an aide described as "a small private party."
WASHINGTON, April 2 -- The index of primary-market prices was unchanged at 101.3 (1957-59 equals 100) during the week ended March 30, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.
Churchgoers have been asked to pray tomorrow for the unity of American Protestantism.

The sixth annual musicale and dance in behalf of the Austrian student fellowship fund at the Graduate School of Business of Columbia University will be held Monday in the Trianon Ballroom of the New York Hilton.
The race quickened yesterday between two department store chains seeking control of the Meier Frank Company, Oregon's leading retailer.
LAHORE, Pakistan, April 21 (Reuters) -- Pakistan, put in to bat on a rain-soaked wicket, scored 176 runs for five wickets on the first day of the second cricket test match against New Zealand today.
The happy relations between the United States and Mexico have been strengthened by a triumph of what Mexicans hail as the "new diplomacy."
A grand jury investigation of the police in connection with the discredited confession of George Whitmore Jr. for the 1963 murders of Janice Wylie and Emily Hoffert was demanded yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- The Presidency is pinning a medal on a general, hearing two troubadours, lending a bed to an evangelical preacher, lending an ear to an ambassador in crisis and throwing a surprise party for a Congressional crony.

Mayor Wagner has decided to gain political favor with his Spanish-speaking supporters by hitchhiking a ride on the voting rights bill. His letter to the leaders of the State Legislature urging lower voting standards in New York is based on a misconception and can only produce confusion.

The Merchant Marine Institute has asked the Treasury Department to establish a system under which United States ship operators could buy and use Government-held foreign currencies amassed as a result of surplus disposal programs and other foreign assistance programs.
PITTSBURGH, April 2 (UPI) -- Steel contract negotiators met for two hours this morning but canceled a scheduled afternoon session to give the industry time to digest the union's demands.

BONN, April 2 -- Communist East Germany, with apparent Soviet backing, has begun a program of anticipatory reprisals against a scheduled meeting of the West German Parliament in West Berlin next week.

The impending proxy fight between the Pure Oil Company and dissident stockholders was called off yesterday when management agreed to place a member of the holders' group on its own slate of nominees for the board.

SANTIAGO, Chile, April 2 -- United States military transport planes began today an airlift of blankets and tents to Chile to help provide shelter for the 250,000 people left homeless by Sunday's earthquake.

LONDON, April 2 (UPI) -- Ed Trippe of New York, the Oxford strok, was warned today not to let Cambridge out of his sight when the universities meet tomorrow on the River Thames in their 111th boat race.
Retrial of George Coughlin, 28-year-old vacuum cleaner salesman accused of assaulting a switchboard operator last year, was set yesterday for June 9.

CARACAS, Venezuela, April 2 -- Vice Admiral Wolfgang Larrazabal, former President, and other opposition leaders blamed the Government of President Raul Leoni today for the killing of one man and the wounding of 20 yesterday during the suppression of an anti-Government demonstration.
WASHINGTON, April 2 -- Agreement was reached today on a formula for a second means of application in the voting rights bill.

LINDENHURST, L.I., April 2 -- More than 400 policemen today rounded up 40 persons suspected of forming the nucleus of a $4-million-a-year narcotics ring that has been supplying 1,000 addicts in Suffolk and Nassau Counties.
MOSCOW, April 2 -- The Soviet Union's leaders are likely to ignore President Johnson's latest invitation to visit the United States.

OTTAWA, April 2 (AP) -- Paul Hellyer, the Defense Minister, announced today the scrapping of the $227 million Mid-Canada Warning Line, which a retired air force officer had once described as a "colossal blunder."

KARACHI, Pakistan, April 2 -- Premier Chou En-lai of Communist China arrived in Karachi from Algiers this afternoon for a one-day official visit with President Mohammad Ayub Khan and other Pakistani leaders.
An 18-year-old college dropout was held yesterday without bail on a homicide charge in the slaying of his druggist father in their Brooklyn apartment early Thursday.
SUITA, Japan, March 28 -- Big new housing projects and satellite city developments, like the mammoth Senri New Town here, are bringing revolutionary changes to traditional Japanese ways of life.

SURRENDERING a cheap trick to opponents, whether by declarer or defenders, can he a holdup play or a duck. The mechanics are the same, but the aim is different. The holdup is intended to cut the opponents' communications, while the duck is intended to preserve one's own.

The Savings Bank of Rockland County, the first new savings bank in New York State in 35 years, opens today in Monsey a hamlet between Spring Valley and Suffern. It also is the first savings bank in the county.
WASHINGTON, April 2 -- The International Business Machines Corporation received a patent this week for its most capacious computer memory.
MONTREAL, April 2 (UPI) -- Punch Imlach, still fuming about the officials, "from top to bottom," vowed today his Toronto Maple Leafs would "play it as hard as we can, as long as we can."

Legislation recently introduced in the New York Legislature states that in all cases where a confession is to be used as a basis for an indictment either a judge or a defense attorney must be present during the questioning of a suspect leading to the confession.
BALTIMORE, April 2 -- The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. today urged the nation's business community to suspend immediately all plant expansion and location in Alabama.
LONDON, April 2 -- Britain has asked the governments of 11 countries to submit ideas on ending the war in Vietnam.

PALM BEACH, April 2 -- Jose Ferrex, who won a 1950 Academy Award for his moving soliloquies in the film "Cyrano de Bergerac," opened the Florida Arts Festival last night in a role that did not call for a single line.
New cars from the United States and from eight foreign countries, accessories, gadgets, safety exhibits and a smattering of special items filled the Coliseum yesterday.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., April 2 -- A stay preventing the State Liquor Authority from going through with its plan to issue new package store licenses has been granted here in State Supreme Court.

The Franklin National Bank of Mineola, L.I., reported yesterday net operating earnings of $2,359,503, or 62 cents a share, for the first three months of 1965. This compared with earnings of $2,472,621, or 65 cents a share, in the corresponding period of last year.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 2 -- The secretary general of the United Nations' new Trade and Development Board, Dr. Raul Prebisch, warned today that the world was again losing ground in the fight to reduce the gap between rich and poor countries.
Actors Equity Association and the League of New York Theaters yesterday signed a contract covering wages, hours and other working conditions for Broadway performers.
The Racquet and Tennis Club defeated Queen's Club of London, 11 to 3, yesterday in their international court tennis match.

A "GREAT experiment" was undertaken this week by Jack and Mary Taylor, owners of the Mayacamas Vineyards in Napa, Calif. They hoped to "explode the myth" that California wines do not vary from year to year.

Bold Lad will run at Aqueduct today, but not in the main race on the program. The Wheatley Stable's star, who was the champion of his age division last year, will make his debut as a 3-year-old in a six-furlong "overnight" race, immediately precceding the main event.

LOS ANGELES, April 2 (UPI) -- Sandy Koufax has an arthritic condition in his left elbow that probably will prevent the Los Angeles Dodgers' star left-hander from pitching on opening day and may sharply limit his playing future. Koufax had been expected to face the Mets at Shea Stadium in the opening game April 12.
BUCHAREST, March 29 -- The Communist leadership here is urging writers and painters to show "courage" in exploring new styles and contemporary subjects.
The State Mediation Board intervened yesterday in the strike called against Bloomingdale's store. For the first time, Stern's New York store was picketed late in the day.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 2 -- After making a minor squad cut, the New York Mets presented tonight a familiar sight to 2,402 spectators at Al Lang Field and television viewers back in New York: they lost to the St. Louis Cardinals, 4-2.

TRENTON, April 4 -- The search for a plan to reapportion the New Jersey Legislature has wound through dark, stuffy passages of numbers and rhetoric, and the rare moments of light and fresh air have been welcomed.

One man was killed and three women were injured on the Henry Hudson Parkway yesterday when an auto, apparently out of control, jumped the divider, struck another car and was thrown back into the path of a third.

In a development involving several of the oldest retailing names in New York, Hammacher Schlemmer, a gift specialty store founded in 1848, will soon acquire PlummerMcCutcheon, a combination of two stores merged in 1963 but originating 110 years ago.

TOKYO, April 4 (AP) -- The Hanoi radio said today that North Vietnam's Council of Ministers had decided to strengthen the nation's "economy and national defense" to cope with the United States air raids.

Puccini's "Tosca" was given its 14th performance of the season at the Metropolitan Opera on Saturday night. This total is almost unheard of these days. The wear and tear on the work, with its constant changes of cast, was all too apparent.
ROME, April 4 (AP) -- Pope Paul VI said today in a Passion Sunday Lenten service that Christ was crucified by Jews who did not know who He was.
On March 24 you had a news article headed "1641 House Shelters Young Canarsie Family" which stated that this house is "believed to be the oldest frame house in the United States."

MOSCOW, April 4 -- A leading Soviet law journal has charged that the late Andrei Y. Vishinsky, prosecutor in the Soviet "show trials" of the nineteen-thirties, promoted Stalinist terror not only through his legal theories but also with "practical directives."

FARMINGDALE, L.I., April 4 (AP) -- More than 1,600 members of the International Association of Machinists voted overwhelmingly tonight to accept a proposed contract with the Republic Aviation Corporation.
The top management of the fast-growing Braniff Airways, Inc., passes this week to 44-year-old Harding L. Lawrence, former executive vice president of Continental Airlines.
WASHINGTON, April 4 -- Representative Adam Clayton Powell, Democrat of Manhattan, moved into the new Ray-House Office Building last week.

The George Shearing Quintet made its first local concert appearance in three years last night in the auditorium of Hunter College as part of a benefit for the Jefferson Park Junior High School Scholarship Fund.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, April 4 (AP) -- One of the nation's longest newspaper strikes -- now in its 228th day -- neared an end today as The Youngstown Vindicator and the striking American Newspaper Guild announced they had agreed on a settlement.

We Japanese as Asians, with Okinawa as an armed base, are very much concerned about the Vietnamese war. The country has been a battleground for almost twenty years. The people are weary, the land is ruined, and young and old, men and women are dead. Promising American youth, who might have made important contributions to their country, also are dead.

WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP) -- The two F-105's that were downed today were said to have been caught with full bomb loads and thus were not so maneuverable or so fast as they would have been had they been free of their heavy bombs.

BERLIN, April 4 (AP) -- In what appeared to be a counter challenge to the Communists, Vice Chancellor Erich Mende announced today that the West German Cabinet would meet in West Berlin at the same time as the Bundestag.
WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP) -- Senator John McClellan, Democrat of Arkansas, said tonight new legislation was needed in two areas of the Federal banking laws.

CRYSTAL MOUNTAIN, Wash., April 4 (AP) -- Nancy Greene of Canada completed a sweep of the American Alpine ski championships today when she sped through the 57 gates of the giant slalom to win in 2 minutes 5.36 seconds.

LONDON April 4 -- The Chancellor of the Exchequer, James Callaghan, a former inland-revenue tax collector, will tell the British people Tuesday how he will raise about $22.5 billion to run the country over the next financial year.
The basement garage in the West Side Airlines Terminal on the east side of 10th Avenue from 41st to 42d Street has been leased to Avis Rent A Car by Irving Maidman, owner of the terminal.
THEY met first in the lobby of the Windemere Hotel at the mountain resort of Darjeeling, India.

The self-governing British colony of Rhodesia in southern Africa is inching steadily toward a unilateral declaration of independence. A general election has been called for May 7 in which the implicit issue is independence, with all signs pointing to victory for the incumbent Rhodesian Front party and its leader, Prime Minister Ian Smith.
Moral objections to capital punishment were underscored yesterday by the Rev. Benjamin Minifie in his sermon at Grace Episcopal Church, Broadway and 10th Street.

About 70,000 persons jammed the Coliseum yesterday to see the cars and accessories on display at the International Automobile Show. It was the largest single day's attendance for any exhibit at the Coliseum, show officials said.
A $25 million issue of Malaysia bonds, the first sale of securities by the Southeast Asian country in the United States, is scheduled to be offered tomorrow and is expected to be oversubscribed.
The Ford Foundation announced yesterday grants totaling $1,863,000 for programs designed to attract more Negroes into business and for economic research and cultural projects.
WASHINGTON, April 4 -- Communist China and the Soviet Union were reported today to be negotiating large wheat purchases from Argentina.
PORTLAND, Ore., April 4 -- A strike of newspaper printers and mailers, which began here nearly five and a half years ago, finally collapsed this afternoon.
BOSTON, April 4 -- The civil rights movement, whose targets have been concentrated in the South, is beginning to take aim in Boston.
BONN, April 4 -- Mayor Willy Brandt of West Berlin was barred by the East German police from traveling on the autobahn to his own city today.
MOSCOW, April 4 -- The Soviet Press announced today that collective farmers would be able to get homebuilding loans from the State Bank.
LOS ANGELES, April 4 (AP) -- Elgin Baylor of the Los Angeles Lakers entered Daniel Freeman Hospital today for surgery to repair a torn left kneecap.
LONDON, April 4 -- Prince Philip said today his role as husband of Queen Elizabeth II prevented him from indulging in small pleasures like visiting a pub or catching a movie.

Will there be a special legislative election in New York State next November? The state is under a mandate from the three-judge statutory Federal court to hold one, but the situation is so clouded by massive legal and political uncertainties that no one knows.
PIANO playing of a sensitive and markedly feminine cast was offered by Kaibi Laretei in her American debut recital in Philharmonic Hall last night.

AT this time a year ago Ken Venturi was a bitterly disappointed young man, so frustrated that he was on the brink of despair. What drove him there was the news that the last two available places on the invitation list to the Masters at Augusta had been assigned. It was a brutal blow to his pride.
Sammy Davis attacked bigotry yesterday as something "we can't let happen." He said, "We must not let bigots use the liberties they are trying to destroy."

A PERENNIALLY girlish designer who garnered fame 15 years ago with the paper doll silhouette (a petticoated, but otherwise strictly unembellished dress for junior sizes) is letting friends tell her that she has just scored another fashion discovery.
The nomination of Robert Meyer as a director of the P. Lorillard Company was announced over the weekend. The nomination will be considered at the annual stockholder meeting tomorrow.

The tobacco industry continues its bitter and exaggerated resistance to the proposed legislation that would require health warnings on all cigarette packages. Its spokesmen have not gone to the extent of claiming that cigarette smoking is healthful. But they are less than frank in disputing statistical evidence linking smoking with the big increase in the incidence of lung cancer and other chronic diseases.
BEDFORD, N.Y., April 4 -- Janet Sullivan of Westport, Conn., who rides out of the Cedar Lodge Farm, dominated the horsemanship division of the Sunnyfield Farm horse show today.

TO fill the hour left open by the departure of "The Entertainers," the Columbia Broadcasting System introduced on Saturday evening a series called "Secret Agent." It is cut to what now appears to be next season's most probable new trend in programing -- James Bondish outings of every conceivable form and variation.

DETROIT, April 4 -- A little-noticed controversy involving the family car, which seems destined to have significant influence on the welfare and pocketbooks of millions of Americans in the years ahead, is raging throughout the nation.

A special committee of the City Council has started a comprehensive survey of the sources, causes, nature, effects and economics of air pollution -- which is fine if it leads to a more effective attack on this grave menace to health. But it should not take long for the committee to find out that one basic weakness in the city's program for air pollution control is very simple: not enough money.
PARIS, April 4 -- The visit by Prime Minister Harold Wilson gave President de Gaulle a chance to play a role he enjoys very much -- the affluent, imperious, omniscient uncle.
WASHINGTON, April 4 (UPI) -- President Johnson named five new members today to the White House Science Advisory Committee.
The completion of a $250,000 renovation at Holy Trinity Lutheran Church, Central Park West and 65th Street, was marked yesterday by a special rededication service.

IN THE CENTRAL HIGHLANDS, South Vietnam, April 4 -- At a hilltop military outpost here near the Laotian border, United States, officers found evidence today that the Vietcong may be bringing artillery into this vulnerable area for the first time.

The Denison Singers, from the liberal arts university in Granville, Ohio, appeared at Carnegie Recital Hall last night. Now on a 10-concert tour of the East, the 14-voice mixed choir was under the direction of its founder, William Osborne.
WASHINGTON, April 4 -- Congress moves tomorrow into what could be the single most important week of the session, with action scheduled on medical care for the aged and aid to the nation's schools.
Pan American World Airways and its striking pilots failed to resolve their contract dispute at a joint meeting last night, according to Leverett Edwards, a Federal mediator.

GREENSBORO, N.C., April 4 -- Sam Snead won the Greater Greensboro open for the eighth time today and every senior golfer smiled. With a final 68 the 52-year-old Snead became the oldest ever to win a tour tournament.
BUDAPEST, April 4 -- The Hungarian Air Force displayed its most modern jet fighters for the first time today in a parade marking the 20th anniversary of Hungary's liberation from Nazi rule.
FORT MYERS, Fla., April 4 -- There were three highly unexpected three-run outbursts at Terry Park today as the Pittsburgh Pirates defeated the New York Mets, 9-8, in 10 innings.

A Jesuit priest and a lawyer told the Bronx chapter of the Catholic Interracial Council how they felt as civil-rights demonstrators in Selma, Ala., last month. One conceded that he had been afraid, the other that he had been embarrassed.

ATLANTIC CITY. April 4 (UPI) -- A strike in the glass container industry was headed i off tonight when 8,000 skilled iworkers were granted a 50-cent{ an-hour package increase in a ! three-year contract
GENEVA, April 4 -- Geneva voted today to remain a world center dedicated to international cooperation.

MILL VALLEY, Calif., April 4 -- A stand of stately redwoods was symbolically dedicated today to the late Dag Hammarskjold, who found inner peace and contentment during a brief visit to Muir Woods National Monument 10 years ago.
BOSTON, April 5 (AP) -- Leighton (Hap) Emms was named today the general manager of the Boston Bruins' National Hockey League team.
ALMOST invariably, when a dress designer finds she is going to have a baby, a new maternity fashion is born. Jenny Bell, the sportswear designer, is no exception.

American Metal Climax, Inc., and the Homestake Mining Company announced yesterday that they had reached a long-term agreement with the Montana Phosphate Products Company and the Magnet Cove Barium Corporation to smelt and refine 70,000 tons of lead concentrate a year in Missouri.

TORONTO, April 5 -- The Ford Motor Company of Canada, Ltd., has begun exporting 400 cars a month to upper New York State under the new automotive free-trade agreement, announced in January, between Canada and the United States.

MAJOR league baseball has got to do something more constructive in the field of college baseball, accordiing to Bill McCarthy, who coached New York University teams for 40 years before retiring in 1962.
Record sales and earnings were registered for the first quarter of this year by the American Enka Corporation, Philip B. Stull, chairman and president, reported yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 5 (AP) -- The president of the Marine Firemen's Union, holding contracts with Pacific Coast steamship companies, said today there was no justification for reducing the number of engine-room personnel as proposed by ship owners.
Supporters of the Colony House Settlement have arranged their annual dinner dance for April 24 at Delmonico's.
The Federal Home Loan Banks are making an offering of $524 million of notes today.
BERLIN, April 5 -- The superhighway linking this former German capital with the West was closed for four hours today by Soviet and East German authorities.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- Mayor Joseph T. Smitherman of Selma, Ala., and another white man were "flimflammed" out of $107 here early today by a Negro who offered to "show them the town," the Washington police reported.

The Times March 24 editorial of Senator Javits's Vice-Presidential possibilities and the front-page news article March 23 neglect one important point. That he is not likely to run with Governor Rockefeller as the Presidential candidate is not simply because two New Yorkers "would be too much of a good thing" or because of "the unwritten law that a national ticket must reflect geographical diversity."
The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company expects 1965 to be another good year, but hinted at possible price rises at the annual meeting of stockholders held yesterday in Akron, Ohio.

WASHINGTON, April 5 (UPI) -- The Supreme Court agreed today to review the Federal conviction of Ralph Ginzburg on charges of mailing a quarterly called Eros and two other publications found by a Philadelphia judge to be obscene.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 5 -- Zoilo Versalles of the Minnesota Twins drew a humiliating and expensive reprimand today when Manager Sam Mele benched him in the middle of an inning and then fined him $300.
The United States Government bond market appeared to indicate yesterday that Britain's budget, to be made public today, would not upset interest rates here.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 5 -- Hailed as "the most representative forum in the history of international economic cooperation," the United Nations Trade and Development Board began organizing itself here today on a permanent basis.
WASHINGTON, April 5 -- "I know the battle's about over, but . . ."
CAIRO, April 5 -- Egyptian Air Force planes operating from Yemen have bombed the Saudi Arabian seaport town of Qizan during the last week, diplomatic sources reported today.

DETROIT, April 5 -- Eight workers walked into a large room here last Friday, sat down on stools alongside a big cream-colored chamber, and put their eyes to viewing slots not unlike those on old stereoscopes. They were submitting themselves as unpaid guinea pigs for one of the automobile industry's most important research projects.
TRENTON, April 5 -- The State Assembly completed legislative approval today of a bill establishing a tristate transportation commission.
New Park Mining received most of the attention on the American Stock Exchange yesterday, as the market closed mostly up in moderate trading.
The annual dinner dance for the Vacation Camp for the Blind will be given Saturday, April 24 in the Grand Ballroom of the Pierre Hotel. The event will be called Spring Fantasy.

The Ohio State University Libraries have bought a collection of books, papers and photographs connected with the late James Thurber from his brother, Robert Thurber. The collection contains childhood drawings by the humorist and a 22-page Western story that he wrote while in high school, as well as letters and postcards to literary acquaintances.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- In the latest draft of the Dirksen-Administration voting rights bill, Federal courts would be empowered to suspend state and local poll taxes when they are used to prevent Negroes from voting.
The playing fields of the Ivy League, fertile grounds for the New York Giants, will be featured once again in the National Football League team's exhibition-game schedule this summer.
Three of New York City's major banks reported yesterday that their first-quarter earnings had shot ahead of last year's performance.

Park Commissioner Newbold Morris, who says he does not care for abstract art, has sent back to Lincoln Center a proposal to install on a city-owned plaza there a huge nonmobile sculpture by Alexander Calder.
Mayor Wagner came under fire yesterday from two sources seeking to unseat him in the Democratic primary.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- The substitute for the Katzenbach-Dirksen voting rights bill that was offered to Congress today by the House Republican leadership vitally serves the public interest in a number of ways.
The Greek Line's new flagship, the Queen Anna Maria, swept regally into port under balmy skies yesterday carrying 496 passengers on her maiden voyage.
Queens Borough President Mario J. Cariello was accused yesterday of blocking proposals for three low-income housing projects because of community fears of "undesirables."

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- News item: The F.B.I. has arrested a former executive of Procter Gamble on charges of industrial espionage. Alleged spy is accused of trying to sell the Colgate Toothpaste Company Procter Gamble's secret strategy for marketing Crest toothpaste.

The first shipment of paintings and memorabilia of the late Sir Winston Churchill was unpacked yesterday in a Long Island City warehouse and cleared by United States Customs officials for transfer to the World's Fair.

Walter C. Sauer, vice chairman of the Export-Import Bank, defended yesterday the bank's policy of lending money to foreign governments as justified as long as it helps prepare the ground for private investment.
MONTEGO BAY, Jamaica, April 5 -- Ticonderoga, the 72-foot scratch boat, and Maredea, a 60-foot yawl, were still locked in a slow-moving duel for the lead in the Miami-to-Montego Bay race today.

MINEOLA, L.I., April 5 -- County Executive Eugene H. Nickerson promptly vetoed a resolution adopted unanimously by the Board of Supervisors today that disapproved of any move to extend the jurisdiction of the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority into Nassau County.
Yale University announced yesterday a program under which some students would take five years to complete their four-year bachelor's degree but would devote a year to work in emerging nations.

Without any fanfare other than those in the opera itself, "Aida" was given by he Metropolitan Opera for the 500th time last night. Ironically, Verdi's popular work was sung in German by a largely German cast when it was first given in the house, on Nov. 12, 1886.
The chairman of the Senate Banking Committee indicated yesterday that there was a strong feeling in the Senate that there should be some silver retained in American coins.
WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP) -- The Agency for International Development says the burden of meeting payments on current debts is imperiling the progress of undeveloped nations.

There is a bit more cordiality in Franco-British relations after the Paris talks between President de Gaulle and Prime Minister Wilson. The modest improvement is more the result of an improved atmosphere than of specific agreement on the most important issues facing both countries.
Andrea Dworkin, the Bennington College freshman whose charges of "maltreatment" at the Women's House of Detention touched off four investigations, received a suspended sentence yesterday.

The Hospital and Planning Council of Southern New York endorsed yesterday the Blue Cross application for rate increases ranging from 6 to 40 per cent for many of the 7.5 million subscribers in New York City and 12 downstate counties.
ALBANY, April 5 -- Methods of holding down crime in New York City's subways were proposed today in bills urged upon members of the State Assembly.

The Coast Guard played host here yesterday to 50 officials of the Prefectura Nacional Maritima Argentina, the Argentine counterpart of the service, at a day-long demonstration of Coast Guard operations in New York harbor.
RIO DE JANEIRO, April 5 -- Brazil has successfully negotiated foreign private financing to pay off its commercial creditors in the United States and Europe.
WASHINGTON, April 5 (UPI) -- The Senate approved today stricter controls on tobacco growers, subject to their approval, in an effort to curb surpluses and improve quality.
United Air Lines announced yesterday plans to buy 75 jetliners at a total cost of $375 million -- the largest and most expensive purchase of jet aircraft by a single commercial airline.

A BOOK about an important subject traps the unwary into believing that it must therefore be an important book. But the correlation is at best chancy -- as we see again and again during any publishing year.
WASHINGTON, April 5 -- President Johnson will make what was described as a definitive speech on Vietnam Wednesday night.
CAMDEN, Ala., April 5 -- The Mayor of Camden turned back five civil rights marches today by arresting 11 leaders and lobbing smoke and tear-gas bombs into the crowd of demonstrators.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., April 5 (UPI) -- A single by Gene Oliver with none out in the 12th inning following two singles and a wild throw gave the Milwaukee Braves a 1-0 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers today.

The board of directors of Action, Inc., have voted to change the organization's name to the Action Council for Better Cities. The private, nonprofit group, whose offices are at 2 West 46th Street, was organized in 1954 as the American Council to Improve Our Neighborhoods, and its name was shortened in 1959.
LEXINGTON, Ky., April 5 (AP) -- Strong support developed today for maintaining the office of bishop in a proposed sweeping reunion of American Protestant churches.

The printers' union -- continuing its strike threat against seven of the city's newspapers -- held extended meetings at The Daily News yesterday, making the paper miss its first two editions. Bertram, A. Powers, president of New York Typographical Union No. 6, called a meeting of News printers in the afternoon to discuss the dispute between the union and the publishers.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- The Supreme Court held today that the Sixth Amendment's guarantee of the right of accused persons to be confronted with the witnesses against them applied to state criminal trials.
WASHINGTON, April 5 (UPI) -- The First State Bank of Covington, Tex., closed its doors today. It was the fifth Federally insured bank to collapse this year.

Miracle Mart, Inc., an 80 per cent-owned subsidiary of the Bailey Company of Cleveland, is purchasing the inventory and accounts receivable of the three Bailey department stores in Cleveland from its parent, the privately owned Bailey Company.

ANTIQUES and accessories shops are still a rare find on Manhattan's West Side, north of Columbus Circle. But two shops have opened in recent months that are of more than passing interest to those in search of turn-of-the-century and younger decorations.
WARSAW, April 5 -- The Soviet leaders came to Communist Poland today to mark 20 years of Polish-Soviet friendship and to sign a new treaty for another 20 years.
WASHINGTON, April 5 -- The Supreme Court held today that a television advertiser could not show a false demonstration to prove a claim about a product, even if the claim was true.
Prices advanced moderately yesterday on the London stock exchange in brisk trading.
THERE is no sense in comparing the fighting quality of flatfishes with trout or salmon, or even ladyfish and Jack Cravalles for that matter.
Life will soon be made easier for mothers pushing perambulators, shoppers shoving carts and invalids in wheelchairs on the sidewalks of New York.

The chief of the District Attorney's frauds bureau charged yesterday that Murray Helwitz, manager of the Shubert theaters' central ticket office, had exacted more than $250,000 annually for several years from brokers to sell them tickets.
MOSCOW, April 5 -- The United States today rejected Soviet charges that American ships and planes had interfered with Soviet shipping.
WASHINGTON, April 5 -- The Treasury bill rate rose a little today after hovering for several weeks at a level barely above 3.9 per cent.

In a $5 million transaction, the Outremer Development Corporation, headed by Sydney M. Stein, a lawyer, of Williston Park, L.I., has purchased the assets of Shirley, L.I., Inc., from the estate of Walter T. Shirley, realty developer.
ATLANTA, ApriI 5 -- The Rev. Billy Graham announced today that he had broken speaking engagements in England late this month to accept "several urgent invitations" from Alabama.
TRENTON, April 5 (AP) -- A bill to permit state-chartered banks to provide more liberal mortgage terms was approved today by the New Jersey Assembly.
DETROIT, April 5 (AP) -- Automobile production records toppled in the first quarter of 1965 as the public continued its unparalleled car-buying spree.

The announcement that President Johnson is to make an address on Vietnam tomorrow could mean much, or, if the President is simply going to repeat the arguments that he, Secretary Rusk, Secretary McNamara, General Taylor and other Administration spokesmen have been uttering for two months, it could mean little.
A state mediator met with union and company representatives yesterday in an effort to end the 6-day-old strike at Bloomingdale's department store.

Current events in Asia make it more vital than ever to get correct information about what is going on there. This is one reason the ban on travel to mainland China is a violation of our right to know.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, April 5 (UPI) -- Government officials today expelled a young woman Peace Corp worker because "Indonesia does not need the Peace Corps."

CHICAGO, April 5 -- Federal Judge Richard B. Austin entered a final judgment today in favor of the Zenith Radio Corporation of Chicago against the Hazeltine Corporation and its subsidiary, Hazeltine Research, Inc., of New York, for $19,042,173, plus costs and lawyer's fees.

With the barbecue season approaching, After Six Formals, a producer of men's formal wear, is attempting to make this season's hamburger outings the best-dressed ever. "Dressing for a summer affair used to mean plaid shorts, knee socks and a sheepish grin," the copy in the ad suggests.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W.Va., April 5 (UPI) -- The nation's savings-and-loan associations have successfully "turned the corner in a crucial period in the development of the business," the president of the United States Savings and Loan League said today.
The Radio Corporation of America announced yesterday that Siemens Halske, A.G., of West Germany has ordered 26 Spectra 70 computer systems valued at more than $9 million.

AT an hour when most viewers undoubtedly were watching the Oscar award ceremonies, the Columbia Broadcasting System's television network presented last night a singularly forthright documentary on abortion.

Jack Benny, whose weekly television show will not continue after this season, said yesterday he would star on two special hour-long shows next season on the National Broadcasting Company network. The 71-year-old comedian will thus continue the uninterrupted association with broacasting that began in 1932.
Prices of Maine potato futures rose the daily limit yesterday in the April and May contracts on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP) -- Government agents broke up today a $1,000-a-day numbers racket in the Pentagon and two other Government buildings. Fifty-nine persons were arrested.
WASHINGTON, April 5 -- Individuals saved a record of $29.1 billion last year, even after deducting an increase of $22.9 billion in their debts, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

The Royal Crown Cola Company, Columbus, Ga., elected William E. Uzzell, 51 years old as its president and chief executive officer yesterday at a meeting of the company's board of directors in Richmond, Va.
WASHINGTON, April 5 -- The Supreme Court held today that when the National Labor Relations Board establishes collective bargaining units it can take into account the extent of union organization.

FIFTYSIX, Ark., April 5 (UPI) -- Navy divers helped four trapped cave explorers swim to safety one by one through 300 feet of murky water today. One diver collapsed and died as the last man was rescued.
HOLLYWOOD, April 5 -- The producers of two plays by the controversial Negro playwright LeRoi Jones charged today they were being pressured out of business locally by the police and newspapers.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., April 5 -- Cletis Boyer of the New York Yankees posted $200 bond today on a warrant charging him with assault and battery, and a hearing was scheduled for May 11 in Municipal Court.

ALBANY, April 5 -- Both Republicans and Democrats began to search in earnest today for ways to save at least part of Governor Rockefeller's proposed 2 per cent sales tax. With a vote on the budget due in the Senate tomorrow, the spirit of compromise was in the air.

Governor Rockefeller announced yesterday the nominations of Herman C. Nolen and Anson F. Sherman to seats on the State Banking Board and the reappointment of Samuel A. Leidesdorf and Joseph A. Kaiser.

HOUSTON, April 5 (UPI) -- Comdr. Walter M. Schirra and Maj. Thomas P. Stafford were named today to make the first United States attempt to rendezvous an orbiting spacecraft with a second vehicle in space -- possibly within nine months.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, April 5 -- The Government has put three of Leopoldville's six newspapers out of business, apparently because they had derided the way it was running the Congo's marathon general election.
WASHINGTON, April 5 -- The Senate voted down today a proposal to enact a time-payment plan for persons who cannot pay their income-tax bills by the April 15 filing deadline.

The Pure Oil Company mailed amended proxy statements to its shareholders yesterday nominating Marlin E. Sandlin as a director. Mr. Sandlin had been a member of a stockholders group that was considering challenging Pure Oil's management at the company's annual meeting April 10.
Walter Arm, the Police Department's Deputy Commissioner in charge of community relations for 10 years, resigned yesterday to become a vice president of Rheingold Breweries.
Mayor Wagner opened a drive last night to free the subways of the terror spread by "the mugger, the hoodlum and the young punk."
SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 4. -- The streets of Saigon are dangerous for young South Vietnamese who have evaded military service.

The election of three senior vice presidents of James Talcott, Inc., was announced yesterday by the industrial finance concern. Judson J. Mohl, Russell B. Donahue and Edward J. Eckert were elevated from the rank of vice president.

Your March 30 news report on the "walkout" at Brooklyn College of some students at a lecture by President Gideonse sponsored by the Interreligious Coordinating Council failed to stress that the students involved were invited to leave by the President since they had come to the meeting with the specific purpose of staging a "demonstration," and they were obviously not members of the sponsoring students' religious clubs.

Negotiations between Pan American World Airways and the striking Air Line Pilots Association are to be moved to Washington today by Leverett Edwards, a Federal mediator. It was hoped that a change in locale night produce a change in the negotiators' stands.
