Two musicians from Canada, Andrew Dawes, violinist, and Claude Savard, pianist, were treated to a New York debut before an invited audience last night at Carnegie Recital Hall.
District Attorney Frank D. O'Connor of Queens said yesterday that an investigation indicated that inferior lumber was being used extensively in construction projects here.
WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP) -- The Federal Home Loan Bank Board announced today that some savings-and-loan associations would be exempt from interest-rate regulations issued last week.
OTTAWA, April 5 -- The Government announced today that it would present a comprehensive anti-poverty program to the new session of the Canadian Parliament.

Paul Joseph Jennings, who challenged one of America's long entrenched labor leaders, is a stocky bespectacled man with sharp, grayish-blue eyes, a deceptively mild manner and a dedication to the union movement.
WASHINGTON, April 5 -- James B. Carey, hot-tempered president of the International Union of Electrical Workers, was not legally re-elected, the Labor Department reported today.

SANTA MONICA, Calif., April 5 -- Two beaming Britons, Rex Harrison and Julie Andrews, won the principal Academy Awards tonight, and "My Fair Lady" received the Oscar as the best motion picture of 1964.

The stock market turned downward in the late trading yesterday, erasing almost all of the gain made early in the day. Trading activity was only moderate, with interest centered mostly in special-situation issues.
The British pound scored a solid advance yesterday in moderate trading on foreign exchange markets here.

CHICAGO, April 5 -- A "packaging explosion" that will require new contributions in technology and resources from the paper industry was predicted today by David L. Luke 3d, president of the West Virginia Pulp and Paper Company.
LONDON, April 5 -- Playbill, the theater program publication, is moving into the West End. It is expected to begin publication in the fall.

LOS ANGELES, April 5 (UPI) -- Jerry West scored on a rebound of his own missed jump shot with 23 seconds to play tonight to allow the Los Angeles Lakers to beat the Baltimore Bullets, 118-115. The Lakers thus took a 2-0 lead in the National Basketball Association Western Division play-off finals.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, April 3 -- A senior agricultural official disclosed today that the Communist Government was preparing important measures to better the lot of Rumania's three million cooperative farm families, who have had hard times since World War II.

A prosecutor charged yesterday that witnesses balking in a grand jury investigation of last summer's Harlem riots had "agreed to kill police officers" and that one had warned a prospective cooperative witness that "his body might be found hanging by a lamppost."
Criticism of remarks on civil rights demonstrations in Selma, Ala., made Sunday at a policemen's communion breakfast here by William F. Buckley Jr. came from several quarters yesterday.

IN less than a week the baseball season will begin, but many preconceived notions have been scrambled beyond recognition on how the National League pennant race will end. Medical men have pre-empted the managers in controlling the destinies of at least three ball clubs.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., April 5 -- Mel Stottlemyre, who started three World Series games as a rookie against the St. Louis Cardinals' ace, Bob Gibson, frowned into the sun today and said: "All winter long, every time I'd have a dream, there would be Gibson pitching against me."

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- President Johnson proposed to Congress today revisions in the farm program designed to cut Federal costs, raise farm income and put more reliance on the open market for farm prices.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 5 -- Golfers who plan to join the professional tour will soon have to attend a special school, it was learned today.
LONDON, April 5 -- A magistrate's court today heard the story of a British guided-missile expert who turned spy for the Soviet Union to keep up with his mortgage payments.
CANTON, China -- "In this province," said the bright young man from the Foreign Affairs Bureau, "there is no rest for the land."
SARASOTA, Fla., April 5 (AP) -- John Buzhardt and rookie Bob Locker held the Philadelphia Phillies to one hit today as the Chicago White Sox scored a 2-0 exhibition-game victory.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 5 -- The United States and the Soviet Union exchanged bitter charges over the war in Vietnam today at a meeting of the Committee to Define Aggression.

Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, Inc., plans to spend no more than $50,000 of its own capital to get its "bus-train" program working, Victor Muscat, chairman and president, told group of about 40 stockholders yesterday morning in the Biltmore Hotel.

Rabbi Israel Miller, president of the Rabbinical Council of America, asserted yesterday that he found it difficult to reconcile a sermon by Pope Paul VI on Sunday with the pending Vatican Council declaration on Jewish-Christian relations.

NEW ORLEANS -- When a visitor to New Orleans recently inquired where to find an expert on local cooking, many sources mentioned a young playwright and short-story writer who lives near the Vieux Carre.
The leader of the Catholic Traditionalist Movement said yesterday that he was asking all American bishops to join him in conducting a referendum on the recent changes in the liturgy of the church.

LONDON, April 5 -- Increasing Spanish pressure against Gibralatar brought a declaration by the British Government today that it would "take whatever measures may be necessary to defend and sustain" its fortress colony.
WASHINGTON, April 5 -- A Federal official said tonight that "some exceptions" were being made to the requirement that youths enrolled in the Neighborhood Youth Corps be paid at least $1.25 an hour.

NOBODY is surprised when two tyros overbid, reach an impossible contract, and go down a large number of tricks. But when it happens to national champions it may be rewarding to study the circumstances.
A bizarre campaign to frustrate a White House economy move and to force the Administration to continue wasteful expenditures of hundreds of millions of dollars is under way at present in the capital.
A powder-blue panel truck bearing the legend "Planned Parenthood" pulled up yesterday afternoon at a Presbyterian church in the Hunts Point section of the East Bronx.

SINCE 1958 Jean de Rigault has been bringing over from Paris productions in French that have been welcomed on college campuses all over this country. Last night his Le Treteau de Paris, as he now calls his venture, opened a two-week engagement at the Barbizon-Plaza Theater with its presentation of Paul Claudel's "L'Annonce Faite a Marie" ("The Tidings Brought to Mary").
SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 5 -- The United States mounted two more air strikes against North Vietnam today. The American planes did not encounter any enemy MIG's during the raids.

When a taxpayer and his wife both work, they will ordinarily pay less tax if they file a joint Federal return. But contrary to the belief of some taxpayers, it does not follow that in similar circumstances they will pay less tax to New York State by filing joint returns.
Bache Co.'s experiment with an "uptown" advertising agency has failed after only two months.
Cecil C. Simmons, first vice president of Horace S. Ely and Company, has been appointed chairman of the Serial Federal Savings and Loan Association.
PITTSBURGH, April 5 (UPI) -- A strike against towboat operators entered its fifth day today amid charges they were trying to break the unions involved.

Lewis D. Gilbert, a tireless champion of shareholders rights, said yesterday he was unruffled by a near-tussle with an unidentified man last week at the annual meeting of the Thatcher Glass Manufacturing Company at a midtown hotel.

PARIS, April 5 -- The Foreign Ministry acknowledged today that France was prepared to sell supersonic fighter planes to Saudi Arabia, but said that French pilots would be forbidden to fly the craft in combat missions.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- The final countdown for the launching of the world's first commercial satellite is expected to begin at 10 A.M. tomorrow, officials of the Communications Satellite Corporation said tonight.

Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, working through the New York State Education Department, will help provide live performances of music, dance and drama for junior and senior high school students throughout the state.
MOSCOW, April 5 -- The Soviet Union announced today the demotion of another high Khrushchev nominee.
Professional tennis will put on its first indoor show in Manhattan in two years from April 28 to May 2.

Kastor, Hilton, Chesley, Clifford Atherton, the advertising agency on trial in Federal Court, Brooklyn, on charges of promoting a $16 million hoax in the sale of reducing pills, insisted yesterday the campaign involved nothing more than "puffery."

SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 5 -- Hard-core Vietcong units in two key regions of South Vietnam are reported to have received orders to move northward. It was not clear whether they were moving to new battle positions within the country or to North Vietnam.

Prairie Schooner scudded over the six furlongs at Aqueduct like a Coast Guard cutter yesterday to win the feature event on the program. The 4-year-old campaigner, owned by the High Tide Stable, thrilled a crowd of 34,121 fans with a nose victory in an exciting four-horse photo finish.
LONDON, April 5 (AP) -- The Soviet Union pulled out of the Davis Cup tennis competition today four weeks before its team was due to meet Rhodesia in the European Zone first round.

Your April 3 editorial "The Mayor on Voting" assumes that English literacy measured by minimal eighth-grade schooling should continue as New York's indispensable condition for applied citizenship at the polls.

Robert L. Cooper has been named executive director of Associated Community Teams, Inc., the Harlem agency known as Act, is part of the antipoverty program sponsored by New York City and the Federal Government.
The British pound dipped yesterday in moderate dealings on foreign exchange markets here. The trading range was the smallest in several days.
Employes of the Diners' Club went on strike here yesterday to demand an election for representation by a union.
Sears, Roebuck Co. and the J.C. Penney Company reported yesterday that they attained record sales in March and in the first two months of their fiscal years.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 6 -- Premier Chou En-lai has sent word to U Thant, the Secretary General, that any negotiations on peace in Vietnam must be undertaken directly with the Vietcong forces in South Vietnam and not with Communist China or North Vietnam.
More than 30 Puerto Rican leaders told Mayor Wagner in a 70-minute conference at City Hall late yesterday that their community's relationship with the Police Department was "at its lowest ebb."

Just when Braullo Baeza, the placid Panamanian, was enjoying one of the most successful early season campaigns of his career, along came some traffic problems on Aqueduct's backstretch yesterday to give him cause for pause.
WASHINGTON, April 6 -- There is no sense of expectation of crisis here over the current Communist harassment of Western travel to Berlin.
MATHIS, Tex., April 6 -- Two Mexican-Americans were elected to the City Council here today, and a Mayor was elected with Mexican-American support.

Aboard the Oceanic, in the Mediterranean, April 7 -- A maiden voyage of a new luxury liner, the Oceanic, out of one of the world's most beautiful harbors, Naples, sounds like one of life's more romantic adventures. If this maiden voyage is typical, however, such adventures are appreciated only by the experienced traveler for the crew is still trying hard to eliminate kinks.
BRUSSELS, April 6 -- President de Gaulle's new crusade against the United States dollar is going to cost France at least $18.4 million in lost investment revenue in 1965.

Pickets marched outside the office of the New York city Labor Council yesterday to protest what they called discriminatory policies at the Electchester Cooperative Housing Development in Flushing Queens.
Mayor Wagner's speech to the city promising greater protection to the public in the subways was a declaration of war against crime and hoodlumism.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 6 -- The Lafayette Motor Inn on South North Carolina Avenue near Pacific Avenue, one of the resort's most elaborate hotels, was sold today by Frank P. Gravatt to Roy J. Riker, a Burington County banker and realty investor.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- There were more versions today of the "flimflam" of Joseph T. Smitherman, the segregationist Mayor of Selma, Ala., by a Negro slicker than participants in the episode, but all versions agreed that it was altogether a bit awkward.
MEXICO CITY, April 6 -- Hundreds of students clashed with the police tonight when they were stopped from marching on the United States Embassy with banners critical of American policy in Vietnam.
MIAMI, April 6 (AP) -- Eight persons who survived the crash of a plane off a Bahamas island yesterday were rescued today. The Coast Guard said they were in good condition.

An architect, a specialist in industrial leasing and a state official will analyze trends in housing, real estate and industry on the "Contact-WINS" program over radio station WINS next Wednesday from 10:30 to midnight.

Honeywell, Inc., realigned its top management yesterday following the retirement of Paul B. Wishart as chairman of the 80-year-old producer of temperature-control and electronic data-processing equipment.
John J. Gilhooley, a member of the Transit Authority, called upon the system's 1,212 policemen yesterday to seize the opportunity that had been offered them to wipe out subway crime.
PARIS, April 6 -- President de Gaulle declared today that the peace of the world was in danger and that France had a great role to play in the eternal debate between war and peace.
LEXINGTON, Ky., April (AP) -- A call was sounded today for "formal negotiations" to form a new communion uniting 23 million American Protestants.

WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP) -- An 11-member study group of House Republicans accused President Johnson today of not providing effective, imaginative leadership on foreign problems of common concern to all non-Communist nations.
ALBANY, April 6 -- After nearly a quarter-century of failures, the Democrats in the Assembly passed a bill today to abolish blue-ribbon juries in New York City.

Britain's Labor Government had to perform an extremely difficult balancing act in presenting its first full-scale budget. Labor had to make clear to Britain's foreign creditors that it would do all that could be done to defend the pound without resorting to the kind of restrictive policies that might throw the domestic economy into a tailspin.
Mayor Wagner announced a settlement of the dispute between the printers and newspaper publishers at 2:10 A.M. today.

The three Florida beach boys who stole 24 gems from the American Museum of Natural History and assisted in the return of nine of them, were sentenced yesterday to serve three consecutive one-year jail terms.
This discussion deals essentially with NATO strategy and tactics and the problem of how to keep limited a European conventional, or limited, war.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 6 -- Mao Tse-tung has urged Arabs to boycott Europe and the United States "because the West likes neither us nor you."

CHICAGO, April 6 (AP) -- The Chicago Black Hawks poured in three goals in 2 minutes 40 seconds of the first period tonight, then coasted to a 5-2 victory over the Detroit Red Wings in the Stanley Cup semi-final hockey playoffs.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- Former Gov. Terry Sanford of North Carolina will direct a two year study to find ways of strengthening the role of the states in the Federal-state relationship. Special attention will be given to education, a big and growing item in state budgets.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- The new Secretary of the Treasury said in his first speech today that the voluntary program for curbing the outflow of private capital from the United States "cannot and should not be looked upon as a permanent solution" to the nation's balance-of-payments problem.

THE old adage that children should be seen and not heard is rapidly becoming as outdated as the bustle. In recognition of the growing importance of the voice of the teenager in the market place (they now spend about $10 billion a year), 21 youngsters were invited to air their views yesterday at the third annual consumer conference of the Advertising Women of New York.

THE American Ballet Theater opened the final week of its 25th anniversary season at the New York State Theater last night with a program that offered Balanchine's "Theme and Variations," Tetley's "Sargasso," Robbins's "Les Noces," and the premiere of Bentley Stone's "L'Inconnue."

Too many city, state and Federal agencies are "hungrily" looking forward to the expanding air carrier industry as a means of increasing tax and other revenues, according to Robert F. Six, president of Continental Airlines.

WASHINGTON, April 6 (UPI) -- President Johnson told Congress today that United States citizens would have to pay the interest-equalization tax when they buy stocks and bonds originating in the Bahamas, Bermuda, Ireland, Kuwait and Portugal, effective May 6.

The vigor of the Soviet reaction to today's scheduled one-day meeting in Berlin of the Bonn Bundestag should not have come as a surprise. It was precisely to avoid such a reaction that the Allies refused to countenance similar meetings for six successive years.
The Port of New York faces an uphill struggle in efforts to improve its competitive position, the Port of New York Authority said here yesterday.
A $25 million issue of Malaysia bonds was formally offered here yesterday and quickly sold out.
URZICENI, Rumania, March 29 -- Ask a man in the fields of Rumania what the difference is between his life on the farm 20 years ago and now and he is likely to shrug.

JULIUS GROSSMAN does a lot of conducting in this city, but it is usually in odd places. In the summer months he and his Municipal Concerts Orchestra give free concerts in the parks -- last year there were 16 of them.

MOST of the top cars in this year's United States Auto Club championship series, which reaches a peak in the 500-mile race at Indianapolis, will be lightweight, rear-mounted engine types. The first full-scale turnout for the new machines in the East is scheduled for the 100-mile U.S.A.C. title race at Trenton Speedway on April 25.
Grace Line yesterday announced the election of J. Edward Meyer Jr., director of trade development, to the post of assistant vice president.

HARTFORD, April 6 (UPI) -- Stock markets have increased in importance although corporations raised less than 4 per cent of their capital requirements through equity financing in the last decade, Keith Funston, president of the New York Stock Exchange, said tonight.
LONDON, April 6 (AP) -- The Reed Paper Group announced today that it had won a seven-week battle for control of Wall Paper Manufacturers, Ltd., Britain's largest wallpaper company.
Mrs. Laurance S. Rockefeller was elected a trustee of the Whitney Museum of American Art yesterday at a meeting of its board of trustees at the museum, 22 West 54th Street.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 6 -- An improvement in the morale and performance of the South Vietnamese Government and its troops has been the chief discernible result of the last month's air strikes against North Vietnam, a senior American military spokesman said today.

TOKYO, April 6 -- United States policy in South Vietnam came under fire today in a report by a senior diplomat sent to survey the situation in Vietnam by Premier Eisaku Sato. The diplomat, Shunichi Matsumoto, expressed doubts as to Washington's view that the Vietcong insurgency was predominantly a Communist movement.

A FELLOW met on a Putnam County trout stream early the other day didn't think it at all odd that before his line would cast, he occasionally had to snap off the ice that had formed in the guide rings of his rod. When one fishes that early, freezing conditions are to be expected.

HAMBURG, Germany, April 6 -- Henry Miller's story, "The Smile at the Foot of the Ladder," slipped on to the operatic stage here tonight, bowed gracefully and basked in the warmth of enthusiastic applause.

BIOGRAPHY, wrote Hesketh Pearson in his introduction to "Extraordinary People," "thrives on eccentricity, idiosyncrasy, comicality, the stuff of gossip and scandal. Singularity of character is the flesh and bones of enduring biography, anything that differentiates a man from those about him, that makes him peculiar, not typical."
LONDON, April 6 -- The Labor Government took stern measures today to reorganize Britain's economy and to right her international balance of payments.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., April 6 -- The New York Yankees auditioned the Mets' opening-day opponents, the Los Angeles Dodgers, tonight and what they learned should cheer neither the Yankees nor the Mets.

HELMSTEDT, Germany, April 6 -- Hundreds of motorists smoked, talked and fidgeted through long weary hours on the autobahn near this border town today as they waited for the East German police to let traffic through to Berlin.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- Whether he likes it or not, the consumer is going to pay more for some farm foods. This is the essence of what President Johnson told Congress yesterday in his farm message outlining proposed changes in agriculture programs.
ALBANY, April 6 -- A modified state sales tax appeared tonight to stand a good chance of legislative approval.
The Government applied some more heat yesterday to the already embattled multibillion-dollar tobacco industry.

The flutist Sebastian Caratelli, who made his local debut last season, presented another program yesterday at Carnegie Recital Hall. Mr. Caratelli's musical credentials are imposing -- he has played with the N.B.C., Cleveland, Pittsburgh and Detroit Symphony Orchestras -- and he lost no time in establishing his firm technical command of his instrument.
Office leasing in the city which dropped in February, moved sharply upward last month, according to a monthly report by Julien J. Studley, Inc., realty brokerage concern.

NEW DELHI -- India's second elected Prime Minister, Lal Bahadur Shastri, has none of Pandit Nehru's carefully cultivated glamour. Nehru, a wealthy aristocrat, reared by English governesses and educated in Britain's snootiest institutions, was a man of the world and, although a revolutionary, much aware of it.
Trading in the London stock market was quiet yesterday as investors awaited news on the national budget that was presented to the Parliament after the exchange closed.
ALBANY, April 6 -- The Democratic bill increasing the state's minimum wage to $1.50 an hour, passed by the Senate two weeks ago tomorrow, has not been sent to Governor Rockefeller.
WASHINGTON, April 6 -- The cherry blossoms didn't come out today but Hubert H. Humphrey did.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., April 6 -- Citing Negro demands for employment, George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations said today that there must be enough jobs to go around.

DETROIT, April 6 (AP) -- A team of industrial chemists reported today that an insecticide effective against houseflies and certain other pests but "remarkably safe" for warm-blooded animals had been developed.
" THE BUS" is a good picture, certainly not a great one and anything but a finished work of film art. Just good.

The bitterly cruel choices forced upon individual women and on the medical profession by overly restrictive law were movingly presented in the Columbia Broadcasting System's documentary television program on abortion. As we have previously noted is true in New York State and elsewhere, law that makes an abortion legal only when performed to save the life of a mother, is certainly an example of man's inhumanity to man -- or, more directly, to woman.
The Dilowa Hutukhtu, the highest ranking Buddhist lama in the United States, is dying in a tiny three-room apartment in a shabby building just east of Third Avenue on 32d Street.

SAIGON, Wednesday, April 7 (AP) -- A fierce three-day battle in the swampy rice fields south of Saigon ended last night with 276 Vietcong killed and 33 captured, United States military spokesmen reported today. Six Americans died in the action.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 6 -- The Actor's Workshop of San Francisco staggered this year by the departure of a group of its mainstays to New York, charted a comeback today.
The volume of trading set a record yesterday in Maine potato futures but prices declined on profit taking on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
ROME, April 6 -- If the war in Vietnam is doing nothing else, it is demonstrating the need for greater coordination of allied policy all over the world.

EVEN in repose, John Joseph Gilhooley presents an image like the spanking new stainless steel subway cars he favors -- businesslike, built for speed, motor purring quietly but intensely under the functional facade, and yet a trifle romantic despite it all.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 6 -- Dr. Raul Prebisch, secretary general of the United Nations Trade and Development Conference, appealed strongly today against any expansion of what he termed "discriminatory preferential systems" in interna tional trade and urged their liquidation.
ALBANY, April 6 (AP) -- The State Bureau of Narcotic Control said today that 172 pharmacies in the state, including 86 in New York City, had been illegally selling cough syrups containing narcotics.

BRISTOL, England, April 6 -- One of the few major Soviet song and dance ensembles not previously seen in the West, the Red Navy Ensemble, opened a long British tour at the Hippodrome Theater last night.

TRENTON, April 6 (AP) -- The Port of New York Authority has completed its study of two north Jersey sites proposed for jetports and has found no reason to change its previous verdict that they are financially impractical.

Special elements of personal tragedy attend the resignation of James B. Carey as president of the International Union of Electrical Workers. He was one of the most engaging young leaders to come out of the unionization of the mass production industries in the early years of the New Deal.

A concert of large-scale works by A.W. Binder was given at Philharmonic Hall last night. Maurice Levine conducted symphony orchestra; Joan Caplan, contralto; Joseph Sopher, tenor; Lawrence Davidson, bass baritone, and Hanoch Greenfield, pianist, were the excellent soloists.
IN bridge, as in life, much hard work turns out to be wasted effort. This becomes particularly obvious when important matches are exhibited on Bridge-O-Rama, the large-screen viewing device.

Monday's $375 million jetliner order by United Air Lines may generate as much as $50 million in new business for the Pratt Whitney division of United Aircraft Corporation. Pratt and Whitney makes the engines for all six jets involved in the deal -- the largest and most expensive purchase of jet aircraft by a single commercial airline.
The President's latest farm message amounts to much ado about not much of anything.
Mayor Wagner predicted yesterday a successful season for the World's Fair.

WASHINGTON, April 6 (UPI) -- Buford Ellington, head of the President's Office of Emergency Planning, announced today he would make an in-depth study of whether residual oil import controls are in the national interest.
Revlon, Inc., the cosmetics producer, announced yesterday the election to the new post of group vice president-subsidiaries of Irving J. Bottner, Alec R. Faberman and Paul P. Woolard.
LISBON, April 6 -- Six university students pleaded not guilty today to charges of conspiring for the Portuguese Communist party, which is outlawed.
A new clue to the possible cause of rheumatoid arthritis was reported here yesterday.
NAIROBI, Kenya, April 6 -- Twenty-nine Kenyan students told today after their return from the Soviet Union of misery, hostility and beatings they suffered while at a university in Baku.
Government and corporate bond prices rose slightly yesterday. Some dealers considered the advance a reaction to the new British budget.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 6 -- Having chosen the future over Yogi Berra by arranging to keep all six of their remaining first-year players and not putting Yogi on the active list, the New York Mats went out tonight and lost to the Chicago White Sox 3-1.
WASHINGTON, April 6 -- The accelerated pace of fighting in Vietnam is reflected in a rising casualty rate -- American as well as Vietnamese -- according to the latest official figures.
WORK done by Marc Chagall during the last dozen years, shown in a loan exhibition at the Perls Gallery, 1016 Madison Avenue at 79th Street, proves that this eminent artist is still painting strongly.
WASHINGTON, April 6 -- The Administration's $1.3 billion school-aid bill emerged unchanged from Senate committee today and moved to the floor for opening debate tomorrow.

For the last five months he had been one of New York's forgotten men. But yesterday Kenneth B. Keating was strolling jauntily down Park Avenue, the campaign manner in all his movements -- his blue eyes twinkling smiles of recognition, his right hand quickly extended to those who called out, "Hello, Senator -- you're looking great, Senator."
WASHINGTON, April 6 -- The Kennedy round of trade negotiations is entering a new and accelerated phase, two United States officials stated today.
WASHINGTON, April 6 -- House approval this week of the Administration's program of medical care for the aged was virtually assured today as the Rules Committee sent the authorizing bill to the floor.

PARIS, April 6 -- With the vanguard of the 1965 tourist invasion already in command of strategic cafes and museums, the Government today began a large-scale compaign to persuade Frenchmen to treat tourists with kindness.
TORONTO, April 6 (AP) -- Dave Keon's unassisted goal gave the Toronto Maple Leafs a 3-2 overtime victory over the Montreal Canadiens tonight.

THE telecast of the annual Oscar awards was the high moment of theater in the current television season. In setting, in cast of players and in emotional undercurrents, the denouement of the backstage drama stemming from Jack L. Warner's decision to use Audrey Hepburn rather than Julie Andrews in the film version of "My Fair Lady" unfolded with the inexorable relentlessness of a Greek play.
Samsonite Corporation, the luggage concern, raised sales and earnings in 1964 to the highest levels in its 54-year history, King D. Shwayder, president, reported yesterday.
Portugal's apparel industry may be on the crest of an export boom similar to that experienced in recent years by both the Italian and Spanish industries, two Portuguese spokesmen declared yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 6 -- District Attorney Frank D. O'Connor of Queens came to the capital today and attempted to organize bipartisan support for a direct primary law in New York State.

CHEESECAKE -- the type that appeals to women as well as men -- can be a gloriously creamy concoction or a dry disappointment. Fortunately, however, two cheesecakes sampled recently are difinitely in the glorious category.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- President Johnson asked the Senate today to ratify two amendments to the United Nations Charter that would increase the memberships of the Security Council and the Economic and Social Council.
HOLLYWOOD, April 6 -- The film industry's self-administered censorship code is undergoing the first major overhaul of its 35-year history.

NOBODY dropped a pin, but if anyone had, it would have made a clatter. It was 9 o'clock on a recent Monday morning, and four young men and nine young women sat perched on stools waiting the arrival of the master.
WASHINGTON, April 6 -- The House Banking Committee approved unanimously today legislation authorizing a 25 per cent increase in the United States quota in the International Monetary Fund.

A $2 million damage suit was filed yesterday in Federal Court here against the Ford Motor Company, which was accused of fraud in including Richard I. Zraick of 142 96th Street, Brooklyn, to enter into a dealership contract for the sale of Ford cars in Paterson, N.J.
ALGIERS, April 6 -- President Ahmed Ben Bella presented an $840 million budget for 1965 tonight. He said it represented a "transition" to Socialism.
VIENNA, April 6 (AP) -- The United States and West Germany agreed today to merge their two color television systems for adoption in most West European countries.
The American Hoist and Derrick Company's dividend policy and debt position are two of the reasons why Poor Co. directors may turn down a merger proposal the company made last month.
Shares traded on the American Stock Exchange yesterday weakened in quiet trading.

The George A. Fuller Company, one of the nation's largest contractors and construction companies, will reverse the trend of private companies going public, if a proposed plan of purchase is consummated. The directors of the company approved yesterday an offer to acquire Fullers business and assets, Lou R. Crandall, chairman, announced yesterday.
ROME, April 6 -- Pope Paul VI will soon issue a decree modifying Roman Catholic Church regulations for mixed marriages, Vatican sources said today.

Charles W. Ufford Jr. of the Harvard Club was elected president of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association at its annual meeting and dinner last night in the Princeton Club. Ufford also received the President's Prize for the highest winning percentage in Class A league play last season.
I read with some surprise the letter signed "Reservists," published March 24.
The stock brokerage house of Bache Co. announced yesterday that its advertising account would remain uptown and, in fact, would move to the main drag -- Madison Avenue.

Leading into Room 901 of the New York Stock Exchange at 11 Wall Street, far above the hue and cry of the trading floor, is a walnut-stained metal door bearing these words of eternal employe hope and opportunity: "Personnel -- Benefit Plans, Salaries Wages."

SALISBURY, N.C., April 6 -- Bobby Dodd of Georgia Tech is a refreshingly different type of college football coach. If he had not built up so much prestige in his profession over the years, the other lodge brothers would begin to look askance at some of his far-out theories and wonder if they shouldn't ask him to turn in his union card.

RICHMOND, April 6 (UPI) -- Indictments were returned today against an Army sergeant and a former Army sergeant accused of selling missile data and other defense secrets to the Russians for more than a decade.

Three men were named yesterday in separate indictments yesterday by a Federal grand jury on charges of preparing fraudulent income tax returns for taxpayers. The indictments accused the three of preparing 252 fraudulent returns that defrauded the Government of almost $60,000.
Eastern Air Lines disclosed last night that it had placed another equipment order. This one is for four outsized DC-8 jet airliners.

ALBANY, April 6 -- The Senate seat once held by Manhattan Borough President Constance Baker Motley has been vacant for six weeks but neither Republican or Democratic leaders are pressing for a special election to fill the seat.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., April 6 -- Response to a Democratic advertisement seeking qualified candidates for public office in this South Fork township has been poor, according to the town's Democratic chairman.
Heavy competition in the making of precision bearings appears to be dooming an attempt to increase prices.

WASHINGTON, April 6 (UPI) -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee recommended today that Congress go on record as favoring an interruption of aid for any country that allows United States property to be damaged by mob action.
VOGUE magazine's Prix de Paris, for 24 years one of the fashion industry's most important talent searches, is being revived.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, April 6 (UPI) -- The Turkish Cypriote leader, Dr. Fazil Kutchuk, accused Britain today of having failed to live up to her responsibilities to the Turkish community on Cyprus.

The Board of Education has offered a wide choice of integrated high schools, beginning with the fall term, to about 6,000 ninth graders who already have been assigned to seven schools with high enrollments of Negroes and Puerto Ricans.

William F. Buckley Jr. sent copies of a speech he made at a policemen's communion breakfast here to some of his critics yesterday to support his contention it had been misrepresented in news accounts.
An investigation of alleged rigged bids for city painting jobs spread to the Board of Education yesterday.
A former actor-waiter, who scored a hit last season with his first producing venture, has been barred from soliciting funds for a proposed Broadway production.

CLEARWATER, Fla., April 6 (AP) -- Bob Kiersky of Pittsburgh, the defending champion, defeated George Edmundson of Tampa, Fla., 2 up, today in the opening round of match play in the 31st annual American seniors golf tournament.
OTTAWA, April 6 -- John Diefenbaker, leader of the Conservative Opposition, opened debate on Prime Minister Lester B. Pearson's new legislative program tonight with a move for a no-confidence vote.
ST. LOUIS, April 6 (AP) -- A.J. Cervantes, a Democrat who said St. Louis had suffered a "progress gap" under 16 years of Democratic control, was elected Mayor of this city of 711,000 today.
The Stanley Warner Corporation reported yesterday record earnings in the quarter and six months ended Feb. 27.

Opening day ceremonies of the 1965 season of the New York World's Fair will be televised live by station WABC-TV (Channel 7) from 9:30 A.M. to noon on April 21. From 7:30 to 8:30 that evening a tour of the fair will be televised nationally by the Columbia Broadcasting System.
MONTEGO BAY, Jamaica, April 6 -- Three days after the start of the Miami-Montego Bay yacht race, the 72-foot ketch Ticonderoga today got the wind she likes and began pulling away from the fleet.

PHILADELPHIA, April 6 -- Home for the Philadelphia 76ers had all the warmth and friendliness that poets write about tonight as the 76ers evened the National Basketball Association Eastern Division final playoff series with the Boston Celtics at Convention Hall.

Sales and profits of the P. Lorillard Company, the nation's oldest tobacco concern, are expected to be "substantially higher" for the first quarter of this year than in the corresponding period last year, Morgan J. Cramer, president, told the company's annual meeting yesterday.

Columbia's climb from the depths in intercollegiate rowing is a tortuous process, but under the enthusiastic hardworking young coach, Carl Ullrich, definite progress has been made in the four years he has been developing Light Blue eights.
The New York City Central Labor Council voted at a meeting yesterday to give "all-out support" to the store clerks union on strike at Bloomingdale's.
Nearly 90,000 public and parochial school children will be without transportation this morning if school bus drivers carry out a threat to strike.
BERLIN, April 6 (AP) -- Russian tanks clattered along East Germany's express highways today, pushing traffic off the road.

McGraw-Hill plans publication of the Atlantic Policy Studies, a series sponsored by the Council on Foreign Relations. The studies will measure the resources of the Atlantic countries and consider how they can shape a world in which freedom can flourish.
American businessmen with interests in Britain breathed a sigh of relief yesterday that the new Labor Government's budget indicated continued support for the pound at its present $2.80 level.
WASHINGTON, April 6 -- An Early Bird communications satellite was launched front Cape Kennedy tonight, opening a new chapter in the space age.

LONDON, April 6 -- In moving to reduce British consumption by $700 million a year and the outflow of capital by a sum that may be at least $275 million a year, James Callaghan, Chancellor of the Exchequer, has taken strong action to defend the 16-year-old parity of the pound at $2.80.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector) April 6 -- Dr. Kurt Birrenbach, the special West German envoy, arrived here today for the third round of talks on German economic and security aid to Israel.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 6 -- Specialists on Asian affairs estimated today that North Vietnam could absorb considerable punishment from United States air strikes over an extended period without any decisive disruption of its economy.

The fifth annual Crystal Ball, a benefit for the Episcopal Mission Society in the Diocese of New York, will be held on April 30 at Brookside, the estate of Mr. and Mrs. Roger Glenn Mook in Rye, N.Y. The ball is under the auspices of the Westchester Committee of the society's woman's council Mrs. Mook is chairman of the event.
Armed robbers in Queens invaded two homes yesterday, seizing a total of $29,400 in jewelry, furs and money.
PARIS, April 6 -- The French Government recently rejected a request by the United States to reopen its consulate in Papeete, the capital of Tahiti and French islands in the South Pacific.
Peter W. Gavian has been named financial vice president of Nuclear Utility Services, Inc. He was treasurer of Greater Washington Industrial Investments, Inc.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 6 -- The 15th annual United Nations Art Club Exhibition for the benefit of the United Nations Children's Fund opens tomorrow in the public lobby of the General Assembly Building to run through May 5.
WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP) -- Negotiators went back to work today in an effort to settle a dispute that has halted operations of Pan American Airways.
The Bankers Trust Company reported yesterday a 26 per cent jump in first-quarter earnings, the largest relative gain shown so far for the period by any major New York City Bank.

The cold war in international monetary relations is entering a new phase. With Britain's Labor Government curbing its expansionist concepts in order to bolster the beseiged pound and with the Johnson Administration gaining the spirited cooperation of the American business community in reasserting the basic strength of the dollar, prospects for negotiations on reform of the present monetary system have improved.
WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP) -- The National Congress of American Indians opposed today legislation to terminate Federal supervision of the Colville Indians of Washington State.

BERLIN, April 6 -- Communist authorities temporarily blockaded the principal highway linking Berlin with West Germany again today in direct challenge of the Western allies' right of free access to the former German capital.
THE following menu is suggested as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A recipe is given for the easy-to-prepare main dish.
The National Industrial Conference Board announced yesterday that Albert T. Sommers, an assistant vice president, was elected a vice president of the economic research organization.
An easy tone prevailed in the stock market yesterday and closing prices were slightly below those on Monday.
Bertrand Russell was quoted yesterday as having said that "were I in New York, I would certainly be guilty of trying to overthrow the government of the State of New York."

YONKERS, April 6 -- Safe Return proved to be a speedball from New Zealand tonight, when the 8-year-old gelding from Christchurch led from wire to wire in the Invitation one-mile pace, the feature at Yonkers Raceway.

ARMONK, N.Y., April 6 -- Wellesley-in-Westchester will give a discotheque dance on April 24 at the Bel Aire Country Club. Proceeds will go to the Wellesley College scholarship and faculty salary advancement funds.
BOSTON, April 6 -- Corruption involving "scores of millions of dollars" exists in the state government of Massachusetts, according to a report being prepared by the state's Crime Commission.
Unscrupulous lumber mills and chiseling builders are trying to flood the metropolitan area with inferior structural wood, city officials said yesterday.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 6 -- Arnold Palmer explained today how it felt to be back in the land of Arnold Palmer. A year ago he won the Masters golf tournament here for the fourth time and made it look easy.
The Union Electric Company sold $35 million of 30-year first-mortgage bonds yesterday to an investment banking syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc.
WASHINGTON, April 6 -- An Administration spokesman threw cold water today on a Senate proposal to control air pollution attributed to automobile exhaust.
Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson came to New York City last night for dinner, cocktails and a special guided tour of a new exhibit of American art, all at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
The final version of the city's bill to preserve landmarks was approved yesterday by 33 of the City Council's 35 members.

LOS ANGELES, April 6 (AP) -- Mayor Samuel W. Yorty's quest for a second term appeared headed for success tonight. With more than half of the city's precincts reporting, he held a large lead over Representative James Roosevelt.
WASHINGTON, April 6 -- James B. Carey said today that he would resign as president of the strife-torn International Union of Electrical Workers.
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., April 7 -- The New York Yankees lost today for the 17th time in 27 games this spring, then prepared to pull up stakes and head for New York by way of the West Coast.
Mrs. Myrtie H. Johnson, 35-year-old head of the public reference room here of the Securities and Exchange Commission, is preparing for a sharp rise in activity.
WASHINGTON, April 7 -- Following are excerpts from recent Administration statements on the United States attitude toward negotiations on Vietnam:

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- A House Judiciary subcommittee began detailed consideration of the voting-rights bill today. The pressure immediately developed for including an outright ban on state and local poll taxes.
Albert Benjamin (Happy) Chandler, a former Commissioner of Baseball, United States Senator and Governor of Kentucky, returned to sports yesterday in a fighting mood.
The New York and the American Stock Exchanges reported yesterday the changes carried below in the shareholdings of officers, directors and controlling stockholders of listed companies.

COMMACK, L.I., April 7 -- The happiest person on Long Island tonight may have been the owner of Barton's liquor store in Farmingdale. He supplied the champagne for the Long Island Ducks' victory party after they captured the Walker Cup Trophy, emblematic of the Eastern Hockey League's championship.

SYOSSET, L.I., April 7 -- A green Rockefeller Center on a suburban scale was recommended for the heart of Nassau County today by the Regional Plan Association. The new center would be established in a 10-square-mile area including Mitchel Field and the surrounding 5,000 acres.
The directors of the General Instrument Corporation resumed dividend payments on the common stock, with the declaration yesterday of a 2 per cent distribution on the 2,570,311 shares outstanding.

The Chase Manhattan Bank reported yesterday that its first-quarter after-tax earnings climbed 7.5 per cent from the level a year earlier to $22,176,574, or $1.06 a share. In the first three months of 1964, the bank earned $20,625,896, or 98 cents a share.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 7 -- Thirty-five United States Navy planes destroyed seven trucks and damaged four others today during bombing and strafing attacks along a major highway in North Vietnam.
CAIRO, April 7 -- "Spellbound, that's it," the critic wrote. "The audience was too spellbound to applaud. I tried to clap myself but I said it's better not to and I sank back into my emotions."

MIDDLE ISLAND, L.I., April 6 -- Anyone with the means and will can buy a drugstore, a general store, perhaps even a blacksmith's shop, but it isn't often that they will find all three for sale under one roof, as they can do in this Long Island town.
What are the minimum standards for a good judge?
The Board of Higher Education agreed last night to give John J. Meng, president of Hunter College, a six-month leave to serve as a special consultant on academic planning to St. John's University.

NASSAU, Bahamas, April 7 (AP) -- Don Aronow, a former Brooklyn College athlete who builds power boats as a hobby, drove a new hull of his own design to a record victory today in the 160-mile Miami-to-Nassau race.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., April 7 (AP) -- The end of a teachers' work stoppage in this city sent pupils and teachers back to school today in a mood that one high school principal described as "very subdued and very pleased to be back."
A strike by the employes of severalhundred shops in the garment industry was threatened yesterday for May 3 by District 65 of the Retail, While-sale and Department Store Workers Union.
PHILADELPHIA, April 7 -- The industrialized Western world has no monopoly on air pollution and its possible ill effects, according to a scientific report here today.

What A Treat contributed an upset at Aqueduct yesterday when she won the $27,550 Prioress Stakes. The six-furlong sprint for 3-year-old fillies loomed as a "sure thing" for the Ethel D. Jacobs entry of Admiring and Adorable and the 26,489 fans bet the pair into 7-to-10 favoritism.
VIENNA, April 7 -- A 45-nation conference called to recommend color television standards for the world ended today without having achieved its purpose.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- The man who has so much to do with the Early Bird communications satellite is Leo Dewey Welch, the tall, graying, blue-eyed chairman and chief executive officer of the Communications Satellite Corporation.

BERLIN, April 7 -- Soviet jet fighters zoomed low over West Berlin's Congress Hall today in angry protest against the presence there of the West German Parliament. Communist authorities again blocked land access to the city for part of the day.

HOUSTON, April 7 -- Paul Richards talked while he waited for the car to take him and his visitor to the Astrodome and the general manager of the Houston ball club is much better at talking than at waiting.
Civil rights lawyers tried a new tactic yesterday in their drive against racial discrimination in housing by accusing the Akron, Ohio, Board of Realtors of violating the Sherman Antitrust Act.
BOGALUSA, La., Thursday, April 8 (UPI) -- William Yates, a Congress of Racial Equality worker, said early today that about 30 shots were fired over and into a Negro home where he was staying.
The stock market advanced slightly yesterday, but there was no definite trend. Trading was quiet throughout the session.

LOS ANGELES, Calif., April 7 (UPI) -- The SNAP 10-A satellite, which carries the first nuclear power plant operated in space, has run into mysterious trouble with another major experiment -- its ion engine.

TOKYO, April 7 (AP) -- The Vietcong threatened today to shoot a kidnapped United States aid officer, Gustav C. Hertz of Leesburg, Va., if the Saigon Government executed a terrorist arrested in the bombing of the United States embassy March 30.
A year ago Kingman Brewster Jr. was inaugurated as president of Yale in a ceremony of pomp such as had not been witnessed in academia for many years.
MRS. DOROTHY BENITEZ of South Plainfield, N.J., married 25 years this month, told her husband, a barber, not to buy her silver for the anniversary. She would go to Chicago and win some, she said.

WROCLAW, Poland, April 7 -- Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin of the Soviet Union condemned United States activities in Vietnam today and said "peace-loving nations will never forgive the United States imperialists' barbarism" there.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., April 7 (AP) -- Three white men, arrested two weeks ago in connection with the slaying of a Detroit housewife, were charged today in a Federal indictment with conspiring to pursue and assault civil rights marchers.
M. Lamar Muse has been elected president of Central Airlines. He was financial vice president of Southern Airways. As president, he succeeds L.E. Glasgow.

The Rev. Gommar A. De Pauw, spiritual leader of the Catholic Traditionalist Movement, yesterday "disassociated" himself from the conservative group on the direct order of his superior, Lawrence Cardinal Shehan of Baltimore.
The civil-rights effort against tax-exempt municipal bond sales to finance segregated facilities has been taken out of the Street and into the courts.

The American Broadcasting Company will make use of the so-called isolated camera for "instant replays" when it begins televising major league baseball April 17. The technique was widely used last year in television coverage of professional football.

When an out-of-state resident who works in Manhattan goes home at night, he does not necessarily leave his New York State tax problems at the office. True, the general rule is that income earned in New York is taxable by this state, and what is earned in New Jersey, Connecticut, Pennsylvania and elsewhere is not.
A stock that was subject to a speculative spree last fall -- Fotochrome, Inc. -- showed renewed signs of life yesterday on the American Stock Exchange.

WASHINGTON, April 7 (UPI) -- A Federal grand jury indicted today two Negroes involved in a Senate investigation into bank failures on charges of defrauding a now-defunct Texas bank of nearly $190,000.
The Ford Motor Company and the Hertz Corporation announced yesterday that they would engage in a joint advertising program, beginning late this year.
MOSCOW, April 7 -- The Soviet Union denied today allegations abroad that 14 Soviet astronauts had died in space accidents since 1960.

ATLANTA, April 7 (AP) -- A former grand dragon of the Florida Ku Klux Klan has offered to provide the House Un-American Activities Committee information about the Klan, the publisher of The Atlanta Constitution said tonight.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 7 -- Ninety-one of the world's finest golfers will begin play tomorrow at the Augusta National Golf Club in the 29th Masters tournament.
Seven young women will be presented at the St. Nicholas Society Paas (Dutch for Easter) Festival Ball on April 24 in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.
The Arkansas Power and Light Company raised $32.5 million yesterday through the sales of bonds and preferred stock.
PITTSBURGH, April 7 (AP) -- A Canadian financial consultant filed suit against an oil company today demanding $17,661,489 for services he contends he performed.
MADRID, April 7 -- A reorganization of the university students' organization on a more representative basis was decreed today by the Spanish Government.
Two New York psychologists have reported making animals apparently smarter than normal by giving them growth hormone before they are born.
PARIS, April 7 -- "We gnomes think it's positive," a Zurich banker said today.
A jukebox company allegedly headed by a Cosa Nostra figure succeeded yesterday in preventing the State Liquor Authority from examining its records.

HOUSTON April 7 -- "Nobody can ever see this," said Roy Mark Hofheinz, jabbing a cigar toward his Astrodome, "and go back to Kalamazoo, Chicago, New York, you name it, and still think this town is bush league, that this town is Indian territory."
While Comsat's first revenue-producing satellite reached for the sky yesterday, the company launched its proxy statement for its 1965 annual meeting.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- In one of his most learned and longest opinions, Chief Justice Warren sustained the judgment of the Federal Trade Commission that the televised "sandpaper" commercial of the Colgate-Palmolive Company misled the viewers.
BERLIN, April 7 (Reuters) -- Two world records were set today at the start of a United States-West German track and field meet.

The Advertising Writers Association of New York presented its annual Gold and Silver Key awards last night and inducted Rosser Reeves, chairman of Ted Bates Co., Inc., into the Advertising Hall of Fame.

DETROIT, April 7 -- The automobile industry, although still asserting that the need for nationwide controls of automobile exhaust has not been proved, said today that it could provide devices on 1968 models if Congress insisted.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, April 7 -- Several bomb hoaxes, which security officers said were the latest tactic in Indonesia's war of nerves against Malaysia, were staged today in Kuala Lumpur and Sinapore.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., April 7 -- Roger Maris was found not guilty of assault and battery today after he took the witness stand for 17 minutes and denied he was the New York Yankees' leading after-hours slugger.
LONDON, April 7 -- Britain has just become one of the few countries outside the Communist bloc to disallow tax benefits for business entertaining.

OTTAWA, April 7 (Canadian Press) -- The minority Liberal Government of Prime Minister Lester D. Pearson easily survived its first test of confidence in the House of Commons today, drawing support from members of the Social Credit and Creditiste (Quebec) parties and two former Conservatives.
New York City will ask the Legislature for authority for a long-term 20 per cent increase in real estate taxes and short-term interim borrowing to raise more than $150 million a year.

THE PRINCETON CHAMBER ORCHESTRA made its debut last night in Town Hall, playing a program of string music. Then why call itself a chamber orchestra? It was explained that the group does occasionally use winds and brass, which would put it in the chamber rather than string orchestra category.

THE normal feast-or-famine syndrome of Seventh Avenue has plenty to feed on these days. Although the spring sun finally broke through high and clear over the avenue's concrete skyline, the season unhappily was already being written off by many garment men as a heartbreaker.

As executive director of the Bronx Union Branch of the Y.M.C.A. of Greater New York, which is located in the southeast Bronx, I am concerned about the possibility that our immediate neighborhood may become an even more dangerous community if unrestricted issuance of package liquor store licenses is permitted.

About 30 physicians took time out from their professional duties yesterday to picket the International Automobile Show in the Coliseum at Columbus Circle. They were protesting "safety defects in current auto designs," according to the sandwich board signs that the men and women carried.
WASHINGTON, April 7 -- Manufacturing corporations increased profits in the fourth quarter of last year by every basic measure -- dollar total, percentage of sales and as a percentage of investment.

In the March 31 issue of The Times, C.L. Sulzberger reported that "there had been indications that China wished to make of Ceylon the bottom half of a nutcracker whose top is Tibet and slowly, immutably, to crush India in between."

The Mayor of Rye, N.Y. -- population 15,000 -- was named yesterday as the next United States manager and president of the Royal-Globe Insurance Companies, the world's largest property and casualty insurance organization.
LOS ANGELES, April 7 -- Mayor Samuel W. Yorty won a second four-year term by a landslide over Representative James Roosevelt and five other candidates.
WASHINGTON -- "I mustn't show you the kitchen," Mrs. Turgut Menemencioglu said, sounding like any ordinary housewife as she greeted a guest. "It is nothing to look at and we are having it repaired."

TOKYO, April 7 (Comtelburo) -- The Ministry of Finance said today Japanese banks were expected shortly to repay loans totaling $11 million to three foreign banks on behalf of the Sanyo Steel Company, which now is in receivership.
HONG KONG, April 7 -- North Vietnam announced today the appointment of a new Foreign Minister, a move that may mean an increasingly militant stand by Hanoi.

The United Nations, in the first large-scale move from its original East Side headquarters, has leased 47,300 square feet of office space at 866 United Nations Plaza, one block north of the General Assembly Building.

WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP) -- A New York weekly newspaper manager and two members of the Women Strike for Peace, an organization opposing nuclear bombs, went on trial today before Federal Judge Edward M. Curran on contempt of Congress charges.
MOSCOW, April 7 -- The Chinese Communists were reported tonight to have ceased putting obstacles in the way of Soviet arms shipments to North Vietnam.

The Police Department asserted yesterday that newly increased inspections had saved a Puerto Rican prisoner from attempted suicide. Four Puerto Rican suicides by hanging in police cells occurred in February and March.
ROME, April 7 -- A Vatican Lenten mass last Sunday at a parish church the Pope "was not engaging in a polemic, nor did he intend any offense to the Jews."

City chapters of the Congress of Racial Equality announced yesterday they were unalterably opposed to the re-election of Mayor Wagner. To dramatize their position, they plan a series of demonstrations, including an opening-day action at the World's Fair.

RICHMOND, April 7 -- A Federal Appeals Court said here today that the United States Constitution did not require the transportation of pupils from one area to another "solely for the purpose of mixing the races in the schools."

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 7 -- Achkar Marof, Guinea's chief delegate, deplored today what he called the "wanton executions" of opponents of South Africa's apartheid or racial segregation policies. He said these policies of Prime Minister Hendrik F. Verwoerd were "leading the whites on a suicidal path."

BOLOGNA, Italy, April 6 -Bologna, the biggest Communist-ruled city west of the Iron Curtain, represents the "smiling efficient, showcase face" of Italian Communism turned toward the rest of the country and the world.
The New York State Banking Board approved yesterday the proposed merger of the Grace National Bank into the Marine Midland Trust Company, both in New York City.
Dr. Sterling Wade Brown was elected president yesterday of the National Conference of Christians and Jews.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- Republicans began peppering President Johnson's $1.3 billion school-aid bill with proposed amendments as debate on the biggest of the Great Society programs opened today in the Senate.
About 50,000 state institutional employes will receive their regular pay tomorrow despite the fact that New York does not have a budget from which to pay them.
This week's largest single new municipal issue, the $10 million State of California San Francisco Harbor Development bonds, was awarded yesterday to a syndicate headed by the United California Bank.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 7 (AP) -- Miss Susan Stein, the daughter of Jules Stein, founder of the Music Corporation of America, the theatrical agency, suffered a fractured skull in a highway accident last night. She was reported in serious condition today in a Bermuda hospital after surgery.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- The ignominious fall of James B. Carey at the age of 53 illustrates one aspect of a problem that American unions have never solved: How to develop new leaders and provide for their orderly elevation to high posts.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 7 -- The newly formed United Nations Trade and Development Board ended three days of behind-the-scenes tension today and elected the remaining 11 members of its 12-man official bureau -- but not without a minor victory for the Soviet Union.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- President Johnson presented the National Teacher of the Year Award to a sixth-grade teacher from Colorado today and let out a poorly kept secret by saying he might like to win the award himself someday.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- The second annual Otto Awards for Distinguished and Humane Inaction were put in the mail without fanfare Monday night while the movie industry was passing out Oscars on television.
The Star of India sapphire, which was stolen from the American Museum of Natural History with 23 other gems last October, will have its own display on the main floor of the museum.

WASHINGTON, April 7 (UPI) -- Senator Paul H. Douglas, chairman of a joint economic committee studying ocean shipping rates, said today that Congress may have to outlaw rate discrimination against United States exporters.

WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board proposed today that air-taxi operators be allowed to carry mail. The board also proposed to extend the operating authority of air-taxi services indefinitely. It is now due to expire next Dec. 31.
TODAY'S books contrast the realities and illusions of modern life. They quicken our wonder at the odd ways and chances that wreck dreams or exalt the positions of ordinary and extraordinary people.
A letter written by President Franklin D. Roosevelt, with stress on the Ten Commandments, will be placed on display today in the main lobby of Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue and 65th Street.

Two young women who had escaped from a Massachusetts mental hospital crashed through three roadblocks while leading the police of Connecticut, Westchester County and New York City on a 45-mile Chase yesterday morning.
WASHINGTON, April 7 (UPI) -- Many of America's best spies abroad are top Communist party officials, Senator Milton R. Young, Republican of North Dakota, said today.
President Johnson's address on South Vietnam was seen and heard last night by an estimated 60,000,000 television viewers in the country, of whom 5,500,000 were in the New York metropolitan area.

It was a pleasant trick of destiny that the first foreign chief of state received by President Johnson since his inauguration came from one of the poorest, weakest and most remote countries in the world. He was President Maurice Yameogo of Upper Volta, a landlocked country that once was a part of French West Africa.
WASHINGTON, April 7 -- The Early Bird satellite passed its first communications test today with a mark of "excellent."
STANLEYVILLE, the Congo, April 7 -- Former Belgian colonial administrators are returning to the Congo to take up positions they left when the country became independent five years ago.
The publishers of seven of the city's daily newspapers reached an agreement with the photo-engravers last night. The publishers' dispute with the printers was settled early yesterday morning.
The nation's electric power production rose 9.4 per cent in the week ended April 3 from the level in the corresponding 1965 week, it was reported yesterday by the Edison Electric, Institute.

LEXINGTON, Ky., April 7 (UPI) -- Six Protestant denominations, after three years of talks, took the first concrete step today toward merging into a united church that would band together more than one-third of the nation's Protestants.
Data published in Pravda, the Communist party newspaper, indicate the non-Communist world widened its industrial production lead over the Communist countries during 1964.
BALTIMORE, April 7 -- President Johnson said tonight that the United States was ready to begin, without prior conditions, diplomatic discussions to end the war in Vietnam.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 7 -- Robert H. Gerdes was advanced today from president to chairman of the Pacific Gas and Electric Company, one of the nation's biggest investor-owned utilities, with assets exceeding $3 billion.
There is something polluting the Administration's testimony on the Clean Air Act; and from its odor, we judge that "something" to be politics.

The Waterfront Commission obtained a temporary order in a New Jersey state court yesterday that prevents the International Longshoremen's Association and the New York Shipping Association from requiring newly registered longshoremen to pass a pre-employment medical examination.

CHICAGO, April 7 -- D.C. Burnham, president of the Westinghouse Electric Company, told the annual stockholders' meeting here in McCormick Place that the company was prepared to build and "guarantee" a seawater-conversion plant with a capacity of 50 million gallons a day.

A $30 million damage suit charging patent infringement was filed here yesterday in Federal Court against the International Business Machines Corporation by an inventor who has done considerable work for the Navy.
Not far north of the Queensboro Bridge a group of hard workers in hard hats are pulling gneiss and schist from the East River.
WASHINGTON, April 7 (UPI) -- Members of Congress differed widely in their reaction to President Johnson's speech tonight on United States policy in Vietnam.
The Great American Insurance Company realigned its top management yesterday and announced the selection of a new director.
A survey of 400 Californians at a Los Angeles hospital has brought to light patterns of hormone change that seem typical of various forms of cancer, including those that attack the lungs.

TOKYO, April 7 -- Japan will send a delegation to a potentially important meeting of Asian and African leaders in Indonesia beginning April 17. She hopes to establish there her first unofficial contact with Communist China on a significant level.
Street repair work in the vicinity of the World's Fair in Queens is being expedited to make the thoroughfares ready for the exposition's opening on April 21.
CIBA, Ltd., the big pharmaceutical and chemical producer of Switzerland, last year turned in the highest sales and earnings in its 80-year history, according to a report issued yesterday.

HALLANDALE, Fla., April 7 (AP) -- Tibidabo and I'm Rusty, a two 3-year-old colts who did not make the Florida Derby, won the two divisions of the Hallandale Handicap at Gulf-stream Park today in identical times of 1:11 for the six furlongs.
The Medical Society of New York called yesterday for "total war" against health quackery and vowed forceful action to eradicate it in the state.
WASHINGTON, April 7 -- Ray C. Bliss, who took office last Thursday as Republican National Chairman, has begun to reshape the headquarters staff to meet his professional and personal demands.
The State Department of Mental Health has begun a "thorough review" of charges that certain widely used tranquilizers had affected the eyes of patients.

Under the proposed Voting Rights Act of 1965, Alabama would be one of six states forbidden from continuing to apply any literacy test to voter applicants. One reason for this seemingly harsh restriction can be seen from the character of some of the questions recently used on the Alabama literacy test.

LONDON, April 7 -- The American dancer Charles Weidman, one of the pioneers of the modern movement, opened his London debut season with a "calligraphic artist," Mikhail Santaro, at the Commonwealth Institute last night.
The Wellington Management Company, adviser to the Wellington Fund, announced yesterday the appointment of Daniel S. Ahearn as a vice president and a member of its investment committee.
Representative Adam Clayton Powell came to New York yesterday. It was the first time in five months that he had been known to have set foot here on a weekday.
WASHINGTON, April 7 (UPI) -- The House has voted $325,000 to build an armored bubble-top limousine for use by President Johnson.
WASHINGTON, April 7 -- Two major considerations were understood here to have prompted President Johnson's offer tonight to talk with anyone at any time about Vietnam.
TRYING to find trend in fishing activity for the four-state area of New York, New Jersey, Pennsylvania and Connecticut is like trying to grab an eel.
PARIS, April 7 -- Paris newspapers headlined France's "victory" today in the battle of color television.

WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP) -- Applicants for Federal grants to construct hospitals, nursing homes, health centers and related facilities now must provide satisfactory assurance that they are complying with the Civil Rights Act.
WASHINGTON, April 7 -Sherpa guides, who are indispendable to Mount Everest explorers, have a larger interest in Mount Kennedy these days, although they may never touch its slopes.
BUCHAREST, March 31 -- A feeling of frustration comes over the visitor to this country on being told by Rumanians that he did not see what he saw and did not hear what he heard.

ONE of the minor surprises of the World Team Olympiad held in New York a year ago was the excellent performance of the Australian team, which finished sixth in a field of 29. It was surprising only because the Australians inevitably suffer from a lack of experience in international competition.
WASHINGTON, April 7 -- Paul Jennings took over today as president of the International Union of Electrical Workers, ending a long battle for power within the strife-torn union.

TOKYO, Thursday, April 8 -- Japan will cooperate with the United States in measures to achieve stabilization in South Vietnam advanced by President Johnson in his speech yesterday, a Government spokesman said today.

The Federal District Court here abruptly halted yesterday the imposition of extra charges on shippers by 18 steamship lines that carry cargoes out of Atlantic and Gulf ports to South American and Caribbean ports.

Oscar Kolin was elected president yesterday of Helena Rubinstein. Inc., according to an announcement by Roy V. Titus, chairman and chief executive officer. The election took place at a special board meeting at which time Miss Mala Rubinstein was elected a director.

In the living room of a tiny ground-floor rear flat in a shabby tenement at 204 East 32d Street, the Dilowa Hutukhtu -- Living Buddha of the yellow Sect of Mahayana Buddhism -- died at 7:15 A.M. yesterday.

ALBANY, April 7 -- A bill that would help New York City recover the hundreds of thousands of dollars it spends repairing slum tenements won final approval today from the Democratic dominated Legislature.
The British pound rose yesterday in active trading on foreign exchange markets here.
ALBANY, April 7 -- The cost of a telephone call in outlying suburban areas of New York City will go up in some places and down in others next month.

WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP) -- All Federal veterans hospitals and offices would continue operating through June 30 under a resolution unanimously approved today by a Senate Veterans Affairs Subcommittee.
The 8:13 left 145th Street and Lenox Avenue last night with seven passengers and a rosy-cheeked city patrolman named Michael Fox riding shotgun.

The nation's stock of gasoline declined 981,000 barrels in the week ended last Friday, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the weekend, supplies totaled 231,183,000 barrels, compared with the record 232,164,000 a week earlier and 214,864,000 a year ago.

" Africa: From Independence to Tomorrow," by David Hapgood, will be published by Atheneum on April 22. The author suggests that Africa is being damaged by the continuation of education along lines introduced by the former colonial powers.
A wildcat strike by 1,000 drivers and mechanics left 81,350 public and parochial school pupils without bus service yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 7 -- The United States is nearing agreement with Jordan to supply additional arms, including tanks, to help modernize her army.
BONN, April 7 -- Badische Anilin Soda Fabrik, West Germany's mammoth chemical company, celebrated its 100th birthday yesterday.
A grand master and former United States champion, Arthur Bisguier of New York, is flying tomorrow to Zagreb, Yugoslavia, to play in the Tournament of Peace, which begins Monday.
On Oct. 10, 1959, Tony Canzoneri, who had earned more than $500,000 in the boxing ring, died in a $21-a-week hotel room in the Times Square area.
The Union Carbide Corporation announced yesterday the development of a new family of plastics that it said was one of the "strongest, most heat-resisting" thermoplastics now now available.
DUBLIN, April 7 (AP) -- Ireland voted for her next government today in brilliant sunshine.

CAMDEN, Ala., April 7 (UPI) -- The police used smoke bombs and tear-gas bombs today to disperse civil rights demonstrators, some of them out-of-state white clergymen participating in protests here for the first time.

BALTIMORE, April 7 (UPI) -- Bailey Howell, a doubtful starter until game time, came up with a 29-point effort tonight to enable the Baltimore Bullets to beat the Los Angeles Lakers, 122-115, and stay alive in the finals of the National Basketball Association's Western Division playoffs.

YONKERS, April 7 -- Cardigan Bay, last season's $100,000 purchase, is poised to make his first start of 1965 tomorrow night at Yonkers Raceway. The 9-year-old pacing gelding from New Zealand, now owned by an American syndicate, is listed as the 2-to-1 favorite to win the $25,000 Preview Pace.
The campus revolt at Brooklyn College spread to the faculty yesterday.
Copper futures rebounded on the New York Commodity Exchange yesterday with three deliveries closing at new contract highs.
PARIS, April 7 -- A half-century tradition of equal military service for everyone was dropped today by the French Government.

Most bond dealers sat back yesterday and viewed Tuesday's British budget message with a critical eye. They were generally encouraged by what they saw, but much to their disappointment, the budget generated little new business.
WASHINGTON, April 7 -- The House began debate on medical care for the aged today with the expectation of favorable action tomorrow by a one-sided vote.
LAKELAND, Fla., April 7 -- Ron Hunt, the only All-Star game starter to represent the New York Mets, was sent to New York today for a medical examination. He has a persistently painful finger.
Restrictions on women visitors in the dormitories is the major reason a large majority of Columbia College seniors live off campus, a recent survey has indicated.

MONTEGO BAY, Jamaica, April 7 -- The 72-foot ketch Ticonderoga sped through the Windward Passage between Cuba and Haiti today and started a downward run toward the finish line in the Miami-Montego Bay yacht race.

HAVANA, April 7 -- The Cuban Communist revolution must create the austere "Man of the 21st Century" and shun the pitfalls of material well-being, Maj. Ernesto Che Guevara, Minister of Industry, said in an article published here today.

PLUMAGE shook, trembled and flew on some of New York's most polished women at a supper party held Tuesday night at the Waldorf-Astoria. Maggie and Clyde Newhouse had invited their guests to wear feathers to preview the new discotheque, Le Gigue, in Peacock Alley.
ALBANY, April 7 -- The minority Republicans, maneuvering to water down Governor Rockefeller's sales-tax proposal, scuttled Democratic hopes of passing a state budget in the Senate today.
ANTIGO, Wis., April 7 (UPI) -- Residents of this community where tooth decay increased greatly after discontinuance of fluoridation want the chemical returned to their drinking water.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 7 -- Rangy sweepswingers of 6-feet-3-inches to 6-feet-7-inches are battling for positions on the dear old Rutgers crew as never before in the six-year coaching regime of Bill Leavitt.
PARIS, April 7 -- France today withdrew a proposal that had threatened to break up the seven-nation organization formed three years ago to build a European space rocket.

LONDON, April 7 -- A strong pound and a weak stock market were the initial financial reactions today to the increased taxes announced in yesterday's tough, deflationary budget. But stocks, after the heaviest selling since last December, rallied briskly to erase nearly all their losses by the end of official trading.

FLEMINGTON, N.J., April 7 -- The American Tobacco Company is undecided on whether to raise the wholesale price of its filter cigarettes.
