On the theory, perhaps, that one battle at a time is enough -- and passing the Rockefeller tax package at Albany is a king-size battle -- the Republicans have made no progress on the second front of trying to find a strong man to run for Mayor against Wagner.

LONDON, April 7 -- The Labor Government introduced legislation today to outlaw racial discrimination at all "places of public resort" in Britain.
The proprietor of a grocery store in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn shot and killed a 25-year-old man last night. He told the police the man had been holding up the store.

High among the proposals made by President Johnson last night for developing Southeast Asia is a project already begun by the United Nations -- harnessing the Mekong River.
LONDON, April 8 -- A nationwide outbreak of influenza among British race horses characterized by violent bouts of coughing has been traced to a virus that originated in Miami, experts said today.

THE struggle and sacrifice of the Jewish people to win a homeland was recounted last night in a documentary of remorseless realism, an hour film that scared the viewer's consciousness with the tireless nobility and animal barbarity of the human race.

Ford C. Frick, the commissioner of baseball, will be asked today to arbitrate a dispute between the Department of Parks and the New York Mets about the use of Shea Stadium for an exhibition football game next summer.
Meter maids will begin distributing leaflets to motorists next Monday to explain that the maids will begin enforcing more parking regulations starting April 19.
BRUSSELS, April 8 -- A treaty to consolidate Western Europe's economic community was signed today by ministers of the six member nations.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 8 -- Gary Player, shooting with brilliant precision, carded a seven-under-par 65 today and took the lead the first round of the Masters golf tournament. Before a sellout crowd, the 29-year-old South African, the only foreigner ever to win here, gained a two-stroke advantage over the best of his 90 rivals.

HOUSTON, April 8 -- With uncharacteristic modesty, Texans list the Wonders of the World in this fashion: the Pyramids of Egypt, the Hanging Gardens of Babylon, Phidias's Statue of Zeus, the Temple of Artemis, the Tomb of Mausolus, the Colossus of Rhodes, the Pharos at Alexandria and the Astrodome.

PALM BEACH, Fla. -- Palm Beach society, which sometimes appears to consist of everything that's not nailed down, has its quieter people. APPOMATTOX, Va., April 8 -- Most mornings this time of year, a heavy mist blankets the area around Appomattox, lending it a dreamlike quality that disappears only when the sun breaks through around noon.

YONKERS, April 8 -- Meadow Skipper completed a sensational 1:59 2/5 mile clocking on Yonkers' half-mile track tonight and easily captured the $25,000 Preview Pace.

There were two soloists and three concertos for last night's New York Philharmonic concert. ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., April 8 -- Residents of this community have started a campaign for free speech following the arrest of two residents who tried to question Mayor Harry Lister and four Village Board members at a town meeting.
LONDON, April 8 (UPI) -- A "Cheap Holidays in America" venture was started here today.

HAVANA, April 8 -- Premier Fidel Castro announced today that by Tuesday more than four million tons of sugar of the current harvest had been produced and urged the nation to make an all-out effort to reach 5.1 million tons by May 1.

TOKYO, Friday, April 9 -- The Peking radio said today President Johnson's offer of peace negotiations on Vietnam was a trick. It said his speech Wednesday was "full of lies and deceptions." The first reaction by Peking to the proposals came in a broadcast by the official Peking radio. The official press agency Hsinhua later distributed the dispatch.
BERLIN, April 8 -- The Soviet Union resumed its off-and-on blockade of allied vehicles today, skillfully evading United States attempts to assert the right of unrestricted access to Berlin.
NEWARK, April 8 -- Eight major oil companies were indicted today by a Federal grand jury here on charges of conspiring to fix retail gasoline prices in New Jersey, Pennsylvania and Delaware.

The applause of the free world and -- surely -- of a great majority of Americans reflects the fact that in his Johns Hopkins speech on Vietnam, President Johnson has enunciated a new policy and therefore opened a new and hopeful phase of the conflict.
Robert W. Hess, pianist, was awarded $215 yesterday in a breach-of-contract suit against Teresa Stitch-Randall, soprano. The case was tried before Judge William Shea.
Mounted and foot patrolmen prevented a clash yesterday between a group of Bloomingdale's striking pickets and a trucker making a delivery to the department store at 60th Street and Lexington Avenue.
BANGKOK, Thailand, April 8 (AP) -- The United States Air Force has moved 18 of its most advanced interceptor jets, the F-4C Phantom II's, into eastern Thailand, reliable sources said today.

WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture charged today one of the largest meat packing companies in the country with engaging in unfair trade practices by offering gifts, including cameras, mink stoles and automobiles, to retail-store employes for extra efforts in selling its meat products.

A century ago today, which happened to be Palm Sunday, two soldiers met in a plantation house near Appomattox Court House, Va. They chatted for a few minutes about the Mexican War, when both were officers in the United States Army. Grant, the younger, nearing 48, instinctively deferred to General Lee, who was a dignified 58.
LONDON, April 8 -- The Government acted on the long-term economic front today as the pound and the stock market continued their post-budget recoveries.
The Department of Real Estate defended yesterday its raising of rents in four buildings it operates under the Receivership Law.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, said today that James B. Carey had refused his request to resign from the federation's executive council.
WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP) -- Negotiations continued today with no sign of a break reported in the week-old strike of pilots against Pan American Airways.
SAIGON, Friday, April 9 -- The lawyer for Nguyen Van Hai, sentenced to death today for his part in the United States Embassy bombing, said that he was seeking to appeal at once

A professor who had an active part in planning the "Hot Line" communication system between the White House and the Kremlin has been appointed Buell G. Gallagher Visiting Professor of psychology at Stanford University and former head of the Group Networks Laboratory at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, will help start the City University's graduate program in social psychology, which will be conducted at City and Brooklyn Colleges.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, April 9 -- A Vietnamese military tribunal sentenced to death today a Vietcong terrorist involved in the United States Embassy bombing March 30.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- Total business inventories increased by only $300 million in February, compared with an average of nearly three times that much in each of the preceding three months, the Commerce Department reported today.
The city's plan to seek a 20 per cent increase in real estate taxes, with interim authority for short-term borrowing up to $250 million a year, was branded "financial blackmail" yesterday.
LONDON, April 8 -- The British Government today warmly welcomed President Johnson's speech on Vietnam.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -Republicans are raising money, recruiting members, and researching ideas with missionary fevor, but much of it is beyond control of the party's new national chairman, Ray C. Bliss.
The American Federation of Teachers has asked its arch rival, the National Education Association, to join forces with it to establish national ground rules for collective bargaining elections.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 8 -- High-ranking Vietnamese officials said today that the Saigon Government had received President Johnson's policy speech on Vietnam with apprehension.

THE last but one of Carnegie Hall's International Festival of Visiting Orchestras series took place last night with the appearance of the Hague Philharmonic. This orchestra, under Willem van Otterloo, toured this country in 1963, leaving excellent memories.
One of the nation's major underwriters and distributors of securities, Blyth Co., Inc., became a member corporation of the New York Stock Exchange, yesterday, but it did so without fanfare.
CARACAS, Venezuela, April 8 -- Former President Marcos Perez Jimenez, charged with embezzling millions in public funds, went on trial here today.
EAST LANSING, Mich., April 8 (UPI) -- Bomb threats and pickets disrupted an all-night "teach-in" tonight at Michigan State University.
TRENTON, April 8 -- Democratic and Republican legislative leaders reached agreement late this afternoon on a solution to New Jersey's year-old reapportionment problem.
Prices for Maine potato futures prices moved upward in active trading yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 8 -- Bobby Jones was seated in the bedroom of his cottage near the 10th tee of the Augusta National Golf Club this morning when he was suddenly confronted by a stranger.
PARIS, April 8 -- The Government of France began to loosen its 18-month-old restraints on credit today. It cut the bank rate to 3 1/2 per cent from 4 per cent.
One thousand Brooklynites demonstrated their support of civil rights at a Borough Hall rally late yesterday afternoon entitled "Brooklyn's Stand With Selma, U.S.A."

The top leadership of management and labor in the long-shore industry vowed yesterday to oppose vigorously efforts by the Waterfront Commission to force the industry to accept new men without medical clearance.

MOSCOW, April 8 -- President Mohammad Ayub Khan of Pakistan toasted the "growing friendship and understanding" between his country and the Soviet Union today at a Kremlin reception given by President Anastas I. Mikoyan.
The majority of issues showing changes on the American Stock Exchange made advances yesterday as volume rose to its highest level in almost a month.

The Board of Education said yesterday that the strike by school bus drivers and mechanics had had "a serious adverse effect" on the city's school children. It appealed to the bus employes, "in behalf of the children," to end their two-day strike and "return to work as soon as possible."

WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP) -- Senator Spessard L. Holland accused the Johnson Administration today of "sweeping under the rug" a part of the losses incurred in carrying out farm-price and subsidy programs.

MONTREAL, April 8 -- The St. Lawrence Seaway opened its seventh season here today at 8:30 A.M. But first-day traffic was delayed by heavy masses of ice in the Lake St. Francis section of the waterway.
The Urban Renewal Administration announced yesterday it sold $159,748,000 of preliminary loan notes for local agencies at an average annual interest rate of 2.3526 per cent.

Three towns joined the Scenic Hudson Conservation Conference yesterday in a new attack on the Federal Power Commission's order granting Consolidated Edison a license to cut into Storm King Mountain for its new power project.
Mayor Wagner made an unannounced midnight-to-2 A.M. tour of the subways yesterday morning to observe the mass deployment of policemen in his new campaign against subway crime.

More than 600 guests dined and danced last night at the Ba Rouge et Noir to benefit Irvington House, a center for the care of children with heart disease. The third annual event was held in the Trianon and Mercury Suites at the New York York Hilton.
FULL-LENGTH dressing mirrors are among the innovations that herald the arrival of the first women guests at the 35-year-old William Sloane House of the Young Men's Christian Association.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- Adlai E. Stevenson, chief delegate to the United Nations, reported on the letter from U Thant to President Johnson at a Cabinet meeting today. Afterward the text was made available. It follows:
The General Electric Company reported yesterday record sales and earnings for the first quarter.

TEHERAN, Iran, April 8 -- Secretary of State Dean Rusk today sought understanding and support for the United States' position on Vietnam from members of the Central Treaty Organization. Although American officials said the response was "positive," other diplomats reported indifferences to the President's appeal.
WASHINGTON, April 8 -- Laurance S. Rockefeller of New York has given $100,000 to help beautify the nation's Capital, the White House announced today.
John H. Ewing, chairman of Abercrombie Fitch Company, has sold a "substantial" block of his stock in the store chain which has its main branch in Manhattan.
Some of Stanley Steingut's chief supporters said yesterday that they might attempt to depose him as county leader unless he stopped what they described as brooding and regained his political vigor.
The British pound advanced for the second day on foreign exchange markets here. The chief impetus continued to be the new British budget.
The New York World's Fair opens its 1965 season on April 21 and it won't come a day too soon for the market-letter writers of Wall Street.

CHICAGO, April 8 -- Hazeltine Corporation and its wholly owned subsidiary, Hazeltine Research, Inc., filed today separate mandamus actions in the United States Circuit Court of Appeals in opposition to a $19 million antitrust damage award made to Zenith Radio Corporation.

WASHINGTON, April 8 The Senate Foreign Relations Committee responded to a strong Administration appeal and voted today to restore a $115 million cut in military assistance funds in the $3.4 billion foreign aid authorization bill.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 8 -- Fred McLeod and Jock Hutchison played a fast 18 holes and a slow 19th today in the Masters golf tournament. They had planned it that way.
A blue-ribbon jury of one woman and 11 men was picked yesterday in the State Supreme Court in Brooklyn, to try George Whitmore Jr., for the murder of Mrs. Minnie Edmonds last April 14.

CHICAGO, April 8 (UPI) -- Bobby Hull scored on a 60-foot slap shot with 11 minutes to play tonight, giving the Chicago Black Hawks a 2-1 victory over the Detroit Red Wings and tying their Stanley Cup semi-final series at two games each.

MIDDLETOWN, Ohio -- This town on the east bank of the meandering Great Miami River has some 45,000 inhabitants, or just a few thousand more than work for the Armco Steel Corporation, which also is at home here.
SYDNEY, Australia, April 8 -- The Australian Government went along today with President Johnson's readiness to engage in discussions with North Vietnam.
BUFFALO, April 8 -- Poetry and politics have clashed here in a controversy that has deeply stirred the students and faculty of one of the largest universities in western New York.
WASHINGTON, April 8 -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported the following spot primary market prices for the dates shown:
BOSTON, April 8 (UPI) -- The Boston Celtics stopped Wilt Chamberlain for nearly 24 minutes tonight and beat the Philadelphia 76ers, 112-94, for a 2-1 lead in the Eastern playoff finals.

ONE OF the reasons why many novels are dismal failures is that their authors concentrate on two things: putting across a message and expressing their own personal emotions. These elements can be part of good fiction; by themselves they cannot substitute for good fiction, which is essentially a story about believable people made interesting by good character ization.

HAVANA, April 8 (AP) -- Premier Fidel Castro's police, swooped down at dawn today to arrest 40 Baptist preachers and 13 laymen, including two American citizens on charges of spying for the United States.

WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP) -- Two leaders of Women Strike for Peace and a New York man were convicted of contempt of Congress today for refusing to testify at a closed session of a subcommittee of the House Committee on Un-American Activities.
Wall Street, which savors such things, had another juicy bit of corporate news to chew over yesterday.
The House passage of the medicare bill represents a historic triumph in a long struggle.
Robert B. Blaikie, the West Side independent Democrat, announced yesterday that he would seek the Democratic nomination for Manhattan Borough President, and, if elected would abolish the job.

President Harry D. Gideonse of Brooklyn College, in a letter to the Kingsman, student weekly, renewed his charge yesterday that recent demonstrations on campus had been instigated by a small nucleus of Communist-oriented students and outsiders that they have brought in.
WASHINGTON, April 9 -- The Administration agreed today to support, with minor modifications, a bipartisan antismog bill proposed by Senator Edmund S. Muskie.
Stanley Steingut's supporters on the Kings County Democratic Committee pledged loyalty to the county leader yesterday after a luncheon conference in a private dining room at Luchow's restaurant.

Bill Mahorney strengthened his lead among the jockeys at Aqueduct yesterday by riding two winners, while his nearest rival, Larry Adams, was unable to score. In adding to his advantage Mahorney had the big working edge over Adams, since he had seven mounts as against two for the runner-up.
The London stock market continued firm yesterday as limited selling and selective buying pushed prices forward in light trading.
With respect to aiding countries with surplus agricultural supplies, there are three problems our Government should consider more seriously than it does now.

PARIS, April 9 -- The final installment of Coco Chanel's spring-summer 1965 collection -- the bulk of it was shown in February -- trickled out today and proved that no calendar will cause Chanel to panic.
WASHINGTON, April 9 -- The school bill passed by the Senate and sent to the White House calls for $1,307,582,973 in Federal allocations in the year starting July 1.
MOSCOW, April 9 (UPI) -- Poland and the Soviet Union accused the United States tonight of endangering world peace with "armed aggression" against North Vietnam.
PHILADELPHIA, April 9 (AP) -- Hal Greer's 35-foot shot as the buzzer sounded tied the game and the Philadelphia 76ers defeated the Boston Celtics in overtime tonight, 134-131.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 9 -- A courageous but baffled Ken Venturi was forced to the sidelines again today. The United States open champion unwillingly became a non-qualifier for the last two rounds of the Masters.
A New York minister has accepted a dual assignment in Berlin as a representative of the Lutheran World Federation and as an English-speaking pastor.

A grand jury is investigating an assertion by a convicted perjurer that an alleged $100,000 payment to Assemblyman Hyman E. Mintz to bribe one or more state officials was returned to two sports promoters because "Governor Rockefeller got wind of it."
SIR WINSTON CHURCHILL once said that if Admiral Darlan were ever called upon to shoot Marshal Petain, he would happily do so -- in the name of Petain, at Vichy.
Puerto Rican civil rights leaders have canceled all meetings that were scheduled with the Police Department to discuss ways to improve relations.
The Board of Education expressed hope yesterday that striking school-bus drivers and mechanics would return to work on Monday.

SAIGON, April 9 -- the decision to land 3,000 additional marines in Central Vietnam arises from United States concern over the protection of the air base at Danang and of the large communications center outside Hue.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 9 -- The man upon whom U Thant will lean heavily for advice on the economic aspects of President Johnson's proposals for Southeast Asia is Chakravarthi Vigayaraghava Narasimhan, the Secretary General's chef de cabinet, or staff chief.
LONDON, April 9 -- Delegates from 67 maritime countries signed a charter today to reduce the formalities involved in arrivals and departures of commercial shipping.

CHICAGO, April 9 -- Dr. John K. Lattimer said today that there was a "striking parallel" between one aspect of the stabbing of Secretary of State William H. Seward on the night President Lincoln was shot and Mrs. John F. Kennedy's "acute amnesia" immediately after President Kennedy was shot.
WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP) -- An atomic snooper that looks like a coffee urn and whistles at gold has been developed for use of the Customs Service, the Atomic Energy Commission reported today.
Communist China has accused the United States of hundreds of air and sea intrusions, including reconnaissance flights to photograph military and industrial installations.
WASHINGTON, April 9 -- Retail sales in March, seasonally adjusted, dropped 1 per cent below the record February level, the Commerce Department reported today.

Senator Seymour R. Thaler called on the State Insurance Department yesterday to defer action on the Blue Cross request for rate increases until pending Federal and state health-cost legislation had been resolved.

DUBLIN, April 9 (AP) -- Ireland's general elections were thrown into a turmoil tonight when a dispute broke out over the validity of ballots that had been cast by patients in mental hospitals.
MONTEGO BAY, Jamaica, April 9 -- The world's most traveled ocean racing yacht, S.A. (Huey) Long's Ondine, became second to finish in the Miami-Montego Bay race early today.
George A. Culp, operating head of the C.I.T. Service Leasing Corporation since its formation in 1958, was formally installed yesterday as the concern's first president.

A history of Jewish resistance in the Warsaw Ghetto, "To Die with Honor," by Leonard Tushnet, will be published this month by The Citadel Press. The story, said to be based on research in Warsaw, is one of disunity on the subject of resistance to the Nazis in the first months after the fall of Poland in 1939 and eventually of agreement on formation of the Jewish Fighting Organization that battled the Nazis in 1943.
New York newspaper publishers and the pressmen's union reached agreement yesterday afternoon on terms for a two-year contact.

HAVANA, April 9 -- Emil Anton Stadelhofer, the Swiss Ambassador, called today on the Cuban Foreign Ministry to seek information concerning two United States Baptist preachers arrested with at least 51 other persons on espionage charges earlier this week.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- Although the income of the college professor appears to be lifting him from his "traditional level of genteel poverty," he is still losing ground in relation to other professionals, according to a report made public here today.
Senator Robert F. Kennedy was given a hard ribbing by the Explorers Club last night, but he was not there to hear it.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 9 -- Ben Hogan hit his approach shot to the 18th green at the Augusta National Golf Club today and started the long walk uphill.

CAIRO, April 9 -- First indications have appeared in the press that the Government plans to slow its ambitious economic development program and is reconciled to falling short of its goal of doubling the national income in a decade.

LONDON, April 8 -- For five years the Harlequin Ballet has been hovering around the British provinces. Tonight, for the first time, it penetrated into London, starting a season at the New Lyric Theater in Hammersmith.

NEW DELHI, April 9 (AP) -- Indian officials said at least 27 Pakistanis were killed or wounded and four captured in fighting that broke out in a disputed border area today. India's losses were put at two killed and three wounded.

LAWRENCE, Kan., April 9 -- A conference on Eastern European affairs was told today that there is a consensus in the Soviet Union that research scientists must be permitted to pursue their work free of the paralyzing effect of ideological interference.

WHEN it comes to presenting Custer's Last Stand on television the electronic journalists would be wise to defer to the Hollywood impresarios. John H. Secondari, of the special projects division of the American Broadcasting Company's news department, tried last night to simulate the Battle of the Little Big Horn; it was a sorry engagement for soldier, Indian and viewer.
The Harlem Hospital Auxiliary has arranged an evening at Yonkers Raceway for April 21. The admission price of $12.50 will include a roast chicken dinner.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- The National Council on the Arts which took 87 years to make its debut, held its first meeting at the White House today after being sworn in during a 15-minute standing room only ceremony attended by President Johnson.
WASHINGTON, April 9 The Early Bird communications satellite was moved into a final orbit today that stationed it over the Atlantic.
ALBANY, April 9 -- State Democratic leaders are trying to patch the torn fabric of their political organization by choosing a new party leader.

WESTPORT, Conn., April 9 -- The state police went on the alert today against chiselers who have been outsmarting automatic change hoppers at toll booths on the Connecticut Turnpike and the Merritt Parkway.

The bearded 37-year-old man with the large brown eyes, thick beard and receding hairline, one of America's outstanding playwrights, spoke earnestly yesterday about the state of the European theater. "You get the feeling," he said, "that you're running into American plays in every capital."

JERSEY CITY, April 9 -- The B Jersey City Y.W.C.A. relay team of Eileen Reilly, Carolyn Buell, Francis Ryan and Carol Cole captured the Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union junior women's 440-yard free-style swimming championship tonight.

NAIROBI, Kenya, April 9 -- The Government of Kenya issued today one of its clearest statements on its intention to adhere to moderate and prudent policies and nonalignment with the Communist world. In doing so it publicly rebuked a junior minister for suggesting otherwise.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., April 91 -- The State Liquor Authority was free today to resume is-sing new package store licenses.
DANANG, South Vietnam, Saturday, April 10 -- A 1,400 man battalion of United States Marines began landing on a beach two miles north of Danang this morning.

HACKENSACK, N.J., April 9 -- The Packanack Lake Country Club and Community Association advised a court here today that it was willing to accept the resignations of two families that had brought suit against it, charging discriminatory practices.
The American Express Company has upgraded the cash side of its settlement offer to creditors of the American Express Warehousing Company, Ltd., to $60 million, from $45 million.

ALBANY, April 9 -- Governor Rockefeller held conferences with legislative leaders of both parties today to try to win support for the budget bills that were supposed to have been passed by April 1 with the expiration of the fiscal year.

Former President Harry S. Truman says that despite some rumors of trouble in the Far East, the outbreak of the Korean war came as a "complete surprise to everyone."

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- Two Virginia civil engineers have invented survival kit designed to lift a crash victim into the air with a cluster of balloons.
" YOU will excuse me," said Anouk Aimee, the French film star with the delicately boned, faintly brooding face, as she brushed away a tear yesterday at noon in her suite at the Savoy Plaza.

TORONTO, April 9 -- The Canadian dollar, after tumbling 88 points between January and March, is making a modest recovery. The new-found strength reflects to some extent a resumed, although limited, inflow of United States dollars.
BOGALUSA, La., April 9 -- A traffic accident during a Negro protest march touched off a flurry of violence that threatened to turn into a riot in downtown Bogalusa today.
ATLANTA, April 9 -- "This is the happiest occasion for Atlanta since General Sherman decided to head South for Savannah in 1864," Mayor Ivan Allen Jr. told the Milwaukee Braves today.
PEKING, April 9 -- Communist China said tonight that Chinese planes clashed today with eight American aircraft over Hainan, a Chinese island in the South China Sea.

A RADICALLY new breed of interior designers may be about to emerge on the professional scene, if the senior students' exhibition at the Parsons School of Design, which opened yesterday, is any indication.
Prices for copper futures rebounded yesterday, advancing 0.35 to 1.35 cents a pound in active trading on the New York Commodity Exchange. Both the May and July deliveries reached new contract highs.
Raw steel production in the United States set records in March and the first quarter of this year, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

BALBOA, Canal Zone, April 9 -- Major unforeseen or uncontrollable costs expected to total more than $2,000,000 have cropped up for the Panama Canal this spring, reducing the funds available for capital improvement.
The Hotel Trades Council has unveiled a do-it-yourself legal-aid clinic that has operated circumspectly for three years because of bar association opposition.
HOLLYWOOD, April 9 -- The "Harlow Sweepstakes" rolled into a critical phase this week, and even the most jaded Hollywood observers conceded they had never seen anything quite like it.

The world's largest star sapphire, the Star of India, will go on special exhibition today on the main floor of the American Museum of Natural History. It will be protected by an exhibition case that is actually a two-ton safe incorporating the latest mechanical and electronic safety devices.
Women clerical employes of the Diners Club picketed the Army recruiting headquarters here yesterday protesting that soldiers were taking their jobs while they were on strike.

The long litigation by ten Eastern railroads to declare New York State's full-crew laws invalid has failed. Unless a decision in the Supreme Court in White Plains is upset on appeal, the remedy must be found in the New York Legislature, where it more logically belonged all the time.

APPOMATTOX, Va., April 9 -- The surrender of Robert E. Lee, General of the Armies of the Confederate States, to Lieut Gen. Ulysses S. Grant 100 years ago was commemorated at simple ceremonies here today.
SIOUX CITY, Iowa, April 9 (UPI) -- Seven persons were arrested today when pickets threw stones and shouted jeers and obscenities at new workers entering the strikebound Raskin Packing Company here.
LAUREL, Md., April 9 (AP) -- Half a dozen 3-year-old colts headed by Tom Rolfe and Bosun, all candidates for the Kentucky Derby, are slated to start in the $30,000 added Chesapeake Stakes tomorrow.

HONG KONG, April 9 (AP) -- A United States researcher said today that Communist China was a month behind schedule in carrying out its second nuclear test. He suggested that there might be political or technical reasons for the delay.
DUBLIN, April 9 -- Prime Minister Sean Lemass's Fianna Fail party appeared tonight to have won a majority, which was its purpose in calling elections for a new Dail Eireann (Parliament).

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- In the midst of debate on the school aid bill today, Senator Sam J. Ervin, Democrat of North Carolina, made a determined effort to amend the bill to permit taxpayers to test the bill's constitutionality in the Federal courts.
LONDON April 9 -- The Tatler, which over the last 64 years which has carved a niche as the magazine in Britain with the broadest "A," is expected to produce its last issue in September.
The recovery movement in the stock market continued yesterday for the second consecutive day in the heaviest trading in more than a month.
The Pieta, Michelangelo's masterpiece in marble, was taken from its winter cocoon yesterday as the Vatican Pavilion at the World's Fair reached the final stages of preparation for its second season.

WASHINGTON, April 9 (UPI) -- Company and union negotiators returned to the bargaining table today in an effort to break the continuing deadlock in the strike of Pan American World Airways pilots.

In a letter published April 3 Jeremy Bernstein questioned Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s advocacy of civil disobedience as a method of securing political change. Mr. Bernstein argued that unjust laws should be altered within the legal framework of American society.

Despite rising Soviet-American tension on several fronts, President Johnson acted adroitly in announcing appointment of a special committee to study the possible expansion of trade with the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe. The Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor accused the New York Shipping Association and the International Longshoremen's Association yesterday of "misrepresenting facts" in voicing their objections to a court order obtained by the bistate agency.

FULLERTON, Calif., April 9 (AP) -- Norton Simon, California industrialist, said today he would contribute up to 100,000 ($280,000) toward a fund to keep in England Rembrandt's "Titus" which Mr. Simon recently purchased.

CHICAGO, April 9 -- Federal Judge Julius J. Hoffman granted attorneys for the New York Stock Exchange an extension of time today until June 1 to answer a lawsuit charging it and four brokerage concerns with violating antitrust laws.

" Abortion and the Law," called by one critic a "singularly forthright documentary," will be repeated from 10 to 11 P.M. on May 17 by the Columbia Broadcasting System television network.
PITTSBURGH, April 9 (AP) -- David J. McDonald was asked today to step aside as chief bargainer for the United Steelworkers of America in contract talks with the basic steel industry. He refused.
The Burroughs Corporation lent $745,075 to 14 of its top officers to enable them to buy shares held in the company's treasury, according to the office-equipment producer's proxy statement.
VANCOUVER, B.C., April 9 -- The International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union has imposed a boycott on the handling of Alabama-made products by its 65,000 members.

The police made a dozen arrests and seized a crate with 30 pigeons during the second night's operation of the city's new campaign against crime underground.
ALBANY, April 9 -- The constitutionality of a law that may reduce the retail price of liquor was sustained today by a State Supreme Court justice.
PHILADELPHIA, April 9 -- A note of progress in the fight against acute leukemia in children was reported here today to the American Association for Cancer Research.

DOMINATING this week's art activities is the mammoth exhibition, "Three Centuries of American Painting," on view at the Metropolitan Museum of Art through Oct. 17. With the exception of a few loans, everything there, in a survey that ranges from the 17th century to the present, belongs to the museum's own vast holdings, much of which, like the submerged part of an iceberg, never sees the light of day.
Why all the furor over the Negroes voting? Did anyone stage marches and aid us during all the years that the citizens of Washington could not vote?
MANKATO, Minn., April 9 (AP) -- Weary flood workers began a tense watch tonight expecting a crest of the Minnesota River, which has forced 8,000 persons out of their homes.

SOME of the most interesting deals for the bridge analyst are those offering opportunities for both sides. The deal shown today, played in a team match many years ago, was a cut-and-thrust affair. East encouraged his partner to find a good line of defense, but South saw through the plot and evolved an effective counter.

Charles Huntley, the man for whom the new procedure for testing the voluntariness of confessions in New York courts has been named, has learned learned that his own confession has been upheld in State Supreme Court.

The status of foreign investments in United States-flag merchant shipping remains under a cloud as the result of a Federal court ruling earlier this week on litigation involving the holders of foreign bonds in an American bulk carrier.
TWO posh flower establishments, ensconced this month at new addresses, are diverting strollers from their gallery browsing along upper Madison Avenue.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- The White House is approaching prominent figures in industry, education and patent law to complete the membership of the President's Commission on the Patent System, which has just been established.
A year has passed since three airliners skidded off slippery runways at New York airports in one 12-hour period, endangering the lives of 228 passengers and crew.
BALTIMORE, April 9 -- Fifteen sleepy-eyed demonstrators remained inside School Board headquarters here today after an all-night sit-in protesting facilities at a Negro high school.
COLLEGE STATION, Tex., April 9 (UPI) -- Randy Matson broke the world outdoor shot-put record tonight with a 67-foot-11 1/4-inch put on his sixth effort.
WASHINGTON, April 9 -- The Defense Department said today it was not known whether the MIG fighters that took part in the encounter in the South China Sea were North Vietnamese or Communist Chinese.

BUENOS AIRES, April 9 (AP) -- Argentina sold one million tons of wheat to Red China, sharply increasing this country's trickling trade with the Communist countries in an effort to get rid of millions of tons of surplus wheat.

WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP) -- Representative Oren Harris said today that if the results of smoking cigarettes were as bad as pictured he wondered why the Surgeon General did not recommend a complete prohibition.
WASHINGTON, April 9 -- Manufacturing employment rose in March to 17,814,000, its highest point in 21 years, the Labor Department said today.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- The index of wholesale primary market prices advanced two-tenths of 1 per cent to 101.5 of its 1957-59 during the week ended April 6, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. Farm products and processed foods increased in price, while industrial commodities averaged unchanged.
The Chesapeake Ohio Railway's offer of $42.50 a share for the common stock of the Chicago, South Shore South Bend Railroad has been stopped, temporarily, by the Interstate Commerce Commission.
The coin-collecting business, an industry traditionally made up of many small shopkeepers and a few large mail-order houses, is experiencing the winds of change.

Senate Majority Leader Zaretzki has finally found a law he is sure the State Legislature will pass this year. It is the Democratic program for revising the Condon-Wadlin Act, which since 1947 has prescribed penalties for strikes by state or municipal employes.
The third in the series of illuminating folk concerts sponsored by the Newport Folk Foundation and by the Friends of Old Time Music was held last night at the New School for Social Research.
WASHINGTON, April 9 -- Secretary of Labor W. Willard Wirtz today extended for varying periods up to June 30 authorization for a maximum of 6,500 West Indians to remain in Florida for farm work.
THE vogue for attending internationally oriented cooking schools continues unabated.
The Government and corporate bond markets moved in opposite directions yesterday, although there was not enough business in either market to establish a trend.

CORNWALL-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., April 9 -- Village officials and war veterans today denounced the flying of the United States flag from a stripped tree atop Storm King Mountain to protest the Consolidated Edison Company's $162 million hydroelectric project there.
A top United Nations official and amateur thespian blended the Marx brothers with vintage Milton Berle Thursday night and last night as the lead in a Turkish-language farce at Judson Hall.

Members of the New York Stock Exchange will find in their Monday morning mail a chatty newsletter from president Keith Funston that touches on such topics as public ownership of brokerage houses and a visit with "Commissioner Manny Cohen at his home."

CAIRO, April 9 -- A special West German envoy said today that Bonn had promised the Government of the United Arab Republic that its recognition of Israel would not include any guarantee of her borders.
I was shocked by your editorial of March 23 advocating a referendum on the question of legalizing off-track betting in New York City.
FORT ST. JOHN, B.C. -- Down in Vancouver, the forsythia has been blooming for weeks. But here in the bleak Peace River country of northeastern British Columbia, one finds other signs of spring.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- The Chinese Communist assertion that a United States jet had downed another American plane in the South China Sea today raised the question whether safety devices can prevent such mishaps.

CLUJ, Rumania, April 1 -- When James E. Augerot walks down the Main Street of this pretty city with the long stride of a Westerner, he invariably draws a dozen friendly greetings from residents, whether they are of Rumanian, Hungarian or German origan.
VIENNA, April 9 -- The Hungarian Foreign Minister, Janos Peter, said at a news conference here today that "the Mindszenty question" was not at present a concern of his Government.
RIO DE JANEIRO, April 9 -- Brazil's business leaders asked today for a "reformulation" of the Government's anti-inflation program to avert a depression.

GLENVIEW, Ill., April 9 (AP) -- Linda Darnell, the actress, was burned in an early morning fire today that damaged the home of friends where she was staying. She was reported "still in critical condition" after undergoing four hours of surgery.

Robert L. Milligan, President of the Pure Oil Company, is expected to try to placate a powerful group of Texas stockholders at the company's annual meeting today in Columbus, Ohio, with a detailed explanation of why management has tentatively accepted the merger proposal of the Union Oil Company of California.
The New York Jets of the American Football League have decided to do battle with the New York Giants -- at the gate, if not on the field.
PANAMA CITY, April 9 (AP) -- Carlos Ortiz will make his fifth defense of the world lightweight title tomorrow night as a surprisingly narrow favorite over his low-ranking opponent.
Ford C. Frick, the commissioners of baseball, upheld the New York Mets yesterday in their refusal to permit the use of Shea Stadium for a proposed exhibition football game this summer.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 9 -- Adlai E. Stevenson conferred for an hour today with the Secretary General, U Thant, on President Johnson's ideas for United States and United Nations cooperation in working for peace and economic development in Southeast Asia.
ELISABETH SCHWARZKOPF'S Carnegie Hall recital last night was afflicted by distractions that would have spoiled the work of a lesser singer, but they only seemed to point up her artistry.
WASHINGTON, April 9 -- The Senate passed the Administration's $1.3 billion school aid bill tonight without change and sent it to the White House.

A young sailor in a stolen car was attempting to outrace pursuing police in Brooklyn yesterday afternoon when he went through a stop sign and crashed into another car, killing its driver, the police said.
HONG KONG, April 9 -- President Ho Chi Minh of North Vietnam was reported today to have demanded the withdrawal of United States forces from South Vietnam as a condition for any settlement.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 9 -- United States Navy jets clashed this morning with unidentified Communist MIG fighters over the coastal waters of Hainan, the American mission here announced.
The British pound declined slightly yesterday after advancing for two days after the release of Britain's budget Tuesday.

BERLIN, April 9 -- Soviet and East German control authorities staged another snap shutdown of the Berlin-West Germany autobahn tonight, dashing hopes that this week's Communist squeeze on Western allied communications had ended.

Surrounded by active and retired naval officers, many in uniform and some in their 70's and 80's, Mayor Wagner signed a local law yesterday giving the name Admiral George Dewey Promenade to the broad walk along the seawall at Battery Park.

ALGIERS, April 9 -- President Ahmed Ben Bella closed a major prison here today, freed 1,200 nonpolitical prisoners and announced that fifty-seven other prisons would be converted to new uses "for the building of socialism."
HOUSTON, April 9 -- With President Johnson present, the Astrodome -- the world's largest air-conditioned room -- opened tonight with the first indoor major league baseball game.
VIEQUES, P.R., April 9 -- Two thousand marines and more than 1,700 Army paratroopers landed from sea and sky today on the sandy beaches and mesquite covered hills of this island.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- Beating a midnight deadline by a scant four hours, the Senate Judiciary Committee reported a voting rights bill to the Senate tonight without recommendation. Earlier, a House Judiciary subcommittee approved, 10 to 1, its version of a voting rights measure.
CHARLOTTE, N.C., April 9 -- Carlton Willey of the Mets today pitched an impressive six innings against the Minnesota Twins that were worth an estimated $4,000 to the seasoned right-hander.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 9 -- A high-ranking Government official said today that it had been decided to dismiss Rear Adm. Chung Tan Cang as head of the South Vietnamese Navy.

Federal-Mogul-Bower Bearings, Inc., Detroit-based manufacturer of bearings, seals and allied products, had a net income in 1964 of $16,588,764 compared with $15,713,817 earned the year before, the annual report disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- There is still a chance that an American astronaut may attempt to match the Soviet feat of moving around outside his spacecraft on the next Gemini flight, the Federal space agency said today.

HALLANDALE, Fla., April 9 (AP) -- Oldest Girl scored a nose victory over Back to Back in the eighth race at Gulfstream Park today, but the real excitement of the afternoon was generated in the first race when Du' Speedster got home at 104-1, the second-highest-priced horse to win at Gulfstream.

LAUREL, Md., April 10 -- Powhatan's Tom Rolfe, a "probable'' Kentucky Derby starter going into the race, looked like a definite one today after the 44th running of the $34,025 Chesapeake Stakes.

LONDON -- The British aircraft industry, bloody but unbowed after recent Government decisions to buy cheaper American military planes, is trying to get a bigger piece of the American civil aviation market.

LAWRENCE, Kan., April 10 -- The third Midwest Slavic conference has provided indications that American scholars are making breakthroughs in Soviet and Eastern European studies.

DESIDERIUS ERASMUS of Rotterdam (1466 ? -- 1536) is one of our fellowmen best worth knowing and one of those easiest to know. Thompson of Haverford College.

SAN FRANCISCO -- A 10-mile stretch of wild dunes and Pacific beach was added to the nation's public recreation lands recently with the opening of an access road and parking lot near Point Reyes, Calif. Secretary of the Interior Stewart L. Udall is now expected to sign an order making the Point Reyes National Seashore a legal entity.

Twenty years ago Arthur Clarke, a young Englishman who later achieved fame as a scientist and science-fiction writer, wrote that three communications satellites stationed over the Atlantic, Pacific and Indian Oceans could link all the nations of the world.

WASHINGTON, April 10 (UPI) -- The Democratic National Chairman, John M. Bailey, said today the party would hold a $100-a-plate dinner in Washington on June 3 to start a drive to keep control of Congress in next year's elections.

HIGHLAND MILLS, N.Y. -- On a recent spring day, when the crocuses were buried beneath six inches of fresh snow, a one-mile section of a new route between New York's smoggy skyline and the green and rugged Catskills was relocated along Schunemunk Mountain's boulder-strewn slopes.
HAVANA, April 10 -- Heavy overcoats must be hot sellers in this sultry island if classified advertisements in the press mean anything.

FOR a long time James Baldwin, Public Figure, had consumed most of the energy and time of the private writer within. In recent months, however, the balance has begun to shift back. As a result Baldwin, just returned from Europe for the opening on Thursday of his play, "The Amen Corner," looked unusually rested and relaxed during a recent conversation in his spacious, sparely furnished apartment on West End Avenue in the 80's.
I read Ward Allan Howe's article on the Huntington Library in San Marino, Calif., (March 21) with great interest, since my husband and I had visited it only two weeks before.
After 36 years in the labor movement, James Barron Carey, 53, suddenly found himself last week without a union.

CLINTON, N.J. -- Two years ago, there was a rolling valley of farms and pastures northwest of this country town. Now the valley holds one of the largest fresh-water lakes in New Jersey, and yesterday, after appropriate ceremonies, the new Spruce Run Reservoir and recreation area was opened to public use.

THOUGH the main emphasis in Hollywood is still on the big-budget, big-name spectaculars, some filmmakers and studios seem to be showing a greater willingness to experiment with films that are less expensive but more literate.

A RINGING, athletic tone and well-balanced technique are Erick Friedman's chief assets in the new release of the Bach Sonatas for Violin and Harpsichord, complete, all six of them. Thrown in as a bonus is the Chaconne from the Second Partite for Unaccompanied Violin.

WHY do writers so often insist upon choosing, for themselves, or for characters, names which are already celebrated in the field of murder? An English writer calls himself "Peter Chambers," which is the name of Henry Kane's long-established detective.

AMONG the strollers, carriage-pushers and dogwalkers in Washington Square Park one crisp spring day last week, a photographer could be seen taking rapid-fire shots of a smartly dressed woman in a red coat, her black hair piled high on her head.
WASHINGTON, April 10 (UPI) -- Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara was asked today to investigate the propriety of the Falcon Foundation in raising funds for prospective Air Academy athletes.
In a news story in your issue of March 28 William D. Smith wrote that "at the age of 38 John Diebold . . . is known as the man who coined the word automation."

SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 10 -- When President Johnson offered peace this week to Hanoi, he made a stipulation that predictably would be rejected by the Communists. The President insisted on an independent South Vietnam that would be securely guaranteed.
MIDDLEBURG, Va., April 10 (AP) -- William L. Rochester Jr.'s Sportation moved in front at the next-to-last fence today and raced to an upset victory in the Middleburg Hunt Cup.
The World's Fair Marina, which turned out to be some thing less than a Taj Mahal of boating last year, is making another try.

SAN JUAN, P.R., April 10 -- About 4,000 Marines and Army paratroopers fought a sham war today across the sun-baked brown hills of Vieques, a Puerto Rican island near here that has long been the traditional training ground of the Atlantic fleet.
WEST ORANGE, N.J., April 11 -- Tequita, an 8-year-old bay mare, who has served stints on the race track and breeding farms, won three classes today at the Woodland Riding Club Horse Show.

HALLANDALE, Fla., April 10 (AP) -- John M. Olin's Babington tied the world record and broke the track record for a mile and a sixteenth today when he overtook Cool Prince in the last 100 yards and won the $10,000 Fort Lauderdale Purse by a length on the turf at Gulfstream Park.
UNITED STATES NAVAL BASE, Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, April 5 -- The mangoes are ripening in neat yards, the lemon trees are bearing fruit and the papaya is fresh and juicy in Gitmo.
The world's largest passenger liner, Cunard Line's Queen Elizabeth, now can boast of containing the world's largest floating beer kegs.

Dr. Benjamin M. Spock, the child-care specialist, led 3,000 parents and children in a sprawling procession from Columbus Circle to the United Nations yesterday to demand an immediate cease-fire in Vietnam.

CARACAS, Venezuela, April 10 -- Interior Minister Gonzalo Barrios announced today the arrest of three foreigners accused of having carried $330,000 from Italy to finance Communist terrorism in Venezuela.

THESE two books offer hundreds of alphabetically arranged entries defining Scriptural words, identifying characters, discussing individual Biblical books in a clear, helpful fashion. The Northcott volume, with artfully designed pages and profuse illustrations, many in color, is the more attractive book and its entries are fuller and more readable.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., April 10 -- Victor Romagna, at the helm of Scusi, and Patrick O'Neal, with Humbug, sailed to a joint 1-point lead in the Interclub Class today as Larchmont Yacht Club's annual two-day spring invitation regatta of frostbite dinghies opened.

DANANG, South Vietnam, April 10 -- Gen. Vo Nguyen Giap blasted the name of Dienbienphu into history 11 years ago. It has come to stand for a crushing and unexpected military defeat, a national humiliation that breaks the will and ability of a people to go on fighting.

Friday night will mark the beginning of one of the oldest holidays on earth. It is the Jewish festival of Passover -- its name derives from the miracle in Egypt more than 3,000 years ago when the Almighty smote the first-born of the Egyptians but passed over the homes of the Israelites.
The strictest measures to conserve water in many years were ordered yesterday by Mayor Wagner.
HARTFORD, April 10 (UPI) -- Fire swept a Jewish auditorium here today, causing damage in excess of $100,000. Officials said it was the work of vandals who also desecrated an adjoining chapel.
NEW DELHI, April 10 -- The Indian Army has relieved police units guarding a marshy region where Indians and Pakistanis exchanged gunfire yesterday in the gravest frontier clash of recent years.
The Jewish National Fund of America announced last night that Samuel J. Lefrak, New York builder and philanthropist, had been selected to receive its John F. Kennedy Peace Award.

WHEN Franklin D. Roosevelt died, just 20 years ago tomorrow, the success of the Manhattan Project was by no means assured. The President had been told that The Bomb would work, but the scientists were not altogether confident until they ran off their terrible experiment at Alamogordo on July 16, 1945.
What keeps the stock of the American Telephone Telegraph Company trading near, its 1964-65 low despite words of encouragement from Wall Street?

BEL KAUFMAN'S article, "A Herd of Ponies" (March 21), probably has struck fire in the heart of every teacher of English. I possess several "Cliff's Notes" and unfortunately so do many of my students. High school students pool their dollars to acquire enough of these literary desecrations to pass around among, themselves and to last them for a year's worth of book reports.

President Johnson's proposal for "unconditional" discussions to end the war in Vietnam injected new life into the stock market late last week after two desultory months of caution, nervousness and price stagnancy.
Merchants are inclined to agree that Easter volume this year leaves something to be desired. Consumer purchasing of Easter finery has been desultory when it should be bustling.
A FACULTY member of Amherst, visiting Yale recently, looked around at the very impressive rebuilding of the center of New Haven and, after the manner of professors, was not impressed.

PIKESVILLE, Md., April 10 -- The first of the best-of-breed awards at the Associated Specialty Dog Clubs of Maryland show went today to the Boston terrier, Ch. Z.K. Showman Sweet and Pretty, of the Mar-Sam Kennels of Pasadena, Md.

IN recent months there have been books written by people in such diverse trades as refuse collection and school custodianship. Add to the off-beat school a writer whose first novel is published this week, James Lowell McPherson, author of "Goodbye Rosie." .Mr. McPherson is the Postmaster of Marble Dale, Conn., a smallish place at the western end of the state, near New Milford.

How did rational, ingenious, loquacious man evolve from the dumb beasts? Ever since Darwin and other early protagonists of evolution persuaded the scientific world that this had happened, the question has intrigued mankind.

Oxford is different and, despite Britain's painful creaking towards egalitarianism, always will be. It lends glamour to any title in which it appears, and the index, if there be one, will never disappoint.

COMPOSER DAVID Amram thinks serious music should have equal time on television with Lawrence Welk. And this week, at least, it will. For the American Broadcasting Company will offer both Amram and Welk in hour-long shows.

ELIZABETH, N.J., April 10 -- A 24-year-old laborer was booked here today as one of three armed thugs who forced their way into a physician's home last night and terrorized four adults and four children for an hour before fleeing with $5,000 in cash and jewelry.

IN an expert bridge game, the hands on which both sides take part in the auction slightly outnumber those on which one side monopolizes the bidding. But standard textbooks rarely do justice to the defensive bidding problems that arise when the opponents have opened the bidding.

OTTAWA, April 10 -- The Liberal Government of Prime Minister Lester B. Pearson has survived a concerted onslaught by its four opposition parties, and now clearly stands a good chance of avoiding forced national elections this year.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., April 10 -- Representative Otis G. Pike, Democrat of Riverhead, called this week for the creation of a National Marine Parks system.

CHICAGO, April 10 -- A month-long controversy over a judge's ruling against policemen for drawing their guns in making an arrest apparently has been resolved in the judge's favor.

THE taxpayer whose income is from wages or salary is undoubtedly hit hardest by Federal income tax, for there are no tax loopholes for him. IN a major bid to regain its one-time leadership in the press and professional camera fields, Graflex, Inc., a subsidiary of the General Precision Equipment Corporation, introduced a new kind of camera last week. IN reviewing "Fun in a Chinese Laundry" by Josef von Sternberg (March 14), Bosley Crowther writes that the author's name was originally Joe Stern. If I had been other than this unusual gentleman's only niece, perhaps I would be amused.

LONDON, April 10 -- "Three-pence off," says the sign at an Esso station in West London. Pennants flap in the spring breeze. A Jaguar fills up with Golden Esso.

Adam Clayton Powell stood tall, very tall, in a long black robe at the white marble altar of his crowded church yesterday. For a second, he gazed silently out at the people. Threatening to pull out of world organizations is getting to be a habit with George Meany, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. Last month it was the International Confederation of Free Trade Unions; now it is the International Labor Organization. He complains that Communist-bloc nations within the I.L.O. have been trying to turn it into a political propaganda agency, and he is "completely dissatisfied" with the lack of effective resistance by the United States Government.

About 500 young members of the Protestant, Roman Catholic and Jewish faiths participated yesterday in a model seder, or ritual meal, at the Stephen Wise Free Synagogue, 30 West 68th Street.

An audience made up mostly of musicians applauded everything warmly on David Schwartz's viola program at Carnegie Recital Hall yesterday afternoon, including two novelties.

The Board of Regents has proposed drastic changes in the procedures by which candidates for the city's Board of Education are selected. These revisions would turn the selection panel, which now submits to the Mayor a list of eligible persons, into a purely advisory body. The Mayor now must pick candidates from the list submitted to him, but the new procedure would enable him to ignore the panel's choices.

FARADJE, the Congo, April 10 -- Government forces fighting here in the northeastern Congo have seized vast supplies of arms and ammunition abandoned by the rebels.

The city's expanded meter maid force began yesterday a week-long task in which they will issue warnings of their new enforcement powers. By nightfall they had affixed leaflets to about 8,000 cars parked illegally in various ways over which they formerly had no jurisdiction.

LONDON, April 12 -- The Governments of North Vietnam and Communist China have turned down British suggestions that Patrick Gordon Walker, the former Foreign Secretary, visit Hanoi and Peking to discuss the Vietnam situation.

John J. (Jack) Donohue, who has enjoyed great success as a scholastic coach at St. Nicholas of Tolentine of the Bronx and more recently at Power Memorial in Manhattan, was named head coach of varsity basketball at Holy Cross College yesterday.
Steel production in the United States edged up two-tenths of 1 per cent in the week ended Saturday, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

Robert F. Kennedy's campaign statements about Republican Senator Kenneth B. Keating last fall were described yesterday as "such as to lead to a substantial distortion in the public's mind as to Keating's position" on the nuclear test-ban treaty.

LAUSANNE, Switzerland, April 12 (AP) -- Avery Brundage, the United States president of the International Olympic Committee, hinted today that a continued French refusal to guarantee visas for East German athletes might force the I.O.C. to take the 1968 Winter Olympic Games away from the French town of Grenoble.
SEOUL, South Korea, Tuesday, April 13 (UPI) -- Club-swinging policemen battled today a mob of 3,000 university students protesting agreements normalizing relations between South Korea and Japan.

The New York Times Company had a consolidated net income last year of $4,252,854, equal to $9.16 a share of common stock, the 1964 annual report disclosed yesterday. This compared with $1,069,127, or $1.39 a share, for 1963, when the New York City newspaper strike halted operations throughout the first quarter.
CHICAGO, April 12 -- The death toll in yesterday's tornado disaster rose today to at least 239.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 12 -- The Roman Catholic hierarchy in Saigon appealed today to Premier Phan Huy Quat to stop what it regarded as a threat of a purge of Catholic military commanders.
Soviet astronomers have been battling vigorously in recent months to get greatly expanded research funds, at the expense of Soviet nuclear physicists and their expensive atom smashers, if need be.
LONDON, April 12 -- British space experts were reserved tonight about the Soviet interpretation although some did not dismiss it categorically.
DETROIT, April 12 (AP) -- United States automobile producers continued to rewrite the production record book this week as they set two more records.
Maine potatoes provided the highlight of a generally firm commodity futures market yesterday, registering a sharp price rise in brisk trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange.

Agonizing re-enactment, not anticipated reappraisal, was the best the New York Mets could offer their noisy faithful yesterday as they opened their fourth National League season in the same old way: losing.
WHEN Alfred Lunt told Lynn Fontanne, "Next week we're playing Minnesota." she replied, "If it's in Texas I'll love it."
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 12 -- Southern Rhodesia's participation in the United Nations Tin Conference has drawn objections from Afro-Asian states.

LOS ANGELES, April 12 -- The Los Angeles Philharmonic Orchestra, closing its first season in the new Music Center this week, has almost doubled its highest previous gross. The orchestra, under the direction of Zubin Mehta, played to nearly 125,000 persons during 40 concerts, nearly twice last season's total, producing a gross of about $725,000.

A new clemency petition by Morton Sobell, now nearly half through a 30-year prison sentence for a spy conspiracy has led the Department of Justice to send forms for a bid to commute the sentence to his lawyer, William M. Kunstler.
WASHINGTON, April 12 -- Yields on newly offered Treasury bills changed only slightly this week, with rates on 91-day and 182-day bills declining slightly.

HOUSTON, April 12 (AP) -- Richie Allen drove in both Philadelphia runs with a home run in support of Chris Short's four-hit pitching as the Phillies shut out the Astros, 2-0, tonight, marring Houston's first opener in its roof-covered $31.6 million Astrodome.

Mims Thomason, president of The United Press International, announced yesterday that H. Roger Tatarian had been named editor and Francis T. Leary executive editor of the news agency. Mr. Leary also has been elected a vice president.
Jack Nicklaus came out of the clouds yesterday at 12,500 feet.

" Michael Joe: A Novel of Irish Life," by William Cotter Murray, the first winner of the Meredith-Iowa Writer's Award of $5,000, will be published by Appleton-Century on April 19. This tale of small town life in Ireland got into the competition for a Midwest prize because its author had an Irish upbringing and University of Iowa Writers' Workshop training.
WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP) -- Ten Soviet scientists today began a 15-das, tour of nuclear installations in the United States.

LAWRENCEBURG, Tenn., April 12 (AP) -- The Murray Ohio bicycle plant, shut down for five weeks by a Teamsters strike, resumed full production on its day shift today as the police cleared pickets out of the way.
MOSCOW, April 12 -- Some Soviet scientists believe that radio emissions they have received from space have been sent by "rational beings" living on a distant planet, Tass reported today.

OMAHA, April 12 (AP) -- Discharge notices have been sent to more than 1,000 union members employed at the Omaha plant of the Cudahy Packing Company, Edward Cudahy, president and chairman of the board, said today.

Rarely in diplomatic history have there been negotiations so dramatic and tragic -- so fraught with virtuous intentions, personal vanities, blindness and betrayal -- as those that culminated in the four-power conference between Hitler, Chamberlain. Daladier and Mussolini at Munich, Sept. 29 and 30, 1938. It was here that democratic (and unrepresented) Czechoslovakia was dismembered to appease what Hitler called his "last territorial claim in Europe."
WASHINGTON, April 12 -- President Johnson threw out the first ball today and then sat back and enjoyed himself amid leading lights of the Washington Establishment.

ROCK ISLAND, Ill., April 12 (AP) -- The Army awarded today a four-year defense contract totaling $114.5 million to the Cadillac Motor Car division of the General Motors Corporation for manufacture of the self-propelled 155 mm. howitzer, M109, and the armored reconnaissance assault vehicle, XM551 General Sheridan.
On weekends, in many areas of the United States, long caravans of station wagons, with ski-racks on their roofs, wind out of major cities and proceed toward snow slopes, some nearby and some distant.
BOSTON, April 12 (AP) -- National Education Television is beginning to become "a large and enticing target" for pressure groups opposing controversial programs, its president said today.

KANSAS CITY, April 12 (UPI) -- Jerry Lumpe and a rookie, John Sullivan, each slammed a two-run homer and Larry Sherry pitched three hitless innings in relief tonight to lead the Detroit Tigers to a 6-2 victory over the Kansas City Athletics.

A SINGLE slice of piping hot apple pie topped with a wedge of melting cheese served 15 seconds after being ordered or a complete turkey platter ready to eat less than two minutes after removal from refrigerated storage are not fantasies of the future.
WASHINGTON, April 12 -- The nation's war on poverty was pictured today as "off to a good start" by members of Congress who have seen it in action.

JERSEY CITY, April 12 -- The arrest of two brother's and their neighbor here in connection with the counterfeiting of $1. $5 and $10 bills was announced today by the Newark office of the Secret Service.

MONTEGO BAY, Jamaica, April 12 -- The smallest boat in the fleet, Warner Willcox's 32-foot sloop, Stardust, won Class B honors today in the Miami-Montego Bay yacht race. The Coral Reef (Fla.) Yacht Club entrant covered the 844-mile course in 9 days 2 hours 6 minutes.
David Coleman, who was convicted of the rape-murder of a 77-year old Brooklyn woman in 1960, was returned to death row yesterday.
Oil and mining shares dominated trading yesterday on the American Stock Exchange, and the market generally advanced on heavy volume.

The city has reversed a five-year-old policy and will let the Veterans of Foreign Wars Loyalty Day paraders march north on Fifth Avenue from 44th Street this year instead of north from 60th Street, where spectators would be far fewer.

For almost 20 years. Roland T. Carr, senior vice president of the Riggs National Bank in Washington, has been immersed in a job of historical detection -- locating the 221 checks that Abraham Lincoln drew on Riggs between his first inauguration and his assassination.

Convertible bonds advanced on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, following closely on the heels of a rise in the stock market that took the Dow-Jones industrial stock average to a record closing high.
ALBANY, April 12 -- The Senate unanimously confirmed today the appointment of Walter J. Mahoney of Buffalo, former Senate majority leader, as a member of the State Thruway Authority.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 12 -- Communities hit by tornadoes yesterday were alerted 35 minutes to five hours before they struck, according to the nation's tornado warning center here.

HONG KONG, Tuesday, April 13 -- Hsinhua, the Chinese Communist press agency disclosed today contents of the note delivered yesterday to Terence P. Garvey, the British Charge d'Affaires in Peking, in response to a British proposal that a special representative be sent to Peking to "contact the Chinese Government on problems of Vietnam and Indochina."
NEW HAVEN, April 12 (AP) -- An agreement was reached today to drop the two remaining insurance suits arising out of the 1960 death of Westport lawyer Julian Frank in an airplane crash.

ROME, April 12 -- Deputy Premier Pietro Nenni, a Socialist, had an hour interview tonight with Pope Paul VI -- an encounter marking a turning point in relations between the Vatican and the officially Marxist and atheist Italian Socialists.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- The President harshly enforced the political power to jam his Federal education bill through Congress exactly as drafted, except for one slight and immaterial change. The performance was miraculous for three reasons in particular:
Striking school bus drivers have agreed to transport about 1,000 severely handicapped pupils to and from school starting today.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- William Francis Raborn Jr. is famous for his role in managing the development of the Polaris missile. But he is no one-weapon zealot. "I am not the kind of man," he once said, "who when he puts his pants on in the morning thinks the whole world is dressed."
WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board refused today to relax time limit restrictions on the round trip excursion fares of National Airlines between Miami and Eastern cities.
May I congratulate The Times on its recent superb reporting with respect to the air pollution problem.
WEST MILFORD, N.J., April 12 -- Six thousand children in three Passaic County municipalities and one in Morris County had an unexpected day off from school today.

OAKVILLE, Ont., April 12 -- Canadian sales of North American-built cars should increase by 3 per cent this year over the record 1964 level, Karl E. Scott, president of the Ford Motor Company of Canada, Ltd. said today.
The elections of P. Stokes Gaither and Lester L. Colbert Jr. as directors of Reichhold Chemicals, Inc., was announced yesterday.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., April 12 -- Neither rain nor snow nor flood stopped the Minnesota Twins today as they opened the American League baseball season by defeating the defending champion New York Yankees, 5-4 in 11 innings.

Three approaches to the problem of educating children from disadvantaged homes and a new journal to report on efforts in this field will be supported by grants totaling $4,455,000 announced yesterday by the Ford Foundation.

The Soviet announcement that signs have been detected of what may be an extraterrestrial civilization naturally rouses great interest, tempered by reserve until further evidence is available. It may be that there is a more prosaic explanation for the regular pattern of radio waves, repeated every hundred days, which the Soviet astronomers have detected.
WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP) -- Secretary of the Treasury Henry H. Fowler went before a Congressional subcommittee today to defend a plan to streamline the 175-year-old Bureau of the Customs.

A behind-the-scenes tour at the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts will be conducted by its architects April 29. Proceeds will benefit the scholarship fund of the women's architectural auxiliary of the New York Chapter of the American Institute of Architects.
MONTREAL, April 12 -- Thieves broke into the vault of a bank in a Montreal shopping center and, using torches and diamond-tipped drills, looted 400 to 700 safe-deposit boxes over the weekend.
Construction of the main building of Harlem Hospital will begin in July, amid assurances by the city that there will be no racial discrimination in hiring workers.
A lawyer who is also a business executive was indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on charges of failing to file income-tax returns for 1958 through 1960 and for tax evasion in 1960.

The Board of Education's announced policy of returning the high schools to a four-year program received qualified support yesterday from the United Parents Associations and the Vocational High School Principals Association.
" WET PAINT," which came to the Renata last night, is one of those little revues in which the performers are so pleasant and anxious to please that you only wish to say kind words about it.
The British pound advanced yesterday in moderate activity on foreign exchange markets here.

The National Broadcasting Company's Channel 4 here will replace "The Pressman-Ryan Report" (6:30 to 6:55 P.M.) on May 10 with an expanded news program to be presented from 6 to 7 P.M., Mondays through Fridays.

LOS ANGELES, April 12 -- State Attorney General Thomas C. Lynch reported to the Legislature today that "private army" organizations representing themselves as patriotic groups constituted "a threat to the peace and security of our state" and should he outlawed.
George Whitmore Jr. went on trial yesterday in State Supreme Court, Brooklyn, for the murder of Mrs. Minnie Edmonds on April 14 last year.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 12 -- Nigeria's Chief S.O. Adebo appealed urgently today to the Board of Trade and Development "not to fiddle while cocoa burns -- literally as well as metaphorically."

John T. Fitzgerald and John T. Moriarty have been appointed district supervisors of the management department of Douglas L. Elliman Co. Mr. Fitzgerald was formerly a property manager for Helmsley-Spear. Mr. Moriarty had been a management executive with the Sprain Construction Company.

Freight rate surcharges announced by 18 steamship lines have had "substantial impact and reverberations" on United States relations with Latin-American countries, Timothy J. May, managing director of the Federal Maritime Commission, declared yesterday.
The Catholic wing of the Episcopal Church has protested the ordination, scheduled for today, of the first woman to Holy Orders in the Episcopal Church in the United States.
PUNTA ARENAS, Chile, April 11 -- The narrow, deeply chiseled land mass known as Chilean Patagonia, a region of sheep and ice glaciers, is moving haltingly but eagerly into the modern era.
ALBANY, April 12 --Another day dragged to a conclusion in the Legislature today with no progress on the budget that was supposed to have been passed by April 1.

PEQUANNOCK, N.J., April 12 -- Mrs. Barbara Gillooly Massa, who has been teaching her children at home in the belief that she is better able to "raise a superior breed of people" than the public schools, has been charged with violating the state's compulsory education statute.
WASHINGTON, April 12 (UPI) -- Northeast Airlines asked the Civil Aeronautics Board today to let it try an experiment in which fares would be related to the number of passengers on a flight.

LONDON, April 12 -- Six days after one of the most complex British budget messages in years, the London financial district has turned from worrying about sterling to worrying about the future state of corporate profits.
Radio Corporation of America reported yesterday its best first quarter in history.

NEW DELHI, April 12 -- Prime Minister Lal Bahadur Shastri told Parliament today that India would not "allow" Pakistan to retain her military post at Kanjarkot on the marshy border between the Indian state of Gujerat and West Pakistan.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 12 -- The Vietcong are reported to have engendered resentment among peasants in many areas of South Vietnam by sharply raising taxes on recent rice harvests.
TRENTON, April 12 -- The Legislature passed today and Governor Richard J. Hughes quickly signed a measure that calls for the election this fall of a Senate of 29 members from 14 districts.
Former President Harry S. Truman, as is his custom when he visits New York, went for a morning walk on the upper East Side yesterday, and, as is his custom, made some controversial statements.
WASHLNGTON, April 12 -The biological revolution offers lessons that may help man cope with the revolution in human affairs, Dr. Jonas E. Salk, developer of the first antipolio vaccine, said today.

TOKYO, April 8 -- While the teeming life of one of Tokyo's busiest centers swirled around them, silk-robbed Shinto priests and hundreds of animal-lovers paid ceremonial homage today to the memory of one of Japan's most beloved figures, the faithful dog Hachiko.
PORTLAND, Ore., April 12 -- Canda told the United States today that she would not share any of here vast supply of surplus water without a suitable economic return.
ANY mother who has to get a pretty daughter dressed and out of the house in the morning can appreciate Frances Klein's problem. She used to prod a bevy of six.
WASHINGTON, April 12 -- The International Association of Machinists is facing a strike by clerical employes at the union's national headquarters here.

MONROE, Wis., April 12 (UPI) -- The tornado devastation in southern Wisconsin's dairy farm belt came into sharp focus today with three persons dead, about 150 injured, 600 homeless and property damage mounting into the millions of dollars.
It was a day for small boys to forget about school and grown men to forget about their income tax -- at least for the time being.
