Sales of ordinary life insurance by the Mutual Benefit Life Insurance Company, Newark, N.J., reached a new high in the first quarter, it reported yesterday.
Federated Department Stores, Inc., continued its long-term upward trend with record sales and earnings in the 52 weeks ended Jan. 30.

The Newfoundland and Labrador Power Commission has placed directly with institutional investors in the United States and Canada $37 million of 5 1/4 per cent sinking fund bonds due Feb. 15, 1990. The figure is in United States funds.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., April 12 -- The Board of Supervisors approved today the hiring of 355 high school dropouts by Suffolk under the county's antipoverty program.

It may have been the same old story over at Shea Stadium yesterday, but it was a New Page at Aqueduct. George D. Widener's 4-year-old horse of that name thrilled and pleased the favorite players among the 29,657 at the race course by winning the feature event on the card.

OTTAWA, April 12 -- Canada's unexpectedly vigorous economy reduced the Government's budgetary deficit to $83 million in the fiscal year that ended March 31. The deficit in the previous year was $619.2 million.
Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, Inc., continued yesterday its fight for its trading life before the New York Stock Exchange.
KARACHI, Pakistan, April 12 -- Pakistani forces said today they had destroyed two Indian tanks and disabled four others in the fighting in the Rann of Cutch.
UMTALI, Rhodesia, April 12 (Reuters) -- An American teacher was fined 25 ($70) today for writing a poem that the authorities said was likely to engender feelings of hostility toward the police.

Most of the business leaders who responded to this newspaper's survey on the effectiveness of President Johnson's program of voluntary restraints are cooperating fully in the attempt to stem the outflow of dollars. They warned, however, that the United States will face a serious decline in earnings from abroad if they are forced to maintain such restraint for a prolonged period.
DESPITE drastic cast changes and a promise of new scripts stressing drama of earnest conflict, the Mets still are enmeshed in the theater of the absurd.
Any increase in the city's basic real estate tax will "severely worsen" the city's housing problem, the Metropolitan Fair Rent Committee declared yesterday.

MONTREAL, April 12 (Canadian Press) -- An International Air Transport Association spokesman said tonight that all 81 member airlines had voted to ban movies and closed-circuit television on international flights.

INDIANAPOLIS, April 12 (AP) -- The death toll in Indiana's worst disaster climbed toward 150 tonight as National Guardsmen and volunteers combed the debris of 22 tornado-shattered towns and hundreds of farms.

OKLAHOMA CITY, April 12 (UPI) -- Justice N.B. Johnson of the Oklahoma Supreme Court told the State Senate today he was not guilty of impeachment charges accusing him of having taken money for favorable court opinions.
Municipal-bond sales dealers are awaiting today's $125 million New York City bond offering, the largest single tax-exempt offering so far this year, with more than usual interest.

REMINISCENCES of President Franklin D. Roosevelt as a father and a friend made for an attractive and human half-hour last night on the network of the Columbia Broadcasting System. Charles Kuralt narrated the program, entitled "F.D.R. Remembered," on the 20th anniversary of Mr. Roosevelt's death.
ATLANTIC CITY, April 12 -- The discovery of a way to detect susceptibility to glaucoma decades before the blinding eye disorder strikes was reported at a scientific meeting here today.

THE style displayed by the Metropolitan Museum of Art in its new exhibition, "Three Centuries of American Painting," no less than the greatness of its collections, will make a particular appeal to antiquarians and others interested in the American scene.
The St. Regis Roof will be the setting April 22 for the fourth armual Botticelli Ball, a benefit for Orphans of Italy.

Within 50 miles of Times Square lives about one-tenth of the nation's population. Every weekday morning more than 3 million of these 19 million people travel to their jobs in the lower half of Manhattan, the nine square miles between Central Park and the Battery.

The mystery of who supplied the drivers for the 22 trucks that made deliveries on Sunday to Bloomingdale's department store grew deeper yesterday. The store has remained open despite a strike that began April 1.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- James L. Robertson, a governor of the Federal Reserve Board, urged Congress today to end the present "triple standard" of bank regulation by creating a single Federal agency to do the job.

The American Museum of Natural History, which was sorely beset by a sensational gem theft last fall and a murder in its lobby during the winter, had another unhappy experience yesterday. Its basement was flooded and the building could not be opened for the day.
The National Broadcasting Company has given permission to Police Lieut. Thomas R. Gilligan to view today a film of a television program in which he was allegedly characterized as being mentally ill.
ST. PAUL, April 12 (AP) -- Minnesota s exhausting combat with flooding rivers spread to the Mississippi River today as new high water poured in from swollen tributaries.
If the ads in the subway cars and stations are beginning to look a bit familiar, it's because some of them have been there a lot longer than they should have.

Joseph Martin, a 49-year-old reporter and feature writer for The Daily News, was selected yesterday to succeed Deputy Police Commissioner Walter Arm, who has been in charge of community relations for the Police Department.
BERLIN, April 12 -- West Berliners crossed through the wall to visit relatives in East Germany today as the two-week period of Easter visits began.
A foundation study of audiences who saw Shakespeare in the city's neighborhoods last summer drew the criticism yesterday of the play's producer over some of its findings.

IN a recipe for gefilte fish for Passover that appeared last Sunday in The New York Times Magazine, there was a listing of cracker crumbs or bread crumbs as well as matzoh meal among the ingredients. However, both cracker crumbs and bread crumbs contain leaven and are therefore proscribed for Passover.

Herbert Blau and Jules Irving, the San Franciscans who recently assumed stewardship of the Lincoln Center Repertory Theater, said yesterday that the theater's ticket prices will be unchanged next season.

PITTSBURGH, April 12 (AP) -- Bob Bailey's home run leading off the 10th inning today broke up a brilliant pitching duel between Juan Marichal of the Giants and Bob Veale of Pittsburgh and gave the Piirates a 1-0 victory over San Francisco.

YONKERS, April 12 -- Earle Avery, 71 years young, gets around almost as quickly as the harness horses he drives. The energetic Canadian reinsman trained standard breds at Yonkers Raceway this morning, attended the luncheon-draw for Thursday night's $100,000 International Pace at the Hampshire House in Manhattan and then rushed back to the track, where he directed Meadow Skipper through his final workout for that event.

Fabric gloves improve with washing, both in appearance and in longevity, according to Mrs. Florence G. Minifie, extension clothing specialist at Rutgers University, who points out that gritty soil causes fabric to wear out more quickly than does laundering.
Second thoughts on last week's Labor Government budget sent prices tumbling yesterday on the London stock market.
NOTHING points up the individual beauty of Bruckner's orchestration better than the performance the Philadelphia Orchestra gave of his Fifth Symphony in Carnegie Hall last night.

WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP) -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee approved unanimously today President Johnson's nomination of Palmer Hoyt, editor and publisher of The Denver Post, as a member of the United States Advisory Commission on Information.

THE memorial exhibition opening today of 40 drawings acquired by the Museum of Modern Art through the generosity of the late John S. Newberry must be counted among the memorable art events of the current season.
THE crackle and glow of H.L. Mencken live on in these pages. He will sometimes be remembered for his ideas -- and always for his style.

A surge of customers at the Boston store of Jordan Marsh Co. quickly bought $178,000 worth of ladies' handbags yesterday that had been purchased from goods salvaged from the Neiman-Marcus department store in Dallas after a fire last December.
LONDON, April 12 -- Peter Diamand, head of the Holland Festival since 1949, was appointed artistic director of the Edinburgh International Festival today. He succeeds the Earl of Harewood.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 12 -- Dr. Carroll Witten of Louisville, Ky., was named today president-elect of the American Academy of General Practice, composed of 28,500 of the nation's 67,000 family doctors. He takes office next year.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- The Federal Government opened the way for a possible showdown with Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama by granting antipoverty funds to biracial groups in Birmingham and three other cities in that state.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 13 -- The Secretary General, U Thant, began conferences today with Eugene R. Black, retired president of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, on President Johnson's proposals for a vast program of economic development in Southeast Asia.

CHICAGO, April 13 (UPI) -- Survivors of the nation's third worst tornado disaster buried their dead, succored their sick and rescued the battered treasures of lifetimes from mountains of rubble in five Middle Western states today.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 13 -- Secretary of Agriculture Orville L. Freeman told farm groups today that unless they lined up behind the Administration's farm bill they might lose Government programs supporting the commodities they produce.

HAVANA, April 13 -- Premier Fidel Castro's Government announced today it had agreed in principle with the Soviet Union on the development of some Cuban industries. The announcement came amid renewed speculation on the future of Ernesto Che Guevara, the Minister of Industry and a key figure in the Castro regime.
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- There will be nobody at Ford's Theater tomorrow to think about the 100th anniversary of Abraham Lincoln's assassination but workmen and engineers.

New computations of lunar motion by scientists of Columbia University and International Business Machines Corporation allow prediction of the moon's position at any moment with an error of only a few feet.

The Composers Cooperative Society, a new group organized by a handful of composers living in New York, presented its first concert last night. Each work heard in the Carnegie Recital Hall presentation was being given its New York premiere.
WARSAW, April 13 -- "De you have a telephone?" a Pole was asked. "No," he replied. "0nly Jews have telephones in this country."

Surrounded by six men who were members of his Cabinet, Harry S. Truman received the annual award of Freedom House last night at a dinner marking the 20th anniversary of his first full day as President of the United States.

The Studebaker Corporation turned in its fifth consecutive profitable quarter in the three months ended March 31, with earnings from operations up 74 per cent from the first-quarter level a year earlier. Byers A. Burlingame, president, announced the figures yesterday at the company's South Bend Ind., headquarters.

General Industrial Enterprises, Inc., an investment company, has increased its holdings in the common stock of Best Co., to about 115,000 shares, or about 20 per cent of the outstanding common. The company is planning to make further purchases.
ATLANTIC CITY April 13 -- The discovery of a breed of laboratory animal that gets congestive heart failure and related troubles just as people do was reported here today.

Ramco Enterprises Inc., a New York operating company that controls Cartier, Inc., announced yesterday that it had entered into an agreement to acquire a major interest in John B. Stetson Company, Philadelphia.

Members of the three European teams that will compete in the three-day round-robin Easter international soccer tournament starting tomorrow night at Downing Stadium, Randalls Island, arrived yesterday at Kennedy International Airport.
THE HAGUE, April 13 (UPI) -- The Premier-designate, Dr. Joseph L.T. Cals, announced today that he has formed a coalition Cabinet, ending a seven-week-old government crisis.
TRENTON, April 13 -- Gov. Richard J. Hughes approved today a plan for putting out the garbage and peat fires that have been smoldering in the Jersey Meadows since 1959.
BONN, April 13 -- Gold holdings of the Bundesbank, West Germany's Federal bank, rose by $400 million last year, the bank disclosed today in its annual report for 1961.
LONDON, April 13 -- The Labor Government was defeated in the House of Lords today on an issue that could provoke a renewal of the ancient conflict over the Lords' power.
The stock market advanced yesterday for the fourth consecutive session and pushed two key averages to records for the second straight day.
SELMA, Ala., April 13 -- A Dallas County grand jury indicted three Selma white men today on a charge of murder in the slaying of the Rev. James J. Reeb, a white minister from Boston.

WASHINGTON, April 13 (UPI) -- President Johnson has ordered withdraw a Secret Service request for two new armored Presidential cars already approved by the House, Treasury Secretary Henry H. Fowler said today.

LOS ANGELES, April 13 (UPI) -- Ralph Terry, returning to his pitching form of past years as a Yankee, made a winning debut for the Cleveland Indians tonight by holding the Los Angeles Angels to four hits while hurling a 7-1 victory in the Angels' opener.
The British Government's announcement of disappointing trade figures for March brought a sharp drop in prices yesterday on the London Stock Exchange.

" Hello, Dolly!" the title song of the Broadway musical, won 2 of the 47 Grammys presented by the National Academy of Recording Artists last night. The award for the best male vocal performance went to Louis Armstrong for his rendition of the song, and Jerry Herman, its composer, received the "song of the year" Grammy.
The Manuafcturers Hanover Trust Company asked Congress yesterday to nullify the bank's recent civil conviction for violation of the Sherman and Clayton Antitrust Acts.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- A House Labor subcommittee studying operations of the poverty program was thrown briefly into turmoil today as one witness impugned the integrity of another. Both were summoned back for further testimony and rebuttal at an extra session at 9 o'clock tomorrow morning.
SAIGON, Wednesday, April 14 (AP) -- A United States Marine batallion of 1,400 men waded ashore near Danang today to bring the number of Marines in South Vietnam to more than 8,000.

THE contrast becomes more sharply etched when an observer can compare two successive baseball games he has witnessed, one within the magnificent enclosure of Houston's Astrodome and the next in the great outdoors of Shea Stadium. They provide built-in standards of measurement and even make the mind wander back over the years to something Alvin Dark said when he was playing ball for he Chicago Cubs near the end of his career.
The first one-man exhibition in this country of a Soviet painter, arranged under the cultural exchange agreement, will open here early next month.
A handful of stockholders had their annual joust yesterday with the management of the Western Electric Company.

The eighth annual luncheon of the Greater New York Chapter of Links, Inc., will be held on Saturday at the Americana Hotel. On the program will be a panel and round-table discussions on the role of women in world affairs.

New York criminal lawyers are having second thoughts about the advantages of contesting their clients' confessions in advance of trial. The principal reason for the concern is that since the new method for challenging the voluntariness of confessions was introduced in January, trial judges have rejected the contentions of five of the state's best-known murder defendants that their confessions had been obtained through coercion.

ELIZABETH, N.J., April 13 (UPI) -- Three former Clark Township councilmen, a present councilman and the public works director were indicted by a grand jury today on charges of extorting $5,000 from a mortician in return for a building variance.
In the warm hazy dusk of an early spring day 100 years ago, boys ran through the downtown streets of Washington passing out freshly printed handbills.
The $5.9 million experimental program for the social and physical rehabilitation of a single, decaying block in Central Harlem officially began yesterday at a City Hall ceremony.
ONE of the notable phenomena of our culture is the emergence, over the last two decades or so, of what might be called a Jewish-American consciousness.

In the first quarter of 1965, United Aircraft Corporation had sales of more than $300 million and earnings of about $1.30 a share, H.M. Horner, chairman, reported yesterday at the annual stockholders' meeting in East Hartford, Conn.

MARLBORO, N.Y., April 13 -- There is nothing quite like the shame that a proud and sensitive man feels when, in front of thousands of admirers and surrounded by cameras and critics, he is physically demolished by another man, Floyd Patterson was saying at his camp today.
Steven Carson, a Lincoln scholar who is working for a master's degree in history at New York University, paid tribute to the President in a memorial published in The New York Times today.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- The State Department disclosed today that the United States was discussing the sale or gift of arms to five Middle East nations -- Iraq, Israel, Jordan, Lebanon and Saudi Arabia.
The failure of the state to adopt a budget will begin tomorrow to cost the city about $10,000 a day that it would normally be making in short-term investments.

Three clubmen, who wined and dined California gold mine investors at the Yale and Princeton Clubs and allegedly extracted $500,000 but no ore, have been barred from the securities business in New York State.
A new tennis cup, one of the handsomest in competition, was put up yesterday by Cartier, the Fifth Avenue jewelers, for the first professional tournament to be held at the Newport (R.I.) Casino.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- North Vietnam has offered a four-point formula for peace in Southeast Asia and has invited the United States to recognize that formula as the basis for an international conference.

PARIS -- Just a hundred years ago Abraham Lincoln was assassinated after having started the emancipation of American Negroes, a process still incomplete. As Lincoln lay dying, sub-Saharan Africa -- where United States Negroes originated -- was just beginning to lose its liberty to European conquerors.

Faculty members at St. John's University have been given two additional weeks to consider the latest offer of salary increases and added fringe benefits before returning their contracts for next year.
LONDON, April 13 -- Britain has replied sharply to Communist China's refusal to accept a visit from Patrick Gordon Walker, former Foreign Secretary, on his tour of the Far East.
The Government's Medicare program can be expected to exert downward pressure on drug prices, Francis C. Brown, chairman and president of Schering Corporation told the annual meeting yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Apri 13 -- Two used Gemini spacecraft will be flown by the Air Force in tests related to a manned orbiting laboratory, it was disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP) -- George Meany said today the labor federation would seek full compliance with the new equal employment section of the Civil Rights Act. He said it would stand ready to use. boycotts and strikes where necessary against any employers who refused to comply.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 13 -- More than 80 American and South Vietnamese aircraft wrecked another North Vietnamese bridge today and attacked two radar stations previously hit. The assaults followed a two-day respite in the air strikes against the North.

ALBANY, April 13 -- A labor leader today denounced a bill that would repeal the Condon-Wadlin Law which prohibits strikes by public employes, because it would strip the unions involved of their bargaining rights.

Instant cages -- an innovation of the automated age -- are hustling lions and tigers in and out of the spotlight at Madison Square Garden faster than ever these days, thanks to a circus executive with the corporate-sounding name of McCormick Steele.

ALGIERS, April 13 -- Algeria led Arab delegates today in urging a halt to continued Albanian and Chinese Communist "polemics" against the Soviet Union at the Moscow-organized International Teachers Conference here.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 13 -- At 10:45 A.M. central standard time Sunday, the Severe Local Storm Center here warned Weather Bureaus across the country that "severe thunderstorms with large hail, damaging winds and several tornadoes" were expected that afternoon from Missouri to Indiana.

Following is the text of an English-language report by Hsinhua, the Chinese Communist press agency, on the essentials of a policy declaration by Premier Pham Van Dong of North Vietnam, as mentioned in the United States:
A MAJOR hotel chain has decided that women should be treated like women and when 31 Hilton Corporation hotels put out the welcome mat later this week it will be covered with frills and furbelows.
NORFOLK, Va., April 13 (AP) -- Borrowing a leaf from professional football, the United States Second Fleet has installed the two-platoon system.
A clear path was opened in court yesterday for introduction of two confessions made by George Whitmore Jr. to the police on April 24, 1964, involving a rape attempt and a murder.

The annual "Parade of the Flowers," a fashion show and luncheon sponsored by the auxiliary of St. Luke's Hospital, will be held on April 22 in the Plaza's Grand Ballroom. Guests are requested to bring rummage to be sold by the organization's thrift shop at 330 East 59th Street.
Yale University is one of the financial beneficiaries of the television popularity rating of "Peyton Place," the serialized saga of simmering teen-age emotions in a New England town.
The Chesapeake Ohio Railway has terminated its offer to purchase stock control of the Chicago, South Shore South Bend Railroad.
BUDAPEST, April 13 -- Visitors streamed into the fifth-floor flat at 2 Belgrade Quay today to congratulate Prof. Gyorgy Lukacs, the Marxist critic and philosopher on his 80th birthday.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 13 (AP) -- Harvard University announced today the appointment of Robert S. Fitzgerald, poet and translator of classics, as Boylston Professor of Rhetoric and Oratory, effective July 1.

CHICAGO, April 13 (UPI) -- The Chicago Black Hawks broke up a tight battle with tile Detroit Red Wings tonight with a three-goal outburst in the final eight minutes for a 4-0 victory that deadlocked their Stanley Cup series at three games each.
The British pound held its, own on foreign-exchange markets both here and in London despite heavy selling pressure.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 13 -- Meteorologists at the nation's tornado warning center here said today that anyone in the path of a twister should take shelter in the southwest corner of his basement.
Trading on the American Stock Exchange lacked a definite trend yesterday as declines exceeded advances by a narrow margin in active trading.

THE San Francisco Ballet, the oldest professional ballet company in the United States, has finally come to New York for an extended visit. It opened last night at the New York State Theater, where it will remain through Sunday.

Sales and earnings of the Corn Products Company in the first quarter of this year exceeded those in the corresponding period of any prior year. A.N. McFarlane, chairman and chief executive officer, reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- President Johnson will view flooded and tornado-stricken regions of the Middle West tomorrow.

" Auschwitz in England: A Record of a Libel Action," by Mavis M. Hill and L. Norman Williams, will be published by Stein Day on April 27. The authors are members of the bar of England. The book presents a detailed report on the trial that resulted when a Dr. Dering sued Leon Uris and the publishers of his book, "Exodus."

A proposed ban on in-flight movies was angrily denounced yesterday by one of the developers of plane films as "a flagrant, arrogant move . . . to deprive the public of the most popular means yet devised to relieve the monotony of long flights."

Pan American Day, which is celebrated every year on April 14, has a special significance today because it is the 75th anniversary of what is now called the Organization of American States. This makes the O.A.S. the oldest international organization of its kind in the world.
Prices of convertible bonds continued to rise yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange as stock averages climbed to historic highs for the second consecutive day.

ALBANY, April 13 -- The chairman of a legislative committee turned over to New York City for investigation today the sworn testimony of a woman who recounted her 20 "filthy," "snakepit" days in the Women's House of Detention.

Acting Superintendent of Schools Bernard E. Donovan has returned from a trip to Albany with the disturbing news that a sense of urgency is draining out of the politicians' concern for the public schools. Experts in the State Education Department are said to be pessimistic about the Legislature's action on school aid, and Dr. Donovan found too many legislators ready to take a relaxed view about the fiscal crisis of the city schools.
" Fade Out -- Fade In" will fade from the Broadway scene Saturday, bringing a stormy theater venture to a relatively quiet end.
The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People yesterday approved the withdrawal of its Mississippi branches from the Council of Federated Organizations.
Strong demand for silver was the highlight of a generally mixed commodity futures market yesterday.

The General Electric Company plans to proceed with the multimillion-dollar cash purchase of the electric housewares operations of Landers, Frary Clark of New Britain, Conn. Both companies announced yesterday they had received antitrust clearance from the Department of Justice for the proposed acquisition.

STONY POINT, N.Y., April 13 -- A critical water situation in northern Rockland County is believed to have been eased. It was announced today that agreement had been reached for the purchase by the Spring Valley Water Company, Inc., of the water-supply facilities of the Haverstraw division of the Utilities and Industries Corporation.

Net income of the Beech Aircraft Corporation in the second fiscal quarter rose to an indicated $1,180,010, equal to 42 cents a share, from $851,659, or 30 cents, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier, it was disclosed yesterday.

In a move to "stimulate the creative impulse in all departments" of the agency, the Zlowe Company, Inc., has promoted its creative director to president. He is Milton Sutton, a senior vice president, who has been with the agency for 20 years.
MOSCOW, April 13 -- Soviet scientists declared today that it was premature to assume that radio waves received from space had emanated from "rational beings."
PALO ALTO, Calif., April 13 -- The Stanford University chapter of Sigma Chi fraternity has pledged a Negro to membership and has been suspended by the national organization.

The essay, the flexible yet precise literary form of Francis Bacon, Charles Lamb and Ralph Waldo Emerson, has been chosen by Time magazine as the ideal format for it to present "the second thoughts and greater reflections" of a growingly complex and computerized age.
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- President Johnson is sending Henry Cabot Lodge to consult with six friendly governments in Asia and the South Pacific on the situation in Vietnam.

WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP) -- A spokesman for the major cigarette manufacturers urged a House committee today to block the Federal Trade Commission's plan to require health hazard warnings on cigarette labels or in advertising.
The author of this book is a nationally recognized authority on admiralty law and a knowledgeable writer on salvage, seamen, ships, navigation and the maze of laws that surround them.

Powerful dogs straining at their leashes led their owners down dimly lit back alleys of the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn Monday night as the Bedford-Stuyvesant Safety Patrol took to the field.

With the Dow-Jones industrial average closing at record highs for each of the last two days, most Wall Street analysts are encouraged by market prospects. Yesterday, this popular stock index gained 1.65 to end at 908.01.
Tom Farrell of St. John's America's best half-miler in the Olympic Games, will spend most of the coming track season running the quarter-mile. The formula may be unusual, but it has worked before.

The former head of a Federal investigation into alleged criminal activities by officials of the American Guild of Variety Artists has been appointed to a $500-a-week position with the union, it was disclosed yesterday.
CORNING, N.Y., April 13 (AP) -- The Corning Glass Works reported today a first-quarter net income of $8,587,694, or $1.25 a share of common stock after preferred dividend requirements.
ADAM MEREDITH, one of the world's great bridge players, was the chief beneficiary in the will of his longtime bridge partner, Miss Ruth T. Sherman, who died last week.
Developments in the week-long school bus strike yesterday embroiled the Transit Authority in a controversy with its bus drivers.

Mr. Grainger was described yesterday by his sister, Mrs. Margaret Auclair of West Hartford, Conn., as a "very outgoing and very dedicated" man who liked the Vietnamese people. Mrs. Auclair spoke for her mother. Mrs. Vincent Grainger of 68 Van Buren Avenue, West Hartford, who was in seclusion.
Bloomingdale's department store and the union representing 3,300 of its employes who are on strike resumed negotiations yesterday. The talks were broken off Sunday.

A blustery wind blew across 45th Street outside the Morosco Theatre yesterday morning. Dan Dailey sniffled and sneezed. Bethel Leslie coughed. Tom Bosley shivered. A Marlin sports car purred. And the publicity man responsible for them all being there purred, too.

The American Jewish Congress's plan to test the constitutionality of the new Federal law on aid to education was attacked yesterday by Rabbi Max J. Routtenberg, president of the Rabbinical Assembly, an organization of 800 Conservative rabbis.

YADKINVILLE, N.C., April 13 (AP) -- Stuart Thomas Saunders Jr., 24 years old, son of the president of the Pennsylvania Railroad, was ordered held on a manslaughter charge today in the traffic deaths of three persons March 28.
An 18-year-old youth was taken into custody and charged with homicide yesterday in the recent slaying of a 62-year-old Washington Heights housewife.

Gov. John N. Dempsey of Connecticut made public yesterday an emergency plan under which the four states served by the New Haven Railroad would provide a total of $11.5 million to keep its passenger service alive at least another year.
PITTSBURGH, April 13 (AP) -- Al McBean put down a ninth-inning uprising, preserving Bob Friend's victory tonight as the Pittsburgh Pirates defeated the San Francisco Giants, 5-2.
U.S. Smelting, Refining and Mining Company has assumed operating control of Mueller Brass Company after acquiring 74 per cent of its outstanding stock.
WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP) -- The Justice Department asked a Federal Court today to require three publishers of city directories to show why they should not be held in contempt of court.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Secretary of Commerce John T. Connor conceded today that the interaction of various elements in the Administration's voluntary balance-of-payments program might be hurting American exports.

Motorists driving west along Rockaway Boulevard, about a mile and a furlong from Aqueduct, must have been startled at noon yesterday when they saw a horse swimming. The animal went gracefully through the water in the outdoor pool at the Holiday Inn.

Sophia Loren, who has teamed with her producer husband, Carlo Ponti, in making the current "Operation Crossbow" and the forthcoming "Lady L." for Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, will make two more films for the company. Both will be produced by Mr. Ponti.

MONTREAL, April 13 -- A zone recalling the run on banks when President Franklin D. Roosevelt declared a moritorium on deposits and withdrawals in 1933 was enacted here today as holders of safety deposit boxes stormed a bank whose vault was looted over the weekend.
Warren Spahn, who has established many records for left-handed pitchers, will try today to give the New York Mets and their left-handed manager, Casey Stengel, a cherished record of their own.
A new owner plans extensive modernization of the former Remington Rand Building at 315 Park Avenue South, the southeast corner of 24th Street.

The Dinkler Hotel Corporation of New York and Mercury Insurance Underwriters of Los Angles have announced that they will jointly build luxury hotels at airport terminals in the United States and Canada.
Sales and earnings of the Monsanto Company reached record levels in the first quarter of this year.

KANSAS CITY, April 13 (AP) -- The Detroit Tigers scored seven runs in the first two innings today and breezed to an 11-4 victory over the Kansas City Athletics before a crowd of 2.028 at Municipal Stadium. Al Kaline drove in five of the Detroit runs.

James B. Donovan, president of the Board of Education, called on Governor Rockefeller yesterday to press for substantial increases in state aid for education in addition to the Federal funds to be provided by President Johnson's Education Aid Bill.
Hirsch Jacobs, the talented trainer from Forest Hills, had just cause for cheer yesterday as he saw his daughter's gray colt, Turn to Reason, mile a runaway of a mile race at Aqueduct.
LEXINGTON, Ky., April 13 (AP) -- Kenny Knapp rode four winners at Keeneland today including Bully Heart in the South Creek Purse.

RICHMOND, Va., April 13 -- One of the nation's leading cigarette makers acknowledged today that the question of health hazards in smoking "is a serious matter despite the fact that direct proof of a cause-and-effect relationship is still lacking."
A FIVE-STORY town house on East 55th Street is painted a dramatic black and white and has across its front a sign with letters a foot high that spell out McMillen Inc.
L. Judson Morhouse, former Republican State Chairman, will appear at a Federal hearing in Rochester concerning the Finger Lakes race track in upstate New York, but he will not testify.
The election of Chris J. Witting as president and chief executive officer of the Crouse-Hinds Company was announced yesterday at the annual stockholders' meeting in Syracuse.
EDMONTON, Alberta, April 13 -- Peter Lazarovich voiced dissent today from the notion that Canada is a country of two languages -- English and French.
A nearly blind musician lost a round yesterday in his battle to become a junior high school music teacher. But his lawyers said he would keep up his court fight.

Business confidence is booming. With economic activity going from strength to strength there is no reason for a letdown in the mood of the business community. Yet its good spirits is not attributable solely to rising sales curves and a bumper crop of earnings. It also stems from the continued harmony in the relations between business and Government.

In your articles of April 7 and 8 on the Dilowa Hutukhtu, the highest ranking Buddhist Lama in the United States, it was correctly implied that the Dilowa was living in reduced circumstances in a nondescript building on 32d Street. However, no mention was made of the medical care that he was receiving.
Operation revenues of Trans World Airlines, Inc. in tile first quarter of this year were $131.4 million, up 15.8 per cent from the $113.5 million in revenues in the corresponding period last year.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- The House of Representatives approved late today its version of a constitutional amendment to meet the problems of Presidential inability, and to keep the post of Vice President filled.
LONDON, April 13 -- The British trade gap widened last month, sending stock prices down sharply and causing nervousness in the foreign exchange market, where the pound slipped 0.03125, to $2.7953.
PARIS, April 13 - President de Gaulle's Government has again applied the brakes on progress toward supranationalism in the European Common Market.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., April 13 -- The Republican-controlled executive committee of the Illinois Senate voted 13 to 9 today against the reappointment of Charles Gray as chairman of the state's Fair Employment Practices Commission.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 13 -- The Secretary General, U. Thant, has called the 114-member Disarmament Commission to hold an organizational meeting April 21 and begin its work session April 26.
The Prudential Insurance company announced yesterday plans to form a regional office in Newark to handle insurance and investment operations in the Middle Atlantic States.
TORONTO, April 13 -- The six-week-old Windfall stock investigation sent new shock waves through the Canadian securities and mining industries today.
LONDON, April 13 -- The remains of Lady Anne Mowbray, the 15th-century infant duchess whose coffin was unearthed in the East End of London in December, will be reinterred in Westminster Abbey.

BRANDON, Miss., April 13 -- A fire last night destroyed a tiny Negro church in a sparsely settled area 12 miles northwest of Brandon, the Rankin County seat. Six members of the church sought to register as voters yesterday.

A seven-acre plot with a two-story warehouse at 40 West 225th Street, north of the Harlem River, formerly occupied by Seeman Brothers, wholesale grocers, has been purchased by Harry G. Silverstein Sons, real estate investors.
The faction opposed to Stanley Steingut as county leader of the Brooklyn Democratic party will end its 18-month boycott of executive committee meetings and seek negotiations to end party differences.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Secretary of Commerce John T. Connor disclosed today that he was planning to meet with representatives of the automobile industry to discuss the problem of "built-in speed" and its implications for highway safety.
ALBANY, Wednesday, April 14 -- The Assembly approved Governor Rockefeller's controversial 2 per cent statewide sales tax early today. The vote was 82-67.
BALTIMORE, April 13 (AP) -The Los Angeles Lakers held off a late rally by Baltimore and defeated the Bullets, 117 -- 115, tonight, advancing to the National Basketball Association final playoffs.

Four men, including an executive vice president of the McGraw-Hill, Inc.' publishing company, were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on unconnected charges of incometax evasion or failure to file returns.
AS Sune Carlson waited for his mid-morning coffee, he glanced with distaste at the glass of iced water before him and commented on this "nasty American habit that kills the taste of food."

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 13 -- Western Germany land the Netherlands strongly urged the Board of Trade and Development today to promote collaboration in its activities with the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.

The management of the Atlantic Improvement Corporation promised stockholders yesterday a cash distribution of "significant proportions" when the city pays the company for 22.5 million square feet of oceanfront property acquired at Breezy Point, Queens.
Ilan Rogoff, a 21-year-old pianist who was born in Israel and has been attending the Mannes College of Music here, gave his debut recital last night at Town Hall.

PITTSBURGH, April 13 -- The United Steelworkers of America and the basic steel industry appeared today to be heading toward an agreement to extend their contracts well past May 1, the present strike deadline.

DUBLIN, April 13 -- With the finish of the long-drawn-out recount in Longford-Westmeath constituency tonight, Sean Lemass has won 72 seats and will form the next Irish Government when the new Dail Eireann (Parliament) meets April 21.
ALBANY, April 13 -- The Assembly passed a bill today compelling New York City landlords to provide heat around the clock from Oct. 1 to May 31.
Herb McKenley, a former world-record-holding runner, must soon sit in judgment of himself.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- The United States and a number of Western European countries were reported today to have turned down in effect Ghana's requests for hundreds of millions of dollars in emergency loans to ease her deficit in international payments.

WORCESTER, Mass. April 13 (UPI) -- Jack Donohue, the new Holy Cross basketball coach, said today that he would make his first recruiting bid to 7-foot-1-inch Lew Alcindor tomorrow. Z Tile 33year-old Donohue, i lwhose Aleindor-led Power Me-i Imorial teams have won Newl [York City Catholic high sehool championships the last three;; years, said his hope to bring ,Alcindor with him to Holy; Cross was "obvious."

FOR the National Orchestral Association concert in Carnegie Hall last night, John Barnett, the conductor, did an instructive thing. He placed Hans Werner Henze's "Nachtstucke und Arien," written by the German composer in 1957, before the intermission and some standard Richard Strauss works after it.

CINCINNATI, April 13 (UPI) -- Tony Perez, a rookie first baseman, hit his first major league homer tonight with the bases filled and led the Cincinnati Reds to an 8-3 victory over the Milwaukee Braves.

TORONTO, April 13 (UPI) -- David Molson, the president of the Montreal Canadiens, confirmed today that National Hockey League governors are searching for a "capable" man to assist and eventually replace Clarence Campbell as the league president.

BOSTON, April 13 (UPI) -- The United States Court of Appeals ruled today that Northeast Airlines is entitled to a full hearing before the Civil Aeronautics Board in the fight to retain its Florida route.
New York City awarded its second bond issue of the year, $125 million general improvement bonds, yesterday to a 100-member syndicate headed by the First National City Bank.
WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP) -- The White House said today that a special committee would report to President Johnson June 1 on the proposed closing of Veterans Administration hospitals and homes.
At this distance in time the murderous attack on Abraham Lincoln, a century ago today, is tangled in myth and mystery. He knew his danger, dreamed his own death.
WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP) -- Representative of five cities objected today to modernizing the Bureau of Customs to an extent that would downgrade their ports.

LONDON, April 13 -- The British are like a family whose children have all grown up and left home. It is a bit awkward, as they say, especially since they have also lost most of the family fortune, but they are determined to make a new life for themselves just the same.

PHILADELPIA, April 13 -As expected, the Eastern Division championship of the National Basketball Association will be decided Thursday night when the Boston Celtics and the Philadelphia 76ers meet in the seventh game of their playoff series in Boston.

All seven games that the New York Jets of the American Football League will play away from home next fall will be televised here in color over Channel 4, WNBC-TV. It will be the first time that professional football has been presented in color on a regular basis.

WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP) -- Vice President Humphrey hinted today that President Johnson would accede to the demands of organized labor and ask Congress to increase the Federal minimum wage, now $1.25 an hour.

A slender, blond, German-born wife of an Army sergeant testified yesterday that the chief prosecution witness in the murder trial of Mark Fein had telephoned her prior to the time of the murder, asking to borrow a car in which to move "a large box."
Plans for the construction of the first ocean-going, self-propelled ship with an aluminum hull were announced jointly yesterday by the United Tanker Corporation and the Reynolds Metals Company.

NIAMEY, Niger, April 13 (UPI) -- A grenade was hurled toward President Hamani Diori today. It failed to injure him but killed a child and wounded at least three members of a visiting football team from Mali.

THE failure of the rear-engine Chaparrals in the first of the United States road racing championship events at Pensacola, Fla., last Sunday was the biggest surprise of the season in this sport. Fresh from their victory in the 12-hour grind at Sebring, Jim Hall and Hap Sharp went in to the Pensacola 201-mile race as overwhelming favorites.
LOS ANGELES, April 13 -"I never saw a worse performance in all my years with the Yankees," said Elston Howard, shaking his head.
LANSING, Kan., Wednesday, April 14 (AP) -- Richard Eugene Hickock and Perry Edward Smith were hanged here early today for the 1959 murders of a west Kansas farm family of four.
A bid by editors of 13 college newspapers to send student journalists to report stories in Cuba during the Easter vacation has been turned down by the State Department.
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- President Johnson announced today that he would summon White House conferences on education, health, beautification and civil rights this summer.

LONDON, April 13 -- Prime Minister Harold Wilson was asked by a friend recently whether he had not gone pretty far out on a limb with his statement that those speculating on devaluation of the pound were "nut cases."
Except for the fact that each killed a President, John Wilkes Booth and Lee Harvey Oswald had little in common.

GREEN BAY, Wis., April 13 (UPI) -- The Green Bay Packers of the National Football League traded today Dan Currie, a linebacker, to the Los Angeles Rams for Carroll Dale, a split end, in a straight player swap.
Catalytic Construction of Canada, Ltd., has announced the election of A.C. Martinsen as president. Mr. Martinsen was formerly executive vice president.

While New Yorkers were still buttoning their topcoats against chilly April days, a specialist in air-conditioning was warning building owners this week against troubles that might lie ahead when the mercury starts mounting.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- The Treasury and Post Office Departments agreed with an irate Senate Judiciary subcommittee today that the guarantees of the Constitution should take precedence over the difficulties of the Internal Revenue Service with "flagrant" tax-evaders.
CHICAGO, April 13 (AP) -Roberto Pena smashed his second homer in two days today and scored another run on an error as the Chicago Cubs defeated the St. Louis Cardinals, 3-1.
A PARISIAN of Polish origin, whose first name means "of the sun" in Persian, looks like the ideal woman in Coco Chanel's suits. She owns 12 of them.
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee agreed temporarily today to require the Administration to submit to Congress a new and different foreign aid program by July 1, 1966.

TORONTO, April 13 (AP) -- Claude Provost's goal at 16 minutes 33 seconds of the first overtime period gave the Montreal Canadiens a 4-3 victory over the defending champion Toronto Maple Leafs tonight and sent the Canadiens into the Stanley Cup finals.
