PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., April 13 -- In wind gusts up to 40 miles an hour, eight-oared shells from Marietta College defeated Iona crews on the Hunter Island Lagoon rowing course today.
DOVER, N.J., April 13 (AP) -- The number of cases of infectious hepatitis in this area increased to 66 today as health service officials continued their efforts to trace the source of the outbreak.

SYDNEY, Australia, April 13 -- The Australian Government is making an urgent survey of the effects of United States overseas investment policies on financial operations of American companies in Australia.

President Johnson's speech leaves unchanged the basic fallacy in American policy toward Vietnam. He continues to assume that the conflict there is essentially a military invasion, like those of Nazi Germany, when in fact it is essentially a civil war.
New visual aids to help subway-train riders know where they are going and when they can expect to get there are now being installed.
WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP) -- President Johnson soaked up sunshine today on the White House balcony with three foreign Ambassadors, newsmen and the husband of a European queen.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 13 -- The United States Embassy reported today that Joseph W. Grainger, an American aid official captured last August, was killed on Jan. 12 by a Vietcong soldier.
WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP) -- The Senate made it official today. It will get its usual Easter holiday recess, from tonight until Wednesday, April 21.
The Erie-Lackawanna Railroad faces "a slow death" if the Pennsylvania and New York Central railroads are permitted to merge, and the Erie is not included in the Norfolk Western Railway system.

New York is getting short shrift from Washington -- by default. Work on the Federal building complex in Foley Square has been resumed from controversial plans rejected by the city, public officials, the New York State Association of Architects, New York State Association of the Professions, Fine Arts Federation, local professional planning and civic groups and citizens concerned with the city's development.

LAUREL, Md., April 13 (AP) Mrs. Ben Cohen's High Folly, a 4-year-old filly, won the $6,000 Feminine Touch Purse by 1 1/2 lengths today at Laurel Park and returned $33.60 for $2 to win as longshots dominated the winner's circle.

The Westinghouse Electric Corporation reported yesterday that its first-quarter earnings were slightly more than double the year-ago level, while sales billed and new orders received were both at first-quarter highs.
ATHENS, April 13 (UPI) -- The crew of the 21,735-ton Norwegian tanker Ferncoast abandoned ship when an explosion touched off a fire but returned today in a desperate attempt to save their vessel.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- At 3:55 this afternoon, the phone rang in the Republican cloakroom just off the Senate floor. Senator Jacob K, Javits, his secretary reported, had left his overcoat there and wanted it brought to his office.
ST. PAUL, April 13 -- Record Mississippi River flood waters poured into St. Paul today, sub-merging the downtown Holman Airport and closing Union Station.

BALTIMORE, April 13 (UPI) -- The Chicago White Sox scored four runs off Steve Barber in the first three innings and weathered a couple of late Baltimore threats today to defeat the Orioles, 5-3, in the season's opener for both clubs.
A New Jersey court lifted yesterday a restraining order denying the waterfront industry the right to require a pre-employment medical examination for longshoremen seeking work in the port.

BERLIN, April 12 -- While the Communists were blocking the roads to West Berlin last week and buzzing the city with jet fighters, the United States infantry brigade stationed there went about its business with studied casualness.
A woman who lives in the East Side apartment house in which Mark Fein allegedly murdered his bookmaker testified yesterday concerning shots she heard coming from outside the building.

The San Francisco Ballet, which has come to the New York State Theater for a stay of one week, gave a matinee and an evening performance yesterday of two works choreographed by Lew Christensen, director of the company.

NEW HAVEN, April 13 -- Nothing less than the greatest group of its kind ever privately assembled, "English Paintings, Drawings and Water-colors, 1700-1850. From the Collection of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Mellon," opens tomorrow at the Yale University Art Gallery.

TOLEDO, Ohio, April 14 -- President Johnson toured today areas of the Middle West that had been struck by tornadoes and floods. He said it was the will of the nation that "the Government of this good and generous people should be ready and will be ready to assist in every useful way."

An auction at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, part of it conducted American-style, the other part, English-style, set a public-sale record for a Degas last night and, perhaps, a precedent for sales in New York's leading auction house.

Poetic justice proved no match for the defensive incompetence of the New York Mets at Shea Stadium yesterday, and the result was a disorderly, 11-inning, 7-6 loss to the Houston Astros instead of a glorious victory for Warren Spahn.

The dangers of Communist aggression have increased as a result of the better struggle between Moscow and Peking for the leadership of the world Communist movement, W. Averell Harriman, Ambassador at Large, declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP) -- Sugar Ray Robinson, once the middleweight boxing champion, has won a dispute with the Internal Revenue Service. A ruling by the United States Tax Court wipes out most of a back tax claim of $352,000 involving Mr. Robinson's title bout against Carmen Basilio in September, 1957.
WASHINGTON, April 14 (UPI) -- The House Ways and Means Committee approved today a bill to implement participation in the International Coffee Agreement designed to stabilize world coffee prices.

NEW DELHI, April 14 -- Cease-fire negotiations between India and Pakistan in dispute over their border in the Rann of Cutch appeared tonight to be unlikely in near future. The gloomy outlook arose from a meeting between Arshad Hussein, the Pakistani High Commissioner, and C.S. Jha, India's Foreign Secretary.

ACCRA, Ghana, April 14 (AP) -- A Ghanaian Government delegation will leave soon for Europe and North America to seek loans for the country's development, Finance Minister Kwani Amoako-Atta announced today.
PITTSBURGH, April 14 (AP) -- Claude Osteen pitched a two-hitter and Ron Fairly hit a two-run homer as the Los Angeles Dodgers defeated the Pittsburgh Pirates, 3-1, tonight.
WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP) -- A newly formed progressive Republican organization announced the addition of 19 members to its operating committee tonight.
LOS ANGELES, April 14 -- The New York Yankees scored on Dean Chance tonight, but they left three men on base in the ninth inning and lost to the Los Angeles Angels, 4 -- 3.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- A nuclear reactor that may go on orbiting the earth for 40,000 years has already proved its worth as a power plant for long range space missions Atomic Energy Commission officials said today.

NAIROBI, Kenya, April 14 -- A shipment of weapons from the Soviet Union is expected to arrive in Kenya soon with Russian technicians to show the army how to use them, Defense Minister Njeroge Mungai announced today.

The Court of Appeals decision yesterday throwing out as unconstitutional the redistricting plan adopted by the Legislature last December leaves New York State with a gaping hole in its statute books. Quite properly, the court called upon the present Legislature to enact a new apportionment and redistricting statute.
TORONTO, April 14 -- A new Canadian mining scandal erupted today.
The election of John S. Andrews, William D. Innes and Fred G. Secrest as vice presidents of the Ford Motor Company was announced yesterday by Henry Ford 2d, chairman.

PITTSBURGH, April 14 -- Negotiators for the basic steel industry and the United Steelworkers of America focused today on trying to reach agreement on a plan that would have the effect of extending the present contracts past the May 1 strike deadline.

LONDON, April 14 -- The Government rejected a fervent appeal in the House of Lords today to take oral contraceptives off the market pending the result of all investigation into whether the pills had dangerous side-effects.
CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., April 14 -- The world's largest building was "topped out" today at the 525-foot level, completing one of the biggest construction projects in history.
I want to express my gratitude to The New York Times for its excellent editorials, particularly those concerning our policies in Vietnam.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee approved today a foreign aid authorization bill calling for $3,352,170,000 in each of the next two fiscal years. The measure would also present the Johnson Administration with a legislative mandate to submit to Congress a new approach to foreign aid by July 1, 1966.
LONDON, April 14 -- The House of Lords challenged the Labor Government tonight for the second time in two days.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., April 14 (UPI) -- In a wide-ranging statement on civil rights, 22 Alabama business groups tonight urged Alabamians to support "full protection and opportunity" under the law for Negroes and whites, including employment and voting.

" H. M.S. PINAFORE," one of the more foolproof of the Gilbert and Sullivan series, sailed into the City Center last night on a gentle wind. The members of the Gilbert and Sullivan Company gave the popular old piece a pleasant but rather mild performance, very polite, quite tidy, and -- in trying to be English -- altogether un-English.

PHILADELPHIA, April 14 (AP) -- Willie Mays's two-run homer helped rout Jim Bunning tonight and led the San Francisco Giants to a 5-2 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies before 31,923 fans -- the largest crowd for a home opener here in five years.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., April 14 (AP) -- A civil rights charge against one of four men identified as members of the Ku Klux Klan arrested after the killing of a Detroit housewife was dismissed today at the request of the Federal Government.
The three television networks disclosed further plans yesterday for presenting news programs from Europe by means of the Early Bird communications satellite, which was launched last week.

ST. PAUL, April 14 (UPI) -- The worst flood in the history of the Upper Mississippi River rampaged through the St. Paul lowlands today, forcing a dozen more industries behind a leaky dike to be evacuated.
The British pound forged ahead in active trading yesterday on foreign exchange markets here.

The 26-room brownstone mansion at 4 East 93d Street has been sold by Mrs. Roger W. Straus for $280,000. The five-story residence, with six baths, an elevator and a garden, was bought by the Mount Sinai School of Medicine and then sold to the Louise Wise Adoption Services.
The national administrative secretary of the American Guild of Variety Artists charged yesterday that the union's welfare accounts were a "shambles of misplaced and missing records."

TOKYO, April 14 -- One ancient Japanese pastime that visitors can master on the first try, unlike the highly stylized arts of flower arrangement and the tea ceremony, is said to be facing extinction in the industrialization and hustle of modern Japan.

SAIGON Thursday, April 15 (AP) --An explosion ripped through an ammunition storage, area last night at the United' States Army's 117th Aviation Company compound in Quinhon. A military spokesman said there was a possibility that the blast had been set of by Vietcong saboteurs.
OF the many people who have attended the classes at his cooking school, Michael Field recalls with special affection "the woman who spoke with a heavy Turkish accent."

A careless and insanitary medical examination, worms in the food, mice and roaches in the cells, the needless death of a neglected inmate -- these allegations are the familiar notes in the latest bulletin from that grim fortress in Greenwich Village, the Women's House of Detention.

" We're all for protecting womanhood, but we're against exploiting the fears and apprehensions of people with this kind of junk." Markets Commissioner Albert S. Pacetta said yesterday as he demonstrated a so-called anti-mugger spray.

WASHINGTON, April 14 (UPI) -- A special House Commerce subcommittee, headed by Representative Paul G. Rogers, Democrat of Florida, will investigate the rapid growth of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare.
The most important thing about Hanoi's counter-proposal for a Vietnam settlement is not what it says but that it was said at all -- after Peking's violent rejection of President Johnson's peace plan.

The George F. Driscoll Company, a general contracting concern, has leased the 18th floor at 529 Fifth Avenue, at 44th Street, and will occupy the space in May. It will be the first move in 22 years for Driscoll, which is now at 41 East 42d Street.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Thursday, April 15 (Reuters) -- The United States Peace Corps will cease operations and its members will leave Indonesia in the next few weeks, it was announced today.
With many Americans grudgingly filling out their income tax returns in time for tonight's deadline, two elderly citizens had some kind words yesterday for the Internal Revenue Service.
DANANG, South Vietnam, Thursday. April 15 (UPI) -- A Vietnamese firing squad today executed a Vietcong terrorist who tried to blow up a Danang hotel filled with United States servicemen on April 4.
WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP) -- Directors of the American Society of Newspaper Editors said today that rigid official curbs on crime news coverage would be impractical and possibly dangerous.
Oils fell but leading industrials gained ground yesterday on the London Stock Exchange.
A YOUNG man swung wide the door of The House of the Magic Rabbit recently and asked, "Where Did Josie Go? Do you have it?"
WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP) -- A 15-year-old youth from Springfield, Ill., has been appointed as the first Negro page in the House of Representatives.

Directors of the May Department Stores Company increased the quarterly dividend yesterday with the declaration of 37 1/2 cents a share, or $1.50 a year. The new rate, which is payable June 1 to holders of record May 15, compares with 30 cents quarterly or 51.20 annually.
WASHINGTON, April 14 -- The gross national product recorded its largest quarterly gain in more than three years during the first quarter of this year.

ALBANY, April 14 (AP) -- Republicans and Democrats in the Assembly joined today to approve overwhelmingly a proposal to extend the term of office for legislators in both houses from two to four years.
ROME, April 14 -- Italian deputies pressed demands today for a Government investigation and disclosure of Italian Communist party involvement in subversive activities in Venezuela.
ALBANY, April 14 -- The Democratic legislative leaders have abandoned a pledge to create a nonpartisan commission to reapportion the Legislature.
BOGALUSA, La., April 14 (AP) -- Negro pickets, with policemen standing guard, marched in front of midtown stores today and segregationists countered with a "buy in."
WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP) -- The consensus of top intelligence officials is that there are no intermediate-range ballistic missiles in Cuba, a Congressional report said today.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- After 166 years of inaction Congress now has taken all but the last step to provide for continuity in the exercise of the powers and duties of the Presidency by a citizen "able" physically and mentally to exercise them.
Associate Justice Arthur J. Goldberg of the United States Supreme Sourt urged last night that the United States assume the lead in international cooperation for the protection of individual rights.

The 10th annual Peacock Ball for the benefit of the New York University Medical Center will be held on May 1 at the Plaza. The Lila Motley Cancer Foundation is sponsoring the event, which will be held in the hotel's Grand Ballroom and the Terrace Room.

Taxpayers who must file a second return by midnight tonight -- the first-quarter estimate of tax due for 1965 -- may have difficulty finding the new tables. Tax officials have not distributed the tables widely, fearing taxpayers making out their regular returns might err and use the lower 1965 rates in figuring their 1964 tax.

The first man ever to win two Olympic marathon races stepped off a plane at Kennedy International Airport yesterday and announced that he was "honored to run for the World's Fair" and "anxious to see a New York baseball game."
Actors Equity Association decided yesterday not to renew a court injunction seeking to prevent the Union des Artistes of the Province of Quebec from implementing an exclusive jurisdictional contract.
New York City headed into a fiscal crisis of its own last night as a result of the Legislature's tardiness in adopting a state budget.

ALBANY, April 14 -- Following are excerpts from opinions in today's reapportionment decision by the Court of Appeals; the majority opinion was written by Chief Judge Charles S. Desmond; Judge Francis Bergan wrote a concurring opinion, and Judge John Van Voorhis dissented:
WASHINGTON, April 14 -- The House Committee on Un-American Activities received $50,000 today to investigate the Ku Klux Klan.
ALGIERS, April 14 -- Ronald B. Ramsey, an American psychologist, who has been held by the Algerians on unspecified charges since Dec. 29 said today that he had been tortured again by his captors.
An arbitrator ruled yesterday that a Vandyke beard, if "kept trim," might be worn by a platform employe of the Transit Authority. A "beatnik beard" was ruled out.
MOSCOW, April 14 -- A kerchief decorated with a map of prewar Germany was the subject of an indignant letter in he Soviet press today.
The Celanese Corporation of America made news on a variety of fronts yesterday:
JERSEY CITY, April 14 -- The R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company will "contest vigorously" the application of the Justice Department to block the company's proposed acquisition of Penick Ford, Ltd., Inc.

YONKERS, April 14 -- One International Pace, the year's first $100,000 harness race in the United States and the first of eight such king-sized purses to be offered here in 1965, will be contested tomorrow night at Yonkers Raceway.
New-car sales early in April sustained a record pace, and there is no letup in sight.
WASHINGTON, April 14 -- "Positive action soon must replace delay and procrastination'' on the development of an American supersonic airliner, Senator A. S. Mike Monroney said today.
PARIS, April 14 -- South Vietnam is attempting to improve its diplomatic relations with France, Vice Premier Trail Van Tuyen said today.

More than 200 artists have donated paintings, drawings, sculpture and prints to the 4th annual Artists for CORE exhibition and sale, to be held from April 29 through May 8 at the Graham Gallery, 1014 Madison Avenue, at 79th Street.
Prices see-sawed yesterday on the American Stock Exchange as volume edged up to 2.2 million shares from 2.1 million on the previous day.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- The directors of Cleveland's antipoverty program were accused today of having a "vested interest" in preventing the poor from becoming "a new political force" in the community.

Laurance S. Rockefeller expressed the hope yesterday that Federal legislation to preserve the Hudson River would be "held in abeyance" to give the state a clear opportunity to do the job. He is chairman of the State Council of Parks and of the Hudson River Valley Commission.

The Silurians, a society of present and former New York newspapermen, will give their award for the best news story last year to Martin Gansberg of The New York Times for his article on the 38 silent witnesses to the murder of Catherine Genovese.

Eintracht of Frankfurt, Germany, and Fiorentina of Florence, Italy, are regarded as the teams to beat in the first international Easter round-robin soccer tournament starting tonight at Downing, Stadium, Randalls Island.
Senator Robert F. Kennedy urged the Interstate Commerce Commission yesterday to mediate the issues blocking agreement on how to save the New Haven Railroad's passenger service.
Bloomingdale's sent telegrams yesterday to more than 100 of 3,300 striking empl0yes warning them that they would be replaced if they did not "return to work immediately."

LISBON, April 14 -- The United States has sought to "moderate" differences between Portugal and her African and Asian opponents, George W. Anderson Jr., United States Ambassador to Portugal, declared here today.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 14 -- Interrogation of Vietcong defectors and prisoners has indicated that intensified air attacks have lowered morale in Communist-held areas of South Vietnam.
CHICAGO, April 14 (AP) -- Two homers by Ron Santo and one by George Altman helped the Chicago Cubs to a second straight victory over the champion St. Louis Cardinals, 7-3, today.
BOSTON, April 14 -- Racial imbalance exists in Massachusetts public schools and is harmful to both white and nonwhite children, a special study committee reported today.
BETHESDA, Md., April 13 (UPI) -- A 35-year-old woman took her own life tonight, hours after committing what the police described as the "mercy killing" of Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor's sister-in-law.
ALBANY, April 14 -- The Court of Appeals ruled today that the basic Republican plan of legislative apportionment enacted last December violated the State Constitution.
WASHINGTON, April 14 -- President Johnson and Congress have completed 100 days of legislative action that may rank as one of the most remarkable periods of domestic achievement in American history.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- The United States called on the Communist nations, and especially North Vietnam today to reply to the recent appeal by 17 nonaligned nations that negotiations on Vietnam be started soon without any preconditions.
THOMAS C. GRIFFIN has been named associate editor of the American Bridge League's monthly bulletin. He succeeds Albert Dormer, who resigned to return to England.

THE world is still and the only sound is tile clear song of unseen birds. Yet this is the city. The evening sun falls across broad lawns that slope toward the river's edge. Sometimes, near the water, pheasants flutter in the brush.

As Mrs. Eleanor Vellines, a senior meter maid, saw it, it could hardly have been coincidental that every time she closed in on an overtime parker on Lydig Avenue in the Bronx, someone popped up and slipped a dime in the meter.

I am afraid that I must disagree with the April 3 letter of my son, Dr. Jeremy Bernstein. He takes to task Dr. Martin Luther King (although agreeing with his objectives) for espousing the violation of unjust laws.

The nation's gasoline stock rose 435,000 barrels in the week ended last Friday, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the weekend, supplies totaled 231,518,000 barrels, compared with 231,183,000 a week earlier and 215,891,000 a year ago.
This book provides further evidence of the scholarship of the Air Force Academy faculty, for Major Pustay is Associate Professor of Political Science and Assistant Dean.

FAIRFIELD Conn., April 14 -- A group of students at Fairfield University, a Roman Catholic school near here, has placed on general distribution shelves 100 books that the church considers to be "harmful to the faith and morals of the faithful."
The stock market climbed to new high ground for the third successive session yesterday.

Towers of varied shapes, limited only by architects' imaginations, would be encouraged in place of the standard "cheesebox" designs for office and apartment buildings under a zoning law revision voted yesterday.
The installing of historic treasures at the United States Pavilion at the World's Fair may be delayed because technicians are experiencing difficulty in adjusting a sensitive ultrasonic alarm system.

THIS is the time of year when countless high school seniors throughout the nation will be watching the mail nervously to learn which colleges -- if any -- have accepted them for admission next September. But there is at least one young man who has no such cares. He can select virtually any college he wishes and the red carpet will promptly be rolled out before him.
" We have reached the point where a constructive dialogue between Negro and white is essential to the welfare of our nation."

SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 14 -- United States analysts said today that the latest peace proposals by Hanoi to end the war in South Vietnam failed to indicate any substantive change in the Communist stand.

The Xerox Corporation surpassed all previous records for any three-month period in its 61-year history in the first quarter this year. Earnings rose 52 per cent on a 49 per cent gain in revenues over a year before, the report disclosed yesterday.

MEXICO CITY, April i4 -- Mexican authorities said today that about30 persons were arrested in the last two days in Mexico City in raids on Communist party headquarters and the headquarters of affiliated parties.
The Italian Welfare League will hold its 15th La Primavera luncheon and fashion show in the Plaza's Grand Ballroom on Tuesday.

THE Colombian-born proprietor of Arte de Colombia, a new shop at 204 West 10th Street, revisited his native country several years ago after many years in the United States. Touring the little villages of Colombia, he and his wife were struck by the attractiveness of the native handicrafts.
LONDON, April 14 -- There are growing doubts in official circles that Britain will place a large order for the United States F-111 strike fighter.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- The Administration, in a step to curb the spread of atomic weapons, is considering a proposal under which the nuclear powers would provide to non-nuclear nations a guarantee of protection against atomic attack.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Vice President Hubert H. Humphrey announced today United States support for the economic integration of Latin America, which is expected to lead in time to a common market for the Western Hemisphere.
TOKYO, April 14 -- Foreign Minister Etsusaburo Shiina declared in Parliament today that it would be "unfair" to demand that the United States alone withdraw its armed forces from South Vietnam.
WASHINGTON, April 14 -- The intellectuals' fascination with Ian Fleming's fantasy hero, James Bond, arises from the same vice of learned men that compelled them to seek significance in the hula hoop.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 14 -- Mihajlo Mihajlov, the scholar who was indicted on charges of having written critically of the Soviet Union, was reported today to have been released from jail in Zadar pending trial.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- The National Association of Supervisors of State Banks favors expansion of the powers of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation as a means of reducing conflicts among the three Federal agencies that regulate banks.
ALBANY, April 14 -- The statewide sales tax that won final approval in the Legislature tonight is a complicated document that is bound to create headaches for taxpayer and collector alike.
A LIGHTING system for the home, called Lytespan, in which adjustable spotlights can be attached at any point along fan electrified track, has been developed by Lightolier, 11 East 136th Street.
Five or six is not normally too young an age at which a parent can start a child's allowance, according to Sidonle Matsner Gruenberg, author of a new booklet, "Your Child and Money."

MILWAUKEE, April 14 -- The Braves, a baseball team from Milwaukee, are moving to Atlanta because the owners, who come from Chicago, can make more money there. Meanwhile, major league baseball's first lame-duck season must be played, and it will begin here tomorrow when the Braves take on the Chicago Cubs before a crowd of perhaps 20,000.

The largest ship ever constructed for year-round cruising, the 39,241-ton Oceanic, made a spectacular maiden entry into New York Harbor yesterday. But she was also accompanied by a picketing plane and boatloads of pickets belonging to an American seamen's union.
Millions of Christian will begin their solemn preparations today -- Maundy Thursday -- and tomorrow -- Good Friday -- for the joyful festival of the Resurrection on Easter Sunday.
Harold Allen, one of the three brothers to have made the name of the Wall Street securities concern of Allen Co. synonymous with "special situation," is something of a special situation himself.

LAFAYETTE, Ind., April 14 -- Dr. Frederick Seitz, president of the National Academy of Sciences, warned today that the present system of Federal grants, if not modified, might be "disastrous" to some areas of science.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 14 -- The International Tin Conference adjourned today after completing revision of the second five-year international agreement on the commodity, which is due to expire on June 30, 1966.
LAKE SUCCESS, L.I., April 14 -- More than 3,600 production workers at the Sperry Gyroscope Company struck today over the dismissal of two maintenance workers.
Australia is planning to sell $25 million of 20-year bonds.
BERNARD SHAW'S crackling wit recharged television last night for one uninterrupted hour as the "Esso Repertory Theater" brought to vivid life "Don Juan in Hell."
BOSTON, April 14 -- Stockholders of the Boston Maine Corporation defeated today a bid by a Chicago group that had sought to take control of the railroad.
The International Business Machines Corporation announced yesterday the appointment of Dr. Herman H. Goldstine as director of scientific development for its data-processing division.

WASHINGTON, April 14 (UPI) -- President Johnson and West Berlin's Mayor, Willy Brandt, met for 25 minutes today. Their conference was delayed for nearly an hour by the President's day-long swing through the Midwestern flood and tornado areas.
WACO, Tex., April 14 (UPI) -- Randy Matson of Texas A. and M. smashed the National Collegiate discus record by more than eight feet today with a throw of 201 feet 5 1/2 inches.
" I wondered why Mr. Jacobs put all three of them in the race, and now I know," said Wally Blum after he had ridden Affectionately to victory in the $27,850 Distaff Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday.

Joan Yarbrough and her husband, Robert Cowan, made their debut last night as duo-pianists in a short but interesting program at Carnegie Recital Hall. She studied in Boston, he at the Juilliard and Eastman Schools of Music, and their playing showed promising musicality.
WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Congress was told today that "bold steps" must be taken if President Johnson's orders to clean up the Potomac River are to be carried out.
MOBILE, Ala., April 14 (UPI) -- Dallas County Sheriff James G. Clark Jr. sent a telegram to former President Harry S. Truman today thanking him for statements criticizing the civil rights movement.
The appointments of Frederick W. Gill and Walter J. Riether as vice presidents of the First National City Bank were announced yesterday.

The chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board warned savings institutions yesterday that they could expect the board to exert greater influence over the policies of the system's 12 district banks in the future.
LONDON, April 14 -- The British Government is more hopeful about the long-term outlook for peace talks on Vietnam than visible events would indicate.

Dr. Ray E. Trussell, the Commissioner of Hospitals, announced yesterday that stricter standards of medical care would be enforced in voluntary general hospitals for patients whose bills were paid by the city.
LONDON, April 14 -- Britain is mobilizing her secondary financial reserves as part of her determined efforts to defend the pound.

A 12-year-old Brooklyn boy who is handicapped by deafness and a speech impediment, was home yesterday after wandering lost, frightened and penniless for 18 hours through the mazes of the city's subway system.
SACRAMENTO. Calif, April 11 -- Legislators have taken their first step toward outlawing private army organizations in California.

An Assistant Attorney General, a confidential investigator in the office of State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz and a lawyer were arrested here yesterday and charged with an attempted shakedown of a Brooklyn undertaker.

MOSCOW, April 14 -- The Soviet Government newspaper Izvestia published on its front page without comment tonight excerpts from two North Vietnamese statements attacking American "aggression" and vowing to continue the war.
WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP) -- An engine-room fire aboard the carrier Ranger off South Vietnam killed an enlisted man yesterday, the Defense Department reported today.

BONN, Aug. 14 -- A brief flare-up of the 20-year conflict over Berlin is over, and the tangible results of 10 days of systematic Communist harassment of Western Allied communications with the isolated city are few.

It is regrettable that the "scholars" reported (Times, April 10) to have assayed "bad Samaritans" did not first assay more carefully the scriptural passage (Luke x, 30-37) to which allusion is supposedly made.

THE Chief Judge of the Court of Appeals, a saloon-keeper's son who made the extraordinary climb to the state's top court in 1940, observed yesterday that he had now occupied that bench "longer than anybody, ever."
HOUSTON, April 14 -- Shell-shocked survivors of the Master golf tournament begin the process of rehabilitation tomorrow when the Houston Classic opens at the Sharpsburg Country Club.

The Democratic leaders in the New York Legislature have pledged their party to give high priority to enactment of a strong legislative code of ethics. A year ago the Republicans then in control emasculated the recommendations of the Special Committee on Ethics headed by Cloyd Laporte and enacted instead a supposedly face-saving measure with far too many loopholes.

WALTHAM, Mass., April 14 -- The nameplate of the Liberty ship Louis D. Brandeis was presented today to Abram L.I Sachar, president of Brandeis University. The presentation was made here on the campus by Ralph E. Casey, president of the American Merchant Marine Institute.
Government bond prices continued to inch upward yesterday but the advance failed to evoke much enthusiasm from dealers.
Volunteers of the Lots for Little Thrift Shop at 1343 Third Avenue near 77th Street have arranged their annual luncheon for May 4 at the Waldorf-Astoria.

H.W. Fowler's "A Dictionary of .Modern English Usage" will be brought out again by Oxford University Press on May 6 in a second edition, revised and edited by Sir Ernest Gowers. From the time the work appeared in 1926, it has been the desk companion of innumerable writers.

The Public Housing Administration announced yesterday that it had sold $112,395,000 of temporary loan notes at an average interest rate of 2,360 per cent, up from 2,332 per cent for a similar sale in March.
Transit Authority bus drivers were upheld yesterday by Theodore W. Kheel in their refusal to accede to a plan to provide city buses to transport handicapped children to school.
ALBANY, April 14 -- The Legislature finally passed a budget for the State of New York tonight -- including a 2 per cent state sales tax -- 14 days after the constitutional deadline.

PHOENIX, Ariz., April 14 -- Former Senator Barry Goldwater declared tonight that he had no intention of deserting the political philosophy that he espoused in his unsuccessful Republican campaign for the Presidency last year.

IT may be somewhat disloyal to the Northeast to say it, but the best fishing right now is way down in Florida, where the snook and tarpon are in and waiting for anglers, particularly in the Keys and Everglades areas.
Arthur Murray, Inc., is dancing to a new tune these days. The dance studios are under new ownership after 51 years of operation by Katherine and Arthur Murray.
ALBANY, April 14 - Following is the roll-call vote in the Legislature today on Governor Rockefeller's proposed 2 per cent state sales tax:
As usual, the program offered by Johannes Somary and his Amor Artis Chorale last night at Town Hall was filled with the freshest and rarest early music.
WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board ordered Trans World Airlines today to refund $2,152,000 in mail subsidy payments allowed under temporary rates.
West Germany will supply Israel indirectly with arms she had promised before Chancellor Ludwig Erhard canceled Bonn's military aid program, according to a report from Tel Aviv.

LAST week, in the auditorium of the Riga Hotel in Riga, the capital of Latvia, Paul Keres of the Soviet Union defeated his countryman Boria Spassky in a game that will have a crucial bearing on determining the challenger for the world title, now held by another Soviet grand master, Tigran Petrosian.
The United States Lines yesterday accepted delivery of the American Ranger, a 13,000 dead-weight-ton cargoliner, built in the yard of the Sun Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company, Chester, Pa.
Prime Minister Harold Wilson of Britain told an elite audience of financiers and businessmen here last night that Britain would fight to the last ditch to maintain the level of the pound.

THE Rhodesian Ridgeback, a big, rugged hound native to South Africa, has backers who claim remarkable prowess for the dog. "They are the only breed in the world that can keep a lion at bay for the hunter's kill -- prod live," says the breed history of the Rhodesian Ridgeback Club of the United States.
The discredited confession of George Whitmore Jr. to the slaying of Janice Wylie and Emily Hoffert in 1963 went into the court record yesterday in his trial on another murder.

ATLANTA, April 14 -- Eight hundred Southerners came to Atlanta today to find out how tough the Johnson Administration is going to be in cutting off Federal funds because of racial discrimination. They got no clear answer.
The chairman and two directors of the financially embattled Yale Express System, Inc., have exchanged nearly a million Class A and B shares for stock of the Celpa Corporation.
Tight supplies and threats of a strike at Bolivian mines sent futures prices of tin up 75 to 225 points (hundreths of a cent a pound) yesterday. There was only one sale, however.
JERSEY, Channel Islands, April 14 (Reuters) -- A British DC-3 airliner crashed as it tried to land in thick fog here tonight, killing 26 of the 27 persons aboard.
ATLANTIC CITY, April 14 -- Scientists have found a new "window" through which to view life processes in health and disease.
Four meet records were set as more than 2,000 schoolboys from New York and New Jersey opened the 11th annual two-day Queens-Iona Relays at Downing Stadium on Randails Island yesterday.

Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Inc., in line with the upward trend of the motion picture industry, turned in the highest revenues since its separation from theater operations in March, 1959, for the 16 and 28 weeks ended March 18.
The Freedom National Bank stockholder meeting yesterday, unlike last year's, was the sort of event one could safely bring small children to -- and Bernice Rhinehart did.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Belatedly and with obvious reluctance, the Democratic National Committee has paid the Air Force $149,019.69 for President Johnson's use of official White House planes in the 1964 campaign.
The nation's electric power production rose 7.4 pet cent in the week ended April 10 from the level in the corresponding 1964 week, it was reported yesterday by the Edison Electric Institute.
BALTIMORE, April 14 (AP) -- Mill Pappas, the Baltimore star who missed the opening-day assignment because of a sore elbow, shut out the Chicago White Sox, 6-0, on six hits today.

SINCE World War II the Nobel Prize for Literature has often gone to Frenchmen. Gide, Mauriac, Camus, Perse, are on the roll. In refusing it -- even before it was formally offered -- Sartre achieved a special existentialist celebrity.
LONDON, April 14 -- Britons will pay an additional 1 ($2.80) a year to watch television, Postmaster General Anthony Wedgwood Benn announced today in the House of Commons.
One day after a state inquiry made public her tale of 20 "snakepit" days in the Women's House of Detention, 39-year-old Mrs. Irene Perry was rearrested here yesterday and later released in $500 bail.
The new president of an old company took a look at the future yesterday at the company's annual meeting here.

While nearly 1,000 persons demonstrated behind police barricades in protest, the Board of Education held a marathon public hearing yesterday on the school system's proposed integration plan for next fall.

Evidence is accumulating that the Administration's "voluntary" controls on United States foreign loans and investments have tightened European capital supplies. A Times correspondent in Europe recently pointed out that the program "is working in the direction intended.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 14 -- United States aircraft dropped three million propaganda leaflets over four cities in North Vietnam today in an attempt to exploit centuries of Vietnamese distrust of the Chinese.
Nine rabbinic and lay Jewish Orthodox groups criticized yesterday the American Jewish Congress for its intention to challenge the new $1.3 billion school aid law.

MEXICO CITY -- The most curious of Mexico's new museums is one called Anahuacalli, which for understandable reasons is usually referred to as the Diego Rivera museum. Anahuac, which means near the water, was once the name of an old Aztec empire in the Valley of Mexico, and Anahuacalli would mean home of or place of the Anahuac, which, if we've got it right, was also the name of the valley's inhabitants.

CHICAGO, April 15 (AP) -- An error set up the eighth-inning single that ruined Bennie Daniels's bid for a no-hitter today, but the Washington Senators went on to a 3-1 victory and spoiled the Chicago White Sox' home opener.
HOUSTON, April 15 -- Bert Yancey, a golfer who is proving that opportunity knocks twice, shot a six-under-par 65 today to take the first-round lead in the Houston classic.

ORLANDO, Fla., April 15 -- Secretary of Labor W. Willard Wirtz, looking over Florida's demands for imported farm labor, created a mechanism today that may satisfy some of California's claim that it needs Mexican labor.

THE Yankee propaganda bureau overreached itself slightly seven years ago and inadvertently hung an albatross around the neck of a prize rookie named Deron Johnson. He has taken a long while to unburden himself of it. The extra load was the extravagant label: "another l,lickey Mantle."
The budget muddle in New York City, worsened by delay at Albany in enacting a state budget, took on politically strident overtones yesterday.
BONN, April 15 -- West Germany is nearing the end of its Middle East ordeal, and the outlook seems brighter than anyone here dared hope a month ago.
BOGALUSA, April 15 -- Governor McKeithen said tonight that he would not meet with civil rights leader who are now demonstrating in Bogalusa.
The American Stock Exchange has reported the changes carried below in the shareholdings of officers, directors and controlling stockholders of listed companies.

Andrew A. Friedland, a 23- year-old student who was scheduled to graduate at the head of his class from the School of Medicine of New York University Medical Center, was fatally injured Wednesday afternoon when an automobile he was driving turned over several times on the Skyline Drive of Shenandoah National Park near Waynesboro, Va.
Copper futures prices rose smartly yesterday on the New York Commodity Exchange, following increases on the London market and reports from dealers of continuing good demand for the metal.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., April 15 (UPI) -- A Negro leader said today that a statement issued by 22 major business groups urging compliance with the Civil Rights Act of 1964 was the most important step ever taken by Alabama's "white power structure."
The British pound continued to gain on foreign-exchange markets both here and in London.
I used to be a great admirer of The New York Times, but am not any more. Your hysteria over Vietnam has led me to change my mind.
ROME, April 15 -- Pope Paul VI washed the feet of 12 lame and blind youths today in a symbolic act of humility opening the three final days of Holy Week.
In a step-up of the city's drive against subway crime, Mayor Wagner announced last night plans for quickly increasing the Transit Authority's police force from 1,200 to 2,000 men.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- Vice President Humphrey predicted today that the 89th Congress, "acting out the will of the American people, "would approve all President Johnson's proposed Great Society legislation.
A LOOK at the fishing facilities at Captree State Park and the Robert Moses State Park, just across the bay, yesterday showed everything in tip-top shape for the flounder flippers.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, April 16 (Reuters) -- The Turkish Cypriote leader, Fazil Kutchuk, protested strongly tonight to the commander of the United Nations peace-keeping force, Gen. Kodendera S. Thimayya, over the isolation of the Turkish quarter of Nicosia by Greek Cypriotes.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- A subordinate white officer at the Pentagon today described all those around Maj. Gen. Benjamin Oliver Davis Jr. as "overjoyed" at the announcement that he had been nominated for promotion to lieutenant general in the Air Force -- the first Negro ever to reach that rank in the United States armed forces.
SAVAGE, Md., April 16 -- Forty horses galloped on purpose in six races at Laurel Raceway's remodeled trotting track today, and got away with it.
MOSCOW, April 16 -- Moscow's Central Synagogue was crowded tonight with more than 2,000 worshipers for the beginning of Passover.

KANSAS CITY, April 16 -- The little boy in the sailor suit with "U.S.S. Galveston" embroidered on the collar tugged at his mother's sleeve as the New York Yankees passed and asked who all those big boys were.
The Communist block's international bank is doing a rising volume of business with banks and wealthy individuals in Western Europe, Soviet sources report.
HONG KONG, April 16 -- Peking asserted today that the question of war or peace in Vietnam hinged on whether the United States would "get out" of South Vietnam.
ALGIERS, April 16 -- President Tito of Yugoslavia marked the second day of his state visit here by joining President Ahmed Ben Bella at a 90-minute mass rally on Algiers' Africa Square.
BOGALUSA, La., April 16 -- A Negro civil rights demonstrator said today that he was interrogated by men in white hoods and sheriff's uniforms in the city jail last night.
SAIGON, Saturday, April 17 (UPI) -- A 21-year-old girl led South Vietnamese policemen to a stockpile of Communist bombs and grenades in Saigon, the authorities announced today.

The Times of April 11 published a letter from Walter A. Sheldon urging that the Interstate Commerce Commission require railroads, airlines and bus companies serving the Southern states "to stamp their tickets to these states with appropriate warnings so the traveler will know that he travels at his own risk."
AUSTIN, Tex., April 16 -- President Johnson has postponed a number of visits by foreign leaders because of "the Congressional work load" and "the situation in Vietnam," the White House said today.

The Paramount Theater, which was declared dead and was even in the process of being buried, bounced back to life yesterday with traditional Paramount rites -- throngs of shrieking kids waiting to worship at the altar of an idol -- in this case, Soupy Sales.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 16 Bar and restaurant owners of San Francisco's North Beach, the old home of the beatniks, are under orders to clothe their bare-bosomed and semi-nude waitresses. The order becomes effective Monday throughout California.
WASHINGTON, April 16 -- A Senate subcommittee urged today that a Federal minimum wage be established for agricultural workers.

The four works presented by the San Francisco Ballet at the New York State Theater last night were "Lucifer," "Fantasma" and Divertissement d'Auber" (all choreographed by Lew Christensen) and Ron Poindexter's "The Set," the only non-Christensen ballet the company is offering during its New York stay.

Trucks lined up along the west side of 60th Street between Third and Lexington Avenues yesterday to deliver general merchandise to Bloomingdale's department store as it prepared for the resumption of normal business today.

EAST LANSING, Mich., April 16 (AP) -- Although shipping tonnage of the St. Lawrence Seaway has doubled since 1959. industry in the lake states still falls far short of taking full advantage of the waterway, a transportation specialist has written.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), April 16 -- Amid a din of hammer blows, concrete mixers, pneumatic drills and bulldozers Israel's palace of culture, the National Museum, is nearing completion in a wild race against the calendar to meet the deadline of May 11.
Tomorrow New York churchgoers will mark the most joyful day in the Christian calendar with solemn prayer, meditation on the mystery of the Resurrection, song and traditional Easter dawn services.
ZURICH, Switzerland, April 16 -- A brass plate on the door of a villa overlooking Lake Zurich says, in clearly etched letters, Thomas Mann.
PARIS, April 16 -- A physician, his brother and a friend were being held today as leaders of a gang that has looted churches and chateaux of art works valued at $7 million or more in recent years.
BOSTON, April 16 (AP) -- Leaders of the Textile Workers Union today scheduled a meeting to discuss a wage dispute that sent 5,000 cotton-rayon workers out on strike in New England factories.
ALBANY, April 16 -- Mayor Wagner endorsed today the idea of reapportionment by a non-partisan commission. In doing so he took issue with the Democratic leaders of the Legislature.
THE venerable art of girl-watching will receive fresh encouragement when the World's Fair opens Wednesday for its second season at Flushing Meadows.

LAWRENCE, Kan., April 16 (UPI) -- Kansas took the four-mile relay and Abilene Christian, helped by Southern Illinois's disqualification, won the university sprint medley relay today at the 40th annual Kansas Relays.
The Metropolitan Opera season ending tonight is unusual in that members of the orchestra played under a contract that had expired before the season began.
The 20th annual Caramoor Festival opens Saturday, June 19. Julius Rudel, general director of the New York City Opera, will be the musical director for his second season.

VALHALLA, N.Y., April 16 -- The American Legion Post here is split over whether it should have cancelled plans for a Memorial Day speech by Representative Richard L. Ottinger because he had opposed investigations by the House Un-American Activities Committee.
The scholarship fund of the Paderewski Foundation will receive the proceeds of a concert, reception and supper to be held April 30 at the Colony Club.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- The index of primary market prices increased 0.1 per cent, to 101.6 (1957-59 equals 100) during the week ended April 13, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. Farm products moved up in price while processed foods and industrial commodities averaged unchanged.
ALBANY, April 16 -- A substantial number of Democratic legislators are dissatisfied with their leadership, particularly that of Joseph Zaretzki in the Senate.

Eintracht of Frankfurt, West Germany, and Fiorentina of Florence, Italy, regarded as the strongest teams in the competition, triumphed as the first international Easter round-robin soccer tournament began last night at Downing Stadium, Randalls Island.
MOBILE, Ala., April 16 (AP) -- Congressional districts redrawn in Alabama by the Legislature last year were declared unconstitutional today by a three-judge Federal court.

In spite of all temptation to produce an adaptation of the works of Gilbert and Sullivan, English copyright laws until a few years ago forbade any tinkering with them. At the end of 1961, though, when the Gilbert and Sullivan works passed into the public domain, two professors at Bristol University, George Rowell and Kenneth Mobbs, decided to add a 15th Savoy opera to the existing canon.
PEOPLE who find martinis as unsinkable as Molly Brown, or are capsized by their alcoholic impact, are apparently turning to lighter aperitifs.

SEOUL, South Korea, Saturday, April 17 -- About 300 students stormed the gates of the Government building today after three battalions of combat troops had reinforced the police in the city to help quell disorders.
THE Russians entered World War II with a built-in handicap of their own devising. Many of their best commanders had been alienated during the purge trials of the 1930's -- or shot out of hand.

HOUSTON, April 16 -- Bert Yancey made birdies on two of the last five holes today to salvage a share of the Houston golf classic lead after it appeared the Texas Aggies were taking over the tournament.

" The Mikado" made its first appearance in the current brief season of the Gilbert and Sullivan Company at yesterday's City Center matinee. Rightly or wrongly, this is the work that has come to be as representative of G. S. as the "Blue Danube" is of Johann Strauss, and yesterday's performance demonstrated (to a predominantly youthful audience) how remarkably its freshness has been preserved for 80 years.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Attorney General Nicholas deB. Katzenbach told the nation's newspaper editors today what information the Justice Department would, and would not, supply in Federal criminal proceedings.
A new political party is being formed in Brooklyn by the Congress of Racial Equality and the Rev. Milton A. Galamison, who led last winter's seven-week school boycott.
" This is about 50 -- er . . . 50 -- er . . . -- wait a minute," the man in the checked suit said yesterday.

BALTIMORE, April 16 (AP) -- The publishers of The Baltimore Sun papers and the American Newspaper Guild broke off contract negotiations tonight without arriving at a settlement before the midnight deadline.
WASHINGTON, April 16 -- More than 10,000 students from all over the country are expected to descend on the capital tomorrow to protest against Administration policies in Vietnam.
I.D. Robbins, the only announced candidate against Mayor Wagmer, said yesterday that talks with Republicans at the "highest level" had indicated that he would get the Republican nomination for Mayor.

The peace of a Good Friday service at St. Patrick's Cathedral was shattered yesterday about 9:30 A.M. when a man hurled a five-pound chunk of concrete at a glass-encased statue of the late Pope Pius XII, shattering the glass but not damaging the statue.

PUNTA ARENAS, Chile, April 11 -- In the wasteland of Magallanes, the most southerly communities of the Western Hemisphere are striving to overcome two enemies worse than the cruel climate -- isolation and boredom.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- President Johnson is preparparing the biggest shift in diplomatic assignments in four years. The program will involve changes in at least five major State Department jobs and more than a dozen United States embassies.

TOKYO, April 16 -Strong leftist student opposition has caused the cancellation of speeches by Walt W. Rostow, chairman of the State Department Policy Planning Council, at three leading Japanese universities this month.

PARIS, April 16 -- France's Minister of Defense declared today that in the absence of a common nuclear strategy the meeting of the North Atlantic alliance's defense ministers would prove unsuccessful.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -The Ranger project's photographs of the moon have provided answers needed for the next steps toward landing men there, officials of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said today.
MOSCOW, April 16 -- The Cleveland Symphony Orchestra, under the direction of George Szell, was given an enthusiastic reception here today in the opening performance of a five-week Soviet tour.
MONSEY, N.Y., April 16 -- The police tried tonight to identify a body that was burned beyond recognition today when fire destroyed Rubenfeld's Monsey Park Hotel in this Rockland County community.
Villanova's strong men will attempt to become iron men today in the 11th annual Queens-Iona Relays at Randalls Island.
All stock, commodity and money markets in Britain and on the Continent will be closed Monday in observance of the Easter holiday.
STONY BROOK, L.I., April 16 The Suffolk Museum is packing some of its treasures into specially designed "boodle boxes" to be sent to elementary schools over the county.

LJUBLJANA, Yugoslavia, April 15 (Reuters) -- Communist China, the defender, and Japan, a strong contender, gained crushing victories today in the Swaythling Cup team semi-finals in the world table-tennis championships.
WASHINGTON, April 16 -- The Government's top mediator entered the steel negotiations today in an effort to avert a strike May 1.

A woman and a girl believed to be her 13-year-old daughter were found strangled last night in all apartment in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn.

Bold Lad returns to stakes competition today in the $75,000-added Wood Memorial. The famous colt, representing the Wheatley Stable, will be the 1-3 betting choice in the 1 1/8-mile event for 3-year-olds that is entrenching itself as one of New York's more important spring events.

The owner of an employment agency who advertised jobs at the World's Fair here for "blue-eyed blondes," apologized yesterday. She told the State Commission for Human Rights she did it "inadvertently" and would readvertise and invite applications from persons of all races and creeds.
THE next time Willie Mays hits two or more home runs in one game, he will establish a distinguished but seldom-noted record: a National League mark for most multiple-homer games in a career.
YONKERS, April 16 -- The Good Time Pace, an event begun here in 1950, will be presented as scheduled Thursday night at Yonkers Raceway.
Edward S. Muller, a purchasing agent of the United States Rubber Company, has been elected president of the Purchasing Agents of Connecticut.
Sargent Shriver's Office of Economic Opportunity is looking with disquiet at New York City's antipoverty program, sources within the Federal agency said yesterday.

Despite its relatively old age, the pace of the economic expansion is quickening. According to the Commerce Department, the nation's output of goods and services hit an annual rate of $649 billion in the first quarter, a very spirited advance over the level reached in the last quarter of 1964. March brought big jumps in both the Federal Reserve's production index and in personal incomes.

KANSAS CITY, April 16 (AP) -- "Slowness of public reaction to tornado warnings was the biggest contributor by far" to the high fatality rate in the storms that swept the upper Midwest last Sunday, a Weather Bureau expert reported today.

JERUSALEM (Jordanian Sector), April 16 -- Prayers and lamentations echoed today along the narrow cobblestoned Way of the Cross, revered as the path that Jesus long ago followed to Calvary and crucifixion.
MOSCOW, April 16 (AP) -- A Moscow newspaper said today that former Vice President Richard M. Nixon's one-day visit to Moscow last weekend was a publicity stunt.

WASHINGTON, April 16 (AP) -- Col. George S. Howard, retired, chief of the Air Force Band for two decades, was acquitted today by a court-martial on charges of theft and conspiracy to steal from the United States.
WASHINGTON, April 16 (AP) -- The United States Court of Claims ruled today that tax refunds should be paid to E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc. and the International Business Machines Corporation.

A rugged, handsome 35-year-old truck mechanic whose self-proclaimed feats of derring-do-even excelled those of the fictional hero, James Bond, was jolted out of his dream world yesterday in Federal Court.
AUSTIN, Tex., April 16 -- President Johnson announced today he would nominate a Negro Air Force officer to be a lieutenant general, the highest rank ever held by a Negro in the armed forces.
BRIDES will probably be the biggest beneficiaries of a retail business transaction that was announced yesterday.

ROOSEVELT ROADS, P.R., April 7 -- The United States Navy regards its bases here and at Guantanamo Bay in Cuba as strategic keys to the Caribbean and training sites indispensable to the Atlantic Fleet. Guantanamo and Roosevelt Roads, together with Key West, dominate the principal maritime entrances to the Caribbean -- the Straits of Florida and the Windward and the Mona Passages.

The threat of a steel strike in the United States has helped Japanese steel makers increase their exports to this country by about 20 per cent in the last six months, according to a Japanese executive.

What is the public getting for the extra $25 million? these people ask. The fact that from 1952 to 1964 the city's public was getting a bargain in the form of the 25-cent first drop is conveniently over-looked.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., April 16 -- The Ad Hoc Committee for Free Speech submitted a plan to the Village Board today to encourage public participation at board meetings and to "effect a closer spirit of cooperation between the board and the public."

A grant of $500,000 from the Rockefeller Foundation, plus the prospect of aid from other foundations, seems to have given Channel 13 another precarious hold on life. SAN FRANCISCO, April 16 (UPI) -- The Very Rev. James A. Pike, Episcopal Bishop of California, has postponed the ordination of a woman to holy orders until he can argue his case before the church's House of Bishops, it was reported today.

HALLANDALE, Fla., April 16 (AP) -- Thirteen distance runners will match strides for 1 1/2 miles tomorrow in the $65,200 Pan American Handicap at Gulfstream Park -- the last big race in Florida this season.

Preparations began this week for the closing late next year of the 47-year-old Brooklyn Army Terminal. The 105-acre site in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn was earmarked for closing last year by Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara as part of a broad economy drive.
WASHINGTON, April 16 (UPI) -- Secretary of Commerce John T. Connor said today that the Government had no intention of telling Americans where to travel or where not to travel.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 16 (AP) -- Iyo Pimentel of Caracas, Venezuela, upset top-seeded Frank Froehling of Coral Gables, Fla., 7 -- 5, 6 -- 1, today in the Masters international tennis tournament and advanced to the semi-finals.

Passover, the most ancient of all Jewish festivals, began at sundown yesterday. Jews throughout the world gathered at the Seder, the traditional ritual and feast that told of the liberation of the children of ancient Israel from Egyptian bondage.

WASHINGTON, April 16 (AP) -- The United States Court of Claims ruled today that all subscribers to the Dow-Jones News were exempt Service from the 8 per cent Federal excise tax on wire charges.

In a realignment of top management of the Procter Gamble Company, Howard Morgens, president, announced yesterday that Donald H. Robinson, vice president-group executive, will be in charge of the food products division, effective June 1. He will also continue supervisory responsibility for the company's oil mill crushing operations.

" Mister Buddwing" and company plan to head back to Hollywood this weekend, having scoured the town from the Bronx to the Bowery in one of the most diligent location safaris for a movie here in recent years.

THE language of art criticism is never as precise as one would like it to be, being at best a translation of often inexactly definable visual phenomena into words of limited meaning. Furthermore, a time lag exists between the coining of a word for a new art genre and its general acceptance.
WASHINGTON, April 16 -After 10 years, the Phillips Petroleum Company obtained a patent this week for an important synthetic rubber.
LONDON, April 16 (AP) -- Britain's Royal Ballet Company, starring Dame Margot Fonteyn, left London by plane for New York today on a three-month tour of the United States and Canada.
The proposed ban on motion pictures on airlines flying international routes was voided, in effect, yesterday.
ROME, April 16 -- Pope Paul VI walked unsheltered through light rain tonight carrying a cross in a re-enactment of the Crucifixion of Jesus.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Administration officials said today they were not surprised by the first signs that North Vietnam was preparing to install Soviet antiaircraft missiles to help defend Hanoi, its capital.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), April 16 (AP) -- Authoritative Israeli sources asserted today that Lebanon had carried out a new step in Arab plans to divert the headwaters of the Jordan River.

NEW DELHI, April 16 -- The Chinese Communists calculated some time ago that the weakest psychological aspect of the Indian Army was the vast gap between officers and enlisted men, a vestige of British military organization.

The naming of Albert H. Morgan as the first president of the Tri-State Air Pollution Foundation, Inc., was announced yesterday. The foundation is a nonpartisan citizens' committee concerned with developing an air pollution control program in the New York metropolitan area.

A card party to benefit the Church Charity Foundation of the Episcopal Diocese of Long Island will be held by the foundation's woman's board on Friday, in the Grand Ballroom of the Granada Hotel in Brooklyn.

The capital of a stone column from a synagogue where Jesus worshiped will rest on the altar of the Abyssinian Baptist Church in Harlem tomorrow, a temporary gift of the American-Israel pavilion of the World's Fair.
The heavyweight crews of Columbia, Yale, Navy, Brown and Dartmouth swing their oars in competition for the first time today in the burgeoning rowing season.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- The International Association of Machinists and the union that represents the 180 clerical workers at machinists' national headquarters here have agreed on a new two-year contract.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 16 -- Tanyug, the official Yugoslav press agency, disclosed today that the district court in Zadar had altered the order of charges against Mihajlo Mihajlov, the Yugoslav scholar charged with having derided the Soviet Union in a magazine article.

The Metropolitan Opera ends its current season with Puccini's "Tosca., at 2 P.M. and Verdi's "Rigoletto" at 8.

The Maine Maritime Academy's training' ship, the State of Maine, will be used as a trade fair ship in Washington, the week of May 17, it was announced yesterday.

ALBANY, Calif., April 16 (AP) -- Rain and mud, forecast by the weatherman, could change the complexion of tomorrow's Golden Jubilee running of the California Derby. The race is worth $71,150 with an expected field of 14 at Golden Gate Fields.
WASHINGTON, April 16 -- The Administration has decided to build a small atomic submarine to carry out the first extensive exploration of the ocean bottoms, Congressional sources disclosed today.

PORTLAND, Ore., April 16 -The Meier Frank Company, one of the most important independent department stores in the West, is about to become part of a chain because of dissesion within the family that owned about 80 per cent of the stock.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 16 -- The Committee on Defining Aggression voted unanimously today to put off its efforts for two more years unless a majority of its members deem it desirable to reconvene next April.
MOBILE, Ala., April 16 -- A three-judge Federal court ordered Sheriff James G. Clark Jr. of Dallas County today to cease using members of the county posse to police racial matters.

Readers of portents can have a field day analyzing some aspects of the three-game series between the New York Mets and the San Francisco Giants today and tomorrow. Today's ladies' day single game, scheduled for 2:15 P.M., and tomorrow's double-header starting at 1:05 P.M., will constitute New York's first big baseball weekend of the season.

NAIROBI, Kenya, April 16 (UPI) Mrs. Pat Moss Carlsson of Britain, enjoying better luck than her husband and her brother, led the East African Safari survivors tonight when they turned back toward Nairobi, after completing half of the 3,000-mile auto rally.

CAIRO, April 16 -- The Egyptian Government is asking the United States to provide $500 million worth of surplus food in the next three years, informed sources said today.
State Supreme Court Justice Birdie Amsterdam refused yesterday to intervene in the nomination of delegates to the June convention of the American Guild of Variety Artists.

England has offered a unit of six battalions and the necessary logistics toward a permanent United Nations peace-keeping force. Denmark, Sweden and New Zealand are in various stages of earmarking combat troops for the same purpose.
Consumption of newsprint in this country rose to record levels in March and for the three months ended March 31.
